She (Stant) made no circumstance of thus coming upon him (huntress), save so far as the intelligence in her (Stant) face could at any moment make a circumstance of almost anything. If when she (Stant) moved off she (Stant) looked like a huntress, she (Stant) looked when she (Stant) came nearer like his (huntress) notion, perhaps not wholly correct, of a muse. But what she (Stant) said was simply:
``You see you're not rid of me. How is dear Maggie?'' (she)

It was to come soon enough by the quite unforced operation of chance, the young man's opportunity to ask her (Stant) the question suggested by Mrs. Assingham shortly before her (Stant) entrance. The license, had he (man) chosen to embrace it, was within a few minutes all there--the license given him (man) literally to inquire of this young lady how long she (lady) was likely to be with them. For a matter of the mere domestic order had quickly determined, on Mrs. Assingham's part, a withdrawal, of a few moments, which had the effect of leaving her (Assingham) visitors free.

``Mrs. Betterman's there?'' (she)
she (Assingham) had said to Charlotte in allusion to some member of the household who was to have received her (Assingham) and seen her (Assingham) belongings settled; to which Charlotte had replied that she (Charlotte) had encountered only the butler, who had been quite charming. She (Charlotte) had deprecated any action taken on behalf of her (Charlotte) effects; but her (Charlotte) hostess, rebounding from accumulated cushions, evidently saw more in Mrs. Betterman's non-appearance than could meet the casual eye. What she (Betterman) saw, in short, demanded her (Betterman) intervention, in spite of an earnest
``Let ME go!'' (she)
from the girl, and a prolonged smiling wail over the trouble she (Betterman) was giving. The Prince was quite aware, at this moment, that departure, for himself, was indicated; the question of Miss Stant's installation didn't demand his (Prince) presence; it was a case for one to go away--if one hadn't a reason for staying. He (Prince) had a reason, however--of that he (Prince) was equally aware; and he (Prince) had not for a good while done anything more conscious and intentional than not, quickly, to take leave. His (Prince) visible insistence--for it came to that--even demanded of him (Prince) a certain disagreeable effort, the sort of effort he (Prince) had mostly associated with acting for an idea. His (Prince) idea was there, his (Prince) idea was to find out something, something he (Prince) wanted much to know, and to find it out not tomorrow, not at some future time, not in short with waiting and wondering, but if possible before quitting the place. This particular curiosity, moreover, confounded itself a little with the occasion offered him (Prince) to satisfy Mrs. Assingham's own; he (Prince) wouldn't have admitted that he (Prince) was staying to ask a rude question--there was distinctly nothing rude in his (Prince) having his (Prince) reasons. It would be rude, for that matter, to turn one's back, without a word or two, on an old friend.

Well, as it came to pass, he (friend) got the word or two, for Mrs. Assingham's preoccupation was practically simplifying. The little crisis was of shorter duration than our account of it; duration, naturally, would have forced him (friend) to take up his (friend) hat. He (friend) was somehow glad, on finding himself alone with Charlotte, that he (friend) had not been guilty of that inconsequence. Not to be flurried was the kind of consistency he (friend) wanted, just as consistency was the kind of dignity. And why couldn't he (friend) have dignity when he (friend) had so much of the good conscience, as it were, on which such advantages rested? He (friend) had done nothing he (friend) oughtn't--he (friend) had in fact done nothing at all. Once more, as a man conscious of having known many women, he (man) could assist, as he (man) would have called it, at the recurrent, the predestined phenomenon, the thing always as certain as sunrise or the coming round of Saints' days, the doing by the woman of the thing that gave her (woman) away. She (woman) did it, ever, inevitably, infallibly--she (woman) couldn't possibly not do it. It was her (woman) nature, it was her (woman) life, and the man could always expect it without lifting a finger. This was HIS (man), the man's, any man's, position and strength--that he (man) had necessarily the advantage, that he (man) only had to wait, with a decent patience, to be placed, in spite of himself, it might really be said, in the right. Just so the punctuality of performance on the part of the other creature was her (woman) weakness and her (woman) deep misfortune--not less, no doubt, than her (woman) beauty. It produced for the man that extraordinary mixture of pity and profit in which his (man) relation with her (woman), when he (man) was not a mere brute, mainly consisted; and gave him (man) in fact his (man) most pertinent ground of being always nice to her (woman), nice about her (woman), nice FOR her (woman). She (woman) always dressed her (woman) act up, of course, she (woman) muffled and disguised and arranged it, showing in fact in these dissimulations a cleverness equal to but one thing in the world, equal to her (woman) abjection: she (woman) would let it be known for anything, for everything, but the truth of which it was made. That was what, precisely, Charlotte Stant would be doing now; that was the present motive and support, to a certainty, of each of her (Stant) looks and motions. She (Stant) was the twentieth woman, she (Stant) was possessed by her (Stant) doom, but her (Stant) doom was also to arrange appearances, and what now concerned him (woman) was to learn how she (Stant) proposed. He (woman) would help her (Stant), would arrange WITH her (Stant) to any point in reason; the only thing was to know what appearance could best be produced and best be preserved. Produced and preserved on her (Stant) part of course; since on his (woman) own there had been luckily no folly to cover up, nothing but a perfect accord between conduct and obligation.

They stood there together, at all events, when the door had closed behind their friend, with a conscious, strained smile and very much as if each waited for the other to strike the note or give the pitch. The young man held himself, in his (man) silent suspense--only not more afraid because he (man) felt her (Stant) own fear. She (Stant) was afraid of herself, however; whereas, to his (man) gain of lucidity, he (man) was afraid only of her (Stant). Would she (Stant) throw herself into his (man) arms, or would she (Stant) be otherwise wonderful? She (Stant) would see what he (man) would do--so their queer minute without words told him (man); and she (Stant) would act accordingly. But what could he (man) do but just let her (Stant) see that he (man) would make anything, everything, for her (Stant), as honourably easy as possible? Even if she (Stant) should throw herself into his (man) arms he (man) would make that easy--easy, that is, to overlook, to ignore, not to remember, and not, by the same token, either, to regret. This was not what in fact happened, though it was also not at a single touch, but by the finest gradations, that his (man) tension subsided.

``It's too delightful to be back!'' (she)
she (Stant) said at last; and it was all she (Stant) definitely gave him (man)--being moreover nothing but what anyone else might have said. Yet with two or three other things that, on his (man) response, followed it, it quite pointed the path, while the tone of it, and her (Stant) whole attitude, were as far removed as need have been from the truth of her (Stant) situation. The abjection that was present to him (man) as of the essence quite failed to peep out, and he (man) soon enough saw that if she (Stant) was arranging she (Stant) could be trusted to arrange. Good--it was all he (man) asked; and all the more that he (man) could admire and like her (Stant) for it.

The particular appearance she (Stant) would, as they said, go in for was that of having no account whatever to give him (man)--it would be in fact that of having none to give anybody--of reasons or of motives, of comings or of goings. She (Stant) was a charming young woman who had met him (man) before, but she (Stant) was also a charming young woman with a life of her (Stant) own. She (Stant) would take it high--up, up, up, ever so high. Well then, he (man) would do the same; no height would be too great for them, not even the dizziest conceivable to a young person so subtle. The dizziest seemed indeed attained when, after another moment, she (Stant) came as near as she (Stant) was to come to an apology for her (Stant) abruptness.

``I've been thinking of Maggie, and at last I yearned for her (Maggie). I wanted to see her (Maggie) happy--and it doesn't strike me I find you too shy to tell me I SHALL.'' (unknown)

``Of course she (Maggie)'s happy, thank God! Only it's almost terrible, you know, the happiness of young, good, generous creatures. It rather frightens one. But the Blessed Virgin and all the Saints,'' (Prince)
said the Prince,
``have her (Maggie) in their keeping.'' (Prince)

``Certainly they have. She (Maggie)'s the dearest of the dear. But I needn't tell you,'' (the girl)
the girl added.

``Ah,'' (he)
he (Prince) returned with gravity,
``I feel that I've still much to learn about her (Maggie).'' (he)
To which he (Prince) subjoined
``She (Maggie)'ll rejoice awfully in your being with us.'' (he)

``Oh, you don't need me!'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte smiled.
``It's her (Maggie) hour. It's a great hour. One has seen often enough, with girls, what it is. But that,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``is exactly why. Why I've wanted, I mean, not to miss it.'' (she)

He (Prince) bent on her (Charlotte) a kind, comprehending face.

``You mustn't miss anything.'' (He)
He (Prince) had got it, the pitch, and he (Prince) could keep it now, for all he (Prince) had needed was to have it given him (Prince). The pitch was the happiness of his (Prince) wife that was to be--the sight of that happiness as a joy for an old friend. It was, yes, magnificent, and not the less so for its coming to him (friend), suddenly, as sincere, as nobly exalted. Something in Charlotte's eyes seemed to tell him (friend) this, seemed to plead with him (friend) in advance as to what he (friend) was to find in it. He (friend) was eager--and he (friend) tried to show her (Charlotte) that too--to find what she (Charlotte) liked; mindful as he (friend) easily could be of what the friendship had been for Maggie. It had been armed with the wings of young imagination, young generosity; it had been, he (friend) believed--always counting out her (Maggie) intense devotion to her (Maggie) father--the liveliest emotion she (Maggie) had known before the dawn of the sentiment inspired by himself. She (Maggie) had not, to his (friend) knowledge, invited the object of it to their wedding, had not thought of proposing to her (Maggie), for a matter of a couple of hours, an arduous and expensive journey. But she (Maggie) had kept her (Maggie) connected and informed, from week to week, in spite of preparations and absorptions.
``Oh, I've been writing to Charlotte--I wish you knew her (Charlotte) better:'' (he)
he (friend) could still hear, from recent weeks, this record of the fact, just as he (friend) could still be conscious, not otherwise than queerly, of the gratuitous element in Maggie's wish, which he (friend) had failed as yet to indicate to her (Maggie). Older and perhaps more intelligent, at any rate, why shouldn't Charlotte respond--and be quite FREE to respond--to such fidelities with something more than mere formal good manners? The relations of women with each other were of the strangest, it was true, and he (friend) probably wouldn't have trusted here a young person of his (friend) own race. He (friend) was proceeding throughout on the ground of the immense difference--difficult indeed as it might have been to disembroil in this young person HER race-quality. Nothing in her (Charlotte) definitely placed her (Charlotte); she (Charlotte) was a rare, a special product. Her (Charlotte) singleness, her (Charlotte) solitude, her (Charlotte) want of means, that is her (Charlotte) want of ramifications and other advantages, contributed to enrich her (Charlotte) somehow with an odd, precious neutrality, to constitute for her (Charlotte), so detached yet so aware, a sort of small social capital. It was the only one she (Charlotte) had--it was the only one a lonely, gregarious girl COULD have, since few, surely, had in anything like the same degree arrived at it, and since this one indeed had compassed it but through the play of some gift of nature to which you could scarce give a definite name.

It wasn't a question of her (Charlotte) strange sense for tongues, with which she (Charlotte) juggled as a conjuror at a show juggled with balls or hoops or lighted brands--it wasn't at least entirely that, for he (you) had known people almost as polyglot whom their accomplishment had quite failed to make interesting. He (you) was polyglot himself, for that matter--as was the case too with so many of his (you) friends and relations; for none of whom, more than for himself, was it anything but a common convenience. The point was that in this young woman it was a beauty in itself, and almost a mystery: so, certainly, he (you) had more than once felt in noting, on her (woman) lips, that rarest, among the Barbarians, of all civil graces, a perfect felicity in the use of Italian. He (you) had known strangers--a few, and mostly men--who spoke his (you) own language agreeably; but he (you) had known neither man nor woman who showed for it Charlotte's almost mystifying instinct. He (you) remembered how, from the first of their acquaintance, she (Charlotte) had made no display of it, quite as if English, between them, his (you) English so matching with hers, were their inevitable medium. He (you) had perceived all by accident--by hearing her (Charlotte) talk before him (you) to somebody else that they had an alternative as good; an alternative in fact as much better as the amusement for him (you) was greater in watching her (Charlotte) for the slips that never came. Her (Charlotte) account of the mystery didn't suffice: her (Charlotte) recall of her (Charlotte) birth in Florence and Florentine childhood; her (Charlotte) parents, from the great country, but themselves already of a corrupt generation, demoralised, falsified, polyglot well before her (Charlotte), with the Tuscan balia who was her (Charlotte) first remembrance; the servants of the villa, the dear contadini of the poder, the little girls and the other peasants of the next podere, all the rather shabby but still ever so pretty human furniture of her (Charlotte) early time, including the good sisters of the poor convent of the Tuscan hills, the convent shabbier than almost anything else, but prettier too, in which she (Charlotte) had been kept at school till the subsequent phase, the phase of the much grander institution in Paris at which Maggie was to arrive, terribly frightened, and as a smaller girl, three years before her (girl) own ending of her (girl) period of five. Such reminiscences, naturally, gave a ground, but they had not prevented him (girl) from insisting that some strictly civil ancestor--generations back, and from the Tuscan hills if she (girl) would-made himself felt, ineffaceably, in her (girl) blood and in her (girl) tone. She (girl) knew nothing of the ancestor, but she (girl) had taken his (ancestor) theory from him (ancestor), gracefully enough, as one of the little presents that make friendship flourish. These matters, however, all melted together now, though a sense of them was doubtless concerned, not unnaturally, in the next thing, of the nature of a surmise, that his (ancestor) discretion let him (ancestor) articulate.

``You haven't, I rather gather, particularly liked your country?'' (unknown)
They would stick, for the time, to their English.

``It doesn't, I fear, seem particularly mine. And it doesn't in the least matter, over there, whether one likes it or not--that is to anyone but one's self. But I didn't like it,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
said Charlotte Stant.

``That's not encouraging then to me, is it?'' (the Prince)
the Prince went on.

``Do you mean because you're going?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, of course we're going. I've wanted immensely to go.'' (She)
She (Stant) hesitated.
``But now?--immediately?'' (unknown)

``In a month or two--it seems to be the new idea.'' (he)
On which there was something in her (Stant) face--as he (Prince) imagined--that made him (Prince) say:
``Didn't Maggie write to you?'' (him)

``Not of your going at once. But of course you must go. And of course you must stay'' (Charlotte)
--Charlotte was easily clear--
``as long as possible.'' (Charlotte)

``Is that what you did?'' (he)
he (Prince) laughed.
``You stayed as long as possible?'' (unknown)

``Well, it seemed to me so--but I hadn't `interests.' You'll have them--on a great scale. It's the country for interests,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.
``If I had only had a few I doubtless wouldn't have left it.'' (He)

He (Prince) waited an instant; they were still on their feet.

``Yours then are rather here?'' (unknown)

``Oh, mine!'' (the girl)
--the girl smiled.
``They take up little room, wherever they are.'' (him)

It determined in him (Prince), the way this came from her (girl) and what it somehow did for her-it determined in him (Prince) a speech that would have seemed a few minutes before precarious and in questionable taste. The lead she (girl) had given him (Prince) made the difference, and he (Prince) felt it as really a lift on finding an honest and natural word rise, by its license, to his (Prince) lips. Nothing surely could be, for both of them, more in the note of a high bravery.

``I've been thinking it all the while so probable, you know, that you would have seen your way to marrying.'' (She)

She (girl) looked at him (Prince) an instant, and, just for these seconds, he (Prince) feared for what he (Prince) might have spoiled.

``To marrying whom?'' (unknown)

``Why, some good, kind, clever, rich American.'' (she)

Again his (Prince) security hung in the balance--then she (girl) was, as he (Prince) felt, admirable.

``I tried everyone I came across. I did my best. I showed I had come, quite publicly, FOR that. Perhaps I showed it too much. At any rate it was no use. I had to recognise it. No one would have me.'' (she)
Then she (girl) seemed to show as sorry for his (Prince) having to hear of her (girl) anything so disconcerting. She (girl) pitied his (Prince) feeling about it; if he (Prince) was disappointed she (girl) would cheer him (Prince) up.
``Existence, you know, all the same, doesn't depend on that. I mean,'' (she)
she (girl) smiled,
``on having caught a husband.'' (she)

``Oh--existence!'' (the Prince)
the Prince vaguely commented.
``You think I ought to argue for more than mere existence?'' (she)
she (girl) asked.
``I don't see why MY existence--even reduced as much as you like to being merely mine--should be so impossible. There are things, of sorts, I should be able to have--things I should be able to be. The position of a single woman to-day is very favourable, you know.'' (unknown)

``Favourable to what?'' (unknown)

``Why, just TO existence--which may contain, after all, in one way and another, so much. It may contain, at the worst, even affections; affections in fact quite particularly; fixed, that is, on one's friends. I'm extremely fond of Maggie, for instance--I quite adore her (Maggie). How could I adore her (Maggie) more if I were married to one of the people you speak of?'' (The Prince)

The Prince gave a laugh.

``You might adore HIM more--!'' (unknown)

``Ah, but it isn't, is it?'' (she)
she (girl) asked,
``a question of that.'' (she)

``My dear friend,'' (he)
he (Prince) returned,
``it's always a question of doing the best for one's self one can--without injury to others.'' (he)
He (Prince) felt by this time that they were indeed on an excellent basis; so he (Prince) went on again, as if to show frankly his (Prince) sense of its firmness.
``I venture therefore to repeat my hope that you'll marry some capital fellow; and also to repeat my belief that such a marriage will be more favourable to you, as you call it, than even the spirit of the age.'' (She)

She (girl) looked at him (Prince) at first only for answer, and would have appeared to take it with meekness had she (girl) not perhaps appeared a little more to take it with gaiety.

``Thank you very much,'' (she)
she (girl) simply said; but at that moment their friend was with them again. It was undeniable that, as she (girl) came in, Mrs. Assingham looked, with a certain smiling sharpness, from one of them to the other; the perception of which was perhaps what led Charlotte, for reassurance, to pass the question on.
``The Prince hopes so much I shall still marry some good person.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Whether it worked for Mrs. Assingham or not, the Prince was himself, at this, more than ever reassured. He (Prince) was SAFE, in a word--that was what it all meant; and he (Prince) had required to be safe. He (Prince) was really safe enough for almost any joke.

``It's only,'' (he)
he (Prince) explained to their hostess,
``because of what Miss Stant has been telling me. Don't we want to keep up her (you) courage?'' (hostess)
If the joke was broad he (Prince) had at least not begun it--not, that is, AS a joke; which was what his (Prince) companion's address to their friend made of it.
``She (you) has been trying in America, she (you) says, but hasn't brought it off.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

The tone was somehow not what Mrs. Assingham had expected, but she (Assingham) made the best of it.

``Well then,'' (she)
she (Assingham) replied to the young man,
``if you take such an interest you must bring it off.'' (the man)

``And you must help, dear,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
Charlotte said unperturbed--
``as you've helped, so beautifully, in such things before.'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
With which, before Mrs. Assingham could meet the appeal, she (Assingham) had addressed herself to the Prince on a matter much nearer to him (Prince).
``YOUR marriage is on Friday?--on Saturday?'' (unknown)

``Oh, on Friday, no! For what do you take us? There's not a vulgar omen we're neglecting. On Saturday, please, at the Oratory, at three o’clock--before twelve assistants exactly.'' (unknown)

``Twelve including ME?'' (him)

It struck him (Prince)--he (Prince) laughed.

``You'll make the thirteenth. It won't do!'' (unknown)

``Not,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``if you're going in for `omens.' Should you like me to stay away?'' (Charlotte)

``Dear no--we'll manage. We'll make the round number--we'll have in some old woman. They must keep them there for that, don't they?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham's return had at last indicated for him (Prince) his (Prince) departure; he (Prince) had possessed himself again of his (Prince) hat and approached her (Charlotte) to take leave. But he (Prince) had another word for Charlotte.

``I dine to-night with Mr. Verver. Have you any message?'' (The girl)

The girl seemed to wonder a little.

``For Mr. Verver?'' (unknown)

``For Maggie--about her (Maggie) seeing you early. That, I know, is what she (Maggie)'ll like.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll come early--thanks.'' (unknown)

``I daresay,'' (he)
he (Prince) went on,
``she (Maggie)'ll send for you. I mean send a carriage.'' (he)

``Oh, I don't require that, thanks. I can go, for a penny, can't I?'' (she)
she (Charlotte) asked of Mrs. Assingham,
``in an omnibus.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Oh, I say!'' (the Prince)
said the Prince while Mrs. Assingham looked at her (Assingham) blandly.

``Yes, love--and I'll give you the penny. She (Maggie) shall get there,'' (the lady)
the good lady added to their friend.

But Charlotte, as the latter took leave of her (Charlotte), thought of something else.

``There's a great favour, Prince, that I want to ask of you. I want, between this and Saturday, to make Maggie a marriage-present.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I say!'' (the man)
the young man again soothingly exclaimed.

``Ah, but I MUST,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on.
``It's really almost for that I came back. It was impossible to get in America what I wanted.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham showed anxiety.

``What is it then, dear, you want?'' (the girl)

But the girl looked only at their companion.

``That's what the Prince, if he (Prince)'ll be so good, must help me to decide.'' (unknown)

``Can't _I_,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham asked,
``help you to decide?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Certainly, darling, we must talk it well over.'' (she)
And she (Assingham) kept her (Assingham) eyes on the Prince.
``But I want him (Prince), if he (Prince) kindly will, to go with me to look. I want him (Prince) to judge with me and choose. That, if you can spare the hour,'' (she)
she (Assingham) said,
``is the great favour I mean.'' (she)

He (Prince) raised his (Prince) eyebrows at her (Assingham)--he (Prince) wonderfully smiled.

``What you came back from America to ask? Ah, certainly then, I must find the hour!'' (He)
He (Prince) wonderfully smiled, but it was rather more, after all, than he (Prince) had been reckoning with. It went somehow so little with the rest that, directly, for him (Prince), it wasn't the note of safety; it preserved this character, at the best, but by being the note of publicity. Quickly, quickly, however, the note of publicity struck him (character) as better than any other. In another moment even it seemed positively what he (character) wanted; for what so much as publicity put their relation on the right footing? By this appeal to Mrs. Assingham it was established as right, and she (Assingham) immediately showed that such was her (Assingham) own understanding.

``Certainly, Prince,'' (she)
she (Assingham) laughed,
``you must find the hour!'' (she)
And it was really so express a license from her (Assingham), as representing friendly judgment, public opinion, the moral law, the margin allowed a husband about to be, or whatever, that, after observing to Charlotte that, should she (Charlotte) come to Portland Place in the morning, he (husband) would make a point of being there to see her (Charlotte) and so, easily, arrange with her (Charlotte) about a time, he (husband) took his (husband) departure with the absolutely confirmed impression of knowing, as he (husband) put it to himself, where he (husband) was. Which was what he (husband) had prolonged his (husband) visit for. He (husband) was where he (husband) could stay.

IV

``I don't quite see, my dear,'' (Colonel)
Colonel Assingham said to his (husband) wife the night of Charlotte's arrival,
``I don't quite see, I'm bound to say, why you take it, even at the worst, so ferociously hard. It isn't your fault, after all, is it? I'll be hanged, at any rate, if it's mine.'' (Charlotte)

The hour was late, and the young lady who had disembarked at Southampton that morning to come up by the

``steamer special,'' (the lady morning)
and who had then settled herself at an hotel only to re-settle herself a couple of hours later at a private house, was by this time, they might hope, peacefully resting from her (lady) exploits. There had been two men at dinner, rather battered brothers-in-arms, of his (husband) own period, casually picked up by her (lady) host the day before, and when the gentlemen, after the meal, rejoined the ladies in the drawing-room, Charlotte, pleading fatigue, had already excused herself. The beguiled warriors, however, had stayed till after eleven--Mrs. Assingham, though finally quite without illusions, as she (Assingham) said, about the military character, was always beguiling to old soldiers; and as the Colonel had come in, before dinner, only in time to dress, he (Colonel) had not till this moment really been summoned to meet his (Colonel) companion over the situation that, as he (Colonel) was now to learn, their visitor's advent had created for them. It was actually more than midnight, the servants had been sent to bed, the rattle of the wheels had ceased to come in through a window still open to the August air, and Robert Assingham had been steadily learning, all the while, what it thus behoved him (Robert) to know. But the words just quoted from him (Robert) presented themselves, for the moment, as the essence of his (Robert) spirit and his (Robert) attitude. He (Robert) disengaged, he (Robert) would be damned if he (Robert) didn't--they were both phrases he (Robert) repeatedly used--his (Robert) responsibility. The simplest, the sanest, the most obliging of men, he (Robert) habitually indulged in extravagant language. His (Robert) wife had once told him (Robert), in relation to his (Robert) violence of speech; that such excesses, on his (Robert) part, made her (wife) think of a retired General whom she (wife) had once seen playing with toy soldiers, fighting and winning battles, carrying on sieges and annihilating enemies with little fortresses of wood and little armies of tin. Her (wife) husband's exaggerated emphasis was his (husband) box of toy soldiers, his (husband) military game. It harmlessly gratified in him (husband), for his (husband) declining years, the military instinct; bad words, when sufficiently numerous and arrayed in their might, could represent battalions, squadrons, tremendous cannonades and glorious charges of cavalry. It was natural, it was delightful--the romance, and for her (wife) as well, of camp life and of the perpetual booming of guns. It was fighting to the end, to the death, but no one was ever killed.

Less fortunate than she (wife), nevertheless, in spite of his (husband) wealth of expression, he (husband) had not yet found the image that described her (wife) favourite game; all he (husband) could do was practically to leave it to her (wife), emulating her (wife) own philosophy. He (husband) had again and again sat up late to discuss those situations in which her (wife) finer consciousness abounded, but he (husband) had never failed to deny that anything in life, anything of hers, could be a situation for himself. She (wife) might be in fifty at once if she (wife) liked--and it was what women did like, at their ease, after all; there always being, when they had too much of any, some man, as they were well aware, to get them out. He (man) wouldn't at any price, have one, of any sort whatever, of his (man) own, or even be in one along with her (wife). He (man) watched her (wife), accordingly, in her (wife) favourite element, very much as he (man) had sometimes watched, at the Aquarium, the celebrated lady who, in a slight, though tight, bathing-suit, turned somersaults and did tricks in the tank of water which looked so cold and uncomfortable to the non-amphibious. He (man) listened to his (man) companion to-night, while he (man) smoked his (man) last pipe, he (man) watched her (lady) through her (lady) demonstration, quite as if he (man) had paid a shilling. But it was true that, this being the case, he (man) desired the value of his (man) money. What was it, in the name of wonder, that she (lady) was so bent on being responsible FOR? What did she (lady) pretend was going to happen, and what, at the worst, could the poor girl do, even granting she (girl) wanted to do anything? What, at the worst, for that matter, could she (girl) be conceived to have in her (girl) head?

``If she (your) had told me the moment she (your) got here,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham replied,
``I shouldn't have my difficulty in finding out. But she (your) wasn't so obliging, and I see no sign at all of her (your) becoming so. What's certain is that she (your) didn't come for nothing. She (your) wants'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--she (Assingham) worked it out at her (Assingham) leisure--
``to see the Prince again. THAT isn't what troubles me. I mean that such a fact, as a fact, isn't. But what I ask myself is, What does she (your) want it FOR?'' (she)

``What's the good of asking yourself if you know you don't know?'' (The Colonel)
The Colonel sat back at his (Colonel) own ease, with an ankle resting on the other knee and his (Colonel) eyes attentive to the good appearance of an extremely slender foot which he (Colonel) kept jerking in its neat integument of fine-spun black silk and patent leather. It seemed to confess, this member, to consciousness of military discipline, everything about it being as polished and perfect, as straight and tight and trim, as a soldier on parade. It went so far as to imply that someone or other would have
``got'' (someone)
something or other, confinement to barracks or suppression of pay, if it hadn't been just as it was. Bob Assingham was distinguished altogether by a leanness of person, a leanness quite distinct from physical laxity, which might have been determined, on the part of superior powers, by views of transport and accommodation, and which in fact verged on the abnormal. He (Assingham)
``did'' (He)
himself as well as his (Assingham) friends mostly knew, yet remained hungrily thin, with facial, with abdominal cavities quite grim in their effect, and with a consequent looseness of apparel that, combined with a choice of queer light shades and of strange straw-like textures, of the aspect of Chinese mats, provocative of wonder at his (Assingham) sources of supply, suggested the habit of tropic islands, a continual cane-bottomed chair, a governorship exercised on wide verandahs. His (Assingham) smooth round head, with the particular shade of its white hair, was like a silver pot reversed; his (Assingham) cheekbones and the bristle of his (Assingham) moustache were worthy of Attila the Hun. The hollows of his (Assingham) eyes were deep and darksome, but the eyes within them, were like little blue flowers plucked that morning. He (Assingham) knew everything that could be known about life, which he (Assingham) regarded as, for far the greater part, a matter of pecuniary arrangement. His (Assingham) wife accused him (Assingham) of a want, alike, of moral and of intellectual reaction, or rather indeed of a complete incapacity for either. He (Assingham) never went even so far as to understand what she (wife) meant, and it didn't at all matter, since he (Assingham) could be in spite of the limitation a perfectly social creature. The infirmities, the predicaments of men neither surprised nor shocked him (Assingham), and indeed--which was perhaps his (Assingham) only real loss in a thrifty career--scarce even amused; he (Assingham) took them for granted without horror, classifying them after their kind and calculating results and chances. He (Assingham) might, in old bewildering climates, in old campaigns of cruelty and license, have had such revelations and known such amazements that he (Assingham) had nothing more to learn. But he (Assingham) was wholly content, in spite of his (Assingham) fondness, in domestic discussion, for the superlative degree; and his (Assingham) kindness, in the oddest way, seemed to have nothing to do with his (Assingham) experience. He (Assingham) could deal with things perfectly, for all his (Assingham) needs, without getting near them.

This was the way he (Assingham) dealt with his (Assingham) wife, a large proportion of whose meanings he (Assingham) knew he (Assingham) could neglect. He (Assingham) edited, for their general economy, the play of her (wife) mind, just as he (Assingham) edited, savingly, with the stump of a pencil, her (wife) redundant telegrams. The thing in the world that was least of a mystery to him (Assingham) was his (Assingham) Club, which he (Assingham) was accepted as perhaps too completely managing, and which he (Assingham) managed on lines of perfect penetration. His (Assingham) connection with it was really a master-piece of editing. This was in fact, to come back, very much the process he (Assingham) might have been proposing to apply to Mrs. Assingham's view of what was now before them; that is to their connection with Charlotte Stant's possibilities. They wouldn't lavish on them all their little fortune of curiosity and alarm; certainly they wouldn't spend their cherished savings so early in the day. He (Assingham) liked Charlotte, moreover, who was a smooth and compact inmate, and whom he (Assingham) felt as, with her (Charlotte) instincts that made against waste, much more of his (Assingham) own sort than his (Assingham) wife. He (Assingham) could talk with her (wife) about Fanny almost better than he (Assingham) could talk with Fanny about Charlotte. However, he (Assingham) made at present the best of the latter necessity, even to the pressing of the question he (Assingham) has been noted as having last uttered.

``If you can't think what to be afraid of, wait till you can think. Then you'll do it much better. Or otherwise, if that's waiting too long, find out from HER. Don't try to find out from ME. Ask her (your) herself.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham denied, as we know, that her (Assingham) husband had a play of mind; so that she (Assingham) could, on her (Assingham) side, treat these remarks only as if they had been senseless physical gestures or nervous facial movements. She (Assingham) overlooked them as from habit and kindness; yet there was no one to whom she (Assingham) talked so persistently of such intimate things.

``It's her (your) friendship with Maggie that's the immense complication. Because THAT,'' (she)
she (Assingham) audibly mused,
``is so natural.'' (she)

``Then why can't she (your) have come out for it?'' (unknown)

``She (your) came out,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham continued to meditate,
``because she (your) hates America. There was no place for her (your) there--she (your) didn't fit in. She (your) wasn't in sympathy--no more were the people she (your) saw. Then it's hideously dear; she (your) can't, on her (your) means, begin to live there. Not at all as she (your) can, in a way, here.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``In the way, you mean, of living with US?'' (unknown)

``Of living with anyone. She (your) can't live by visits alone--and she (your) doesn't want to. She (your)'s too good for it even if she (your) could. But she (your) will--she (your) MUST, sooner or later--stay with THEM. Maggie will want her (Maggie)--Maggie will make her (Maggie). Besides, she (Maggie)'ll want to herself.'' (unknown)

``Then why won't that do,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel asked,
``for you to think it's what she (Maggie) has come for?'' (the Colonel)

``How will it do, HOW?'' (she)
--she (Assingham) went on as without hearing him (Colonel).

``That's what one keeps feeling.'' (unknown)

``Why shouldn't it do beautifully?'' (unknown)

``That anything of the past,'' (she)
she (Assingham) brooded,
``should come back NOW? How will it do, how will it do?'' (she)

``It will do, I daresay, without your wringing your hands over it. When, my dear,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel pursued as he (Colonel) smoked,
``have you ever seen anything of yours--anything that you've done--NOT do?'' (he)

``Ah, I didn't do this!'' (unknown)
It brought her (Assingham) answer straight.
``I didn't bring her (it) back.'' (unknown)

``Did you expect her (it) to stay over there all her (it) days to oblige you?'' (unknown)

``Not a bit--for I shouldn't have minded her (it) coming after their marriage. It's her (it) coming, this way, before.'' (she)
To which she (Assingham) added with inconsequence:
``I'm too sorry for her (it)--of course she (it) can't enjoy it. But I don't see what perversity rides her (it). She (it) needn't have looked it all so in the face--as she (it) doesn't do it, I suppose, simply for discipline. It's almost--that's the bore of it--discipline to ME.'' (she)

``Perhaps then,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
said Bob Assingham,
``that's what has been her (it) idea. Take it, for God's sake, as discipline to you and have done with it. It will do,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
he (Assingham) added,
``for discipline to me as well.'' (he)

She (Assingham) was far, however, from having done with it; it was a situation with such different sides, as she (Assingham) said, and to none of which one could, in justice, be blind.

``It isn't in the least, you know, for instance, that I believe she (it)'s bad. Never, never,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham declared.
``I don't think that of her (it).'' (unknown)

``Then why isn't that enough?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Nothing was enough, Mrs. Assingham signified, but that she (Assingham) should develop her (Assingham) thought.

``She (it) doesn't deliberately intend, she (it) doesn't consciously wish, the least complication. It's perfectly true that she (it) thinks Maggie a dear--as who doesn't? She (it)'s incapable of any PLAN to hurt a hair of her (it) head. Yet here she (it) is--and there THEY are,'' (she)
she (Assingham) wound up.

Her (Assingham) husband again, for a little, smoked in silence.

``What in the world, between them, ever took place?'' (unknown)

``Between Charlotte and the Prince? Why, nothing--except their having to recognise that nothing COULD. That was their little romance--it was even their little tragedy.'' (unknown)

``But what the deuce did they DO?'' (unknown)

``Do? They fell in love with each other--but, seeing it wasn't possible, gave each other up.'' (unknown)

``Then where was the romance?'' (unknown)

``Why, in their frustration, in their having the courage to look the facts in the face.'' (unknown)

``What facts?'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel went on.

``Well, to begin with, that of their neither of them having the means to marry. If she (their) had had even a little--a little, I mean, for two--I believe he (it) would bravely have done it.'' (husband)
After which, as her (Assingham) husband but emitted an odd vague sound, she (Assingham) corrected herself.
``I mean if he (it) himself had had only a little--or a little more than a little, a little for a prince. They would have done what they could'' (she)
--she (Assingham) did them justice
''--if there had been a way. But there wasn't a way, and Charlotte, quite to her (Charlotte) honour, I consider, understood it. He (Colonel) HAD to have money--it was a question of life and death. It wouldn't have been a bit amusing, either, to marry him (Colonel) as a pauper--I mean leaving him (Colonel) one. That was what she (Charlotte) had--as HE (Colonel) had--the reason to see.'' (she)

``And their reason is what you call their romance?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) looked at him (Colonel) a moment.

``What do you want more?'' (unknown)

``Didn't HE (prince),'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel inquired,
``want anything more? Or didn't, for that matter, poor Charlotte herself?'' (the Colonel)

She (Charlotte) kept her (Charlotte) eyes on him (Colonel); there was a manner in it that half answered.

``They were thoroughly in love. She (Charlotte) might have been his (prince)--'' (She)
She (Charlotte) checked herself; she (Charlotte) even for a minute lost herself.
``She (Charlotte) might have been anything she (Charlotte) liked--except his (prince) wife.'' (unknown)

``But she (Charlotte) wasn't,'' (the Colonel)
said the Colonel very smokingly.

``She (Charlotte) wasn't,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham echoed.

The echo, not loud but deep, filled for a little the room. He (Colonel) seemed to listen to it die away; then he (Colonel) began again.

``How are you sure?'' (She)

She (Assingham) waited before saying, but when she (Assingham) spoke it was definite.

``There wasn't time.'' (He)

He (Colonel) had a small laugh for her (Assingham) reason; he (Colonel) might have expected some other.

``Does it take so much time?'' (She)

She (Assingham) herself, however, remained serious.

``It takes more than they had.'' (He)

He (Colonel) was detached, but he (Colonel) wondered.

``What was the matter with their time?'' (she)
After which, as, remembering it all, living it over and piecing it together, she (Assingham) only considered,
``You mean that you came in with your idea?'' (she)
he (Colonel) demanded.

It brought her (Assingham) quickly to the point, and as if also in a measure to answer herself.

``Not a bit of it--THEN. But you surely recall,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on,
``the way, a year ago, everything took place. They had parted before he (prince) had ever heard of Maggie.'' (she)

``Why hadn't he (prince) heard of her (Maggie) from Charlotte herself?'' (unknown)

``Because she (Maggie) had never spoken of her (Maggie).'' (unknown)

``Is that also,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel inquired,
``what she (Maggie) has told you?'' (the Colonel)

``I'm not speaking,'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife returned,
``of what she (Maggie) has told me. That's one thing. I'm speaking of what I know by myself. That's another.'' (wife)

``You feel, in other words, that she (Maggie) lies to you?'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham more sociably asked.

She (wife) neglected the question, treating it as gross.

``She (Maggie) never so much, at the time, as named Maggie.'' (him)

It was so positive that it appeared to strike him (Assingham).

``It's he (prince) then who has told you?'' (She)

She (wife) after a moment admitted it.

``It's he (prince).'' (unknown)

``And he (prince) doesn't lie?'' (unknown)

``No--to do him (prince) justice. I believe he (prince) absolutely doesn't. If I hadn't believed it,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham declared, for her (Assingham) general justification,
``I would have had nothing to do with him (prince)--that is in this connection. He (prince)'s a gentleman--I mean ALL as much of one as he (prince) ought to be. And he (prince) had nothing to gain. That helps,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) added,
``even a gentleman. It was I who named Maggie to him (gentleman)--a year from last May. He (gentleman) had never heard of her (Maggie) before.'' (she)

``Then it's grave,'' (the Colonel)
said the Colonel.

She (Assingham) hesitated.

``Do you mean grave for me?'' (unknown)

``Oh, that everything's grave for `you' is what we take for granted and are fundamentally talking about. It's grave--it WAS--for Charlotte. And it's grave for Maggie. That is it WAS--when he (gentleman) did see her (Maggie). Or when she (Maggie) did see HIM.'' (unknown)

``You don't torment me as much as you would like,'' (she)
she (Assingham) presently went on,
``because you think of nothing that I haven't a thousand times thought of, and because I think of everything that you never will. It would all,'' (she)
she (Assingham) recognised,
``have been grave if it hadn't all been right. You can't make out,'' (she)
she (Assingham) contended,
``that we got to Rome before the end of February.'' (she)

He (Colonel) more than agreed.

``There's nothing in life, my dear, that I CAN make out.'' (she)

Well, there was nothing in life, apparently, that she (Assingham), at real need, couldn't.

``Charlotte, who had been there, that year, from early, quite from November, left suddenly, you'll quite remember, about the 10th of April. She (Charlotte) was to have stayed on--she (Charlotte) was to have stayed, naturally, more or less, for us; and she (Charlotte) was to have stayed all the more that the Ververs, due all winter, but delayed, week after week, in Paris, were at last really coming. They were coming--that is Maggie was--largely to see her (Maggie), and above all to be with her (Maggie) THERE. It was all altered--by Charlotte's going to Florence. She (Charlotte) went from one day to the other--you forget everything. She (Charlotte) gave her (Charlotte) reasons, but I thought it odd, at the time; I had a sense that something must have happened. The difficulty was that, though I knew a little, I didn't know enough. I didn't know her (Charlotte) relation with him (you) had been, as you say, a `near' thing--that is I didn't know HOW near. The poor girl's departure was a flight--she (girl) went to save herself.'' (He)

He (Colonel) had listened more than he (Colonel) showed--as came out in his (Colonel) tone.

``To save herself?'' (unknown)

``Well, also, really, I think, to save HIM too. I saw it afterwards--I see it all now. He (you) would have been sorry--he (you) didn't want to hurt her (girl).'' (unknown)

``Oh, I daresay,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel laughed.
``They generally don't!'' (unknown)

``At all events,'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife pursued,
``she (girl) escaped--they both did; for they had had simply to face it. Their marriage couldn't be, and, if that was so, the sooner they put the Apennines between them the better. It had taken them, it is true, some time to feel this and to find it out. They had met constantly, and not always publicly, all that winter; they had met more than was known--though it was a good deal known. More, certainly,'' (wife)
she (wife) said,
``than I then imagined--though I don't know what difference it would after all have made with me. I liked him (me), I thought him (me) charming, from the first of our knowing him (me); and now, after more than a year, he (me) has done nothing to spoil it. And there are things he (me) might have done--things that many men easily would. Therefore I believe in him (me), and I was right, at first, in knowing I was going to. So I haven't'' (she)
--and she (wife) stated it as she (wife) might have quoted from a slate, after adding up the items, the sum of a column of figures--
``so I haven't, I say to myself, been a fool.'' (she)

``Well, are you trying to make out that I've said you have? All their case wants, at any rate,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham declared,
``is that you should leave it well alone. It's theirs now; they've bought it, over the counter, and paid for it. It has ceased to be yours.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

``Of which case,'' (she)
she (wife) asked,
``are you speaking?'' (she)

He (Assingham) smoked a minute: then with a groan:

``Lord, are there so many?'' (He)

``There's Maggie's and the Prince's, and there's the Prince's and Charlotte's.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes; and then,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel scoffed,
``there's Charlotte's and the Prince's.'' (the Colonel)

``There's Maggie's and Charlotte's,'' (she)
she (wife) went on--
``and there's also Maggie's and mine. I think too that there's Charlotte's and mine. Yes,'' (she)
she (wife) mused,
``Charlotte's and mine is certainly a case. In short, you see, there are plenty. But I mean,'' (she)
she (wife) said,
``to keep my head.'' (she)

``Are we to settle them all,'' (he)
he (Colonel) inquired,
``to-night?'' (he)

``I should lose it if things had happened otherwise--if I had acted with any folly.'' (She)
She (wife) had gone on in her (wife) earnestness, unheeding of his (Colonel) question.
``I shouldn't be able to bear that now. But my good conscience is my strength; no one can accuse me. The Ververs came on to Rome alone--Charlotte, after their days with her (Charlotte) in Florence, had decided about America. Maggie, I daresay, had helped her (Maggie); she (Maggie) must have made her (Maggie) a present, and a handsome one, so that many things were easy. Charlotte left them, came to England, `joined' somebody or other, sailed for New York. I have still her (Charlotte) letter from Milan, telling me; I didn't know at the moment all that was behind it, but I felt in it nevertheless the undertaking of a new life. Certainly, in any case, it cleared THAT air--I mean the dear old Roman, in which we were steeped. It left the field free--it gave me a free hand. There was no question for me of anybody else when I brought the two others together. More than that, there was no question for them. So you see,'' (she)
she (wife) concluded,
``where that puts me.'' (she)
She (wife) got up, on the words, very much as if they were the blue daylight towards which, through a darksome tunnel, she (wife) had been pushing her (wife) way, and the elation in her (wife) voice, combined with her (wife) recovered alertness, might have signified the sharp whistle of the train that shoots at last into the open. She (wife) turned about the room; she (wife) looked out a moment into the August night; she (wife) stopped, here and there, before the flowers in bowls and vases. Yes, it was distinctly as if she (wife) had proved what was needing proof, as if the issue of her (wife) operation had been, almost unexpectedly, a success. Old arithmetic had perhaps been fallacious, but the new settled the question. Her (wife) husband, oddly, however, kept his (husband) place without apparently measuring these results. As he (husband) had been amused at her (wife) intensity, so he (husband) was not uplifted by her (wife) relief; his (husband) interest might in fact have been more enlisted than he (husband) allowed.
``Do you mean,'' (he)
he (husband) presently asked,
``that he (Roman) had already forgot about Charlotte?'' (he)

She (wife) faced round as if he (husband) had touched a spring.

``He (Roman) WANTED to, naturally--and it was much the best thing he (Roman) could do.'' (She)
She (wife) was in possession of the main case, as it truly seemed; she (wife) had it all now.
``He (Roman) was capable of the effort, and he (Roman) took the best way. Remember too what Maggie then seemed to us.'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie)'s very nice; but she (Maggie) always seems to me, more than anything else, the young woman who has a million a year. If you mean that that's what she (woman) especially seemed to him (Roman), you of course place the thing in your light. The effort to forget Charlotte couldn't, I grant you, have been so difficult.'' (unknown)

This pulled her (wife) up but for an instant.

``I never said he (Roman) didn't from the first--I never said that he (Roman) doesn't more and more--like Maggie's money.'' (unknown)

``I never said I shouldn't have liked it myself,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham returned. He (Assingham) made no movement; he (Assingham) smoked another minute.
``How much did Maggie know?'' (unknown)

``How much?'' (She)
She (wife) seemed to consider--as if it were between quarts and gallons--how best to express the quantity.
``She (Maggie) knew what Charlotte, in Florence, had told her (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``And what had Charlotte told her (Charlotte)?'' (unknown)

``Very little.'' (unknown)

``What makes you so sure?'' (unknown)

``Why, this--that she (Charlotte) couldn't tell her (Charlotte).'' (she)
And she (wife) explained a little what she (wife) meant.
``There are things, my dear--haven't you felt it yourself, coarse as you are?--that no one could tell Maggie. There are things that, upon my word, I shouldn't care to attempt to tell her (Maggie) now.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel smoked on it.

``She (Maggie)'d be so scandalised?'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie)'d be so frightened. She (Maggie)'d be, in her (Maggie) strange little way, so hurt. She (Maggie) wasn't born to know evil. She (Maggie) must never know it.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham had a queer grim laugh; the sound of which, in fact, fixed his (Assingham) wife before him (Assingham).
``We're taking grand ways to prevent it.'' (she)

But she (wife) stood there to protest.

``We're not taking any ways. The ways are all taken; they were taken from the moment he (it) came up to our carriage that day in Villa Borghese--the second or third of her (Maggie) days in Rome, when, as you remember, you went off somewhere with Mr. Verver, and the Prince, who had got into the carriage with us, came home with us to tea. They had met; they had seen each other well; they were in relation: the rest was to come of itself and as it could. It began, practically, I recollect, in our drive. Maggie happened to learn, by some other man's greeting of him (man), in the bright Roman way, from a streetcorner as we passed, that one of the Prince's baptismal names, the one always used for him (Prince) among his (Prince) relations, was Amerigo: which -LRB-as you probably don't know, however, even after a lifetime of ME-RRB-, was the name, four hundred years ago, or whenever, of the pushing man who followed, across the sea, in the wake of Columbus and succeeded, where Columbus had failed, in becoming godfather, or name-father, to the new Continent; so that the thought of any connection with him (godfather) can even now thrill our artless breasts.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel's grim placidity could always quite adequately meet his (Colonel) wife's not infrequent imputation of ignorances, on the score of the land of her (wife) birth, unperturbed and unashamed; and these dark depths were even at the present moment not directly lighted by an inquiry that managed to be curious without being apologetic.

``But where does the connection come in?'' (wife)

His (Colonel) wife was prompt.

``By the women--that is by some obliging woman, of old, who was a descendant of the pushing man, the make-believe discoverer, and whom the Prince is therefore luckily able to refer to as an ancestress. A branch of the other family had become great--great enough, at least, to marry into his (Prince); and the name of the navigator, crowned with glory, was, very naturally, to become so the fashion among them that some son, of every generation, was appointed to wear it. My point is, at any rate, that I recall noticing at the time how the Prince was, from the start, helped with the dear Ververs by his (Prince) wearing it. The connection became romantic for Maggie the moment she (Maggie) took it in; she (Maggie) filled out, in a flash, every link that might be vague. `By that sign,' I quite said to myself, `he (Prince)'ll conquer'--with his (Prince) good fortune, of course, of having the other necessary signs too. It really,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham,
``was, practically, the fine side of the wedge. Which struck me as also,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) wound up,
``a lovely note for the candour of the Ververs.'' (she)

The Colonel took in the tale, but his (Colonel) comment was prosaic.

``He (Prince) knew, Amerigo, what he (Prince) was about. And I don't mean the OLD one.'' (unknown)

``I know what you mean!'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife bravely threw off.

``The old one'' (he)
--he (Colonel) pointed his (Colonel) effect
``isn't the only discoverer in the family.'' (he)

``Oh, as much as you like! If he (Prince) discovered America--or got himself honoured as if he (Prince) had--his (Prince) successors were, in due time, to discover the Americans. And it was one of them in particular, doubtless, who was to discover how patriotic we are.'' (unknown)

``Wouldn't this be the same one,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel asked,
``who really discovered what you call the connection?'' (the Colonel)

She (wife) gave him (Colonel) a look.

``The connection's a true thing--the connection's perfectly historic, Your insinuations recoil upon your cynical mind. Don't you understand,'' (she)
she (wife) asked,
``that the history of such people is known, root and branch, at every moment of its course?'' (she)

``Oh, it's all right,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
said Bob Assingham.

``Go to the British Museum,'' (companion)
his (Assingham) companion continued with spirit.

``And what am I to do there?'' (unknown)

``There's a whole immense room, or recess, or department, or whatever, filled with books written about his (I) family alone. You can see for yourself.'' (unknown)

``Have you seen for YOUR self?'' (She)

She (wife) faltered but an instant.

``Certainly--I went one day with Maggie. We looked him (I) up, so to say. They were most civil.'' (she)
And she (wife) fell again into the current her (wife) husband had slightly ruffled.
``The effect was produced, the charm began to work, at all events, in Rome, from that hour of the Prince's drive with us. My only course, afterwards, had to be to make the best of it. It was certainly good enough for that,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham hastened to add,
``and I didn't in the least see my duty in making the worst. In the same situation, to-day; I wouldn't act differently. I entered into the case as it then appeared to me--and as, for the matter of that, it still does. I LIKED it, I thought all sorts of good of it, and nothing can even now,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) said with some intensity,
``make me think anything else.'' (she)

``Nothing can ever make you think anything you don't want to,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel, still in his (Colonel) chair, remarked over his (Colonel) pipe.
``You've got a precious power of thinking whatever you do want. You want also, from moment to moment, to think such desperately different things. What happened,'' (he)
he (Colonel) went on,
``was that you fell violently in love with the Prince yourself, and that as you couldn't get me out of the way you had to take some roundabout course. You couldn't marry him (Prince), any more than Charlotte could--that is not to yourself. But you could to somebody else--it was always the Prince, it was always marriage. You could to your little friend, to whom there were no objections.'' (he)

``Not only there were no objections, but there were reasons, positive ones--and all excellent, all charming.'' (She)
She (Assingham) spoke with an absence of all repudiation of his (Colonel) exposure of the spring of her (Assingham) conduct; and this abstention, clearly and effectively conscious, evidently cost her (Assingham) nothing.
``It IS always the Prince; and it IS always, thank heaven, marriage. And these are the things, God grant, that it will always be. That I could help, a year ago, most assuredly made me happy, and it continues to make me happy.'' (unknown)

``Then why aren't you quiet?'' (unknown)

``I AM quiet,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

He (Colonel) looked at her (Assingham), with his (Colonel) colourless candour, still in his (Colonel) place; she (Assingham) moved about again, a little, emphasising by her (Assingham) unrest her (Assingham) declaration of her (Assingham) tranquillity. He (Colonel) was as silent, at first, as if he (Colonel) had taken her (Assingham) answer, but he (Colonel) was not to keep it long.

``What do you make of it that, by your own show, Charlotte couldn't tell her (Charlotte) all? What do you make of it that the Prince didn't tell her (Charlotte) anything? Say one understands that there are things she (Charlotte) can't be told--since, as you put it, she (Charlotte) is so easily scared and shocked.'' (He)
He (Colonel) produced these objections slowly, giving her (Assingham) time, by his (Colonel) pauses, to stop roaming and come back to him (Colonel). But she (Assingham) was roaming still when he (Colonel) concluded his (Colonel) inquiry.
``If there hadn't been anything there shouldn't have been between the pair before Charlotte bolted--in order, precisely, as you say, that there SHOULDN'T be: why in the world was what there HAD been too bad to be spoken of?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham, after this question, continued still to circulate--not directly meeting it even when at last she (Assingham) stopped.

``I thought you wanted me to be quiet.'' (unknown)

``So I do--and I'm trying to make you so much so that you won't worry more. Can't you be quiet on THAT?'' (She)

She (Assingham) thought a moment--then seemed to try.

``To relate that she (Charlotte) had to `bolt' for the reasons we speak of, even though the bolting had done for her (Charlotte) what she (Charlotte) wished--THAT I can perfectly feel Charlotte's not wanting to do.'' (unknown)

``Ah then, if it HAS done for her (Charlotte) what she (Charlotte) wished-!'' (the Colonel)
But the Colonel's conclusion hung by the
``if'' (the Colonel)
which his (Colonel) wife didn't take up. So it hung but the longer when he (Colonel) presently spoke again.
``All one wonders, in that case, is why then she (Charlotte) has come back to him (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``Say she (Charlotte) hasn't come back to him (Charlotte). Not really to HIM.'' (unknown)

``I'll say anything you like. But that won't do me the same good as your saying it.'' (unknown)

``Nothing, my dear, will do you good,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham returned.
``You don't care for anything in itself; you care for nothing but to be grossly amused because I don't keep washing my hands--!'' (unknown)

``I thought your whole argument was that everything is so right that this is precisely what you do.'' (wife)

But his (Colonel) wife, as it was a point she (Assingham) had often made, could go on as she (Assingham) had gone on before. ``You're perfectly indifferent, really; you're perfectly immoral. You've taken part in the sack of cities, and I'm sure you've done dreadful things yourself. But I DON'T trouble my head, if you like. `So now there!''' she (I) laughed.

He (I) accepted her (I) laugh, but he (I) kept his (I) way.

``Well, I back poor Charlotte.'' (unknown)

```Back' her (Assingham)?''

``To know what she (Charlotte) wants.'' (unknown)

``Ah then, so do I. She (Charlotte) does know what she (Charlotte) wants.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
And Mrs. Assingham produced this quantity, at last, on the girl's behalf, as the ripe result of her (Assingham) late wanderings and musings. She (Assingham) had groped through their talk, for the thread, and now she (Assingham) had got it.
``She (Charlotte) wants to be magnificent.'' (unknown)

``She (Charlotte) is,'' (the Colonel)
said the Colonel almost cynically.

``She (Charlotte) wants'' (wife)
--his (Colonel) wife now had it fast
``to be thoroughly superior, and she (Charlotte)'s capable of that.'' (wife)

``Of wanting to?'' (unknown)

``Of carrying out her (Charlotte) idea.'' (unknown)

``And what IS her (Charlotte) idea?'' (unknown)

``To see Maggie through.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

Bob Assingham wondered.

``Through what?'' (unknown)

``Through everything. She (Charlotte) KNOWS the Prince.'' (unknown)

``And Maggie doesn't. No, dear thing'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--Mrs. Assingham had to recognise it--
``she (Maggie) doesn't.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``So that Charlotte has come out to give her (Charlotte) lessons?'' (She)

She (Assingham) continued, Fanny Assingham, to work out her (Assingham) thought.

``She (Charlotte) has done this great thing for him (Prince). That is, a year ago, she (Charlotte) practically did it. She (Charlotte) practically, at any rate, helped him (Prince) to do it himself--and helped me to help him (Prince). She (Charlotte) kept off, she (Charlotte) stayed away, she (Charlotte) left him (Prince) free; and what, moreover, were her (Charlotte) silences to Maggie but a direct aid to him (Prince)? If she (Maggie) had spoken in Florence; if she (Maggie) had told her (Maggie) own poor story; if she (Maggie) had, come back at any time--till within a few weeks ago; if she (Maggie) hadn't gone to New York and hadn't held out there: if she (Maggie) hadn't done these things all that has happened since would certainly have been different. Therefore she (Maggie)'s in a position to be consistent now. She (Maggie) knows the Prince,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham repeated. It involved even again her (Assingham) former recognition.
``And Maggie, dear thing, doesn't.'' (She)

She (Assingham) was high, she (Assingham) was lucid, she (Assingham) was almost inspired; and it was but the deeper drop therefore to her (Assingham) husband's flat common sense.

``In other words Maggie is, by her (Maggie) ignorance, in danger? Then if she (Maggie)'s in danger, there IS danger.'' (unknown)

``There WON'T be--with Charlotte's understanding of it. That's where she (Charlotte) has had her (Charlotte) conception of being able to be heroic, of being able in fact to be sublime. She (Charlotte) is, she (Charlotte) will be'' (the lady)
--the good lady by this time glowed.
``So she (Charlotte) sees it--to become, for her (Charlotte) best friend, an element of POSITIVE safety.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

Bob Assingham looked at it hard.

``Which of them do you call her (Charlotte) best friend?'' (She)

She (lady) gave a toss of impatience.

``I'll leave you to discover!'' (she)
But the grand truth thus made out she (lady) had now completely adopted.
``It's for US, therefore, to be hers.'' (unknown)

```Hers'?''

``You and I. It's for us to be Charlotte's. It's for us, on our side, to see HER through.'' (unknown)

``Through her (Charlotte) sublimity?'' (unknown)

``Through her (Charlotte) noble, lonely life. Only--that's essential--it mustn't be lonely. It will be all right if she (Charlotte) marries.'' (unknown)

``So we're to marry her (Charlotte)?'' (unknown)

``We're to marry her (Charlotte). It will be,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham continued,
``the great thing I can do.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
She (Assingham) made it out more and more.
``It will make up.'' (unknown)

``Make up for what?'' (she)
As she (Assingham) said nothing, however, his (Assingham) desire for lucidity renewed itself.
``If everything's so all right what is there to make up for?'' (unknown)

``Why, if I did do either of them, by any chance, a wrong. If I made a mistake.'' (unknown)

``You'll make up for it by making another?'' (she)
And then as she (Assingham) again took her (Assingham) time:
``I thought your whole point is just that you're sure.'' (she)

``One can never be ideally sure of anything. There are always possibilities.'' (unknown)

``Then, if we can but strike so wild, why keep meddling?'' (him)

It made her (Assingham) again look at him (Assingham).

``Where would you have been, my dear, if I hadn't meddled with YOU?'' (unknown)

``Ah, that wasn't meddling--I was your own. I was your own,'' (the Colonel)
said the Colonel,
``from the moment I didn't object.'' (the Colonel)

``Well, these people won't object. They are my own too--in the sense that I'm awfully fond of them. Also in the sense,'' (she)
she (Assingham) continued,
``that I think they're not so very much less fond of me. Our relation, all round, exists--it's a reality, and a very good one; we're mixed up, so to speak, and it's too late to change it. We must live IN it and with it. Therefore to see that Charlotte gets a good husband as soon as possible--that, as I say, will be one of my ways of living. It will cover,'' (she)
she (Assingham) said with conviction,
``all the ground.'' (she)
And then as his (Colonel) own conviction appeared to continue as little to match:
``The ground, I mean, of any nervousness I may ever feel. It will be in fact my duty and I shan't rest till my duty's performed.'' (She)
She (Assingham) had arrived by this time at something like exaltation.
``I shall give, for the next year or two if necessary, my life to it. I shall have done in that case what I can.'' (He)

He (Colonel) took it at last as it came.

``You hold there's no limit to what you `can'?'' (unknown)

``I don't say there's no limit, or anything of the sort. I say there are good chances--enough of them for hope. Why shouldn't there be when a girl is, after all, all that she (girl) is?'' (unknown)

``By after `all' you mean after she (girl)'s in love with somebody else?'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel put his (Colonel) question with a quietude doubtless designed to be fatal; but it scarcely pulled her (Assingham) up.

``She (girl)'s not too much in love not herself to want to marry. She (girl) would now particularly like to.'' (unknown)

``Has she (girl) told you so?'' (unknown)

``Not yet. It's too soon. But she (girl) will. Meanwhile, however, I don't require the information. Her (girl) marrying will prove the truth.'' (unknown)

``And what truth?'' (unknown)

``The truth of everything I say.'' (unknown)

``Prove it to whom?'' (unknown)

``Well, to myself, to begin with. That will be enough for me--to work for her (girl). What it will prove,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham presently went on,
``will be that she (girl)'s cured. That she (girl) accepts the situation.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

He (Colonel) paid this the tribute of a long pull at his (Colonel) pipe.

``The situation of doing the one thing she (girl) can that will really seem to cover her (girl) tracks?'' (wife)

His (Colonel) wife looked at him (Colonel), the good dry man, as if now at last he (Colonel) was merely vulgar.

``The one thing she (girl) can do that will really make new tracks altogether. The thing that, before any other, will be wise and right. The thing that will best give her (girl) her (girl) chance to be magnificent.'' (He)

He (Colonel) slowly emitted his (Colonel) smoke.

``And best give you, by the same token, yours to be magnificent with her (girl)?'' (unknown)

``I shall be as magnificent, at least, as I can.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

Bob Assingham got up.

``And you call ME immoral?'' (She)

She (wife) hesitated.

``I'll call you stupid if you prefer. But stupidity pushed to a certain point IS, you know, immorality. Just so what is morality but high intelligence?'' (he)
This he (Assingham) was unable to tell her (wife); which left her (wife) more definitely to conclude.
``Besides, it's all, at the worst, great fun.'' (unknown)

``Oh, if you simply put it at THAT--!'' (unknown)

His (Assingham) implication was that in this case they had a common ground; yet even thus he (Assingham) couldn't catch her (wife) by it.

``Oh, I don't mean,'' (she)
she (wife) said from the threshold,
``the fun that you mean. Good-night.'' (she)
In answer to which, as he (Assingham) turned out the electric light, he (Assingham) gave an odd, short groan, almost a grunt. He (Assingham) HAD apparently meant some particular kind.

V

``Well, now I must tell you, for I want to be absolutely honest.'' (Charlotte)
So Charlotte spoke, a little ominously, after they had got into the Park.
``I don't want to pretend, and I can't pretend a moment longer. You may think of me what you will, but I don't care. I knew I shouldn't and I find now how little. I came back for this. Not really for anything else. For this,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) repeated as, under the influence of her (Charlotte) tone, the Prince had already come to a pause.

``For `this'?'' (He)
He (Prince) spoke as if the particular thing she (Charlotte) indicated were vague to him (Prince)--or were, rather, a quantity that couldn't, at the most, be much.

It would be as much, however, as she (Charlotte) should be able to make it.

``To have one hour alone with you.'' (unknown)
It had rained heavily in the night, and though the pavements were now dry, thanks to a cleansing breeze, the August morning, with its hovering, thick-drifting clouds and freshened air, was cool and grey. The multitudinous green of the Park had been deepened, and a wholesome smell of irrigation, purging the place of dust and of odours less acceptable, rose from the earth. Charlotte had looked about her (Charlotte), with expression, from the first of their coming in, quite as if for a deep greeting, for general recognition: the day was, even in the heart of London, of a rich, low-browed, weatherwashed English type. It was as if it had been waiting for her (Charlotte), as if she (Charlotte) knew it, placed it, loved it, as if it were in fact a part of what she (Charlotte) had come back for. So far as this was the case the impression of course could only be lost on a mere vague Italian; it was one of those for which you had to be, blessedly, an American--as indeed you had to be, blessedly, an American for all sorts of things: so long as you hadn't, blessedly or not, to remain in America. The Prince had, by half-past ten--as also by definite appointment--called in Cadogan Place for Mrs. Assingham's visitor, and then, after brief delay, the two had walked together up Sloane Street and got straight into the Park from Knightsbridge. The understanding to this end had taken its place, after a couple of days, as inevitably consequent on the appeal made by the girl during those first moments in Mrs. Assingham's drawing-room. It was an appeal the couple of days had done nothing to invalidate--everything, much rather, to place in a light, and as to which, obviously, it wouldn't have fitted that anyone should raise an objection. Who was there, for that matter, to raise one, from the moment Mrs. Assingham, informed and apparently not disapproving, didn't intervene? This the young man had asked himself--with a very sufficient sense of what would have made him (man) ridiculous. He (man) wasn't going to begin--that at least was certain--by showing a fear. Even had fear at first been sharp in him (man), moreover, it would already, not a little, have dropped; so happy, all round, so propitious, he (man) quite might have called it, had been the effect of this rapid interval.

The time had been taken up largely by his (man) active reception of his (man) own wedding-guests and by Maggie's scarce less absorbed entertainment of her (Maggie) friend, whom she (Maggie) had kept for hours together in Portland Place; whom she (Maggie) had not, as wouldn't have been convenient, invited altogether as yet to migrate, but who had been present, with other persons, his (man) contingent, at luncheon, at tea, at dinner, at perpetual repasts--he (man) had never in his (man) life, it struck him (man), had to reckon with so much eating--whenever he (man) had looked in. If he (man) had not again, till this hour, save for a minute, seen Charlotte alone, so, positively, all the while, he (man) had not seen even Maggie; and if, therefore, he (man) had not seen even Maggie, nothing was more natural than that he (man) shouldn't have seen Charlotte. The exceptional minute, a mere snatch, at the tail of the others, on the huge Portland Place staircase had sufficiently enabled the girl to remind him (man)--so ready she (girl) assumed him (man) to be--of what they were to do. Time pressed if they were to do it at all. Everyone had brought gifts; his (man) relations had brought wonders--how did they still have, where did they still find, such treasures? She (girl) only had brought nothing, and she (girl) was ashamed; yet even by the sight of the rest of the tribute she (girl) wouldn't be put off. She (girl) would do what she (girl) could, and he (man) was, unknown to Maggie, he (man) must remember, to give her (Maggie) his (man) aid. He (man) had prolonged the minute so far as to take time to hesitate, for a reason, and then to risk bringing his (man) reason out. The risk was because he (man) might hurt her (Maggie)--hurt her (Maggie) pride, if she (Maggie) had that particular sort. But she (Maggie) might as well be hurt one way as another; and, besides, that particular sort of pride was just what she (Maggie) hadn't. So his (man) slight resistance, while they lingered, had been just easy enough not to be impossible.

``I hate to encourage you--and for such a purpose, after all--to spend your money.'' (She)

She (Maggie) had stood a stair or two below him (man); where, while she (Maggie) looked up at him (man) beneath the high, domed light of the hall, she (Maggie) rubbed with her (Maggie) palm the polished mahogany of the balustrade, which was mounted on fine ironwork, eighteenth-century English.

``Because you think I must have so little? I've enough, at any rate--enough for us to take our hour. Enough,'' (she)
she (Maggie) had smiled,
``is as good as a feast! And then,'' (she)
she (Maggie) had said,
``it isn't of course a question of anything expensive, gorged with treasure as Maggie is; it isn't a question of competing or outshining. What, naturally, in the way of the priceless, hasn't she (Maggie) got?
