She (Maggie) had got up with these last words; she (Maggie) stood there before him (father) with that particular suggestion in her (Maggie) aspect to which even the long habit of their life together had not closed his (father) sense, kept sharp, year after year, by the collation of types and signs, the comparison of fine object with fine object, of one degree of finish, of one form of the exquisite with another--the appearance of some slight, slim draped

``antique'' (him)
of Vatican or Capitoline halls, late and refined, rare as a note and immortal as a link, set in motion by the miraculous infusion of a modern impulse and yet, for all the sudden freedom of folds and footsteps forsaken after centuries by their pedestal, keeping still the quality, the perfect felicity, of the statue; the blurred, absent eyes, the smoothed, elegant, nameless head, the impersonal flit of a creature lost in an alien age and passing as an image in worn relief round and round a precious vase. She (creature) had always had odd moments of striking him (their), daughter of his (their) very own though she (creature) was, as a figure thus simplified,
``generalised'' (she)
in its grace, a figure with which his (their) human connection was fairly interrupted by some vague analogy of turn and attitude, something shyly mythological and nymphlike. The trick, he (their) was not uncomplacently aware, was mainly of his (their) own mind; it came from his (their) caring for precious vases only less than for precious daughters. And what was more to the point still, it often operated while he (their) was quite at the same time conscious that Maggie had been described, even in her (Maggie) prettiness, as
``prim'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
--Mrs. Rance herself had enthusiastically used the word of her (Rance); while he (their) remembered that when once she (Rance) had been told before him (their), familiarly, that she (Rance) resembled a nun, she (Rance) had replied that she (Rance) was delighted to hear it and would certainly try to; while also, finally, it was present to him (their) that, discreetly heedless, thanks to her (Rance) long association with nobleness in art, to the leaps and bounds of fashion, she (Rance) brought her (Rance) hair down very straight and flat over her (Rance) temples, in the constant manner of her (Rance) mother, who had not been a bit mythological. Nymphs and nuns were certainly separate types, but Mr. Verver, when he (Verver) really amused himself, let consistency go. The play of vision was at all events so rooted in him (Verver) that he (Verver) could receive impressions of sense even while positively thinking. He (Verver) was positively thinking while Maggie stood there, and it led for him (Verver) to yet another question--which in its turn led to others still.
``Do you regard the condition as hers then that you spoke of a minute ago?'' (unknown)

``The condition--?'' (unknown)

``Why that of having loved so intensely that she (them)'s, as you say, `beyond everything'?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie had scarcely to reflect--her (Maggie) answer was so prompt.

``Oh no. She (them)'s beyond nothing. For she (them) has had nothing.'' (unknown)

``I see. You must have had things to be them. It's a kind of law of perspective.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie didn't know about the law, but she (Maggie) continued definite.

``She (them)'s not, for example, beyond help.'' (unknown)

``Oh well then, she (them) shall have all we can give her (them). I'll write to her (them),'' (he)
he (Verver) said,
``with pleasure.'' (he)

``Angel!'' (she)
she (Maggie) answered as she (Maggie) gaily and tenderly looked at him (Verver).

True as this might be, however, there was one thing more--he (Verver) was an angel with a human curiosity.

``Has she (them) told you she (them) likes me much?'' (unknown)

``Certainly she (them) has told me--but I won't pamper you. Let it be enough for you it has always been one of my reasons for liking HER.'' (unknown)

``Then she (them)'s indeed not beyond everything,'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver more or less humorously observed.

``Oh it isn't, thank goodness, that she (them)'s in love with you. It's not, as I told you at first, the sort of thing for you to fear.'' (He)

He (Verver) had spoken with cheer, but it appeared to drop before this reassurance, as if the latter overdid his (Verver) alarm, and that should be corrected.

``Oh, my dear, I've always thought of her (them) as a little girl.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (them)'s not a little girl,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

``Then I'll write to her (them) as a brilliant woman.'' (unknown)

``It's exactly what she (them) is.'' (Mr. Verver)

Mr. Verver had got up as he (Verver) spoke, and for a little, before retracing their steps, they stood looking at each other as if they had really arranged something. They had come out together for themselves, but it had produced something more. What it had produced was in fact expressed by the words with which he (Verver) met his (Verver) companion's last emphasis.

``Well, she (them) has a famous friend in you, Princess.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie took this in--it was too plain for a protest.

``Do you know what I'm really thinking of?'' (she)
she (Maggie) asked.

He (Verver) wondered, with her (Maggie) eyes on him (Verver)--eyes of contentment at her (Maggie) freedom now to talk; and he (Verver) wasn't such a fool, he (Verver) presently showed, as not, suddenly, to arrive at it.

``Why, of your finding her (Princess) at last yourself a husband.'' (unknown)

``Good for YOU!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie smiled.
``But it will take,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added,
``some looking.'' (she)

``Then let me look right here with you,'' (father)
her (Maggie) father said as they walked on.

XI

Mrs. Assingham and the Colonel, quitting Fawns before the end of September, had come back later on; and now, a couple of weeks after, they were again interrupting their stay, but this time with the question of their return left to depend, on matters that were rather hinted at than importunately named. The Lutches and Mrs. Rance had also, by the action of Charlotte Stant's arrival, ceased to linger, though with hopes and theories, as to some promptitude of renewal, of which the lively expression, awakening the echoes of the great stone-paved, oak-panelled, galleried hall that was not the least interesting feature of the place, seemed still a property of the air. It was on this admirable spot that, before her (Stant) October afternoon had waned, Fanny Assingham spent with her (Assingham) easy host a few moments which led to her (Assingham) announcing her (Assingham) own and her (Assingham) husband's final secession, at the same time as they tempted her (Assingham) to point the moral of all vain reverberations. The double door of the house stood open to an effect of hazy autumn sunshine, a wonderful, windless, waiting, golden hour, under the influence of which Adam Verver met his (Verver) genial friend as she (Assingham) came to drop into the post-box with her (Assingham) own hand a thick sheaf of letters. They presently thereafter left the house together and drew out half-an-hour on the terrace in a manner they were to revert to in thought, later on, as that of persons who really had been taking leave of each other at a parting of the ways. He (Verver) traced his (Verver) impression, on coming to consider, back to a mere three words she (Assingham) had begun by using about Charlotte Stant. She (Stant) simply

``cleared them out'' (She)
--those had been the three words, thrown off in reference to the general golden peace that the Kentish October had gradually ushered in, the
``halcyon'' (She)
days the full beauty of which had appeared to shine out for them after Charlotte's arrival. For it was during these days that Mrs. Rance and the Miss Lutches had been observed to be gathering themselves for departure, and it was with that difference made that the sense of the whole situation showed most fair--the sense of how right they had been to engage for so ample a residence, and of all the pleasure so fruity an autumn there could hold in its lap. This was what had occurred, that their lesson had been learned; and what Mrs. Assingham had dwelt upon was that without Charlotte it would have been learned but half. It would certainly not have been taught by Mrs. Rance and the Miss Lutches if these ladies had remained with them as long as at one time seemed probable. Charlotte's light intervention had thus become a cause, operating covertly but none the less actively, and Fanny Assingham's speech, which she (Assingham) had followed up a little, echoed within him (their), fairly to startle him (their), as the indication of something irresistible. He (their) could see now how this superior force had worked, and he (their) fairly liked to recover the sight--little harm as he (their) dreamed of doing, little ill as he (their) dreamed of wishing, the three ladies, whom he (their) had after all entertained for a stiffish series of days. She (Assingham) had been so vague and quiet about it, wonderful Charlotte, that he (their) hadn't known what was happening--happening, that is, as a result of her (Charlotte) influence.
``Their fires, as they felt her (Princess), turned to smoke,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham remarked; which he (their) was to reflect on indeed even while they strolled. He (their) had retained, since his (their) long talk with Maggie--the talk that had settled the matter of his (their) own direct invitation to her (Maggie) friend--an odd little taste, as he (their) would have described it, for hearing things said about this young woman, hearing, so to speak, what COULD be said about her (woman): almost as it her (woman) portrait, by some eminent hand, were going on, so that he (their) watched it grow under the multiplication of touches. Mrs. Assingham, it struck him (their), applied two or three of the finest in their discussion of their young friend--so different a figure now from that early playmate of Maggie's as to whom he (friend) could almost recall from of old the definite occasions of his (friend) having paternally lumped the two children together in the recommendation that they shouldn't make too much noise nor eat too much jam. His (friend) companion professed that in the light of Charlotte's prompt influence she (Charlotte) had not been a stranger to a pang of pity for their recent visitors.
``I felt in fact, privately, so sorry for them, that I kept my impression to myself while they were here--wishing not to put the rest of you on the scent; neither Maggie, nor the Prince, nor yourself, nor even Charlotte HERself, if you didn't happen to notice. Since you didn't, apparently, I perhaps now strike you as extravagant. But I'm not--I followed it all. One SAW the consciousness I speak of come over the poor things, very much as I suppose people at the court of the Borgias may have watched each other begin to look queer after having had the honour of taking wine with the heads of the family. My comparison's only a little awkward, for I don't in the least mean that Charlotte was consciously dropping poison into their cup. She (Charlotte) was just herself their poison, in the sense of mortally disagreeing with them--but she (Charlotte) didn't know it.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (Charlotte) didn't know it?'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver had asked with interest.

``Well, I THINK she (Charlotte) didn't'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--Mrs. Assingham had to admit that she (Assingham) hadn't pressingly sounded her (Assingham).
``I don't pretend to be sure, in every connection, of what Charlotte knows. She (Charlotte) doesn't, certainly, like to make people suffer--not, in general, as is the case with so many of us, even other women: she (Charlotte) likes much rather to put them at their ease with her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) likes, that is--as all pleasant people do--to be liked.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (Charlotte) likes to be liked?'' (companion)
her (Assingham) companion had gone on.

``She (Charlotte) did, at the same time, no doubt, want to help us--to put us at our ease. That is she (Charlotte) wanted to put you--and to put Maggie about you. So far as that went she (Maggie) had a plan. But it was only AFTER--it was not before, I really believe--that she (Maggie) saw how effectively she (Maggie) could work.'' (Mr. Verver)

Again, as Mr. Verver felt, he (Verver) must have taken it up.

``Ah, she (Maggie) wanted to help us?--wanted to help ME?'' (unknown)

``Why,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham asked after an instant,
``should it surprise you?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

He (Verver) just thought.

``Oh, it doesn't!'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie) saw, of course, as soon as she (Maggie) came, with her (Maggie) quickness, where we all were. She (Maggie) didn't need each of us to go, by appointment, to her (Maggie) room at night, or take her (Maggie) out into the fields, for our palpitating tale. No doubt even she (Maggie) was rather impatient.'' (unknown)

``OF the poor things?'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver had here inquired while he (Verver) waited.

``Well, of your not yourselves being so--and of YOUR not in particular. I haven't the least doubt in the world, par exemple, that she (Maggie) thinks you too meek.'' (unknown)

``Oh, she (Maggie) thinks me too meek?'' (unknown)

``And she (Maggie) had been sent for, on the very face of it, to work right in. All she (Maggie) had to do, after all, was to be nice to you.'' (unknown)

``To--a--ME?'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver.

He (Verver) could remember now that his (Verver) friend had positively had a laugh for his (Verver) tone.

``To you and to every one. She (Maggie) had only to be what she (Maggie) is--and to be it all round. If she (Maggie)'s charming, how can she (Maggie) help it? So it was, and so only, that she (Maggie) `acted'-as the Borgia wine used to act. One saw it come over them--the extent to which, in her (Maggie) particular way, a woman, a woman other, and SO other, than themselves, COULD be charming. One saw them understand and exchange looks, then one saw them lose heart and decide to move. For what they had to take home was that it's she (Maggie) who's the real thing.'' (unknown)

``Ah, it's she (Maggie) who's the real thing?'' (HE)
As HE (Verver) had not hitherto taken it home as completely as the Miss Lutches and Mrs. Rance, so, doubtless, he (Verver) had now, a little, appeared to offer submission in his (Verver) appeal.
``I see, I see'' (he)
--he (Verver) could at least simply take it home now; yet as not without wanting, at the same time, to be sure of what the real thing was.
``And what would it be--a--definitely that you understand by that?'' (She)

She (Rance) had only for an instant not found it easy to say.

``Why, exactly what those women themselves want to be, and what her (Maggie) effect on them is to make them recognise that they never will.'' (unknown)

``Oh--of course never?'' (unknown)

It not only remained and abode with them, it positively developed and deepened, after this talk, that the luxurious side of his (Verver) personal existence was now again furnished, socially speaking, with the thing classed and stamped as

``real'' (he)
--just as he (Verver) had been able to think of it as not otherwise enriched in consequence of his (Verver) daughter's marriage. The note of reality, in so much projected light, continued to have for him (Verver) the charm and the importance of which the maximum had occasionally been reached in his (Verver) great
``finds'' (him)
--continued, beyond any other, to keep him (Verver) attentive and gratified. Nothing perhaps might affect us as queerer, had we time to look into it, than this application of the same measure of value to such different pieces of property as old Persian carpets, say, and new human acquisitions; all the more indeed that the amiable man was not without an inkling, on his (man) own side, that he (man) was, as a taster of life, economically constructed. He (man) put into his (man) one little glass everything he (man) raised to his (man) lips, and it was as if he (man) had always carried in his (man) pocket, like a tool of his (man) trade, this receptacle, a little glass cut with a fineness of which the art had long since been lost, and kept in an old morocco case stamped in uneffaceable gilt with the arms of a deposed dynasty. As it had served him (man) to satisfy himself, so to speak, both about Amerigo and about the Bernadino Luini he (man) had happened to come to knowledge of at the time he (man) was consenting to the announcement of his (man) daughter's betrothal, so it served him (man) at present to satisfy himself about Charlotte Stant and an extraordinary set of oriental tiles of which he (man) had lately got wind, to which a provoking legend was attached, and as to which he (man) had made out, contentedly, that further news was to be obtained from a certain Mr. Gutermann-Seuss of Brighton. It was all, at bottom, in him (Gutermann-Seuss), the aesthetic principle, planted where it could burn with a cold, still flame; where it fed almost wholly on the material directly involved, on the idea -LRB-followed by appropriation-RRB- of plastic beauty, of the thing visibly perfect in its kind; where, in short, in spite of the general tendency of the
``devouring element'' (him)
to spread, the rest of his (Gutermann-Seuss) spiritual furniture, modest, scattered, and tended with unconscious care, escaped the consumption that in so many cases proceeds from the undue keeping-up of profane altar-fires. Adam Verver had in other words learnt the lesson of the senses, to the end of his (Verver) own little book, without having, for a day, raised the smallest scandal in his (Verver) economy at large; being in this particular not unlike those fortunate bachelors, or other gentlemen of pleasure, who so manage their entertainment of compromising company that even the austerest housekeeper, occupied and competent below-stairs, never feels obliged to give warning.

That figure has, however, a freedom that the occasion doubtless scarce demands, though we may retain it for its rough negative value. It was to come to pass, by a pressure applied to the situation wholly from within, that before the first ten days of November had elapsed he (Verver) found himself practically alone at Fawns with his (Verver) young friend; Amerigo and Maggie having, with a certain abruptness, invited his (Verver) assent to their going abroad for a month, since his (Verver) amusement was now scarce less happily assured than his (Verver) security. An impulse eminently natural had stirred within the Prince; his (Prince) life, as for some time established, was deliciously dull, and thereby, on the whole, what he (Prince) best liked; but a small gust of yearning had swept over him (Prince), and Maggie repeated to her (Maggie) father, with infinite admiration, the pretty terms in which, after it had lasted a little, he (father) had described to her (Maggie) this experience. He (father) called it a

``serenade,'' (He)
a low music that, outside one of the windows of the sleeping house, disturbed his (father) rest at night. Timid as it was, and plaintive, he (father) yet couldn't close his (father) eyes for it, and when finally, rising on tiptoe, he (father) had looked out, he (father) had recognised in the figure below with a mandolin, all duskily draped in her (Maggie) grace, the raised appealing eyes and the one irresistible voice of the ever-to-be-loved Italy. Sooner or later, that way, one had to listen; it was a hovering, haunting ghost, as of a creature to whom one had done a wrong, a dim, pathetic shade crying out to be comforted. For this there was obviously but one way--as there were doubtless also many words for the simple fact that so prime a Roman had a fancy for again seeing Rome. They would accordingly--hadn't they better?--go for a little; Maggie meanwhile making the too-absurdly artful point with her (Maggie) father, so that he (father) repeated it, in his (father) amusement, to Charlotte Stant, to whom he (father) was by this time conscious of addressing many remarks, that it was absolutely, when she (Stant) came to think, the first thing Amerigo had ever asked of her (Stant).
``She (Maggie) doesn't count of course his (Maggie) having asked of her (Maggie) to marry him (Maggie)'' (Mr. Verver)
-- this was Mr. Verver's indulgent criticism; but he (Verver) found Charlotte, equally touched by the ingenuous Maggie, in easy agreement with him (Verver) over the question. If the Prince had asked something of his (Prince) wife every day in the year, this would be still no reason why the poor dear man should not, in a beautiful fit of homesickness, revisit, without reproach, his (man) native country.

What his (man) father-in-law frankly counselled was that the reasonable, the really too reasonable, pair should, while they were about it, take three or four weeks of Paris as well--Paris being always, for Mr. Verver, in any stress of sympathy, a suggestion that rose of itself to the lips. If they would only do that, on their way back, or however they preferred it, Charlotte and he (Verver) would go over to join them there for a small look--though even then, assuredly, as he (Verver) had it at heart to add, not in the least because they should have found themselves bored at being left together. The fate of this last proposal indeed was that it reeled, for the moment, under an assault of destructive analysis from Maggie, who--having, as she (Maggie) granted, to choose between being an unnatural daughter or an unnatural mother, and

``electing'' (an mother)
for the former--wanted to know what would become of the Principino if the house were cleared of everyone but the servants. Her (mother) question had fairly resounded, but it had afterwards, like many of her (mother) questions, dropped still more effectively than it had risen: the highest moral of the matter being, before the couple took their departure, that Mrs. Noble and Dr. Brady must mount unchallenged guard over the august little crib. If she (Noble) hadn't supremely believed in the majestic value of the nurse, whose experience was in itself the amplest of pillows, just as her (Noble) attention was a spreading canopy from which precedent and reminiscence dropped as thickly as parted curtains--if she (Noble) hadn't been able to rest in this confidence she (Noble) would fairly have sent her (Noble) husband on his (husband) journey without her (Noble). In the same manner, if the sweetest--for it was so she (Noble) qualified him (husband)--of little country doctors hadn't proved to her (Noble) his (husband) wisdom by rendering irresistible, especially on rainy days and in direct proportion to the frequency of his (husband) calls, adapted to all weathers, that she (Noble) should converse with him (husband) for hours over causes and consequences, over what he (husband) had found to answer with his (husband) little five at home, she (Noble) would have drawn scant support from the presence of a mere grandfather and a mere brilliant friend. These persons, accordingly, her (Noble) own predominance having thus, for the time, given way, could carry with a certain ease, and above all with mutual aid, their consciousness of a charge. So far as their office weighed they could help each other with it--which was in fact to become, as Mrs. Noble herself loomed larger for them, not a little of a relief and a diversion.

Mr. Verver met his (Verver) young friend, at certain hours, in the day-nursery, very much as he (Verver) had regularly met the child's fond mother--Charlotte having, as she (Charlotte) clearly considered, given Maggie equal pledges and desiring never to fail of the last word for the daily letter she (Maggie) had promised to write. She (Maggie) wrote with high fidelity, she (Maggie) let her (Maggie) companion know, and the effect of it was, remarkably enough, that he (companion) himself didn't write. The reason of this was partly that Charlotte

``told all about him (Maggie)'' (Charlotte)
--which she (Charlotte) also let him (companion) know she (Charlotte) did--and partly that he (companion) enjoyed feeling, as a consequence, that he (companion) was generally, quite systematically, eased and, as they said,
``done'' (he)
for. Committed, as it were, to this charming and clever young woman, who, by becoming for him (companion) a domestic resource, had become for him (companion) practically a new person--and committed, especially, in his (companion) own house, which somehow made his (companion) sense of it a deeper thing--he (companion) took an interest in seeing how far the connection could carry him (companion), could perhaps even lead him (companion), and in thus putting to the test, for pleasant verification, what Fanny Assingham had said, at the last, about the difference such a girl could make. She (girl) was really making one now, in their simplified existence, and a very considerable one, though there was no one to compare her (girl) with, as there had been, so usefully, for Fanny--no Mrs. Rance, no Kitty, no Dotty Lutch, to help her (Dotty) to be felt, according to Fanny's diagnosis, as real. She (Fanny) was real, decidedly, from other causes, and Mr. Verver grew in time even a little amused at the amount of machinery Mrs. Assingham had seemed to see needed for pointing it. She (Assingham) was directly and immediately real, real on a pleasantly reduced and intimate scale, and at no moments more so than during those--at which we have just glanced--when Mrs. Noble made them both together feel that she (Noble), she (Noble) alone, in the absence of the queen-mother, was regent of the realm and governess of the heir. Treated on such occasions as at best a pair of dangling and merely nominal court-functionaries, picturesque hereditary triflers entitled to the petites entrees but quite external to the State, which began and ended with the Nursery, they could only retire, in quickened sociability, to what was left them of the Palace, there to digest their gilded insignificance and cultivate, in regard to the true Executive, such snuff-taking ironies as might belong to rococo chamberlains moving among china lap-dogs.

Every evening, after dinner, Charlotte Stant played to him (heir); seated at the piano and requiring no music, she (Stant) went through his (heir)

``favourite things'' (she)
--and he (heir) had many favourites--with a facility that never failed, or that failed but just enough to pick itself up at a touch from his (heir) fitful voice. She (Stant) could play anything, she (Stant) could play everything--always shockingly, she (Stant) of course insisted, but always, by his (heir) own vague measure, very much as if she (Stant) might, slim, sinuous and strong, and with practised passion, have been playing lawn-tennis or endlessly and rhythmically waltzing. His (heir) love of music, unlike his (heir) other loves, owned to vaguenesses, but while, on his (heir) comparatively shaded sofa, and smoking, smoking, always smoking, in the great Fawns drawing-room as everywhere, the cigars of his (heir) youth, rank with associations--while, I say, he (heir) so listened to Charlotte's piano, where the score was ever absent but, between the lighted candles, the picture distinct, the vagueness spread itself about him (heir) like some boundless carpet, a surface delightfully soft to the pressure of his (heir) interest. It was a manner of passing the time that rather replaced conversation, but the air, at the end, none the less, before they separated, had a way of seeming full of the echoes of talk. They separated, in the hushed house, not quite easily, yet not quite awkwardly either, with tapers that twinkled in the large dark spaces, and for the most part so late that the last solemn servant had been dismissed for the night.

Late as it was on a particular evening toward the end of October, there had been a full word or two dropped into the still-stirring sea of other voices--a word or two that affected our friend even at the moment, and rather oddly, as louder and rounder than any previous sound; and then he (friend) had lingered, under pretext of an opened window to be made secure, after taking leave of his (friend) companion in the hall and watching her (companion) glimmer away up the staircase. He (friend) had for himself another impulse than to go to bed; picking up a hat in the hall, slipping his (friend) arms into a sleeveless cape and lighting still another cigar, he (friend) turned out upon the terrace through one of the long drawing-room windows and moved to and fro there for an hour beneath the sharp autumn stars. It was where he (friend) had walked in the afternoon sun with Fanny Assingham, and the sense of that other hour, the sense of the suggestive woman herself, was before him (friend) again as, in spite of all the previous degustation we have hinted at, it had not yet been. He (friend) thought, in a loose, an almost agitated order, of many things; the power that was in them to agitate having been part of his (friend) conviction that he (friend) should not soon sleep. He (friend) truly felt for a while that he (friend) should never sleep again till something had come to him (friend); some light, some idea, some mere happy word perhaps, that he (friend) had begun to want, but had been till now, and especially the last day or two, vainly groping for.

``Can you really then come if we start early?'' (he)
--that was practically all he (friend) had said to the girl as she (girl) took up her (girl) bedroom light. And
``Why in the world not, when I've nothing else to do, and should, besides, so immensely like it?'' (unknown)
--this had as definitely been, on her (girl) side, the limit of the little scene. There had in fact been nothing to call a scene, even of the littlest, at all--though he (friend) perhaps didn't quite know why something like the menace of one hadn't proceeded from her (girl) stopping half-way upstairs to turn and say, as she (girl) looked down on him (friend), that she (girl) promised to content herself, for their journey, with a toothbrush and a sponge. There hovered about him (friend), at all events, while he (friend) walked, appearances already familiar, as well as two or three that were new, and not the least vivid of the former connected itself with that sense of being treated with consideration which had become for him (friend), as we have noted, one of the minor yet so far as there were any such, quite one of the compensatory, incidents of being a father-in-law. It had struck him (father-in-law), up to now, that this particular balm was a mixture of which Amerigo, as through some hereditary privilege, alone possessed the secret; so that he (father-in-law) found himself wondering if it had come to Charlotte, who had unmistakably acquired it, through the young man's having amiably passed it on. She (Charlotte) made use, for her (Charlotte) so quietly grateful host, however this might be, of quite the same shades of attention and recognition, was mistress in an equal degree of the regulated, the developed art of placing him (man) high in the scale of importance. That was even for his (man) own thought a clumsy way of expressing the element of similarity in the agreeable effect they each produced on him (man), and it held him (man) for a little only because this coincidence in their felicity caused him (man) vaguely to connect or associate them in the matter of tradition, training, tact, or whatever else one might call it. It might almost have been--if such a link between them was to be imagined--that Amerigo had, a little,
``coached'' (Amerigo)
or incited their young friend, or perhaps rather that she (it) had simply, as one of the signs of the general perfection Fanny Assingham commended in her (Assingham), profited by observing, during her (Assingham) short opportunity before the start of the travellers, the pleasant application by the Prince of his (Prince) personal system. He (Prince) might wonder what exactly it was that they so resembled each other in treating him (Prince) like--from what noble and propagated convention, in cases in which the exquisite
``importance'' (him)
was to be neither too grossly attributed nor too grossly denied, they had taken their specific lesson; but the difficulty was here of course that one could really never know--couldn't know without having been one's self a personage; whether a Pope, a King, a President, a Peer, a General, or just a beautiful Author.

Before such a question, as before several others when they recurred, he (General) would come to a pause, leaning his (General) arms on the old parapet and losing himself in a far excursion. He (General) had as to so many of the matters in hand a divided view, and this was exactly what made him (General) reach out, in his (General) unrest, for some idea, lurking in the vast freshness of the night, at the breath of which disparities would submit to fusion, and so, spreading beneath him (General), make him (General) feel that he (General) floated. What he (General) kept finding himself return to, disturbingly enough, was the reflection, deeper than anything else, that in forming a new and intimate tie he (General) should in a manner abandon, or at the best signally relegate, his (General) daughter. He (General) should reduce to definite form the idea that he (General) had lost her (daughter)--as was indeed inevitable--by her (daughter) own marriage; he (General) should reduce to definite form the idea of his (General) having incurred an injury, or at the best an inconvenience, that required some makeweight and deserved some amends. And he (General) should do this the more, which was the great point, that he (General) should appear to adopt, in doing it, the sentiment, in fact the very conviction, entertained, and quite sufficiently expressed, by Maggie herself, in her (Maggie) beautiful generosity, as to what he (General) had suffered--putting it with extravagance--at her (Maggie) hands. If she (Maggie) put it with extravagance the extravagance was yet sincere, for it came--which she (Maggie) put with extravagance too--from her (Maggie) persistence, always, in thinking, feeling, talking about him (General), as young. He (General) had had glimpses of moments when to hear her (Maggie) thus, in her (Maggie) absolutely unforced compunction, one would have supposed the special edge of the wrong she (Maggie) had done him (General) to consist in his (General) having still before him (General) years and years to groan under it. She (Maggie) had sacrificed a parent, the pearl of parents, no older than herself: it wouldn't so much have mattered if he (General) had been of common parental age. That he (General) wasn't, that he (General) was just her (Maggie) extraordinary equal and contemporary, this was what added to her (Maggie) act the long train of its effect. Light broke for him (General) at last, indeed, quite as a consequence of the fear of breathing a chill upon this luxuriance of her (Maggie) spiritual garden. As at a turn of his (General) labyrinth he (General) saw his (General) issue, which opened out so wide, for the minute, that he (General) held his (General) breath with wonder. He (General) was afterwards to recall how, just then, the autumn night seemed to clear to a view in which the whole place, everything round him (General), the wide terrace where he (General) stood, the others, with their steps, below, the gardens, the park, the lake, the circling woods, lay there as under some strange midnight sun. It all met him (General) during these instants as a vast expanse of discovery, a world that looked, so lighted, extraordinarily new, and in which familiar objects had taken on a distinctness that, as if it had been a loud, a spoken pretension to beauty, interest, importance, to he (General) scarce knew what, gave them an inordinate quantity of character and, verily, an inordinate size. This hallucination, or whatever he (General) might have called it, was brief, but it lasted long enough to leave him (General) gasping. The gasp of admiration had by this time, however, lost itself in an intensity that quickly followed--the way the wonder of it, since wonder was in question, truly had been the strange DELAY of his (General) vision. He (General) had these several days groped and groped for an object that lay at his (General) feet and as to which his (General) blindness came from his (General) stupidly looking beyond. It had sat all the while at his (General) hearth-stone, whence it now gazed up in his (General) face.

Once he (General) had recognised it there everything became coherent. The sharp point to which all his (General) light converged was that the whole call of his (General) future to him (General), as a father, would be in his (General) so managing that Maggie would less and less appear to herself to have forsaken him (General). And it not only wouldn't be decently humane, decently possible, not to make this relief easy to her (Maggie)--the idea shone upon him (General), more than that, as exciting, inspiring, uplifting. It fell in so beautifully with what might be otherwise possible; it stood there absolutely confronted with the material way in which it might be met. The way in which it might be met was by his (General) putting his (General) child at peace, and the way to put her (Maggie) at peace was to provide for his (General) future--that is for hers--by marriage, by a marriage as good, speaking proportionately, as hers had been. As he (General) fairly inhaled this measure of refreshment he (General) tasted the meaning of recent agitations. He (General) had seen that Charlotte could contribute--what he (General) hadn't seen was what she (Charlotte) could contribute TO. When it had all supremely cleared up and he (General) had simply settled this service to his (General) daughter well before him (General) as the proper direction of his (General) young friend's leisure, the cool darkness had again closed round him (General), but his (General) moral lucidity was constituted. It wasn't only moreover that the word, with a click, so fitted the riddle, but that the riddle, in such perfection, fitted the word. He (General) might have been equally in want and yet not have had his (General) remedy. Oh, if Charlotte didn't accept him (General), of course the remedy would fail; but, as everything had fallen together, it was at least there to be tried. And success would be great--that was his (General) last throb--if the measure of relief effected for Maggie should at all prove to have been given by his (General) own actual sense of felicity. He (General) really didn't know when in his (General) life he (General) had thought of anything happier. To think of it merely for himself would have been, even as he (General) had just lately felt, even doing all justice to that condition--yes, impossible. But there was a grand difference in thinking of it for his (General) child.

XII

It was at Brighton, above all, that this difference came out; it was during the three wonderful days he (General) spent there with Charlotte that he (General) had acquainted himself further--though doubtless not even now quite completely--with the merits of his (General) majestic scheme. And while, moreover, to begin with, he (General) still but held his (General) vision in place, steadying it fairly with his (General) hands, as he (General) had often steadied, for inspection, a precarious old pot or kept a glazed picture in its right relation to the light, the other, the outer presumptions in his (General) favour, those independent of what he (General) might himself contribute and that therefore, till he (General) should

``speak,'' (he)
remained necessarily vague--that quantity, I say, struck him (General) as positively multiplying, as putting on, in the fresh Brighton air and on the sunny Brighton front, a kind of tempting palpability. He (General) liked, in this preliminary stage, to feel that he (General) should be able to
``speak'' (he)
and that he (General) would; the word itself being romantic, pressing for him (General) the spring of association with stories and plays where handsome and ardent young men, in uniforms, tights, cloaks, high-boots, had it, in soliloquies, ever on their lips; and the sense on the first day that he (General) should probably have taken the great step before the second was over conduced already to make him (General) say to his (General) companion that they must spend more than their mere night or two. At his (General) ease on the ground of what was before him (General) he (General) at all events definitely desired to be, and it was strongly his (General) impression that he (General) was proceeding step by step. He (General) was acting--it kept coming back to that--not in the dark, but in the high golden morning; not in precipitation, flurry, fever, dangers these of the path of passion properly so called, but with the deliberation of a plan, a plan that might be a thing of less joy than a passion, but that probably would, in compensation for that loss, be found to have the essential property, to wear even the decent dignity, of reaching further and of providing for more contingencies. The season was, in local parlance,
``on,'' (Charlotte)
the elements were assembled; the big windy hotel, the draughty social hall, swarmed with
``types,'' (Charlotte)
in Charlotte's constant phrase, and resounded with a din in which the wild music of gilded and befrogged bands, Croatian, Dalmatian, Carpathian, violently exotic and nostalgic, was distinguished as struggling against the perpetual popping of corks. Much of this would decidedly have disconcerted our friends if it hadn't all happened, more preponderantly, to give them the brighter surprise. The noble privacy of Fawns had left them--had left Mr. Verver at least--with a little accumulated sum of tolerance to spend on the high pitch and high colour of the public sphere. Fawns, as it had been for him (Verver), and as Maggie and Fanny Assingham had both attested, was out of the world, whereas the scene actually about him (Verver), with the very sea a mere big booming medium for excursions and aquariums, affected him (Verver) as so plump in the conscious centre that nothing could have been more complete for representing that pulse of life which they had come to unanimity at home on the subject of their advisedly not hereafter forgetting. The pulse of life was what Charlotte, in her (Charlotte) way, at home, had lately reproduced, and there were positively current hours when it might have been open to her (Charlotte) companion to feel himself again indebted to her (Charlotte) for introductions. He (companion) had
``brought'' (He)
her (Charlotte), to put it crudely, but it was almost as if she (Charlotte) were herself, in her (Charlotte) greater gaiety, her (Charlotte) livelier curiosity and intensity, her (Charlotte) readier, happier irony, taking him (companion) about and showing him (companion) the place. No one, really, when he (companion) came to think, had ever taken him (companion) about before--it had always been he (companion), of old, who took others and who in particular took Maggie. This quickly fell into its relation with him (companion) as part of an experience--marking for him (companion), no doubt, what people call, considerately, a time of life; a new and pleasant order, a flattered passive state, that might become--why shouldn't it?-- one of the comforts of the future.

Mr. Gutermann-Seuss proved, on the second day--our friend had waited till then--a remarkably genial, a positively lustrous young man occupying a small neat house in a quarter of the place remote from the front and living, as immediate and striking signs testified, in the bosom of his (man) family. Our visitors found themselves introduced, by the operation of close contiguity, to a numerous group of ladies and gentlemen older and younger, and of children larger and smaller, who mostly affected them as scarce less anointed for hospitality and who produced at first the impression of a birthday party, of some anniversary gregariously and religiously kept, though they subsequently fell into their places as members of one quiet domestic circle, preponderantly and directly indebted for their being, in fact, to Mr. Gutermann-Seuss. To the casual eye a mere smart and shining youth of less than thirty summers, faultlessly appointed in every particular, he (Gutermann-Seuss) yet stood among his (Gutermann-Seuss) progeny--eleven in all, as he (Gutermann-Seuss) confessed without a sigh, eleven little brown clear faces, yet with such impersonal old eyes astride of such impersonal old noses--while he (Gutermann-Seuss) entertained the great American collector whom he (Gutermann-Seuss) had so long hoped he (Gutermann-Seuss) might meet, and whose charming companion, the handsome, frank, familiar young lady, presumably Mrs. Verver, noticed the graduated offspring, noticed the fat, ear-ringed aunts and the glossy, cockneyfied, familiar uncles, inimitable of accent and assumption, and of an attitude of cruder intention than that of the head of the firm; noticed the place in short, noticed the treasure produced, noticed everything, as from the habit of a person finding her (Verver) account at any time, according to a wisdom well learned of life, in almost any

``funny'' (a person)
impression. It really came home to her (Verver) friend on the spot that this free range of observation in her (Verver), picking out the frequent funny with extraordinary promptness, would verily henceforth make a different thing for him (friend) of such experiences, of the customary hunt for the possible prize, the inquisitive play of his (friend) accepted monomania; which different thing could probably be a lighter and perhaps thereby a somewhat more boisterously refreshing form of sport. Such omens struck him (friend) as vivid, in any case, when Mr. Gutermann-Seuss, with a sharpness of discrimination he (Gutermann-Seuss) had at first scarce seemed to promise, invited his (Gutermann-Seuss) eminent couple into another room, before the threshold of which the rest of the tribe, unanimously faltering, dropped out of the scene. The treasure itself here, the objects on behalf of which Mr. Verver's interest had been booked, established quickly enough their claim to engage the latter's attention; yet at what point of his (Verver) past did our friend's memory, looking back and back, catch him (Verver), in any such place, thinking so much less of wares artfully paraded than of some other and quite irrelevant presence? Such places were not strange to him (Verver) when they took the form of bourgeois back-parlours, a trifle ominously grey and grim from their north light, at watering-places prevailingly homes of humbug, or even when they wore some aspect still less, if not perhaps still more, insidious. He (Verver) had been everywhere, pried and prowled everywhere, going, on occasion, so far as to risk, he (Verver) believed, life, health and the very bloom of honour; but where, while precious things, extracted one by one from thrice-locked yet often vulgar drawers and soft satchels of old oriental ilk, were impressively ranged before him (Verver), had he (Verver), till now, let himself, in consciousness, wander like one of the vague?

He (Verver) didn't betray it--ah THAT he (Verver) knew; but two recognitions took place for him (Verver) at once, and one of them suffered a little in sweetness by the confusion. Mr. Gutermann-Seuss had truly, for the crisis, the putting down of his (Gutermann-Seuss) cards, a rare manner; he (Gutermann-Seuss) was perfect master of what not to say to such a personage as Mr. Verver while the particular importance that dispenses with chatter was diffused by his (Verver) movements themselves, his (Verver) repeated act of passage between a featureless mahogany meuble and a table so virtuously disinterested as to look fairly smug under a cotton cloth of faded maroon and indigo, all redolent of patriarchal teas. The Damascene tiles, successively, and oh so tenderly, unmuffled and revealed, lay there at last in their full harmony and their venerable splendour, but the tribute of appreciation and decision was, while the spectator considered, simplified to a point that but just failed of representing levity on the part of a man who had always acknowledged without shame, in such affairs, the intrinsic charm of what was called discussion. The infinitely ancient, the immemorial amethystine blue of the glaze, scarcely more meant to be breathed upon, it would seem, than the cheek of royalty--this property of the ordered and matched array had inevitably all its determination for him (man), but his (man) submission was, perhaps for the first time in his (man) life, of the quick mind alone, the process really itself, in its way, as fine as the perfection perceived and admired: every inch of the rest of him (man) being given to the foreknowledge that an hour or two later he (man) should have

``spoken.'' (he)
The burning of his (man) ships therefore waited too near to let him (man) handle his (man) opportunity with his (man) usual firm and sentient fingers--waited somehow in the predominance of Charlotte's very person, in her (Charlotte) being there exactly as she (Charlotte) was, capable, as Mr. Gutermann-Seuss himself was capable, of the right felicity of silence, but with an embracing ease, through it all, that made deferred criticism as fragrant as some joy promised a lover by his (lover) mistress, or as a big bridal bouquet held patiently behind her (mistress). He (lover) couldn't otherwise have explained, surely, why he (lover) found himself thinking, to his (lover) enjoyment, of so many other matters than the felicity of his (lover) acquisition and the figure of his (lover) cheque, quite equally high; any more than why, later on, with their return to the room in which they had been received and the renewed encompassment of the tribe, he (lover) felt quite merged in the elated circle formed by the girl's free response to the collective caress of all the shining eyes, and by her (girl) genial acceptance of the heavy cake and port wine that, as she (girl) was afterwards to note, added to their transaction, for a finish, the touch of some mystic rite of old Jewry.

This characterisation came from her (girl) as they walked away--walked together, in the waning afternoon, back to the breezy sea and the bustling front, back to the nimble and the flutter and the shining shops that sharpened the grin of solicitation on the mask of night. They were walking thus, as he (girl) felt, nearer and nearer to where he (girl) should see his (girl) ships burn, and it was meanwhile for him (girl) quite as if this red glow would impart, at the harmonious hour, a lurid grandeur to his (girl) good faith. It was meanwhile too a sign of the kind of sensibility often playing up in him (girl) that--fabulous as this truth may sound--he (girl) found a sentimental link, an obligation of delicacy, or perhaps even one of the penalties of its opposite, in his (girl) having exposed her (girl) to the north light, the quite properly hard business-light, of the room in which they had been alone with the treasure and its master. She (girl) had listened to the name of the sum he (master) was capable of looking in the face. Given the relation of intimacy with him (master) she (girl) had already, beyond all retractation, accepted, the stir of the air produced at the other place by that high figure struck him (master) as a thing that, from the moment she (girl) had exclaimed or protested as little as he (master) himself had apologised, left him (master) but one thing more to do. A man of decent feeling didn't thrust his (man) money, a huge lump of it, in such a way, under a poor girl's nose--a girl whose poverty was, after a fashion, the very basis of her (girl) enjoyment of his (man) hospitality--without seeing, logically, a responsibility attached. And this was to remain none the less true for the fact that twenty minutes later, after he (man) had applied his (man) torch, applied it with a sign or two of insistence, what might definitely result failed to be immediately clear. He (man) had spoken--spoken as they sat together on the out-of-the-way bench observed during one of their walks and kept for the previous quarter of the present hour well in his (man) memory's eye; the particular spot to which, between intense pauses and intenser advances, he (man) had all the while consistently led her (man). Below the great consolidated cliff, well on to where the city of stucco sat most architecturally perched, with the rumbling beach and the rising tide and the freshening stars in front and above, the safe sense of the whole place yet prevailed in lamps and seats and flagged walks, hovering also overhead in the close neighbourhood of a great replete community about to assist anew at the removal of dish-covers.

``We've had, as it seems to me, such quite beautiful days together, that I hope it won't come to you too much as a shock when I ask if you think you could regard me with any satisfaction as a husband.'' (he)
As if he (man) had known she (man) wouldn't, she (man) of course couldn't, at all gracefully, and whether or no, reply with a rush, he (man) had said a little more--quite as he (man) had felt he (man) must in thinking it out in advance. He (man) had put the question on which there was no going back and which represented thereby the sacrifice of his (man) vessels, and what he (man) further said was to stand for the redoubled thrust of flame that would make combustion sure.
``This isn't sudden to me, and I've wondered at moments if you haven't felt me coming to it. I've been coming ever since we left Fawns--I really started while we were there.'' (He)
He (man) spoke slowly, giving her (man), as he (man) desired, time to think; all the more that it was making her (man) look at him (man) steadily, and making her (man) also, in a remarkable degree, look
``well'' (him)
while she (man) did so--a large and, so far, a happy, consequence. She (man) wasn't at all events shocked--which he (man) had glanced at but for a handsome humility--and he (man) would give her (man) as many minutes as she (man) liked.
``You mustn't think I'm forgetting that I'm not young.'' (unknown)

``Oh, that isn't so. It's I that am old. You ARE young.'' (she)
This was what she (man) had at first answered--and quite in the tone too of having taken her (man) minutes. It had not been wholly to the point, but it had been kind--which was what he (man) most wanted. And she (man) kept, for her (man) next words, to kindness, kept to her (man) clear, lowered voice and unshrinking face.
``To me too it thoroughly seems that these days have been beautiful. I shouldn't be grateful to them if I couldn't more or less have imagined their bringing us to this.'' (She)
She (man) affected him (man) somehow as if she (man) had advanced a step to meet him (man) and yet were at the same time standing still. It only meant, however, doubtless, that she (man) was, gravely and reasonably, thinking--as he (man) exactly desired to make her (man). If she (man) would but think enough she (man) would probably think to suit him (man).
``It seems to me,'' (she)
she (man) went on,
``that it's for YOU to be sure.'' (she)

``Ah, but I AM sure,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver.
``On matters of importance I never speak when I'm not. So if you can yourself FACE such a union you needn't in the least trouble.'' (She)

She (man) had another pause, and she (man) might have been felt as facing it while, through lamplight and dusk, through the breath of the mild, slightly damp southwest, she (man) met his (Verver) eyes without evasion. Yet she (man) had at the end of another minute debated only to the extent of saying:

``I won't pretend I don't think it would be good for me to marry. Good for me, I mean,'' (she)
she (man) pursued,
``because I'm so awfully unattached. I should like to be a little less adrift. I should like to have a home. I should like to have an existence. I should like to have a motive for one thing more than another--a motive outside of myself. In fact,'' (she)
she (man) said, so sincerely that it almost showed pain, yet so lucidly that it almost showed humour,
``in fact, you know, I want to BE married. It's--well, it's the condition.'' (she)

``The condition--?'' (He)
He (Verver) was just vague.

``It's the state, I mean. I don't like my own. `Miss,' among us all, is too dreadful--except for a shopgirl. I don't want to be a horrible English old-maid.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you want to be taken care of. Very well then, I'll do it.'' (unknown)

``I dare say it's very much that. Only I don't see why, for what I speak of,'' (she)
she (man) smiled--
``for a mere escape from my state--I need do quite so MUCH.'' (she)

``So much as marry me in particular?'' (unknown)

Her (man) smile was as for true directness.

``I might get what I want for less.'' (unknown)

``You think it so much for you to do?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (man) presently said,
``I think it's a great deal.'' (she)

Then it was that, though she (man) was so gentle, so quite perfect with him (Verver), and he (Verver) felt he (Verver) had come on far--then it was that of a sudden something seemed to fail and he (Verver) didn't quite know where they were. There rose for him (Verver), with this, the fact, to be sure, of their disparity, deny it as mercifully and perversely as she (man) would. He (Verver) might have been her (man) father.

``Of course, yes--that's my disadvantage: I'm not the natural, I'm so far from being the ideal match to your youth and your beauty. I've the drawback that you've seen me always, so inevitably, in such another light.'' (she)

But she (man) gave a slow headshake that made contradiction soft--made it almost sad, in fact, as from having to be so complete; and he (Verver) had already, before she (man) spoke, the dim vision of some objection in her (man) mind beside which the one he (Verver) had named was light, and which therefore must be strangely deep.

``You don't understand me. It's of all that it is for YOU to do--it's of that I'm thinking.'' (him)

Oh, with this, for him (Verver), the thing was clearer!

``Then you needn't think. I know enough what it is for me to do.'' (she)

But she (man) shook her (man) head again.

``I doubt if you know. I doubt if you CAN.'' (unknown)

``And why not, please--when I've had you so before me? That I'm old has at least THAT fact about it to the good--that I've known you long and from far back.'' (unknown)

``Do you think you've `known' me?'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
asked Charlotte Stant. He (Verver) hesitated--for the tone of it, and her (man) look with it might have made him (Verver) doubt. Just these things in themselves, however, with all the rest, with his (Verver) fixed purpose now, his (Verver) committed deed, the fine pink glow, projected forward, of his (Verver) ships, behind him (Verver), definitely blazing and crackling--this quantity was to push him (Verver) harder than any word of her (man) own could warn him (Verver). All that she (man) was herself, moreover, was so lighted, to its advantage, by the pink glow. He (Verver) wasn't rabid, but he (Verver) wasn't either, as a man of a proper spirit, to be frightened.
``What is that then--if I accept it--but as strong a reason as I can want for just LEARNING to know you?'' (She)

She (man) faced him (Verver) always--kept it up as for honesty, and yet at the same time, in her (man) odd way, as for mercy.

``How can you tell whether if you did you would?'' (she)

It was ambiguous for an instant, as she (man) showed she (man) felt.

``I mean when it's a question of learning, one learns sometimes too late.'' (unknown)

``I think it's a question,'' (he)
he (Verver) promptly enough made answer,
``of liking you the more just for your saying these things. You should make something,'' (he)
he (Verver) added,
``of my liking you.'' (he)

``I make everything. But are you sure of having exhausted all other ways?'' (unknown)

This, of a truth, enlarged his (Verver) gaze.

``But what other ways?'' (unknown)

``Why, you've more ways of being kind than anyone I ever knew.'' (unknown)

``Take it then,'' (he)
he (Verver) answered,
``that I'm simply putting them all together for you.'' (he)
She (man) looked at him (Verver), on this, long again--still as if it shouldn't be said she (man) hadn't given him (Verver) time or had withdrawn from his (Verver) view, so to speak, a single inch of her (man) surface. This at least she (man) was fully to have exposed. It represented her (man) as oddly conscientious, and he (Verver) scarce knew in what sense it affected him (Verver). On the whole, however, with admiration.
``You're very, very honourable.'' (unknown)

``It's just what I want to be. I don't see,'' (she)
she (man) added,
``why you're not right, I don't see why you're not happy, as you are. I can not ask myself, I can not ask YOU,'' (she)
she (man) went on,
``if you're really as much at liberty as your universal generosity leads you to assume. Oughtn't we,'' (she)
she (man) asked,
``to think a little of others? Oughtn't I, at least, in loyalty--at any rate in delicacy--to think of Maggie?'' (she)
With which, intensely gentle, so as not to appear too much to teach him (Verver) his (Verver) duty, she (man) explained.
``She (Maggie)'s everything to you--she (Maggie) has always been. Are you so certain that there's room in your life--?'' (unknown)

``For another daughter?--is that what you mean?'' (She)
She (man) had not hung upon it long, but he (Verver) had quickly taken her (man) up.

He (Verver) had not, however, disconcerted her (man).

``For another young woman--very much of her (woman) age, and whose relation to her (woman) has always been so different from what our marrying would make it. For another companion,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
said Charlotte Stant.

``Can't a man be, all his (man) life then,'' (he)
he (Verver) almost fiercely asked,
``anything but a father?'' (he)
But he (Verver) went on before she (Stant) could answer.
``You talk about differences, but they've been already made--as no one knows better than Maggie. She (Maggie) feels the one she (Maggie) made herself by her (Maggie) own marriage--made, I mean, for me. She (Maggie) constantly thinks of it--it allows her (Maggie) no rest. To put her (Maggie) at peace is therefore,'' (he)
he (Verver) explained,
``what I'm trying, with you, to do. I can't do it alone, but I can do it with your help. You can make her (Maggie),'' (he)
he (Verver) said,
``positively happy about me.'' (he)

``About you?'' (she)
she (Stant) thoughtfully echoed.
``But what can I make her (Maggie) about herself?'' (unknown)

``Oh, if she (Maggie)'s at ease about me the rest will take care of itself. The case,'' (he)
he (Verver) declared,
``is in your hands. You'll effectually put out of her (Maggie) mind that I feel she (Maggie) has abandoned me.'' (he)

Interest certainly now was what he (Verver) had kindled in her (Stant) face, but it was all the more honourable to her (Stant), as he (Verver) had just called it that she (Stant) should want to see each of the steps of his (Verver) conviction.

``If you've been driven to the `likes' of me, mayn't it show that you've felt truly forsaken?'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm willing to suggest that, if I can show at the same time that I feel consoled.'' (unknown)

``But HAVE you,'' (she)
she (Stant) demanded,
``really felt so?'' (she)
He (Verver) hesitated.

``Consoled?'' (unknown)

``Forsaken.'' (unknown)

``No--I haven't. But if it's her (Maggie) idea--!'' (unknown)
If it was her (Stant) idea, in short, that was enough. This enunciation of motive, the next moment, however, sounded to him (Verver) perhaps slightly thin, so that he (Verver) gave it another touch.
``That is if it's my idea. I happen, you see, to like my idea.'' (unknown)

``Well, it's beautiful and wonderful. But isn't it, possibly,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte asked,
``not quite enough to marry me for?'' (Charlotte)

``Why so, my dear child? Isn't a man's idea usually what he (man) does marry for?'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte, considering, looked as if this might perhaps be a large question, or at all events something of an extension of one they were immediately concerned with.

``Doesn't that a good deal depend on the sort of thing it may be?'' (She)
She (Charlotte) suggested that, about marriage, ideas, as he (Verver) called them, might differ; with which, however, giving no more time to it, she (Charlotte) sounded another question.
``Don't you appear rather to put it to me that I may accept your offer for Maggie's sake? Somehow'' (she)
--she (Charlotte) turned it over--
``I don't so clearly SEE her (Maggie) quite so much finding reassurance, or even quite so much needing it.'' (she)

``Do you then make nothing at all of her (Maggie) having been so ready to leave us?'' (Charlotte)

Ah, Charlotte on the contrary made much!

``She (Maggie) was ready to leave us because she (Maggie) had to be. From the moment the Prince wanted it she (Maggie) could only go with him (Prince).'' (unknown)

``Perfectly--so that, if you see your way, she (Maggie) will be able to `go with him (Prince)' in future as much as she (Maggie) likes.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte appeared to examine for a minute, in Maggie's interest, this privilege--the result of which was a limited concession.

``You've certainly worked it out!'' (unknown)

``Of course I've worked it out--that's exactly what I HAVE done. She (Maggie) hadn't for a long time been so happy about anything as at your being there with me.'' (unknown)

``I was to be with you,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``for her (Maggie) security.'' (Charlotte)

``Well,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
Adam Verver rang out,
``this IS her (Maggie) security. You've only, if you can't see it, to ask her (Maggie).'' (Adam Verver/Adam)

```Ask' her (Charlotte)?''--the girl echoed it in wonder.

``Certainly--in so many words. Telling her (Maggie) you don't believe me.'' (she)

Still she (Charlotte) debated.

``Do you mean write it to her (Maggie)?'' (unknown)

``Quite so. Immediately. To-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't think I can write it,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
said Charlotte Stant.
``When I write to her (Maggie)'' (she)
--and she (Stant) looked amused for so different a shade--
``it's about the Principino's appetite and Dr. Brady's visits.'' (she)

``Very good then--put it to her (Maggie) face to face. We'll go straight to Paris to meet them.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte, at this, rose with a movement that was like a small cry; but her (Charlotte) unspoken sense lost itself while she (Charlotte) stood with her (Charlotte) eyes on him (Verver)--he (Verver) keeping his (Verver) seat as for the help it gave him (Verver), a little, to make his (Verver) appeal go up. Presently, however, a new sense had come to her (Charlotte), and she (Charlotte) covered him (Verver), kindly, with the expression of it.

``I do think, you know, you must rather `like' me.'' (unknown)

``Thank you,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver.
``You WILL put it to her (Maggie) yourself then?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) had another hesitation.

``We go over, you say, to meet them?'' (unknown)

``As soon as we can get back to Fawns. And wait there for them, if necessary, till they come.'' (unknown)

``Wait--a--at Fawns?'' (unknown)

``Wait in Paris. That will be charming in itself.'' (unknown)

``You take me to pleasant places.'' (She)
She (Charlotte) turned it over.
``You propose to me beautiful things.'' (unknown)

``It rests but with you to make them beautiful and pleasant. You've made Brighton--!'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (she)
--she (Charlotte) almost tenderly protested.
``With what I'm doing now?'' (unknown)

``You're promising me now what I want. Aren't you promising me,'' (he)
he (Verver) pressed, getting up,
``aren't you promising me to abide by what Maggie says?'' (he)

Oh, she (Charlotte) wanted to be sure she (Charlotte) was.

``Do you mean she (Maggie)'ll ASK it of me?'' (him)

It gave him (Verver) indeed, as by communication, a sense of the propriety of being himself certain. Yet what was he (Verver) but certain?

``She (Maggie)'ll speak to you. She (Maggie)'ll speak to you FOR me.'' (her)

This at last then seemed to satisfy her (Charlotte).

``Very good. May we wait again to talk of it till she (Maggie) has done so?'' (He)
He (Verver) showed, with his (Verver) hands down in his (Verver) pockets and his (Verver) shoulders expressively up, a certain disappointment. Soon enough, none the less, his (Verver) gentleness was all back and his (Verver) patience once more exemplary.
``Of course I give you time. Especially,'' (he)
he (Verver) smiled,
``as it's time that I shall be spending with you. Our keeping on together will help you perhaps to see. To see, I mean, how I need you.'' (he)

``I already see,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``how you've persuaded yourself you do.'' (Charlotte)
But she (Charlotte) had to repeat it.
``That isn't, unfortunately, all.'' (unknown)

``Well then, how you'll make Maggie right.'' (unknown)

```Right'?'' She (Charlotte) echoed it as if the word went far. And

``O--oh!'' (unknown)
she (Charlotte) still critically murmured as they moved together away.

XIII

He (Verver) had talked to her (Charlotte) of their waiting in Paris, a week later, but on the spot there this period of patience suffered no great strain. He (Verver) had written to his (Verver) daughter, not indeed from Brighton, but directly after their return to Fawns, where they spent only forty-eight hours before resuming their journey; and Maggie's reply to his (Verver) news was a telegram from Rome, delivered to him (Verver) at noon of their fourth day and which he (Verver) brought out to Charlotte, who was seated at that moment in the court of the hotel, where they had agreed that he (Verver) should join her (Charlotte) for their proceeding together to the noontide meal. His (Verver) letter, at Fawns--a letter of several pages and intended lucidly, unreservedly, in fact all but triumphantly, to inform--had proved, on his (Verver) sitting down to it, and a little to his (Verver) surprise, not quite so simple a document to frame as even his (Verver) due consciousness of its weight of meaning had allowed him (Verver) to assume: this doubtless, however, only for reasons naturally latent in the very wealth of that consciousness, which contributed to his (Verver) message something of their own quality of impatience. The main result of their talk, for the time, had been a difference in his (Verver) relation to his (Verver) young friend, as well as a difference, equally sensible, in her (Verver) relation to himself; and this in spite of his (Verver) not having again renewed his (Verver) undertaking to

``speak'' (friend)
to her (Verver) so far even as to tell her (Verver) of the communication despatched to Rome. Delicacy, a delicacy more beautiful still, all the delicacy she (Verver) should want, reigned between them--it being rudimentary, in their actual order, that she (Verver) mustn't be further worried until Maggie should have put her (Maggie) at her (Maggie) ease.

It was just the delicacy, however, that in Paris--which, suggestively, was Brighton at a hundredfold higher pitch--made, between him (Verver) and his (Verver) companion, the tension, made the suspense, made what he (Verver) would have consented perhaps to call the provisional peculiarity, of present conditions. These elements acted in a manner of their own, imposing and involving, under one head, many abstentions and precautions, twenty anxieties and reminders--things, verily, he (Verver) would scarce have known how to express; and yet creating for them at every step an acceptance of their reality. He (Verver) was hanging back, with Charlotte, till another person should intervene for their assistance, and yet they had, by what had already occurred, been carried on to something it was out of the power of other persons to make either less or greater. Common conventions--that was what was odd--had to be on this basis more thought of; those common conventions that, previous to the passage by the Brighton strand, he (Verver) had so enjoyed the sense of their overlooking. The explanation would have been, he (Verver) supposed--or would have figured it with less of unrest--that Paris had, in its way, deeper voices and warnings, so that if you went at all

``far'' (he)
there it laid bristling traps, as they might have been viewed, all smothered in flowers, for your going further still. There were strange appearances in the air, and before you knew it you might be unmistakably matching them. Since he (Verver) wished therefore to match no appearance but that of a gentleman playing with perfect fairness any game in life he (Verver) might be called to, he (Verver) found himself, on the receipt of Maggie's missive, rejoicing with a certain inconsistency. The announcement made her (Maggie) from home had, in the act, cost some biting of his (Verver) pen to sundry parts of him (Verver)--his (Verver) personal modesty, his (Verver) imagination of her (Maggie) prepared state for so quick a jump, it didn't much matter which--and yet he (Verver) was more eager than not for the drop of delay and for the quicker transitions promised by the arrival of the imminent pair. There was after all a hint of offence to a man of his (man) age in being taken, as they said at the shops, on approval. Maggie, certainly, would have been as far as Charlotte herself from positively desiring this, and Charlotte, on her (Charlotte) side, as far as Maggie from holding him (man) light as a real value. She (Maggie) made him (man) fidget thus, poor girl, but from generous rigour of conscience.

These allowances of his (man) spirit were, all the same, consistent with a great gladness at the sight of the term of his (man) ordeal; for it was the end of his (man) seeming to agree that questions and doubts had a place. The more he (man) had inwardly turned the matter over the more it had struck him (man) that they had in truth only an ugliness. What he (man) could have best borne, as he (man) now believed, would have been Charlotte's simply saying to him (man) that she (Charlotte) didn't like him (man) enough. This he (man) wouldn't have enjoyed, but he (man) would quite have understood it and been able ruefully to submit. She (Charlotte) did like him (man) enough--nothing to contradict that had come out for him (man); so that he (man) was restless for her (Charlotte) as well as for himself. She (Charlotte) looked at him (man) hard a moment when he (man) handed her (Charlotte) his (man) telegram, and the look, for what he (man) fancied a dim, shy fear in it, gave him (man) perhaps his (man) best moment of conviction that--as a man, so to speak--he (man) properly pleased her (Charlotte). He (man) said nothing--the words sufficiently did it for him (man), doing it again better still as Charlotte, who had left her (Charlotte) chair at his (man) approach, murmured them out.

``We start to-night to bring you all our love and joy and sympathy.'' (she)
There they were, the words, and what did she (Charlotte) want more? She (Charlotte) didn't, however, as she (Charlotte) gave him (man) back the little unfolded leaf, say they were enough--though he (man) saw, the next moment, that her (Charlotte) silence was probably not disconnected from her (Charlotte) having just visibly turned pale. Her (Charlotte) extraordinarily fine eyes, as it was his (man) present theory that he (man) had always thought them, shone at him (man) the more darkly out of this change of colour; and she (Charlotte) had again, with it, her (Charlotte) apparent way of subjecting herself, for explicit honesty and through her (Charlotte) willingness to face him (man), to any view he (man) might take, all at his (man) ease, and even to wantonness, of the condition he (man) produced in her (Charlotte). As soon as he (man) perceived that emotion kept her (Charlotte) soundless he (man) knew himself deeply touched, since it proved that, little as she (Charlotte) professed, she (Charlotte) had been beautifully hoping. They stood there a minute while he (man) took in from this sign that, yes then, certainly she (Charlotte) liked him (man) enough--liked him (man) enough to make him (man), old as he (man) was ready to brand himself, flush for the pleasure of it. The pleasure of it accordingly made him (man) speak first.
``Do you begin, a little, to be satisfied?'' (she)

Still, however, she (Charlotte) had to think.

``We've hurried them, you see. Why so breathless a start?'' (unknown)

``Because they want to congratulate us. They want,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver,
``to SEE our happiness.'' (Adam Verver/Adam)

She (Charlotte) wondered again--and this time also, for him (Verver), as publicly as possible.

``So much as that?'' (unknown)

``Do you think it's too much?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) continued to think plainly.

``They weren't to have started for another week.'' (unknown)

``Well, what then? Isn't our situation worth the little sacrifice? We'll go back to Rome as soon as you like WITH them.'' (he)

This seemed to hold her (Charlotte)--as he (Verver) had previously seen her (Charlotte) held, just a trifle inscrutably, by his (Verver) allusions to what they would do together on a certain contingency.

``Worth it, the little sacrifice, for whom? For us, naturally--yes,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said.
``We want to see them--for our reasons. That is,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) rather dimly smiled,
``YOU do.'' (she)

``And you do, my dear, too!'' (he)
he (Verver) bravely declared.
``Yes then--I do too,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) after an instant ungrudging enough acknowledged.
``For us, however, something depends on it.'' (unknown)

``Rather! But does nothing depend on it for them?'' (unknown)

``What CAN--from the moment that, as appears, they don't want to nip us in the bud? I can imagine their rushing up to prevent us. But an enthusiasm for us that can wait so very little--such intense eagerness, I confess,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``more than a little puzzles me. You may think me,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) also added,
``ungracious and suspicious, but the Prince can't at all want to come back so soon. He (Prince) wanted quite too intensely to get away.'' (she)

Mr. Verver considered.

``Well, hasn't he (Prince) been away?'' (unknown)

``Yes, just long enough to see how he (Prince) likes it. Besides,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``he (Prince) may not be able to join in the rosy view of our case that you impute to her (You). It can't in the least have appeared to him (Prince) hitherto a matter of course that you should give his (Prince) wife a bouncing stepmother.'' (Charlotte)

Adam Verver, at this, looked grave.

``I'm afraid then he (Prince)'ll just have to accept from us whatever his (Prince) wife accepts; and accept it--if he (Prince) can imagine no better reason--just because she (wife) does. That,'' (he)
he (Verver) declared,
``will have to do for him (Prince).'' (he)

His (Verver) tone made her (Charlotte) for a moment meet his (Verver) face; after which,

``Let me,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) abruptly said,
``see it again'' (she)
--taking from him (Verver) the folded leaf that she (Charlotte) had given back and he (Verver) had kept in his (Verver) hand.
``Isn't the whole thing,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) asked when she (Charlotte) had read it over,
``perhaps but a way like another for their gaining time?'' (she)
