He (Verver) again stood staring; but the next minute, with that upward spring of his (Verver) shoulders and that downward pressure of his (Verver) pockets which she (Charlotte) had already, more than once, at disconcerted moments, determined in him (Verver), he (Verver) turned sharply away and wandered from her (Charlotte) in silence. He (Verver) looked about in his (Verver) small despair; he (Verver) crossed the hotel court, which, overarched and glazed, muffled against loud sounds and guarded against crude sights, heated, gilded, draped, almost carpeted, with exotic trees in tubs, exotic ladies in chairs, the general exotic accent and presence suspended, as with wings folded or feebly fluttering, in the superior, the supreme, the inexorably enveloping Parisian medium, resembled some critical apartment of large capacity, some

``dental,'' (ladies)
medical, surgical waiting-room, a scene of mixed anxiety and desire, preparatory, for gathered barbarians, to the due amputation or extraction of excrescences and redundancies of barbarism. He (ladies) went as far as the porte-cochere, took counsel afresh of his (ladies) usual optimism, sharpened even, somehow, just here, by the very air he (ladies) tasted, and then came back smiling to Charlotte.
``It is incredible to you that when a man is still as much in love as Amerigo his (man) most natural impulse should be to feel what his (man) wife feels, to believe what she (wife) believes, to want what she (wife) wants?--in the absence, that is, of special impediments to his (man) so doing.'' (she)
The manner of it operated--she (Charlotte) acknowledged with no great delay this natural possibility.
``No--nothing is incredible to me of people immensely in love.'' (unknown)

``Well, isn't Amerigo immensely in love?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) hesitated but as for the right expression of her (Charlotte) sense of the degree--but she (Charlotte) after all adopted Mr. Verver's.

``Immensely.'' (unknown)

``Then there you are!'' (She)

She (Charlotte) had another smile, however--she (Charlotte) wasn't there quite yet.

``That isn't all that's wanted.'' (unknown)

``But what more?'' (unknown)

``Why that his (man) wife shall have made him (man) really believe that SHE really believes.'' (Charlotte)
With which Charlotte became still more lucidly logical.
``The reality of his (man) belief will depend in such a case on the reality of hers. The Prince may for instance now,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``have made out to his (Prince) satisfaction that Maggie may mainly desire to abound in your sense, whatever it is you do. He (Prince) may remember that he (Prince) has never seen her (Maggie) do anything else.'' (she)

``Well,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver,
``what kind of a warning will he (Prince) have found in that? To what catastrophe will he (Prince) have observed such a disposition in her (Maggie) to lead?'' (Adam Verver/Adam)

``Just to THIS one!'' (she)
With which she (Charlotte) struck him (Verver) as rising straighter and clearer before him (Verver) than she (Charlotte) had done even yet.

``Our little question itself?'' (him)
Her (Charlotte) appearance had in fact, at the moment, such an effect on him (Verver) that he (Verver) could answer but in marvelling mildness.
``Hadn't we better wait a while till we call it a catastrophe?'' (he)

Her (Charlotte) rejoinder to this was to wait--though by no means as long as he (Verver) meant. When at the end of her (Charlotte) minute she (Charlotte) spoke, however, it was mildly too.

``What would you like, dear friend, to wait for?'' (unknown)
It lingered between them in the air, this demand, and they exchanged for the time a look which might have made each of them seem to have been watching in the other the signs of its overt irony. These were indeed immediately so visible in Mr. Verver's face that, as if a little ashamed of having so markedly produced them--and as if also to bring out at last, under pressure, something she (Charlotte) had all the while been keeping back--she (Charlotte) took a jump to pure plain reason.
``You haven't noticed for yourself, but I can't quite help noticing, that in spite of what you assume--WE assume, if you like--Maggie wires her (Maggie) joy only to you. She (Maggie) makes no sign of its overflow to me.'' (he)

It was a point--and, staring a moment, he (Verver) took account of it. But he (Verver) had, as before, his (Verver) presence of mind--to say nothing of his (Verver) kindly humour.

``Why, you complain of the very thing that's most charmingly conclusive! She (Maggie) treats us already as ONE.'' (the girl)

Clearly now, for the girl, in spite of lucidity and logic, there was something in the way he (Verver) said things--! She (girl) faced him (Verver) in all her (girl) desire to please him (Verver), and then her (girl) word quite simply and definitely showed it.

``I do like you, you know.'' (unknown)

Well, what could this do but stimulate his (Verver) humour?

``I see what's the matter with you. You won't be quiet till you've heard from the Prince himself. I think,'' (the man)
the happy man added,
``that I'll go and secretly wire to him (Prince) that you'd like, reply paid, a few words for yourself.'' (the man)

It could apparently but encourage her (girl) further to smile.

``Reply paid for him (Prince), you mean--or for me?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I'll pay, with pleasure, anything back for you--as many words as you like.'' (he)
And he (Verver) went on, to keep it up.
``Not requiring either to see your message.'' (She)

She (girl) could take it, visibly, as he (Verver) meant it.

``Should you require to see the Prince's?'' (unknown)

``Not a bit. You can keep that also to yourself.'' (she)

On his (Verver) speaking, however, as if his (Verver) transmitting the hint were a real question, she (girl) appeared to consider--and almost as if for good taste--that the joke had gone far enough.

``It doesn't matter. Unless he (Prince) speaks of his (Prince) own movement--! And why should it be,'' (she)
she (girl) asked,
``a thing that WOULD occur to him (Prince)?'' (she)

``I really think,'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver concurred,
``that it naturally wouldn't. HE (Prince) doesn't know you're morbid.'' (Mr. Verver)

She (girl) just wondered--but she (girl) agreed.

``No--he (Prince) hasn't yet found it out. Perhaps he (Prince) will, but he (Prince) hasn't yet; and I'm willing to give him (Prince) meanwhile the benefit of the doubt.'' (she)
So with this the situation, to her (girl) view, would appear to have cleared had she (girl) not too quickly had one of her (girl) restless relapses.
``Maggie, however, does know I'm morbid. SHE hasn't the benefit.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver a little wearily at last,
``I think I feel that you'll hear from her (Maggie) yet.'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
It had even fairly come over him (Verver), under recurrent suggestion, that his (Verver) daughter's omission WAS surprising. And Maggie had never in her (Maggie) life been wrong for more than three minutes.

``Oh, it isn't that I hold that I've a RIGHT to it,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte the next instant rather oddly qualified--and the observation itself gave him (Verver) a further push.

``Very well--I shall like it myself.'' (her)

At this then, as if moved by his (Verver) way of constantly--and more or less against his (Verver) own contention--coming round to her (Charlotte), she (Charlotte) showed how she (Charlotte) could also always, and not less gently, come half way.

``I speak of it only as the missing GRACE--the grace that's in everything that Maggie does. It isn't my due'' (she)
--she (Charlotte) kept it up--
``but, taking from you that we may still expect it, it will have the touch. It will be beautiful.'' (she)

``Then come out to breakfast.'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver had looked at his (Verver) watch.
``It will be here when we get back.'' (unknown)

``If it isn't'' (Charlotte)
--and Charlotte smiled as she (Charlotte) looked about for a feather boa that she (Charlotte) had laid down on descending from her (Charlotte) room--
``if it isn't it will have had but THAT slight fault.'' (she)

He (Verver) saw her (Charlotte) boa on the arm of the chair from which she (Charlotte) had moved to meet him (Verver), and, after he (Verver) had fetched it, raising it to make its charming softness brush his (Verver) face--for it was a wondrous product of Paris, purchased under his (Verver) direct auspices the day before--he (Verver) held it there a minute before giving it up.

``Will you promise me then to be at peace?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) looked, while she (Charlotte) debated, at his (Verver) admirable present.

``I promise you.'' (unknown)

``Quite for ever?'' (unknown)

``Quite for ever.'' (unknown)

``Remember,'' (he)
he (Verver) went on, to justify his (Verver) demand,
``remember that in wiring you she (you)'ll naturally speak even more for her (you) husband than she (you) has done in wiring me.'' (he)

It was only at a word that Charlotte had a demur. ```Naturally'--?''

``Why, our marriage puts him (husband) for you, you see--or puts you for him (husband)--into a new relation, whereas it leaves his (husband) relation to me unchanged. It therefore gives him (husband) more to say to you about it.'' (unknown)

``About its making me his (husband) stepmother-in-law--or whatever I SHOULD become?'' (she)
Over which, for a little, she (Charlotte) not undivertedly mused.
``Yes, there may easily be enough for a gentleman to say to a young woman about that.'' (unknown)

``Well, Amerigo can always be, according to the case, either as funny or as serious as you like; and whichever he (gentleman) may be for you, in sending you a message, he (gentleman)'ll be it ALL.'' (the girl looks)
And then as the girl, with one of her (Charlotte) so deeply and oddly, yet so tenderly, critical looks at him (Verver), failed to take up the remark, he (Verver) found himself moved, as by a vague anxiety, to add a question.
``Don't you think he (gentleman)'s charming?'' (unknown)

``Oh, charming,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
said Charlotte Stant.
``If he (gentleman) weren't I shouldn't mind.'' (unknown)

``No more should I!'' (friend)
her (Stant) friend harmoniously returned.

``Ah, but you DON'T mind. You don't have to. You don't have to, I mean, as I have. It's the last folly ever to care, in an anxious way, the least particle more than one is absolutely forced. If I were you,'' (she)
she (Stant) went on--
``if I had in my life, for happiness and power and peace, even a small fraction of what you have, it would take a great deal to make me waste my worry. I don't know,'' (she)
she (Stant) said,
``what in the world--that didn't touch my luck--I should trouble my head about.'' (she)

``I quite understand you--yet doesn't it just depend,'' (Mr. Verver)
Mr. Verver asked,
``on what you call one's luck? It's exactly my luck that I'm talking about. I shall be as sublime as you like when you've made me all right. It's only when one is right that one really has the things you speak of. It isn't they,'' (Mr. Verver)
he (Verver) explained,
``that make one so: it's the something else I want that makes THEM right. If you'll give me what I ask, you'll see.'' (he)

She (Stant) had taken her (Stant) boa and thrown it over her (Stant) shoulders, and her (Stant) eyes, while she (Stant) still delayed, had turned from him (Verver), engaged by another interest, though the court was by this time, the hour of dispersal for luncheon, so forsaken that they would have had it, for free talk, should they have been moved to loudness, quite to themselves. She (Stant) was ready for their adjournment, but she (Stant) was also aware of a pedestrian youth, in uniform, a visible emissary of the Postes et Telegraphes, who had approached, from the street, the small stronghold of the concierge and who presented there a missive taken from the little cartridge-box slung over his (emissary) shoulder. The portress, meeting him (emissary) on the threshold, met equally, across the court, Charlotte's marked attention to his (emissary) visit, so that, within the minute, she (Charlotte) had advanced to our friends with her (Charlotte) cap-streamers flying and her (Charlotte) smile of announcement as ample as her (Charlotte) broad white apron. She (Charlotte) raised aloft a telegraphic message and, as she (Charlotte) delivered it, sociably discriminated.

``Cette fois-ci pour madame!'' (she)
--with which she (Charlotte) as genially retreated, leaving Charlotte in possession. Charlotte, taking it, held it at first unopened. Her (Charlotte) eyes had come back to her (Charlotte) companion, who had immediately and triumphantly greeted it.
``Ah, there you are!'' (She)

She (Charlotte) broke the envelope then in silence, and for a minute, as with the message he (companion) himself had put before her (Charlotte), studied its contents without a sign. He (companion) watched her (Charlotte) without a question, and at last she (Charlotte) looked up.

``I'll give you,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) simply said,
``what you ask.'' (she)

The expression of her (Charlotte) face was strange--but since when had a woman's at moments of supreme surrender not a right to be? He (companion) took it in with his (companion) own long look and his (companion) grateful silence--so that nothing more, for some instants, passed between them. Their understanding sealed itself--he (companion) already felt that she (Charlotte) had made him (companion) right. But he (companion) was in presence too of the fact that Maggie had made HER so; and always, therefore, without Maggie, where, in fine, would he (companion) be? She (Maggie) united them, brought them together as with the click of a silver spring, and, on the spot, with the vision of it, his (companion) eyes filled, Charlotte facing him (companion) meanwhile with her (Charlotte) expression made still stranger by the blur of his (companion) gratitude. Through it all, however, he (companion) smiled.

``What my child does for me--!'' (he)

Through it all as well, that is still through the blur, he (companion) saw Charlotte, rather than heard her (Charlotte), reply. She (Charlotte) held her (Charlotte) paper wide open, but her (Charlotte) eyes were all for his (companion).

``It isn't Maggie. It's the Prince.'' (unknown)

``I SAY!'' (he)
--he (companion) gaily rang out.
``Then it's best of all.'' (unknown)

``It's enough.'' (unknown)

``Thank you for thinking so!'' (he)
To which he (companion) added
``It's enough for our question, but it isn't--is it? quite enough for our breakfast? Dejeunons.'' (he)

She (Charlotte) stood there, however, in spite of this appeal, her (Charlotte) document always before them.

``Don't you want to read it?'' (He)

He (companion) thought.

``Not if it satisfies you. I don't require it.'' (she)

But she (Charlotte) gave him (companion), as for her (Charlotte) conscience, another chance.

``You can if you like.'' (He)

He (companion) hesitated afresh, but as for amiability, not for curiosity.

``Is it funny?'' (she)

Thus, finally, she (Charlotte) again dropped her (Charlotte) eyes on it, drawing in her (Charlotte) lips a little.

``No--I call it grave.'' (unknown)

``Ah, then, I don't want it.'' (unknown)

``Very grave,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
said Charlotte Stant.

``Well, what did I tell you of him (I)?'' (he)
he (companion) asked, rejoicing, as they started: a question for all answer to which, before she (Stant) took his (companion) arm, the girl thrust her (Stant) paper, crumpled, into the pocket of her (Stant) coat.

PART THIRD

XIV

Charlotte, half way up the

``monumental'' (PART THIRD XIV Charlotte way)
staircase, had begun by waiting alone--waiting to be rejoined by her (Charlotte) companion, who had gone down all the way, as in common kindness bound, and who, his (companion) duty performed, would know where to find her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) was meanwhile, though extremely apparent, not perhaps absolutely advertised; but she (Charlotte) would not have cared if she (Charlotte) had been--so little was it, by this time, her (Charlotte) first occasion of facing society with a consciousness materially, with a confidence quite splendidly, enriched. For a couple of years now she (Charlotte) had known as never before what it was to look
``well'' (she)
--to look, that is, as well as she (Charlotte) had always felt, from far back, that, in certain conditions, she (Charlotte) might. On such an evening as this, that of a great official party in the full flush of the London spring-time, the conditions affected her (Charlotte), her (Charlotte) nerves, her (Charlotte) senses, her (Charlotte) imagination, as all profusely present; so that perhaps at no moment yet had she (Charlotte) been so justified of her (Charlotte) faith as at the particular instant of our being again concerned with her (Charlotte), that of her (Charlotte) chancing to glance higher up from where she (Charlotte) stood and meeting in consequence the quiet eyes of Colonel Assingham, who had his (Colonel) elbows on the broad balustrade of the great gallery overhanging the staircase and who immediately exchanged with her (Assingham) one of his (Colonel) most artlessly familiar signals. This simplicity of his (Colonel) visual attention struck her (Assingham), even with the other things she (Assingham) had to think about, as the quietest note in the whole high pitch--much, in fact, as if she (Assingham) had pressed a finger on a chord or a key and created, for the number of seconds, an arrest of vibration, a more muffled thump. The sight of him (Colonel) suggested indeed that Fanny would be there, though so far as opportunity went she (Fanny) had not seen her (Fanny). This was about the limit of what it could suggest.

The air, however, had suggestions enough--it abounded in them, many of them precisely helping to constitute those conditions with which, for our young woman, the hour was brilliantly crowned. She (woman) was herself in truth crowned, and it all hung together, melted together, in light and colour and sound: the unsurpassed diamonds that her (woman) head so happily carried, the other jewels, the other perfections of aspect and arrangement that made her (woman) personal scheme a success, the PROVED private theory that materials to work with had been all she (woman) required and that there were none too precious for her (woman) to understand and use--to which might be added lastly, as the strong-scented flower of the total sweetness, an easy command, a high enjoyment, of her (woman) crisis. For a crisis she (woman) was ready to take it, and this ease it was, doubtless, that helped her (woman), while she (woman) waited, to the right assurance, to the right indifference, to the right expression, and above all, as she (woman) felt, to the right view of her (woman) opportunity for happiness--unless indeed the opportunity itself, rather, were, in its mere strange amplitude, the producing, the precipitating cause. The ordered revellers, rustling and shining, with sweep of train and glitter of star and clink of sword, and yet, for all this, but so imperfectly articulate, so vaguely vocal--the double stream of the coming and the going, flowing together where she (woman) stood, passed her (woman), brushed her (woman), treated her (woman) to much crude contemplation and now and then to a spasm of speech, an offered hand, even in some cases to an unencouraged pause; but she (woman) missed no countenance and invited no protection: she (woman) fairly liked to be, so long as she (woman) might, just as she (woman) was--exposed a little to the public, no doubt, in her (woman) unaccompanied state, but, even if it were a bit brazen, careless of queer reflections on the dull polish of London faces, and exposed, since it was a question of exposure, to much more competent recognitions of her (woman) own. She (woman) hoped no one would stop--she (woman) was positively keeping herself; it was her (woman) idea to mark in a particular manner the importance of something that had just happened. She (woman) knew how she (woman) should mark it, and what she (woman) was doing there made already a beginning.

When presently, therefore, from her (woman) standpoint, she (woman) saw the Prince come back she (woman) had an impression of all the place as higher and wider and more appointed for great moments; with its dome of lustres lifted, its ascents and descents more majestic, its marble tiers more vividly overhung, its numerosity of royalties, foreign and domestic, more unprecedented, its symbolism of

``State'' (she)
hospitality both emphasised and refined. This was doubtless a large consequence of a fairly familiar cause, a considerable inward stir to spring from the mere vision, striking as that might be, of Amerigo in a crowd; but she (woman) had her (woman) reasons, she (woman) held them there, she (woman) carried them in fact, responsibly and overtly, as she (woman) carried her (woman) head, her (woman) high tiara, her (woman) folded fan, her (woman) indifferent, unattended eminence; and it was when he (fan) reached her (woman) and she (woman) could, taking his (fan) arm, show herself as placed in her (woman) relation, that she (woman) felt supremely justified. It was her (woman) notion of course that she (woman) gave a glimpse of but few of her (woman) grounds for this discrimination--indeed of the most evident alone; yet she (woman) would have been half willing it should be guessed how she (woman) drew inspiration, drew support, in quantity sufficient for almost anything, from the individual value that, through all the picture, her (woman) husband's son-in-law kept for the eye, deriving it from his (son-in-law) fine unconscious way, in the swarming social sum, of outshining, overlooking and overtopping. It was as if in separation, even the shortest, she (woman) half forgot or disbelieved how he (son-in-law) affected her (woman) sight, so that reappearance had, in him (son-in-law), each time, a virtue of its own--a kind of disproportionate intensity suggesting his (son-in-law) connection with occult sources of renewal. What did he (son-in-law) do when he (son-in-law) was away from her (woman) that made him (son-in-law) always come back only looking, as she (woman) would have called it,
``more so?'' (she)
Superior to any shade of cabotinage, he (son-in-law) yet almost resembled an actor who, between his (son-in-law) moments on the stage, revisits his (son-in-law) dressing-room and, before the glass, pressed by his (son-in-law) need of effect, retouches his (son-in-law) make-up. The Prince was at present, for instance, though he (Prince) had quitted her (woman) but ten minutes before, still more than then the person it pleased her (woman) to be left with--a truth that had all its force for her (woman) while he (Prince) made her (woman) his (Prince) care for their conspicuous return together to the upper rooms. Conspicuous beyond any wish they could entertain was what, poor wonderful man, he (man) couldn't help making it; and when she (woman) raised her (woman) eyes again, on the ascent, to Bob Assingham, still aloft in his (Assingham) gallery and still looking down at her (woman), she (woman) was aware that, in spite of hovering and warning inward voices, she (woman) even enjoyed the testimony rendered by his (Assingham) lonely vigil to the lustre she (woman) reflected.

He (Assingham) was always lonely at great parties, the dear Colonel--it wasn't in such places that the seed he (Colonel) sowed at home was ever reaped by him (Colonel); but nobody could have seemed to mind it less, to brave it with more bronzed indifference; so markedly that he (Colonel) moved about less like one of the guests than like some quite presentable person in charge of the police arrangements or the electric light. To Mrs. Verver, as will be seen, he (Colonel) represented, with the perfect good faith of his (Colonel) apparent blankness, something definite enough; though her (Verver) bravery was not thereby too blighted for her (Verver) to feel herself calling him (Colonel) to witness that the only witchcraft her (Verver) companion had used, within the few minutes, was that of attending Maggie, who had withdrawn from the scene, to her (Maggie) carriage. Notified, at all events, of Fanny's probable presence, Charlotte was, for a while after this, divided between the sense of it as a fact somehow to reckon with and deal with, which was a perception that made, in its degree, for the prudence, the pusillanimity of postponement, of avoidance--and a quite other feeling, an impatience that presently ended by prevailing, an eagerness, really, to BE suspected, sounded, veritably arraigned, if only that she (Charlotte) might have the bad moment over, if only that she (Charlotte) might prove to herself, let alone to Mrs. Assingham also, that she (Assingham) could convert it to good; if only, in short, to be

``square,'' (she)
as they said, with her (Assingham) question. For herself indeed, particularly, it wasn't a question; but something in her (Assingham) bones told her (Assingham) that Fanny would treat it as one, and there was truly nothing that, from this friend, she (Fanny) was not bound in decency to take. She (Fanny) might hand things back with every tender precaution, with acknowledgments and assurances, but she (Fanny) owed it to them, in any case, and it to all Mrs. Assingham had done for her (Assingham), not to get rid of them without having well unwrapped and turned them over.

To-night, as happened--and she (Assingham) recognised it more and more, with the ebbing minutes, as an influence of everything about her (Assingham)--to-night exactly, she (Assingham) would, no doubt, since she (Assingham) knew why, be as firm as she (Assingham) might at any near moment again hope to be for going through that process with the right temper and tone. She (Assingham) said, after a little, to the Prince,

``Stay with me; let no one take you; for I want her (I), yes, I do want her (I) to see us together, and the sooner the better'' (the Prince)
--said it to keep her (Assingham) hand on him (Prince) through constant diversions, and made him (Prince), in fact, by saying it, profess a momentary vagueness. She (Assingham) had to explain to him (Prince) that it was Fanny Assingham, she (Assingham) wanted to see--who clearly would be there, since the Colonel never either stirred without her (Assingham) or, once arrived, concerned himself for her (Assingham) fate; and she (Assingham) had, further, after Amerigo had met her (Assingham) with
``See us together? why in the world? hasn't she (I) often seen us together?'' (Amerigo)
to inform him (Colonel) that what had elsewhere and otherwise happened didn't now matter and that she (Assingham) at any rate well knew, for the occasion, what she (Assingham) was about.
``You're strange, cara mia,'' (he)
he (Colonel) consentingly enough dropped; but, for whatever strangeness, he (Colonel) kept her (Assingham), as they circulated, from being waylaid, even remarking to her (Assingham) afresh as he (Colonel) had often done before, on the help rendered, in such situations, by the intrinsic oddity of the London
``squash,'' (he)
a thing of vague, slow, senseless eddies, revolving as in fear of some menace of conversation suspended over it, the drop of which, with some consequent refreshing splash or spatter, yet never took place. Of course she (Assingham) was strange; this, as they went, Charlotte knew for herself: how could she (Charlotte) be anything else when the situation holding her (Charlotte), and holding him (Colonel), for that matter, just as much, had so the stamp of it? She (Charlotte) had already accepted her (Charlotte) consciousness, as we have already noted, that a crisis, for them all, was in the air; and when such hours were not depressing, which was the form indeed in which she (Charlotte) had mainly known them, they were apparently in a high degree exhilarating.

Later on, in a corner to which, at sight of an empty sofa, Mrs. Assingham had, after a single attentive arrest, led her (Assingham) with a certain earnestness, this vision of the critical was much more sharpened than blurred. Fanny had taken it from her (Fanny): yes, she (Fanny) was there with Amerigo alone, Maggie having come with them and then, within ten minutes, changed her (Maggie) mind, repented and departed.

``So you're staying on together without her (I)?'' (the woman)
the elder woman had asked; and it was Charlotte's answer to this that had determined for them, quite indeed according to the latter's expectation, the need of some seclusion and her (Charlotte) companion's pounce at the sofa. They were staying on together alone, and--oh distinctly!--it was alone that Maggie had driven away, her (Maggie) father, as usual, not having managed to come. ```As usual'--?'' Mrs. Assingham had seemed to wonder; Mr. Verver's reluctances not having, she (Assingham) in fact quite intimated, hitherto struck her (Assingham). Charlotte responded, at any rate, that his (Verver) indisposition to go out had lately much increased--even though to-night, as she (Charlotte) admitted, he (Verver) had pleaded his (Verver) not feeling well. Maggie had wished to stay with him (Verver)--for the Prince and she (Maggie), dining out, had afterwards called in Portland Place, whence, in the event, they had brought her (Maggie), Charlotte, on. Maggie had come but to oblige her (Maggie) father--she (Maggie) had urged the two others to go without her (Maggie); then she (Maggie) had yielded, for the time, to Mr. Verver's persuasion. But here, when they had, after the long wait in the carriage, fairly got in; here, once up the stairs, with the rooms before them, remorse had ended by seizing her (Maggie): she (Maggie) had listened to no other remonstrance, and at present therefore, as Charlotte put it, the two were doubtless making together a little party at home. But it was all right--so Charlotte also put it: there was nothing in the world they liked better than these snatched felicities, little parties, long talks, with ``I'll come to you to-morrow,'' and ``No, I'll come to you,'' make-believe renewals of their old life. They were fairly, at times, the dear things, like children playing at paying visits, playing at ``Mr. Thompson'' and
``Mrs. Fane,'' (Mr. Thompson Fane each)
each hoping that the other would really stay to tea. Charlotte was sure she (Charlotte) should find Maggie there on getting home--a remark in which Mrs. Verver's immediate response to her (Verver) friend's inquiry had culminated. She (Verver) had thus, on the spot, the sense of having given her (Verver) plenty to think about, and that moreover of liking to see it even better than she (Verver) had expected. She (Verver) had plenty to think about herself, and there was already something in Fanny that made it seem still more.

``You say your husband's ill? He (husband) felt too ill to come?'' (unknown)

``No, my dear--I think not. If he (husband) had been too ill I wouldn't have left him (husband).'' (unknown)

``And yet Maggie was worried?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham asked.

``She (Maggie) worries, you know, easily. She (Maggie)'s afraid of influenza--of which he (husband) has had, at different times, though never with the least gravity, several attacks.'' (unknown)

``But you're not afraid of it?'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte had for a moment a pause; it had continued to come to her (Charlotte) that really to have her (Charlotte) case

``out,'' (Charlotte)
as they said, with the person in the world to whom her (Charlotte) most intimate difficulties had oftenest referred themselves, would help her (Charlotte), on the whole, more than hinder; and under that feeling all her (Charlotte) opportunity, with nothing kept back; with a thing or two perhaps even thrust forward, seemed temptingly to open. Besides, didn't Fanny at bottom half expect, absolutely at the bottom half WANT, things?--so that she (Fanny) would be disappointed if, after what must just have occurred for her (Fanny), she (Fanny) didn't get something to put between the teeth of her (Fanny) so restless rumination, that cultivation of the fear, of which our young woman had already had glimpses, that she (woman) might have
``gone too far'' (she)
in her (woman) irrepressible interest in other lives. What had just happened--it pieced itself together for Charlotte--was that the Assingham pair, drifting like everyone else, had had somewhere in the gallery, in the rooms, an accidental concussion; had it after the Colonel, over his (Colonel) balustrade, had observed, in the favouring high light, her (Charlotte) public junction with the Prince. His (Prince) very dryness, in this encounter, had, as always, struck a spark from his (Prince) wife's curiosity, and, familiar, on his (Prince) side, with all that she (wife) saw in things, he (Prince) had thrown her (wife), as a fine little bone to pick, some report of the way one of her (wife) young friends was
``going on'' (friends)
with another. He (Prince) knew perfectly--such at least was Charlotte's liberal assumption--that she (Charlotte) wasn't going on with anyone, but she (Charlotte) also knew that, given the circumstances, she (Charlotte) was inevitably to be sacrificed, in some form or another, to the humorous intercourse of the inimitable couple. The Prince meanwhile had also, under coercion, sacrificed her (Charlotte); the Ambassador had come up to him (Ambassador) with a message from Royalty, to whom he (Ambassador) was led away; after which she (Charlotte) had talked for five minutes with Sir John Brinder, who had been of the Ambassador's company and who had rather artlessly remained with her (Charlotte). Fanny had then arrived in sight of them at the same moment as someone else she (Fanny) didn't know, someone who knew Mrs. Assingham and also knew Sir John. Charlotte had left it to her (Charlotte) friend's competence to throw the two others immediately together and to find a way for entertaining her (Charlotte) in closer quarters. This was the little history of the vision, in her (Charlotte), that was now rapidly helping her (Charlotte) to recognise a precious chance, the chance that mightn't again soon be so good for the vivid making of a point. Her (Charlotte) point was before her (Charlotte); it was sharp, bright, true; above all it was her (Charlotte) own. She (Charlotte) had reached it quite by herself; no one, not even Amerigo--Amerigo least of all, who would have nothing to do with it--had given her (Charlotte) aid. To make it now with force for Fanny Assingham's benefit would see her (Assingham) further, in the direction in which the light had dawned, than any other spring she (Assingham) should, yet awhile, doubtless, be able to press. The direction was that of her (Assingham) greater freedom--which was all in the world she (Assingham) had in mind. Her (Assingham) opportunity had accordingly, after a few minutes of Mrs. Assingham's almost imprudently interested expression of face, positively acquired such a price for her (Assingham) that she (Assingham) may, for ourselves, while the intensity lasted, rather resemble a person holding out a small mirror at arm's length and consulting it with a special turn of the head. It was, in a word, with this value of her (Assingham) chance that she (Assingham) was intelligently playing when she (Assingham) said in answer to Fanny's last question:
``Don't you remember what you told me, on the occasion of something or other, the other day? That you believe there's nothing I'm afraid of? So, my dear, don't ask me!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Mayn't I ask you,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham returned,
``how the case stands with your poor husband?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Certainly, dear. Only, when you ask me as if I mightn't perhaps know what to think, it seems to me best to let you see that I know perfectly what to think.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham hesitated; then, blinking a little, she (Assingham) took her (Assingham) risk.

``You didn't think that if it was a question of anyone's returning to him (husband), in his (husband) trouble, it would be better you yourself should have gone?'' (Charlotte)

Well, Charlotte's answer to this inquiry visibly shaped itself in the interest of the highest considerations. The highest considerations were good humour, candour, clearness and, obviously, the REAL truth.

``If we couldn't be perfectly frank and dear with each other, it would be ever so much better, wouldn't it? that we shouldn't talk about anything at all; which, however, would be dreadful--and we certainly, at any rate, haven't yet come to it. You can ask me anything under the sun you like, because, don't you see? you can't upset me.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure, my dear Charlotte,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham laughed,
``I don't want to upset you.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Indeed, love, you simply COULDN'T even if you thought it necessary--that's all I mean. Nobody could, for it belongs to my situation that I'm, by no merit of my own, just fixed--fixed as fast as a pin stuck, up to its head, in a cushion. I'm placed--I can't imagine anyone MORE placed. There I AM!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny had indeed never listened to emphasis more firmly applied, and it brought into her (Assingham) own eyes, though she (Assingham) had reasons for striving to keep them from betrayals, a sort of anxiety of intelligence.

``I dare say--but your statement of your position, however you see it, isn't an answer to my inquiry. It seems to me, at the same time, I confess,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham added,
``to give but the more reason for it. You speak of our being `frank.' How can we possibly be anything else? If Maggie has gone off through finding herself too distressed to stay, and if she (Maggie)'s willing to leave you and her (Maggie) husband to show here without her (Maggie), aren't the grounds of her (Maggie) preoccupation more or less discussable?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``If they're not,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte replied,
``it's only from their being, in a way, too evident. They're not grounds for me--they weren't when I accepted Adam's preference that I should come to-night without him (Adam): just as I accept, absolutely, as a fixed rule, ALL his (Adam) preferences. But that doesn't alter the fact, of course, that my husband's daughter, rather than his (husband) wife, should have felt SHE could, after all, be the one to stay with him (husband), the one to make the sacrifice of this hour--seeing, especially, that the daughter has a husband of her (daughter) own in the field.'' (Charlotte)
With which she (Charlotte) produced, as it were, her (Charlotte) explanation.
``I've simply to see the truth of the matter--see that Maggie thinks more, on the whole, of fathers than of husbands. And my situation is such,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``that this becomes immediately, don't you understand? a thing I have to count with.'' (she)

Mrs. Assingham, vaguely heaving, panting a little but trying not to show it, turned about, from some inward spring, in her (Assingham) seat.

``If you mean such a thing as that she (Maggie) doesn't adore the Prince--!'' (unknown)

``I don't say she (Maggie) doesn't adore him (Prince). What I say is that she (Maggie) doesn't think of him (Prince). One of those conditions doesn't always, at all stages, involve the other. This is just HOW she (Maggie) adores him (Prince),'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
Charlotte said.
``And what reason is there, in the world, after all, why he (Prince) and I shouldn't, as you say, show together? We've shown together, my dear,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``before.'' (she)

Her (Charlotte) friend, for a little, only looked at her (Charlotte)--speaking then with abruptness.

``You ought to be absolutely happy. You live with such GOOD people.'' (Charlotte)

The effect of it, as well, was an arrest for Charlotte; whose face, however, all of whose fine and slightly hard radiance, it had caused, the next instant, further to brighten.

``Does one ever put into words anything so fatuously rash? It's a thing that must be said, in prudence, FOR one--by somebody who's so good as to take the responsibility: the more that it gives one always a chance to show one's best manners by not contradicting it. Certainly, you'll never have the distress, or whatever, of hearing me complain.'' (unknown)

``Truly, my dear, I hope in all conscience not!'' (the woman)
and the elder woman's spirit found relief in a laugh more resonant than was quite advised by their pursuit of privacy.

To this demonstration her (woman) friend gave no heed.

``With all our absence after marriage, and with the separation from her (somebody) produced in particular by our so many months in America, Maggie has still arrears, still losses to make up--still the need of showing how, for so long, she (Maggie) simply kept missing him (Maggie). She (Maggie) missed his (Maggie) company--a large allowance of which is, in spite of everything else, of the first necessity to her (Maggie). So she (Maggie) puts it in when she (Maggie) can--a little here, a little there, and it ends by making up a considerable amount. The fact of our distinct establishments--which has, all the same, everything in its favour,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte hastened to declare,
``makes her (Maggie) really see more of him (Maggie) than when they had the same house. To make sure she (Maggie) doesn't fail of it she (Maggie)'s always arranging for it--which she (Maggie) didn't have to do while they lived together. But she (Maggie) likes to arrange,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte steadily proceeded;
``it peculiarly suits her (Maggie); and the result of our separate households is really, for them, more contact and more intimacy. To-night, for instance, has been practically an arrangement. She (Maggie) likes him (Maggie) best alone. And it's the way,'' (Charlotte)
said our young woman,
``in which he (Maggie) best likes HER. It's what I mean therefore by being `placed.' And the great thing is, as they say, to `know' one's place. Doesn't it all strike you,'' (woman)
she (Charlotte) wound up,
``as rather placing the Prince too?'' (she)

Fanny Assingham had at this moment the sense as of a large heaped dish presented to her (Assingham) intelligence and inviting it to a feast--so thick were the notes of intention in this remarkable speech. But she (Assingham) also felt that to plunge at random, to help herself too freely, would--apart from there not being at such a moment time for it--tend to jostle the ministering hand, confound the array and, more vulgarly speaking, make a mess. So she (Assingham) picked out, after consideration, a solitary plum.

``So placed that YOU have to arrange?'' (unknown)

``Certainly I have to arrange.'' (unknown)

``And the Prince also--if the effect for him (Prince) is the same?'' (unknown)

``Really, I think, not less.'' (unknown)

``And does he (Prince) arrange,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham asked,
``to make up HIS (Prince) arrears?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
The question had risen to her (Assingham) lips--it was as if another morsel, on the dish, had tempted her (Assingham). The sound of it struck her (Assingham) own ear, immediately, as giving out more of her (Assingham) thought than she (Assingham) had as yet intended; but she (Assingham) quickly saw that she (Assingham) must follow it up, at any risk, with simplicity, and that what was simplest was the ease of boldness.
``Make them up, I mean, by coming to see YOU?'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte replied, however, without, as her (Charlotte) friend would have phrased it, turning a hair. She (Charlotte) shook her (Charlotte) head, but it was beautifully gentle.

``He (Prince) never comes.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Fanny)
said Fanny Assingham: with which she (Fanny) felt a little stupid.
``There it is. He (Prince) might so well, you know, otherwise.'' (unknown)

```Otherwise'?''--and Fanny was still vague.

It passed, this time, over her (Fanny) companion, whose eyes, wandering, to a distance, found themselves held. The Prince was at hand again; the Ambassador was still at his (Ambassador) side; they were stopped a moment by a uniformed personage, a little old man, of apparently the highest military character, bristling with medals and orders. This gave Charlotte time to go on.

``He (Prince) has not been for three months.'' (friend)
And then as with her (Charlotte) friend's last word in her (Charlotte) ear: ```Otherwise'--yes. He (friend) arranges otherwise. And in my position,'' she (Charlotte) added,
``I might too. It's too absurd we shouldn't meet.'' (unknown)

``You've met, I gather,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham,
``to-night.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Yes--as far as that goes. But what I mean is that I might--placed for it as we both are--go to see HIM.'' (unknown)

``And do you?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny asked with almost mistaken solemnity.

The perception of this excess made Charlotte, whether for gravity or for irony, hang fire a minute.

``I HAVE been. But that's nothing,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``in itself, and I tell you of it only to show you how our situation works. It essentially becomes one, a situation, for both of us. The Prince's, however, is his (Prince) own affair--I meant but to speak of mine.'' (she)

``Your situation's perfect,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham presently declared.

``I don't say it isn't. Taken, in fact, all round, I think it is. And I don't, as I tell you, complain of it. The only thing is that I have to act as it demands of me.'' (unknown)

``To `act'?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham with an irrepressible quaver.

``Isn't it acting, my dear, to accept it? I do accept it. What do you want me to do less?'' (unknown)

``I want you to believe that you're a very fortunate person.'' (unknown)

``Do you call that LESS?'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte asked with a smile.
``From the point of view of my freedom I call it more. Let it take, my position, any name you like.'' (unknown)

``Don't let it, at any rate'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--and Mrs. Assingham's impatience prevailed at last over her (Assingham) presence of mind--
``don't let it make you think too much of your freedom.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``I don't know what you call too much--for how can I not see it as it is? You'd see your own quickly enough if the Colonel gave you the same liberty--and I haven't to tell you, with your so much greater knowledge of everything, what it is that gives such liberty most. For yourself personally of course,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte went on,
``you only know the state of neither needing it nor missing it. Your husband doesn't treat you as of less importance to him (husband) than some other woman.'' (Charlotte)

``Ah, don't talk to me of other women!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny now overtly panted.
``Do you call Mr. Verver's perfectly natural interest in his (Verver) daughter--?'' (unknown)

``The greatest affection of which he (Verver) is capable?'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte took it up in all readiness.
``I do distinctly--and in spite of my having done all I could think of--to make him (Verver) capable of a greater. I've done, earnestly, everything I could--I've made it, month after month, my study. But I haven't succeeded--it has been vividly brought home to me to-night. However,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) pursued,
``I've hoped against hope, for I recognise that, as I told you at the time, I was duly warned.'' (she)
And then as she (Charlotte) met in her (Charlotte) friend's face the absence of any such remembrance:
``He (Verver) did tell me that he (Verver) wanted me just BECAUSE I could be useful about her (I).'' (friend)
With which Charlotte broke into a wonderful smile.
``So you see I AM!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

It was on Fanny Assingham's lips for the moment to reply that this was, on the contrary, exactly what she (Assingham) didn't see; she (Assingham) came in fact within an ace of saying:

``You strike me as having quite failed to help his (Verver) idea to work--since, by your account, Maggie has him (Verver) not less, but so much more, on her (Maggie) mind. How in the world, with so much of a remedy, comes there to remain so much of what was to be obviated?'' (she)
But she (Assingham) saved herself in time, conscious above all that she (Assingham) was in presence of still deeper things than she (Assingham) had yet dared to fear, that there was
``more in it'' (she)
than any admission she (Assingham) had made represented--and she (Assingham) had held herself familiar with admissions: so that, not to seem to understand where she (Assingham) couldn't accept, and not to seem to accept where she (Assingham) couldn't approve, and could still less, with precipitation, advise, she (Assingham) invoked the mere appearance of casting no weight whatever into the scales of her (Assingham) young friend's consistency. The only thing was that, as she (Assingham) was quickly enough to feel, she (Assingham) invoked it rather to excess. It brought her (Assingham), her (Assingham) invocation, too abruptly to her (Assingham) feet. She (Assingham) brushed away everything.
``I can't conceive, my dear, what you're talking about!'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte promptly rose then, as might be, to meet it, and her (Charlotte) colour, for the first time, perceptibly heightened. She (Charlotte) looked, for the minute, as her (Charlotte) companion had looked--as if twenty protests, blocking each other's way, had surged up within her (Charlotte). But when Charlotte had to make a selection, her (Charlotte) selection was always the most effective possible. It was happy now, above all, for being made not in anger but in sorrow.

``You give me up then?'' (unknown)

``Give you up--?'' (unknown)

``You forsake me at the hour of my life when it seems to me I most deserve a friend's loyalty? If you do you're not just, Fanny; you're even, I think,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``rather cruel; and it's least of all worthy of you to seem to wish to quarrel with me in order to cover your desertion.'' (she)
She (Charlotte) spoke, at the same time, with the noblest moderation of tone, and the image of high, pale, lighted disappointment she (Charlotte) meanwhile presented, as of a creature patient and lonely in her (Charlotte) splendour, was an impression so firmly imposed that she (Charlotte) could fill her (Charlotte) measure to the brim and yet enjoy the last word, as it is called in such cases, with a perfection void of any vulgarity of triumph. She (Charlotte) merely completed, for truth's sake, her (Charlotte) demonstration.
``What is a quarrel with me but a quarrel with my right to recognise the conditions of my bargain? But I can carry them out alone,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said as she (Charlotte) turned away. She (Charlotte) turned to meet the Ambassador and the Prince, who, their colloquy with their Field-Marshal ended, were now at hand and had already, between them, she (Charlotte) was aware, addressed her (Charlotte) a remark that failed to penetrate the golden glow in which her (Charlotte) intelligence was temporarily bathed. She (Charlotte) had made her (Charlotte) point, the point she (Charlotte) had foreseen she (Charlotte) must make; she (Charlotte) had made it thoroughly and once for all, so that no more making was required; and her (Charlotte) success was reflected in the faces of the two men of distinction before her (Charlotte), unmistakably moved to admiration by her (Charlotte) exceptional radiance. She (Charlotte) at first but watched this reflection, taking no note of any less adequate form of it possibly presented by poor Fanny--poor Fanny left to stare at her (Fanny) incurred
``score,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
chalked up in so few strokes on the wall; then she (Fanny) took in what the Ambassador was saying, in French, what he (Ambassador) was apparently repeating to her (Fanny).

``A desire for your presence, Madame, has been expressed en tres-haut lieu, and I've let myself in for the responsibility, to say nothing of the honour, of seeing, as the most respectful of your friends, that so august an impatience is not kept waiting.'' (The Personage)
The greatest possible Personage had, in short, according to the odd formula of societies subject to the greatest personages possible,
``sent for'' (the personages)
her (Fanny), and she (Fanny) asked, in her (Fanny) surprise,
``What in the world does he (my) want to do to me?'' (she)
only to know, without looking, that Fanny's bewilderment was called to a still larger application, and to hear the Prince say with authority, indeed with a certain prompt dryness:
``You must go immediately--it's a summons.'' (the Prince)
The Ambassador, using authority as well, had already somehow possessed himself of her (Fanny) hand, which he (Ambassador) drew into his (Ambassador) arm, and she (Fanny) was further conscious as she (Fanny) went off with him (Ambassador) that, though still speaking for her (Fanny) benefit, Amerigo had turned to Fanny Assingham. He (Ambassador) would explain afterwards--besides which she (Assingham) would understand for herself. To Fanny, however, he (Ambassador) had laughed--as a mark, apparently, that for this infallible friend no explanation at all would be necessary.

XV

It may be recorded none the less that the Prince was the next moment to see how little any such assumption was founded. Alone with him (Prince) now Mrs. Assingham was incorruptible.

``They send for Charlotte through YOU?'' (unknown)

``No, my dear; as you see, through the Ambassador.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but the Ambassador and you, for the last quarter-of-an-hour, have been for them as one. He (Ambassador)'s YOUR ambassador.'' (the Fanny)
It may indeed be further mentioned that the more Fanny looked at it the more she (Fanny) saw in it.
``They've connected her (Charlotte) with you--she (Charlotte)'s treated as your appendage.'' (unknown)

``Oh, my `appendage,''' the Prince amusedly exclaimed--

``cara mia, what a name! She (Charlotte)'s treated, rather, say, as my ornament and my glory. And it's so remarkable a case for a mother-in-law that you surely can't find fault with it.'' (unknown)

``You've ornaments enough, it seems to me--as you've certainly glories enough--without her (mother-in-law). And she (mother-in-law)'s not the least little bit,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham observed,
``your mother-in-law. In such a matter a shade of difference is enormous. She (mother-in-law)'s no relation to you whatever, and if she (mother-in-law)'s known in high quarters but as going about with you, then--then--!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
She (Assingham) failed, however, as from positive intensity of vision.
``Then, then what?'' (he)
he (Prince) asked with perfect good-nature.

``She (mother-in-law) had better in such a case not be known at all.'' (unknown)

``But I assure you I never, just now, so much as mentioned her (mother-in-law). Do you suppose I asked them,'' (the man)
said the young man, still amused,
``if they didn't want to see her (mother-in-law)? You surely don't need to be shown that Charlotte speaks for herself--that she (Charlotte) does so above all on such an occasion as this and looking as she (Charlotte) does to-night. How, so looking, can she (Charlotte) pass unnoticed? How can she (Charlotte) not have `success'? Besides,'' (the man)
he (man) added as she (Assingham) but watched his (man) face, letting him (man) say what he (man) would, as if she (Assingham) wanted to see how he (man) would say it,
``besides, there IS always the fact that we're of the same connection, of--what is your word?--the same `concern.' We're certainly not, with the relation of our respective sposi, simply formal acquaintances. We're in the same boat'' (he)
--and the Prince smiled with a candour that added an accent to his (Prince) emphasis.

Fanny Assingham was full of the special sense of his (Prince) manner: it caused her (Assingham) to turn for a moment's refuge to a corner of her (Assingham) general consciousness in which she (Assingham) could say to herself that she (Assingham) was glad SHE wasn't in love with such a man. As with Charlotte just before, she (Charlotte) was embarrassed by the difference between what she (Charlotte) took in and what she (Charlotte) could say, what she (Charlotte) felt and what she (Charlotte) could show.

``It only appears to me of great importance that--now that you all seem more settled here--Charlotte should be known, for any presentation, any further circulation or introduction, as, in particular, her (Charlotte) husband's wife; known in the least possible degree as anything else. I don't know what you mean by the `same' boat. Charlotte is naturally in Mr. Verver's boat.'' (unknown)

``And, pray, am _I_ not in Mr. Verver's boat too? Why, but for Mr. Verver's boat, I should have been by this time'' (She)
--and his (man) quick Italian gesture, an expressive direction and motion of his (man) forefinger, pointed to deepest depths--
``away down, down, down.'' (She)
She (Charlotte) knew of course what he (man) meant--how it had taken his (man) father-in-law's great fortune, and taken no small slice, to surround him (man) with an element in which, all too fatally weighted as he (man) had originally been, he (man) could pecuniarily float; and with this reminder other things came to her (Charlotte)--how strange it was that, with all allowance for their merit, it should befall some people to be so inordinately valued, quoted, as they said in the stock-market, so high, and how still stranger, perhaps, that there should be cases in which, for some reason, one didn't mind the so frequently marked absence in them of the purpose really to represent their price. She (Charlotte) was thinking, feeling, at any rate, for herself; she (Charlotte) was thinking that the pleasure SHE could take in this specimen of the class didn't suffer from his (stranger) consent to be merely made buoyant: partly because it was one of those pleasures -LRB-he (stranger) inspired them-RRB- that, by their nature, COULDN'T suffer, to whatever proof they were put; and partly because, besides, he (stranger) after all visibly had on his (stranger) conscience some sort of return for services rendered. He (stranger) was a huge expense assuredly--but it had been up to now her (Charlotte) conviction that his (stranger) idea was to behave beautifully enough to make the beauty well nigh an equivalent. And that he (stranger) had carried out his (stranger) idea, carried it out by continuing to lead the life, to breathe the air, very nearly to think the thoughts, that best suited his (stranger) wife and her (wife) father-- this she (wife) had till lately enjoyed the comfort of so distinctly perceiving as to have even been moved more than once, to express to him (stranger) the happiness it gave her (wife). He (stranger) had that in his (stranger) favour as against other matters; yet it discouraged her (wife) too, and rather oddly, that he (stranger) should so keep moving, and be able to show her (wife) that he (stranger) moved, on the firm ground of the truth. His (stranger) acknowledgment of obligation was far from unimportant, but she (wife) could find in his (stranger) grasp of the real itself a kind of ominous intimation. The intimation appeared to peep at her (wife) even out of his (stranger) next word, lightly as he (stranger) produced it.

``Isn't it rather as if we had, Charlotte and I, for bringing us together, a benefactor in common?'' (unknown)
And the effect, for his (stranger) interlocutress, was still further to be deepened.
``I somehow feel, half the time, as if he (benefactor) were her (Charlotte) father-in-law too. It's as if he (benefactor) had saved us both--which is a fact in our lives, or at any rate in our hearts, to make of itself a link. Don't you remember'' (he)
--he (stranger) kept it up--
``how, the day she (Charlotte) suddenly turned up for you, just before my wedding, we so frankly and funnily talked, in her (Charlotte) presence, of the advisability, for her (Charlotte), of some good marriage?'' (he)
And then as his (stranger) friend's face, in her (wife) extremity, quite again as with Charlotte, but continued to fly the black flag of general repudiation:
``Well, we really began then, as it seems to me, the work of placing her (Charlotte) where she (Charlotte) is. We were wholly right--and so was she (Charlotte). That it was exactly the thing is shown by its success. We recommended a good marriage at almost any price, so to speak, and, taking us at our word, she (Charlotte) has made the very best. That was really what we meant, wasn't it? Only--what she (Charlotte) has got--something thoroughly good. It would be difficult, it seems to me, for her (Charlotte) to have anything better--once you allow her (Charlotte) the way it's to be taken. Of course if you don't allow her (Charlotte) that the case is different. Her (Charlotte) offset is a certain decent freedom-- which, I judge, she (Charlotte)'ll be quite contented with. You may say that will be very good of her (Charlotte), but she (Charlotte) strikes me as perfectly humble about it. She (Charlotte) proposes neither to claim it nor to use it with any sort of retentissement. She (Charlotte) would enjoy it, I think, quite as quietly as it might be given. The `boat,' you see'' (Charlotte)
--the Prince explained it no less considerately and lucidly--
``is a good deal tied up at the dock, or anchored, if you like, out in the stream. I have to jump out from time to time to stretch my legs, and you'll probably perceive, if you give it your attention, that Charlotte really can't help occasionally doing the same. It isn't even a question, sometimes, of one's getting to the dock--one has to take a header and splash about in the water. Call our having remained here together to-night, call the accident of my having put them, put our illustrious friends there, on my companion's track--for I grant you this as a practical result of our combination--call the whole thing one of the harmless little plunges off the deck, inevitable for each of us. Why not take them, when they occur, as inevitable--and, above all, as not endangering life or limb? We shan't drown, we shan't sink--at least I can answer for myself. Mrs. Verver too, moreover--do her (Verver) the justice--visibly knows how to swim.'' (Prince)

He (Prince) could easily go on, for she (Charlotte) didn't interrupt him (Prince); Fanny felt now that she (Fanny) wouldn't have interrupted him (Prince) for the world. She (Fanny) found his (Prince) eloquence precious; there was not a drop of it that she (Fanny) didn't, in a manner, catch, as it came, for immediate bottling, for future preservation. The crystal flask of her (Fanny) innermost attention really received it on the spot, and she (Fanny) had even already the vision of how, in the snug laboratory of her (Fanny) afterthought, she (Fanny) should be able chemically to analyse it. There were moments, positively, still beyond this, when, with the meeting of their eyes, something as yet unnamable came out for her (Fanny) in his (it) look, when something strange and subtle and at variance with his (it) words, something that GAVE THEM AWAY, glimmered deep down, as an appeal, almost an incredible one, to her (Fanny) finer comprehension. What, inconceivably, was it like? Wasn't it, however gross, such a rendering of anything so occult, fairly like a quintessential wink, a hint of the possibility of their REALLY treating their subject--of course on some better occasion--and thereby, as well, finding it much more interesting? If this far red spark, which might have been figured by her (Fanny) mind as the head-light of an approaching train seen through the length of a tunnel, was not, on her (Fanny) side, an ignis fatuus, a mere subjective phenomenon, it twinkled there at the direct expense of what the Prince was inviting her (Fanny) to understand. Meanwhile too, however, and unmistakably, the real treatment of their subject did, at a given moment, sound. This was when he (Prince) proceeded, with just the same perfect possession of his (Prince) thought--on the manner of which he (Prince) couldn't have improved--to complete his (Prince) successful simile by another, in fact by just the supreme touch, the touch for which it had till now been waiting.

``For Mrs. Verver to be known to people so intensely and exclusively as her (Verver) husband's wife, something is wanted that, you know, they haven't exactly got. He (husband) should manage to be known--or at least to be seen--a little more as his (husband) wife's husband. You surely must by this time have seen for yourself that he (husband) has his (husband) own habits and his (husband) own ways, and that he (husband) makes, more and more--as of course he (husband) has a perfect right to do--his (husband) own discriminations. He (husband)'s so perfect, so ideal a father, and, doubtless largely by that very fact, a generous, a comfortable, an admirable father-in-law, that I should really feel it base to avail myself of any standpoint whatever to criticise him (father-in-law). To YOU, nevertheless, I may make just one remark; for you're not stupid--you always understand so blessedly what one means.'' (He)

He (Prince) paused an instant, as if even this one remark might be difficult for him (Prince) should she (Fanny) give no sign of encouraging him (Prince) to produce it. Nothing would have induced her (Fanny), however, to encourage him (Prince); she (Fanny) was now conscious of having never in her (Fanny) life stood so still or sat, inwardly, as it were, so tight; she (Fanny) felt like the horse of the adage, brought--and brought by her (Fanny) own fault--to the water, but strong, for the occasion, in the one fact that she (Fanny) couldn't be forced to drink. Invited, in other words, to understand, she (Fanny) held her (Fanny) breath for fear of showing she (Fanny) did, and this for the excellent reason that she (Fanny) was at last fairly afraid to. It was sharp for her (Fanny), at the same time, that she (Fanny) was certain, in advance, of his (Fanny) remark; that she (Fanny) heard it before it had sounded, that she (Fanny) already tasted, in fine, the bitterness it would have for her (Fanny) special sensibility. But her (Fanny) companion, from an inward and different need of his (companion) own, was presently not deterred by her (Fanny) silence.

``What I really don't see is why, from his (father-in-law) own point of view--given, that is, his (father-in-law) conditions, so fortunate as they stood--he (father-in-law) should have wished to marry at all.'' (she)
There it was then--exactly what she (Fanny) knew would come, and exactly, for reasons that seemed now to thump at her (Fanny) heart, as distressing to her (Fanny). Yet she (Fanny) was resolved, meanwhile, not to suffer, as they used to say of the martyrs, then and there; not to suffer, odiously, helplessly, in public--which could be prevented but by her (Fanny) breaking off, with whatever inconsequence; by her (Fanny) treating their discussion as ended and getting away. She (Fanny) suddenly wanted to go home much as she (Fanny) had wanted, an hour or two before, to come. She (Fanny) wanted to leave well behind her (Fanny) both her (Fanny) question and the couple in whom it had, abruptly, taken such vivid form--but it was dreadful to have the appearance of disconcerted flight. Discussion had of itself, to her (Fanny) sense, become danger--such light, as from open crevices, it let in; and the overt recognition of danger was worse than anything else. The worst in fact came while she (Fanny) was thinking how she (Fanny) could retreat and still not overtly recognise. Her (Fanny) face had betrayed her (Fanny) trouble, and with that she (Fanny) was lost.
``I'm afraid, however,'' (Prince)
the Prince said,
``that I, for some reason, distress you--for which I beg your pardon. We've always talked so well together--it has been, from the beginning, the greatest pull for me.'' (Prince)
Nothing so much as such a tone could have quickened her (Fanny) collapse; she (Fanny) felt he (Prince) had her (Fanny) now at his (Prince) mercy, and he (Prince) showed, as he (Prince) went on, that he (Prince) knew it.
``We shall talk again, all the same, better than ever--I depend on it too much. Don't you remember what I told you, so definitely, one day before my marriage?--that, moving as I did in so many ways among new things, mysteries, conditions, expectations, assumptions different from any I had known, I looked to you, as my original sponsor, my fairy godmother, to see me through. I beg you to believe,'' (he)
he (Prince) added,
``that I look to you yet.'' (he)

His (Prince) very insistence had, fortunately, the next moment, affected her (Fanny) as bringing her (Fanny) help; with which, at least, she (Fanny) could hold up her (Fanny) head to speak.

``Ah, you ARE through--you were through long ago. Or if you aren't you ought to be.'' (unknown)

``Well then, if I ought to be it's all the more reason why you should continue to help me. Because, very distinctly, I assure you, I'm not. The new things or ever so many of them--are still for me new things; the mysteries and expectations and assumptions still contain an immense element that I've failed to puzzle out. As we've happened, so luckily, to find ourselves again really taking hold together, you must let me, as soon as possible, come to see you; you must give me a good, kind hour. If you refuse it me'' (he)
--and he (Prince) addressed himself to her (Fanny) continued reserve--
``I shall feel that you deny, with a stony stare, your responsibility.'' (he)

At this, as from a sudden shake, her (Fanny) reserve proved an inadequate vessel. She (Fanny) could bear her (Fanny) own, her (Fanny) private reference to the weight on her (Fanny) mind, but the touch of another hand made it too horribly press.

``Oh, I deny responsibility--to YOU. So far as I ever had it I've done with it.'' (He)

He (Prince) had been, all the while, beautifully smiling; but she (Fanny) made his (Prince) look, now, penetrate her (Fanny) again more.

``As to whom then do you confess it?'' (unknown)

``Ah, mio caro, that's--if to anyone--my own business!'' (He)

He (Prince) continued to look at her (Fanny) hard.

``You give me up then?'' (Charlotte)

It was what Charlotte had asked her (Charlotte) ten minutes before, and its coming from him (Prince) so much in the same way shook her (Charlotte) in her (Charlotte) place. She (Charlotte) was on the point of replying

``Do you and she (you) agree together for what you'll say to me?'' (She)
--but she (Charlotte) was glad afterwards to have checked herself in time, little as her (Charlotte) actual answer had perhaps bettered it.
``I think I don't know what to make of you.'' (unknown)

``You must receive me at least,'' (he)
he (Prince) said.

``Oh, please, not till I'm ready for you!'' (she)
--and, though she (Charlotte) found a laugh for it, she (Charlotte) had to turn away. She (Charlotte) had never turned away from him (Prince) before, and it was quite positively for her (Charlotte) as if she (Charlotte) were altogether afraid of him (Prince).

XVI

Later on, when their hired brougham had, with the long vociferation that tormented her (Charlotte) impatience, been extricated from the endless rank, she (Charlotte) rolled into the London night, beside her (Charlotte) husband, as into a sheltering darkness where she (Charlotte) could muffle herself and draw breath. She (Charlotte) had stood for the previous half-hour in a merciless glare, beaten upon, stared out of countenance, it fairly seemed to her (Charlotte), by intimations of her (Charlotte) mistake. For what she (Charlotte) was most immediately feeling was that she (Charlotte) had, in the past, been active, for these people, to ends that were now bearing fruit and that might yet bear a larger crop. She (Charlotte) but brooded, at first, in her (Charlotte) corner of the carriage: it was like burying her (Charlotte) exposed face, a face too helplessly exposed, in the cool lap of the common indifference, of the dispeopled streets, of the closed shops and darkened houses seen through the window of the brougham, a world mercifully unconscious and unreproachful. It wouldn't, like the world she (Charlotte) had just left, know sooner or later what she (Charlotte) had done, or would know it, at least, only if the final consequence should be some quite overwhelming publicity. She (Charlotte) fixed this possibility itself so hard, however, for a few moments, that the misery of her (Charlotte) fear produced the next minute a reaction; and when the carriage happened, while it grazed a turn, to catch the straight shaft from the lamp of a policeman in the act of playing his (policeman) inquisitive flash over an opposite house-front, she (Charlotte) let herself wince at being thus incriminated only that she (Charlotte) might protest, not less quickly, against mere blind terror. It had become, for the occasion, preposterously, terror--of which she (Charlotte) must shake herself free before she (Charlotte) could properly measure her (Charlotte) ground. The perception of this necessity had in truth soon aided her (Charlotte); since she (Charlotte) found, on trying, that, lurid as her (Charlotte) prospect might hover there, she (Charlotte) could none the less give it no name. The sense of seeing was strong in her (Charlotte), but she (Charlotte) clutched at the comfort of not being sure of what she (Charlotte) saw. Not to know what it would represent on a longer view was a help, in turn, to not making out that her (Charlotte) hands were embrued; since if she (Charlotte) had stood in the position of a producing cause she (Charlotte) should surely be less vague about what she (Charlotte) had produced. This, further, in its way, was a step toward reflecting that when one's connection with any matter was too indirect to be traced it might be described also as too slight to be deplored. By the time they were nearing Cadogan Place she (Charlotte) had in fact recognised that she (Charlotte) couldn't be as curious as she (Charlotte) desired without arriving at some conviction of her (Charlotte) being as innocent. But there had been a moment, in the dim desert of Eaton Square, when she (Charlotte) broke into speech.

``It's only their defending themselves so much more than they need--it's only THAT that makes me wonder. It's their having so remarkably much to say for themselves.'' (husband)

Her (Charlotte) husband had, as usual, lighted his (husband) cigar, remaining apparently as busy with it as she (Charlotte) with her (Charlotte) agitation.

``You mean it makes you feel that you have nothing?'' (she)
To which, as she (Charlotte) made no answer, the Colonel added:
``What in the world did you ever suppose was going to happen? The man's in a position in which he (man) has nothing in life to do.'' (the Colonel)

Her (Charlotte) silence seemed to characterise this statement as superficial, and her (Charlotte) thoughts, as always in her (Charlotte) husband's company, pursued an independent course. He (husband) made her (Charlotte), when they were together, talk, but as if for some other person; who was in fact for the most part herself. Yet she (Charlotte) addressed herself with him (husband) as she (Charlotte) could never have done without him (husband).

``He (man) has behaved beautifully--he (man) did from the first. I've thought it, all along, wonderful of him (man); and I've more than once, when I've had a chance, told him (man) so. Therefore, therefore--!'' (she)
But it died away as she (Charlotte) mused.

``Therefore he (man) has a right, for a change, to kick up his (man) heels?'' (unknown)

``It isn't a question, of course, however,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) undivertedly went on,
``of their behaving beautifully apart. It's a question of their doing as they should when together--which is another matter.'' (she)

``And how do you think then,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel asked with interest,
``that, when together, they SHOULD do? The less they do, one would say, the better--if you see so much in it.'' (the Colonel)

His (Colonel) wife, at this, appeared to hear him (Colonel).

``I don't see in it what YOU'D see. And don't, my dear,'' (she)
she (wife) further answered,
``think it necessary to be horrid or low about them. They're the last people, really, to make anything of that sort come in right.'' (she)

``I'm surely never horrid or low,'' (he)
he (Colonel) returned,
``about anyone but my extravagant wife. I can do with all our friends--as I see them myself: what I can't do with is the figures you make of them. And when you take to adding your figures up--!'' (he)
But he (Colonel) exhaled it again in smoke.

``My additions don't matter when you've not to pay the bill.'' (unknown)
With which her (wife) meditation again bore her (wife) through the air.
``The great thing was that when it so suddenly came up for her (wife) he (our) wasn't afraid. If he (our) had been afraid he (our) could perfectly have prevented it. And if I had seen he (our) was--if I hadn't seen he (our) wasn't--so,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham,
``could I. So,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) declared,
``WOULD I. It's perfectly true,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on--
``it was too good a thing for her (wife), such a chance in life, not to be accepted. And I LIKED his (our) not keeping her (wife) out of it merely from a fear of his (our) own nature. It was so wonderful it should come to her (wife). The only thing would have been if Charlotte herself couldn't have faced it. Then, if SHE had not had confidence, we might have talked. But she (Charlotte) had it to any amount.'' (she)

``Did you ask her (Charlotte) how much?'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham patiently inquired.

He (Assingham) had put the question with no more than his (Assingham) usual modest hope of reward, but he (Assingham) had pressed, this time, the sharpest spring of response.

``Never, never--it wasn't a time to `ask.' Asking is suggesting--and it wasn't a time to suggest. One had to make up one's mind, as quietly as possible, by what one could judge. And I judge, as I say, that Charlotte felt she (Charlotte) could face it. For which she (Charlotte) struck me at the time as--for so proud a creature--almost touchingly grateful. The thing I should never forgive her (Charlotte) for would be her (Charlotte) forgetting to whom it is her (Charlotte) thanks have remained most due.'' (unknown)

``That is to Mrs. Assingham?'' (She)

She (Assingham) said nothing for a little--there were, after all, alternatives.

``Maggie herself of course--astonishing little Maggie.'' (unknown)

``Is Maggie then astonishing too?'' (he)
--and he (Assingham) gloomed out of his (Assingham) window.

His (Assingham) wife, on her (wife) side now, as they rolled, projected the same look.

``I'm not sure that I don't begin to see more in her (Maggie) than--dear little person as I've always thought--I ever supposed there was. I'm not sure that, putting a good many things together, I'm not beginning to make her (Maggie) out rather extraordinary.'' (unknown)

``You certainly will if you can,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel resignedly remarked.

Again his (Colonel) companion said nothing; then again she (wife) broke out.

``In fact--I do begin to feel it--Maggie's the great comfort. I'm getting hold of it. It will be SHE who'll see us through. In fact she (Maggie)'ll have to. And she (Maggie)'ll be able.'' (husband)
