Touch by touch her (wife) meditation had completed it, but with a cumulative effect for her (wife) husband's general sense of her (wife) method that caused him (husband) to overflow, whimsically enough, in his (husband) corner, into an ejaculation now frequent on his (husband) lips for the relief that, especially in communion like the present, it gave him (husband), and that Fanny had critically traced to the quaint example, the aboriginal homeliness, still so delightful, of Mr. Verver.

``Oh, Lordy, Lordy!'' (unknown)

``If she (Maggie) is, however,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham continued,
``she (Maggie)'ll be extraordinary enough--and that's what I'm thinking of. But I'm not indeed so very sure,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) added,
``of the person to whom Charlotte ought in decency to be most grateful. I mean I'm not sure if that person is even almost the incredible little idealist who has made her (Charlotte) his (idealist) wife.'' (she)

``I shouldn't think you would be, love,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel with some promptness responded.
``Charlotte as the wife of an incredible little idealist--!'' (unknown)
His (Colonel) cigar, in short, once more, could alone express it.

``Yet what is that, when one thinks, but just what she (Charlotte) struck one as more or less persuaded that she (Charlotte) herself was really going to be?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
--this memory, for the full view, Fanny found herself also invoking.

It made her (Fanny) companion, in truth, slightly gape.

``An incredible little idealist--Charlotte herself?'' (unknown)

``And she (Charlotte) was sincere,'' (wife)
his (companion) wife simply proceeded
``she (Charlotte) was unmistakably sincere. The question is only how much is left of it.'' (wife)

``And that--I see--happens to be another of the questions you can't ask her (Charlotte). You have to do it all,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
said Bob Assingham,
``as if you were playing some game with its rules drawn up--though who's to come down on you if you break them I don't quite see. Or must you do it in three guesses--like forfeits on Christmas eve?'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
To which, as his (Assingham) ribaldry but dropped from her (wife), he (Assingham) further added:
``How much of anything will have to be left for you to be able to go on with it?'' (he)

``I shall go on,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham a trifle grimly declared,
``while there's a scrap as big as your nail. But we're not yet, luckily, reduced only to that.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
She (Assingham) had another pause, holding the while the thread of that larger perception into which her (Assingham) view of Mrs. Verver's obligation to Maggie had suddenly expanded.
``Even if her (its) debt was not to the others--even then it ought to be quite sufficiently to the Prince himself to keep her (its) straight. For what, really, did the Prince do,'' (she)
she (Assingham) asked herself,
``but generously trust her (its)? What did he (Prince) do but take it from her (its) that if she (its) felt herself willing it was because she (its) felt herself strong? That creates for her (its), upon my word,'' (she)
Mrs. Assingham pursued,
``a duty of considering him (Prince), of honourably repaying his (Prince) trust, which--well, which she (its)'ll be really a fiend if she (its) doesn't make the law of her (its) conduct. I mean of course his (Prince) trust that she (its) wouldn't interfere with him (Prince)--expressed by his (Prince) holding himself quiet at the critical time.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

The brougham was nearing home, and it was perhaps this sense of ebbing opportunity that caused the Colonel's next meditation to flower in a fashion almost surprising to his (Colonel) wife. They were united, for the most part, but by his (Colonel) exhausted patience; so that indulgent despair was generally, at the best, his (Colonel) note. He (Colonel) at present, however, actually compromised with his (Colonel) despair to the extent of practically admitting that he (Colonel) had followed her (wife) steps. He (Colonel) literally asked, in short, an intelligent, well nigh a sympathising, question.

``Gratitude to the Prince for not having put a spoke in her (its) wheel--that, you mean, should, taking it in the right way, be precisely the ballast of her (its) boat?'' (unknown)

``Taking it in the right way.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny, catching at this gleam, emphasised the proviso.

``But doesn't it rather depend on what she (its) may most feel to BE the right way?'' (unknown)

``No--it depends on nothing. Because there's only one way--for duty or delicacy.'' (unknown)

``Oh--delicacy!'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
Bob Assingham rather crudely murmured.

``I mean the highest kind--moral. Charlotte's perfectly capable of appreciating that. By every dictate of moral delicacy she (Charlotte) must let him (its) alone.'' (unknown)

``Then you've made up your mind it's all poor Charlotte?'' (he)
he (Assingham) asked with an effect of abruptness.

The effect, whether intended or not, reached her (Fanny)--brought her (Fanny) face short round. It was a touch at which she (Fanny) again lost her (Fanny) balance, at which, somehow, the bottom dropped out of her (Fanny) recovered comfort.

``Then you've made up yours differently? It really struck you that there IS something?'' (him)

The movement itself, apparently, made him (Assingham) once more stand off. He (Assingham) had felt on his (Assingham) nearer approach the high temperature of the question.

``Perhaps that's just what she (Charlotte)'s doing: showing him (its) how much she (Charlotte)'s letting him (its) alone--pointing it out to him (its) from day to day.'' (unknown)

``Did she (Charlotte) point it out by waiting for him (its) to-night on the stair-case in the manner you described to me?'' (unknown)

``I really, my dear, described to you a manner?'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel, clearly, from want of habit, scarce recognised himself in the imputation.

``Yes--for once in a way; in those few words we had after you had watched them come up you told me something of what you had seen. You didn't tell me very much--THAT you couldn't for your life; but I saw for myself that, strange to say, you had received your impression, and I felt therefore that there must indeed have been something out of the way for you so to betray it.'' (She)
She (Fanny) was fully upon him (Colonel) now, and she (Fanny) confronted him (Colonel) with his (Colonel) proved sensibility to the occasion--confronted him (Colonel) because of her (Fanny) own uneasy need to profit by it. It came over her (Fanny) still more than at the time, it came over her (Fanny) that he (Colonel) had been struck with something, even HE (Colonel), poor dear man; and that for this to have occurred there must have been much to be struck with. She (Fanny) tried in fact to corner him (Colonel), to pack him (Colonel) insistently down, in the truth of his (Colonel) plain vision, the very plainness of which was its value; for so recorded, she (Fanny) felt, none of it would escape--she (Fanny) should have it at hand for reference.
``Come, my dear--you thought what you thought: in the presence of what you saw you couldn't resist thinking. I don't ask more of it than that. And your idea is worth, this time, quite as much as any of mine--so that you can't pretend, as usual, that mine has run away with me. I haven't caught up with you. I stay where I am. But I see,'' (she)
she (Fanny) concluded,
``where you are, and I'm much obliged to you for letting me. You give me a point de repere outside myself--which is where I like it. Now I can work round you.'' (she)

Their conveyance, as she (Fanny) spoke, stopped at their door, and it was, on the spot, another fact of value for her (Fanny) that her (Fanny) husband, though seated on the side by which they must alight, made no movement. They were in a high degree votaries of the latch-key, so that their household had gone to bed; and as they were unaccompanied by a footman the coachman waited in peace. It was so indeed that for a minute Bob Assingham waited--conscious of a reason for replying to this address otherwise than by the so obvious method of turning his (Assingham) back. He (Assingham) didn't turn his (Assingham) face, but he (Assingham) stared straight before him (Assingham), and his (Assingham) wife had already perceived in the fact of his (Assingham) not moving all the proof she (wife) could desire-- proof, that is, of her (wife) own contention. She (wife) knew he (Assingham) never cared what she (wife) said, and his (Assingham) neglect of his (Assingham) chance to show it was thereby the more eloquent.

``Leave it,'' (he)
he (Assingham) at last remarked,
``to THEM.'' (he)

```Leave' it--?'' She (wife) wondered.

``Let them alone. They'll manage.'' (unknown)

``They'll manage, you mean, to do everything they want? Ah, there then you are!'' (unknown)

``They'll manage in their own way,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel almost cryptically repeated.

It had its effect for her (wife): quite apart from its light on the familiar phenomenon of her (wife) husband's indurated conscience, it gave her (wife), full in her (wife) face, the particular evocation of which she (wife) had made him (husband) guilty. It was wonderful truly, then, the evocation.

``So cleverly--THAT'S your idea?--that no one will be the wiser? It's your idea that we shall have done all that's required of us if we simply protect them?'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel, still in his (Colonel) place, declined, however, to be drawn into a statement of his (Colonel) idea. Statements were too much like theories, in which one lost one's way; he (Colonel) only knew what he (Colonel) said, and what he (Colonel) said represented the limited vibration of which his (Colonel) confirmed old toughness had been capable. Still, none the less, he (Colonel) had his (Colonel) point to make--for which he (Colonel) took another instant. But he (Colonel) made it, for the third time, in the same fashion.

``They'll manage in their own way.'' (he)
With which he (Colonel) got out.

Oh yes, at this, for his (Colonel) companion, it had indeed its effect, and while he (Colonel) mounted their steps she (Colonel) but stared, without following him (Colonel), at his (Colonel) opening of their door. Their hall was lighted, and as he (Colonel) stood in the aperture looking back at her (Colonel), his (Colonel) tall lean figure outlined in darkness and with his (Colonel) crush-hat, according to his (Colonel) wont, worn cavalierly, rather diabolically, askew, he (Colonel) seemed to prolong the sinister emphasis of his (Colonel) meaning. In general, on these returns, he (Colonel) came back for her (Colonel) when he (Colonel) had prepared their entrance; so that it was now as if he (Colonel) were ashamed to face her (Colonel) in closer quarters. He (Colonel) looked at her (Colonel) across the interval, and, still in her (Colonel) seat, weighing his (Colonel) charge, she (Colonel) felt her (Colonel) whole view of everything flare up. Wasn't it simply what had been written in the Prince's own face BENEATH what he (Prince) was saying?--didn't it correspond with the mocking presence there that she (Colonel) had had her (Colonel) troubled glimpse of? Wasn't, in fine, the pledge that they would

``manage in their own way'' (he)
the thing he (Prince) had been feeling for his (Prince) chance to invite her (Colonel) to take from him (Prince)? Her (Colonel) husband's tone somehow fitted Amerigo's look--the one that had, for her (Colonel), so strangely, peeped, from behind, over the shoulder of the one in front. She (Colonel) had not then read it--but wasn't she (Colonel) reading it when she (Colonel) now saw in it his (Prince) surmise that she (Colonel) was perhaps to be squared? She (Colonel) wasn't to be squared, and while she (Colonel) heard her (Colonel) companion call across to her (Colonel)
``Well, what's the matter?'' (companion)
she (Colonel) also took time to remind herself that she (Colonel) had decided she (Colonel) couldn't be frightened. The
``matter'' (unknown)
?--why, it was sufficiently the matter, with all this, that she (Colonel) felt a little sick. For it was not the Prince that she (Colonel) had been prepared to regard as primarily the shaky one. Shakiness in Charlotte she (Charlotte) had, at the most, perhaps postulated--it would be, she (Charlotte) somehow felt, more easy to deal with. Therefore if HE (Prince) had come so far it was a different pair of sleeves. There was nothing to choose between them. It made her (Charlotte) so helpless that, as the time passed without her (Charlotte) alighting, the Colonel came back and fairly drew her (Charlotte) forth; after which, on the pavement, under the street-lamp, their very silence might have been the mark of something grave--their silence eked out for her (Charlotte) by his (Colonel) giving her (Charlotte) his (Colonel) arm and their then crawling up their steps quite mildly and unitedly together, like some old Darby and Joan who have had a disappointment. It almost resembled a return from a funeral--unless indeed it resembled more the hushed approach to a house of mourning. What indeed had she (Joan) come home for but to bury, as decently as possible, her (Joan) mistake?

XVII

It appeared thus that they might enjoy together extraordinary freedom, the two friends, from the moment they should understand their position aright. With the Prince himself, from an early stage, not unnaturally, Charlotte had made a great point of their so understanding it; she (Charlotte) had found frequent occasion to describe to him (Prince) this necessity, and, her (Charlotte) resignation tempered, or her (Charlotte) intelligence at least quickened, by irrepressible irony, she (Charlotte) applied at different times different names to the propriety of their case. The wonderful thing was that her (Charlotte) sense of propriety had been, from the first, especially alive about it. There were hours when she (Charlotte) spoke of their taking refuge in what she (Charlotte) called the commonest tact--as if this principle alone would suffice to light their way; there were others when it might have seemed, to listen to her (Charlotte), that their course would demand of them the most anxious study and the most independent, not to say original, interpretation of signs. She (Charlotte) talked now as if it were indicated, at every turn, by finger-posts of almost ridiculous prominence; she (Charlotte) talked again as if it lurked in devious ways and were to be tracked through bush and briar; and she (Charlotte) even, on occasion, delivered herself in the sense that, as their situation was unprecedented, so their heaven was without stars. ```Do'?'' she (Charlotte) once had echoed to him (their) as the upshot of passages covertly, though briefly, occurring between them on her (Charlotte) return from the visit to America that had immediately succeeded her (Charlotte) marriage, determined for her (Charlotte) by this event as promptly as an excursion of the like strange order had been prescribed in his (their) own case.

``Isn't the immense, the really quite matchless beauty of our position that we have to `do' nothing in life at all?--nothing except the usual, necessary, everyday thing which consists in one's not being more of a fool than one can help. That's all--but that's as true for one time as for another. There has been plenty of `doing,' and there will doubtless be plenty still; but it's all theirs, every inch of it; it's all a matter of what they've done TO us.'' (unknown)
And she (Charlotte) showed how the question had therefore been only of their taking everything as everything came, and all as quietly as might be. Nothing stranger surely had ever happened to a conscientious, a well-meaning, a perfectly passive pair: no more extraordinary decree had ever been launched against such victims than this of forcing them against their will into a relation of mutual close contact that they had done everything to avoid.

She (Charlotte) was to remember not a little, meanwhile, the particular prolonged silent look with which the Prince had met her (Charlotte) allusion to these primary efforts at escape. She (Charlotte) was inwardly to dwell on the element of the unuttered that her (Charlotte) tone had caused to play up into his (Prince) irresistible eyes; and this because she (Charlotte) considered with pride and joy that she (Charlotte) had, on the spot, disposed of the doubt, the question, the challenge, or whatever else might have been, that such a look could convey. He (Prince) had been sufficiently off his (Prince) guard to show some little wonder as to their having plotted so very hard against their destiny, and she (Charlotte) knew well enough, of course, what, in this connection, was at the bottom of his (Prince) thought, and what would have sounded out more or less if he (Prince) had not happily saved himself from words. All men were brutes enough to catch when they might at such chances for dissent--for all the good it really did them; but the Prince's distinction was in being one of the few who could check himself before acting on the impulse. This, obviously, was what counted in a man as delicacy. If her (Charlotte) friend had blurted or bungled he (friend) would have said, in his (friend) simplicity,

``Did we do `everything to avoid' it when we faced your remarkable marriage?'' (he)
--quite handsomely of course using the plural, taking his (friend) share of the case, by way of a tribute of memory to the telegram she (Charlotte) had received from him (friend) in Paris after Mr. Verver had despatched to Rome the news of their engagement. That telegram, that acceptance of the prospect proposed to them--an acceptance quite other than perfunctory--she (Charlotte) had never destroyed; though reserved for no eyes but her (Charlotte) own it was still carefully reserved. She (Charlotte) kept it in a safe place--from which, very privately, she (Charlotte) sometimes took it out to read it over.
``A la guerre comme a la guerre then'' (unknown)
--it had been couched in the French tongue.
``We must lead our lives as we see them; but I am charmed with your courage and almost surprised at my own.'' (unknown)
The message had remained ambiguous; she (Charlotte) had read it in more lights than one; it might mean that even without her (Charlotte) his (it) career was up-hill work for him (it), a daily fighting-matter on behalf of a good appearance, and that thus, if they were to become neighbours again, the event would compel him (it) to live still more under arms. It might mean on the other hand that he (it) found he (it) was happy enough, and that accordingly, so far as she (Charlotte) might imagine herself a danger, she (Charlotte) was to think of him (it) as prepared in advance, as really seasoned and secure. On his (it) arrival in Paris with his (it) wife, none the less, she (wife) had asked for no explanation, just as he (it) himself had not asked if the document were still in her (wife) possession. Such an inquiry, everything implied, was beneath him (it)--just as it was beneath herself to mention to him (it), uninvited, that she (wife) had instantly offered, and in perfect honesty, to show the telegram to Mr. Verver, and that if this companion had but said the word she (wife) would immediately have put it before him (companion). She (wife) had thereby forborne to call his (companion) attention to her (wife) consciousness that such an exposure would, in all probability, straightway have dished her (wife) marriage; that all her (wife) future had in fact, for the moment, hung by the single hair of Mr. Verver's delicacy -LRB-as she (wife) supposed they must call it-RRB-; and that her (wife) position, in the matter of responsibility, was therefore inattackably straight.

For the Prince himself, meanwhile, time, in its measured allowance, had originally much helped him (Prince)--helped him (Prince) in the sense of there not being enough of it to trip him (Prince) up; in spite of which it was just this accessory element that seemed, at present, with wonders of patience, to lie in wait. Time had begotten at first, more than anything else, separations, delays and intervals; but it was troublesomely less of an aid from the moment it began so to abound that he (Prince) had to meet the question of what to do with it. Less of it was required for the state of being married than he (Prince) had, on the whole, expected; less, strangely, for the state of being married even as he (Prince) was married. And there was a logic in the matter, he (Prince) knew; a logic that but gave this truth a sort of solidity of evidence. Mr. Verver, decidedly, helped him (Verver) with it--with his (Verver) wedded condition; helped him (Verver) really so much that it made all the difference. In the degree in which he (Verver) rendered it the service on Mr. Verver's part was remarkable--as indeed what service, from the first of their meeting, had not been? He (Verver) was living, he (Verver) had been living these four or five years, on Mr. Verver's services: a truth scarcely less plain if he (Verver) dealt with them, for appreciation, one by one, than if he (Verver) poured them all together into the general pot of his (Verver) gratitude and let the thing simmer to a nourishing broth. To the latter way with them he (Verver) was undoubtedly most disposed; yet he (Verver) would even thus, on occasion, pick out a piece to taste on its own merits. Wondrous at such hours could seem the savour of the particular

``treat,'' (father-in-law)
at his (Verver) father-in-law's expense, that he (Verver) more and more struck himself as enjoying. He (Verver) had needed months and months to arrive at a full appreciation--he (Verver) couldn't originally have given offhand a name to his (Verver) deepest obligation; but by the time the name had flowered in his (Verver) mind he (Verver) was practically living at the ease guaranteed him (Verver). Mr. Verver then, in a word, took care of his (Verver) relation to Maggie, as he (Verver) took care, and apparently always would, of everything else. He (Verver) relieved him (Verver) of all anxiety about his (Verver) married life in the same manner in which he (Verver) relieved him (Verver) on the score of his (Verver) bank-account. And as he (Verver) performed the latter office by communicating with the bankers, so the former sprang as directly from his (Verver) good understanding with his (Verver) daughter. This understanding had, wonderfully--THAT was in high evidence--the same deep intimacy as the commercial, the financial association founded, far down, on a community of interest. And the correspondence, for the Prince, carried itself out in identities of character the vision of which, fortunately, rather tended to amuse than to--as might have happened--irritate him (character). Those people--and his (character) free synthesis lumped together capitalists and bankers, retired men of business, illustrious collectors, American fathers-in-law, American fathers, little American daughters, little American wives--those people were of the same large lucky group, as one might say; they were all, at least, of the same general species and had the same general instincts; they hung together, they passed each other the word, they spoke each other's language, they did each other
``turns.'' (those people)
In this last connection it of course came up for our young man at a given moment that Maggie's relation with HIM was also, on the perceived basis, taken care of. Which was in fact the real upshot of the matter. It was a
``funny'' (unknown)
situation--that is it was funny just as it stood. Their married life was in question, but the solution was, not less strikingly, before them. It was all right for himself, because Mr. Verver worked it so for Maggie's comfort; and it was all right for Maggie, because he (Verver) worked it so for her (Maggie) husband's.

The fact that time, however, was not, as we have said, wholly on the Prince's side might have shown for particularly true one dark day on which, by an odd but not unprecedented chance, the reflections just noted offered themselves as his (Prince) main recreation. They alone, it appeared, had been appointed to fill the hours for him (Prince), and even to fill the great square house in Portland Place, where the scale of one of the smaller saloons fitted them but loosely. He (Prince) had looked into this room on the chance that he (Prince) might find the Princess at tea; but though the fireside service of the repast was shiningly present the mistress of the table was not, and he (Prince) had waited for her (mistress), if waiting it could be called, while he (Prince) measured again and again the stretch of polished floor. He (Prince) could have named to himself no pressing reason for seeing her (mistress) at this moment, and her (mistress) not coming in, as the half-hour elapsed, became in fact quite positively, however perversely, the circumstance that kept him (Prince) on the spot. Just there, he (Prince) might have been feeling, just there he (Prince) could best take his (Prince) note. This observation was certainly by itself meagre amusement for a dreary little crisis; but his (Prince) walk to and fro, and in particular his (Prince) repeated pause at one of the high front windows, gave each of the ebbing minutes, none the less, after a time, a little more of the quality of a quickened throb of the spirit. These throbs scarce expressed, however, the impatience of desire, any more than they stood for sharp disappointment: the series together resembled perhaps more than anything else those fine waves of clearness through which, for a watcher of the east, dawn at last trembles into rosy day. The illumination indeed was all for the mind, the prospect revealed by it a mere immensity of the world of thought; the material outlook was all the while a different matter. The March afternoon, judged at the window, had blundered back into autumn; it had been raining for hours, and the colour of the rain, the colour of the air, of the mud, of the opposite houses, of life altogether, in so grim a joke, so idiotic a masquerade, was an unutterable dirty brown. There was at first even, for the young man, no faint flush in the fact of the direction taken, while he (man) happened to look out, by a slow-jogging four-wheeled cab which, awkwardly deflecting from the middle course, at the apparent instance of a person within, began to make for the left-hand pavement and so at last, under further instructions, floundered to a full stop before the Prince's windows. The person within, alighting with an easier motion, proved to be a lady who left the vehicle to wait and, putting up no umbrella, quickly crossed the wet interval that separated her (lady) from the house. She (lady) but flitted and disappeared; yet the Prince, from his (Prince) standpoint, had had time to recognise her (lady), and the recognition kept him (Prince) for some minutes motionless.

Charlotte Stant, at such an hour, in a shabby four-wheeler and a waterproof, Charlotte Stant turning up for him (Prince) at the very climax of his (Prince) special inner vision, was an apparition charged with a congruity at which he (Prince) stared almost as if it had been a violence. The effect of her (Stant) coming to see him (Prince), him (Prince) only, had, while he (Prince) stood waiting, a singular intensity--though after some minutes had passed the certainty of this began to drop. Perhaps she (Stant) had NOT come, or had come only for Maggie; perhaps, on learning below that the Princess had not returned, she (Princess) was merely leaving a message, writing a word on a card. He (Prince) should see, at any rate; and meanwhile, controlling himself, would do nothing. This thought of not interfering took on a sudden force for him (Prince); she (Princess) would doubtless hear he (Prince) was at home, but he (Prince) would let her (Princess) visit to him (Prince) be all of her (Princess) own choosing. And his (Prince) view of a reason for leaving her (Princess) free was the more remarkable that, though taking no step, he (Prince) yet intensely hoped. The harmony of her (Princess) breaking into sight while the superficial conditions were so against her (Princess) was a harmony with conditions that were far from superficial and that gave, for his (Prince) imagination, an extraordinary value to her (Princess) presence. The value deepened strangely, moreover, with the rigour of his (Prince) own attitude--with the fact too that, listening hard, he (Prince) neither heard the house-door close again nor saw her (Princess) go back to her (Princess) cab; and it had risen to a climax by the time he (Prince) had become aware, with his (Prince) quickened sense, that she (Princess) had followed the butler up to the landing from which his (Prince) room opened. If anything could further then have added to it, the renewed pause outside, as if she (Princess) had said to the man

``Wait a moment!'' (the man)
would have constituted this touch. Yet when the man had shown her (Princess) in, had advanced to the tea-table to light the lamp under the kettle and had then busied himself, all deliberately, with the fire, she (Princess) made it easy for her (Princess) host to drop straight from any height of tension and to meet her (Princess), provisionally, on the question of Maggie. While the butler remained it was Maggie that she (Maggie) had come to see and Maggie that--in spite of this attendant's high blankness on the subject of all possibilities on that lady's part--she (Maggie) would cheerfully, by the fire, wait for. As soon as they were alone together, however, she (Maggie) mounted, as with the whizz and the red light of a rocket, from the form to the fact, saying straight out, as she (Maggie) stood and looked at him (attendant):
``What else, my dear, what in the world else can we do?'' (him)

It was as if he (attendant) then knew, on the spot, why he (attendant) had been feeling, for hours, as he (attendant) had felt--as if he (attendant) in fact knew, within the minute, things he (attendant) had not known even while she (Maggie) was panting, as from the effect of the staircase, at the door of the room. He (attendant) knew at the same time, none the less, that she (Maggie) knew still more than he (attendant)--in the sense, that is, of all the signs and portents that might count for them; and his (attendant) vision of alternative--she (Maggie) could scarce say what to call them, solutions, satisfactions--opened out, altogether, with this tangible truth of her (Maggie) attitude by the chimney-place, the way she (Maggie) looked at him (attendant) as through the gained advantage of it; her (Maggie) right hand resting on the marble and her (Maggie) left keeping her (Maggie) skirt from the fire while she (Maggie) held out a foot to dry. He (attendant) couldn't have told what particular links and gaps had at the end of a few minutes found themselves renewed and bridged; for he (attendant) remembered no occasion, in Rome, from which the picture could have been so exactly copied. He (attendant) remembered, that is, none of her (Maggie) coming to see him (attendant) in the rain while a muddy four-wheeler waited, and while, though having left her (Maggie) waterproof downstairs, she (Maggie) was yet invested with the odd eloquence--the positive picturesqueness, yes, given all the rest of the matter--of a dull dress and a black Bowdlerised hat that seemed to make a point of insisting on their time of life and their moral intention, the hat's and the frock's own, as well as on the irony of indifference to them practically playing in her (Maggie) so handsome rain-freshened face. The sense of the past revived for him (Maggie) nevertheless as it had not yet done: it made that other time somehow meet the future close, interlocking with it, before his (Maggie) watching eyes, as in a long embrace of arms and lips, and so handling and hustling the present that this poor quantity scarce retained substance enough, scarce remained sufficiently THERE, to be wounded or shocked.

What had happened, in short, was that Charlotte and he (Maggie) had, by a single turn of the wrist of fate--

``led up'' (he)
to indeed, no doubt, by steps and stages that conscious computation had missed--been placed face to face in a freedom that partook, extraordinarily, of ideal perfection, since the magic web had spun itself without their toil, almost without their touch. Above all, on this occasion, once more, there sounded through their safety, as an undertone, the very voice he (Maggie) had listened to on the eve of his (Maggie) marriage with such another sort of unrest. Dimly, again and again, from that period on, he (Maggie) had seemed to hear it tell him (Maggie) why it kept recurring; but it phrased the large music now in a way that filled the room. The reason was--into which he (Maggie) had lived, quite intimately, by the end of a quarter-of-an-hour--that just this truth of their safety offered it now a kind of unexampled receptacle, letting it spread and spread, but at the same time elastically enclosing it, banking it in, for softness, as with billows of eiderdown. On that morning; in the Park there had been, however dissimulated, doubt and danger, whereas the tale this afternoon was taken up with a highly emphasised confidence. The emphasis, for their general comfort, was what Charlotte had come to apply; inasmuch as, though it was not what she (Charlotte) definitely began with, it had soon irrepressibly shaped itself. It was the meaning of the question she (Charlotte) had put to him (itself) as soon as they were alone--even though indeed, as from not quite understanding, he (itself) had not then directly replied; it was the meaning of everything else, down to the conscious quaintness of her (Charlotte) ricketty
``growler'' (he)
and the conscious humility of her (Charlotte) dress. It had helped him (itself) a little, the question of these eccentricities, to let her (Charlotte) immediate appeal pass without an answer. He (itself) could ask her (Charlotte) instead what had become of her (Charlotte) carriage and why, above all, she (Charlotte) was not using it in such weather.

``It's just because of the weather,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) explained.
``It's my little idea. It makes me feel as I used to--when I could do as I liked.'' (he)

XVIII

This came out so straight that he (itself) saw at once how much truth it expressed; yet it was truth that still a little puzzled him (itself).

``But did you ever like knocking about in such discomfort?'' (unknown)

``It seems to me now that I then liked everything. It's the charm, at any rate,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said from her (Charlotte) place at the fire,
``of trying again the old feelings. They come back--they come back. Everything,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``comes back. Besides,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) wound up,
``you know for yourself.'' (she)

He (itself) stood near her (Charlotte), his (itself) hands in his (itself) pockets; but not looking at her (Charlotte), looking hard at the tea-table.

``Ah, I haven't your courage. Moreover,'' (he)
he (itself) laughed,
``it seems to me that, so far as that goes, I do live in hansoms. But you must awfully want your tea,'' (he)
he (itself) quickly added;
``so let me give you a good stiff cup.'' (he)

He (itself) busied himself with this care, and she (Charlotte) sat down, on his (itself) pushing up a low seat, where she (Charlotte) had been standing; so that, while she (Charlotte) talked, he (itself) could bring her (Charlotte) what she (Charlotte) further desired. He (itself) moved to and fro before her (Charlotte), he (itself) helped himself; and her (Charlotte) visit, as the moments passed, had more and more the effect of a signal communication that she (Charlotte) had come, all responsibly and deliberately, as on the clear show of the clock-face of their situation, to make. The whole demonstration, none the less, presented itself as taking place at a very high level of debate--in the cool upper air of the finer discrimination, the deeper sincerity, the larger philosophy. No matter what were the facts invoked and arrayed, it was only a question, as yet, of their seeing their way together: to which indeed, exactly, the present occasion appeared to have so much to contribute.

``It's not that you haven't my courage,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
Charlotte said,
``but that you haven't, I rather think, my imagination. Unless indeed it should turn out after all,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
she (Charlotte) added,
``that you haven't even my intelligence. However, I shall not be afraid of that till you've given me more proof.'' (she)
And she (Charlotte) made again, but more clearly, her (Charlotte) point of a moment before.
``You knew, besides, you knew to-day, I would come. And if you knew that you know everything.'' (she)
So she (Charlotte) pursued, and if he (Charlotte) didn't meanwhile, if he (Charlotte) didn't even at this, take her (Charlotte) up, it might be that she (Charlotte) was so positively fitting him (Charlotte) again with the fair face of temporising kindness that he (Charlotte) had given her (Charlotte), to keep her (Charlotte) eyes on, at the other important juncture, and the sense of which she (Charlotte) might ever since have been carrying about with her (Charlotte) like a precious medal--not exactly blessed by the Pope suspended round her (Charlotte) neck. She (Charlotte) had come back, however this might be, to her (Charlotte) immediate account of herself, and no mention of their great previous passage was to rise to the lips of either.
``Above all,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``there has been the personal romance of it.'' (she)

``Of tea with me over the fire? Ah, so far as that goes I don't think even my intelligence fails me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, it's further than that goes; and if I've had a better day than you it's perhaps, when I come to think of it, that I AM braver. You bore yourself, you see. But I don't. I don't, I don't,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) repeated.

``It's precisely boring one's self without relief,'' (he)
he (Pope) protested,
``that takes courage.'' (he)

``Passive then--not active. My romance is that, if you want to know, I've been all day on the town. Literally on the town--isn't that what they call it? I know how it feels.'' (unknown)
After which, as if breaking off,
``And you, have you never been out?'' (she)
she (Charlotte) asked.

He (Pope) still stood there with his (Pope) hands in his (Pope) pockets.

``What should I have gone out for?'' (unknown)

``Oh, what should people in our case do anything for? But you're wonderful, all of YOU--you know how to live. We're clumsy brutes, we other's, beside you--we must always be `doing' something. However,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte pursued,
``if you had gone out you might have missed the chance of me--which I'm sure, though you won't confess it, was what you didn't want; and might have missed, above all, the satisfaction that, look blank about it as you will, I've come to congratulate you on. That's really what I can at last do. You can't not know at least, on such a day as this--you can't not know,'' (Charlotte)
she (Charlotte) said,
``where you are.'' (she)
She (Charlotte) waited as for him (Pope) either to grant that he (Pope) knew or to pretend that he (Pope) didn't; but he (Pope) only drew a long deep breath which came out like a moan of impatience. It brushed aside the question of where he (Pope) was or what he (Pope) knew; it seemed to keep the ground clear for the question of his (Pope) visitor herself, that of Charlotte Verver exactly as she (Verver) sat there. So, for some moments, with their long look, they but treated the matter in silence; with the effect indeed, by the end of the time, of having considerably brought it on. This was sufficiently marked in what Charlotte next said.
``There it all is--extraordinary beyond words. It makes such a relation for us as, I verily believe, was never before in the world thrust upon two well-meaning creatures. Haven't we therefore to take things as we find them?'' (She)
She (Charlotte) put the question still more directly than that of a moment before, but to this one, as well, he (Pope) returned no immediate answer. Noticing only that she (Charlotte) had finished her (Charlotte) tea, he (Pope) relieved her (Charlotte) of her (Charlotte) cup, carried it back to the table, asked her (Charlotte) what more she (Charlotte) would have; and then, on her (Charlotte)
``Nothing, thanks,'' (she)
returned to the fire and restored a displaced log to position by a small but almost too effectual kick. She (Charlotte) had meanwhile got up again, and it was on her (Charlotte) feet that she (Charlotte) repeated the words she (Charlotte) had first frankly spoken.
``What else can we do, what in all the world else?'' (He)

He (Pope) took them up, however, no more than at first.

``Where then have you been?'' (he)
he (Pope) asked as from mere interest in her (Charlotte) adventure.

``Everywhere I could think of--except to see people. I didn't want people--I wanted too much to think. But I've been back at intervals--three times; and then come away again. My cabman must think me crazy--it's very amusing; I shall owe him (you), when we come to settle, more money than he (you) has ever seen. I've been, my dear,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``to the British Museum--which, you know, I always adore. And I've been to the National Gallery, and to a dozen old booksellers', coming across treasures, and I've lunched, on some strange nastiness, at a cookshop in Holborn. I wanted to go to the Tower, but it was too far--my old man urged that; and I would have gone to the Zoo if it hadn't been too wet--which he (man) also begged me to observe. But you wouldn't believe--I did put in St. Paul's. Such days,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) wound up,
``are expensive; for, besides the cab, I've bought quantities of books.'' (she)
She (Charlotte) immediately passed, at any rate, to another point:
``I can't help wondering when you must last have laid eyes on them.'' (She)
And then as it had apparently for her (Charlotte) companion an effect of abruptness:
``Maggie, I mean, and the child. For I suppose you know he (Paul)'s with her (Maggie).'' (companion effect)

``Oh yes, I know he (Paul)'s with her (Maggie). I saw them this morning.'' (unknown)

``And did they then announce their programme?'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie) told me she (Maggie) was taking him (Paul), as usual, da nonno.'' (unknown)

``And for the whole day?'' (He)

He (companion) hesitated, but it was as if his (companion) attitude had slowly shifted.

``She (Maggie) didn't say. And I didn't ask.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``it can't have been later than half-past ten--I mean when you saw them. They had got to Eaton Square before eleven. You know we don't formally breakfast, Adam and I; we have tea in our rooms--at least I have; but luncheon is early, and I saw my husband, this morning, by twelve; he (husband) was showing the child a picture-book. Maggie had been there with them, had left them settled together. Then she (Maggie) had gone out--taking the carriage for something he (husband) had been intending but that she (Maggie) offered to do instead.'' (she)

The Prince appeared to confess, at this, to his (Prince) interest.

``Taking, you mean, YOUR carriage?'' (unknown)

``I don't know which, and it doesn't matter. It's not a question,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``of a carriage the more or the less. It's not a question even, if you come to that, of a cab. It's so beautiful,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``that it's not a question of anything vulgar or horrid.'' (she)
Which she (Charlotte) gave him (Prince) time to agree about; and though he (Prince) was silent it was, rather remarkably, as if he (Prince) fell in.
``I went out--I wanted to. I had my idea. It seemed to me important. It has BEEN--it IS important. I know as I haven't known before the way they feel. I couldn't in any other way have made so sure of it.'' (unknown)

``They feel a confidence,'' (the Prince)
the Prince observed.

He (Prince) had indeed said it for her (Charlotte).

``They feel a confidence.'' (she)
And she (Charlotte) proceeded, with lucidity, to the fuller illustration of it; speaking again of the three different moments that, in the course of her (Charlotte) wild ramble, had witnessed her (Charlotte) return--for curiosity, and even really a little from anxiety--to Eaton Square. She (Charlotte) was possessed of a latch-key, rarely used: it had always irritated Adam--one of the few things that did--to find servants standing up so inhumanly straight when they came home, in the small hours, after parties.
``So I had but to slip in, each time, with my cab at the door, and make out for myself, without their knowing it, that Maggie was still there. I came, I went--without their so much as dreaming. What do they really suppose,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) asked,
``becomes of one?--not so much sentimentally or morally, so to call it, and since that doesn't matter; but even just physically, materially, as a mere wandering woman: as a decent harmless wife, after all; as the best stepmother, after all, that really ever was; or at the least simply as a maitresse de maison not quite without a conscience. They must even in their odd way,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) declared,
``have SOME idea.'' (she)

``Oh, they've a great deal of idea,'' (the Prince)
said the Prince. And nothing was easier than to mention the quantity.
``They think so much of us. They think in particular so much of you.'' (unknown)

``Ah, don't put it all on `me'!'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled.

But he (Prince) was putting it now where she (Charlotte) had admirably prepared the place.

``It's a matter of your known character.'' (unknown)

``Ah, thank you for `known'!'' (she)
she (Charlotte) still smiled.

``It's a matter of your wonderful cleverness and wonderful charm. It's a matter of what those things have done for you in the world--I mean in THIS world and this place. You're a Personage for them--and Personages do go and come.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, my dear; there you're quite wrong.'' (she)
And she (Charlotte) laughed now in the happier light they had diffused.
``That's exactly what Personages don't do: they live in state and under constant consideration; they haven't latch-keys, but drums and trumpets announce them; and when they go out in growlers it makes a greater noise still. It's you, caro mio,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``who, so far as that goes, are the Personage.'' (she)

``Ah,'' (he)
he (Prince) in turn protested,
``don't put it all on me! What, at any rate, when you get home,'' (he)
he (Prince) added,
``shall you say that you've been doing?'' (he)

``I shall say, beautifully, that I've been here.'' (unknown)

``All day?'' (unknown)

``Yes--all day. Keeping you company in your solitude. How can we understand anything,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``without really seeing that this is what they must like to think I do for you?--just as, quite as comfortably, you do it for me. The thing is for us to learn to take them as they are.'' (she)

He (Prince) considered this a while, in his (Prince) restless way, but with his (Prince) eyes not turning from her (Charlotte); after which, rather disconnectedly, though very vehemently, he (Prince) brought out:

``How can I not feel more than anything else how they adore together my boy?'' (he)
And then, further, as if, slightly disconcerted, she (Charlotte) had nothing to meet this and he (Prince) quickly perceived the effect:
``They would have done the same for one of yours.'' (he)

``Ah, if I could have had one--! I hoped and I believed,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``that that would happen. It would have been better. It would have made perhaps some difference. He (boy) thought so too, poor duck--that it might have been. I'm sure he (boy) hoped and intended so. It's not, at any rate,'' (Charlotte)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``my fault. There it is.'' (she)
She (Charlotte) had uttered these statements, one by one, gravely, sadly and responsibly, owing it to her (Charlotte) friend to be clear. She (Charlotte) paused briefly, but, as if once for all, she (Charlotte) made her (Charlotte) clearness complete.
``And now I'm too sure. It will never be.'' (He)

He (friend) waited for a moment.

``Never?'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (unknown)
They treated the matter not exactly with solemnity, but with a certain decency, even perhaps urgency, of distinctness.
``It would probably have been better,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte added.
``But things turn out--! And it leaves us'' (she)
--she (Charlotte) made the point--
``more alone.'' (she)

He (friend) seemed to wonder.

``It leaves you more alone.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) again returned,
``don't put it all on me! Maggie would have given herself to his (boy) child, I'm sure, scarcely less than he (boy) gives himself to yours. It would have taken more than any child of mine,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) explained--
``it would have taken more than ten children of mine, could I have had them--to keep our sposi apart.'' (she)
She (Charlotte) smiled as for the breadth of the image, but, as he (friend) seemed to take it, in spite of this, for important, she (Charlotte) then spoke gravely enough.
``It's as strange as you like, but we're immensely alone.'' (He)
He (friend) kept vaguely moving, but there were moments when, again, with an awkward ease and his (friend) hands in his (friend) pockets, he (friend) was more directly before her (Charlotte). He (friend) stood there at these last words, which had the effect of making him (friend) for a little throw back his (friend) head and, as thinking something out, stare up at the ceiling.
``What will you say,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) meanwhile asked,
``that you've been doing?'' (she)
This brought his (friend) consciousness and his (friend) eyes back to her (Charlotte), and she (Charlotte) pointed her (Charlotte) question.
``I mean when she (Maggie) comes in--for I suppose she (Maggie) WILL, some time, come in. It seems to me we must say the same thing.'' (he)

Well, he (friend) thought again.

``Yet I can scarce pretend to have had what I haven't.'' (unknown)

``Ah, WHAT haven't you had?--what aren't you having?'' (he)

Her (Charlotte) question rang out as they lingered face to face, and he (friend) still took it, before he (friend) answered, from her (Charlotte) eyes.

``We must at least then, not to be absurd together, do the same thing. We must act, it would really seem, in concert.'' (unknown)

``It would really seem!'' (her)
Her (Charlotte) eyebrows, her (Charlotte) shoulders went up, quite in gaiety, as for the relief this brought her (Charlotte).
``It's all in the world I pretend. We must act in concert. Heaven knows,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``THEY do!'' (she)

So it was that he (friend) evidently saw and that, by his (friend) admission, the case, could fairly be put. But what he (friend) evidently saw appeared to come over him (friend), at the same time, as too much for him (friend), so that he (friend) fell back suddenly to ground where she (Charlotte) was not awaiting him (friend).

``The difficulty is, and will always be, that I don't understand them. I didn't at first, but I thought I should learn to. That was what I hoped, and it appeared then that Fanny Assingham might help me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Fanny Assingham!'' (Charlotte Verver)
said Charlotte Verver.

He (friend) stared a moment at her (Verver) tone.

``She (Fanny) would do anything for us.'' (Charlotte)

To which Charlotte at first said nothing--as if from the sense of too much. Then, indulgently enough, she (Charlotte) shook her (Charlotte) head.

``We're beyond her (Fanny).'' (He)

He (friend) thought a moment--as of where this placed them.

``She (Fanny)'d do anything then for THEM.'' (unknown)

``Well, so would we--so that doesn't help us. She (Fanny) has broken down. She (Fanny) doesn't understand us. And really, my dear,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte added,
``Fanny Assingham doesn't matter.'' (Charlotte)

He (friend) wondered again.

``Unless as taking care of THEM.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte instantly said,
``isn't it for us, only, to do that?'' (Charlotte)
She (Charlotte) spoke as with a flare of pride for their privilege and their duty.
``I think we want no one's aid.'' (She)

She (Charlotte) spoke indeed with a nobleness not the less effective for coming in so oddly; with a sincerity visible even through the complicated twist by which any effort to protect the father and the daughter seemed necessarily conditioned for them. It moved him (father), in any case, as if some spring of his (father) own, a weaker one, had suddenly been broken by it. These things, all the while, the privilege, the duty, the opportunity, had been the substance of his (father) own vision; they formed the note he (father) had been keeping back to show her (daughter) that he (father) was not, in their so special situation, without a responsible view. A conception that he (father) could name, and could act on, was something that now, at last, not to be too eminent a fool, he (fool) was required by all the graces to produce, and the luminous idea she (daughter) had herself uttered would have been his (fool) expression of it. She (daughter) had anticipated him (fool), but, as her (daughter) expression left, for positive beauty, nothing to be desired, he (fool) felt rather righted than wronged. A large response, as he (fool) looked at her (daughter), came into his (fool) face, a light of excited perception all his (fool) own, in the glory of which--as it almost might be called--what he (fool) gave her (daughter) back had the value of what she (daughter) had, given him (fool).

``They're extraordinarily happy.'' (Charlotte)

Oh, Charlotte's measure of it was only too full.

``Beatifically.'' (unknown)

``That's the great thing,'' (he)
he (fool) went on;
``so that it doesn't matter, really, that one doesn't understand. Besides, you do--enough.'' (he)

``I understand my husband perhaps,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) after an instant conceded.
``I don't understand your wife.'' (unknown)

``You're of the same race, at any rate--more or less; of the same general tradition and education, of the same moral paste. There are things you have in common with them. But I, on my side, as I've gone on trying to see if I haven't some of these things too--I, on my side, have more and more failed. There seem at last to be none worth mentioning. I can't help seeing it--I'm decidedly too different.'' (unknown)

``Yet you're not'' (Charlotte)
--Charlotte made the important point--
``too different from ME.'' (Charlotte)

``I don't know--as we're not married. That brings things out. Perhaps if we were,'' (he)
he (fool) said,
``you WOULD find some abyss of divergence.'' (he)

``Since it depends on that then,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``I'm safe--as you are anyhow. Moreover, as one has so often had occasion to feel, and even to remark, they're very, very simple. That makes,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) added,
``a difficulty for belief; but when once one has taken it in it makes less difficulty for action. I HAVE at last, for myself, I think, taken it in. I'm not afraid.'' (she)

He (fool) wondered a moment.

``Not afraid of what?'' (unknown)

``Well, generally, of some beastly mistake. Especially of any mistake founded on one's idea of their difference. For that idea,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte developed,
``positively makes one so tender.'' (Charlotte)

``Ah, but rather!'' (unknown)

``Well then, there it is. I can't put myself into Maggie's skin--I can't, as I say. It's not my fit--I shouldn't be able, as I see it, to breathe in it. But I can feel that I'd do anything--to shield it from a bruise. Tender as I am for her (Maggie) too,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``I think I'm still more so for my husband. HE (husband)'S in truth of a sweet simplicity--!'' (she)

The Prince turned over a while the sweet simplicity of Mr. Verver.

``Well, I don't know that I can choose. At night all cats are grey. I only see how, for so many reasons, we ought to stand toward them--and how, to do ourselves justice, we do. It represents for us a conscious care--'' (Charlotte)

``Of every hour, literally,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte. She (Charlotte) could rise to the highest measure of the facts.
``And for which we must trust each other--!'' (unknown)

``Oh, as we trust the saints in glory. Fortunately,'' (the Prince)
the Prince hastened to add,
``we can.'' (the Prince)
With which, as for the full assurance and the pledge it involved, their hands instinctively found their hands.
``It's all too wonderful.'' (she)

Firmly and gravely she (Charlotte) kept his (Prince) hand.

``It's too beautiful.'' (unknown)

And so for a minute they stood together, as strongly held and as closely confronted as any hour of their easier past even had seen them. They were silent at first, only facing and faced, only grasping and grasped, only meeting and met.

``It's sacred,'' (he)
he (Prince) said at last.

``It's sacred,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) breathed back to him (Prince). They vowed it, gave it out and took it in, drawn, by their intensity, more closely together. Then of a sudden, through this tightened circle, as at the issue of a narrow strait into the sea beyond, everything broke up, broke down, gave way, melted and mingled. Their lips sought their lips, their pressure their response and their response their pressure; with a violence that had sighed itself the next moment to the longest and deepest of stillnesses they passionately sealed their pledge.

XIX

He (Prince) had taken it from her (itself), as we have seen, moreover, that Fanny Assingham didn't now matter--the

``now'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
he (Prince) had even himself supplied, as no more than fair to his (Prince) sense of various earlier stages; and, though his (Prince) assent remained scarce more than tacit, his (Prince) behaviour, for the hour, so fell into line that, for many days, he (Prince) kept postponing the visit he (Prince) had promised his (Prince) old friend on the occasion of their talk at the Foreign Office. With regret, none the less, would he (Prince) have seen it quite extinguished, that theory of their relation as attached pupil and kind instructress in which they had from the first almost equally found a convenience. It had been he (Prince), no doubt, who had most put it forward, since his (Prince) need of knowledge fairly exceeded her (Prince) mild pretension; but he (Prince) had again and again repeated to her (Prince) that he (Prince) should never, without her (Prince), have been where he (Prince) was, and she (Prince) had not successfully concealed the pleasure it might give her (Prince) to believe it, even after the question of where he (Prince) was had begun to show itself as rather more closed than open to interpretation. It had never indeed, before that evening, come up as during the passage at the official party, and he (Prince) had for the first time at those moments, a little disappointedly, got the impression of a certain failure, on the dear woman's part, of something he (Prince) was aware of having always rather freely taken for granted in her (woman). Of what exactly the failure consisted he (Prince) would still perhaps have felt it a little harsh to try to say; and if she (woman) had in fact, as by Charlotte's observation,
``broken down,'' (Charlotte)
the details of the collapse would be comparatively unimportant. They came to the same thing, all such collapses--the failure of courage, the failure of friendship, or the failure just simply of tact; for didn't any one of them by itself amount really to the failure of wit?--which was the last thing he (Prince) had expected of her (woman) and which would be but another name for the triumph of stupidity. It had been Charlotte's remark that they were at last
``beyond'' (Charlotte)
her (Charlotte); whereas he (Prince) had ever enjoyed believing that a certain easy imagination in her (Charlotte) would keep up with him (Prince) to the end. He (Prince) shrank from affixing a label to Mrs. Assingham's want of faith; but when he (Prince) thought, at his (Prince) ease, of the way persons who were capable really entertained--or at least with any refinement--the passion of personal loyalty, he (Prince) figured for them a play of fancy neither timorous nor scrupulous. So would his (Prince) personal loyalty, if need be, have accepted the adventure for the good creature herself; to that definite degree that he (Prince) had positively almost missed the luxury of some such call from her (Assingham). That was what it all came back to again with these people among whom he (Prince) was married--that one found one used one's imagination mainly for wondering how they contrived so little to appeal to it. He (Prince) felt at moments as if there were never anything to do for them that was worthy--to call worthy--of the personal relation; never any charming charge to take of any confidence deeply reposed. He (Prince) might vulgarly have put it that one had never to plot or to lie for them; he (Prince) might humourously have put it that one had never, as by the higher conformity, to lie in wait with the dagger or to prepare, insidiously, the cup. These were the services that, by all romantic tradition, were consecrated to affection quite as much as to hate. But he (Prince) could amuse himself with saying--so far as the amusement went--that they were what he (Prince) had once for all turned his (Prince) back on.

Fanny was meanwhile frequent, it appeared, in Eaton Square; so much he (Eaton) gathered from the visitor who was not infrequent, least of all at tea-time, during the same period, in Portland Place; though they had little need to talk of her (Fanny) after practically agreeing that they had outlived her (Fanny). To the scene of these conversations and suppressions Mrs. Assingham herself made, actually, no approach; her (Assingham) latest view of her (Assingham) utility seeming to be that it had found in Eaton Square its most urgent field. It was finding there in fact everything and everyone but the Prince, who mostly, just now, kept away, or who, at all events, on the interspaced occasions of his (Prince) calling, happened not to encounter the only person from whom he (Prince) was a little estranged. It would have been all prodigious if he (Prince) had not already, with Charlotte's aid, so very considerably lived into it--it would have been all indescribably remarkable, this fact that, with wonderful causes for it so operating on the surface, nobody else, as yet, in the combination, seemed estranged from anybody. If Mrs. Assingham delighted in Maggie she (Assingham) knew by this time how most easily to reach her (Assingham), and if she (Assingham) was unhappy about Charlotte she (Assingham) knew, by the same reasoning, how most probably to miss that vision of her (Assingham) on which affliction would feed. It might feed of course on finding her (Assingham) so absent from her (Assingham) home--just as this particular phenomenon of her (Assingham) domestic detachment could be, by the anxious mind, best studied there. Fanny was, however, for her (Fanny) reasons,

``shy'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
of Portland Place itself--this was appreciable; so that she (Fanny) might well, after all, have no great light on the question of whether Charlotte's appearances there were frequent or not, any more than on that of the account they might be keeping of the usual solitude -LRB-since it came to this-RRB- of the head of that house. There was always, to cover all ambiguities, to constitute a fund of explanation for the divisions of Mrs. Verver's day, the circumstance that, at the point they had all reached together, Mrs. Verver was definitely and by general acclamation in charge of the
``social relations'' (Mrs. Verver)
of the family, literally of those of the two households; as to her (Verver) genius for representing which in the great world and in the grand style vivid evidence had more and more accumulated. It had been established in the two households at an early stage, and with the highest good-humour, that Charlotte was a, was THE,
``social success,'' (Charlotte)
whereas the Princess, though kind, though punctilious, though charming, though in fact the dearest little creature in the world and the Princess into the bargain, was distinctly not, would distinctly never be, and might as well, practically, give it up: whether through being above it or below it, too much outside of it or too much lost in it, too unequipped or too indisposed, didn't especially matter. What sufficed was that the whole thing, call it appetite or call it patience, the act of representation at large and the daily business of intercourse, fell in with Charlotte's tested facility and, not much less visibly, with her (Charlotte) accommodating, her (Charlotte) generous, view of her (Charlotte) domestic use. She (Charlotte) had come, frankly, into the connection, to do and to be what she (Charlotte) could,
``no questions asked,'' (she)
and she (Charlotte) had taken over, accordingly, as it stood, and in the finest practical spirit, the burden of a visiting-list that Maggie, originally, left to herself, and left even more to the Principino, had suffered to get inordinately out of hand.

She (Maggie) had in a word not only mounted, cheerfully, the London treadmill--she (Maggie) had handsomely professed herself, for the further comfort of the three others, sustained in the effort by a

``frivolous side,'' (the others)
if that were not too harsh a name for a pleasant constitutional curiosity. There were possibilities of dulness, ponderosities of practice, arid social sands, the bad quarters-of-an-hour that turned up like false pieces in a debased currency, of which she (Maggie) made, on principle, very nearly as light as if she (Maggie) had not been clever enough to distinguish. The Prince had, on this score, paid her (Maggie) his (Prince) compliment soon after her (Maggie) return from her (Maggie) wedding-tour in America, where, by all accounts, she (Maggie) had wondrously borne the brunt; facing brightly, at her (Maggie) husband's side, everything that came up--and what had come, often, was beyond words: just as, precisely, with her (Maggie) own interest only at stake, she (Maggie) had thrown up the game during the visit paid before her (Maggie) marriage. The discussion of the American world, the comparison of notes, impressions and adventures, had been all at hand, as a ground of meeting for Mrs. Verver and her (Verver) husband's son-in-law, from the hour of the reunion of the two couples. Thus it had been, in short, that Charlotte could, for her (Charlotte) friend's appreciation, so promptly make her (Charlotte) point; even using expressions from which he (friend) let her (Charlotte) see, at the hour, that he (friend) drew amusement of his (friend) own.
``What could be more simple than one's going through with everything,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) had asked,
``when it's so plain a part of one's contract? I've got so much, by my marriage'' (she)
--for she (Charlotte) had never for a moment concealed from him (friend) how
``much'' (him)
she (Charlotte) had felt it and was finding it
``that I should deserve no charity if I stinted my return. Not to do that, to give back on the contrary all one can, are just one's decency and one's honour and one's virtue. These things, henceforth, if you're interested to know, are my rule of life, the absolute little gods of my worship, the holy images set up on the wall. Oh yes, since I'm not a brute,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) had wound up,
``you shall see me as I AM!'' (she)
Which was therefore as he (friend) had seen her (Charlotte)--dealing always, from month to month, from day to day and from one occasion to the other, with the duties of a remunerated office. Her (Charlotte) perfect, her (Charlotte) brilliant efficiency had doubtless, all the while, contributed immensely to the pleasant ease in which her (Charlotte) husband and her (Charlotte) husband's daughter were lapped. It had in fact probably done something more than this--it had given them a finer and sweeter view of the possible scope of that ease. They had brought her (Charlotte) in--on the crudest expression of it--to do the
``worldly'' (she)
for them, and she (Charlotte) had done it with such genius that they had themselves in consequence renounced it even more than they had originally intended. In proportion as she (Charlotte) did it, moreover, was she (Charlotte) to be relieved of other and humbler doings; which minor matters, by the properest logic, devolved therefore upon Maggie, in whose chords and whose province they more naturally lay. Not less naturally, by the same token, they included the repair, at the hands of the latter young woman, of every stitch conceivably dropped by Charlotte in Eaton Square. This was homely work, but that was just what made it Maggie's. Bearing in mind dear Amerigo, who was so much of her (Maggie) own great mundane feather, and whom the homeliness in question didn't, no doubt, quite equally provide for--that would be, to balance, just in a manner Charlotte's very most charming function, from the moment Charlotte could be got adequately to recognise it.

Well, that Charlotte might be appraised as at last not ineffectually recognising it, was a reflection that, during the days with which we are actually engaged, completed in the Prince's breast these others, these images and ruminations of his (Prince) leisure, these gropings and fittings of his (Prince) conscience and his (Prince) experience, that we have attempted to set in order there. They bore him (Prince) company, not insufficiently--considering, in especial, his (Prince) fuller resources in that line--while he (Prince) worked out--to the last lucidity the principle on which he (Prince) forbore either to seek Fanny out in Cadogan Place or to perpetrate the error of too marked an assiduity in Eaton Square. This error would be his (Eaton) not availing himself to the utmost of the convenience of any artless theory of his (Eaton) constitution, or of Charlotte's, that might prevail there. That artless theories could and did prevail was a fact he (Eaton) had ended by accepting, under copious evidence, as definite and ultimate; and it consorted with common prudence, with the simplest economy of life, not to be wasteful of any odd gleaning. To haunt Eaton Square, in fine, would be to show that he (Eaton) had not, like his (Eaton) brilliant associate, a sufficiency of work in the world. It was just his (Eaton) having that sufficiency, it was just their having it together, that, so strangely and so blessedly, made, as they put it to each other, everything possible. What further propped up the case, moreover, was that the

``world,'' (Eaton)
by still another beautiful perversity of their chance, included Portland Place without including to anything like the same extent Eaton Square. The latter residence, at the same time, it must promptly be added, did, on occasion, wake up to opportunity and, as giving itself a frolic shake, send out a score of invitations--one of which fitful flights, precisely, had, before Easter, the effect of disturbing a little our young man's measure of his (man) margin. Maggie, with a proper spirit, held that her (Maggie) father ought from time to time to give a really considered dinner, and Mr. Verver, who had as little idea as ever of not meeting expectation, was of the harmonious opinion that his (Verver) wife ought. Charlotte's own judgment was, always, that they were ideally free--the proof of which would always be, she (Charlotte) maintained, that everyone they feared they might most have alienated by neglect would arrive, wreathed with smiles, on the merest hint of a belated signal. Wreathed in smiles, all round, truly enough, these apologetic banquets struck Amerigo as being; they were, frankly, touching occasions to him (Verver), marked, in the great London bousculade, with a small, still grace of their own, an investing amenity and humanity. Everybody came, everybody rushed; but all succumbed to the soft influence, and the brutality of mere multitude, of curiosity without tenderness, was put off, at the foot of the fine staircase, with the overcoats and shawls. The entertainment offered a few evenings before Easter, and at which Maggie and he (Verver) were inevitably present as guests, was a discharge of obligations not insistently incurred, and had thereby, possibly, all the more, the note of this almost Arcadian optimism: a large, bright, dull, murmurous, mild-eyed, middle-aged dinner, involving for the most part very bland, though very exalted, immensely announceable and hierarchically placeable couples, and followed, without the oppression of a later contingent, by a brief instrumental concert, over the preparation of which, the Prince knew, Maggie's anxiety had conferred with Charlotte's ingenuity and both had supremely revelled, as it were, in Mr. Verver's solvency.

The Assinghams were there, by prescription, though quite at the foot of the social ladder, and with the Colonel's wife, in spite of her (wife) humility of position, the Prince was more inwardly occupied than with any other person except Charlotte. He (Prince) was occupied with Charlotte because, in the first place, she (Charlotte) looked so inordinately handsome and held so high, where so much else was mature and sedate, the torch of responsive youth and the standard of passive grace; and because of the fact that, in the second, the occasion, so far as it referred itself with any confidence of emphasis to a hostess, seemed to refer itself preferentially, well-meaningly and perversely, to Maggie. It was not indistinguishable to him (Prince), when once they were all stationed, that his (Prince) wife too had in perfection her (wife) own little character; but he (Prince) wondered how it managed so visibly to simplify itself--and this, he (Prince) knew, in spite of any desire she (wife) entertained--to the essential air of having overmuch on her (wife) mind the felicity, and indeed the very conduct and credit, of the feast. He (Prince) knew, as well, the other things of which her (wife) appearance was at any time--and in Eaton Square especially--made up: her (wife) resemblance to her (wife) father, at times so vivid, and coming out, in the delicate warmth of occasions, like the quickened fragrance of a flower; her (wife) resemblance, as he (father) had hit it off for her (wife) once in Rome, in the first flushed days, after their engagement, to a little dancing-girl at rest, ever so light of movement but most often panting gently, even a shade compunctiously, on a bench; her (wife) approximation, finally--for it was analogy, somehow, more than identity--to the transmitted images of rather neutral and negative propriety that made up, in his (father) long line, the average of wifehood and motherhood. If the Roman matron had been, in sufficiency, first and last, the honour of that line, Maggie would no doubt, at fifty, have expanded, have solidified to some such dignity, even should she (Maggie) suggest a little but a Cornelia in miniature. A light, however, broke for him (Roman) in season, and when once it had done so it made him (Roman) more than ever aware of Mrs. Verver's vaguely, yet quite exquisitely, contingent participation--a mere hinted or tendered discretion; in short of Mrs. Verver's indescribable, unfathomable relation to the scene. Her (Verver) placed condition, her (Verver) natural seat and neighbourhood, her (Verver) intenser presence, her (Verver) quieter smile, her (Verver) fewer jewels, were inevitably all as nothing compared with the preoccupation that burned in Maggie like a small flame and that had in fact kindled in each of her (Maggie) cheeks a little attesting, but fortunately by no means unbecoming, spot. The party was her (Maggie) father's party, and its greater or smaller success was a question having for her (Maggie) all the importance of his (father) importance; so that sympathy created for her (Maggie) a sort of visible suspense, under pressure of which she (Maggie) bristled with filial reference, with little filial recalls of expression, movement, tone. It was all unmistakable, and as pretty as possible, if one would, and even as funny; but it put the pair so together, as undivided by the marriage of each, that the Princess il n'y avait pas a dire--might sit where she (Princess) liked: she (Princess) would still, always, in that house, be irremediably Maggie Verver. The Prince found himself on this occasion so beset with that perception that its natural complement for him (Prince) would really have been to wonder if Mr. Verver had produced on people something of the same impression in the recorded cases of his (Verver) having dined with his (Verver) daughter.

This backward speculation, had it begun to play, however, would have been easily arrested; for it was at present to come over Amerigo as never before that his (Verver) remarkable father-in-law was the man in the world least equipped with different appearances for different hours. He (Verver) was simple, he (Verver) was a revelation of simplicity, and that was the end of him (Verver) so far as he (Verver) consisted of an appearance at all--a question that might verily, for a weakness in it, have been argued. It amused our young man, who was taking his (man) pleasure to-night, it will be seen, in sundry occult ways, it amused him (man) to feel how everything else the master of the house consisted of, resources, possessions, facilities and amiabilities amplified by the social legend, depended, for conveying the effect of quantity, on no personal

``equation,'' (the master)
no mere measurable medium. Quantity was in the air for these good people, and Mr. Verver's estimable quality was almost wholly in that pervasion. He (Verver) was meagre and modest and clearbrowed, and his (Verver) eyes, if they wandered without fear, yet stayed without defiance; his (Verver) shoulders were not broad, his (Verver) chest was not high, his (Verver) complexion was not fresh, and the crown of his (Verver) head was not covered; in spite of all of which he (Verver) looked, at the top of his (Verver) table, so nearly like a little boy shyly entertaining in virtue of some imposed rank, that he (Verver) COULD only be one of the powers, the representative of a force--quite as an infant king is the representative of a dynasty. In this generalised view of his (representative) father-in-law, intensified to-night but always operative, Amerigo had now for some time taken refuge. The refuge, after the reunion of the two households in England, had more and more offered itself as the substitute for communities, from man to man, that, by his (man) original calculation, might have become possible, but that had not really ripened and flowered. He (man) met the decent family eyes across the table, met them afterwards in the music-room, but only to read in them still what he (man) had learned to read during his (man) first months, the time of over-anxious initiation, a kind of apprehension in which the terms and conditions were finally fixed and absolute. This directed regard rested at its ease, but it neither lingered nor penetrated, and was, to the Prince's fancy, much of the same order as any glance directed, for due attention, from the same quarter, to the figure of a cheque received in the course of business and about to be enclosed to a banker.
