It made sure of the amount--and just so, from time to time, the amount of the Prince was made sure. He (Prince) was being thus, in renewed instalments, perpetually paid in; he (Prince) already reposed in the bank as a value, but subject, in this comfortable way, to repeated, to infinite endorsement. The net result of all of which, moreover, was that the young man had no wish to see his (man) value diminish. He (man) himself, after all, had not fixed it--the
``figure'' (He)
was a conception all of Mr. Verver's own. Certainly, however, everything must be kept up to it; never so much as to-night had the Prince felt this. He (Prince) would have been uncomfortable, as these quiet expressions passed, had the case not been guaranteed for him (Prince) by the intensity of his (Prince) accord with Charlotte. It was impossible that he (Prince) should not now and again meet Charlotte's eyes, as it was also visible that she (Charlotte) too now and again met her (Charlotte) husband's. For her (Charlotte) as well, in all his (husband) pulses, he (husband) felt the conveyed impression. It put them, it kept them together, through the vain show of their separation, made the two other faces, made the whole lapse of the evening, the people, the lights, the flowers, the pretended talk, the exquisite music, a mystic golden bridge between them, strongly swaying and sometimes almost vertiginous, for that intimacy of which the sovereign law would be the vigilance of
``care,'' (the people lights flowers talk music bridge)
would be never rashly to forget and never consciously to wound.

XX

The main interest of these hours for us, however, will have been in the way the Prince continued to know, during a particular succession of others, separated from the evening in Eaton Square by a short interval, a certain persistent aftertaste. This was the lingering savour of a cup presented to him (Eaton) by Fanny Assingham's hand after dinner, while the clustered quartette kept their ranged companions, in the music-room, moved if one would, but conveniently motionless. Mrs. Assingham contrived, after a couple of pieces, to convey to her (Assingham) friend that, for her (Assingham) part, she (Assingham) was moved--by the genius of Brahms--beyond what she (Assingham) could bear; so that, without apparent deliberation, she (Assingham) had presently floated away, at the young man's side, to such a distance as permitted them to converse without the effect of disdain. It was the twenty minutes enjoyed with her (Assingham), during the rest of the concert, in the less associated electric glare of one of the empty rooms--it was their achieved and, as he (man) would have said, successful, most pleasantly successful, talk on one of the sequestered sofas, it was this that was substantially to underlie his (man) consciousness of the later occasion. The later occasion, then mere matter of discussion, had formed her (Assingham) ground for desiring--in a light undertone into which his (man) quick ear read indeed some nervousness--these independent words with him (man): she (Assingham) had sounded, covertly but distinctly, by the time they were seated together, the great question of what it might involve. It had come out for him (man) before anything else, and so abruptly that this almost needed an explanation. Then the abruptness itself had appeared to explain--which had introduced, in turn, a slight awkwardness.

``Do you know that they're not, after all, going to Matcham; so that, if they don't--if, at least, Maggie doesn't--you won't, I suppose, go by yourself?'' (I)
It was, as I say, at Matcham, where the event had placed him (man), it was at Matcham during the Easter days, that it most befell him (man), oddly enough, to live over, inwardly, for its wealth of special significance, this passage by which the event had been really a good deal determined. He (man) had paid, first and last, many an English country visit; he (man) had learned, even from of old, to do the English things, and to do them, all sufficiently, in the English way; if he (man) didn't always enjoy them madly he (man) enjoyed them at any rate as much, to an appearance, as the good people who had, in the night of time, unanimously invented them, and who still, in the prolonged afternoon of their good faith, unanimously, even if a trifle automatically, practised them; yet, with it all, he (man) had never so much as during such sojourns the trick of a certain detached, the amusement of a certain inward critical, life; the determined need, which apparently all participant, of returning upon itself, of backing noiselessly in, far in again, and rejoining there, as it were, that part of his (man) mind that was not engaged at the front. His (man) body, very constantly, was engaged at the front--in shooting, in riding, in golfing, in walking, over the fine diagonals of meadow-paths or round the pocketed corners of billiard-tables; it sufficiently, on the whole, in fact, bore the brunt of bridge-playing, of breakfasting, lunching, tea-drinking, dining, and of the nightly climax over the bottigliera, as he (man) called it, of the bristling tray; it met, finally, to the extent of the limited tax on lip, on gesture, on wit, most of the current demands of conversation and expression. Therefore something of him (lip), he (lip) often felt at these times, was left out; it was much more when he (lip) was alone, or when he (lip) was with his (lip) own people--or when he (lip) was, say, with Mrs. Verver and nobody else--that he (lip) moved, that he (lip) talked, that he (lip) listened, that he (lip) felt, as a congruous whole.

``English society,'' (he)
as he (lip) would have said, cut him (lip), accordingly, in two, and he (lip) reminded himself often, in his (lip) relations with it, of a man possessed of a shining star, a decoration, an order of some sort, something so ornamental as to make his (lip) identity not complete, ideally, without it, yet who, finding no other such object generally worn, should be perpetually, and the least bit ruefully, unpinning it from his (lip) breast to transfer it to his (lip) pocket. The Prince's shining star may, no doubt, having been nothing more precious than his (lip) private subtlety; but whatever the object was he (lip) just now fingered it a good deal, out of sight--amounting as it mainly did for him (lip) to a restless play of memory and a fine embroidery of thought. Something had rather momentously occurred, in Eaton Square, during his (Eaton) enjoyed minutes with his (Eaton) old friend: his (Eaton) present perspective made definitely clear to him (Eaton) that she (lip) had plumped out for him (Eaton) her (lip) first little lie. That took on--and he (Eaton) could scarce have said why--a sharpness of importance: she (lip) had never lied to him (Eaton) before--if only because it had never come up for her (lip), properly, intelligibly, morally, that she (lip) must. As soon as she (lip) had put to him (Eaton) the question of what he (Eaton) would do--by which she (lip) meant of what Charlotte would also do--in that event of Maggie's and Mr. Verver's not embracing the proposal they had appeared for a day or two resignedly to entertain; as soon as she (Maggie) had betrayed her (Maggie) curiosity as to the line the other pair, so left to themselves, might take, a desire to avoid the appearance of at all too directly prying had become marked in her (Maggie). Betrayed by the solicitude of which she (Maggie) had, already, three weeks before, given him (Verver) a view, she (Maggie) had been obliged, on a second thought, to name, intelligibly, a reason for her (Maggie) appeal; while the Prince, on his (Prince) side, had had, not without mercy, his (Prince) glimpse of her (Maggie) momentarily groping for one and yet remaining unprovided. Not without mercy because, absolutely, he (Prince) had on the spot, in his (Prince) friendliness, invented one for her (Maggie) use, presenting it to her (Maggie) with a look no more significant than if he (Prince) had picked up, to hand back to her (Maggie), a dropped flower.
``You ask if I'm likely also to back out then, because it may make a difference in what you and the Colonel decide?'' (he)
--he (Prince) had gone as far as that for her (Maggie), fairly inviting her (Maggie) to assent, though not having had his (Prince) impression, from any indication offered him (Prince) by Charlotte, that the Assinghams were really in question for the large Matcham party. The wonderful thing, after this, was that the active couple had, in the interval, managed to inscribe themselves on the golden roll; an exertion of a sort that, to do her (Charlotte) justice, he (Prince) had never before observed Fanny to make. This last passage of the chapter but proved, after all, with what success she (Fanny) could work when she (Fanny) would.

Once launched, himself, at any rate, as he (Prince) had been directed by all the terms of the intercourse between Portland Place and Eaton Square, once steeped, at Matcham, in the enjoyment of a splendid hospitality, he (Eaton) found everything, for his (Eaton) interpretation, for his (Eaton) convenience, fall easily enough into place; and all the more that Mrs. Verver was at hand to exchange ideas and impressions with. The great house was full of people, of possible new combinations, of the quickened play of possible propinquity, and no appearance, of course, was less to be cultivated than that of his (Eaton) having sought an opportunity to foregather with his (Eaton) friend at a safe distance from their respective sposi. There was a happy boldness, at the best, in their mingling thus, each unaccompanied, in the same sustained sociability--just exactly a touch of that eccentricity of associated freedom which sat so lightly on the imagination of the relatives left behind. They were exposed as much as one would to its being pronounced funny that they should, at such a rate, go about together--though, on the other hand, this consideration drew relief from the fact that, in their high conditions and with the easy tradition, the almost inspiring allowances, of the house in question, no individual line, however freely marked, was pronounced anything more than funny. Both our friends felt afresh, as they had felt before, the convenience of a society so placed that it had only its own sensibility to consider--looking as it did well over the heads of all lower growths; and that moreover treated its own sensibility quite as the easiest, friendliest, most informal and domesticated party to the general alliance. What anyone

``thought'' (anyone)
of anyone else--above all of anyone else with anyone else--was a matter incurring in these lulls so little awkward formulation that hovering judgment, the spirit with the scales, might perfectly have been imaged there as some rather snubbed and subdued, but quite trained and tactful poor relation, of equal, of the properest, lineage, only of aspect a little dingy, doubtless from too limited a change of dress, for whose tacit and abstemious presence, never betrayed by a rattle of her (anyone) rusty machine, a room in the attic and a plate at the side-table were decently usual. It was amusing, in such lightness of air, that the Prince should again present himself only to speak for the Princess, so unfortunately unable, again, to leave home; and that Mrs. Verver should as regularly figure as an embodied, a beautifully deprecating apology for her (Verver) husband, who was all geniality and humility among his (husband) own treasures, but as to whom the legend had grown up that he (husband) couldn't bear, with the height of his (husband) standards and the tone of the company, in the way of sofas and cabinets, habitually kept by him (husband), the irritation and depression to which promiscuous visiting, even at pompous houses, had been found to expose him (husband). That was all right, the noted working harmony of the clever son-in-law and the charming stepmother, so long as the relation was, for the effect in question, maintained at the proper point between sufficiency and excess.

What with the noble fairness of the place, meanwhile, the generous mood of the sunny, gusty, lusty English April, all panting and heaving with impatience, or kicking and crying, even, at moments, like some infant Hercules who wouldn't be dressed; what with these things and the bravery of youth and beauty, the insolence of fortune and appetite so diffused among his (Hercules) fellow-guests that the poor Assinghams, in their comparatively marked maturity and their comparatively small splendour, were the only approach to a false note in the concert, the stir of the air was such, for going, in a degree, to one's head, that, as a mere matter of exposure, almost grotesque in its flagrancy, his (Hercules) situation resembled some elaborate practical joke carried out at his (Hercules) expense. Every voice in the great bright house was a call to the ingenuities and impunities of pleasure; every echo was a defiance of difficulty, doubt or danger; every aspect of the picture, a glowing plea for the immediate, and as with plenty more to come, was another phase of the spell. For a world so constituted was governed by a spell, that of the smile of the gods and the favour of the powers; the only handsome, the only gallant, in fact the only intelligent acceptance of which was a faith in its guarantees and a high spirit for its chances. Its demand--to that the thing came back--was above all for courage and good-humour; and the value of this as a general assurance--that is for seeing one through at the worst--had not even in the easiest hours of his (its) old Roman life struck the Prince so convincingly. His (its) old Roman life had had more poetry, no doubt, but as he (its) looked back upon it now it seemed to hang in the air of mere iridescent horizons, to have been loose and vague and thin, with large languorous unaccountable blanks. The present order, as it spread about him (its), had somehow the ground under its feet, and a trumpet in its ears, and a bottomless bag of solid shining British sovereigns--which was much to the point--in its hand. Courage and good-humour therefore were the breath of the day; though for ourselves at least it would have been also much to the point that, with Amerigo, really, the innermost effect of all this perceptive ease was perhaps a strange final irritation. He (its) compared the lucid result with the extraordinary substitute for perception that presided, in the bosom of his (its) wife, at so contented a view of his (its) conduct and course--a state of mind that was positively like a vicarious good conscience, cultivated ingeniously on his (its) behalf, a perversity of pressure innocently persisted in; and this wonder of irony became on occasion too intense to be kept wholly to himself. It wasn't that, at Matcham, anything particular, anything monstrous, anything that had to be noticed permitted itself, as they said, to

``happen'' (him)
; there were only odd moments when the breath of the day, as it has been called, struck him (its) so full in the face that he (its) broke out with all the hilarity of
``What indeed would THEY have made of it?'' (he)
``They'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
were of course Maggie and her (Maggie) father, moping--so far as they ever consented to mope in monotonous Eaton Square, but placid too in the belief that they knew beautifully what their expert companions were in for. They knew, it might have appeared in these lights, absolutely nothing on earth worth speaking of--whether beautifully or cynically; and they would perhaps sometimes be a little less trying if they would only once for all peacefully admit that knowledge wasn't one of their needs and that they were in fact constitutionally inaccessible to it. They were good children, bless their hearts, and the children of good children; so that, verily, the Principino himself, as less consistently of that descent, might figure to the fancy as the ripest genius of the trio.

The difficulty was, for the nerves of daily intercourse with Maggie in particular, that her (Maggie) imagination was clearly never ruffled by the sense of any anomaly. The great anomaly would have been that her (Maggie) husband, or even that her (Maggie) father's wife, should prove to have been made, for the long run, after the pattern set from so far back to the Ververs. If one was so made one had certainly no business, on any terms, at Matcham; whereas if one wasn't one had no business there on the particular terms--terms of conformity with the principles of Eaton Square--under which one had been so absurdly dedicated. Deep at the heart of that resurgent unrest in our young man which we have had to content ourselves with calling his (man) irritation--deep in the bosom of this falsity of position glowed the red spark of his (man) inextinguishable sense of a higher and braver propriety. There were situations that were ridiculous, but that one couldn't yet help, as for instance when one's wife chose, in the most usual way, to make one so. Precisely here, however, was the difference; it had taken poor Maggie to invent a way so extremely unusual--yet to which, none the less, it would be too absurd that he (man) should merely lend himself. Being thrust, systematically, with another woman, and a woman one happened, by the same token, exceedingly to like, and being so thrust that the theory of it seemed to publish one as idiotic or incapable--this WAS a predicament of which the dignity depended all on one's own handling. What was supremely grotesque, in fact, was the essential opposition of theories--as if a galantuomo, as HE (man) at least constitutionally conceived galantuomini, could do anything BUT blush to

``go about'' (HE)
at such a rate with such a person as Mrs. Verver in a state of childlike innocence, the state of our primitive parents before the Fall. The grotesque theory, as he (man) would have called it, was perhaps an odd one to resent with violence, and he (man) did it--also as a man of the world--all merciful justice; but, assuredly, none the less, there was but one way REALLY to mark, and for his (man) companion as much as for himself, the commiseration in which they held it. Adequate comment on it could only be private, but it could also at least be active, and of rich and effectual comment Charlotte and he (man) were fortunately alike capable. Wasn't this consensus literally their only way not to be ungracious? It was positively as if the measure of their escape from that danger were given by the growth between them, during their auspicious visit, of an exquisite sense of complicity.

XXI

He (man) found himself therefore saying, with gaiety, even to Fanny Assingham, for their common, concerned glance at Eaton Square, the glance that was so markedly never, as it might have been, a glance at Portland Place:

``What WOULD our cari sposi have made of it here? what would they, you know, really?'' (Eaton)
--which overflow would have been reckless if, already, and surprisingly perhaps even to himself, he (Eaton) had not got used to thinking of this friend as a person in whom the element of protest had of late been unmistakably allayed. He (Eaton) exposed himself of course to her (Fanny) replying:
``Ah, if it would have been so bad for them, how can it be so good for you?'' (He)
--but, quite apart from the small sense the question would have had at the best, she (Fanny) appeared already to unite with him (Eaton) in confidence and cheer. He (Eaton) had his (Eaton) view, as well--or at least a partial one--of the inner spring of this present comparative humility, which was all consistent with the retraction he (Eaton) had practically seen her (Fanny) make after Mr. Verver's last dinner. Without diplomatising to do so, with no effort to square her (Fanny), none to bribe her (Fanny) to an attitude for which he (Verver) would have had no use in her (Fanny) if it were not sincere, he (Verver) yet felt how he (Verver) both held her (Fanny) and moved her (Fanny) by the felicity of his (Verver) taking pity, all instinctively, on her (Fanny) just discernible depression. By just so much as he (Verver) guessed that she (Fanny) felt herself, as the slang was, out of it, out of the crystal current and the expensive picture, by just so much had his (Verver) friendship charmingly made up to her (Fanny), from hour to hour, for the penalties, as they might have been grossly called, of her (Fanny) mistake. Her (Fanny) mistake had only been, after all, in her (Fanny) wanting to seem to him (Verver) straight; she (Fanny) had let herself in for being--as she (Fanny) had made haste, for that matter, during the very first half-hour, at tea, to proclaim herself--the sole and single frump of the party. The scale of everything was so different that all her (Fanny) minor values, her (Fanny) quainter graces, her (Fanny) little local authority, her (Fanny) humour and her (Fanny) wardrobe alike, for which it was enough elsewhere, among her (Fanny) bons amis, that they were hers, dear Fanny Assingham's--these matters and others would be all, now, as nought: five minutes had sufficed to give her (Assingham) the fatal pitch. In Cadogan Place she (Assingham) could always, at the worst, be picturesque--for she (Assingham) habitually spoke of herself as
``local'' (she)
to Sloane Street whereas at Matcham she (Assingham) should never be anything but horrible. And it all would have come, the disaster, from the real refinement, in her (Assingham), of the spirit of friendship. To prove to him (Sloane) that she (Assingham) wasn't really watching him (Sloane)--ground for which would have been too terribly grave--she (Assingham) had followed him (Sloane) in his (Sloane) pursuit of pleasure: SO she (Assingham) might, precisely, mark her (Assingham) detachment. This was handsome trouble for her (Assingham) to take--the Prince could see it all: it wasn't a shade of interference that a good-natured man would visit on her (Assingham). So he (man) didn't even say, when she (Assingham) told him (man) how frumpy she (Assingham) knew herself, how frumpy her (Assingham) very maid, odiously going back on her (Assingham), rubbed it into her (Assingham), night and morning, with unsealed eyes and lips, that she (Assingham) now knew her (Assingham)--he (man) didn't then say
``Ah, see what you've done: isn't it rather your own fault?'' (he)
He (man) behaved differently altogether: eminently distinguished himself--for she (Assingham) told him (man) she (Assingham) had never seen him (man) so universally distinguished--he (man) yet distinguished her (Assingham) in her (Assingham) obscurity, or in what was worse, her (Assingham) objective absurdity, and frankly invested her (Assingham) with her (Assingham) absolute value, surrounded her (Assingham) with all the importance of her (Assingham) wit. That wit, as discriminated from stature and complexion, a sense for
``bridge'' (she)
and a credit for pearls, could have importance was meanwhile but dimly perceived at Matcham; so that his (man)
``niceness'' (she)
to her (Assingham)--she (Assingham) called it only niceness, but it brought tears into her (Assingham) eyes--had the greatness of a general as well as of a special demonstration.

``She (it) understands,'' (he)
he (man) said, as a comment on all this, to Mrs. Verver--
``she (it) understands all she (it) needs to understand. She (it) has taken her (it) time, but she (it) has at last made it out for herself: she (it) sees how all we can desire is to give them the life they prefer, to surround them with the peace and quiet, and above all with the sense of security, most favourable to it. She (it) can't of course very well put it to us that we have, so far as she (it) is concerned, but to make the best of our circumstances; she (it) can't say in so many words `Don't think of me, for I too must make the best of mine: arrange as you can, only, and live as you must.' I don't get quite THAT from her (it), any more than I ask for it. But her (it) tone and her (it) whole manner mean nothing at all unless they mean that she (it) trusts us to take as watchful, to take as artful, to take as tender care, in our way, as she (it) so anxiously takes in hers. So that she (it)'s--well,'' (Mrs. Verver)
the Prince wound up,
``what you may call practically all right.'' (the Prince)
Charlotte in fact, however, to help out his (Prince) confidence, didn't call it anything; return as he (Prince) might to the lucidity, the importance, or whatever it was, of this lesson, she (Charlotte) gave him (Prince) no aid toward reading it aloud. She (Charlotte) let him (Prince), two or three times over, spell it out for himself; only on the eve of their visit's end was she (Charlotte), for once, clear or direct in response. They had found a minute together in the great hall of the house during the half-hour before dinner; this easiest of chances they had already, a couple of times, arrived at by waiting persistently till the last other loiterers had gone to dress, and by being prepared themselves to dress so expeditiously that they might, a little later on, be among the first to appear in festal array. The hall then was empty, before the army of rearranging, cushion-patting housemaids were marshalled in, and there was a place by the forsaken fire, at one end, where they might imitate, with art, the unpremeditated. Above all, here, for the snatched instants, they could breathe so near to each other that the interval was almost engulfed in it, and the intensity both of the union and the caution became a workable substitute for contact. They had prolongations of instants that counted as visions of bliss; they had slow approximations that counted as long caresses. The quality of these passages, in truth, made the spoken word, and especially the spoken word about other people, fall below them; so that our young woman's tone had even now a certain dryness.
``It's very good of her (it), my dear, to trust us. But what else can she (it) do?'' (unknown)

``Why, whatever people do when they don't trust. Let one see they don't.'' (unknown)

``But let whom see?'' (unknown)

``Well, let ME, say, to begin with.'' (unknown)

``And should you mind that?'' (He)

He (our) had a slight show of surprise.

``Shouldn't you?'' (unknown)

``Her (it) letting you see? No,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte;
``the only thing I can imagine myself minding is what you yourself, if you don't look out, may let HER see.'' (Charlotte)
To which she (Charlotte) added:
``You may let her (it) see, you know, that you're afraid.'' (she)

``I'm only afraid of you, a little, at moments,'' (he)
he (our) presently returned.
``But I shan't let Fanny see that.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

It was clear, however, that neither the limits nor the extent of Mrs. Assingham's vision were now a real concern to her (Assingham), and she (Assingham) gave expression to this as she (Assingham) had not even yet done.

``What in the world can she (Fanny) do against us? There's not a word that she (Fanny) can breathe. She (Fanny)'s helpless; she (Fanny) can't speak; she (Fanny) would be herself the first to be dished by it.'' (he)
And then as he (our) seemed slow to follow:
``It all comes back to her (Fanny). It all began with her (Fanny). Everything, from the first. She (Fanny) introduced you to Maggie. She (Fanny) made your marriage.'' (he)

The Prince might have had his (Prince) moment of demur, but at this, after a little, as with a smile dim but deep, he (Prince) came on.

``Mayn't she (Fanny) also be said, a good deal, to have made yours? That was intended, I think, wasn't it? for a kind of rectification.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte, on her (Charlotte) side, for an instant, hesitated; then she (Charlotte) was prompter still. ``I don't mean there was anything to rectify; everything was as it had to be, and I'm not speaking of how she (Fanny) may have been concerned for you and me. I'm speaking of how she (Fanny) took, in her (Fanny) way, each time, THEIR lives in hand, and how, therefore, that ties her (Fanny) up to-day. She (Fanny) can't go to them and say `It's very awkward of course, you poor dear things, but I was frivolously mistaken.'''

He (Fanny) took it in still, with his (Fanny) long look at her (Fanny).

``All the more that she (Fanny) wasn't. She (Fanny) was right. Everything's right,'' (he)
he (Prince) went on,
``and everything will stay so.'' (he)

``Then that's all I say.'' (he)

But he (Prince) worked it out, for the deeper satisfaction, even to superfluous lucidity.

``We're happy, and they're happy. What more does the position admit of? What more need Fanny Assingham want?'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``it's not I who say that she (Fanny) need want anything. I only say that she (Fanny)'s FIXED, that she (Fanny) must stand exactly where everything has, by her (Fanny) own act, placed her (Fanny). It's you who have seemed haunted with the possibility, for her (Fanny), of some injurious alternative, something or other we must be prepared for.'' (Charlotte)
And she (Charlotte) had, with her (Charlotte) high reasoning, a strange cold smile.
``We ARE prepared--for anything, for everything; and AS we are, practically, so she (Fanny) must take us. She (Fanny)'s condemned to consistency; she (Fanny)'s doomed, poor thing, to a genial optimism. That, luckily for her (Fanny), however, is very much the law of her (Fanny) nature. She (Fanny) was born to soothe and to smooth. Now then, therefore,'' (Mrs. Verver)
Mrs. Verver gently laughed,
``she (Fanny) has the chance of her (Fanny) life!'' (Mrs. Verver)

``So that her (Fanny) present professions may, even at the best, not be sincere?--may be but a mask for doubts and fears, and for gaining time?'' (The Prince)

The Prince had looked, with the question, as if this, again, could trouble him (Prince), and it determined in his (Prince) companion a slight impatience.

``You keep talking about such things as if they were our affair at all. I feel, at any rate, that I've nothing to do with her (Fanny) doubts and fears, or with anything she (Fanny) may feel. She (Fanny) must arrange all that for herself. It's enough for me that she (Fanny)'ll always be, of necessity, much more afraid for herself, REALLY, either to see or to speak, than we should be to have her (Fanny) do it even if we were the idiots and cowards we aren't.'' (Charlotte)
And Charlotte's face, with these words--to the mitigation of the slightly hard ring there might otherwise have been in them--fairly lightened, softened, shone out. It reflected as really never yet the rare felicity of their luck. It made her (Charlotte) look for the moment as if she (Charlotte) had actually pronounced that word of unpermitted presumption--so apt is the countenance, as with a finer consciousness than the tongue, to betray a sense of this particular lapse. She (Charlotte) might indeed, the next instant, have seen her (Charlotte) friend wince, in advance, at her (Charlotte) use of a word that was already on her (Charlotte) lips; for it was still unmistakable with him (friend) that there were things he (friend) could prize, forms of fortune he (friend) could cherish, without at all proportionately liking their names. Had all this, however, been even completely present to his (friend) companion, what other term could she (Charlotte) have applied to the strongest and simplest of her (Charlotte) ideas but the one that exactly fitted it? She (Charlotte) applied it then, though her (Charlotte) own instinct moved her (Charlotte), at the same time, to pay her (Charlotte) tribute to the good taste from which they hadn't heretofore by a hair's breadth deviated.
``If it didn't sound so vulgar I should say that we're--fatally, as it were--SAFE. Pardon the low expression--since it's what we happen to be. We're so because they are. And they're so because they can't be anything else, from the moment that, having originally intervened for them, she (Fanny) wouldn't now be able to bear herself if she (Fanny) didn't keep them so. That's the way she (Fanny)'s inevitably WITH us,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte over her (Charlotte) smile.
``We hang, essentially, together.'' (Prince)

Well, the Prince candidly allowed she (Charlotte) did bring it home to him (Prince). Every way it worked out.

``Yes, I see. We hang, essentially, together.'' (friend)

His (Prince) friend had a shrug--a shrug that had a grace.

``Cosa volete?'' (Roman)
The effect, beautifully, nobly, was more than Roman.
``Ah, beyond doubt, it's a case.'' (He)

He (Roman) stood looking at her (Charlotte).

``It's a case. There can't,'' (he)
he (Roman) said,
``have been many.'' (he)

``Perhaps never, never, never any other. That,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``I confess I should like to think. Only ours.'' (she)

``Only ours--most probably. Speriamo.'' (he)
To which, as after hushed connections, he (Roman) presently added:
``Poor Fanny!'' (he)
But Charlotte had already, with a start and a warning hand, turned from a glance at the clock. She (Charlotte) sailed away to dress, while he (Roman) watched her (Charlotte) reach the staircase. His (Roman) eyes followed her (Charlotte) till, with a simple swift look round at him (Roman), she (Charlotte) vanished. Something in the sight, however, appeared to have renewed the spring of his (Roman) last exclamation, which he (Roman) breathed again upon the air.
``Poor, poor Fanny!'' (the party)

It was to prove, however, on the morrow, quite consistent with the spirit of these words that, the party at Matcham breaking up and multitudinously dispersing, he (Roman) should be able to meet the question of the social side of the process of repatriation with due presence of mind. It was impossible, for reasons, that he (Roman) should travel to town with the Assinghams; it was impossible, for the same reasons, that he (Roman) should travel to town save in the conditions that he (Roman) had for the last twenty-four hours been privately, and it might have been said profoundly, thinking out. The result of his (Roman) thought was already precious to him (Roman), and this put at his (Roman) service, he (Roman) sufficiently believed, the right tone for disposing of his (Roman) elder friend's suggestion, an assumption in fact equally full and mild, that he (Roman) and Charlotte would conveniently take the same train and occupy the same compartment as the Colonel and herself. The extension of the idea to Mrs. Verver had been, precisely, a part of Mrs. Assingham's mildness, and nothing could better have characterised her (Assingham) sense for social shades than her (Assingham) easy perception that the gentleman from Portland Place and the lady from Eaton Square might now confess, quite without indiscretion, to simultaneity of movement. She (Assingham) had made, for the four days, no direct appeal to the latter personage, but the Prince was accidental witness of her (Assingham) taking a fresh start at the moment the company were about to scatter for the last night of their stay. There had been, at this climax, the usual preparatory talk about hours and combinations, in the midst of which poor Fanny gently approached Mrs. Verver. She (Verver) said

``You and the Prince, love,'' (She)
--quite, apparently, without blinking; she (Verver) took for granted their public withdrawal together; she (Verver) remarked that she (Verver) and Bob were alike ready, in the interest of sociability, to take any train that would make them all one party.
``I feel really as if, all this time, I had seen nothing of you'' (unknown)
--that gave an added grace to the candour of the dear thing's approach. But just then it was, on the other hand, that the young man found himself borrow most effectively the secret of the right tone for doing as he (man) preferred. His (man) preference had, during the evening, not failed of occasion to press him (man) with mute insistences; practically without words, without any sort of straight telegraphy, it had arrived at a felt identity with Charlotte's own. She (Charlotte) spoke all for their friend while she (Charlotte) answered their friend's question, but she (Charlotte) none the less signalled to him (friend) as definitely as if she (Charlotte) had fluttered a white handkerchief from a window.
``It's awfully sweet of you, darling--our going together would be charming. But you mustn't mind us--you must suit yourselves we've settled, Amerigo and I, to stay over till after luncheon.'' (Amerigo)

Amerigo, with the chink of this gold in his (friend) ear, turned straight away, so as not to be instantly appealed to; and for the very emotion of the wonder, furthermore, of what divination may achieve when winged by a community of passion. Charlotte had uttered the exact plea that he (friend) had been keeping ready for the same foreseen necessity, and had uttered it simply as a consequence of their deepening unexpressed need of each other and without the passing between them of a word. He (friend) hadn't, God knew, to take it from her (Charlotte)--he (God) was too conscious of what he (God) wanted; but the lesson for him (God) was in the straight clear tone that Charlotte could thus distil, in the perfect felicity of her (Charlotte) adding no explanation, no touch for plausibility, that she (Charlotte) wasn't strictly obliged to add, and in the truly superior way in which women, so situated, express and distinguish themselves. She (Charlotte) had answered Mrs. Assingham quite adequately; she (Charlotte) had not spoiled it by a reason a scrap larger than the smallest that would serve, and she (Charlotte) had, above all, thrown off, for his (God) stretched but covered attention, an image that flashed like a mirror played at the face of the sun. The measure of EVERYTHING, to all his (God) sense, at these moments, was in it--the measure especially of the thought that had been growing with him (God) a positive obsession and that began to throb as never yet under this brush of her (Charlotte) having, by perfect parity of imagination, the match for it. His (God) whole consciousness had by this time begun almost to ache with a truth of an exquisite order, at the glow of which she (Charlotte) too had, so unmistakably then, been warming herself--the truth that the occasion constituted by the last few days couldn't possibly, save by some poverty of their own, refuse them some still other and still greater beauty. It had already told them, with an hourly voice, that it had a meaning--a meaning that their associated sense was to drain even as thirsty lips, after the plough through the sands and the sight, afar, of the palm-cluster, might drink in at last the promised well in the desert. There had been beauty, day after day, and there had been, for the spiritual lips, something of the pervasive taste of it; yet it was all, none the less, as if their response had remained below their fortune. How to bring it, by some brave, free lift, up to the same height was the idea with which, behind and beneath everything, he (it) was restlessly occupied, and in the exploration of which, as in that of the sun-chequered greenwood of romance, his (it) spirit thus, at the opening of a vista, met hers. They were already, from that moment, so hand-in-hand in the place that he (it) found himself making use, five minutes later, of exactly the same tone as Charlotte's for telling Mrs. Assingham that he (it) was likewise, in the matter of the return to London, sorry for what mightn't be.

This had become, of a sudden, the simplest thing in the world--the sense of which moreover seemed really to amount to a portent that he (it) should feel, forevermore, on the general head, conveniently at his (it) ease with her (Assingham). He (it) went in fact a step further than Charlotte--put the latter forward as creating his (it) necessity. She (Charlotte) was staying over luncheon to oblige their hostess--as a consequence of which he (it) must also stay to see her (Charlotte) decently home. He (it) must deliver her (Charlotte) safe and sound, he (it) felt, in Eaton Square. Regret as he (it) might, too, the difference made by this obligation, he (it) frankly didn't mind, inasmuch as, over and above the pleasure itself, his (it) scruple would certainly gratify both Mr. Verver and Maggie. They never yet had absolutely and entirely learned, he (it) even found deliberation to intimate, how little he (it) really neglected the first--as it seemed nowadays quite to have become--of his (it) domestic duties: therefore he (it) still constantly felt how little he (it) must remit his (it) effort to make them remark it. To which he (it) added with equal lucidity that they would return in time for dinner, and if he (it) didn't, as a last word, subjoin that it would be

``lovely'' (he)
of Fanny to find, on her (Fanny) own return, a moment to go to Eaton Square and report them as struggling bravely on, this was not because the impulse, down to the very name for the amiable act, altogether failed to rise. His (Eaton) inward assurance, his (Eaton) general plan, had at moments, where she (Fanny) was concerned, its drops of continuity, and nothing would less have pleased him (Eaton) than that she (Fanny) should suspect in him (Eaton), however tempted, any element of conscious
``cheek.'' (him)
But he (Eaton) was always--that was really the upshot--cultivating thanklessly the considerate and the delicate: it was a long lesson, this unlearning, with people of English race, all the little superstitions that accompany friendship. Mrs. Assingham herself was the first to say that she (Assingham) would unfailingly
``report'' (she)
; she (Assingham) brought it out in fact, he (Eaton) thought, quite wonderfully--having attained the summit of the wonderful during the brief interval that had separated her (Assingham) appeal to Charlotte from this passage with himself. She (Assingham) had taken the five minutes, obviously, amid the rest of the talk and the movement, to retire into her (Assingham) tent for meditation--which showed, among several things, the impression Charlotte had made on her (Charlotte). It was from the tent she (Charlotte) emerged, as with arms refurbished; though who indeed could say if the manner in which she (Charlotte) now met him (Eaton) spoke most, really, of the glitter of battle or of the white waver of the flag of truce? The parley was short either way; the gallantry of her (Charlotte) offer was all sufficient.

``I'll go to our friends then--I'll ask for luncheon. I'll tell them when to expect you.'' (unknown)

``That will be charming. Say we're all right.'' (unknown)

``All right--precisely. I can't say more,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham smiled.

``No doubt.'' (he)
But he (Eaton) considered, as for the possible importance of it.
``Neither can you, by what I seem to feel, say less.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I WON'T say less!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny laughed; with which, the next moment, she (Fanny) had turned away. But they had it again, not less bravely, on the morrow, after breakfast, in the thick of the advancing carriages and the exchange of farewells.
``I think I'll send home my maid from Euston,'' (she)
she (Fanny) was then prepared to amend,
``and go to Eaton Square straight. So you can be easy.'' (she)

``Oh, I think we're easy,'' (Prince)
the Prince returned.
``Be sure to say, at any rate, that we're bearing up.'' (unknown)

``You're bearing up--good. And Charlotte returns to dinner?'' (unknown)

``To dinner. We're not likely, I think, to make another night away.'' (unknown)

``Well then, I wish you at least a pleasant day,'' (he)

``Oh,'' (he)
he (Prince) laughed as they separated,
``we shall do our best for it!'' (he)
--after which, in due course, with the announcement of their conveyance, the Assinghams rolled off.

XXII

It was quite, for the Prince, after this, as if the view had further cleared; so that the half-hour during which he (Prince) strolled on the terrace and smoked--the day being lovely--overflowed with the plenitude of its particular quality. Its general brightness was composed, doubtless, of many elements, but what shone out of it as if the whole place and time had been a great picture, from the hand of genius, presented to him (genius) as a prime ornament for his (genius) collection and all varnished and framed to hang up--what marked it especially for the highest appreciation was his (genius) extraordinarily unchallenged, his (genius) absolutely appointed and enhanced possession of it. Poor Fanny Assingham's challenge amounted to nothing: one of the things he (genius) thought of while he (genius) leaned on the old marble balustrade--so like others that he (genius) knew in still more nobly-terraced Italy--was that she (Assingham) was squared, all-conveniently even to herself, and that, rumbling toward London with this contentment, she (Assingham) had become an image irrelevant to the scene. It further passed across him (genius), as his (genius) imagination was, for reasons, during the time, unprecedentedly active,--that he (genius) had, after all, gained more from women than he (genius) had ever lost by them; there appeared so, more and more, on those mystic books that are kept, in connection with such commerce, even by men of the loosest business habits, a balance in his (genius) favour that he (genius) could pretty well, as a rule, take for granted. What were they doing at this very moment, wonderful creatures, but combine and conspire for his (genius) advantage?--from Maggie herself, most wonderful, in her (Maggie) way, of all, to his (genius) hostess of the present hour, into whose head it had so inevitably come to keep Charlotte on, for reasons of her (Charlotte) own, and who had asked, in this benevolent spirit, why in the world, if not obliged, without plausibility, to hurry, her (Charlotte) husband's son-in-law should not wait over in her (Charlotte) company. He (son-in-law) would at least see, Lady Castledean had said, that nothing dreadful should happen to her (Castledean), either while still there or during the exposure of the run to town; and, for that matter, if they exceeded a little their license it would positively help them to have done so together. Each of them would, in this way, at home, have the other comfortably to blame. All of which, besides, in Lady Castledean as in Maggie, in Fanny Assingham as in Charlotte herself, was working; for him (son-in-law) without provocation or pressure, by the mere play of some vague sense on their part--definite and conscious at the most only in Charlotte--that he (son-in-law) was not, as a nature, as a character, as a gentleman, in fine, below his (gentleman) remarkable fortune.

But there were more things before him (gentleman) than even these; things that melted together, almost indistinguishably, to feed his (gentleman) sense of beauty. If the outlook was in every way spacious--and the towers of three cathedrals, in different counties, as had been pointed out to him (gentleman), gleamed discernibly, like dim silver, in the rich sameness of tone--didn't he (gentleman) somehow the more feel it so because, precisely, Lady Castledean had kept over a man of her (Castledean) own, and that this offered a certain sweet intelligibility as the note of the day? It made everything fit; above all it diverted him (man) to the extent of keeping up, while he (man) lingered and waited, his (man) meditative smile. She (Castledean) had detained Charlotte because she (Charlotte) wished to detain Mr. Blint, and she (Charlotte) couldn't detain Mr. Blint, disposed though he (Blint) clearly was to oblige her (Charlotte), without spreading over the act some ampler drapery. Castledean had gone up to London; the place was all her (Castledean) own; she (Castledean) had had a fancy for a quiet morning with Mr. Blint, a sleek, civil, accomplished young man--distinctly younger than her (Castledean) ladyship--who played and sang delightfully -LRB-played even

``bridge'' (ladyship)
and sang the English-comic as well as the French-tragic-RRB-, and the presence--which really meant the absence--of a couple of other friends, if they were happily chosen, would make everything all right. The Prince had the sense, all good-humouredly, of being happily chosen, and it was not spoiled for him (Prince) even by another sense that followed in its train and with which, during his (Prince) life in England, he (Prince) had more than once had reflectively to deal: the state of being reminded how, after all, as an outsider, a foreigner, and even as a mere representative husband and son-in-law, he (son-in-law) was so irrelevant to the working of affairs that he (son-in-law) could be bent on occasion to uses comparatively trivial. No other of her (its) guests would have been thus convenient for their hostess; affairs, of whatever sorts, had claimed, by early trains, every active, easy, smoothly-working man, each in his (man) way a lubricated item of the great social, political, administrative engrenage--claimed most of all Castledean himself, who was so very oddly, given the personage and the type, rather a large item. If he (man), on the other hand, had an affair, it was not of that order; it was of the order, verily, that he (man) had been reduced to as a not quite glorious substitute.

It marked, however, the feeling of the hour with him (man) that this vision of being

``reduced'' (him)
interfered not at all with the measure of his (man) actual ease. It kept before him (man) again, at moments, the so familiar fact of his (man) sacrifices--down to the idea of the very relinquishment, for his (man) wife's convenience, of his (man) real situation in the world; with the consequence, thus, that he (man) was, in the last analysis, among all these so often inferior people, practically held cheap and made light of. But though all this was sensible enough there was a spirit in him (man) that could rise above it, a spirit that positively played with the facts, with all of them; from that of the droll ambiguity of English relations to that of his (man) having in mind something quite beautiful and independent and harmonious, something wholly his (man) own. He (man) couldn't somehow take Mr. Blint seriously--he (Blint) was much more an outsider, by the larger scale, even than a Roman prince who consented to be in abeyance. Yet it was past finding out, either, how such a woman as Lady Castledean could take him (prince)--since this question but sank for him (prince) again into the fathomless depths of English equivocation. He (prince) knew them all, as was said,
``well'' (He)
; he (prince) had lived with them, stayed with them, dined, hunted, shot and done various other things with them; but the number of questions about them he (prince) couldn't have answered had much rather grown than shrunken, so that experience struck him (prince) for the most part as having left in him (prince) but one residual impression. They didn't like les situations nettes--that was all he (prince) was very sure of. They wouldn't have them at any price; it had been their national genius and their national success to avoid them at every point. They called it themselves, with complacency, their wonderful spirit of compromise--the very influence of which actually so hung about him (genius) here, from moment to moment, that the earth and the air, the light and the colour, the fields and the hills and the sky, the blue-green counties and the cold cathedrals, owed to it every accent of their tone. Verily, as one had to feel in presence of such a picture, it had succeeded; it had made, up to now, for that seated solidity, in the rich sea-mist, on which the garish, the supposedly envious, peoples have ever cooled their eyes. But it was at the same time precisely why even much initiation left one, at given moments, so puzzled as to the element of staleness in all the freshness and of freshness in all the staleness, of innocence in the guilt and of guilt in the innocence. There were other marble terraces, sweeping more purple prospects, on which he (peoples) would have known what to think, and would have enjoyed thereby at least the small intellectual fillip of a discerned relation between a given appearance and a taken meaning. The inquiring mind, in these present conditions, might, it was true, be more sharply challenged; but the result of its attention and its ingenuity, it had unluckily learned to know, was too often to be confronted with a mere dead wall, a lapse of logic, a confirmed bewilderment. And moreover, above all, nothing mattered, in the relation of the enclosing scene to his (its) own consciousness, but its very most direct bearings.

Lady Castledean's dream of Mr. Blint for the morning was doubtless already, with all the spacious harmonies re-established, taking the form of

``going over'' (Mr. Blint)
something with him (Blint), at the piano, in one of the numerous smaller rooms that were consecrated to the less gregarious uses; what she (Castledean) had wished had been effected--her (Castledean) convenience had been assured. This made him (Blint), however, wonder the more where Charlotte was--since he (Blint) didn't at all suppose her (Charlotte) to be making a tactless third, which would be to have accepted mere spectatorship, in the duet of their companions. The upshot of everything for him (Blint), alike of the less and of the more, was that the exquisite day bloomed there like a large fragrant flower that he (Blint) had only to gather. But it was to Charlotte he (Blint) wished to make the offering, and as he (Blint) moved along the terrace, which rendered visible parts of two sides of the house, he (Blint) looked up at all the windows that were open to the April morning, and wondered which of them would represent his (Blint) friend's room. It befell thus that his (Blint) question, after no long time, was answered; he (Blint) saw Charlotte appear above as if she (Charlotte) had been called by the pausing of his (Blint) feet on the flags. She (Charlotte) had come to the sill, on which she (Charlotte) leaned to look down, and she (Charlotte) remained there a minute smiling at him (Blint). He (Blint) had been immediately struck with her (Charlotte) wearing a hat and a jacket--which conduced to her (Charlotte) appearance of readiness not so much to join him (Blint), with a beautiful uncovered head and a parasol, where he (Blint) stood, as to take with him (Blint) some larger step altogether. The larger step had been, since the evening before, intensely in his (Blint) own mind, though he (Blint) had not fully thought out, even yet, the slightly difficult detail of it; but he (Blint) had had no chance, such as he (Blint) needed, to speak the definite word to her (Charlotte), and the face she (Charlotte) now showed affected him (Blint), accordingly, as a notice that she (Charlotte) had wonderfully guessed it for herself. They had these identities of impulse--they had had them repeatedly before; and if such unarranged but unerring encounters gave the measure of the degree in which people were, in the common phrase, meant for each other, no union in the world had ever been more sweetened with rightness. What in fact most often happened was that her (Charlotte) rightness went, as who should say, even further than his (Blint) own; they were conscious of the same necessity at the same moment, only it was she (Charlotte), as a general thing, who most clearly saw her (Charlotte) way to it. Something in her (Charlotte) long look at him (Blint) now out of the old grey window, something in the very poise of her (Charlotte) hat, the colour of her (Charlotte) necktie, the prolonged stillness of her (Charlotte) smile, touched into sudden light for him (Blint) all the wealth of the fact that he (Blint) could count on her (Charlotte). He (Blint) had his (Blint) hand there, to pluck it, on the open bloom of the day; but what did the bright minute mean but that her (Charlotte) answering hand was already intelligently out? So, therefore, while the minute lasted, it passed between them that their cup was full; which cup their very eyes, holding it fast, carried and steadied and began, as they tasted it, to praise. He (Blint) broke, however, after a moment, the silence.

``It only wants a moon, a mandolin, and a little danger, to be a serenade.'' (unknown)

``Ah, then,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) lightly called down,
``let it at least have THIS!'' (she)
With which she (Charlotte) detached a rich white rosebud from its company with another in the front of her (Charlotte) dress and flung it down to him (Blint). He (Blint) caught it in its fall, fixing her (Charlotte) again after she (Charlotte) had watched him (Blint) place it in his (Blint) buttonhole.
``Come down quickly!'' (he)
he (Blint) said in an Italian not loud but deep.

``Vengo, vengo!'' (she)
she (Charlotte) as clearly, but more lightly, tossed out; and she (Charlotte) had left him (Blint) the next minute to wait for her (Charlotte).

He (Blint) came along the terrace again, with pauses during which his (Blint) eyes rested, as they had already often done, on the brave darker wash of far-away watercolour that represented the most distant of the cathedral towns. This place, with its great church and its high accessibility, its towers that distinguishably signalled, its English history, its appealing type, its acknowledged interest, this place had sounded its name to him (Blint) half the night through, and its name had become but another name, the pronounceable and convenient one, for that supreme sense of things which now throbbed within him (Blint). He (Blint) had kept saying to himself

``Gloucester, Gloucester, Gloucester,'' (He)
quite as if the sharpest meaning of all the years just passed were intensely expressed in it. That meaning was really that his (Blint) situation remained quite sublimely consistent with itself, and that they absolutely, he (Blint) and Charlotte, stood there together in the very lustre of this truth. Every present circumstance helped to proclaim it; it was blown into their faces as by the lips of the morning. He (Blint) knew why, from the first of his (Blint) marriage, he (Blint) had tried with such patience for such conformity; he (Blint) knew why he (Blint) had given up so much and bored himself so much; he (Blint) knew why he (Blint), at any rate, had gone in, on the basis of all forms, on the basis of his (Blint) having, in a manner, sold himself, for a situation nette. It had all been just in order that his (Blint)--well, what on earth should he (Blint) call it but his (Blint) freedom?--should at present be as perfect and rounded and lustrous as some huge precious pearl. He (Blint) hadn't struggled nor snatched; he (Blint) was taking but what had been given him (Blint); the pearl dropped itself, with its exquisite quality and rarity, straight into his (Blint) hand. Here, precisely, it was, incarnate; its size and its value grew as Mrs. Verver appeared, afar off, in one of the smaller doorways. She (Verver) came toward him (Blint) in silence, while he (Blint) moved to meet her (Verver); the great scale of this particular front, at Matcham, multiplied thus, in the golden morning, the stages of their meeting and the successions of their consciousness. It wasn't till she (Verver) had come quite close that he (Blint) produced for her (Verver) his (Blint)
``Gloucester, Gloucester, Gloucester,'' (he)
and his (Blint)
``Look at it over there!'' (he)

She (Verver) knew just where to look.

``Yes--isn't it one of the best? There are cloisters or towers or some thing.'' (unknown)
And her (Verver) eyes, which, though her (Verver) lips smiled, were almost grave with their depths of acceptance; came back to him (Blint).
``Or the tomb of some old king.'' (unknown)

``We must see the old king; we must `do' the cathedral,'' (he)
he (Blint) said;
``we must know all about it. If we could but take,'' (he)
he (Blint) exhaled,
``the full opportunity!'' (he)
And then while, for all they seemed to give him (Blint), he (Blint) sounded again her (Verver) eyes:
``I feel the day like a great gold cup that we must somehow drain together.'' (he)

``I feel it, as you always make me feel everything, just as you do; so that I know ten miles off how you feel! But do you remember,'' (she)
she (Verver) asked,
``apropos of great gold cups, the beautiful one, the real one, that I offered you so long ago and that you wouldn't have? Just before your marriage'' (she)
--she (Verver) brought it back to him (Blint):
``the gilded crystal bowl in the little Bloomsbury shop.'' (him)

``Oh yes!'' (Prince)
--but it took, with a slight surprise on the `Prince's part, some small recollecting.
``The treacherous cracked thing you wanted to palm off on me, and the little swindling Jew who understood Italian and who backed you up! But I feel this an occasion,'' (he)
he (Prince) immediately added,
``and I hope you don't mean,'' (he)
he (Prince) smiled,
``that AS an occasion it's also cracked.'' (he)

They spoke, naturally, more low than loud, overlooked as they were, though at a respectful distance, by tiers of windows; but it made each find in the other's voice a taste as of something slowly and deeply absorbed.

``Don't you think too much of `cracks,' and aren't you too afraid of them? I risk the cracks,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
``and I've often recalled the bowl and the little swindling Jew, wondering if they've parted company. He (Jew) made,'' (Charlotte)
she (Charlotte) said,
``a great impression on me.'' (she)

``Well, you also, no doubt, made a great impression on him (Jew), and I dare say that if you were to go back to him (Jew) you'd find he (Jew) has been keeping that treasure for you. But as to cracks,'' (the Prince)
the Prince went on--
``what did you tell me the other day you prettily call them in English?-'rifts within the lute'?--risk them as much as you like for yourself, but don't risk them for me.'' (the Prince)
He (Prince) spoke it in all the gaiety of his (Prince) just barely-tremulous serenity.
``I go, as you know, by my superstitions. And that's why,'' (he)
he (Prince) said,
``I know where we are. They're every one, to-day, on our side.'' (he)

Resting on the parapet; toward the great view, she (Charlotte) was silent a little, and he (Prince) saw the next moment that her (Charlotte) eyes were closed.

``I go but by one thing.'' (unknown)
Her (Charlotte) hand was on the sun-warmed stone; so that, turned as they were away from the house, he (Prince) put his (Prince) own upon it and covered it.
``I go by YOU,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said.
``I go by you.'' (he)

So they remained a moment, till he (Prince) spoke again with a gesture that matched.

``What is really our great necessity, you know, is to go by my watch. It's already eleven'' (he)
--he (Prince) had looked at the time;
``so that if we stop here to luncheon what becomes of our afternoon?'' (he)

To this Charlotte's eyes opened straight.

``There's not the slightest need of our stopping here to luncheon. Don't you see,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) asked,
``how I'm ready?'' (she)
He (Prince) had taken it in, but there was always more and more of her (Charlotte).
``You mean you've arranged--?'' (unknown)

``It's easy to arrange. My maid goes up with my things. You've only to speak to your man about yours, and they can go together.'' (unknown)

``You mean we can leave at once?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) let him (Prince) have it all.

``One of the carriages, about which I spoke, will already have come back for us. If your superstitions are on our side,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``so my arrangements are, and I'll back my support against yours.'' (she)

``Then you had thought,'' (he)
he (Prince) wondered,
``about Gloucester?'' (he)

She (Charlotte) hesitated--but it was only her (Charlotte) way.

``I thought you would think. We have, thank goodness, these harmonies. They are food for superstition if you like. It's beautiful,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) went on,
``that it should be Gloucester; `Glo'ster, Glo'ster,' as you say, making it sound like an old song. However, I'm sure Glo'ster, Glo'ster will be charming,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) still added;
``we shall be able easily to lunch there, and, with our luggage and our servants off our hands, we shall have at least three or four hours. We can wire,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) wound up,
``from there.'' (she)

Ever so quietly she (Charlotte) had brought it, as she (Charlotte) had thought it, all out, and it had to be as covertly that he (Prince) let his (Prince) appreciation expand.

``Then Lady Castledean--?'' (unknown)

``Doesn't dream of our staying.'' (He)

He (Prince) took it, but thinking yet.

``Then what does she (Lady) dream--?'' (unknown)

``Of Mr. Blint, poor dear; of Mr. Blint only.'' (him)
Her (Charlotte) smile for him (Prince)--for the Prince himself--was free.
``Have I positively to tell you that she (Lady) doesn't want us? She (Lady) only wanted us for the others--to show she (Lady) wasn't left alone with him (Blint). Now that that's done, and that they've all gone, she (Lady) of course knows for herself--!'' (unknown)

```Knows'?'' the Prince vaguely echoed.

``Why, that we like cathedrals; that we inevitably stop to see them, or go round to take them in, whenever we've a chance; that it's what our respective families quite expect of us and would be disappointed for us to fail of. This, as forestieri,'' (Mrs. Verver)
Mrs. Verver pursued,
``would be our pull--if our pull weren't indeed so great all round.'' (Mrs. Verver)

He (Prince) could only keep his (Prince) eyes on her (Verver).

``And have you made out the very train--?'' (unknown)

``The very one. Paddington--the 6.50 `in.' That gives us oceans; we can dine, at the usual hour, at home; and as Maggie will of course be in Eaton Square I hereby invite you.'' (he)

For a while he (Prince) still but looked at her (Verver); it was a minute before he (Prince) spoke.

``Thank you very much. With pleasure.'' (he)
To which he (Prince) in a moment added:
``But the train for Gloucester?'' (he)

``A local one--11.22; with several stops, but doing it a good deal, I forget how much, within the hour. So that we've time. Only,'' (she)
she (Verver) said,
``we must employ our time.'' (she)

He (Prince) roused himself as from the mere momentary spell of her (Verver); he (Prince) looked again at his (Prince) watch while they moved back to the door through which she (Verver) had advanced. But he (Prince) had also again questions and stops--all as for the mystery and the charm.

``You looked it up--without my having asked you?'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear,'' (she)
she (Verver) laughed,
``I've seen you with Bradshaw! It takes Anglo-Saxon blood.'' (she)

```Blood'?'' he (Prince) echoed. ``You've that of every race!'' It kept her (Verver) before him (Prince).

``You're terrible.'' (he)

Well, he (Prince) could put it as he (Prince) liked.

``I know the name of the inn.'' (unknown)

``What is it then?'' (unknown)

``There are two--you'll see. But I've chosen the right one. And I think I remember the tomb,'' (she)
she (Verver) smiled.

``Oh, the tomb--!'' (him)
Any tomb would do for him (Prince).
``But I mean I had been keeping my idea so cleverly for you, while there you already were with it.'' (unknown)

``You had been keeping it `for' me as much as you like. But how do you make out,'' (she)
she (Verver) asked,
``that you were keeping it FROM me?'' (she)

``I don't--now. How shall I ever keep anything--some day when I shall wish to?'' (unknown)

``Ah, for things I mayn't want to know, I promise you shall find me stupid.'' (she)
They had reached their door, where she (Verver) herself paused to explain.
``These days, yesterday, last night, this morning, I've wanted everything.'' (unknown)

Well, it was all right.

``You shall have everything.'' (XXIII Fanny)

XXIII

Fanny, on her (Fanny) arrival in town, carried out her (Fanny) second idea, despatching the Colonel to his (Colonel) club for luncheon and packing her (Fanny) maid into a cab, for Cadogan Place, with the variety of their effects. The result of this for each of the pair was a state of occupation so unbroken that the day practically passed without fresh contact between them. They dined out together, but it was both in going to their dinner and in coming back that they appeared, on either side, to have least to communicate. Fanny was wrapped in her (Fanny) thoughts still more closely than in the lemon-coloured mantle that protected her (Fanny) bare shoulders, and her (Fanny) husband, with her (Fanny) silence to deal with, showed himself not less disposed than usual, when so challenged, to hold up, as he (husband) would have said, his (husband) end of it. They had, in general, in these days, longer pauses and more abrupt transitions; in one of which latter they found themselves, for a climax, launched at midnight. Mrs. Assingham, rather wearily housed again, ascended to the first floor, there to sink, overburdened, on the landing outside the drawing-room, into a great gilded Venetian chair--of which at first, however, she (Assingham) but made, with her (Assingham) brooding face, a sort of throne of meditation. She (Assingham) would thus have recalled a little, with her (Assingham) so free orientalism of type, the immemorially speechless Sphinx about at last to become articulate. The Colonel, not unlike, on his (Colonel) side, some old pilgrim of the desert camping at the foot of that monument, went, by way of reconnoissance, into the drawing-room. He (Colonel) visited, according to his (Colonel) wont, the windows and their fastenings; he (Colonel) cast round the place the eye, all at once, of the master and the manager, the commandant and the rate-payer; then he (commandant) came back to his (commandant) wife, before whom, for a moment, he (commandant) stood waiting. But she (wife) herself, for a time, continued to wait, only looking up at him (commandant) inscrutably. There was in these minor manoeuvres and conscious patiences something of a suspension of their old custom of divergent discussion, that intercourse by misunderstanding which had grown so clumsy now. This familiar pleasantry seemed to desire to show it could yield, on occasion, to any clear trouble; though it was also sensibly, and just incoherently, in the air that no trouble was at present to be vulgarly recognised as clear.

There might, for that matter, even have been in Mr. Assingham's face a mild perception of some finer sense--a sense for his (Mr.) wife's situation, and the very situation she (wife) was, oddly enough, about to repudiate--that she (wife) had fairly caused to grow in him (Mr.). But it was a flower to breathe upon gently, and this was very much what she (wife) finally did. She (wife) knew he (Mr.) needed no telling that she (wife) had given herself, all the afternoon, to her (wife) friends in Eaton Square, and that her (wife) doing so would have been but the prompt result of impressions gathered, in quantities, in brimming baskets, like the purple grapes of the vintage, at Matcham; a process surrounded by him (Eaton), while it so unmistakably went on, with abstentions and discretions that might almost have counted as solemnities. The solemnities, at the same time, had committed him (Eaton) to nothing--to nothing beyond this confession itself of a consciousness of deep waters. She (wife) had been out on these waters, for him (Eaton), visibly; and his (Eaton) tribute to the fact had been his (Eaton) keeping her (wife), even if without a word, well in sight. He (Eaton) had not quitted for an hour, during her (wife) adventure, the shore of the mystic lake; he (Eaton) had on the contrary stationed himself where she (wife) could signal to him (Eaton) at need. Her (wife) need would have arisen if the planks of her (wife) bark had parted--THEN some sort of plunge would have become his (Eaton) immediate duty. His (Eaton) present position, clearly, was that of seeing her (wife) in the centre of her (wife) sheet of dark water, and of wondering if her (wife) actual mute gaze at him (Eaton) didn't perhaps mean that her (wife) planks WERE now parting. He (Eaton) held himself so ready that it was quite as if the inward man had pulled off coat and waistcoat. Before he (man) had plunged, however--that is before he (man) had uttered a question--he (man) perceived, not without relief, that she (wife) was making for land. He (man) watched her (wife) steadily paddle, always a little nearer, and at last he (man) felt her (wife) boat bump. The bump was distinct, and in fact she (wife) stepped ashore.

``We were all wrong. There's nothing.'' (unknown)

``Nothing--?'' (unknown)
It was like giving her (wife) his (man) hand up the bank.

``Between Charlotte Verver and the Prince. I was uneasy--but I'm satisfied now. I was in fact quite mistaken. There's nothing.'' (unknown)

``But I thought,'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
said Bob Assingham,
``that that was just what you did persistently asseverate. You've guaranteed their straightness from the first.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

``No--I've never till now guaranteed anything but my own disposition to worry. I've never till now,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny went on gravely from her (Fanny) chair,
``had such a chance to see and to judge. I had it at that place--if I had, in my infatuation and my folly,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
she (Fanny) added with expression,
``nothing else. So I did see--I HAVE seen. And now I know.'' (she)
Her (Fanny) emphasis, as she (Fanny) repeated the word, made her (Fanny) head, in her (Fanny) seat of infallibility, rise higher.
``I know.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel took it--but took it at first in silence.

``Do you mean they've TOLD you--?'' (unknown)

``No--I mean nothing so absurd. For in the first place I haven't asked them, and in the second their word in such a matter wouldn't count.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (the Colonel)
said the Colonel with all his (Colonel) oddity,
``they'd tell US.'' (the Colonel)

It made her (Fanny) face him (Colonel) an instant as with her (Fanny) old impatience of his (Colonel) short cuts, always across her (Fanny) finest flower-beds; but she (Fanny) felt, none the less, that she (Fanny) kept her (Fanny) irony down.

``Then when they've told you, you'll be perhaps so good as to let me know.'' (He)

He (Colonel) jerked up his (Colonel) chin, testing the growth of his (Colonel) beard with the back of his (Colonel) hand while he (Colonel) fixed her (Fanny) with a single eye.

``Ah, I don't say that they'd necessarily tell me that they ARE over the traces.'' (unknown)

``They'll necessarily, whatever happens, hold their tongues, I hope, and I'm talking of them now as I take them for myself only. THAT'S enough for me--it's all I have to regard.'' (unknown)
With which, after an instant,
``They're wonderful,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

``Indeed,'' (husband)
her (Assingham) husband concurred,
``I really think they are.'' (husband)

``You'd think it still more if you knew. But you don't know--because you don't see. Their situation'' (he)
--this was what he (husband) didn't see--
``is too extraordinary.'' (he)

```Too'?'' He (husband) was willing to try.

``Too extraordinary to be believed, I mean, if one didn't see. But just that, in a way, is what saves them. They take it seriously.'' (He)

He (husband) followed at his (husband) own pace.

``Their situation?'' (unknown)

``The incredible side of it. They make it credible.'' (unknown)

``Credible then--you do say--to YOU?'' (She)

She (Assingham) looked at him (husband) again for an interval.

``They believe in it themselves. They take it for what it is. And that,'' (she)
she (Assingham) said,
``saves them.'' (she)

``But if what it `is' is just their chance--?'' (unknown)

``It's their chance for what I told you when Charlotte first turned up. It's their chance for the idea that I was then sure she (Charlotte) had.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel showed his (Colonel) effort to recall.

``Oh, your idea, at different moments, of any one of THEIR ideas!'' (him)
This dim procession, visibly, mustered before him (Colonel), and, with the best will in the world, he (Colonel) could but watch its immensity.
``Are you speaking now of something to which you can comfortably settle down?'' (she)

Again, for a little, she (Assingham) only glowered at him (Colonel).

``I've come back to my belief, and that I have done so--'' (he)

``Well?'' (he)
he (Colonel) asked as she (Assingham) paused.

``Well, shows that I'm right--for I assure you I had wandered far. Now I'm at home again, and I mean,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham,
``to stay here. They're beautiful,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
she (Assingham) declared.

``The Prince and Charlotte?'' (unknown)

``The Prince and Charlotte. THAT'S how they're so remarkable. And the beauty,'' (she)
she (Assingham) explained,
``is that they're afraid for them. Afraid, I mean, for the others.'' (she)

``For Mr. Verver and Maggie?'' (unknown)
It did take some following.
``Afraid of what?'' (unknown)

``Afraid of themselves.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel wondered.

``Of THEMSELVES? Of Mr. Verver's and Maggie's selves?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham remained patient as well as lucid.

``Yes--of SUCH blindness too. But most of all of their own danger.'' (He)

He (Colonel) turned it over.

``That danger BEING the blindness--?'' (unknown)

``That danger being their position. What their position contains--of all the elements--I needn't at this time of day attempt to tell you. It contains, luckily--for that's the mercy--everything BUT blindness: I mean on their part. The blindness,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny,
``is primarily her (Maggie) husband's.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

He (Colonel) stood for a moment; he (Colonel) WOULD have it straight.

``Whose husband's?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Verver's,'' (she)
she (Fanny) went on.
``The blindness is most of all his (Verver). That they feel--that they see. But it's also his (Verver) wife's.'' (unknown)

``Whose wife's?'' (he)
he (Colonel) asked as she (Fanny) continued to gloom at him (Colonel) in a manner at variance with the comparative cheer of her (Fanny) contention. And then as she (Fanny) only gloomed:
``The Prince's?'' (she)

``Maggie's own--Maggie's very own,'' (she)
she (Fanny) pursued as for herself.

He (Colonel) had a pause.

``Do you think Maggie so blind?'' (unknown)

``The question isn't of what I think. The question's of the conviction that guides the Prince and Charlotte--who have better opportunities than I for judging.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel again wondered.

``Are you so very sure their opportunities are better?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife asked,
``what is their whole so extraordinary situation, their extraordinary relation, but an opportunity?'' (wife)

``Ah, my dear, you have that opportunity--of their extraordinary situation and relation--as much as they.'' (unknown)

``With the difference, darling,'' (she)
she (wife) returned with some spirit,
``that neither of those matters are, if you please, mine. I see the boat they're in, but I'm not, thank God, in it myself. To-day, however,'' (she)
Mrs. Assingham added,
``to-day in Eaton Square I did see.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Well then, what?'' (she)

But she (Assingham) mused over it still.

``Oh, many things. More, somehow, than ever before. It was as if, God help me, I was seeing FOR them--I mean for the others. It was as if something had happened--I don't know what, except some effect of these days with them at that place--that had either made things come out or had cleared my own eyes.'' (the lady)
