These eyes indeed of the poor lady's rested on her (Assingham) companion's, meanwhile, with the lustre not so much of intenser insight as of a particular portent that he (companion) had at various other times had occasion to recognise. She (Assingham) desired, obviously, to reassure him (companion), but it apparently took a couple of large, candid, gathering, glittering tears to emphasise the fact. They had immediately, for him (companion), their usual direct action: she (Assingham) must reassure him (companion), he (companion) was made to feel, absolutely in her (Assingham) own way. He (companion) would adopt it and conform to it as soon as he (companion) should be able to make it out. The only thing was that it took such incalculable twists and turns. The twist seemed remarkable for instance as she (Assingham) developed her (Assingham) indication of what had come out in the afternoon.
``It was as if I knew better than ever what makes them--'' (unknown)

``What makes them?'' (he)
--he (companion) pressed her (Assingham) as she (Assingham) fitfully dropped.

``Well, makes the Prince and Charlotte take it all as they do. It might well have been difficult to know HOW to take it; and they may even say for themselves that they were a long time trying to see. As I say, to-day,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on,
``it was as if I were suddenly, with a kind of horrible push, seeing through their eyes.'' (she)
On which, as to shake off her (Assingham) perversity, Fanny Assingham sprang up. But she (Assingham) remained there, under the dim illumination, and while the Colonel, with his (Colonel) high, dry, spare look of
``type,'' (the Colonel)
to which a certain conformity to the whiteness of inaccessible snows in his (Colonel) necktie, shirt-front and waistcoat gave a rigour of accent, waited, watching her (Assingham), they might, at the late hour and in the still house, have been a pair of specious worldly adventurers, driven for relief, under sudden stress, to some grim midnight reckoning in an odd corner. Her (Assingham) attention moved mechanically over the objects of ornament disposed too freely on the walls of staircase and landing, as to which recognition, for the time, had lost both fondness and compunction.
``I can imagine the way it works,'' (she)
she (Assingham) said;
``it's so easy to understand. Yet I don't want to be wrong,'' (she)
she (Assingham) the next moment broke out
``I don't, I don't want to be wrong!'' (she)

``To make a mistake, you mean?'' (she)

Oh no, she (Assingham) meant nothing of the sort; she (Assingham) knew but too well what she (Assingham) meant.

``I don't make mistakes. But I perpetrate--in thought--crimes.'' (she)
And she (Assingham) spoke with all intensity.
``I'm a most dreadful person. There are times when I seem not to mind a bit what I've done, or what I think or imagine or fear or accept; when I feel that I'd do it again--feel that I'd do things myself.'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear!'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel remarked in the coolness of debate.

``Yes, if you had driven me back on my `nature.' Luckily for you you never have. You've done every thing else, but you've never done that. But what I really don't a bit want,'' (she)
she (Assingham) declared,
``is to abet them or to protect them.'' (she)

Her (Assingham) companion turned this over.

``What is there to protect them from?--if, by your now so settled faith, they've done nothing that justly exposes them.'' (unknown)

And it in fact half pulled her (Assingham) up.

``Well, from a sudden scare. From the alarm, I mean, of what Maggie MAY think.'' (unknown)

``Yet if your whole idea is that Maggie thinks nothing--?'' (She)

She (Assingham) waited again.

``It isn't my `whole' idea. Nothing is my `whole' idea--for I felt to-day, as I tell you, that there's so much in the air.'' (unknown)

``Oh, in the air--!'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel dryly breathed.

``Well, what's in the air always HAS--hasn't it?--to come down to the earth. And Maggie,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham continued,
``is a very curious little person. Since I was `in,' this afternoon, for seeing more than I had ever done--well, I felt THAT too, for some reason, as I hadn't yet felt it.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``For `some' reason? For what reason?'' (wife)
And then, as his (Colonel) wife at first said nothing:
``Did she (Maggie) give any sign? Was she (Maggie) in any way different?'' (wife)

``She (Maggie)'s always so different from anyone else in the world that it's hard to say when she (Maggie)'s different from herself. But she (Maggie) has made me,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny after an instant,
``think of her (Maggie) differently. She (Maggie) drove me home.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Home here?'' (unknown)

``First to Portland Place--on her (Maggie) leaving her (Maggie) father: since she (Maggie) does, once in a while, leave him (father). That was to keep me with her (Maggie) a little longer. But she (Maggie) kept the carriage and, after tea there, came with me herself back here. This was also for the same purpose. Then she (Maggie) went home, though I had brought her (Maggie) a message from the Prince that arranged their movements otherwise. He (Prince) and Charlotte must have arrived--if they have arrived--expecting to drive together to Eaton Square and keep Maggie on to dinner there. She (Maggie) has everything there, you know--she (Maggie) has clothes.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel didn't in fact know, but he (Colonel) gave it his (Colonel) apprehension.

``Oh, you mean a change?'' (unknown)

``Twenty changes, if you like--all sorts of things. She (Maggie) dresses, really, Maggie does, as much for her (Maggie) father--and she (Maggie) always did--as for her (Maggie) husband or for herself. She (Maggie) has her (Maggie) room in his (husband) house very much as she (Maggie) had it before she (Maggie) was married--and just as the boy has quite a second nursery there, in which Mrs. Noble, when she (Noble) comes with him (boy), makes herself, I assure you, at home. Si bien that if Charlotte, in her (Charlotte) own house, so to speak, should wish a friend or two to stay with her (Charlotte), she (Charlotte) really would be scarce able to put them up.'' (a thrifty entertainer)

It was a picture into which, as a thrifty entertainer himself, Bob Assingham could more or less enter.

``Maggie and the child spread so?'' (unknown)

``Maggie and the child spread so.'' (he)

Well, he (Assingham) considered.

``It IS rather rum,'' (she)

``That's all I claim'' (she)
--she (Fanny) seemed thankful for the word.
``I don't say it's anything more--but it IS, distinctly, rum.'' (the Colonel)

Which, after an instant, the Colonel took up. ```More'? What more COULD it be?''

``It could be that she (Maggie)'s unhappy, and that she (Maggie) takes her (Maggie) funny little way of consoling herself. For if she (Maggie) were unhappy'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--Mrs. Assingham had figured it out--
``that's just the way, I'm convinced, she (Maggie) would take. But how can she (Maggie) be unhappy, since--as I'm also convinced--she (Maggie), in the midst of everything, adores her (Maggie) husband as much as ever?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

The Colonel at this brooded for a little at large.

``Then if she (Maggie)'s so happy, please what's the matter?'' (wife)

It made his (Colonel) wife almost spring at him (Colonel).

``You think then she (Maggie)'s secretly wretched?'' (he)

But he (Colonel) threw up his (Colonel) arms in deprecation.

``Ah, my dear, I give them up to YOU. I've nothing more to suggest.'' (unknown)

``Then it's not sweet of you.'' (She)
She (wife) spoke at present as if he (Colonel) were frequently sweet. ``You admit that it is `rum.'''

And this indeed fixed again, for a moment, his (husband) intention.

``Has Charlotte complained of the want of rooms for her (Charlotte) friends?'' (unknown)

``Never, that I know of, a word. It isn't the sort of thing she (Charlotte) does. And whom has she (Charlotte), after all,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham added,
``to complain to?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Hasn't she (Charlotte) always you?'' (unknown)

``Oh, `me'! Charlotte and I, nowadays--!'' (She)
She (Assingham) spoke as of a chapter closed.
``Yet see the justice I still do her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) strikes me, more and more, as extraordinary.'' (the Colonel)

A deeper shade, at the renewal of the word, had come into the Colonel's face.

``If they're each and all so extraordinary then, isn't that why one must just resign one's self to wash one's hands of them--to be lost?'' (he)
Her (Assingham) face, however, so met the question as if it were but a flicker of the old tone that their trouble had now become too real for--her (Assingham) charged eyes so betrayed the condition of her (Assingham) nerves that he (Colonel) stepped back, alertly enough, to firmer ground. He (Colonel) had spoken before in this light of a plain man's vision, but he (Colonel) must be something more than a plain man now.
``Hasn't she (Charlotte) then, Charlotte, always her (Charlotte) husband--?'' (unknown)

``To complain to? She (Charlotte)'d rather die.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)
--and Bob Assingham's face, at the vision of such extremities, lengthened for very docility.
``Hasn't she (Charlotte) the Prince then?'' (unknown)

``For such matters? Oh, he (Prince) doesn't count.'' (unknown)

``I thought that was just what--as the basis of our agitation--he (Prince) does do!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham, however, had her (Assingham) distinction ready.

``Not a bit as a person to bore with complaints. The ground of MY agitation is, exactly, that she (MY) never on any pretext bores him (Prince). Not Charlotte!'' (Mrs. Verver)
And in the imagination of Mrs. Verver's superiority to any such mistake she (Verver) gave, characteristically, something like a toss of her (Verver) head--as marked a tribute to that lady's general grace, in all the conditions, as the personage referred to doubtless had ever received.

``Ah, only Maggie!'' (the Colonel)
With which the Colonel gave a short low gurgle. But it found his (Colonel) wife again prepared.

``No--not only Maggie. A great many people in London--and small wonder!--bore him (Prince).'' (unknown)

``Maggie only worst then?'' (he)
But it was a question that he (Colonel) had promptly dropped at the returning brush of another, of which she (wife) had shortly before sown the seed.
``You said just now that he (Prince) would by this time be back with Charlotte `if they HAVE arrived.' You think it then possible that they really won't have returned?'' (companion)

His (Colonel) companion exhibited to view, for the idea, a sense of her (wife) responsibility; but this was insufficient, clearly, to keep her (wife) from entertaining it.

``I think there's nothing they're not now capable of--in their so intense good faith.'' (unknown)

``Good faith?'' (he)
--he (Colonel) echoed the words, which had in fact something of an odd ring, critically.

``Their false position. It comes to the same thing.'' (she)
And she (wife) bore down, with her (wife) decision, the superficial lack of sequence.
``They may very possibly, for a demonstration--as I see them--not have come back.'' (He)

He (Colonel) wondered, visibly, at this, how she (wife) did see them.

``May have bolted somewhere together?'' (unknown)

``May have stayed over at Matcham itself till tomorrow. May have wired home, each of them, since Maggie left me. May have done,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham continued,
``God knows what!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
She (Assingham) went on, suddenly, with more emotion--which, at the pressure of some spring of her (Assingham) inner vision, broke out in a wail of distress, imperfectly smothered.
``Whatever they've done I shall never know. Never, never--because I don't want to, and because nothing will induce me. So they may do as they like. But I've worked for them ALL'' (She)
She (Assingham) uttered this last with another irrepressible quaver, and the next moment her (Assingham) tears had come, though she (Assingham) had, with the explosion, quitted her (Assingham) husband as if to hide it from him (husband). She (Assingham) passed into the dusky drawing-room, where, during his (husband) own prowl, shortly previous, he (husband) had drawn up a blind, so that the light of the street-lamps came in a little at the window. She (Assingham) made for this window, against which she (Assingham) leaned her (Assingham) head, while the Colonel, with his (Colonel) lengthened face, looked after her (Assingham) for a minute and hesitated. He (Colonel) might have been wondering what she (Assingham) had really done, to what extent, beyond his (Colonel) knowledge or his (Colonel) conception, in the affairs of these people, she (Assingham) COULD have committed herself. But to hear her (Assingham) cry, and yet try not to, was, quickly enough, too much for him (Colonel); he (Colonel) had known her (Assingham) at other times quite not try not to, and that had not been so bad. He (Colonel) went to her (Assingham) and put his (Colonel) arm round her (Assingham); he (Colonel) drew her (Assingham) head to his (Colonel) breast, where, while she (Assingham) gasped, she (Assingham) let it stay a little--all with a patience that presently stilled her (Assingham). Yet the effect of this small crisis, oddly enough, was not to close their colloquy, with the natural result of sending them to bed: what was between them had opened out further, had somehow, through the sharp show of her (Assingham) feeling, taken a positive stride, had entered, as it were, without more words, the region of the understood, shutting the door after it and bringing them so still more nearly face to face. They remained for some minutes looking at it through the dim window which opened upon the world of human trouble in general and which let the vague light play here and there upon gilt and crystal and colour, the florid features, looming dimly, of Fanny's drawing-room. And the beauty of what thus passed between them, passed with her (Fanny) cry of pain, with her (Fanny) burst of tears, with his (them) wonderment and his (them) kindness and his (them) comfort, with the moments of their silence, above all, which might have represented their sinking together, hand in hand, for a time, into the mystic lake where he (them) had begun, as we have hinted, by seeing her (Fanny) paddle alone--the beauty of it was that they now could really talk better than before, because the basis had at last, once for all, defined itself. What was the basis, which Fanny absolutely exacted, but that Charlotte and the Prince must be saved--so far as consistently speaking of them as still safe might save them? It did save them, somehow, for Fanny's troubled mind--for that was the nature of the mind of women. He (Prince) conveyed to her (Fanny) now, at all events, by refusing her (Fanny) no gentleness, that he (Prince) had sufficiently got the tip, and that the tip was all he (Prince) had wanted. This remained quite clear even when he (Prince) presently reverted to what she (Fanny) had told him (Prince) of her (Fanny) recent passage with Maggie.
``I don't altogether see, you know, what you infer from it, or why you infer anything.'' (he)
When he (Prince) so expressed himself it was quite as if in possession of what they had brought up from the depths.

XXIV

``I can't say more,'' (companion)
this made his (Prince) companion reply,
``than that something in her (Maggie) face, her (Maggie) voice and her (Maggie) whole manner acted upon me as nothing in her (Maggie) had ever acted before; and just for the reason, above all, that I felt her (Maggie) trying her (Maggie) very best--and her (Maggie) very best, poor duck, is very good--to be quiet and natural. It's when one sees people who always ARE natural making little pale, pathetic, blinking efforts for it--then it is that one knows something's the matter. I can't describe my impression--you would have had it for yourself. And the only thing that ever CAN be the matter with Maggie is that. By `that' I mean her (Maggie) beginning to doubt. To doubt, for the first time,'' (companion)
Mrs. Assingham wound up,
``of her (Maggie) wonderful little judgment of her (Maggie) wonderful little world.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

It was impressive, Fanny's vision, and the Colonel, as if himself agitated by it, took another turn of prowling.

``To doubt of fidelity--to doubt of friendship! Poor duck indeed! It will go hard with her (Maggie). But she (Maggie)'ll put it all,'' (he)
he (Colonel) concluded,
``on Charlotte.'' (he)

Mrs. Assingham, still darkly contemplative, denied this with a headshake.

``She (Charlotte) won't `put' it anywhere. She (Charlotte) won't do with it anything anyone else would. She (Charlotte)'ll take it all herself.'' (unknown)

``You mean she (Charlotte)'ll make it out her (Charlotte) own fault?'' (unknown)

``Yes--she (Charlotte)'ll find means, somehow, to arrive at that.'' (unknown)

``Ah then,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel dutifully declared,
``she (Charlotte)'s indeed a little brick!'' (the Colonel)

``Oh,'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife returned,
``you'll see, in one way or another, to what tune!'' (wife)
And she (wife) spoke, of a sudden, with an approach to elation--so that, as if immediately feeling his (Colonel) surprise, she (wife) turned round to him (Colonel).
``She (Charlotte)'ll see me somehow through!'' (unknown)

``See YOU--?'' (unknown)

``Yes, me. I'm the worst. For,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham, now with a harder exaltation,
``I did it all. I recognise that--I accept it. She (Charlotte) won't cast it up at me--she (Charlotte) won't cast up anything. So I throw myself upon her (Charlotte)--she (Charlotte)'ll bear me up.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
She (Assingham) spoke almost volubly--she (Assingham) held him (Colonel) with her (Assingham) sudden sharpness.
``She (Charlotte)'ll carry the whole weight of us.'' (unknown)

There was still, nevertheless, wonder in it.

``You mean she (Charlotte) won't mind? I SAY, love--!'' (he)
And he (Colonel) not unkindly stared.
``Then where's the difficulty?'' (unknown)

``There isn't any!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny declared with the same rich emphasis. It kept him (Colonel) indeed, as by the loss of the thread, looking at her (Fanny) longer.
``Ah, you mean there isn't any for US!'' (She)

She (Fanny) met his (Colonel) look for a minute as if it perhaps a little too much imputed a selfishness, a concern, at any cost, for their own surface. Then she (Fanny) might have been deciding that their own surface was, after all, what they had most to consider.

``Not,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said with dignity,
``if we properly keep our heads.'' (she)
She (Fanny) appeared even to signify that they would begin by keeping them now. This was what it was to have at last a constituted basis.
``Do you remember what you said to me that night of my first REAL anxiety--after the Foreign Office party?'' (unknown)

``In the carriage--as we came home?'' (he)
Yes--he (Colonel) could recall it.
``Leave them to pull through?'' (unknown)

``Precisely. `Trust their own wit,' you practically said, `to save all appearances.' Well, I've trusted it. I HAVE left them to pull through.'' (He)

He (Colonel) hesitated.

``And your point is that they're not doing so?'' (unknown)

``I've left them,'' (she)
she (Fanny) went on,
``but now I see how and where. I've been leaving them all the while, without knowing it, to HER.'' (she)

``To the Princess?'' (unknown)

``And that's what I mean,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham pensively pursued.
``That's what happened to me with her (Princess) to-day,'' (she)
she (Assingham) continued to explain.
``It came home to me that that's what I've really been doing.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I see.'' (unknown)

``I needn't torment myself. She (Princess) has taken them over.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel declared that he (Colonel)

``saw'' (he)
; yet it was as if, at this, he (Colonel) a little sightlessly stared.
``But what then has happened, from one day to the other, to HER? What has opened her (Princess) eyes?'' (unknown)

``They were never really shut. She (Princess) misses him (me).'' (unknown)

``Then why hasn't she (Princess) missed him (me) before?'' (him)

Well, facing him (Colonel) there, among their domestic glooms and glints, Fanny worked it out.

``She (Princess) did--but she (Princess) wouldn't let herself know it. She (Princess) had her (Princess) reason--she (Princess) wore her (Princess) blind. Now, at last, her (Princess) situation has come to a head. To-day she (Princess) does know it. And that's illuminating. It has been,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham wound up,
``illuminating to ME.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Her (Assingham) husband attended, but the momentary effect of his (husband) attention was vagueness again, and the refuge of his (husband) vagueness was a gasp.

``Poor dear little girl!'' (unknown)

``Ah no--don't pity her (girl)!'' (him)

This did, however, pull him (husband) up.

``We mayn't even be sorry for her (girl)?'' (unknown)

``Not now--or at least not yet. It's too soon--that is if it isn't very much too late. This will depend,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham went on;
``at any rate we shall see. We might have pitied her (girl) before--for all the good it would then have done her (girl); we might have begun some time ago. Now, however, she (girl) has begun to live. And the way it comes to me, the way it comes to me--'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
But again she (Assingham) projected her (Assingham) vision.

``The way it comes to you can scarcely be that she (girl)'ll like it!'' (unknown)

``The way it comes to me is that she (girl) will live. The way it comes to me is that she (girl)'ll triumph.'' (She)

She (Assingham) said this with so sudden a prophetic flare that it fairly cheered her (Assingham) husband.

``Ah then, we must back her (girl)!'' (unknown)

``No--we mustn't touch her (girl). We mayn't touch any of them. We must keep our hands off; we must go on tiptoe. We must simply watch and wait. And meanwhile,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham,
``we must bear it as we can. That's where we are--and serves us right. We're in presence.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

And so, moving about the room as in communion with shadowy portents, she (Assingham) left it till he (husband) questioned again.

``In presence of what?'' (unknown)

``Well, of something possibly beautiful. Beautiful as it MAY come off.'' (She)

She (Assingham) had paused there before him (husband) while he (husband) wondered.

``You mean she (girl)'ll get the Prince back?'' (She)

She (Assingham) raised her (Assingham) hand in quick impatience: the suggestion might have been almost abject.

``It isn't a question of recovery. It won't be a question of any vulgar struggle. To `get him (Prince) back' she (girl) must have lost him (Prince), and to have lost him (Prince) she (girl) must have had him (Prince).'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
With which Fanny shook her (Fanny) head.
``What I take her (girl) to be waking up to is the truth that, all the while, she (girl) really HASN'T had him (Prince). Never.'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear--!'' (the Colonel)
the poor Colonel panted.

``Never!'' (wife)
his (Colonel) wife repeated. And she (wife) went on without pity.
``Do you remember what I said to you long ago--that evening, just before their marriage, when Charlotte had so suddenly turned up?'' (he)

The smile with which he (Colonel) met this appeal was not, it was to be feared, robust.

``What haven't you, love, said in your time?'' (unknown)

``So many things, no doubt, that they make a chance for my having once or twice spoken the truth. I never spoke it more, at all events, than when I put it to you, that evening, that Maggie was the person in the world to whom a wrong thing could least be communicated. It was as if her (Maggie) imagination had been closed to it, her (Maggie) sense altogether sealed, That therefore,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny continued,
``is what will now HAVE to happen. Her (Maggie) sense will have to open.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``I see.'' (He)
He (Colonel) nodded.
``To the wrong.'' (He)
He (Colonel) nodded again, almost cheerfully--as if he (Colonel) had been keeping the peace with a baby or a lunatic.
``To the very, very wrong.'' (wife)

But his (Colonel) wife's spirit, after its effort of wing, was able to remain higher.

``To what's called Evil--with a very big E: for the first time in her (Maggie) life. To the discovery of it, to the knowledge of it, to the crude experience of it.'' (she)
And she (wife) gave, for the possibility, the largest measure.
``To the harsh, bewildering brush, the daily chilling breath of it. Unless indeed'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
--and here Mrs. Assingham noted a limit
``unless indeed, as yet -LRB-so far as she (Maggie) has come, and if she (Maggie) comes no further-RRB-, simply to the suspicion and the dread. What we shall see is whether that mere dose of alarm will prove enough.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

He (Colonel) considered.

``But enough for what then, dear--if not enough to break her (Maggie) heart?'' (unknown)

``Enough to give her (Maggie) a shaking!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham rather oddly replied.
``To give her (Maggie), I mean, the right one. The right one won't break her (Maggie) heart. It will make her (Maggie),'' (she)
she (Assingham) explained--
``well, it will make her (Maggie), by way of a change, understand one or two things in the world.'' (she)

``But isn't it a pity,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel asked,
``that they should happen to be the one or two that will be the most disagreeable to her (Maggie)?'' (the Colonel)

``Oh, `disagreeable'--? They'll have had to be disagreeable--to show her (Maggie) a little where she (Maggie) is. They'll have HAD to be disagreeable to make her (Maggie) sit up. They'll have had to be disagreeable to make her (Maggie) decide to live.'' (Bob Assingham/Bob)

Bob Assingham was now at the window, while his (Assingham) companion slowly revolved; he (Assingham) had lighted a cigarette, for final patience, and he (Assingham) seemed vaguely to

``time'' (he)
her (Assingham) as she (Assingham) moved to and fro. He (Assingham) had at the same time to do justice to the lucidity she (Assingham) had at last attained, and it was doubtless by way of expression of this teachability that he (Assingham) let his (Assingham) eyes, for a minute, roll, as from the force of feeling, over the upper dusk of the room. He (Assingham) had thought of the response his (Assingham) wife's words ideally implied.

``Decide to live--ah yes!--for her (Maggie) child.'' (unknown)

``Oh, bother her (Maggie) child!'' (he)
--and he (Assingham) had never felt so snubbed, for an exemplary view, as when Fanny now stopped short.
``To live, you poor dear, for her (Maggie) father--which is another pair of sleeves!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

And Mrs. Assingham's whole ample, ornamented person irradiated, with this, the truth that had begun, under so much handling, to glow.

``Any idiot can do things for her (Maggie) child. She (Maggie)'ll have a motive more original, and we shall see how it will work her (Maggie). She (Maggie)'ll have to save HIM.'' (unknown)

``To `save' him (idiot)--?'' (unknown)

``To keep her (Maggie) father from her (Maggie) own knowledge. THAT'' (she)
--and she (Assingham) seemed to see it, before her (Assingham), in her (Assingham) husband's very eyes--
``will be work cut out!'' (husband)
With which, as at the highest conceivable climax, she (Assingham) wound up their colloquy.
``Good night!'' (him)

There was something in her (Assingham) manner, however--or in the effect, at least, of this supreme demonstration that had fairly, and by a single touch, lifted him (husband) to her (Assingham) side; so that, after she (Assingham) had turned her (Assingham) back to regain the landing and the staircase, he (husband) overtook her (Assingham), before she (Assingham) had begun to mount, with the ring of excited perception.

``Ah, but, you know, that's rather jolly!'' (unknown)

``Jolly'--?'' (she)
she (Assingham) turned upon it, again, at the foot of the staircase.

``I mean it's rather charming.'' (unknown)

```Charming'--?'' It had still to be their law, a little, that she (Assingham) was tragic when he (husband) was comic.

``I mean it's rather beautiful. You just said, yourself, it would be. Only,'' (he)
he (husband) pursued promptly, with the impetus of this idea, and as if it had suddenly touched with light for him (husband) connections hitherto dim--
``only I don't quite see why that very care for him (father) which has carried her (Maggie) to such other lengths, precisely, as affect one as so `rum,' hasn't also, by the same stroke, made her (Maggie) notice a little more what has been going on.'' (him)

``Ah, there you are! It's the question that I've all along been asking myself.'' (She)
She (Assingham) had rested her (Assingham) eyes on the carpet, but she (Assingham) raised them as she (Assingham) pursued--she (Assingham) let him (husband) have it straight.
``And it's the question of an idiot.'' (unknown)

``An idiot--?'' (unknown)

``Well, the idiot that I'VE been, in all sorts of ways--so often, of late, have I asked it. You're excusable, since you ask it but now. The answer, I saw to-day, has all the while been staring me in the face.'' (unknown)

``Then what in the world is it?'' (unknown)

``Why, the very intensity of her (myself) conscience about him (idiot)--the very passion of her (myself) brave little piety. That's the way it has worked,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham explained
``and I admit it to have been as `rum' a way as possible. But it has been working from a rum start. From the moment the dear man married to ease his (man) daughter off, and it then happened, by an extraordinary perversity, that the very opposite effect was produced--!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
With the renewed vision of this fatality, however, she (Assingham) could give but a desperate shrug.

``I see,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel sympathetically mused.
``That WAS a rum start.'' (she)

But his (Colonel) very response, as she (Assingham) again flung up her (Assingham) arms, seemed to make her (Assingham) sense, for a moment, intolerable.

``Yes--there I am! I was really at the bottom of it,'' (she)
she (Assingham) declared;
``I don't know what possessed me--but I planned for him (man), I goaded him (man) on.'' (she)
With which, however, the next moment, she (Assingham) took herself up.
``Or, rather, I DO know what possessed me--for wasn't he (man) beset with ravening women, right and left, and didn't he (man), quite pathetically, appeal for protection, didn't he (man), quite charmingly, show one how he (man) needed and desired it? Maggie,'' (she)
she (Assingham) thus lucidly continued,
``couldn't, with a new life of her (Maggie) own, give herself up to doing for him (man) in the future all she (Maggie) had done in the past--to fencing him (man) in, to keeping him (man) safe and keeping THEM off. One perceived this,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on--
``out of the abundance of one's affection and one's sympathy.'' (she)
It all blessedly came back to her (Assingham)--when it wasn't all, for the fiftieth time, obscured, in face of the present facts, by anxiety and compunction.
``One was no doubt a meddlesome fool; one always IS, to think one sees people's lives for them better than they see them for themselves. But one's excuse here,'' (she)
she (Assingham) insisted,
``was that these people clearly DIDN'T see them for themselves--didn't see them at all. It struck one for very pity--that they were making a mess of such charming material; that they were but wasting it and letting it go. They didn't know HOW to live--and somehow one couldn't, if one took an interest in them at all, simply stand and see it. That's what I pay for'' (she)
--and the poor woman, in straighter communion with her (Assingham) companion's intelligence at this moment, she (Assingham) appeared to feel, than she (Assingham) had ever been before, let him (companion) have the whole of the burden of her (Assingham) consciousness.
``I always pay for it, sooner or later, my sociable, my damnable, my unnecessary interest. Nothing of course would suit me but that it should fix itself also on Charlotte--Charlotte who was hovering there on the edge of our lives, when not beautifully, and a trifle mysteriously, flitting across them, and who was a piece of waste and a piece of threatened failure, just as, for any possible good to the WORLD, Mr. Verver and Maggie were. It began to come over me, in the watches of the night, that Charlotte was a person who COULD keep off ravening women--without being one herself, either, in the vulgar way of the others; and that this service to Mr. Verver would be a sweet employment for her (Charlotte) future. There was something, of course, that might have stopped me: you know, you know what I mean--it looks at me,'' (she)
she (Assingham) veritably moaned,
``out of your face! But all I can say is that it didn't; the reason largely being--once I had fallen in love with the beautiful symmetry of my plan--that I seemed to feel sure Maggie would accept Charlotte, whereas I didn't quite make out either what other woman, or what other KIND of woman, one could think of her (woman) accepting.'' (she)

``I see--I see.'' (She)
She (Assingham) had paused, meeting all the while his (companion) listening look, and the fever of her (Assingham) retrospect had so risen with her (Assingham) talk that the desire was visibly strong in him (companion) to meet her (Assingham), on his (companion) side, but with cooling breath.
``One quite understands, my dear.'' (unknown)

It only, however, kept her (Assingham) there sombre.

``I naturally see, love, what you understand; which sits again, perfectly, in your eyes. You see that I saw that Maggie would accept her (Maggie) in helpless ignorance. Yes, dearest'' (unknown)
--and the grimness of her (Assingham) dreariness suddenly once more possessed her (Assingham):
``you've only to tell me that that knowledge was my reason for what I did. How, when you do, can I stand up to you? You see,'' (she)
she (Assingham) said with an ineffable headshake,
``that I don't stand up! I'm down, down, down,'' (she)
she (Assingham) declared;
``yet'' (she)
she (Assingham) as quickly added--
``there's just one little thing that helps to save my life.'' (she)
And she (Assingham) kept him (companion) waiting but an instant.
``They might easily--they would perhaps even certainly--have done something worse.'' (He)

He (companion) thought.

``Worse than that Charlotte--?'' (unknown)

``Ah, don't tell me,'' (she)
she (Assingham) cried,
``that there COULD have been nothing worse. There might, as they were, have been many things. Charlotte, in her (Charlotte) way, is extraordinary.'' (she)

He (companion) was almost simultaneous.

``Extraordinary!'' (unknown)

``She (Charlotte) observes the forms,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

He (companion) hesitated.

``With the Prince--?'' (unknown)

``FOR the Prince. And with the others,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on.
``With Mr. Verver--wonderfully. But above all with Maggie. And the forms'' (she)
--she (Assingham) had to do even THEM justice--
``are two-thirds of conduct. Say he (Verver) had married a woman who would have made a hash of them.'' (she)

But he (companion) jerked back.

``Ah, my dear, I wouldn't say it for the world!'' (unknown)

``Say,'' (she)
she (Assingham) none the less pursued,
``he (Verver) had married a woman the Prince would really have cared for.'' (she)

``You mean then he (Prince) doesn't care for Charlotte--?'' (the Colonel)
This was still a new view to jump to, and the Colonel, perceptibly, wished to make sure of the necessity of the effort. For that, while he (Colonel) stared, his (Colonel) wife allowed him (Colonel) time; at the end of which she (wife) simply said:
``No!'' (she)

``Then what on earth are they up to?'' (she)
Still, however, she (wife) only looked at him (Colonel); so that, standing there before her (wife) with his (Colonel) hands in his (Colonel) pockets, he (Colonel) had time, further, to risk, soothingly, another question.
``Are the `forms' you speak of--that are two-thirds of conduct--what will be keeping her (Charlotte) now, by your hypothesis, from coming home with him (Prince) till morning?'' (unknown)

``Yes--absolutely. THEIR forms.'' (unknown)

```Theirs'--?''

``Maggie's and Mr. Verver's--those they IMPOSE on Charlotte and the Prince. Those,'' (she)
she (wife) developed,
``that, so perversely, as I say, have succeeded in setting themselves up as the right ones.'' (she)

He (Colonel) considered--but only now, at last, really to relapse into woe.

``Your `perversity,' my dear, is exactly what I don't understand. The state of things existing hasn't grown, like a field of mushrooms, in a night. Whatever they, all round, may be in for now is at least the consequence of what they've DONE. Are they mere helpless victims of fate?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Well, Fanny at last had the courage of it,

``Yes--they are. To be so abjectly innocent--that IS to be victims of fate.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``And Charlotte and the Prince are abjectly innocent--?'' (she)

It took her (Fanny) another minute, but she (Fanny) rose to the full height.

``Yes. That is they WERE--as much so in their way as the others. There were beautiful intentions all round. The Prince's and Charlotte's were beautiful--of THAT I had my faith. They WERE--I'd go to the stake. Otherwise,'' (she)
she (Fanny) added,
``I should have been a wretch. And I've not been a wretch. I've only been a double-dyed donkey.'' (she)

``Ah then,'' (he)
he (Colonel) asked,
``what does our muddle make THEM to have been?'' (he)

``Well, too much taken up with considering each other. You may call such a mistake as that by what ever name you please; it at any rate means, all round, their case. It illustrates the misfortune,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham gravely,
``of being too, too charming.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

This was another matter that took some following, but the Colonel again did his (Colonel) best.

``Yes, but to whom?--doesn't it rather depend on that? To whom have the Prince and Charlotte then been too charming?'' (unknown)

``To each other, in the first place--obviously. And then both of them together to Maggie.'' (unknown)

``To Maggie?'' (he)
he (Colonel) wonderingly echoed.

``To Maggie.'' (She)
She (Assingham) was now crystalline.
``By having accepted, from the first, so guilelessly--yes, so guilelessly, themselves--her (Maggie) guileless idea of still having her (Maggie) father, of keeping him (father) fast, in her (Maggie) life.'' (unknown)

``Then isn't one supposed, in common humanity, and if one hasn't quarrelled with him (father), and one has the means, and he (father), on his (father) side, doesn't drink or kick up rows--isn't one supposed to keep one's aged parent in one's life?'' (unknown)

``Certainly--when there aren't particular reasons against it. That there may be others than his (father) getting drunk is exactly the moral of what is before us. In the first place Mr. Verver isn't aged.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel just hung fire--but it came.

``Then why the deuce does he (Verver)--oh, poor dear man!--behave as if he (Verver) were?'' (She)

She (Assingham) took a moment to meet it.

``How do you know how he (Verver) behaves?'' (unknown)

``Well, my own love, we see how Charlotte does!'' (she)
Again, at this, she (Assingham) faltered; but again she (Assingham) rose.
``Ah, isn't my whole point that he (Verver)'s charming to her (Charlotte)?'' (unknown)

``Doesn't it depend a bit on what she (Charlotte) regards as charming?'' (She)

She (Assingham) faced the question as if it were flippant, then with a headshake of dignity she (Assingham) brushed it away.

``It's Mr. Verver who's really young--it's Charlotte who's really old. And what I was saying,'' (she)
she (Assingham) added,
``isn't affected!'' (she)

``You were saying'' (he)
--he (Colonel) did her (Assingham) the justice--
``that they're all guileless.'' (he)

``That they were. Guileless, all, at first--quite extraordinarily. It's what I mean by their failure to see that the more they took for granted they could work together the more they were really working apart. For I repeat,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny went on,
``that I really believe Charlotte and the Prince honestly to have made up their minds, originally, that their very esteem for Mr. Verver--which was serious, as well it might be!--would save them.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``I see.'' (Colonel)
The Colonel inclined himself.
``And save HIM.'' (unknown)

``It comes to the same thing!'' (unknown)

``Then save Maggie.'' (unknown)

``That comes,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham,
``to something a little different. For Maggie has done the most.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

He (Colonel) wondered.

``What do you call the most?'' (unknown)

``Well, she (Maggie) did it originally--she (Maggie) began the vicious circle. For that--though you make round eyes at my associating her (Maggie) with `vice'--is simply what it has been. It's their mutual consideration, all round, that has made it the bottomless gulf; and they're really so embroiled but because, in their way, they've been so improbably GOOD.'' (unknown)

``In their way--yes!'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel grinned.

``Which was, above all, Maggie's way.'' (unknown)
No flicker of his (Colonel) ribaldry was anything to her (Assingham) now.
``Maggie had in the first place to make up to her (Maggie) father for her (Maggie) having suffered herself to become--poor little dear, as she (Maggie) believed--so intensely married. Then she (Maggie) had to make up to her (Maggie) husband for taking so much of the time they might otherwise have spent together to make this reparation to Mr. Verver perfect. And her (Maggie) way to do this, precisely, was by allowing the Prince the use, the enjoyment, whatever you may call it, of Charlotte to cheer his (Prince) path--by instalments, as it were--in proportion as she (Charlotte) herself, making sure her (Charlotte) father was all right, might be missed from his (father) side. By so much, at the same time, however,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham further explained,
``by so much as she (Charlotte) took her (Charlotte) young stepmother, for this purpose, away from Mr. Verver, by just so much did this too strike her (Charlotte) as something again to be made up for. It has saddled her (Charlotte), you will easily see, with a positively new obligation to her (Charlotte) father, an obligation created and aggravated by her (Charlotte) unfortunate, even if quite heroic, little sense of justice. She (Charlotte) began with wanting to show him (father) that his (father) marriage could never, under whatever temptation of her (Charlotte) own bliss with the Prince, become for her (Charlotte) a pretext for deserting or neglecting HIM. Then that, in its order, entailed her (Charlotte) wanting to show the Prince that she (Charlotte) recognised how the other desire--this wish to remain, intensely, the same passionate little daughter she (daughter) had always been--involved in some degree, and just for the present, so to speak, her (daughter) neglecting and deserting him (Prince). I quite hold,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Fanny with characteristic amplitude parenthesised,
``that a person can mostly feel but one passion--one TENDER passion, that is--at a time. Only, that doesn't hold good for our primary and instinctive attachments, the `voice of blood,' such as one's feeling for a parent or a brother. Those may be intense and yet not prevent other intensities--as you will recognise, my dear, when you remember how I continued, tout betement, to adore my mother, whom you didn't adore, for years after I had begun to adore you. Well, Maggie'' (Fanny)
--she (Assingham) kept it up--
``is in the same situation as I was, PLUS complications from which I was, thank heaven, exempt: PLUS the complication, above all, of not having in the least begun with the sense for complications that I should have had. Before she (Maggie) knew it, at any rate, her (Maggie) little scruples and her (Maggie) little lucidities, which were really so divinely blind--her (Maggie) feverish little sense of justice, as I say--had brought the two others together as her (Maggie) grossest misconduct couldn't have done. And now she (Maggie) knows something or other has happened--yet hasn't heretofore known what. She (Maggie) has only piled up her (Maggie) remedy, poor child--something that she (Maggie) has earnestly but confusedly seen as her (Maggie) necessary policy; piled it on top of the policy, on top of the remedy, that she (Maggie) at first thought out for herself, and that would really have needed, since then, so much modification. Her (Maggie) only modification has been the growth of her (Maggie) necessity to prevent her (Maggie) father's wondering if all, in their life in common, MAY be so certainly for the best. She (Maggie) has now as never before to keep him (father) unconscious that, peculiar, if he (father) makes a point of it, as their situation is, there's anything in it all uncomfortable or disagreeable, anything morally the least out of the way. She (Maggie) has to keep touching it up to make it, each day, each month, look natural and normal to him (father); so that--God forgive me the comparison!--she (Maggie)'s like an old woman who has taken to `painting' and who has to lay it on thicker, to carry it off with a greater audacity, with a greater impudence even, the older she (Maggie) grows.'' (she)
And Fanny stood a moment captivated with the image she (Fanny) had thrown off.
``I like the idea of Maggie audacious and impudent--learning to be so to gloss things over. She (Maggie) could--she (Maggie) even will, yet, I believe--learn it, for that sacred purpose, consummately, diabolically. For from the moment the dear man should see it's all rouge--!'' (She)
She (Fanny) paused, staring at the vision.

It imparted itself even to Bob.

``Then the fun would begin?'' (him)
As it but made her (Fanny) look at him (Bob) hard, however, he (Bob) amended the form of his (Bob) inquiry.
``You mean that in that case she (Maggie) WILL, charming creature, be lost?'' (She)

She (Fanny) was silent a moment more.

``As I've told you before, she (Maggie) won't be lost if her (Maggie) father's saved. She (Maggie)'ll see that as salvation enough.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel took it in.

``Then she (Maggie)'s a little heroine.'' (unknown)

``Rather--she (Maggie)'s a little heroine. But it's his (father) innocence, above all,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham added,
``that will pull them through.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Her (Assingham) companion, at this, focussed again Mr. Verver's innocence.

``It's awfully quaint.'' (unknown)

``Of course it's awfully quaint! That it's awfully quaint, that the pair are awfully quaint, quaint with all our dear old quaintness--by which I don't mean yours and mine, but that of my own sweet countrypeople, from whom I've so deplorably degenerated--that,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham declared,
``was originally the head and front of their appeal to me and of my interest in them. And of course I shall feel them quainter still,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) rather ruefully subjoined,
``before they've done with me!'' (she)

This might be, but it wasn't what most stood in the Colonel's way.

``You believe so in Mr. Verver's innocence after two years of Charlotte?'' (She)

She (Assingham) stared.

``But the whole point is just that two years of Charlotte are what he (Verver) hasn't really--or what you may call undividedly--had.'' (unknown)

``Any more than Maggie, by your theory, eh, has `really or undividedly,' had four of the Prince? It takes all she (Maggie) hasn't had,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel conceded,
``to account for the innocence that in her (Maggie), too, so leaves us in admiration.'' (the Colonel)

So far as it might be ribald again she (Assingham) let this pass.

``It takes a great many things to account for Maggie. What is definite, at all events, is that--strange though this be--her (Maggie) effort for her (Maggie) father has, up to now, sufficiently succeeded. She (Maggie) has made him (father), she (Maggie) makes him (father), accept the tolerably obvious oddity of their relation, all round, for part of the game. Behind her (Maggie) there, protected and amused and, as it were, exquisitely humbugged--the Principino, in whom he (father) delights, always aiding--he (father) has safely and serenely enough suffered the conditions of his (father) life to pass for those he (father) had sublimely projected. He (father) hadn't worked them out in detail--any more than I had, heaven pity me!--and the queerness has been, exactly, in the detail. This, for him (father), is what it was to have married Charlotte. And they both,'' (she)
she (Assingham) neatly wound up, ```help.'''

```Both'--?''

``I mean that if Maggie, always in the breach, makes it seem to him (father) all so flourishingly to fit, Charlotte does her (Charlotte) part not less. And her (Charlotte) part is very large. Charlotte,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny declared,
``works like a horse.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

So there it all was, and her (Fanny) husband looked at her (Fanny) a minute across it.

``And what does the Prince work like?'' (She)

She (Fanny) fixed him (husband) in return.

``Like a Prince!'' (she)
Whereupon, breaking short off, to ascend to her (Fanny) room, she (Fanny) presented her (Fanny) highly--decorated back--in which, in odd places, controlling the complications of its aspect, the ruby or the garnet, the turquoise and the topaz, gleamed like faint symbols of the wit that pinned together the satin patches of her (Fanny) argument.

He (husband) watched her (Fanny) as if she (Fanny) left him (husband) positively under the impression of her (Fanny) mastery of her (Fanny) subject; yes, as if the real upshot of the drama before them was but that he (husband) had, when it came to the tight places of life--as life had shrunk for him (husband) now--the most luminous of wives. He (husband) turned off, in this view of her (Fanny) majestic retreat, the comparatively faint little electric lamp which had presided over their talk; then he (husband) went up as immediately behind her (Fanny) as the billows of her (Fanny) amber train allowed, making out how all the clearness they had conquered was even for herself a relief--how at last the sense of the amplitude of her (Fanny) exposition sustained and floated her (Fanny). Joining her (Fanny), however, on the landing above, where she (Fanny) had already touched a metallic point into light, he (husband) found she (Fanny) had done perhaps even more to create than to extinguish in him (husband) the germ of a curiosity. He (husband) held her (Fanny) a minute longer--there was another plum in the pie.

``What did you mean some minutes ago by his (Prince) not caring for Charlotte?'' (unknown)

``The Prince's? By his (Prince) not `really' caring?'' (She)
She (Fanny) recalled, after a little, benevolently enough.
``I mean that men don't, when it has all been too easy. That's how, in nine cases out of ten, a woman is treated who has risked her (woman) life. You asked me just now how he (Prince) works,'' (she)
she (Fanny) added;
``but you might better perhaps have asked me how he (Prince) plays.'' (she)

Well, he (husband) made it up.

``Like a Prince?'' (unknown)

``Like a Prince. He (Prince) is, profoundly, a Prince. For that,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said with expression,
``he (Prince)'s--beautifully--a case. They're far rarer, even in the `highest circles,' than they pretend to be--and that's what makes so much of his (Prince) value. He (Prince)'s perhaps one of the very last--the last of the real ones. So it is we must take him (Prince). We must take him (Prince) all round.'' (she)

The Colonel considered.

``And how must Charlotte--if anything happens--take him (Prince)?'' (her)

The question held her (Fanny) a minute, and while she (Fanny) waited, with her (Fanny) eyes on him (Colonel), she (Fanny) put out a grasping hand to his (Colonel) arm, in the flesh of which he (Colonel) felt her (Fanny) answer distinctly enough registered. Thus she (Fanny) gave him (Colonel), standing off a little, the firmest, longest, deepest injunction he (Colonel) had ever received from her (Fanny).

``Nothing--in spite of everything--WILL happen. Nothing HAS happened. Nothing IS happening.'' (He)

He (Colonel) looked a trifle disappointed.

``I see. For US.'' (unknown)

``For us. For whom else?'' (he)
And he (Colonel) was to feel indeed how she (Fanny) wished him (Colonel) to understand it.
``We know nothing on earth--!'' (he)
It was an undertaking he (Colonel) must sign.

So he (Colonel) wrote, as it were, his (Colonel) name.

``We know nothing on earth.'' (the soldiers)
It was like the soldiers' watchword at night.

``We're as innocent,'' (she)
she (Fanny) went on in the same way,
``as babes.'' (she)

``Why not rather say,'' (he)
he (Colonel) asked,
``as innocent as they themselves are?'' (he)

``Oh, for the best of reasons! Because we're much more so.'' (He)

He (Colonel) wondered.

``But how can we be more--?'' (unknown)

``For them? Oh, easily! We can be anything.'' (unknown)

``Absolute idiots then?'' (unknown)

``Absolute idiots. And oh,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny breathed,
``the way it will rest us!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Well, he (Colonel) looked as if there were something in that.

``But won't they know we're not?'' (She)

She (Fanny) barely hesitated.

``Charlotte and the Prince think we are--which is so much gained. Mr. Verver believes in our intelligence--but he (Verver) doesn't matter.'' (unknown)

``And Maggie? Doesn't SHE know--?'' (unknown)

``That we see before our noses?'' (unknown)
Yes, this indeed took longer.
``Oh, so far as she (Maggie) may guess it she (Maggie)'ll give no sign. So it comes to the same thing.'' (He)

He (Colonel) raised his (Colonel) eyebrows.

``Comes to our not being able to help her (Maggie)?'' (unknown)

``That's the way we SHALL help her (Maggie).'' (unknown)

``By looking like fools?'' (She)

She (Fanny) threw up her (Fanny) hands.

``She (Maggie) only wants, herself, to look like a bigger! So there we are!'' (she)
With which she (Fanny) brushed it away--his (Colonel) conformity was promised. Something, however, still held her (Fanny); it broke, to her (Fanny) own vision, as a last wave of clearness.
``Moreover NOW,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said,
``I see! I mean,'' (she)
she (Fanny) added,--
``what you were asking me: how I knew to-day, in Eaton Square, that Maggie's awake.'' (she)
And she (Fanny) had indeed visibly got it.
``It was by seeing them together.'' (unknown)

``Seeing her (Maggie) with her (Maggie) father?'' (He)
He (Colonel) fell behind again.
``But you've seen her (Maggie) often enough before.'' (unknown)

``Never with my present eyes. For nothing like such a test--that of this length of the others' absence together--has hitherto occurred.'' (unknown)

``Possibly! But if she (Maggie) and Mr. Verver insisted upon it--?'' (unknown)

``Why is it such a test? Because it has become one without their intending it. It has spoiled, so to speak, on their hands.'' (unknown)

``It has soured, eh?'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel said.

``The word's horrible--say rather it has `changed.' Perhaps,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny went on,
``she (Maggie) did wish to see how much she (Maggie) can bear. In that case she (Maggie) HAS seen. Only it was she (Maggie) alone who--about the visit--insisted. Her (Maggie) father insists on nothing. And she (Maggie) watches him (father) do it.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Her (Fanny) husband looked impressed.

``Watches him (father)?'' (unknown)

``For the first faint sign. I mean of his (father) noticing. It doesn't, as I tell you, come. But she (Maggie)'s there for it to see. And I felt,'' (she)
she (Fanny) continued,
``HOW she (Maggie)'s there; I caught her (Maggie), as it were, in the fact. She (Maggie) couldn't keep it from me--though she (Maggie) left her (Maggie) post on purpose--came home with me to throw dust in my eyes. I took it all--her (Maggie) dust; but it was what showed me.'' (she)
With which supreme lucidity she (Fanny) reached the door of her (Fanny) room.
``Luckily it showed me also how she (Maggie) has succeeded. Nothing--from him (it)--HAS come.'' (unknown)

``You're so awfully sure?'' (unknown)

``Sure. Nothing WILL. Good-night,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said.
``She (Maggie)'ll die first.'' (unknown)

BOOK SECOND: THE PRINCESS

PART FOURTH

XXV

It was not till many days had passed that the Princess began to accept the idea of having done, a little, something she (Princess) was not always doing, or indeed that of having listened to any inward voice that spoke in a new tone. Yet these instinctive postponements of reflection were the fruit, positively, of recognitions and perceptions already active; of the sense, above all, that she (Princess) had made, at a particular hour, made by the mere touch of her (Princess) hand, a difference in the situation so long present to her (Princess) as practically unattackable. This situation had been occupying, for months and months, the very centre of the garden of her (Princess) life, but it had reared itself there like some strange, tall tower of ivory, or perhaps rather some wonderful, beautiful, but outlandish pagoda, a structure plated with hard, bright porcelain, coloured and figured and adorned, at the overhanging eaves, with silver bells that tinkled, ever so charmingly, when stirred by chance airs. She (Princess) had walked round and round it--that was what she (Princess) felt; she (Princess) had carried on her (Princess) existence in the space left her (Princess) for circulation, a space that sometimes seemed ample and sometimes narrow: looking up, all the while, at the fair structure that spread itself so amply and rose so high, but never quite making out, as yet, where she (Princess) might have entered had she (Princess) wished. She (Princess) had not wished till now--such was the odd case; and what was doubtless equally odd, besides, was that, though her (Princess) raised eyes seemed to distinguish places that must serve, from within, and especially far aloft, as apertures and outlooks, no door appeared to give access from her (Princess) convenient garden level. The great decorated surface had remained consistently impenetrable and inscrutable. At present, however, to her (Princess) considering mind, it was as if she (Princess) had ceased merely to circle and to scan the elevation, ceased so vaguely, so quite helplessly to stare and wonder: she (Princess) had caught herself distinctly in the act of pausing, then in that of lingering, and finally in that of stepping unprecedentedly near. The thing might have been, by the distance at which it kept her (Princess), a Mahometan mosque, with which no base heretic could take a liberty; there so hung about it the vision of one's putting off one's shoes to enter, and even, verily, of one's paying with one's life if found there as an interloper. She (Princess) had not, certainly, arrived at the conception of paying with her (Princess) life for anything she (Princess) might do; but it was nevertheless quite as if she (Princess) had sounded with a tap or two one of the rare porcelain plates. She (Princess) had knocked, in short--though she (Princess) could scarce have said whether for admission or for what; she (Princess) had applied her (Princess) hand to a cool smooth spot and had waited to see what would happen. Something had happened; it was as if a sound, at her (Princess) touch, after a little, had come back to her (Princess) from within; a sound sufficiently suggesting that her (Princess) approach had been noted.

If this image, however, may represent our young woman's consciousness of a recent change in her (woman) life--a change now but a few days old--it must at the same time be observed that she (woman) both sought and found in renewed circulation, as I have called it, a measure of relief from the idea of having perhaps to answer for what she (woman) had done. The pagoda in her (woman) blooming garden figured the arrangement--how otherwise was it to be named?--by which, so strikingly, she (woman) had been able to marry without breaking, as she (woman) liked to put it, with the past. She (woman) had surrendered herself to her (woman) husband without the shadow of a reserve or a condition, and yet she (woman) had not, all the while, given up her (woman) father--the least little inch. She (woman) had compassed the high city of seeing the two men beautifully take to each other, and nothing in her (woman) marriage had marked it as more happy than this fact of its having practically given the elder, the lonelier, a new friend. What had moreover all the while enriched the whole aspect of success was that the latter's marriage had been no more meassurably paid for than her (woman) own. His (friend) having taken the same great step in the same free way had not in the least involved the relegation of his (friend) daughter. That it was remarkable they should have been able at once so to separate and so to keep together had never for a moment, from however far back, been equivocal to her (daughter); that it was remarkable had in fact quite counted, at first and always, and for each of them equally, as part of their inspiration and their support. There were plenty of singular things they were NOT enamoured of--flights of brilliancy, of audacity, of originality, that, speaking at least for the dear man and herself, were not at all in their line; but they liked to think they had given their life this unusual extension and this liberal form, which many families, many couples, and still more many pairs of couples, would not have found workable. That last truth had been distinctly brought home to them by the bright testimony, the quite explicit envy, of most of their friends, who had remarked to them again and again that they must, on all the showing, to keep on such terms, be people of the highest amiability--equally including in the praise, of course, Amerigo and Charlotte. It had given them pleasure--as how should it not?--to find themselves shed such a glamour; it had certainly, that is, given pleasure to her (Charlotte) father and herself, both of them distinguishably of a nature so slow to presume that they would scarce have been sure of their triumph without this pretty reflection of it. So it was that their felicity had fructified; so it was that the ivory tower, visible and admirable doubtless, from any point of the social field, had risen stage by stage. Maggie's actual reluctance to ask herself with proportionate sharpness why she (Maggie) had ceased to take comfort in the sight of it represented accordingly a lapse from that ideal consistency on which her (Maggie) moral comfort almost at any time depended. To remain consistent she (Maggie) had always been capable of cutting down more or less her (Maggie) prior term.

Moving for the first time in her (Maggie) life as in the darkening shadow of a false position, she (Maggie) reflected that she (Maggie) should either not have ceased to be right--that is, to be confident--or have recognised that she (Maggie) was wrong; though she (Maggie) tried to deal with herself, for a space, only as a silken-coated spaniel who has scrambled out of a pond and who rattles the water from his (Maggie) ears. Her (Maggie) shake of her (Maggie) head, again and again, as she (Maggie) went, was much of that order, and she (Maggie) had the resource, to which, save for the rude equivalent of his (Maggie) generalising bark, the spaniel would have been a stranger, of humming to herself hard as a sign that nothing had happened to her (Maggie). She (Maggie) had not, so to speak, fallen in; she (Maggie) had had no accident and had not got wet; this at any rate was her (Maggie) pretension until after she (Maggie) began a little to wonder if she (Maggie) mightn't, with or without exposure, have taken cold. She (Maggie) could at all events remember no time at which she (Maggie) had felt so excited, and certainly none--which was another special point--that so brought with it as well the necessity for concealing excitement. This birth of a new eagerness became a high pastime, in her (Maggie) view, precisely by reason of the ingenuity required for keeping the thing born out of sight. The ingenuity was thus a private and absorbing exercise, in the light of which, might I so far multiply my metaphors, I should compare her (Maggie) to the frightened but clinging young mother of an unlawful child. The idea that had possession of her (mother) would be, by our new analogy, the proof of her (mother) misadventure, but likewise, all the while, only another sign of a relation that was more to her (mother) than anything on earth. She (mother) had lived long enough to make out for herself that any deep-seated passion has its pangs as well as its joys, and that we are made by its aches and its anxieties most richly conscious of it. She (mother) had never doubted of the force of the feeling that bound her (mother) to her (mother) husband; but to become aware, almost suddenly, that it had begun to vibrate with a violence that had some of the effect of a strain would, rightly looked at, after all but show that she (mother) was, like thousands of women, every day, acting up to the full privilege of passion. Why in the world shouldn't she (mother), with every right--if, on consideration, she (mother) saw no good reason against it? The best reason against it would have been the possibility of some consequence disagreeable or inconvenient to others-- especially to such others as had never incommoded her (mother) by the egotism of THEIR passions; but if once that danger were duly guarded against the fulness of one's measure amounted to no more than the equal use of one's faculties or the proper playing of one's part. It had come to the Princess, obscurely at first, but little by little more conceivably, that her (Princess) faculties had not for a good while been concomitantly used; the case resembled in a manner that of her (Princess) once-loved dancing, a matter of remembered steps that had grown vague from her (Princess) ceasing to go to balls. She (Princess) would go to balls again--that seemed, freely, even crudely, stated, the remedy; she (Princess) would take out of the deep receptacles in which she (Princess) had laid them away the various ornaments congruous with the greater occasions, and of which her (Princess) store, she (Princess) liked to think, was none of the smallest. She (Princess) would have been easily to be figured for us at this occupation; dipping, at off moments and quiet hours, in snatched visits and by draughty candle-light, into her (Princess) rich collections and seeing her (Princess) jewels again a little shyly, but all unmistakably, glow. That in fact may pass as the very picture of her (Princess) semi-smothered agitation, of the diversion she (Princess) to some extent successfully found in referring her (Princess) crisis, so far as was possible, to the mere working of her (Princess) own needs.

It must be added, however, that she (Princess) would have been at a loss to determine--and certainly at first--to which order, that of self-control or that of large expression, the step she (Princess) had taken the afternoon of her (Princess) husband's return from Matcham with his (husband) companion properly belonged. For it had been a step, distinctly, on Maggie's part, her (Maggie) deciding to do something, just then and there, which would strike Amerigo as unusual, and this even though her (Maggie) departure from custom had merely consisted in her (Maggie) so arranging that he (husband) wouldn't find her (Maggie), as he (husband) would definitely expect to do, in Eaton Square. He (Eaton) would have, strangely enough, as might seem to him (Eaton), to come back home for it, and there get the impression of her (Maggie) rather pointedly, or at least all impatiently and independently, awaiting him (Eaton). These were small variations and mild manoeuvres, but they went accompanied on Maggie's part, as we have mentioned, with an infinite sense of intention. Her (Maggie) watching by his (Eaton) fireside for her (Maggie) husband's return from an absence might superficially have presented itself as the most natural act in the world, and the only one, into the bargain, on which he (Eaton) would positively have reckoned. It fell by this circumstance into the order of plain matters, and yet the very aspect by which it was, in the event, handed over to her (Maggie) brooding fancy was the fact that she (Maggie) had done with it all she (Maggie) had designed. She (Maggie) had put her (Maggie) thought to the proof, and the proof had shown its edge; this was what was before her (Maggie), that she (Maggie) was no longer playing with blunt and idle tools, with weapons that didn't cut. There passed across her (Maggie) vision ten times a day the gleam of a bare blade, and at this it was that she (Maggie) most shut her (Maggie) eyes, most knew the impulse to cheat herself with motion and sound. She (Maggie) had merely driven, on a certain Wednesday, to Portland Place, instead of remaining in Eaton Square, and she (Maggie) privately repeated it again and again--there had appeared beforehand no reason why she (Maggie) should have seen the mantle of history flung, by a single sharp sweep, over so commonplace a deed. That, all the same, was what had happened; it had been bitten into her (Maggie) mind, all in an hour, that nothing she (Maggie) had ever done would hereafter, in some way yet to be determined, so count for her (Maggie)--perhaps not even what she (Maggie) had done in accepting, in their old golden Rome, Amerigo's proposal of marriage. And yet, by her (Maggie) little crouching posture there, that of a timid tigress, she (Maggie) had meant nothing recklessly ultimate, nothing clumsily fundamental; so that she (Maggie) called it names, the invidious, the grotesque attitude, holding it up to her (Maggie) own ridicule, reducing so far as she (Maggie) could the portee of what had followed it. She (Maggie) had but wanted to get nearer--nearer to something indeed that she (Maggie) couldn't, that she (Maggie) wouldn't, even to herself, describe; and the degree of this achieved nearness was what had been in advance incalculable. Her (Maggie) actual multiplication of distractions and suppressions, whatever it did for her (Maggie), failed to prevent her (Maggie) living over again any chosen minute--for she (Maggie) could choose them, she (Maggie) could fix them--of the freshness of relation produced by her (Maggie) having administered to her (Maggie) husband the first surprise to which she (Maggie) had ever treated him (husband). It had been a poor thing, but it had been all her (Maggie) own, and the whole passage was backwardly there, a great picture hung on the wall of her (Maggie) daily life, for her (Maggie) to make what she (Maggie) would of.

It fell, for retrospect, into a succession of moments that were WATCHABLE still; almost in the manner of the different things done during a scene on the stage, some scene so acted as to have left a great impression on the tenant of one of the stalls. Several of these moments stood out beyond the others, and those she (Maggie) could feel again most, count again like the firm pearls on a string, had belonged more particularly to the lapse of time before dinner--dinner which had been so late, quite at nine o’clock, that evening, thanks to the final lateness of Amerigo's own advent. These were parts of the experience--though in fact there had been a good many of them--between which her (Maggie) impression could continue sharply to discriminate. Before the subsequent passages, much later on, it was to be said, the flame of memory turned to an equalising glow, that of a lamp in some side-chapel in which incense was thick. The great moment, at any rate, for conscious repossession, was doubtless the first: the strange little timed silence which she (Maggie) had fully gauged, on the spot, as altogether beyond her (Maggie) own intention, but which--for just how long? should she (Maggie) ever really know for just how long?--she (Maggie) could do nothing to break. She (Maggie) was in the smaller drawing-room, in which she (Maggie) always

``sat,'' (she)
and she (Maggie) had, by calculation, dressed for dinner on finally coming in. It was a wonder how many things she (Maggie) had calculated in respect to this small incident--a matter for the importance of which she (Maggie) had so quite indefinite a measure. He (Maggie) would be late--he (Maggie) would be very late; that was the one certainty that seemed to look her (Maggie) in the face. There was still also the possibility that if he (Maggie) drove with Charlotte straight to Eaton Square he (Maggie) might think it best to remain there even on learning she (Charlotte) had come away. She (Charlotte) had left no message for him (Maggie) on any such chance; this was another of her (Charlotte) small shades of decision, though the effect of it might be to keep him (Maggie) still longer absent. He (Maggie) might suppose she (Charlotte) would already have dined; he (Maggie) might stay, with all he (Maggie) would have to tell, just on purpose to be nice to her (Charlotte) father. She (Charlotte) had known him (father) to stretch the point, to these beautiful ends, far beyond that; he (father) had more than once stretched it to the sacrifice of the opportunity of dressing.

If she (Charlotte) herself had now avoided any such sacrifice, and had made herself, during the time at her (Charlotte) disposal, quite inordinately fresh and quite positively smart, this had probably added, while she (Charlotte) waited and waited, to that very tension of spirit in which she (Charlotte) was afterwards to find the image of her (Charlotte) having crouched. She (Charlotte) did her (Charlotte) best, quite intensely, by herself, to banish any such appearance; she (Charlotte) couldn't help it if she (Charlotte) couldn't read her (Charlotte) pale novel--ah, that, par exemple, was beyond her (Charlotte)! but she (Charlotte) could at least sit by the lamp with the book, sit there with her (Charlotte) newest frock, worn for the first time, sticking out, all round her (Charlotte), quite stiff and grand; even perhaps a little too stiff and too grand for a familiar and domestic frock, yet marked none the less, this time, she (Charlotte) ventured to hope, by incontestable intrinsic merit. She (Charlotte) had glanced repeatedly at the clock, but she (Charlotte) had refused herself the weak indulgence of walking up and down, though the act of doing so, she (Charlotte) knew, would make her (Charlotte) feel, on the polished floor, with the rustle and the

``hang,'' (she)
still more beautifully bedecked. The difficulty was that it would also make her (Charlotte) feel herself still more sharply in a state; which was exactly what she (Charlotte) proposed not to do. The only drops of her (Charlotte) anxiety had been when her (Charlotte) thought strayed complacently, with her (Charlotte) eyes, to the front of her (Charlotte) gown, which was in a manner a refuge, a beguilement, especially when she (Charlotte) was able to fix it long enough to wonder if it would at last really satisfy Charlotte. She (Charlotte) had ever been, in respect to her (Charlotte) clothes, rather timorous and uncertain; for the last year, above all, she (Charlotte) had lived in the light of Charlotte's possible and rather inscrutable judgment of them. Charlotte's own were simply the most charming and interesting that any woman had ever put on; there was a kind of poetic justice in her (woman) being at last able, in this particular, thanks to means, thanks quite to omnipotence, freely to exercise her (woman) genius. But Maggie would have described herself as, in these connections, constantly and intimately
``torn'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
; conscious on one side of the impossibility of copying her (Maggie) companion and conscious on the other of the impossibility of sounding her (Maggie), independently, to the bottom. Yes, it was one of the things she (Maggie) should go down to her (Maggie) grave without having known--how Charlotte, after all had been said, really thought her (Charlotte) stepdaughter looked under any supposedly ingenious personal experiment. She (Charlotte) had always been lovely about the stepdaughter's material braveries--had done, for her (Charlotte), the very best with them; but there had ever fitfully danced at the back of Maggie's head the suspicion that these expressions were mercies, not judgments, embodying no absolute, but only a relative, frankness. Hadn't Charlotte, with so perfect a critical vision, if the truth were known, given her (Charlotte) up as hopeless--hopeless by a serious standard, and thereby invented for her (Charlotte) a different and inferior one, in which, as the only thing to be done, she (Charlotte) patiently and soothingly abetted her (Charlotte)? Hadn't she (Charlotte), in other words, assented in secret despair, perhaps even in secret irritation, to her (Charlotte) being ridiculous?--so that the best now possible was to wonder, once in a great while, whether one mightn't give her (Charlotte) the surprise of something a little less out of the true note than usual. Something of this kind was the question that Maggie, while the absentees still delayed, asked of the appearance she (Maggie) was endeavouring to present; but with the result, repeatedly again, that it only went and lost itself in the thick air that had begun more and more to hang, for our young woman, over her (woman) accumulations of the unanswered. They were THERE, these accumulations; they were like a roomful of confused objects, never as yet
``sorted,'' (she)
which for some time now she (woman) had been passing and re-passing, along the corridor of her (woman) life. She (woman) passed it when she (woman) could without opening the door; then, on occasion, she (woman) turned the key to throw in a fresh contribution. So it was that she (woman) had been getting things out of the way. They rejoined the rest of the confusion; it was as if they found their place, by some instinct of affinity, in the heap. They knew, in short, where to go; and when she (woman), at present, by a mental act, once more pushed the door open, she (woman) had practically a sense of method and experience. What she (woman) should never know about Charlotte's thought--she (Charlotte) tossed THAT in. It would find itself in company, and she (Charlotte) might at last have been standing there long enough to see it fall into its corner. The sight moreover would doubtless have made her (Charlotte) stare, had her (Charlotte) attention been more free--the sight of the mass of vain things, congruous, incongruous, that awaited every addition. It made her (Charlotte) in fact, with a vague gasp, turn away, and what had further determined this was the final sharp extinction of the inward scene by the outward. The quite different door had opened and her (Charlotte) husband was there.
