It had been as strange as she (Charlotte) could consent, afterwards, to think it; it had been, essentially, what had made the abrupt bend in her (Charlotte) life: he (husband) had come back, had followed her (Charlotte) from the other house, VISIBLY uncertain--this was written in the face he (husband) for the first minute showed her (Charlotte). It had been written only for those seconds, and it had appeared to go, quickly, after they began to talk; but while it lasted it had been written large, and, though she (Charlotte) didn't quite know what she (Charlotte) had expected of him (husband), she (Charlotte) felt she (Charlotte) hadn't expected the least shade of embarrassment. What had made the embarrassment--she (Charlotte) called it embarrassment so as to be able to assure herself she (Charlotte) put it at the very worst--what had made the particular look was his (husband) thus distinguishably wishing to see how he (husband) should find her (Charlotte). Why FIRST--that had, later on, kept coming to her (Charlotte); the question dangled there as if it were the key to everything. With the sense of it on the spot, she (Charlotte) had felt, overwhelmingly, that she (Charlotte) was significant, that so she (Charlotte) must instantly strike him (husband), and that this had a kind of violence beyond what she (Charlotte) had intended. It was in fact even at the moment not absent from her (Charlotte) view that he (husband) might easily have made an abject fool of her (Charlotte)--at least for the time. She (Charlotte) had indeed, for just ten seconds, been afraid of some such turn: the uncertainty in his (husband) face had become so, the next thing, an uncertainty in the very air. Three words of impatience the least bit loud, some outbreak of

``What in the world are you `up to', and what do you mean?'' (she)
any note of that sort would instantly have brought her (Charlotte) low--and this all the more that heaven knew she (Charlotte) hadn't in any manner designed to be high. It was such a trifle, her (Charlotte) small breach with custom, or at any rate with his (husband) natural presumption, that all magnitude of wonder had already had, before one could deprecate the shadow of it, the effect of a complication. It had made for him (husband) some difference that she (Charlotte) couldn't measure, this meeting him (husband) at home and alone instead of elsewhere and with others, and back and back it kept coming to her (Charlotte) that the blankness he (husband) showed her (Charlotte) before he (husband) was able to SEE might, should she (Charlotte) choose to insist on it, have a meaning--have, as who should say, an historic value--beyond the importance of momentary expressions in general. She (Charlotte) had naturally had on the spot no ready notion of what he (husband) might want to see; it was enough for a ready notion, not to speak of a beating heart, that he (husband) DID see, that he (husband) saw his (husband) wife in her (wife) own drawing-room at the hour when she (wife) would most properly be there. He (husband) hadn't in any way challenged her (wife), it was true, and, after those instants during which she (wife) now believed him (husband) to have been harbouring the impression of something unusually prepared and pointed in her (wife) attitude and array, he (husband) had advanced upon her (wife) smiling and smiling, and thus, without hesitation at the last, had taken her (wife) into his (husband) arms. The hesitation had been at the first, and she (wife) at present saw that he (husband) had surmounted it without her (wife) help. She (wife) had given him (husband) no help; for if, on the one hand, she (wife) couldn't speak for hesitation, so on the other--and especially as he (husband) didn't ask her (wife)--she (wife) couldn't explain why she (wife) was agitated. She (wife) had known it all the while down to her (wife) toes, known it in his (husband) presence with fresh intensity, and if he (husband) had uttered but a question it would have pressed in her (wife) the spring of recklessness. It had been strange that the most natural thing of all to say to him (husband) should have had that appearance; but she (wife) was more than ever conscious that any appearance she (wife) had would come round, more or less straight, to her (wife) father, whose life was now so quiet, on the basis accepted for it, that any alteration of his (father) consciousness even in the possible sense of enlivenment, would make their precious equilibrium waver. THAT was at the bottom of her (wife) mind, that their equilibrium was everything, and that it was practically precarious, a matter of a hair's breadth for the loss of the balance. It was the equilibrium, or at all events her (wife) conscious fear about it, that had brought her (wife) heart into her (wife) mouth; and the same fear was, on either side, in the silent look she (wife) and Amerigo had exchanged. The happy balance that demanded this amount of consideration was truly thus, as by its own confession, a delicate matter; but that her (wife) husband had also HIS (husband) habit of anxiety and his (husband) general caution only brought them, after all, more closely together. It would have been most beautifully, therefore, in the name of the equilibrium, and in that of her (wife) joy at their feeling so exactly the same about it, that she (wife) might have spoken if she (wife) had permitted the truth on the subject of her (wife) behaviour to ring out--on the subject of that poor little behaviour which was for the moment so very limited a case of eccentricity.

```Why, why' have I made this evening such a point of our not all dining together? Well, because I've all day been so wanting you alone that I finally couldn't bear it, and that there didn't seem any great reason why I should try to. THAT came to me--funny as it may at first sound, with all the things we've so wonderfully got into the way of bearing for each other. You've seemed these last days--I don't know what: more absent than ever before, too absent for us merely to go on so. It's all very well, and I perfectly see how beautiful it is, all round; but there comes a day when something snaps, when the full cup, filled to the very brim, begins to flow over. That's what has happened to my need of you--the cup, all day, has been too full to carry. So here I am with it, spilling it over you--and just for the reason that is the reason of my life. After all, I've scarcely to explain that I'm as much in love with you now as the first hour; except that there are some hours--which I know when they come, because they almost frighten me--that show me I'm even more so. They come of themselves--and, ah, they've been coming! After all, after all--!'' Some such words as those were what DIDN'T ring out, yet it was as if even the unuttered sound had been quenched here in its own quaver. It was where utterance would have broken down by its very weight if he (me) had let it get so far. Without that extremity, at the end of a moment, he (me) had taken in what he (me) needed to take--that his (me) wife was TESTIFYING, that she (wife) adored and missed and desired him (me). ``After all, after all,'' since she (wife) put it so, she (wife) was right. That was what he (me) had to respond to; that was what, from the moment that, as has been said, he (me)

``saw,'' (unknown)
he (me) had to treat as the most pertinent thing possible. He (me) held her (wife) close and long, in expression of their personal reunion--this, obviously, was one way of doing so. He (me) rubbed his (me) cheek, tenderly, and with a deep vague murmur, against her (wife) face, that side of her (wife) face she (wife) was not pressing to his (me) breast. That was, not less obviously, another way, and there were ways enough, in short, for his (me) extemporised ease, for the good humour she (wife) was afterwards to find herself thinking of as his (me) infinite tact. This last was partly, no doubt, because the question of tact might be felt as having come up at the end of a quarter of an hour during which he (me) had liberally talked and she (wife) had genially questioned. He (me) had told her (wife) of his (me) day, the happy thought of his (me) roundabout journey with Charlotte, all their cathedral-hunting adventure, and how it had turned out rather more of an affair than they expected. The moral of it was, at any rate, that he (me) was tired, verily, and must have a bath and dress--to which end she (Charlotte) would kindly excuse him (me) for the shortest time possible. She (Charlotte) was to remember afterwards something that had passed between them on this--how he (me) had looked, for her (Charlotte), during an instant, at the door, before going out, how he (me) had met her (Charlotte) asking him (me), in hesitation first, then quickly in decision, whether she (Charlotte) couldn't help him (me) by going up with him (me). He (me) had perhaps also for a moment hesitated, but he (me) had declined her (Charlotte) offer, and she (Charlotte) was to preserve, as I say, the memory of the smile with which he (me) had opined that at that rate they wouldn't dine till ten o’clock and that he (me) should go straighter and faster alone. Such things, as I say, were to come back to her (Charlotte)--they played, through her (Charlotte) full after-sense, like lights on the whole impression; the subsequent parts of the experience were not to have blurred their distinctness. One of these subsequent parts, the first, had been the not inconsiderable length, to her (Charlotte) later and more analytic consciousness, of this second wait for her (Charlotte) husband's reappearance. She (Charlotte) might certainly, with the best will in the world, had she (Charlotte) gone up with him (husband), have been more in his (husband) way than not, since people could really, almost always, hurry better without help than with it. Still, she (Charlotte) could actually hardly have made him (husband) take more time than he (husband) struck her (Charlotte) taking, though it must indeed be added that there was now in this much-thinking little person's state of mind no mere crudity of impatience. Something had happened, rapidly, with the beautiful sight of him (husband) and with the drop of her (Charlotte) fear of having annoyed him (husband) by making him (husband) go to and fro. Subsidence of the fearsome, for Maggie's spirit, was always, at first, positive emergence of the sweet, and it was long since anything had been so sweet to her (Maggie) as the particular quality suddenly given by her (Maggie) present emotion to the sense of possession.

XXVI

Amerigo was away from her (Maggie) again, as she (Maggie) sat there, as she (Maggie) walked there without him (husband)--for she (Maggie) had, with the difference of his (husband) presence in the house, ceased to keep herself from moving about; but the hour was filled nevertheless with the effect of his (husband) nearness, and above all with the effect, strange in an intimacy so established, of an almost renewed vision of the facts of his (husband) aspect. She (Maggie) had seen him (husband) last but five days since, yet he (husband) had stood there before her (Maggie) as if restored from some far country, some long voyage, some combination of dangers or fatigues. This unquenchable variety in his (husband) appeal to her (Maggie) interest, what did it mean but that--reduced to the flatness of mere statement--she (Maggie) was married, by good fortune, to an altogether dazzling person? That was an old, old story, but the truth of it shone out to her (Maggie) like the beauty of some family picture, some mellow portrait of an ancestor, that she (Maggie) might have been looking at, almost in surprise, after a long intermission. The dazzling person was upstairs and she (Maggie) was down, and there were moreover the other facts of the selection and decision that this demonstration of her (Maggie) own had required, and of the constant care that the equilibrium involved; but she (Maggie) had, all the same, never felt so absorbingly married, so abjectly conscious of a master of her (Maggie) fate. He (master) could do what he (master) would with her (Maggie); in fact what was actually happening was that he (master) was actually doing it.

``What he (it) would,'' (he)
what he (master) REALLY would--only that quantity itself escaped perhaps, in the brightness of the high harmony, familiar naming and discussing. It was enough of a recognition for her (Maggie) that, whatever the thing he (master) might desire, he (master) would always absolutely bring it off. She (Maggie) knew at this moment, without a question, with the fullest surrender, how he (master) had brought off, in her (Maggie), by scarce more than a single allusion, a perfect flutter of tenderness. If he (master) had come back tired, tired from his (master) long day, the exertion had been, literally, in her (Maggie) service and her (Maggie) father's. They two had sat at home at peace, the Principino between them, the complications of life kept down, the bores sifted out, the large ease of the home preserved, because of the way the others held the field and braved the weather. Amerigo never complained--any more than, for that matter, Charlotte did; but she (Charlotte) seemed to see to-night as she (Charlotte) had never yet quite done that their business of social representation, conceived as they conceived it, beyond any conception of her (Charlotte) own, and conscientiously carried out, was an affair of living always in harness. She (Charlotte) remembered Fanny Assingham's old judgment, that friend's description of her (Charlotte) father and herself as not living at all, as not knowing what to do or what might be done for them; and there came back to her (Charlotte) with it an echo of the long talk they had had together, one September day at Fawns, under the trees, when she (Charlotte) put before him (father) this dictum of Fanny's.

That occasion might have counted for them--she (Fanny) had already often made the reflection--as the first step in an existence more intelligently arranged. It had been an hour from which the chain of causes and consequences was definitely traceable--so many things, and at the head of the list her (Fanny) father's marriage, having appeared to her (Fanny) to flow from Charlotte's visit to Fawns, and that event itself having flowed from the memorable talk. But what perhaps most came out in the light of these concatenations was that it had been, for all the world, as if Charlotte had been

``had in,'' (Charlotte)
as the servants always said of extra help, because they had thus suffered it to be pointed out to them that if their family coach lumbered and stuck the fault was in its lacking its complement of wheels. Having but three, as they might say, it had wanted another, and what had Charlotte done from the first but begin to act, on the spot, and ever so smoothly and beautifully, as a fourth? Nothing had been, immediately, more manifest than the greater grace of the movement of the vehicle--as to which, for the completeness of her (Charlotte) image, Maggie was now supremely to feel how every strain had been lightened for herself. So far as SHE was one of the wheels she (Maggie) had but to keep in her (Maggie) place; since the work was done for her (Maggie) she (Maggie) felt no weight, and it wasn't too much to acknowledge that she (Maggie) had scarce to turn round. She (Maggie) had a long pause before the fire during which she (Maggie) might have been fixing with intensity her (Maggie) projected vision, have been conscious even of its taking an absurd, fantastic shape. She (Maggie) might have been watching the family coach pass and noting that, somehow, Amerigo and Charlotte were pulling it while she (Charlotte) and her (Charlotte) father were not so much as pushing. They were seated inside together, dandling the Principino and holding him (father) up to the windows, to see and be seen, like an infant positively royal; so that the exertion was ALL with the others. Maggie found in this image a repeated challenge; again and yet again she (Maggie) paused before the fire: after which, each time, in the manner of one for whom a strong light has suddenly broken, she (Maggie) gave herself to livelier movement. She (Maggie) had seen herself at last, in the picture she (Maggie) was studying, suddenly jump from the coach; whereupon, frankly, with the wonder of the sight, her (Maggie) eyes opened wider and her (Maggie) heart stood still for a moment. She (Maggie) looked at the person so acting as if this person were somebody else, waiting with intensity to see what would follow. The person had taken a decision--which was evidently because an impulse long gathering had at last felt a sharpest pressure. Only how was the decision to be applied?--what, in particular, would the figure in the picture do? She (Maggie) looked about her (Maggie), from the middle of the room, under the force of this question, as if THERE, exactly, were the field of action involved. Then, as the door opened again, she (Maggie) recognised, whatever the action, the form, at any rate, of a first opportunity. Her (Maggie) husband had reappeared--he (husband) stood before her (Maggie) refreshed, almost radiant, quite reassuring. Dressed, anointed, fragrant, ready, above all, for his (husband) dinner, he (husband) smiled at her (Maggie) over the end of their delay. It was as if her (Maggie) opportunity had depended on his (husband) look--and now she (Maggie) saw that it was good. There was still, for the instant, something in suspense, but it passed more quickly than on his (husband) previous entrance. He (husband) was already holding out his (husband) arms. It was, for hours and hours, later on, as if she (Maggie) had somehow been lifted aloft, were floated and carried on some warm high tide beneath which stumbling blocks had sunk out of sight. This came from her (Maggie) being again, for the time, in the enjoyment of confidence, from her (Maggie) knowing, as she (Maggie) believed, what to do. All the next day, and all the next, she (Maggie) appeared to herself to know it. She (Maggie) had a plan, and she (Maggie) rejoiced in her (Maggie) plan: this consisted of the light that, suddenly breaking into her (Maggie) restless reverie, had marked the climax of that vigil. It had come to her (Maggie) as a question--
``What if I've abandoned THEM, you know? What if I've accepted too passively the funny form of our life?'' (she)
There would be a process of her (Maggie) own by which she (Maggie) might do differently in respect to Amerigo and Charlotte--a process quite independent of any process of theirs. Such a solution had but to rise before her (Charlotte) to affect her (Charlotte), to charm her (Charlotte), with its simplicity, an advantageous simplicity she (Charlotte) had been stupid, for so long, not to have been struck by; and the simplicity meanwhile seemed proved by the success that had already begun to attend her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) had only had herself to do something to see how immediately it answered. This consciousness of its having answered with her (Charlotte) husband was the uplifting, sustaining wave. He (husband) had
``met'' (He)
her (Charlotte)--she (Charlotte) so put it to herself; met her (Charlotte) with an effect of generosity and of gaiety, in especial, on his (husband) coming back to her (Charlotte) ready for dinner, which she (Charlotte) wore in her (Charlotte) breast as the token of an escape for them both from something not quite definite, but clearly, much less good. Even at that moment, in fact, her (Charlotte) plan had begun to work; she (Charlotte) had been, when he (husband) brightly reappeared, in the act of plucking it out of the heart of her (Charlotte) earnestness--plucking it, in the garden of thought, as if it had been some full-blown flower that she (Charlotte) could present to him (husband) on the spot. Well, it was the flower of participation, and as that, then and there, she (Charlotte) held it out to him (husband), putting straightway into execution the idea, so needlessly, so absurdly obscured, of her (Charlotte) SHARING with him (husband), whatever the enjoyment, the interest, the experience might be--and sharing also, for that matter, with Charlotte.

She (Charlotte) had thrown herself, at dinner, into every feature of the recent adventure of the companions, letting him (husband) see, without reserve, that she (Charlotte) wished to hear everything about it, and making Charlotte in particular, Charlotte's judgment of Matcham, Charlotte's aspect, her (Charlotte) success there, her (Charlotte) effect traceably produced, her (Charlotte) clothes inimitably worn, her (Charlotte) cleverness gracefully displayed, her (Charlotte) social utility, in fine, brilliantly exemplified, the subject of endless inquiry. Maggie's inquiry was most empathetic, moreover, for the whole happy thought of the cathedral-hunt, which she (Maggie) was so glad they had entertained, and as to the pleasant results of which, down to the cold beef and bread-and-cheese, the queer old smell and the dirty table-cloth at the inn, Amerigo was good-humouredly responsive. He (Charlotte) had looked at her (Maggie) across the table, more than once, as if touched by the humility of this welcome offered to impressions at second-hand, the amusements, the large freedoms only of others--as if recognising in it something fairly exquisite; and at the end, while they were alone, before she (Maggie) had rung for a servant, he (servant) had renewed again his (servant) condonation of the little irregularity, such as it was, on which she (Maggie) had ventured. They had risen together to come upstairs; he (servant) had been talking at the last about some of the people, at the very last of all about Lady Castledean and Mr. Blint; after which she (Castledean) had once more broken ground on the matter of the

``type'' (she)
of Gloucester. It brought her (Castledean), as he (Blint) came round the table to join her (Castledean), yet another of his (Blint) kind conscious stares, one of the looks, visibly beguiled, but at the same time not invisibly puzzled, with which he (Blint) had already shown his (Blint) sense of this charming grace of her (Castledean) curiosity. It was as if he (Blint) might for a moment be going to say:--
``You needn't PRETEND, dearest, quite so hard, needn't think it necessary to care quite so much!'' (he)
--it was as if he (Blint) stood there before her (Castledean) with some such easy intelligence, some such intimate reassurance, on his (Blint) lips. Her (Castledean) answer would have been all ready--that she (Castledean) wasn't in the least pretending; and she (Castledean) looked up at him (Blint), while he (Blint) took her (Castledean) hand, with the maintenance, the real persistence, of her (Castledean) lucid little plan in her (Castledean) eyes. She (Castledean) wanted him (Blint) to understand from that very moment that she (Castledean) was going to be WITH him (Blint) again, quite with them, together, as she (Castledean) doubtless hadn't been since the
``funny'' (she)
changes--that was really all one could call them--into which they had each, as for the sake of the others, too easily and too obligingly slipped. They had taken too much for granted that their life together required, as people in London said, a special
``form'' (people)
--which was very well so long as the form was kept only for the outside world and was made no more of among themselves than the pretty mould of an iced pudding, or something of that sort, into which, to help yourself, you didn't hesitate to break with the spoon. So much as that she (They) would, with an opening, have allowed herself furthermore to observe; she (They) wanted him (herself) to understand how her (They) scheme embraced Charlotte too; so that if he (herself) had but uttered the acknowledgment she (They) judged him (herself) on the point of making--the acknowledgment of his (herself) catching at her (They) brave little idea for their case--she (They) would have found herself, as distinctly, voluble almost to eloquence.

What befell, however, was that even while she (They) thus waited she (They) felt herself present at a process taking place rather deeper within him (herself) than the occasion, on the whole, appeared to require--a process of weighing something in the balance, of considering, deciding, dismissing. He (herself) had guessed that she (They) was there with an idea, there in fact by reason of her (They) idea; only this, oddly enough, was what at the last stayed his (herself) words. She (They) was helped to these perceptions by his (herself) now looking at her (They) still harder than he (herself) had yet done--which really brought it to the turn of a hair, for her (They), that she (They) didn't make sure his (herself) notion of her (They) idea was the right one. It was the turn of a hair, because he (herself) had possession of her (They) hands and was bending toward her (They), ever so kindly, as if to see, to understand, more, or possibly give more--she (They) didn't know which; and that had the effect of simply putting her (They), as she (They) would have said, in his (herself) power. She (They) gave up, let her (They) idea go, let everything go; her (They) one consciousness was that he (herself) was taking her (They) again into his (herself) arms. It was not till afterwards that she (They) discriminated as to this; felt how the act operated with him (herself) instead of the words he (herself) hadn't uttered--operated, in his (herself) view, as probably better than any words, as always better, in fact, at any time, than anything. Her (They) acceptance of it, her (They) response to it, inevitable, foredoomed, came back to her (They), later on, as a virtual assent to the assumption he (herself) had thus made that there was really nothing such a demonstration didn't anticipate and didn't dispose of, and that the spring acting within herself moreover might well have been, beyond any other, the impulse legitimately to provoke it. It made, for any issue, the third time since his (herself) return that he (herself) had drawn her (They) to his (herself) breast; and at present, holding her (They) to his (herself) side as they left the room, he (herself) kept her (They) close for their moving into the hall and across it, kept her (They) for their slow return together to the apartments above. He (herself) had been right, overwhelmingly right, as to the felicity of his (herself) tenderness and the degree of her (They) sensibility, but even while she (They) felt these things sweep all others away she (They) tasted of a sort of terror of the weakness they produced in her (They). It was still, for her (They), that she (They) had positively something to do, and that she (They) mustn't be weak for this, must much rather be strong. For many hours after, none the less, she (They) remained weak--if weak it was; though holding fast indeed to the theory of her (They) success, since her (They) agitated overture had been, after all, so unmistakably met.

She (They) recovered soon enough on the whole, the sense that this left her (They) Charlotte always to deal with--Charlotte who, at any rate, however SHE might meet overtures, must meet them, at the worst, more or less differently. Of that inevitability, of such other ranges of response as were open to Charlotte, Maggie took the measure in approaching her (Charlotte), on the morrow of her (Charlotte) return from Matcham, with the same show of desire to hear all her (Charlotte) story. She (Charlotte) wanted the whole picture from her (Charlotte), as she (Charlotte) had wanted it from her (Charlotte) companion, and, promptly, in Eaton Square, whither, without the Prince, she (Charlotte) repaired, almost ostentatiously, for the purpose, this purpose only, she (Charlotte) brought her (Charlotte) repeatedly back to the subject, both in her (Charlotte) husband's presence and during several scraps of independent colloquy. Before her (Charlotte) father, instinctively, Maggie took the ground that his (father) wish for interesting echoes would be not less than her (Charlotte) own--allowing, that is, for everything his (father) wife would already have had to tell him (father), for such passages, between them, as might have occurred since the evening before. Joining them after luncheon, reaching them, in her (wife) desire to proceed with the application of her (wife) idea, before they had quitted the breakfast-room, the scene of their mid-day meal, she (wife) referred, in her (wife) parent's presence, to what she (wife) might have lost by delay, and expressed the hope that there would be an anecdote or two left for her (wife) to pick up. Charlotte was dressed to go out, and her (Charlotte) husband, it appeared, rather positively prepared not to; he (husband) had left the table, but was seated near the fire with two or three of the morning papers and the residuum of the second and third posts on a stand beside him (husband)--more even than the usual extravagance, as Maggie's glance made out, of circulars, catalogues, advertisements, announcements of sales, foreign envelopes and foreign handwritings that were as unmistakable as foreign clothes. Charlotte, at the window, looking into the side-street that abutted on the Square, might have been watching for their visitor's advent before withdrawing; and in the light, strange and coloured, like that of a painted picture, which fixed the impression for her (Charlotte), objects took on values not hitherto so fully shown. It was the effect of her (Charlotte) quickened sensibility; she (Charlotte) knew herself again in presence of a problem, in need of a solution for which she (Charlotte) must intensely work: that consciousness, lately born in her (Charlotte), had been taught the evening before to accept a temporary lapse, but had quickly enough again, with her (Charlotte) getting out of her (Charlotte) own house and her (Charlotte) walking across half the town--for she (Charlotte) had come from Portland Place on foot--found breath still in its lungs.

It exhaled this breath in a sigh, faint and unheard; her (Charlotte) tribute, while she (Charlotte) stood there before speaking, to realities looming through the golden mist that had already begun to be scattered. The conditions facing her (Charlotte) had yielded, for the time, to the golden mist--had considerably melted away; but there they were again, definite, and it was for the next quarter of an hour as if she (Charlotte) could have counted them one by one on her (Charlotte) fingers. Sharp to her (Charlotte) above all was the renewed attestation of her (Charlotte) father's comprehensive acceptances, which she (Charlotte) had so long regarded as of the same quality with her (Charlotte) own, but which, so distinctly now, she (Charlotte) should have the complication of being obliged to deal with separately. They had not yet struck her (Charlotte) as absolutely extraordinary--which had made for her (Charlotte) lumping them with her (Charlotte) own, since her (Charlotte) view of her (Charlotte) own had but so lately begun to change; though it instantly stood out for her (Charlotte) that there was really no new judgment of them she (Charlotte) should be able to show without attracting in some degree his (father) attention, without perhaps exciting his (father) surprise and making thereby, for the situation she (Charlotte) shared with him (father), some difference. She (Charlotte) was reminded and warned by the concrete image; and for a minute Charlotte's face, immediately presented to her (Charlotte), affected her (Charlotte) as searching her (Charlotte) own to see the reminder tell. She (Charlotte) had not less promptly kissed her (Charlotte) stepmother, and then had bent over her (Charlotte) father, from behind, and laid her (Charlotte) cheek upon him (father); little amenities tantamount heretofore to an easy change of guard--Charlotte's own frequent, though always cheerful, term of comparison for this process of transfer. Maggie figured thus as the relieving sentry, and so smoothly did use and custom work for them that her (Maggie) mate might even, on this occasion, after acceptance of the pass-word, have departed without irrelevant and, in strictness, unsoldierly gossip. This was not, none the less, what happened; inasmuch as if our young woman had been floated over her (woman) first impulse to break the existing charm at a stroke, it yet took her (woman) but an instant to sound, at any risk, the note she (woman) had been privately practising. If she (woman) had practised it the day before, at dinner, on Amerigo, she (woman) knew but the better how to begin for it with Mrs. Verver, and it immensely helped her (Verver), for that matter, to be able at once to speak of the Prince as having done more to quicken than to soothe her (Verver) curiosity. Frankly and gaily she (Verver) had come to ask--to ask what, in their unusually prolonged campaign, the two had achieved. She (Verver) had got out of her (Verver) husband, she (Verver) admitted, what she (Verver) could, but husbands were never the persons who answered such questions ideally. He (husband) had only made her (Verver) more curious, and she (Verver) had arrived early, this way, in order to miss as little as possible of Charlotte's story.

``Wives, papa,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said;
``are always much better reporters--though I grant,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) added for Charlotte,
``that fathers are not much better than husbands. He (papa) never,'' (Charlotte)
she (Charlotte) smiled,
``tells me more than a tenth of what you tell him (papa); so I hope you haven't told him (papa) everything yet, since in that case I shall probably have lost the best part of it.'' (she)
Maggie went, she (Maggie) went--she (Maggie) felt herself going; she (Maggie) reminded herself of an actress who had been studying a part and rehearsing it, but who suddenly, on the stage, before the footlights, had begun to improvise, to speak lines not in the text. It was this very sense of the stage and the footlights that kept her (Maggie) up, made her (Maggie) rise higher: just as it was the sense of action that logically involved some platform--action quite positively for the first time in her (Maggie) life, or, counting in the previous afternoon, for the second. The platform remained for three or four days thus sensibly under her (Maggie) feet, and she (Maggie) had all the while, with it, the inspiration of quite remarkably, of quite heroically improvising. Preparation and practice had come but a short way; her (Maggie) part opened out, and she (Maggie) invented from moment to moment what to say and to do. She (Maggie) had but one rule of art--to keep within bounds and not lose her (Maggie) head; certainly she (Maggie) might see for a week how far that would take her (Maggie). She (Maggie) said to herself, in her (Maggie) excitement, that it was perfectly simple: to bring about a difference, touch by touch, without letting either of the three, and least of all her (Maggie) father, so much as suspect her (Maggie) hand. If they should suspect they would want a reason, and the humiliating truth was that she (Maggie) wasn't ready with a reason--not, that is, with what she (Maggie) would have called a reasonable one. She (Maggie) thought of herself, instinctively, beautifully, as having dealt, all her (Maggie) life, at her (Maggie) father's side and by his (father) example, only in reasonable reasons; and what she (Maggie) would really have been most ashamed of would be to produce for HIM, in this line, some inferior substitute. Unless she (Maggie) were in a position to plead, definitely, that she (Maggie) was jealous she (Maggie) should be in no position to plead, decently, that she (Maggie) was dissatisfied. This latter condition would be a necessary implication of the former; without the former behind it it would HAVE to fall to the ground. So had the case, wonderfully, been arranged for her (Maggie); there was a card she (Maggie) could play, but there was only one, and to play it would be to end the game. She (Maggie) felt herself--as at the small square green table, between the tall old silver candlesticks and the neatly arranged counters--her (Maggie) father's playmate and partner; and what it constantly came back to, in her (Maggie) mind, was that for her (Maggie) to ask a question, to raise a doubt, to reflect in any degree on the play of the others, would be to break the charm. The charm she (Maggie) had to call it, since it kept her (Maggie) companion so constantly engaged, so perpetually seated and so contentedly occupied. To say anything at all would be, in fine, to have to say WHY she (Maggie) was jealous; and she (Maggie) could, in her (Maggie) private hours, but stare long, with suffused eyes, at that impossibility.

By the end of a week, the week that had begun, especially, with her (Maggie) morning hour, in Eaton Square, between her (Maggie) father and his (father) wife, her (Maggie) consciousness of being beautifully treated had become again verily greater than her (Maggie) consciousness of anything else; and I must add, moreover, that she (Maggie) at last found herself rather oddly wondering what else, as a consciousness, could have been quite so overwhelming. Charlotte's response to the experiment of being more with her (Charlotte) OUGHT, as she (Charlotte) very well knew, to have stamped the experiment with the feeling of success; so that if the success itself seemed a boon less substantial than the original image of it, it enjoyed thereby a certain analogy with our young woman's aftertaste of Amerigo's own determined demonstrations. Maggie was to have retained, for that matter, more than one aftertaste, and if I have spoken of the impressions fixed in her (Maggie) as soon as she (Maggie) had, so insidiously, taken the field, a definite note must be made of her (Maggie) perception, during those moments, of Charlotte's prompt uncertainty. She (Charlotte) had shown, no doubt--she (Charlotte) couldn't not have shown--that she (Charlotte) had arrived with an idea; quite exactly as she (Charlotte) had shown her (Charlotte) husband, the night before, that she (Charlotte) was awaiting him (husband) with a sentiment. This analogy in the two situations was to keep up for her (Charlotte) the remembrance of a kinship of expression in the two faces in respect to which all she (Charlotte) as yet professed to herself was that she (Charlotte) had affected them, or at any rate the sensibility each of them so admirably covered, in the same way. To make the comparison at all was, for Maggie, to return to it often, to brood upon it, to extract from it the last dregs of its interest--to play with it, in short, nervously, vaguely, incessantly, as she (Maggie) might have played with a medallion containing on either side a cherished little portrait and suspended round her (Maggie) neck by a gold chain of a firm fineness that no effort would ever snap. The miniatures were back to back, but she (Maggie) saw them forever face to face, and when she (Maggie) looked from one to the other she (Maggie) found in Charlotte's eyes the gleam of the momentary

``What does she (I) really want?'' (Charlotte)
that had come and gone for her (Maggie) in the Prince's. So again, she (Maggie) saw the other light, the light touched into a glow both in Portland Place and in Eaton Square, as soon as she (Maggie) had betrayed that she (Maggie) wanted no harm--wanted no greater harm of Charlotte, that is, than to take in that she (Charlotte) meant to go out with her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) had been present at that process as personally as she (Charlotte) might have been present at some other domestic incident--the hanging of a new picture, say, or the fitting of the Principino with his (Eaton) first little trousers.

She (Charlotte) remained present, accordingly, all the week, so charmingly and systematically did Mrs. Verver now welcome her (Verver) company. Charlotte had but wanted the hint, and what was it but the hint, after all, that, during the so subdued but so ineffaceable passage in the breakfast-room, she (Charlotte) had seen her (Charlotte) take? It had been taken moreover not with resignation, not with qualifications or reserves, however bland; it had been taken with avidity, with gratitude, with a grace of gentleness that supplanted explanations. The very liberality of this accommodation might indeed have appeared in the event to give its own account of the matter--as if it had fairly written the Princess down as a person of variations and had accordingly conformed but to a rule of tact in accepting these caprices for law. The caprice actually prevailing happened to be that the advent of one of the ladies anywhere should, till the fit had changed, become the sign, unfailingly, of the advent of the other; and it was emblazoned, in rich colour, on the bright face of this period, that Mrs. Verver only wished to know, on any occasion, what was expected of her (Verver), only held herself there for instructions, in order even to better them if possible. The two young women, while the passage lasted, became again very much the companions of other days, the days of Charlotte's prolonged visits to the admiring and bountiful Maggie, the days when equality of condition for them had been all the result of the latter's native vagueness about her (Maggie) own advantages. The earlier elements flushed into life again, the frequency, the intimacy, the high pitch of accompanying expression--appreciation, endearment, confidence; the rarer charm produced in each by this active contribution to the felicity of the other: all enhanced, furthermore--enhanced or qualified, who should say which?--by a new note of diplomacy, almost of anxiety, just sensible on Charlotte's part in particular; of intensity of observance, in the matter of appeal and response, in the matter of making sure the Princess might be disposed or gratified, that resembled an attempt to play again, with more refinement, at disparity of relation. Charlotte's attitude had, in short, its moments of flowering into pretty excesses of civility, self-effacements in the presence of others, sudden little formalisms of suggestion and recognition, that might have represented her (Charlotte) sense of the duty of not

``losing sight'' (others)
of a social distinction. This impression came out most for Maggie when, in their easier intervals, they had only themselves to regard, and when her (Maggie) companion's inveteracy of never passing first, of not sitting till she (Maggie) was seated, of not interrupting till she (Maggie) appeared to give leave, of not forgetting, too, familiarly, that in addition to being important she (Maggie) was also sensitive, had the effect of throwing over their intercourse a kind of silver tissue of decorum. It hung there above them like a canopy of state, a reminder that though the lady-in-waiting was an established favourite, safe in her (Maggie) position, a little queen, however, good-natured, was always a little queen and might, with small warning, remember it.

And yet another of these concomitants of feverish success, all the while, was the perception that in another quarter too things were being made easy. Charlotte's alacrity in meeting her (Charlotte) had, in one sense, operated slightly overmuch as an intervention: it had begun to reabsorb her (Charlotte) at the very hour of her (Charlotte) husband's showing her (Charlotte) that, to be all there, as the phrase was, he (husband) likewise only required--as one of the other phrases was too--the straight tip. She (Charlotte) had heard him (husband) talk about the straight tip, in his (husband) moods of amusement at English slang, in his (husband) remarkable displays of assimilative power, power worthy of better causes and higher inspirations; and he (husband) had taken it from her (Charlotte), at need, in a way that, certainly in the first glow of relief, had made her (Charlotte) brief interval seem large. Then, however, immediately, and even though superficially, there had declared itself a readjustment of relations to which she (Charlotte) was, once more, practically a little sacrificed.

``I must do everything,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) had said,
``without letting papa see what I do--at least till it's done!'' (she)
but she (Charlotte) scarce knew how she (Charlotte) proposed, even for the next few days, to blind or beguile this participant in her (Charlotte) life. What had in fact promptly enough happened, she (Charlotte) presently recognised, was that if her (Charlotte) stepmother had beautifully taken possession of her (Charlotte), and if she (Charlotte) had virtually been rather snatched again thereby from her (Charlotte) husband's side, so, on the other hand, this had, with as little delay, entailed some very charming assistance for her (Charlotte) in Eaton Square. When she (Charlotte) went home with Charlotte, from whatever happy demonstration, for the benefit of the world in which they supposed themselves to live, that there was no smallest reason why their closer association shouldn't be public and acclaimed--at these times she (Charlotte) regularly found that Amerigo had come either to sit with his (Eaton) father-in-law in the absence of the ladies, or to make, on his (Eaton) side, precisely some such display of the easy working of the family life as would represent the equivalent of her (Charlotte) excursions with Charlotte. Under this particular impression it was that everything in Maggie most melted and went to pieces--every thing, that is, that belonged to her (Maggie) disposition to challenge the perfection of their common state. It divided them again, that was true, this particular turn of the tide--cut them up afresh into pairs and parties; quite as if a sense for the equilibrium was what, between them all, had most power of insistence; quite as if Amerigo himself were all the while, at bottom, equally thinking of it and watching it. But, as against that, he (himself) was making her (Maggie) father not miss her (Maggie), and he (himself) could have rendered neither of them a more excellent service. He (himself) was acting in short on a cue, the cue given him (himself) by observation; it had been enough for him (himself) to see the shade of change in her (Maggie) behaviour; his (himself) instinct for relations, the most exquisite conceivable, prompted him (himself) immediately to meet and match the difference, to play somehow into its hands. That was what it was, she (Maggie) renewedly felt, to have married a man who was, sublimely, a gentleman; so that, in spite of her (Maggie) not wanting to translate ALL their delicacies into the grossness of discussion, she (Maggie) yet found again and again, in Portland Place, moments for saying:
``If I didn't love you, you know, for yourself, I should still love you for HIM.'' (she)
He (gentleman) looked at her (Maggie), after such speeches, as Charlotte looked, in Eaton Square, when she (Charlotte) called HER attention to his (Eaton) benevolence: through the dimness of the almost musing smile that took account of her (Charlotte) extravagance, harmless though it might be, as a tendency to reckon with.
``But my poor child,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte might under this pressure have been on the point of replying,
``that's the way nice people ARE, all round--so that why should one be surprised about it? We're all nice together--as why shouldn't we be? If we hadn't been we wouldn't have gone far--and I consider that we've gone very far indeed. Why should you `take on' as if you weren't a perfect dear yourself, capable of all the sweetest things?--as if you hadn't in fact grown up in an atmosphere, the atmosphere of all the good things that I recognised, even of old, as soon as I came near you, and that you've allowed me now, between you, to make so blessedly my own.'' (Charlotte)
Mrs. Verver might in fact have but just failed to make another point, a point charmingly natural to her (Verver) as a grateful and irreproachable wife.
``It isn't a bit wonderful, I may also remind you, that your husband should find, when opportunity permits, worse things to do than to go about with mine. I happen, love, to appreciate my husband--I happen perfectly to understand that his (husband) acquaintance should be cultivated and his (husband) company enjoyed.'' (Charlotte)

Some such happily-provoked remarks as these, from Charlotte, at the other house, had been in the air, but we have seen how there was also in the air, for our young woman, as an emanation from the same source, a distilled difference of which the very principle was to keep down objections and retorts. That impression came back--it had its hours of doing so; and it may interest us on the ground of its having prompted in Maggie a final reflection, a reflection out of the heart of which a light flashed for her (Maggie) like a great flower grown in a night. As soon as this light had spread a little it produced in some quarters a surprising distinctness, made her (Maggie) of a sudden ask herself why there should have been even for three days the least obscurity. The perfection of her (Maggie) success, decidedly, was like some strange shore to which she (Maggie) had been noiselessly ferried and where, with a start, she (Maggie) found herself quaking at the thought that the boat might have put off again and left her (Maggie). The word for it, the word that flashed the light, was that they were TREATING her (Maggie), that they were proceeding with her (Maggie)--and, for that matter, with her (Maggie) father--by a plan that was the exact counterpart of her (Maggie) own. It was not from her (Maggie) that they took their cue, but--and this was what in particular made her (Maggie) sit up--from each other; and with a depth of unanimity, an exact coincidence of inspiration that, when once her (Maggie) attention had begun to fix it, struck her (Maggie) as staring out at her (Maggie) in recovered identities of behaviour, expression and tone. They had a view of her (Maggie) situation, and of the possible forms her (Maggie) own consciousness of it might take--a view determined by the change of attitude they had had, ever so subtly, to recognise in her (Maggie) on their return from Matcham. They had had to read into this small and all-but-suppressed variation a mute comment--on they didn't quite know what; and it now arched over the Princess's head like a vault of bold span that important communication between them on the subject couldn't have failed of being immediate. This new perception bristled for her (Princess), as we have said, with odd intimations, but questions unanswered played in and out of it as well--the question, for instance, of why such promptitude of harmony SHOULD have been important. Ah, when she (Princess) began to recover, piece by piece, the process became lively; she (Princess) might have been picking small shining diamonds out of the sweepings of her (Princess) ordered house. She (Princess) bent, in this pursuit, over her (Princess) dust-bin; she (Princess) challenged to the last grain the refuse of her (Princess) innocent economy. Then it was that the dismissed vision of Amerigo, that evening, in arrest at the door of her (Princess) salottino while her (Princess) eyes, from her (Princess) placed chair, took him (Princess) in--then it was that this immense little memory gave out its full power. Since the question was of doors, she (Princess) had afterwards, she (Princess) now saw, shut it out; she (Princess) had responsibly shut in, as we have understood, shut in there with her (Princess) sentient self, only the fact of his (Princess) reappearance and the plenitude of his (Princess) presence. These things had been testimony, after all, to supersede any other, for on the spot, even while she (Princess) looked, the warmly-washing wave had travelled far up the strand. She (Princess) had subsequently lived, for hours she (Princess) couldn't count, under the dizzying, smothering welter positively in submarine depths where everything came to her (Princess) through walls of emerald and mother-of-pearl; though indeed she (Princess) had got her (Princess) head above them, for breath, when face to face with Charlotte again, on the morrow, in Eaton Square. Meanwhile, none the less, as was so apparent, the prior, the prime impression had remained, in the manner of a spying servant, on the other side of the barred threshold; a witness availing himself, in time, of the lightest pretext to re-enter. It was as if he (witness) had found this pretext in her (Charlotte) observed necessity of comparing--comparing the obvious common elements in her (Charlotte) husband's and her (Charlotte) stepmother's ways of now

``taking'' (stepmother)
her (Charlotte). With or without her (Charlotte) witness, at any rate, she (Charlotte) was led by comparison to a sense of the quantity of earnest intention operating, and operating so harmoniously, between her (Charlotte) companions; and it was in the mitigated midnight of these approximations that she (Charlotte) had made out the promise of her (Charlotte) dawn.

It was a worked-out scheme for their not wounding her (Charlotte), for their behaving to her (Charlotte) quite nobly; to which each had, in some winning way, induced the other to contribute, and which therefore, so far as that went, proved that she (Charlotte) had become with them a subject of intimate study. Quickly, quickly, on a certain alarm taken, eagerly and anxiously, before they SHOULD, without knowing it, wound her (Charlotte), they had signalled from house to house their clever idea, the idea by which, for all these days, her (Charlotte) own idea had been profiting. They had built her (Charlotte) in with their purpose--which was why, above her (Charlotte), a vault seemed more heavily to arch; so that she (Charlotte) sat there, in the solid chamber of her (Charlotte) helplessness, as in a bath of benevolence artfully prepared for her (Charlotte), over the brim of which she (Charlotte) could but just manage to see by stretching her (Charlotte) neck. Baths of benevolence were very well, but, at least, unless one were a patient of some sort, a nervous eccentric or a lost child, one was usually not so immersed save by one's request. It wasn't in the least what she (Charlotte) had requested. She (Charlotte) had flapped her (Charlotte) little wings as a symbol of desired flight, not merely as a plea for a more gilded cage and an extra allowance of lumps of sugar. Above all she (Charlotte) hadn't complained, not by the quaver of a syllable--so what wound in particular had she (Charlotte) shown her (Charlotte) fear of receiving? What wound HAD she (Charlotte) received--as to which she (Charlotte) had exchanged the least word with them? If she (Charlotte) had ever whined or moped they might have had some reason; but she (Charlotte) would be hanged--she (Charlotte) conversed with herself in strong language--if she (Charlotte) had been, from beginning to end, anything but pliable and mild. It all came back, in consequence, to some required process of their own, a process operating, quite positively, as a precaution and a policy. They had got her (Charlotte) into the bath and, for consistency with themselves--which was with each other--must keep her (Charlotte) there. In that condition she (Charlotte) wouldn't interfere with the policy, which was established, which was arranged. Her (Charlotte) thought, over this, arrived at a great intensity--had indeed its pauses and timidities, but always to take afterwards a further and lighter spring. The ground was well-nigh covered by the time she (Charlotte) had made out her (Charlotte) husband and his (husband) colleague as directly interested in preventing her (Charlotte) freedom of movement. Policy or no policy, it was they themselves who were arranged. She (Charlotte) must be kept in position so as not to DISarrange them. It fitted immensely together, the whole thing, as soon as she (Charlotte) could give them a motive; for, strangely as it had by this time begun to appear to herself, she (Charlotte) had hitherto not imagined them sustained by an ideal distinguishably different from her (Charlotte) own. Of course they were arranged--all four arranged; but what had the basis of their life been, precisely, but that they were arranged together? Amerigo and Charlotte were arranged together, but she (Charlotte)--to confine the matter only to herself--was arranged apart. It rushed over her (Charlotte), the full sense of all this, with quite another rush from that of the breaking wave of ten days before; and as her (Charlotte) father himself seemed not to meet the vaguely-clutching hand with which, during the first shock of complete perception, she (Charlotte) tried to steady herself, she (Charlotte) felt very much alone.

XXVII

There had been, from far back--that is from the Christmas time on--a plan that the parent and the child should

``do something lovely'' (the child)
together, and they had recurred to it on occasion, nursed it and brought it up theoretically, though without as yet quite allowing it to put its feet to the ground. The most it had done was to try a few steps on the drawing-room carpet, with much attendance, on either side, much holding up and guarding, much anticipation, in fine, of awkwardness or accident. Their companions, by the same token, had constantly assisted at the performance, following the experiment with sympathy and gaiety, and never so full of applause, Maggie now made out for herself, as when the infant project had kicked its little legs most wildly--kicked them, for all the world, across the Channel and half the Continent, kicked them over the Pyrenees and innocently crowed out some rich Spanish name. She (Maggie) asked herself at present if it had been a
``real'' (She)
belief that they were but wanting, for some such adventure, to snatch their moment; whether either had at any instant seen it as workable, save in the form of a toy to dangle before the other, that they should take flight, without wife or husband, for one more look,
``before they died,'' (husband)
at the Madrid pictures as well as for a drop of further weak delay in respect to three or four possible prizes, privately offered, rarities of the first water, responsibly reported on and profusely photographed, still patiently awaiting their noiseless arrival in retreats to which the clue had not otherwise been given away. The vision dallied with during the duskier days in Eaton Square had stretched to the span of three or four weeks of springtime for the total adventure, three or four weeks in the very spirit, after all, of their regular life, as their regular life had been persisting; full of shared mornings, afternoons, evenings, walks, drives,
``looks-in,'' (Eaton)
at old places, on vague chances; full also, in especial, of that purchased social ease, the sense of the comfort and credit of their house, which had essentially the perfection of something paid for, but which
``came,'' (Eaton)
on the whole, so cheap that it might have been felt as costing--as costing the parent and child--nothing. It was for Maggie to wonder, at present, if she (Maggie) had been sincere about their going, to ask herself whether she (Maggie) would have stuck to their plan even if nothing had happened.

Her (Maggie) view of the impossibility of sticking to it now may give us the measure of her (Maggie) sense that everything had happened. A difference had been made in her (Maggie) relation to each of her (Maggie) companions, and what it compelled her (Maggie) to say to herself was that to behave as she (Maggie) might have behaved before would be to act, for Amerigo and Charlotte, with the highest hypocrisy. She (Charlotte) saw in these days that a journey abroad with her (Charlotte) father would, more than anything else, have amounted, on his (father) part and her (Charlotte) own, to a last expression of an ecstasy of confidence, and that the charm of the idea, in fact, had been in some such sublimity. Day after day she (Charlotte) put off the moment of

``speaking,'' (she)
as she (Charlotte) inwardly and very comprehensively, called it--speaking, that is, to her (Charlotte) father; and all the more that she (Charlotte) was ridden by a strange suspense as to his (father) himself breaking silence. She (Charlotte) gave him (father) time, gave him (father), during several days, that morning, that noon, that night, and the next and the next and the next; even made up her (Charlotte) mind that if he (father) stood off longer it would be proof conclusive that he (father) too wasn't at peace. They would then have been, all successfully, throwing dust in each other's eyes; and it would be at last as if they must turn away their faces, since the silver mist that protected them had begun to grow sensibly thin. Finally, at the end of April, she (Charlotte) decided that if he (father) should say nothing for another period of twenty-four hours she (Charlotte) must take it as showing that they were, in her (Charlotte) private phraseology, lost; so little possible sincerity could there be in pretending to care for a journey to Spain at the approach of a summer that already promised to be hot. Such a proposal, on his (father) lips, such an extravagance of optimism, would be HIS (father) way of being consistent--for that he (father) didn't really want to move, or to move further, at the worst, than back to Fawns again, could only signify that he (father) wasn't, at heart, contented. What he (father) wanted, at any rate, and what he (father) didn't want were, in the event, put to the proof for Maggie just in time to give her (Maggie) a fresh wind. She (Maggie) had been dining, with her (Maggie) husband, in Eaton Square, on the occasion of hospitality offered by Mr. and Mrs. Verver to Lord and Lady Castledean. The propriety of some demonstration of this sort had been for many days before our group, the question reduced to the mere issue of which of the two houses should first take the field. The issue had been easily settled--in the manner of every issue referred in any degree to Amerigo and Charlotte: the initiative obviously belonged to Mrs. Verver, who had gone to Matcham while Maggie had stayed away, and the evening in Eaton Square might have passed for a demonstration all the more personal that the dinner had been planned on
``intimate'' (Eaton)
lines. Six other guests only, in addition to the host and the hostess of Matcham, made up the company, and each of these persons had for Maggie the interest of an attested connection with the Easter revels at that visionary house. Their common memory of an occasion that had clearly left behind it an ineffaceable charm--this air of beatific reference, less subdued in the others than in Amerigo and Charlotte, lent them, together, an inscrutable comradeship against which the young woman's imagination broke in a small vain wave.

It wasn't that she (woman) wished she (woman) had been of the remembered party and possessed herself of its secrets; for she (woman) didn't care about its secrets--she (woman) could concern herself at present, absolutely, with no secret but her (woman) own. What occurred was simply that she (woman) became aware, at a stroke, of the quantity of further nourishment required by her (woman) own, and of the amount of it she (woman) might somehow extract from these people; whereby she (woman) rose, of a sudden, to the desire to possess and use them, even to the extent of braving, of fairly defying, of directly exploiting, of possibly quite enjoying, under cover of an evil duplicity, the felt element of curiosity with which they regarded her (woman). Once she (woman) was conscious of the flitting wing of this last impression--the perception, irresistible, that she (woman) was something for their queer experience, just as they were something for hers--there was no limit to her (woman) conceived design of not letting them escape. She (woman) went and went, again, to-night, after her (woman) start was taken; went, positively, as she (woman) had felt herself going, three weeks before, on the morning when the vision of her (woman) father and his (father) wife awaiting her (woman) together in the breakfast-room had been so determinant. In this other scene it was Lady Castledean who was determinant, who kindled the light, or at all events the heat, and who acted on the nerves; Lady Castledean whom she (Castledean) knew she (Castledean), so oddly, didn't like, in spite of reasons upon reasons, the biggest diamonds on the yellowest hair, the longest lashes on the prettiest, falsest eyes, the oldest lace on the most violet velvet, the rightest manner on the wrongest assumption. Her (Castledean) ladyship's assumption was that she (Castledean) kept, at every moment of her (Castledean) life, every advantage--it made her (Castledean) beautifully soft, very nearly generous; so she (Castledean) didn't distinguish the little protuberant eyes of smaller social insects, often endowed with such a range, from the other decorative spots on their bodies and wings. Maggie had liked, in London, and in the world at large, so many more people than she (Maggie) had thought it right to fear, right even to so much as judge, that it positively quickened her (Maggie) fever to have to recognise, in this case, such a lapse of all the sequences. It was only that a charming clever woman wondered about her (woman)--that is wondered about her (woman) as Amerigo's wife, and wondered, moreover, with the intention of kindness and the spontaneity, almost, of surprise.

The point of view--that one--was what she (woman) read in their free contemplation, in that of the whole eight; there was something in Amerigo to be explained, and she (woman) was passed about, all tenderly and expertly, like a dressed doll held, in the right manner, by its firmly-stuffed middle, for the account she (woman) could give. She (woman) might have been made to give it by pressure of her (woman) stomach; she (woman) might have been expected to articulate, with a rare imitation of nature,

``Oh yes, I'm HERE all the while; I'm also in my way a solid little fact and I cost originally a great deal of money: cost, that is, my father, for my outfit, and let in my husband for an amount of pains--toward my training--that money would scarce represent.'' (she)
Well, she (woman) WOULD meet them in some such way, and she (woman) translated her (woman) idea into action, after dinner, before they dispersed, by engaging them all, unconventionally, almost violently, to dine with her (woman) in Portland Place, just as they were, if they didn't mind the same party, which was the party she (woman) wanted. Oh she (woman) was going, she (woman) was going--she (woman) could feel it afresh; it was a good deal as if she (woman) had sneezed ten times or had suddenly burst into a comic song. There were breaks in the connection, as there would be hitches in the process; she (woman) didn't wholly see, yet, what they would do for her (woman), nor quite how, herself, she (woman) should handle them; but she (woman) was dancing up and down, beneath her (woman) propriety, with the thought that she (woman) had at least begun something--she (woman) so fairly liked to feel that she (woman) was a point for convergence of wonder. It wasn't after all, either, that THEIR wonder so much signified--that of the cornered six, whom it glimmered before her (woman) that she (woman) might still live to drive about like a flock of sheep: the intensity of her (woman) consciousness, its sharpest savour, was in the theory of her (woman) having diverted, having, as they said, captured the attention of Amerigo and Charlotte, at neither of whom, all the while, did she (Charlotte) so much as once look. She (Charlotte) had pitched them in with the six, for that matter, so far as they themselves were concerned; they had dropped, for the succession of minutes, out of contact with their function--had, in short, startled and impressed, abandoned their post.
``They're paralysed, they're paralysed!'' (she)
she (Charlotte) commented, deep within; so much it helped her (Charlotte) own apprehension to hang together that they should suddenly lose their bearings.

Her (Charlotte) grasp of appearances was thus out of proportion to her (Charlotte) view of causes; but it came to her (Charlotte) then and there that if she (Charlotte) could only get the facts of appearance straight, only jam them down into their place, the reasons lurking behind them, kept uncertain, for the eyes, by their wavering and shifting, wouldn't perhaps be able to help showing. It wasn't of course that the Prince and Mrs. Verver marvelled to see her (Verver) civil to their friends; it was rather, precisely, that civil was just what she (Verver) wasn't: she (Verver) had so departed from any such custom of delicate approach--approach by the permitted note, the suggested

``if,'' (she)
the accepted vagueness--as would enable the people in question to put her (Verver) off if they wished. And the profit of her (Verver) plan, the effect of the violence she (Verver) was willing to let it go for, was exactly in their BEING the people in question, people she (Verver) had seemed to be rather shy of before and for whom she (Verver) suddenly opened her (Verver) mouth so wide. Later on, we may add, with the ground soon covered by her (Verver) agitated but resolute step, it was to cease to matter what people they were or weren't; but meanwhile the particular sense of them that she (Verver) had taken home to-night had done her (Verver) the service of seeming to break the ice where that formation was thickest. Still more unexpectedly, the service might have been the same for her (Verver) father; inasmuch as, immediately, when everyone had gone, he (father) did exactly what she (Verver) had been waiting for and despairing of--and did it, as he (father) did everything, with a simplicity that left any purpose of sounding him (father) deeper, of drawing him (father) out further, of going, in his (father) own frequent phrase,
``behind'' (him)
what he (father) said, nothing whatever to do. He (father) brought it out straight, made it bravely and beautifully irrelevant, save for the plea of what they should lose by breaking the charm:
``I guess we won't go down there after all, will we, Mag?--just when it's getting so pleasant here.'' (He)
That was all, with nothing to lead up to it; but it was done for her (Verver) at a stroke, and done, not less, more rather, for Amerigo and Charlotte, on whom the immediate effect, as she (Charlotte) secretly, as she (Charlotte) almost breathlessly measured it, was prodigious. Everything now so fitted for her (Charlotte) to everything else that she (Charlotte) could feel the effect as prodigious even while sticking to her (Charlotte) policy of giving the pair no look. There were thus some five wonderful minutes during which they loomed, to her (Charlotte) sightless eyes, on either side of her (Charlotte), larger than they had ever loomed before, larger than life, larger than thought, larger than any danger or any safety. There was thus a space of time, in fine, fairly vertiginous for her (Charlotte), during which she (Charlotte) took no more account of them than if they were not in the room.

She (Charlotte) had never, never treated them in any such way--not even just now, when she (Charlotte) had plied her (Charlotte) art upon the Matcham band; her (Charlotte) present manner was an intenser exclusion, and the air was charged with their silence while she (Charlotte) talked with her (Charlotte) other companion as if she (Charlotte) had nothing but him (companion) to consider. He (companion) had given her (Charlotte) the note amazingly, by his (companion) allusion to the pleasantness--that of such an occasion as his (companion) successful dinner--which might figure as their bribe for renouncing; so that it was all as if they were speaking selfishly, counting on a repetition of just such extensions of experience. Maggie achieved accordingly an act of unprecedented energy, threw herself into her (Maggie) father's presence as by the absolute consistency with which she (Maggie) held his (father) eyes; saying to herself, at the same time that she (Maggie) smiled and talked and inaugurated her (Maggie) system,

``What does he (husband) mean by it? That's the question--what does he (husband) mean?'' (she)
but studying again all the signs in him (father) that recent anxiety had made familiar and counting the stricken minutes on the part of the others. It was in their silence that the others loomed, as she (Maggie) felt; she (Maggie) had had no measure, she (Maggie) afterwards knew, of this duration, but it drew out and out--really to what would have been called in simpler conditions awkwardness--as if she (Maggie) herself were stretching the cord. Ten minutes later, however, in the homeward carriage, to which her (Maggie) husband, cutting delay short, had proceeded at the first announcement, ten minutes later she (Maggie) was to stretch it almost to breaking. The Prince had permitted her (Maggie) to linger much less, before his (Prince) move to the door, than they usually lingered at the gossiping close of such evenings; which she (Maggie), all responsive, took for a sign of his (Prince) impatience to modify for her (Maggie) the odd effect of his (Prince) not having, and of Charlotte's not having, instantly acclaimed the issue of the question debated, or more exactly, settled, before them. He (Prince) had had time to become aware of this possible impression in her (Charlotte), and his (Prince) virtually urging her (Charlotte) into the carriage was connected with his (Prince) feeling that he (Prince) must take action on the new ground. A certain ambiguity in her (Charlotte) would absolutely have tormented him (Prince); but he (Prince) had already found something to soothe and correct--as to which she (Charlotte) had, on her (Charlotte) side, a shrewd notion of what it would be. She (Charlotte) was herself, for that matter, prepared, and she (Charlotte) was, of a truth, as she (Charlotte) took her (Charlotte) seat in the brougham, amazed at her (Charlotte) preparation. It allowed her (Charlotte) scarce an interval; she (Charlotte) brought it straight out.

``I was certain that was what father would say if I should leave him (father) alone. I HAVE been leaving him (father) alone, and you see the effect. He (father) hates now to move--he (father) likes too much to be with us. But if you see the effect'' (she)
--she (Charlotte) felt herself magnificently keeping it up--
``perhaps you don't see the cause. The cause, my dear, is too lovely.'' (she)

Her (Charlotte) husband, on taking his (husband) place beside her (Charlotte), had, during a minute or two, for her (Charlotte) watching sense, neither said nor done anything; he (husband) had been, for that sense, as if thinking, waiting, deciding: yet it was still before he (husband) spoke that he (husband), as she (Charlotte) felt it to be, definitely acted. He (husband) put his (husband) arm round her (Charlotte) and drew her (Charlotte) close--indulged in the demonstration, the long, firm embrace by his (husband) single arm, the infinite pressure of her (Charlotte) whole person to his (husband) own, that such opportunities had so often suggested and prescribed. Held, accordingly, and, as she (Charlotte) could but too intimately feel, exquisitely solicited, she (Charlotte) had said the thing she (Charlotte) was intending and desiring to say, and as to which she (Charlotte) felt, even more than she (Charlotte) felt anything else, that whatever he (husband) might do she (Charlotte) mustn't be irresponsible. Yes, she (Charlotte) was in his (husband) exerted grasp, and she (Charlotte) knew what that was; but she (Charlotte) was at the same time in the grasp of her (Charlotte) conceived responsibility, and the extraordinary thing was that, of the two intensities, the second was presently to become the sharper. He (husband) took his (husband) time for it meanwhile, but he (husband) met her (Charlotte) speech after a fashion.

``The cause of your father's deciding not to go?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and of my having wanted to let it act for him (father) quietly--I mean without my insistence.'' (She)
She (Charlotte) had, in her (Charlotte) compressed state, another pause, and it made her (Charlotte) feel as if she (Charlotte) were immensely resisting. Strange enough was this sense for her (Charlotte), and altogether new, the sense of possessing, by miraculous help, some advantage that, absolutely then and there, in the carriage, as they rolled, she (Charlotte) might either give up or keep. Strange, inexpressibly strange--so distinctly she (Charlotte) saw that if she (Charlotte) did give it up she (Charlotte) should somehow give up everything for ever. And what her (Charlotte) husband's grasp really meant, as her (Charlotte) very bones registered, was that she (Charlotte) SHOULD give it up: it was exactly for this that he (husband) had resorted to unfailing magic. He (husband) KNEW HOW to resort to it--he (husband) could be, on occasion, as she (Charlotte) had lately more than ever learned, so munificent a lover: all of which was, precisely, a part of the character she (Charlotte) had never ceased to regard in him (character) as princely, a part of his (character) large and beautiful ease, his (character) genius for charm, for intercourse, for expression, for life. She (Charlotte) should have but to lay her (Charlotte) head back on his (character) shoulder with a certain movement to make it definite for him (character) that she (Charlotte) didn't resist. To this, as they went, every throb of her (Charlotte) consciousness prompted her (Charlotte)--every throb, that is, but one, the throb of her (Charlotte) deeper need to know where she (Charlotte)
``really'' (she)
was. By the time she (Charlotte) had uttered the rest of her (Charlotte) idea, therefore, she (Charlotte) was still keeping her (Charlotte) head and intending to keep it; though she (Charlotte) was also staring out of the carriage-window with eyes into which the tears of suffered pain had risen, indistinguishable, perhaps, happily, in the dusk. She (Charlotte) was making an effort that horribly hurt her (Charlotte), and, as she (Charlotte) couldn't cry out, her (Charlotte) eyes swam in her (Charlotte) silence. With them, all the same, through the square opening beside her (Charlotte), through the grey panorama of the London night, she (Charlotte) achieved the feat of not losing sight of what she (Charlotte) wanted; and her (Charlotte) lips helped and protected her (Charlotte) by being able to be gay.
``It's not to leave YOU, my dear--for that he (father)'ll give up anything; just as he (father) would go off anywhere, I think, you know, if you would go with him (father). I mean you and he (father) alone,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie pursued with her (Maggie) gaze out of her (Maggie) window.

For which Amerigo's answer again took him (Charlotte) a moment.

``Ah, the dear old boy! You would like me to propose him (boy) something--?'' (unknown)

``Well, if you think you could bear it.'' (unknown)

``And leave,'' (the Prince)
the Prince asked,
``you and Charlotte alone?'' (the Prince)

``Why not?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie had also to wait a minute, but when she (Maggie) spoke it came clear.
``Why shouldn't Charlotte be just one of MY reasons--my not liking to leave her (Charlotte)? She (Charlotte) has always been so good, so perfect, to me--but never so wonderfully as just now.
