We have somehow been more together--thinking, for the time, almost only of each other; it has been quite as in old days.'' (she)
And she (Maggie) proceeded consummately, for she (Maggie) felt it as consummate:
``It's as if we had been missing each other, had got a little apart--though going on so side by side. But the good moments, if one only waits for them,'' (she)
she (Maggie) hastened to add,
``come round of themselves. Moreover you've seen for yourself, since you've made it up so to father; feeling, for yourself, in your beautiful way, every difference, every air that blows; not having to be told or pushed, only being perfect to live with, through your habit of kindness and your exquisite instincts. But of course you've seen, all the while, that both he (father) and I have deeply felt how you've managed; managed that he (father) hasn't been too much alone and that I, on my side, haven't appeared, to--what you might call--neglect him (father). This is always,'' (she)
she (Maggie) continued,
``what I can never bless you enough for; of all the good things you've done for me you've never done anything better.'' (she)
She (Maggie) went on explaining as for the pleasure of explaining--even though knowing he (Prince) must recognise, as a part of his (Prince) easy way too, her (Maggie) description of his (Prince) large liberality.
``Your taking the child down yourself, those days, and your coming, each time, to bring him (father) away--nothing in the world, nothing you could have invented, would have kept father more under the charm. Besides, you know how you've always suited him (father), and how you've always so beautifully let it seem to him (father) that he (father) suits you. Only it has been, these last weeks, as if you wished--just in order to please him (father)--to remind him (father) of it afresh. So there it is,'' (she)
she (Maggie) wound up;
``it's your doing. You've produced your effect--that of his (father) wanting not to be, even for a month or two, where you're not. He (father) doesn't want to bother or bore you--THAT, I think, you know, he (father) never has done; and if you'll only give me time I'll come round again to making it my care, as always, that he (father) shan't. But he (father) can't bear you out of his (father) sight.'' (she)

She (Maggie) had kept it up and up, filling it out, crowding it in; and all, really, without difficulty, for it was, every word of it, thanks to a long evolution of feeling, what she (Maggie) had been primed to the brim with. She (Maggie) made the picture, forced it upon him (Prince), hung it before him (Prince); remembering, happily, how he (Prince) had gone so far, one day, supported by the Principino, as to propose the Zoo in Eaton Square, to carry with him (Eaton) there, on the spot, under this pleasant inspiration, both his (Eaton) elder and his (Eaton) younger companion, with the latter of whom he (Eaton) had taken the tone that they were introducing Granddaddy, Granddaddy nervous and rather funking it, to lions and tigers more or less at large. Touch by touch she (Maggie) thus dropped into her (Maggie) husband's silence the truth about his (husband) good nature and his (husband) good manners; and it was this demonstration of his (husband) virtue, precisely, that added to the strangeness, even for herself, of her (Maggie) failing as yet to yield to him (husband). It would be a question but of the most trivial act of surrender, the vibration of a nerve, the mere movement of a muscle; but the act grew important between them just through her (Maggie) doing perceptibly nothing, nothing but talk in the very tone that would naturally have swept her (Maggie) into tenderness. She (Maggie) knew more and more--every lapsing minute taught her (Maggie)--how he (husband) might by a single rightness make her (Maggie) cease to watch him (husband); that rightness, a million miles removed from the queer actual, falling so short, which would consist of his (husband) breaking out to her (Maggie) diviningly, indulgently, with the last happy inconsequence.

``Come away with me, somewhere, YOU--and then we needn't think, we needn't even talk, of anything, of anyone else:'' (her)
five words like that would answer her (Maggie), would break her (Maggie) utterly down. But they were the only ones that would so serve. She (Maggie) waited for them, and there was a supreme instant when, by the testimony of all the rest of him (husband), she (Maggie) seemed to feel them in his (husband) heart and on his (husband) lips; only they didn't sound, and as that made her (Maggie) wait again so it made her (Maggie) more intensely watch. This in turn showed her (Maggie) that he (husband) too watched and waited, and how much he (husband) had expected something that he (husband) now felt wouldn't come. Yes, it wouldn't come if he (husband) didn't answer her (Maggie), if he (husband) but said the wrong things instead of the right. If he (husband) could say the right everything would come--it hung by a hair that everything might crystallise for their recovered happiness at his (husband) touch. This possibility glowed at her (Maggie), however, for fifty seconds, only then to turn cold, and as it fell away from her (Maggie) she (Maggie) felt the chill of reality and knew again, all but pressed to his (husband) heart and with his (husband) breath upon her (Maggie) cheek, the slim rigour of her (Maggie) attitude, a rigour beyond that of her (Maggie) natural being. They had silences, at last, that were almost crudities of mutual resistance--silences that persisted through his (husband) felt effort to treat her (Maggie) recurrence to the part he (husband) had lately played, to interpret all the sweetness of her (Maggie) so talking to him (husband), as a manner of making love to him (husband). Ah, it was no such manner, heaven knew, for Maggie; she (Maggie) could make love, if this had been in question, better than that! On top of which it came to her (Maggie) presently to say, keeping in with what she (Maggie) had already spoken:
``Except of course that, for the question of going off somewhere, he (father)'d go readily, quite delightedly, with you. I verily believe he (father)'d like to have you for a while to himself.'' (she)

``Do you mean he (father) thinks of proposing it?'' (the Prince)
the Prince after a moment sounded.

``Oh no--he (father) doesn't ask, as you must so often have seen. But I believe he (father)'d go `like a shot,' as you say, if you were to suggest it.'' (she)

It had the air, she (Maggie) knew, of a kind of condition made, and she (Maggie) had asked herself while she (Maggie) spoke if it wouldn't cause his (Prince) arm to let her (Maggie) go. The fact that it didn't suggested to her (Maggie) that she (Maggie) had made him (Prince), of a sudden, still more intensely think, think with such concentration that he (Prince) could do but one thing at once. And it was precisely as if the concentration had the next moment been proved in him (Prince). He (Prince) took a turn inconsistent with the superficial impression--a jump that made light of their approach to gravity and represented for her (Maggie) the need in him (Prince) to gain time. That she (Maggie) made out, was his (Prince) drawback--that the warning from her (Maggie) had come to him (Prince), and had come to Charlotte, after all, too suddenly. That they were in face of it rearranging, that they had to rearrange, was all before her (Charlotte) again; yet to do as they would like they must enjoy a snatch, longer or shorter, of recovered independence. Amerigo, for the instant, was but doing as he (Prince) didn't like, and it was as if she (Charlotte) were watching his (Prince) effort without disguise.

``What's your father's idea, this year, then, about Fawns? Will he (father) go at Whitsuntide, and will he (father) then stay on?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie went through the form of thought.

``He (father) will really do, I imagine, as he (father) has, in so many ways, so often done before; do whatever may seem most agreeable to yourself. And there's of course always Charlotte to be considered. Only their going early to Fawns, if they do go,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said,
``needn't in the least entail your and my going.'' (she)

``Ah,'' (Amerigo)
Amerigo echoed,
``it needn't in the least entail your and my going?'' (Amerigo)

``We can do as we like. What they may do needn't trouble us, since they're by good fortune perfectly happy together.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Prince)
the Prince returned,
``your father's never so happy as with you near him (father) to enjoy his (father) being so.'' (Prince)

``Well, I may enjoy it,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``but I'm not the cause of it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``You're the cause,'' (husband)
her (Maggie) husband declared,
``of the greater part of everything that's good among us.'' (husband)
But she (Maggie) received this tribute in silence, and the next moment he (Prince) pursued:
``If Mrs. Verver has arrears of time with you to make up, as you say, she (Verver)'ll scarcely do it--or you scarcely will--by our cutting, your and my cutting, too loose.'' (he)

``I see what you mean,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie mused.

He (Prince) let her (Maggie) for a little to give her (Maggie) attention to it; after which,

``Shall I just quite, of a sudden,'' (her)
he (Prince) asked,
``propose him (our) a journey?'' (he)

Maggie hesitated, but she (Maggie) brought forth the fruit of reflection.

``It would have the merit that Charlotte then would be with me--with me, I mean, so much more. Also that I shouldn't, by choosing such a time for going away, seem unconscious and ungrateful, seem not to respond, seem in fact rather to wish to shake her (Charlotte) off. I should respond, on the contrary, very markedly--by being here alone with her (Charlotte) for a month.'' (unknown)

``And would you like to be here alone with her (Charlotte) for a month?'' (unknown)

``I could do with it beautifully. Or we might even,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said quite gaily,
``go together down to Fawns.'' (she)

``You could be so very content without me?'' (the Prince)
the Prince presently inquired.

``Yes, my own dear--if you could be content for a while with father. That would keep me up. I might, for the time,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``go to stay there with Charlotte; or, better still, she (Charlotte) might come to Portland Place.'' (she)

``Oho!'' (the Prince)
said the Prince with cheerful vagueness.

``I should feel, you see,'' (she)
she (Maggie) continued,
``that the two of us were showing the same sort of kindness.'' (she)

Amerigo thought.

``The two of us? Charlotte and I?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie again hesitated.

``You and I, darling.'' (unknown)

``I see, I see'' (he)
--he (Prince) promptly took it in.
``And what reason shall I give--give, I mean, your father?'' (unknown)

``For asking him (father) to go off? Why, the very simplest--if you conscientiously can. The desire,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``to be agreeable to him (father). Just that only.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Something in this reply made her (Maggie) husband again reflect. ```Conscientiously?' Why shouldn't I conscientiously? It wouldn't, by your own contention,'' he (husband) developed,

``represent any surprise for him (father). I must strike him (father) sufficiently as, at the worst, the last person in the world to wish to do anything to hurt him (father).'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Ah, there it was again, for Maggie--the note already sounded, the note of the felt need of not working harm! Why this precautionary view, she (Maggie) asked herself afresh, when her (Maggie) father had complained, at the very least, as little as herself? With their stillness together so perfect, what had suggested so, around them, the attitude of sparing them? Her (Maggie) inner vision fixed it once more, this attitude, saw it, in the others, as vivid and concrete, extended it straight from her (Maggie) companion to Charlotte. Before she (Maggie) was well aware, accordingly, she (Maggie) had echoed in this intensity of thought Amerigo's last words.

``You're the last person in the world to wish to do anything to hurt him (father).'' (She)

She (Maggie) heard herself, heard her (Maggie) tone, after she (Maggie) had spoken, and heard it the more that, for a minute after, she (Maggie) felt her (Maggie) husband's eyes on her (Maggie) face, very close, too close for her (Maggie) to see him (husband). He (husband) was looking at her (Maggie) because he (husband) was struck, and looking hard--though his (husband) answer, when it came, was straight enough.

``Why, isn't that just what we have been talking about--that I've affected you as fairly studying his (father) comfort and his (father) pleasure? He (father) might show his (father) sense of it,'' (the Prince)
the Prince went on,
``by proposing to ME an excursion.'' (the Prince)

``And you would go with him (father)?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie immediately asked.

He (Prince) hung fire but an instant.

``Per Dio!'' (She)

She (Maggie) also had her (Maggie) pause, but she (Maggie) broke it--since gaiety was in the air--with an intense smile.

``You can say that safely, because the proposal's one that, of his (father) own motion, he (father) won't make.'' (She)

She (Maggie) couldn't have narrated afterwards--and in fact was at a loss to tell herself--by what transition, what rather marked abruptness of change in their personal relation, their drive came to its end with a kind of interval established, almost confessed to, between them. She (Maggie) felt it in the tone with which he (Prince) repeated, after her (Maggie), ```Safely'--?''

``Safely as regards being thrown with him (father) perhaps after all, in such a case, too long. He (father)'s a person to think you might easily feel yourself to be. So it won't,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie said,
``come from father. He (father)'s too modest.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Their eyes continued to meet on it, from corner to corner of the brougham.

``Oh your modesty, between you--!'' (he)
But he (Prince) still smiled for it.
``So that unless I insist--?'' (unknown)

``We shall simply go on as we are.'' (unknown)

``Well, we're going on beautifully,'' (he)
he (Prince) answered--though by no means with the effect it would have had if their mute transaction, that of attempted capture and achieved escape, had not taken place. As Maggie said nothing, none the less, to gainsay his (Prince) remark, it was open to him (Prince) to find himself the next moment conscious of still another idea.
``I wonder if it would do. I mean for me to break in.'' (unknown)

```To break in'--?''

``Between your father and his (father) wife. But there would be a way,'' (he)
he (Prince) said--
``we can make Charlotte ask him (father).'' (he)
And then as Maggie herself now wondered, echoing it again:
``We can suggest to her (Charlotte) to suggest to him (father) that he (father) shall let me take him (father) off.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Oh!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

``Then if he (father) asks her (Charlotte) why I so suddenly break out she (Charlotte)'ll be able to tell him (father) the reason.'' (the footman)

They were stopping, and the footman, who had alighted, had rung at the house-door.

``That you think it would be so charming?'' (unknown)

``That I think it would be so charming. That we've persuaded HER will be convincing.'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on while the footman came back to let them out.
``I see,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said again; though she (Maggie) felt a little disconcerted. What she (Maggie) really saw, of a sudden, was that her (Maggie) stepmother might report her (Maggie) as above all concerned for the proposal, and this brought her (Maggie) back her (Maggie) need that her (Maggie) father shouldn't think her (Maggie) concerned in any degree for anything. She (Maggie) alighted the next instant with a slight sense of defeat; her (Maggie) husband, to let her (Maggie) out, had passed before her (Maggie), and, a little in advance, he (husband) awaited her (Maggie) on the edge of the low terrace, a step high, that preceded their open entrance, on either side of which one of their servants stood. The sense of a life tremendously ordered and fixed rose before her (Maggie), and there was something in Amerigo's very face, while his (husband) eyes again met her (Maggie) own through the dusky lamplight, that was like a conscious reminder of it. He (husband) had answered her (Maggie), just before, distinctly, and it appeared to leave her (Maggie) nothing to say. It was almost as if, having planned for the last word, she (Maggie) saw him (husband) himself enjoying it. It was almost as if--in the strangest way in the world--he (husband) were paying her (Maggie) back, by the production of a small pang, that of a new uneasiness, for the way she (Maggie) had slipped from him (husband) during their drive.

XXVIII

Maggie's new uneasiness might have had time to drop, inasmuch as she (Maggie) not only was conscious, during several days that followed, of no fresh indication for it to feed on, but was even struck, in quite another way, with an augmentation of the symptoms of that difference she (Maggie) had taken it into her (Maggie) head to work for. She (Maggie) recognised by the end of a week that if she (Maggie) had been in a manner caught up her (Maggie) father had been not less so--with the effect of her (Maggie) husband's and his (husband) wife's closing in, together, round them, and of their all having suddenly begun, as a party of four, to lead a life gregarious, and from that reason almost hilarious, so far as the easy sound of it went, as never before. It might have been an accident and a mere coincidence--so at least she (Maggie) said to herself at first; but a dozen chances that furthered the whole appearance had risen to the surface, pleasant pretexts, oh certainly pleasant, as pleasant as Amerigo in particular could make them, for associated undertakings, quite for shared adventures, for its always turning out, amusingly, that they wanted to do very much the same thing at the same time and in the same way. Funny all this was, to some extent, in the light of the fact that the father and daughter, for so long, had expressed so few positive desires; yet it would be sufficiently natural that if Amerigo and Charlotte HAD at last got a little tired of each other's company they should find their relief not so much in sinking to the rather low level of their companions as in wishing to pull the latter into the train in which they so constantly moved.

``We're in the train,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie mutely reflected after the dinner in Eaton Square with Lady Castledean;
``we've suddenly waked up in it and found ourselves rushing along, very much as if we had been put in during sleep--shoved, like a pair of labelled boxes, into the van. And since I wanted to `go' I'm certainly going,'' (Lady Castledean/Castledean)
she (Castledean) might have added;
``I'm moving without trouble--they're doing it all for us: it's wonderful how they understand and how perfectly it succeeds.'' (she)
For that was the thing she (Castledean) had most immediately to acknowledge: it seemed as easy for them to make a quartette as it had formerly so long appeared for them to make a pair of couples--this latter being thus a discovery too absurdly belated. The only point at which, day after day, the success appeared at all qualified was represented, as might have been said, by her (Castledean) irresistible impulse to give her (Castledean) father a clutch when the train indulged in one of its occasional lurches. Then--there was no denying it--his (father) eyes and her (Castledean) own met; so that they were themselves doing active violence, as against the others, to that very spirit of union, or at least to that very achievement of change, which she (Castledean) had taken the field to invoke.

The maximum of change was reached, no doubt, the day the Matcham party dined in Portland Place; the day, really perhaps, of Maggie's maximum of social glory, in the sense of its showing for her (Maggie) own occasion, her (Maggie) very own, with every one else extravagantly rallying and falling in, absolutely conspiring to make her (Maggie) its heroine. It was as if her (Maggie) father himself, always with more initiative as a guest than as a host, had dabbled too in the conspiracy; and the impression was not diminished by the presence of the Assinghams, likewise very much caught-up, now, after something of a lull, by the side-wind of all the rest of the motion, and giving our young woman, so far at least as Fanny was concerned, the sense of some special intention of encouragement and applause. Fanny, who had not been present at the other dinner, thanks to a preference entertained and expressed by Charlotte, made a splendid show at this one, in new orange-coloured velvet with multiplied turquoises, and with a confidence, furthermore, as different as possible, her (Charlotte) hostess inferred, from her (Charlotte) too-marked betrayal of a belittled state at Matcham. Maggie was not indifferent to her (Maggie) own opportunity to redress this balance--which seemed, for the hour, part of a general rectification; she (Maggie) liked making out for herself that on the high level of Portland Place, a spot exempt, on all sorts of grounds, from jealous jurisdictions, her (Maggie) friend could feel as

``good'' (friend)
as any one, and could in fact at moments almost appear to take the lead in recognition and celebration, so far as the evening might conduce to intensify the lustre of the little Princess. Mrs. Assingham produced on her (Assingham) the impression of giving her (Assingham) constantly her (Assingham) cue for this; and it was in truth partly by her (Assingham) help, intelligently, quite gratefully accepted, that the little Princess, in Maggie, was drawn out and emphasised. She (Princess) couldn't definitely have said how it happened, but she (Princess) felt herself, for the first time in her (Princess) career, living up to the public and popular notion of such a personage, as it pressed upon her (Princess) from all round; rather wondering, inwardly too, while she (Princess) did so, at that strange mixture in things through which the popular notion could be evidenced for her (Princess) by such supposedly great ones of the earth as the Castledeans and their kind. Fanny Assingham might really have been there, at all events, like one of the assistants in the ring at the circus, to keep up the pace of the sleek revolving animal on whose back the lady in short spangled skirts should brilliantly caper and posture. That was all, doubtless Maggie had forgotten, had neglected, had declined, to be the little Princess on anything like the scale open to her (Princess); but now that the collective hand had been held out to her (Princess) with such alacrity, so that she (Princess) might skip up into the light, even, as seemed to her (Princess) modest mind, with such a show of pink stocking and such an abbreviation of white petticoat, she (Princess) could strike herself as perceiving, under arched eyebrows, where her (Princess) mistake had been. She (Princess) had invited for the later hours, after her (Princess) dinner, a fresh contingent, the whole list of her (Princess) apparent London acquaintance--which was again a thing in the manner of little princesses for whom the princely art was a matter of course. That was what she (Princess) was learning to do, to fill out as a matter of course her (Princess) appointed, her (Princess) expected, her (Princess) imposed character; and, though there were latent considerations that somewhat interfered with the lesson, she (Princess) was having to-night an inordinate quantity of practice, none of it so successful as when, quite wittingly, she (Princess) directed it at Lady Castledean, who was reduced by it at last to an unprecedented state of passivity. The perception of this high result caused Mrs. Assingham fairly to flush with responsive joy; she (Assingham) glittered at her (Assingham) young friend, from moment to moment, quite feverishly; it was positively as if her (Assingham) young friend had, in some marvellous, sudden, supersubtle way, become a source of succour to herself, become beautifully, divinely retributive. The intensity of the taste of these registered phenomena was in fact that somehow, by a process and through a connexion not again to be traced, she (Assingham) so practised, at the same time, on Amerigo and Charlotte--with only the drawback, her (Charlotte) constant check and second-thought, that she (Charlotte) concomitantly practised perhaps still more on her (Charlotte) father.

This last was a danger indeed that, for much of the ensuing time, had its hours of strange beguilement--those at which her (Charlotte) sense for precautions so suffered itself to lapse that she (Charlotte) felt her (Charlotte) communion with him (father) more intimate than any other. It COULDN'T but pass between them that something singular was happening--so much as this she (Charlotte) again and again said to herself; whereby the comfort of it was there, after all, to be noted, just as much as the possible peril, and she (Charlotte) could think of the couple they formed together as groping, with sealed lips, but with mutual looks that had never been so tender, for some freedom, some fiction, some figured bravery, under which they might safely talk of it. The moment was to come--and it finally came with an effect as penetrating as the sound that follows the pressure of an electric button--when she (Charlotte) read the least helpful of meanings into the agitation she (Charlotte) had created. The merely specious description of their case would have been that, after being for a long time, as a family, delightfully, uninterruptedly happy, they had still had a new felicity to discover; a felicity for which, blessedly, her (Charlotte) father's appetite and her (Charlotte) own, in particular, had been kept fresh and grateful. This livelier march of their intercourse as a whole was the thing that occasionally determined in him (father) the clutching instinct we have glanced at; very much as if he (father) had said to her (Charlotte), in default of her (Charlotte) breaking silence first:

``Everything is remarkably pleasant, isn't it?--but WHERE, for it, after all, are we? up in a balloon and whirling through space, or down in the depths of the earth, in the glimmering passages of a gold-mine?'' (her)
The equilibrium, the precious condition, lasted in spite of rearrangement; there had been a fresh distribution of the different weights, but the balance persisted and triumphed: all of which was just the reason why she (Charlotte) was forbidden, face to face with the companion of her (Charlotte) adventure, the experiment of a test. If they balanced they balanced--she (Charlotte) had to take that; it deprived her (Charlotte) of every pretext for arriving, by however covert a process, at what he (companion) thought.

But she (Charlotte) had her (Charlotte) hours, thus, of feeling supremely linked to him (companion) by the rigour of their law, and when it came over her (Charlotte) that, all the while, the wish, on his (companion) side, to spare her (Charlotte) might be what most worked with him (companion), this very fact of their seeming to have nothing

``inward'' (him)
really to talk about wrapped him (companion) up for her (Charlotte) in a kind of sweetness that was wanting, as a consecration, even in her (Charlotte) yearning for her (Charlotte) husband. She (Charlotte) was powerless, however, was only more utterly hushed, when the interrupting flash came, when she (Charlotte) would have been all ready to say to him (husband),
``Yes, this is by every appearance the best time we've had yet; but don't you see, all the same, how they must be working together for it, and how my very success, my success in shifting our beautiful harmony to a new basis, comes round to being their success, above all; their cleverness, their amiability, their power to hold out, their complete possession, in short, of our life?'' (him)
For how could she (Charlotte) say as much as that without saying a great deal more? without saying
``They'll do everything in the world that suits us, save only one thing--prescribe a line for us that will make them separate.'' (she)
How could she (Charlotte) so much as imagine herself even faintly murmuring that without putting into his (husband) mouth the very words that would have made her (Charlotte) quail?
``Separate, my dear? Do you want them to separate? Then you want US to--you and me? For how can the one separation take place without the other?'' (she)
That was the question that, in spirit, she (Charlotte) had heard him (husband) ask--with its dread train, moreover, of involved and connected inquiries. Their own separation, his (husband) and hers, was of course perfectly thinkable, but only on the basis of the sharpest of reasons. Well, the sharpest, the very sharpest, would be that they could no longer afford, as it were, he (husband) to let his (husband) wife, she (wife) to let her (wife) husband,
``run'' (husband)
them in such compact formation. And say they accepted this account of their situation as a practical finality, acting upon it and proceeding to a division, would no sombre ghosts of the smothered past, on either side, show, across the widening strait, pale unappeased faces, or raise, in the very passage, deprecating, denouncing hands?

Meanwhile, however such things might be, she (wife) was to have occasion to say to herself that there might be but a deeper treachery in recoveries and reassurances. She (wife) was to feel alone again, as she (wife) had felt at the issue of her (wife) high tension with her (wife) husband during their return from meeting the Castledeans in Eaton Square. The evening in question had left her (wife) with a larger alarm, but then a lull had come--the alarm, after all, was yet to be confirmed. There came an hour, inevitably, when she (wife) knew, with a chill, what she (wife) had feared and why; it had taken, this hour, a month to arrive, but to find it before her (wife) was thoroughly to recognise it, for it showed her (wife) sharply what Amerigo had meant in alluding to a particular use that they might make, for their reaffirmed harmony and prosperity, of Charlotte. The more she (Charlotte) thought, at present, of the tone he (it) had employed to express their enjoyment of this resource, the more it came back to her (Charlotte) as the product of a conscious art of dealing with her (Charlotte). He (it) had been conscious, at the moment, of many things--conscious even, not a little, of desiring; and thereby of needing, to see what she (Charlotte) would do in a given case. The given case would be that of her (Charlotte) being to a certain extent, as she (Charlotte) might fairly make it out, MENACED--horrible as it was to impute to him (it) any intention represented by such a word. Why it was that to speak of making her (Charlotte) stepmother intervene, as they might call it, in a question that seemed, just then and there, quite peculiarly their own business--why it was that a turn so familiar and so easy should, at the worst, strike her (Charlotte) as charged with the spirit of a threat, was an oddity disconnected, for her (Charlotte), temporarily, from its grounds, the adventure of an imagination within her (Charlotte) that possibly had lost its way. That, precisely, was doubtless why she (Charlotte) had learned to wait, as the weeks passed by, with a fair, or rather indeed with an excessive, imitation of resumed serenity. There had been no prompt sequel to the Prince's equivocal light, and that made for patience; yet she (Charlotte) was none the less to have to admit, after delay, that the bread he (Prince) had cast on the waters had come home, and that she (Charlotte) should thus be justified of her (Charlotte) old apprehension. The consequence of this, in turn, was a renewed pang in presence of his (Prince) remembered ingenuity. To be ingenious with HER--what DIDN'T, what mightn't that mean, when she (Charlotte) had so absolutely never, at any point of contact with him (Prince), put him (Prince), by as much as the value of a penny, to the expense of sparing, doubting, fearing her (Charlotte), of having in any way whatever to reckon with her (Charlotte)? The ingenuity had been in his (Prince) simply speaking of their use of Charlotte as if it were common to them in an equal degree, and his (Prince) triumph, on the occasion, had been just in the simplicity. She (Charlotte) couldn't--and he (Prince) knew it--say what was true:

``Oh, you `use' her (their), and I use her (their), if you will, yes; but we use her (their) ever so differently and separately--not at all in the same way or degree. There's nobody we really use together but ourselves, don't you see?--by which I mean that where our interests are the same I can so beautifully, so exquisitely serve you for everything, and you can so beautifully, so exquisitely serve me. The only person either of us needs is the other of us; so why, as a matter of course, in such a case as this, drag in Charlotte?'' (he)

She (Charlotte) couldn't so challenge him (Prince), because it would have been--and there she (Charlotte) was paralysed--the NOTE. It would have translated itself on the spot, for his (Prince) ear, into jealousy; and, from reverberation to repercussion, would have reached her (Charlotte) father's exactly in the form of a cry piercing the stillness of peaceful sleep. It had been for many days almost as difficult for her (Charlotte) to catch a quiet twenty minutes with her (Charlotte) father as it had formerly been easy; there had been in fact, of old--the time, so strangely, seemed already far away--an inevitability in her (Charlotte) longer passages with him (father), a sort of domesticated beauty in the calculability, round about them, of everything. But at present Charlotte was almost always there when Amerigo brought her (Charlotte) to Eaton Square, where Amerigo was constantly bringing her (Charlotte); and Amerigo was almost always there when Charlotte brought her (Charlotte) husband to Portland Place, where Charlotte was constantly bringing HIM. The fractions of occasions, the chance minutes that put them face to face had, as yet, of late, contrived to count but little, between them, either for the sense of opportunity or for that of exposure; inasmuch as the lifelong rhythm of their intercourse made against all cursory handling of deep things. They had never availed themselves of any given quarter-of-an-hour to gossip about fundamentals; they moved slowly through large still spaces; they could be silent together, at any time, beautifully, with much more comfort than hurriedly expressive. It appeared indeed to have become true that their common appeal measured itself, for vividness, just by this economy of sound; they might have been talking

``at'' (companions)
each other when they talked with their companions, but these latter, assuredly, were not in any directer way to gain light on the current phase of their relation. Such were some of the reasons for which Maggie suspected fundamentals, as I have called them, to be rising, by a new movement, to the surface--suspected it one morning late in May, when her (Maggie) father presented himself in Portland Place alone. He (father) had his (father) pretext--of that she (Maggie) was fully aware: the Principino, two days before, had shown signs, happily not persistent, of a feverish cold and had notoriously been obliged to spend the interval at home. This was ground, ample ground, for punctual inquiry; but what it wasn't ground for, she (Maggie) quickly found herself reflecting, was his (father) having managed, in the interest of his (father) visit, to dispense so unwontedly--as their life had recently come to be arranged--with his (father) wife's attendance. It had so happened that she (wife) herself was, for the hour, exempt from her (wife) husband's, and it will at once be seen that the hour had a quality all its own when I note that, remembering how the Prince had looked in to say he (Prince) was going out, the Princess whimsically wondered if their respective sposi mightn't frankly be meeting, whimsically hoped indeed they were temporarily so disposed of. Strange was her (Princess) need, at moments, to think of them as not attaching an excessive importance to their repudiation of the general practice that had rested only a few weeks before on such a consecrated rightness. Repudiations, surely, were not in the air--they had none of them come to that; for wasn't she (Princess) at this minute testifying directly against them by her (Princess) own behaviour? When she (Princess) should confess to fear of being alone with her (Princess) father, to fear of what he (father) might then--ah, with such a slow, painful motion as she (Princess) had a horror of!--say to her (Princess), THEN would be time enough for Amerigo and Charlotte to confess to not liking to appear to foregather.

She (Charlotte) had this morning a wonderful consciousness both of dreading a particular question from him (father) and of being able to check, yes even to disconcert, magnificently, by her (Charlotte) apparent manner of receiving it, any restless imagination he (father) might have about its importance. The day, bright and soft, had the breath of summer; it made them talk, to begin with, of Fawns, of the way Fawns invited--Maggie aware, the while, that in thus regarding, with him (father), the sweetness of its invitation to one couple just as much as to another, her (Maggie) humbugging smile grew very nearly convulsive. That was it, and there was relief truly, of a sort, in taking it in: she (Maggie) was humbugging him (father) already, by absolute necessity, as she (Maggie) had never, never done in her (Maggie) life--doing it up to the full height of what she (Maggie) had allowed for. The necessity, in the great dimly-shining room where, declining, for his (father) reasons, to sit down, he (father) moved about in Amerigo's very footsteps, the necessity affected her (Maggie) as pressing upon her (Maggie) with the very force of the charm itself; of the old pleasantness, between them, so candidly playing up there again; of the positive flatness of their tenderness, a surface all for familiar use, quite as if generalised from the long succession of tapestried sofas, sweetly faded, on which his (father) theory of contentment had sat, through unmeasured pauses, beside her (Maggie) own. She (Maggie) KNEW, from this instant, knew in advance and as well as anything would ever teach her (Maggie), that she (Maggie) must never intermit for a solitary second her (Maggie) so highly undertaking to prove that there was nothing the matter with her (Maggie). She (Maggie) saw, of a sudden, everything she (Maggie) might say or do in the light of that undertaking, established connections from it with any number of remote matters, struck herself, for instance, as acting all in its interest when she (Maggie) proposed their going out, in the exercise of their freedom and in homage to the season, for a turn in the Regent's Park. This resort was close at hand, at the top of Portland Place, and the Principino, beautifully better, had already proceeded there under high attendance: all of which considerations were defensive for Maggie, all of which became, to her (Maggie) mind, part of the business of cultivating continuity.

Upstairs, while she (Maggie) left him (Regent) to put on something to go out in, the thought of his (Regent) waiting below for her (Maggie), in possession of the empty house, brought with it, sharply if briefly, one of her (Maggie) abrupt arrests of consistency, the brush of a vain imagination almost paralysing her (Maggie), often, for the minute, before her (Maggie) glass--the vivid look, in other words, of the particular difference his (Regent) marriage had made. The particular difference seemed at such instants the loss, more than anything else, of their old freedom, their never having had to think, where they were together concerned, of any one, of anything but each other. It hadn't been HER marriage that did it; that had never, for three seconds, suggested to either of them that they must act diplomatically, must reckon with another presence--no, not even with her (It) husband's. She (It) groaned to herself, while the vain imagination lasted,

``WHY did he (nobody) marry? ah, why DID he (nobody)?'' (She)
and then it came up to her (It) more than ever that nothing could have been more beautiful than the way in which, till Charlotte came so much more closely into their life, Amerigo hadn't interfered. What she (Charlotte) had gone on owing him (husband) for this mounted up again, to her (Charlotte) eyes, like a column of figures--or call it even, if one would, a house of cards; it was her (Charlotte) father's wonderful act that had tipped the house down and made the sum wrong. With all of which, immediately after her (Charlotte) question, her (Charlotte)
``Why did he (nobody), why did he (nobody)?'' (unknown)
rushed back, inevitably, the confounding, the overwhelming wave of the knowledge of his (father) reason.
``He (nobody) did it for ME, he (nobody) did it for me,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) moaned,
``he (nobody) did it, exactly, that our freedom--meaning, beloved man, simply and solely mine--should be greater instead of less; he (man) did it, divinely, to liberate me so far as possible from caring what became of him (man).'' (she)
She (Charlotte) found time upstairs, even in her (Charlotte) haste, as she (Charlotte) had repeatedly found time before, to let the wonderments involved in these recognitions flash at her (Charlotte) with their customary effect of making her (Charlotte) blink: the question in especial of whether she (Charlotte) might find her (Charlotte) solution in acting, herself, in the spirit of what he (father) had done, in forcing her (Charlotte)
``care'' (he)
really to grow as much less as he (father) had tried to make it. Thus she (Charlotte) felt the whole weight of their case drop afresh upon her (Charlotte) shoulders, was confronted, unmistakably, with the prime source of her (Charlotte) haunted state. It all came from her (Charlotte) not having been able not to mind--not to mind what became of him (father); not having been able, without anxiety, to let him (father) go his (father) way and take his (father) risk and lead his (father) life. She (Charlotte) had made anxiety her (Charlotte) stupid little idol; and absolutely now, while she (Charlotte) stuck a long pin, a trifle fallaciously, into her (Charlotte) hat--she (Charlotte) had, with an approach to irritation, told her (Charlotte) maid, a new woman, whom she (Charlotte) had lately found herself thinking of as abysmal, that she (Charlotte) didn't want her (Charlotte)--she (Charlotte) tried to focus the possibility of some understanding between them in consequence of which he (father) should cut loose.

Very near indeed it looked, any such possibility! that consciousness, too, had taken its turn by the time she (Charlotte) was ready; all the vibration, all the emotion of this present passage being, precisely, in the very sweetness of their lapse back into the conditions of the simpler time, into a queer resemblance between the aspect and the feeling of the moment and those of numberless other moments that were sufficiently far away. She (Charlotte) had been quick in her (Charlotte) preparation, in spite of the flow of the tide that sometimes took away her (Charlotte) breath; but a pause, once more, was still left for her (Charlotte) to make, a pause, at the top of the stairs, before she (Charlotte) came down to him (Charlotte), in the span of which she (Charlotte) asked herself if it weren't thinkable, from the perfectly practical point of view, that she (Charlotte) should simply sacrifice him (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) didn't go into the detail of what sacrificing him (Charlotte) would mean--she (Charlotte) didn't need to; so distinct was it, in one of her (Charlotte) restless lights, that there he (Charlotte) was awaiting her (Charlotte), that she (Charlotte) should find him (Charlotte) walking up and down the drawing-room in the warm, fragrant air to which the open windows and the abundant flowers contributed; slowly and vaguely moving there and looking very slight and young and, superficially, manageable, almost as much like her (Charlotte) child, putting it a little freely, as like her (Charlotte) parent; with the appearance about him (Charlotte), above all, of having perhaps arrived just on purpose to SAY it to her (Charlotte), himself, in so many words:

``Sacrifice me, my own love; do sacrifice me, do sacrifice me!'' (her)
Should she (Charlotte) want to, should she (Charlotte) insist on it, she (Charlotte) might verily hear him (Charlotte) bleating it at her (Charlotte), all conscious and all accommodating, like some precious, spotless, exceptionally intelligent lamb. The positive effect of the intensity of this figure, however, was to make her (Charlotte) shake it away in her (Charlotte) resumed descent; and after she (Charlotte) had rejoined him (Charlotte), after she (Charlotte) had picked him (Charlotte) up, she (Charlotte) was to know the full pang of the thought that her (Charlotte) impossibility was MADE, absolutely, by his (Charlotte) consciousness, by the lucidity of his (Charlotte) intention: this she (Charlotte) felt while she (Charlotte) smiled there for him (Charlotte), again, all hypocritically; while she (Charlotte) drew on fair, fresh gloves; while she (Charlotte) interrupted the process first to give his (Charlotte) necktie a slightly smarter twist and then to make up to him (Charlotte) for her (Charlotte) hidden madness by rubbing her (Charlotte) nose into his (Charlotte) cheek according to the tradition of their frankest levity.

From the instant she (Charlotte) should be able to convict him (Charlotte) of intending, every issue would be closed and her (Charlotte) hypocrisy would have to redouble. The only way to sacrifice him (Charlotte) would be to do so without his (Charlotte) dreaming what it might be for. She (Charlotte) kissed him (Charlotte), she (Charlotte) arranged his (Charlotte) cravat, she (Charlotte) dropped remarks, she (Charlotte) guided him (Charlotte) out, she (Charlotte) held his (Charlotte) arm, not to be led, but to lead him (Charlotte), and taking it to her (Charlotte) by much the same intimate pressure she (Charlotte) had always used, when a little girl, to mark the inseparability of her (girl) doll--she (girl) did all these things so that he (Charlotte) should sufficiently fail to dream of what they might be for.

XXIX

There was nothing to show that her (girl) effort in any degree fell short till they got well into the Park and he (Charlotte) struck her (girl) as giving, unexpectedly, the go-by to any serious search for the Principino. The way they sat down awhile in the sun was a sign of that; his (Charlotte) dropping with her (girl) into the first pair of sequestered chairs they came across and waiting a little, after they were placed, as if now at last she (girl) might bring out, as between them, something more specific. It made her (girl) but feel the more sharply how the specific, in almost any direction, was utterly forbidden her (girl)--how the use of it would be, for all the world, like undoing the leash of a dog eager to follow up a scent. It would come out, the specific, where the dog would come out; would run to earth, somehow, the truth--for she (girl) was believing herself in relation to the truth!--at which she (girl) mustn't so much as indirectly point. Such, at any rate, was the fashion in which her (girl) passionate prudence played over possibilities of danger, reading symptoms and betrayals into everything she (girl) looked at, and yet having to make it evident, while she (girl) recognised them, that she (girl) didn't wince. There were moments between them, in their chairs, when he (girl) might have been watching her (girl) guard herself and trying to think of something new that would trip her (girl) up. There were pauses during which, with her (girl) affection as sweet and still as the sunshine, she (girl) might yet, as at some hard game, over a table, for money, have been defying him (girl) to fasten upon her (girl) the least little complication of consciousness. She (girl) was positively proud, afterwards, of the great style in which she (girl) had kept this up; later on, at the hour's end, when they had retraced their steps to find Amerigo and Charlotte awaiting them at the house, she (Charlotte) was able to say to herself that, truly, she (Charlotte) had put her (Charlotte) plan through; even though once more setting herself the difficult task of making their relation, every minute of the time, not fall below the standard of that other hour, in the treasured past, which hung there behind them like a framed picture in a museum, a high watermark for the history of their old fortune; the summer evening, in the park at Fawns, when, side by side under the trees just as now, they had let their happy confidence lull them with its most golden tone. There had been the possibility of a trap for her (them), at present, in the very question of their taking up anew that residence; wherefore she (them) had not been the first to sound it, in spite of the impression from him (them) of his (them) holding off to see what she (them) would do. She (them) was saying to herself in secret:

``CAN we again, in this form, migrate there? Can I, for myself, undertake it? face all the intenser keeping-up and stretching-out, indefinitely, impossibly, that our conditions in the country, as we've established and accepted them, would stand for?'' (She)
She (them) had positively lost herself in this inward doubt--so much she (them) was subsequently to remember; but remembering then too that her (them) companion, though perceptibly perhaps as if not to be eager, had broken the ice very much as he (companion) had broken it in Eaton Square after the banquet to the Castledeans.

Her (them) mind had taken a long excursion, wandered far into the vision of what a summer at Fawns, with Amerigo and Charlotte still more eminently in presence against that higher sky, would bring forth. Wasn't her (Charlotte) father meanwhile only pretending to talk of it? just as she (Charlotte) was, in a manner, pretending to listen? He (father) got off it, finally, at all events, for the transition it couldn't well help thrusting out at him (father); it had amounted exactly to an arrest of her (Charlotte) private excursion by the sense that he (father) had begun to IMITATE--oh, as never yet!--the ancient tone of gold. It had verily come from him (father) at last, the question of whether she (Charlotte) thought it would be very good--but very good indeed--that he (father) should leave England for a series of weeks, on some pretext, with the Prince. Then it had been that she (Charlotte) was to know her (Charlotte) husband's

``menace'' (husband)
hadn't really dropped, since she (Charlotte) was face to face with the effect of it. Ah, the effect of it had occupied all the rest of their walk, had stayed out with them and come home with them, besides making it impossible that they shouldn't presently feign to recollect how rejoining the child had been their original purpose. Maggie's uneffaced note was that it had, at the end of five minutes more, driven them to that endeavour as to a refuge, and caused them afterwards to rejoice, as well, that the boy's irrepressibly importunate company, in due course secured and enjoyed, with the extension imparted by his (boy) governess, a person expectant of consideration, constituted a cover for any awkwardness. For that was what it had all come to, that the dear man had spoken to her (Maggie) to TRY her (Maggie)--quite as he (man) had been spoken to himself by Charlotte, with the same fine idea. The Princess took it in, on the spot, firmly grasping it; she (Princess) heard them together, her (Princess) father and his (father) wife, dealing with the queer case.
``The Prince tells me that Maggie has a plan for your taking some foreign journey with him (Prince), and, as he (Prince) likes to do everything she (Maggie) wants, he (Prince) has suggested my speaking to you for it as the thing most likely to make you consent. So I do speak--see?--being always so eager myself, as you know, to meet Maggie's wishes. I speak, but without quite understanding, this time, what she (Maggie) has in her (Maggie) head. Why SHOULD she (Maggie), of a sudden, at this particular moment, desire to ship you off together and to remain here alone with me? The compliment's all to me, I admit, and you must decide quite as you like. The Prince is quite ready, evidently, to do his (Prince) part--but you'll have it out with him (Prince). That is you'll have it out with HER.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Something of that kind was what, in her (Princess) mind's ear, Maggie heard--and this, after his (father) waiting for her (Maggie) to appeal to him (father) directly, was her (Maggie) father's invitation to her (Maggie) to have it out. Well, as she (Maggie) could say to herself all the rest of the day, that was what they did while they continued to sit there in their penny chairs, that was what they HAD done as much as they would now ever, ever, have out anything. The measure of this, at least, had been given, that each would fight to the last for the protection, for the perversion, of any real anxiety. She (Maggie) had confessed, instantly, with her (Maggie) humbugging grin, not flinching by a hair, meeting his (Maggie) eyes as mildly as he (Maggie) met hers, she (Maggie) had confessed to her (Maggie) fancy that they might both, he (Maggie) and his (Maggie) son-in-law, have welcomed such an escapade, since they had both been so long so furiously domestic. She (Maggie) had almost cocked her (Maggie) hat under the inspiration of this opportunity to hint how a couple of spirited young men, reacting from confinement and sallying forth arm-in-arm, might encounter the agreeable in forms that would strike them for the time at least as novel. She (Maggie) had felt for fifty seconds, with her (Maggie) eyes, all so sweetly and falsely, in her (Maggie) companion's, horribly vulgar; yet without minding it either--such luck should she (Maggie) have if to be nothing worse than vulgar would see her (Maggie) through.
``And I thought Amerigo might like it better,'' (she)
she (Maggie) had said,
``than wandering off alone.'' (she)

``Do you mean that he (Prince) won't go unless I take him (Prince)?'' (She)

She (Maggie) had considered here, and never in her (Maggie) life had she (Maggie) considered so promptly and so intently. If she (Maggie) really put it that way, her (Maggie) husband, challenged, might belie the statement; so that what would that do but make her (Maggie) father wonder, make him (father) perhaps ask straight out, why she (Maggie) was exerting pressure? She (Maggie) couldn't of course afford to be suspected for an instant of exerting pressure; which was why she (Maggie) was obliged only to make answer:

``Wouldn't that be just what you must have out with HIM?'' (she)

``Decidedly--if he (Prince) makes me the proposal. But he (Prince) hasn't made it yet.'' (she)

Oh, once more, how she (Maggie) was to feel she (Maggie) had smirked!

``Perhaps he (Prince)'s too shy!'' (unknown)

``Because you're so sure he (Prince) so really wants my company?'' (unknown)

``I think he (Prince) has thought you might like it.'' (unknown)

``Well, I should--!'' (he)
But with this he (father) looked away from her (Maggie), and she (Maggie) held her (Maggie) breath to hear him (father) either ask if she (Maggie) wished him (father) to address the question to Amerigo straight, or inquire if she (Maggie) should be greatly disappointed by his (father) letting it drop. What had
``settled'' (her)
her (Maggie), as she (Maggie) was privately to call it, was that he (father) had done neither of these things, and had thereby markedly stood off from the risk involved in trying to draw out her (Maggie) reason. To attenuate, on the other hand, this appearance, and quite as if to fill out the too large receptacle made, so musingly, by his (father) abstention, he (father) had himself presently given her (Maggie) a reason--had positively spared her (Maggie) the effort of asking whether he (father) judged Charlotte not to have approved. He (father) had taken everything on himself--THAT was what had settled her (Charlotte). She (Charlotte) had had to wait very little more to feel, with this, how much he (father) was taking. The point he (father) made was his (father) lack of any eagerness to put time and space, on any such scale, between himself and his (father) wife. He (father) wasn't so unhappy with her (wife)--far from it, and Maggie was to hold that he (father) had grinned back, paternally, through his (father) rather shielding glasses, in easy emphasis of this--as to be able to hint that he (father) required the relief of absence. Therefore, unless it was for the Prince himself--!

``Oh, I don't think it would have been for Amerigo himself. Amerigo and I,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie had said,
``perfectly rub on together.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Well then, there we are.'' (unknown)

``I see'' (she)
--and she (Maggie) had again, with sublime blandness, assented.
``There we are.'' (unknown)

``Charlotte and I too,'' (father)
her (Maggie) father had gaily proceeded,
``perfectly rub on together.'' (father)
And then he (father) had appeared for a little to be making time.
``To put it only so,'' (he)
he (father) had mildly and happily added--
``to put it only so!'' (he)
He (father) had spoken as if he (father) might easily put it much better, yet as if the humour of contented understatement fairly sufficed for the occasion. He (father) had played then, either all consciously or all unconsciously, into Charlotte's hands; and the effect of this was to render trebly oppressive Maggie's conviction of Charlotte's plan. She (Charlotte) had done what she (Charlotte) wanted, his (father) wife had--which was also what Amerigo had made her (Charlotte) do. She (Charlotte) had kept her (Charlotte) test, Maggie's test, from becoming possible, and had applied instead a test of her (Charlotte) own. It was exactly as if she (Charlotte) had known that her (Charlotte) stepdaughter would be afraid to be summoned to say, under the least approach to cross-examination, why any change was desirable; and it was, for our young woman herself, still more prodigiously, as if her (woman) father had been capable of calculations to match, of judging it important he (father) shouldn't be brought to demand of her (woman) what was the matter with her (woman). Why otherwise, with such an opportunity, hadn't he (father) demanded it? Always from calculation--that was why, that was why. He (father) was terrified of the retort he (father) might have invoked:
``What, my dear, if you come to that, is the matter with YOU?'' (he)
When, a minute later on, he (father) had followed up his (father) last note by a touch or two designed still further to conjure away the ghost of the anomalous, at that climax verily she (woman) would have had to be dumb to the question.
``There seems a kind of charm, doesn't there? on our life--and quite as if, just lately, it had got itself somehow renewed, had waked up refreshed. A kind of wicked selfish prosperity perhaps, as if we had grabbed everything, fixed everything, down to the last lovely object for the last glass case of the last corner, left over, of my old show. That's the only take-off, that it has made us perhaps lazy, a wee bit languid--lying like gods together, all careless of mankind.'' (unknown)

``Do you consider that we're languid?'' (she)
--that form of rejoinder she (woman) had jumped at for the sake of its pretty lightness.
``Do you consider that we are careless of mankind?--living as we do in the biggest crowd in the world, and running about always pursued and pursuing.'' (him)

It had made him (father) think indeed a little longer than she (woman) had meant; but he (father) came up again, as she (woman) might have said, smiling.

``Well, I don't know. We get nothing but the fun, do we?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (woman) had hastened to declare;
``we certainly get nothing but the fun.'' (she)

``We do it all,'' (he)
he (father) had remarked,
``so beautifully.'' (he)

``We do it all so beautifully.'' (She)
She (woman) hadn't denied this for a moment.
``I see what you mean.'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean too,'' (he)
he (father) had gone on,
``that we haven't, no doubt, enough, the sense of difficulty.'' (he)

``Enough? Enough for what?'' (unknown)

``Enough not to be selfish.'' (unknown)

``I don't think YOU are selfish,'' (she)
she (woman) had returned--and had managed not to wail it.

``I don't say that it's me particularly--or that it's you or Charlotte or Amerigo. But we're selfish together--we move as a selfish mass. You see we want always the same thing,'' (he)
he (father) had gone on--
``and that holds us, that binds us, together. We want each other,'' (he)
he (father) had further explained;
``only wanting it, each time, FOR each other. That's what I call the happy spell; but it's also, a little, possibly, the immorality.'' (he)

```The immorality'?'' she (woman) had pleasantly echoed.

``Well, we're tremendously moral for ourselves--that is for each other; and I won't pretend that I know exactly at whose particular personal expense you and I, for instance, are happy. What it comes to, I daresay, is that there's something haunting--as if it were a bit uncanny--in such a consciousness of our general comfort and privilege. Unless indeed,'' (he)
he (father) had rambled on,
``it's only I to whom, fantastically, it says so much. That's all I mean, at any rate--that it's sort of soothing; as if we were sitting about on divans, with pigtails, smoking opium and seeing visions. `Let us then be up and doing'--what is it Longfellow says? That seems sometimes to ring out; like the police breaking in--into our opium den--to give us a shake. But the beauty of it is, at the same time, that we ARE doing; we're doing, that is, after all, what we went in for. We're working it, our life, our chance, whatever you may call it, as we saw it, as we felt it, from the first. We HAVE worked it, and what more can you do than that? It's a good deal for me,'' (he)
he (father) had wound up,
``to have made Charlotte so happy--to have so perfectly contented her (Charlotte). YOU, from a good way back, were a matter of course--I mean your being all right; so that I needn't mind your knowing that my great interest, since then, has rather inevitably been in making sure of the same success, very much to your advantage as well, for Charlotte. If we've worked our life, our idea really, as I say--if at any rate I can sit here and say that I've worked my share of it--it has not been what you may call least by our having put Charlotte so at her (Charlotte) ease. THAT has been soothing, all round; that has curled up as the biggest of the blue fumes, or whatever they are, of the opium. Don't you see what a cropper we would have come if she (Charlotte) hadn't settled down as she (Charlotte) has?'' (he)
And he (father) had concluded by turning to Maggie as for something she (Maggie) mightn't really have thought of.
``You, darling, in that case, I verily believe, would have been the one to hate it most.'' (unknown)

``To hate it--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie had wondered.

``To hate our having, with our tremendous intentions, not brought it off. And I daresay I should have hated it for you even more than for myself.'' (unknown)

``That's not unlikely perhaps when it was for me, after all, that you did it.'' (He)

He (father) had hesitated, but only a moment.

``I never told you so.'' (unknown)

``Well, Charlotte herself soon enough told me.'' (unknown)

``But I never told HER,'' (father)
her (Maggie) father had answered.

``Are you very sure?'' (she)
she (Maggie) had presently asked.

``Well, I like to think how thoroughly I was taken with her (Charlotte), and how right I was, and how fortunate, to have that for my basis. I told her (Charlotte) all the good I thought of her (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``Then that,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie had returned,
``was precisely part of the good. I mean it was precisely part of it that she (Charlotte) could so beautifully understand.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Yes--understand everything.'' (unknown)

``Everything--and in particular your reasons. Her (Charlotte) telling me--that showed me how she (Charlotte) had understood.'' (she)

They were face to face again now, and she (Maggie) saw she (Maggie) had made his (father) colour rise; it was as if he (father) were still finding in her (Maggie) eyes the concrete image, the enacted scene, of her (Maggie) passage with Charlotte, which he (father) was now hearing of for the first time and as to which it would have been natural he (father) should question her (Charlotte) further. His (father) forbearance to do so would but mark, precisely, the complication of his (father) fears.

``What she (Charlotte) does like,'' (he)
he (father) finally said,
``is the way it has succeeded.'' (he)

``Your marriage?'' (unknown)

``Yes--my whole idea. The way I've been justified. That's the joy I give her (Charlotte). If for HER, either, it had failed--!'' (unknown)
That, however, was not worth talking about; he (father) had broken off.
``You think then you could now risk Fawns?'' (unknown)

```Risk' it?''

``Well, morally--from the point of view I was talking of; that of our sinking deeper into sloth. Our selfishness, somehow, seems at its biggest down there.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie had allowed him (father) the amusement of her (Maggie) not taking this up.

``Is Charlotte,'' (she)
she (Maggie) had simply asked,
``really ready?'' (she)

``Oh, if you and I and Amerigo are. Whenever one corners Charlotte,'' (he)
he (father) had developed more at his (father) ease,
``one finds that she (Charlotte) only wants to know what we want. Which is what we got her (Charlotte) for!'' (he)

``What we got her (Charlotte) for--exactly!'' (unknown)
And so, for a little, even though with a certain effect of oddity in their more or less successful ease, they left it; left it till Maggie made the remark that it was all the same wonderful her (Maggie) stepmother should be willing, before the season was out, to exchange so much company for so much comparative solitude.

``Ah,'' (he)
he (father) had then made answer,
``that's because her (Charlotte) idea, I think, this time, is that we shall have more people, more than we've hitherto had, in the country. Don't you remember that THAT, originally, was what we were to get her (Charlotte) for?'' (he)

``Oh yes--to give us a life.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie had gone through the form of recalling this, and the light of their ancient candour, shining from so far back, had seemed to bring out some things so strangely that, with the sharpness of the vision, she (Maggie) had risen to her (Maggie) feet.
``Well, with a `life' Fawns will certainly do.'' (He)
He (father) had remained in his (father) place while she (Maggie) looked over his (father) head; the picture, in her (Maggie) vision, had suddenly swarmed. The vibration was that of one of the lurches of the mystic train in which, with her (Maggie) companion, she (Maggie) was travelling; but she (Maggie) was having to steady herself, this time, before meeting his (companion) eyes. She (Maggie) had measured indeed the full difference between the move to Fawns because each of them now knew the others wanted it and the pairing-off, for a journey, of her (Maggie) husband and her (Maggie) father, which nobody knew that either wanted.
``More company'' (husband stepmother)
at Fawns would be effectually enough the key in which her (Maggie) husband and her (Maggie) stepmother were at work; there was truly no question but that she (Maggie) and her (Maggie) father must accept any array of visitors. No one could try to marry him (father) now. What he (father) had just said was a direct plea for that, and what was the plea itself but an act of submission to Charlotte? He (father) had, from his (father) chair, been noting her (Charlotte) look, but he (father) had, the next minute, also risen, and then it was they had reminded each other of their having come out for the boy. Their junction with him (boy) and with his (boy) companion successfully effected, the four had moved home more slowly, and still more vaguely; yet with a vagueness that permitted of Maggie's reverting an instant to the larger issue.

``If we have people in the country then, as you were saying, do you know for whom my first fancy would be? You may be amused, but it would be for the Castledeans.'' (unknown)

``I see. But why should I be amused?'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean I am myself. I don't think I like her (Charlotte)--and yet I like to see her (Charlotte): which, as Amerigo says, is `rum.'''

``But don't you feel she (Charlotte)'s very handsome?'' (father)
her (Maggie) father inquired.

``Yes, but it isn't for that.'' (unknown)

``Then what is it for?'' (unknown)

``Simply that she (Charlotte) may be THERE--just there before us. It's as if she (Charlotte) may have a value--as if something may come of her (Charlotte). I don't in the least know what, and she (Charlotte) rather irritates me meanwhile. I don't even know, I admit, why--but if we see her (Charlotte) often enough I may find out.'' (unknown)

``Does it matter so very much?'' (companion)
her (Maggie) companion had asked while they moved together.

She (Maggie) had hesitated.

``You mean because you do rather like her (Charlotte)?'' (He)

He (companion) on his (companion) side too had waited a little, but then he (companion) had taken it from her (Maggie).

``Yes, I guess I do rather like her (Charlotte).'' (she)

Which she (Maggie) accepted for the first case she (Maggie) could recall of their not being affected by a person in the same way. It came back therefore to his (companion) pretending; but she (Maggie) had gone far enough, and to add to her (Maggie) appearance of levity she (Maggie) further observed that, though they were so far from a novelty, she (Maggie) should also immediately desire, at Fawns, the presence of the Assinghams. That put everything on a basis independent of explanations; yet it was extraordinary, at the same time, how much, once in the country again with the others, she (Maggie) was going, as they used to say at home, to need the presence of the good Fanny. It was the strangest thing in the world, but it was as if Mrs. Assingham might in a manner mitigate the intensity of her (Assingham) consciousness of Charlotte. It was as if the two would balance, one against the other; as if it came round again in that fashion to her (Assingham) idea of the equilibrium. It would be like putting this friend into her (Assingham) scale to make weight--into the scale with her (Assingham) father and herself. Amerigo and Charlotte would be in the other; therefore it would take the three of them to keep that one straight. And as this played, all duskily, in her (Charlotte) mind it had received from her (Charlotte) father, with a sound of suddenness, a luminous contribution.

``Ah, rather! DO let's have the Assinghams.'' (unknown)

``It would be to have them,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) had said,
``as we used so much to have them. For a good long stay, in the old way and on the old terms: `as regular boarders' Fanny used to call it. That is if they'll come.'' (she)

``As regular boarders, on the old terms--that's what I should like too. But I guess they'll come,'' (companion)
her (Charlotte) companion had added in a tone into which she (Charlotte) had read meanings. The main meaning was that he (companion) felt he (companion) was going to require them quite as much as she (Charlotte) was. His (companion) recognition of the new terms as different from the old, what was that, practically, but a confession that something had happened, and a perception that, interested in the situation she (Charlotte) had helped to create, Mrs. Assingham would be, by so much as this, concerned in its inevitable development? It amounted to an intimation, off his (companion) guard, that he (companion) should be thankful for some one to turn to. If she (Assingham) had wished covertly to sound him (companion) he (companion) had now, in short, quite given himself away, and if she (Assingham) had, even at the start, needed anything MORE to settle her (Assingham), here assuredly was enough. He (companion) had hold of his (companion) small grandchild as they retraced their steps, swinging the boy's hand and not bored, as he (companion) never was, by his (companion) always bristling, like a fat little porcupine, with shrill interrogation-points--so that, secretly, while they went, she (Assingham) had wondered again if the equilibrium mightn't have been more real, mightn't above all have demanded less strange a study, had it only been on the books that Charlotte should give him (companion) a Principino of his (companion) own. She (Charlotte) had repossessed herself now of his (companion) other arm, only this time she (Charlotte) was drawing him (companion) back, gently, helplessly back, to what they had tried, for the hour, to get away from--just as he (companion) was consciously drawing the child, and as high Miss Bogle on her (Bogle) left, representing the duties of home, was complacently drawing HER. The duties of home, when the house in Portland Place reappeared, showed, even from a distance, as vividly there before them. Amerigo and Charlotte had come in--that is Amerigo had, Charlotte, rather, having come out--and the pair were perched together in the balcony, he (companion) bare-headed, she (Charlotte) divested of her (Charlotte) jacket, her (Charlotte) mantle, or whatever, but crowned with a brilliant brave hat, responsive to the balmy day, which Maggie immediately
``spotted'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
as new, as insuperably original, as worn, in characteristic generous harmony, for the first time; all, evidently, to watch for the return of the absent, to be there to take them over again as punctually as possible. They were gay, they were amused, in the pleasant morning; they leaned across the rail and called down their greeting, lighting up the front of the great black house with an expression that quite broke the monotony, that might almost have shocked the decency, of Portland Place. The group on the pavement stared up as at the peopled battlements of a castle; even Miss Bogle, who carried her (Bogle) head most aloft, gaped a little, through the interval of space, as toward truly superior beings. There could scarce have been so much of the open mouth since the dingy waits, on Christmas Eve, had so lamentably chanted for pennies--the time when Amerigo, insatiable for English customs, had come out, with a gasped
``Santissima Vergine!'' (Amerigo)
to marvel at the depositaries of this tradition and purchase a reprieve. Maggie's individual gape was inevitably again for the thought of how the pair would be at work.

XXX

She (Maggie) had not again, for weeks, had Mrs. Assingham so effectually in presence as on the afternoon of that lady's return from the Easter party at Matcham; but the intermission was made up as soon as the date of the migration to Fawns--that of the more or less simultaneous adjournment of the two houses--began to be discussed. It had struck her (lady), promptly, that this renewal, with an old friend, of the old terms she (lady) had talked of with her (lady) father, was the one opening, for her (lady) spirit, that wouldn't too much advertise or betray her (lady). Even her (lady) father, who had always, as he (father) would have said,

``believed in'' (he)
their ancient ally, wouldn't necessarily suspect her (lady) of invoking Fanny's aid toward any special inquiry--and least of all if Fanny would only act as Fanny so easily might. Maggie's measure of Fanny's ease would have been agitating to Mrs. Assingham had it been all at once revealed to her (Assingham)--as, for that matter, it was soon destined to become even on a comparatively graduated showing. Our young woman's idea, in particular, was that her (woman) safety, her (woman) escape from being herself suspected of suspicion, would proceed from this friend's power to cover, to protect and, as might be, even showily to represent her (woman)--represent, that is, her (woman) relation to the form of the life they were all actually leading. This would doubtless be, as people said, a large order; but that Mrs. Assingham existed, substantially, or could somehow be made prevailingly to exist, for her (Assingham) private benefit, was the finest flower Maggie had plucked from among the suggestions sown, like abundant seed, on the occasion of the entertainment offered in Portland Place to the Matcham company. Mrs. Assingham, that night, rebounding from dejection, had bristled with bravery and sympathy; she (Assingham) had then absolutely, she (Assingham) had perhaps recklessly, for herself, betrayed the deeper and darker consciousness--an impression it would now be late for her (Assingham) inconsistently to attempt to undo. It was with a wonderful air of giving out all these truths that the Princess at present approached her (Princess) again; making doubtless at first a sufficient scruple of letting her (Princess) know what in especial she (Princess) asked of her (Princess), yet not a bit ashamed, as she (Princess) in fact quite expressly declared, of Fanny's discerned foreboding of the strange uses she (Fanny) might perhaps have for her (Fanny). Quite from the first, really, Maggie said extraordinary things to her (Maggie), such as
``You can help me, you know, my dear, when nobody else can;'' (her)
such as
``I almost wish, upon my word, that you had something the matter with you, that you had lost your health, or your money, or your reputation -LRB-forgive me, love!-RRB- so that I might be with you as much as I want, or keep you with ME, without exciting comment, without exciting any other remark than that such kindnesses are `like' me.'' (her)
We have each our own way of making up for our unselfishness, and Maggie, who had no small self at all as against her (Maggie) husband or her (Maggie) father and only a weak and uncertain one as against her (Maggie) stepmother, would verily, at this crisis, have seen Mrs. Assingham's personal life or liberty sacrificed without a pang.

The attitude that the appetite in question maintained in her (Assingham) was to draw peculiar support moreover from the current aspects and agitations of her (Assingham) victim. This personage struck her (Assingham), in truth, as ready for almost anything; as not perhaps effusively protesting, yet as wanting with a restlessness of her (Assingham) own to know what she (Assingham) wanted. And in the long run--which was none so long either--there was to be no difficulty, as happened, about that.
