It was as if, for all the world, Maggie had let her (Maggie) see that she (Maggie) held her (Maggie), that she (Maggie) made her (Maggie), fairly responsible for something; not, to begin with, dotting all the i's nor hooking together all the links, but treating her (Maggie), without insistence, rather with caressing confidence, as there to see and to know, to advise and to assist. The theory, visibly, had patched itself together for her (Maggie) that the dear woman had somehow, from the early time, had a hand in ALL their fortunes, so that there was no turn of their common relations and affairs that couldn't be traced back in some degree to her (Maggie) original affectionate interest. On this affectionate interest the good lady's young friend now built, before her (friend) eyes--very much as a wise, or even as a mischievous, child, playing on the floor, might pile up blocks, skilfully and dizzily, with an eye on the face of a covertly-watching elder.

When the blocks tumbled down they but acted after the nature of blocks; yet the hour would come for their rising so high that the structure would have to be noticed and admired. Mrs. Assingham's appearance of unreservedly giving herself involved meanwhile, on her (Assingham) own side, no separate recognitions: her (Assingham) face of almost anxious attention was directed altogether to her (Assingham) young friend's so vivid felicity; it suggested that she (Assingham) took for granted, at the most, certain vague recent enhancements of that state. If the Princess now, more than before, was going and going, she (Princess) was prompt to publish that she (Princess) beheld her (Princess) go, that she (Princess) had always known she (Princess) WOULD, sooner or later, and that any appeal for participation must more or less contain and invite the note of triumph. There was a blankness in her (Princess) blandness, assuredly, and very nearly an extravagance in her (Princess) generalising gaiety; a precipitation of cheer particularly marked whenever they met again after short separations: meetings during the first flush of which Maggie sometimes felt reminded of other looks in other faces; of two strangely unobliterated impressions above all, the physiognomic light that had played out in her (Maggie) husband at the shock--she (Maggie) had come at last to talk to herself of the

``shock'' (she)
--of his (husband) first vision of her (Maggie) on his (husband) return from Matcham and Gloucester, and the wonder of Charlotte's beautiful bold wavering gaze when, the next morning in Eaton Square, this old friend had turned from the window to begin to deal with her (Charlotte).

If she (Charlotte) had dared to think of it so crudely she (Charlotte) would have said that Fanny was afraid of her (Fanny), afraid of something she (Fanny) might say or do, even as, for their few brief seconds, Amerigo and Charlotte had been--which made, exactly, an expressive element common to the three. The difference however was that this look had in the dear woman its oddity of a constant renewal, whereas it had never for the least little instant again peeped out of the others. Other looks, other lights, radiant and steady, with the others, had taken its place, reaching a climax so short a time ago, that morning of the appearance of the pair on the balcony of her (woman) house to overlook what she (woman) had been doing with her (woman) father; when their general interested brightness and beauty, attuned to the outbreak of summer, had seemed to shed down warmth and welcome and the promise of protection. They were conjoined not to do anything to startle her (woman)--and now at last so completely that, with experience and practice, they had almost ceased to fear their liability. Mrs. Assingham, on the other hand, deprecating such an accident not less, had yet less assurance, as having less control. The high pitch of her (Assingham) cheer, accordingly, the tentative, adventurous expressions, of the would-be smiling order, that preceded her (Assingham) approach even like a squad of skirmishers, or whatever they were called, moving ahead of the baggage train--these things had at the end of a fortnight brought a dozen times to our young woman's lips a challenge that had the cunning to await its right occasion, but of the relief of which, as a demonstration, she (woman) meanwhile felt no little need.

``You've such a dread of my possibly complaining to you that you keep pealing all the bells to drown my voice; but don't cry out, my dear, till you're hurt--and above all ask yourself how I can be so wicked as to complain. What in the name of all that's fantastic can you dream that I have to complain OF?'' (the Princess)
Such inquiries the Princess temporarily succeeded in repressing, and she (Princess) did so, in a measure, by the aid of her (Princess) wondering if this ambiguity with which her (Princess) friend affected her (Princess) wouldn't be at present a good deal like the ambiguity with which she (Princess) herself must frequently affect her (Princess) father. She (Princess) wondered how she (Princess) should enjoy, on HIS (father) part, such a take-up as she (Princess) but just succeeded, from day to day, in sparing Mrs. Assingham, and that made for her (Assingham) trying to be as easy with this associate as Mr. Verver, blessed man, all indulgent but all inscrutable, was with his (Verver) daughter. She (daughter) had extracted from her (daughter), none the less, a vow in respect to the time that, if the Colonel might be depended on, they would spend at Fawns; and nothing came home to her (daughter) more, in this connection, or inspired her (daughter) with a more intimate interest, than her (daughter) sense of absolutely seeing her (daughter) interlocutress forbear to observe that Charlotte's view of a long visit, even from such allies, was there to be reckoned with.

Fanny stood off from that proposition as visibly to the Princess, and as consciously to herself, as she (Princess) might have backed away from the edge of a chasm into which she (Princess) feared to slip; a truth that contributed again to keep before our young woman her (woman) own constant danger of advertising her (woman) subtle processes. That Charlotte should have begun to be restrictive about the Assinghams--which she (Charlotte) had never, and for a hundred obviously good reasons, been before--this in itself was a fact of the highest value for Maggie, and of a value enhanced by the silence in which Fanny herself so much too unmistakably dressed it. What gave it quite thrillingly its price was exactly the circumstance that it thus opposed her (Fanny) to her (Fanny) stepmother more actively--if she (Fanny) was to back up her (Fanny) friends for holding out--than she (Fanny) had ever yet been opposed; though of course with the involved result of the fine chance given Mrs. Verver to ask her (Verver) husband for explanations. Ah, from the moment she (Verver) should be definitely CAUGHT in opposition there would be naturally no saying how much Charlotte's opportunities might multiply! What would become of her (Charlotte) father, she (Charlotte) hauntedly asked, if his (father) wife, on the one side, should begin to press him (father) to call his (father) daughter to order, and the force of old habit--to put it only at that--should dispose him (father), not less effectively, to believe in this young person at any price? There she (daughter) was, all round, imprisoned in the circle of the reasons it was impossible she (daughter) should give--certainly give HIM. The house in the country was his (father) house, and thereby was Charlotte's; it was her (Charlotte) own and Amerigo's only so far as its proper master and mistress should profusely place it at their disposal. Maggie felt of course that she (Maggie) saw no limit to her (Maggie) father's profusion, but this couldn't be even at the best the case with Charlotte's, whom it would never be decent, when all was said, to reduce to fighting for her (Charlotte) preferences. There were hours, truly, when the Princess saw herself as not unarmed for battle if battle might only take place without spectators.

This last advantage for her (Princess), was, however, too sadly out of the question; her (Princess) sole strength lay in her (Princess) being able to see that if Charlotte wouldn't

``want'' (Charlotte)
the Assinghams it would be because that sentiment too would have motives and grounds. She (Charlotte) had all the while command of one way of meeting any objection, any complaint, on his (Charlotte) wife's part, reported to her (wife) by her (wife) father; it would be open to her (wife) to retort to his (Charlotte) possible
``What are your reasons, my dear?'' (father)
by a lucidly-produced
``What are hers, love, please?--isn't that what we had better know? Mayn't her (yourself) reasons be a dislike, beautifully founded, of the presence, and thereby of the observation, of persons who perhaps know about her (yourself) things it's inconvenient to her (yourself) they should know?'' (she)
That hideous card she (wife) might in mere logic play--being by this time, at her (wife) still swifter private pace, intimately familiar with all the fingered pasteboard in her (wife) pack. But she (wife) could play it only on the forbidden issue of sacrificing him (Charlotte); the issue so forbidden that it involved even a horror of finding out if he (Charlotte) would really have consented to be sacrificed. What she (wife) must do she (wife) must do by keeping her (wife) hands off him (Charlotte); and nothing meanwhile, as we see, had less in common with that scruple than such a merciless manipulation of their yielding beneficiaries as her (wife) spirit so boldly revelled in. She (wife) saw herself, in this connexion, without detachment--saw others alone with intensity; otherwise she (wife) might have been struck, fairly have been amused, by her (wife) free assignment of the pachydermatous quality. If SHE could face the awkwardness of the persistence of her (wife) friends at Fawns in spite of Charlotte, she (Charlotte) somehow looked to them for an inspiration of courage that would improve upon her (Charlotte) own. They were in short not only themselves to find a plausibility and an audacity, but were somehow by the way to pick up these forms for her (Charlotte), Maggie, as well. And she (Maggie) felt indeed that she (Maggie) was giving them scant time longer when, one afternoon in Portland Place, she (Maggie) broke out with an irrelevance that was merely superficial.

``What awfulness, in heaven's name, is there between them? What do you believe, what do you KNOW?'' (she)

Oh, if she (Maggie) went by faces her (Maggie) visitor's sudden whiteness, at this, might have carried her (Maggie) far! Fanny Assingham turned pale for it, but there was something in such an appearance, in the look it put into the eyes, that renewed Maggie's conviction of what this companion had been expecting. She (Maggie) had been watching it come, come from afar, and now that it was there, after all, and the first convulsion over, they would doubtless soon find themselves in a more real relation. It was there because of the Sunday luncheon they had partaken of alone together; it was there, as strangely as one would, because of the bad weather, the cold perverse June rain, that was making the day wrong; it was there because it stood for the whole sum of the perplexities and duplicities among which our young woman felt herself lately to have picked her (woman) steps; it was there because Amerigo and Charlotte were again paying together alone a

``week end'' (Charlotte)
visit which it had been Maggie's plan infernally to promote--just to see if, this time, they really would; it was there because she (Maggie) had kept Fanny, on her (Maggie) side, from paying one she (Maggie) would manifestly have been glad to pay, and had made her (Maggie) come instead, stupidly, vacantly, boringly, to luncheon: all in the spirit of celebrating the fact that the Prince and Mrs. Verver had thus put it into her (Verver) own power to describe them exactly as they were. It had abruptly occurred, in truth, that Maggie required the preliminary help of determining HOW they were; though, on the other hand, before her (Maggie) guest had answered her (Maggie) question everything in the hour and the place, everything in all the conditions, affected her (Maggie) as crying it out. Her (Maggie) guest's stare of ignorance, above all--that of itself at first cried it out. ```Between them?' What do you mean?''

``Anything there shouldn't be, there shouldn't have BEEN--all this time. Do you believe there is--or what's your idea?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny's idea was clearly, to begin with, that her (Fanny) young friend had taken her (Fanny) breath away; but she (Fanny) looked at her (Fanny) very straight and very hard.

``Do you speak from a suspicion of your own?'' (unknown)

``I speak, at last, from a torment. Forgive me if it comes out. I've been thinking for months and months, and I've no one to turn to, no one to help me to make things out; no impression but my own, don't you see? to go by.'' (unknown)

``You've been thinking for months and months?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham took it in.
``But WHAT then, dear Maggie, have you been thinking?'' (unknown)

``Well, horrible things--like a little beast that I perhaps am. That there may be something--something wrong and dreadful, something they cover up.'' (The woman)

The elder woman's colour had begun to come back; she (Assingham) was able, though with a visible effort, to face the question less amazedly.

``You imagine, poor child, that the wretches are in love? Is that it?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

But Maggie for a minute only stared back at her (Maggie).

``Help me to find out WHAT I imagine. I don't know--I've nothing but my perpetual anxiety. Have you any?--do you see what I mean? If you'll tell me truly, that at least, one way or the other, will do something for me.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny's look had taken a peculiar gravity--a fulness with which it seemed to shine.

``Is what it comes to that you're jealous of Charlotte?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean whether I hate her (Charlotte)?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
--and Maggie thought.
``No; not on account of father.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham returned,
``that isn't what one would suppose. What I ask is if you're jealous on account of your husband.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``Well,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie presently,
``perhaps that may be all. If I'm unhappy I'm jealous; it must come to the same thing; and with you, at least, I'm not afraid of the word. If I'm jealous, don't you see? I'm tormented,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) went on--
``and all the more if I'm helpless. And if I'm both helpless AND tormented I stuff my pocket-handkerchief into my mouth, I keep it there, for the most part, night and day, so as not to be heard too indecently moaning. Only now, with you, at last, I can't keep it longer; I've pulled it out, and here I am fairly screaming at you. They're away,'' (she)
she (Maggie) wound up,
``so they can't hear; and I'm, by a miracle of arrangement, not at luncheon with father at home. I live in the midst of miracles of arrangement, half of which I admit, are my own; I go about on tiptoe, I watch for every sound, I feel every breath, and yet I try all the while to seem as smooth as old satin dyed rose-colour. Have you ever thought of me,'' (she)
she (Maggie) asked,
``as really feeling as I do?'' (she)

Her (Maggie) companion, conspicuously, required to be clear.

``Jealous, unhappy, tormented--? No,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham;
``but at the same time--and though you may laugh at me for it!--I'm bound to confess that I've never been so awfully sure of what I may call knowing you. Here you are indeed, as you say--such a deep little person! I've never imagined your existence poisoned, and, since you wish to know if I consider that it need be, I've not the least difficulty in speaking on the spot. Nothing, decidedly, strikes me as more unnecessary.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

For a minute after this they remained face to face; Maggie had sprung up while her (Maggie) friend sat enthroned, and, after moving to and fro in her (Maggie) intensity, now paused to receive the light she (Maggie) had invoked. It had accumulated, considerably, by this time, round Mrs. Assingham's ample presence, and it made, even to our young woman's own sense, a medium in which she (woman) could at last take a deeper breath.

``I've affected you, these months--and these last weeks in especial--as quiet and natural and easy?'' (unknown)

But it was a question that took, not imperceptibly, some answering.

``You've never affected me, from the first hour I beheld you, as anything but--in a way all your own--absolutely good and sweet and beautiful. In a way, as I say,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham almost caressingly repeated,
``just all your very own--nobody else's at all. I've never thought of you but as OUTSIDE of ugly things, so ignorant of any falsity or cruelty or vulgarity as never to have to be touched by them or to touch them. I've never mixed you up with them; there would have been time enough for that if they had seemed to be near you. But they haven't--if that's what you want to know.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``You've only believed me contented then because you've believed me stupid?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham had a free smile, now, for the length of this stride, dissimulated though it might be in a graceful little frisk.

``If I had believed you stupid I shouldn't have thought you interesting, and if I hadn't thought you interesting I shouldn't have noted whether I `knew' you, as I've called it, or not. What I've always been conscious of is your having concealed about you somewhere no small amount of character; quite as much in fact,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny smiled,
``as one could suppose a person of your size able to carry. The only thing was,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
she (Fanny) explained,
``that thanks to your never calling one's attention to it, I hadn't made out much more about it, and should have been vague, above all, as to WHERE you carried it or kept it. Somewhere UNDER, I should simply have said--like that little silver cross you once showed me, blest by the Holy Father, that you always wear, out of sight, next your skin. That relic I've had a glimpse of'' (she)
--with which she (Fanny) continued to invoke the privilege of humour.
``But the precious little innermost, say this time little golden, personal nature of you--blest by a greater power, I think, even than the Pope--that you've never consentingly shown me. I'm not sure you've ever consentingly shown it to anyone. You've been in general too modest.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie, trying to follow, almost achieved a little fold of her (Maggie) forehead.

``I strike you as modest to-day--modest when I stand here and scream at you?'' (unknown)

``Oh, your screaming, I've granted you, is something new. I must fit it on somewhere. The question is, however,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham further proceeded,
``of what the deuce I can fit it on TO. Do you mean,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) asked,
``to the fact of our friends' being, from yesterday to to-morrow, at a place where they may more or less irresponsibly meet?'' (she)
She (Assingham) spoke with the air of putting it as badly for them as possible.
``Are you thinking of their being there alone--of their having consented to be?'' (she)
And then as she (Assingham) had waited without result for her (Assingham) companion to say:
``But isn't it true that--after you had this time again, at the eleventh hour, said YOU wouldn't--they would really much rather not have gone?'' (companion)

``Yes--they would certainly much rather not have gone. But I wanted them to go.'' (unknown)

``Then, my dear child, what in the world is the matter?'' (unknown)

``I wanted to see if they WOULD. And they've had to,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie added.
``It was the only thing.'' (friend)

Her (Maggie) friend appeared to wonder.

``From the moment you and your father backed out?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't mean go for those people; I mean go for us. For father and me,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on.
``Because now they know.'' (unknown)

``They `know'?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham quavered.

``That I've been for some time past taking more notice. Notice of the queer things in our life.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie saw her (Maggie) companion for an instant on the point of asking her (Maggie) what these queer things might be; but Mrs. Assingham had the next minute brushed by that ambiguous opening and taken, as she (Assingham) evidently felt, a better one.

``And is it for that you did it? I mean gave up the visit.'' (unknown)

``It's for that I did it. To leave them to themselves--as they less and less want, or at any rate less and less venture to appear to want, to be left. As they had for so long arranged things,'' (the Princess)
the Princess went on,
``you see they sometimes have to be.'' (the Princess)
And then, as if baffled by the lucidity of this, Mrs. Assingham for a little said nothing:
``Now do you think I'm modest?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

With time, however; Fanny could brilliantly think anything that would serve.

``I think you're wrong. That, my dear, is my answer to your question. It demands assuredly the straightest I can make. I see no `awfulness'--I suspect none. I'm deeply distressed,'' (she)
she (Fanny) added,
``that you should do anything else.'' (she)
It drew again from Maggie a long look.
``You've never even imagined anything?'' (unknown)

``Ah, God forbid!--for it's exactly as a woman of imagination that I speak. There's no moment of my life at which I'm not imagining something; and it's thanks to that, darling,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham pursued,
``that I figure the sincerity with which your husband, whom you see as viciously occupied with your stepmother, is interested, is tenderly interested, in his (husband) admirable, adorable wife.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
She (Assingham) paused a minute as to give her (Assingham) friend the full benefit of this--as to Maggie's measure of which, however, no sign came; and then, poor woman, haplessly, she (woman) crowned her (woman) effort.--
``He (husband) wouldn't hurt a hair of your head.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

It had produced in Maggie, at once, and apparently in the intended form of a smile, the most extraordinary expression.

``Ah, there it is!'' (guest)

But her (Maggie) guest had already gone on.

``And I'm absolutely certain that Charlotte wouldn't either.'' (the Princess)

It kept the Princess, with her (Princess) strange grimace, standing there.

``No--Charlotte wouldn't either. That's how they've had again to go off together. They've been afraid not to--lest it should disturb me, aggravate me, somehow work upon me. As I insisted that they must, that we couldn't all fail--though father and Charlotte hadn't really accepted; as I did this they had to yield to the fear that their showing as afraid to move together would count for them as the greater danger: which would be the danger, you see, of my feeling myself wronged. Their least danger, they know, is in going on with all the things that I've seemed to accept and that I've given no indication, at any moment, of not accepting. Everything that has come up for them has come up, in an extraordinary manner, without my having by a sound or a sign given myself away--so that it's all as wonderful as you may conceive. They move at any rate among the dangers I speak of--between that of their doing too much and that of their not having any longer the confidence, or the nerve, or whatever you may call it, to do enough.'' (unknown)
Her (Princess) tone, by this time, might have shown a strangeness to match her (Princess) smile; which was still more marked as she (Princess) wound up.
``And that's how I make them do what I like!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

It had an effect on Mrs. Assingham, who rose with the deliberation that, from point to point, marked the widening of her (Assingham) grasp.

``My dear child, you're amazing.'' (unknown)

``Amazing--?'' (unknown)

``You're terrible.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie thoughtfully shook her (Maggie) head.

``No; I'm not terrible, and you don't think me so. I do strike you as surprising, no doubt--but surprisingly mild. Because--don't you see?--I AM mild. I can bear anything.'' (unknown)

``Oh, `bear'!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham fluted.

``For love,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

Fanny hesitated.

``Of your father?'' (unknown)

``For love,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie repeated.

It kept her (Maggie) friend watching.

``Of your husband?'' (unknown)

``For love,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie said again.

It was, for the moment, as if the distinctness of this might have determined in her (Maggie) companion a choice between two or three highly different alternatives. Mrs. Assingham's rejoinder, at all events--however much or however little it was a choice--was presently a triumph.

``Speaking with this love of your own then, have you undertaken to convey to me that you believe your husband and your father's wife to be in act and in fact lovers of each other?'' (the Princess)
And then as the Princess didn't at first answer:
``Do you call such an allegation as that `mild'?'' (the Princess)

``Oh, I'm not pretending to be mild to you. But I've told you, and moreover you must have seen for yourself, how much so I've been to them.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham, more brightly again, bridled.

``Is that what you call it when you make them, for terror as you say, do as you like?'' (unknown)

``Ah, there wouldn't be any terror for them if they had nothing to hide.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham faced her (Assingham)--quite steady now.

``Are you really conscious, love, of what you're saying?'' (unknown)

``I'm saying that I'm bewildered and tormented, and that I've no one but you to speak to. I've thought, I've in fact been sure, that you've seen for yourself how much this is the case. It's why I've believed you would meet me half way.'' (unknown)

``Half way to what? To denouncing,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny asked,
``two persons, friends of years, whom I've always immensely admired and liked, and against whom I haven't the shadow of a charge to make?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Maggie looked at her (Maggie) with wide eyes.

``I had much rather you should denounce me than denounce them. Denounce me, denounce me,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said,
``if you can see your way.'' (she)
It was exactly what she (Maggie) appeared to have argued out with herself.
``If, conscientiously, you can denounce me; if, conscientiously, you can revile me; if, conscientiously, you can put me in my place for a low-minded little pig--!'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham, consideringly, as she (Assingham) paused for emphasis.

``I think I shall be saved.'' (friend)

Her (Assingham) friend took it, for a minute, however, by carrying thoughtful eyes, eyes verily portentous, over her (Assingham) head.

``You say you've no one to speak to, and you make a point of your having so disguised your feelings--not having, as you call it, given yourself away. Have you then never seen it not only as your right, but as your bounden duty, worked up to such a pitch, to speak to your husband?'' (unknown)

``I've spoken to him (husband),'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

Mrs. Assingham stared.

``Ah, then it isn't true that you've made no sign.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie had a silence.

``I've made no trouble. I've made no scene. I've taken no stand. I've neither reproached nor accused him (husband). You'll say there's a way in all that of being nasty enough.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Fanny)
dropped from Fanny as if she (Maggie) couldn't help it.

``But I don't think--strangely enough--that he (husband) regards me as nasty. I think that at bottom--for that IS,'' (the Princess strangeness)
said the Princess,
``the strangeness--he (husband)'s sorry for me. Yes, I think that, deep within, he (husband) pities me.'' (the Princess strangeness)

Her (Princess) companion wondered.

``For the state you've let yourself get into?'' (unknown)

``For not being happy when I've so much to make me so.'' (unknown)

``You've everything,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham with alacrity. Yet she (Assingham) remained for an instant embarrassed as to a further advance.
``I don't understand, however, how, if you've done nothing--'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

An impatience from Maggie had checked her (Maggie). ``I've not done absolutely `nothing.'''

``But what then--?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on after a minute,
``he (husband) knows what I've done.'' (she)

It produced on Mrs. Assingham's part, her (Assingham) whole tone and manner exquisitely aiding, a hush not less prolonged, and the very duration of which inevitably gave it something of the character of an equal recognition.

``And what then has HE (husband) done?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie took again a minute.

``He (husband) has been splendid.'' (unknown)

```Splendid'? Then what more do you want?''

``Ah, what you see!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.
``Not to be afraid.'' (guest)

It made her (Maggie) guest again hang fire.

``Not to be afraid really to speak?'' (unknown)

``Not to be afraid NOT to speak.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham considered further.

``You can't even to Charlotte?'' (her)
But as, at this, after a look at her (Assingham), Maggie turned off with a movement of suppressed despair, she (Maggie) checked herself and might have been watching her (Maggie), for all the difficulty and the pity of it, vaguely moving to the window and the view of the hill street. It was almost as if she (Maggie) had had to give up, from failure of responsive wit in her (Maggie) friend--the last failure she (Maggie) had feared--the hope of the particular relief she (Maggie) had been working for. Mrs. Assingham resumed the next instant, however, in the very tone that seemed most to promise her (Assingham) she (Assingham) should have to give up nothing.
``I see, I see; you would have in that case too many things to consider.'' (Princess)
It brought the Princess round again, proving itself thus the note of comprehension she (Princess) wished most to clutch at.
``Don't be afraid.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie took it where she (Maggie) stood--which she (Maggie) was soon able to signify.

``Thank-you.'' (counsellor)

It very properly encouraged her (Maggie) counsellor.

``What your idea imputes is a criminal intrigue carried on, from day to day, amid perfect trust and sympathy, not only under your eyes, but under your father's. That's an idea it's impossible for me for a. moment to entertain.'' (unknown)

``Ah, there you are then! It's exactly what I wanted from you.'' (unknown)

``You're welcome to it!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham breathed.

``You never HAVE entertained it?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie pursued.

``Never for an instant,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny with her (Fanny) head very high.

Maggie took it again, yet again as wanting more.

``Pardon my being so horrid. But by all you hold sacred?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham faced her (Assingham).

``Ah, my dear, upon my positive word as an honest woman.'' (unknown)

``Thank-you then,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

So they remained a little; after which,

``But do you believe it, love?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny inquired.

``I believe YOU.'' (unknown)

``Well, as I've faith in THEM, it comes to the same thing.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie, at this last, appeared for a moment to think again; but she (Maggie) embraced the proposition.

``The same thing.'' (unknown)

``Then you're no longer unhappy?'' (guest)
her (Maggie) guest urged, coming more gaily toward her (Maggie).

``I doubtless shan't be a great while.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

But it was now Mrs. Assingham's turn to want more.

``I've convinced you it's impossible?'' (She)

She (Assingham) had held out her (Assingham) arms, and Maggie, after a moment, meeting her (Maggie), threw herself into them with a sound that had its oddity as a sign of relief.

``Impossible, impossible,'' (she)
she (Maggie) emphatically, more than emphatically, replied; yet the next minute she (Maggie) had burst into tears over the impossibility, and a few seconds later, pressing, clinging, sobbing, had even caused them to flow, audibly, sympathetically and perversely, from her (Maggie) friend.

XXXI

The understanding appeared to have come to be that the Colonel and his (Colonel) wife were to present themselves toward the middle of July for the

``good long visit'' (wife)
at Fawns on which Maggie had obtained from her (Maggie) father that he (father) should genially insist; as well as that the couple from Eaton Square should welcome there earlier in the month, and less than a week after their own arrival, the advent of the couple from Portland Place.
``Oh, we shall give you time to breathe!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny remarked, in reference to the general prospect, with a gaiety that announced itself as heedless of criticism, to each member of the party in turn; sustaining and bracing herself by her (Fanny) emphasis, pushed even to an amiable cynicism, of the confident view of these punctualities of the Assinghams. The ground she (Fanny) could best occupy, to her (Fanny) sense, was that of her (Fanny) being moved, as in this connexion she (Fanny) had always been moved, by the admitted grossness of her (Fanny) avidity, the way the hospitality of the Ververs met her (Fanny) convenience and ministered to her (Fanny) ease, destitute as the Colonel had kept her (Fanny), from the first, of any rustic retreat, any leafy bower of her (Fanny) own, any fixed base for the stale season now at hand. She (Fanny) had explained at home, she (Fanny) had repeatedly reexplained, the terms of her (Fanny) dilemma, the real difficulty of her (Fanny), or--as she (Fanny) now put it--of their position. When the pair could do nothing else, in Cadogan Place, they could still talk of marvellous little Maggie, and of the charm, the sinister charm, of their having to hold their breath to watch her (Maggie); a topic the momentous midnight discussion at which we have been present was so far from having exhausted. It came up, irrepressibly, at all private hours; they had planted it there between them, and it grew, from day to day, in a manner to make their sense of responsibility almost yield to their sense of fascination. Mrs. Assingham declared at such moments that in the interest of this admirable young thing--to whom, she (Assingham) also declared, she (Assingham) had quite
``come over'' (she)
--she (Assingham) was ready to pass with all the world else, even with the Prince himself, the object, inconsequently, as well, of her (Assingham) continued, her (Assingham) explicitly shameless appreciation, for a vulgar, indelicate, pestilential woman, showing her (Assingham) true character in an abandoned old age. The Colonel's confessed attention had been enlisted, we have seen, as never yet, under pressure from his (Colonel) wife, by any guaranteed imbroglio; but this, she (wife) could assure him (Colonel) she (wife) perfectly knew, was not a bit because he (Colonel) was sorry for her (wife), or touched by what she (wife) had let herself in for, but because, when once they had been opened, he (Colonel) couldn't keep his (Colonel) eyes from resting complacently, resting almost intelligently, on the Princess. If he (Colonel) was in love with HER now, however, so much the better; it would help them both not to wince at what they would have to do for her (Princess). Mrs. Assingham had come back to that, whenever he (Colonel) groaned or grunted; she (Assingham) had at no beguiled moment--since Maggie's little march WAS positively beguiling--let him (Colonel) lose sight of the grim necessity awaiting them.
``We shall have, as I've again and again told you, to lie for her (I)--to lie till we're black in the face.'' (unknown)

``To lie `for' her (I)?'' (The Colonel)
The Colonel often, at these hours, as from a vague vision of old chivalry in a new form, wandered into apparent lapses from lucidity.

``To lie TO her (I), up and down, and in and out--it comes to the same thing. It will consist just as much of lying to the others too: to the Prince about one's belief in HIM; to Charlotte about one's belief in HER; to Mr. Verver, dear sweet man, about one's belief in everyone. So we've work cut out--with the biggest lie, on top of all, being that we LIKE to be there for such a purpose. We hate it unspeakably--I'm more ready to be a coward before it, to let the whole thing, to let everyone, selfishly and pusillanimously slide, than before any social duty, any felt human call, that has ever forced me to be decent. I speak at least for myself. For you,'' (she)
she (Maggie) had added,
``as I've given you so perfect an opportunity to fall in love with Maggie, you'll doubtless find your account in being so much nearer to her (Maggie).'' (she)

``And what do you make,'' (the Colonel)
the Colonel could, at this, always imperturbably enough ask,
``of the account you yourself will find in being so much nearer to the Prince; of your confirmed, if not exasperated, infatuation with whom--to say nothing of my weak good-nature about it--you give such a pretty picture?'' (the Colonel)

To the picture in question she (Maggie) had been always, in fact, able contemplatively to return.

``The difficulty of my enjoyment of that is, don't you see? that I'm making, in my loyalty to Maggie, a sad hash of his (Prince) affection for me.'' (unknown)

``You find means to call it then, this whitewashing of his (Prince) crime, being `loyal' to Maggie?'' (unknown)

``Oh, about that particular crime there is always much to say. It is always more interesting to us than any other crime; it has at least that for it. But of course I call everything I have in mind at all being loyal to Maggie. Being loyal to her (Maggie) is, more than anything else, helping her (Maggie) with her (Maggie) father--which is what she (Maggie) most wants and needs.'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel had had it before, but he (Colonel) could apparently never have too much of it.

``Helping her (Maggie) `with' him (father)--?'' (unknown)

``Helping her (Maggie) against him (father) then. Against what we've already so fully talked of--its having to be recognised between them that he (father) doubts. That's where my part is so plain--to see her (Maggie) through, to see her (Maggie) through to the end.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Exaltation, for the moment, always lighted Mrs. Assingham's reference to this plainness; yet she (Assingham) at the same time seldom failed, the next instant, to qualify her (Assingham) view of it.
``When I talk of my obligation as clear I mean that it's absolute; for just HOW, from day to day and through thick and thin, to keep the thing up is, I grant you, another matter. There's one way, luckily, nevertheless, in which I'm strong. I can perfectly count on her (Maggie).'' (The Colonel)

The Colonel seldom failed here, as from the insidious growth of an excitement, to wonder, to encourage.

``Not to see you're lying?'' (unknown)

``To stick to me fast, whatever she (Maggie) sees. If I stick to her (Maggie)--that is to my own poor struggling way, under providence, of watching over them ALL--she (Maggie)'ll stand by me to the death. She (Maggie) won't give me away. For, you know, she (Maggie) easily can.'' (unknown)

This, regularly, was the most lurid turn of their road; but Bob Assingham, with each journey, met it as for the first time.

``Easily?'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie) can utterly dishonour me with her (Maggie) father. She (Maggie) can let him (father) know that I was aware, at the time of his (father) marriage--as I had been aware at the time of her (Maggie) own--of the relations that had pre-existed between his (father) wife and her (Maggie) husband.'' (unknown)

``And how can she (Maggie) do so if, up to this minute, by your own statement, she (Maggie) is herself in ignorance of your knowledge?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

It was a question that Mrs. Assingham had ever, for dealing with, a manner to which repeated practice had given almost a grand effect; very much as if she (Assingham) was invited by it to say that about this, exactly, she (Assingham) proposed to do her (Assingham) best lying. But she (Assingham) said, and with full lucidity, something quite other: it could give itself a little the air, still, of a triumph over his (Assingham) coarseness.

``By acting, immediately with the blind resentment with which, in her (Maggie) place, ninety-nine women out of a hundred would act; and by so making Mr. Verver, in turn, act with the same natural passion, the passion of ninety-nine men out of a hundred. They've only to agree about me,'' (the lady)
the poor lady said;
``they've only to feel at one over it, feel bitterly practised upon, cheated and injured; they've only to denounce me to each other as false and infamous, for me to be quite irretrievably dished. Of course it's I who have been, and who continue to be, cheated--cheated by the Prince and Charlotte; but they're not obliged to give me the benefit of that, or to give either of us the benefit of anything. They'll be within their rights to lump us all together as a false, cruel, conspiring crew, and, if they can find the right facts to support them, get rid of us root and branch.'' (the lady)

This, on each occasion, put the matter so at the worst that repetition even scarce controlled the hot flush with which she (lady) was compelled to see the parts of the whole history, all its ugly consistency and its temporary gloss, hang together. She (lady) enjoyed, invariably, the sense of making her (lady) danger present, of making it real, to her (lady) husband, and of his (husband) almost turning pale, when their eyes met, at this possibility of their compromised state and their shared discredit. The beauty was that, as under a touch of one of the ivory notes at the left of the keyboard, he (husband) sounded out with the short sharpness of the dear fond stupid uneasy man.

``Conspiring--so far as YOU were concerned--to what end?'' (unknown)

``Why, to the obvious end of getting the Prince a wife--at Maggie's expense. And then to that of getting Charlotte a husband at Mr. Verver's.'' (unknown)

``Of rendering friendly services, yes--which have produced, as it turns out, complications. But from the moment you didn't do it FOR the complications, why shouldn't you have rendered them?'' (her)

It was extraordinary for her (lady), always, in this connexion, how, with time given him (husband), he (husband) fell to speaking better for her (lady) than she (lady) could, in the presence of her (lady) clear-cut image of the

``worst,'' (she)
speak for herself. Troubled as she (lady) was she (lady) thus never wholly failed of her (lady) amusement by the way.
``Oh, isn't what I may have meddled `for'--so far as it can be proved I did meddle--open to interpretation; by which I mean to Mr. Verver's and Maggie's? Mayn't they see my motive, in the light of that appreciation, as the wish to be decidedly more friendly to the others than to the victimised father and daughter?'' (She)
She (lady) positively liked to keep it up.
``Mayn't they see my motive as the determination to serve the Prince, in any case, and at any price, first; to `place' him (Prince) comfortably; in other words to find him (Prince) his (Prince) fill of money? Mayn't it have all the air for them of a really equivocal, sinister bargain between us--something quite unholy and louche?'' (the Colonel)

It produced in the poor Colonel, infallibly, the echo. ```Louche,' love--?''

``Why, haven't you said as much yourself?--haven't you put your finger on that awful possibility?'' (She)

She (lady) had a way now, with his (Colonel) felicities, that made him (Colonel) enjoy being reminded of them.

``In speaking of your having always had such a `mash'--?'' (unknown)

``Such a mash, precisely, for the man I was to help to put so splendidly at his (man) ease. A motherly mash an impartial look at it would show it only as likely to have been--but we're not talking, of course, about impartial looks. We're talking of good innocent people deeply worked upon by a horrid discovery, and going much further, in their view of the lurid, as such people almost always do, than those who have been wider awake, all round, from the first. What I was to have got from my friend, in such a view, in exchange for what I had been able to do for him (friend)--well, that would have been an equivalent, of a kind best known to myself, for me shrewdly to consider.'' (she)
And she (lady) easily lost herself, each time, in the anxious satisfaction of filling out the picture.
``It would have been seen, it would have been heard of, before, the case of the woman a man doesn't want, or of whom he (man)'s tired, or for whom he (man) has no use but SUCH uses, and who is capable, in her (woman) infatuation, in her (woman) passion, of promoting his (man) interests with other women rather than lose sight of him (man), lose touch of him (man), cease to have to do with him (man) at all. Cela s'est vu, my dear; and stranger things still--as I needn't tell YOU! Very good then,'' (she)
she (lady) wound up;
``there is a perfectly possible conception of the behaviour of your sweet wife; since, as I say, there's no imagination so lively, once it's started, as that of really agitated lambs. Lions are nothing to them, for lions are sophisticated, are blases, are brought up, from the first, to prowling and mauling. It does give us, you'll admit, something to think about. My relief is luckily, however, in what I finally do think.'' (she)

He (Colonel) was well enough aware, by this time, of what she (lady) finally did think; but he (Colonel) was not without a sense, again, also for his (Colonel) amusement by the way. It would have made him (Colonel), for a spectator of these passages between the pair, resemble not a little the artless child who hears his (Colonel) favourite story told for the twentieth time and enjoys it exactly because he (Colonel) knows what is next to happen.

``What of course will pull them up, if they turn out to have less imagination than you assume, is the profit you can have found in furthering Mrs. Verver's marriage. You weren't at least in love with Charlotte.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham, at this, always brought out,
``my hand in that is easily accounted for by my desire to be agreeable to HIM.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``To Mr. Verver?'' (unknown)

``To the Prince--by preventing her (Charlotte) in that way from taking, as he (Prince) was in danger of seeing her (Charlotte) do, some husband with whom he (Prince) wouldn't be able to open, to keep open, so large an account as with his (Prince) father-in-law. I've brought her (Charlotte) near him (Prince), kept her (Charlotte) within his (Prince) reach, as she (Charlotte) could never have remained either as a single woman or as the wife of a different man.'' (unknown)

``Kept her (wife), on that sweet construction, to be his (man) mistress?'' (unknown)

``Kept her (mistress), on that sweet construction, to be his (man) mistress.'' (She)
She (Assingham) brought it out grandly--it had always so, for her (Assingham) own ear as well as, visibly, for her (Assingham) husband's, its effect.
``The facilities in the case, thanks to the particular conditions, being so quite ideal.'' (unknown)

``Down even to the facility of your minding everything so little--from your own point of view--as to have supplied him (man) with the enjoyment of TWO beautiful women.'' (unknown)

``Down even to THAT--to the monstrosity of my folly. But not,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham added, ```two' of anything. One beautiful woman--and one beautiful fortune. That's what a creature of pure virtue exposes herself to when she (Assingham) suffers her (Assingham) pure virtue, suffers her (Assingham) sympathy, her (Assingham) disinterestedness, her (Assingham) exquisite sense for the lives of others, to carry her (Assingham) too far. Voila.''

``I see. It's the way the Ververs have you.'' (unknown)

``It's the way the Ververs `have' me. It's in other words the way they would be able to make such a show to each other of having me--if Maggie weren't so divine.'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie) lets you off?'' (He)
He (husband) never failed to insist on all this to the very end; which was how he (husband) had become so versed in what she (Assingham) finally thought.

``She (Maggie) lets me off. So that now, horrified and contrite at what I've done, I may work to help her (Maggie) out. And Mr. Verver,'' (she)
she (Assingham) was fond of adding,
``lets me off too.'' (she)

``Then you do believe he (Verver) knows?'' (unknown)

It determined in her (Assingham) always, there, with a significant pause, a deep immersion in her (Assingham) thought.

``I believe he (Verver) would let me off if he (Verver) did know--so that I might work to help HIM out. Or rather, really,'' (she)
she (Assingham) went on,
``that I might work to help Maggie. That would be his (Verver) motive, that would be his (Verver) condition, in forgiving me; just as hers, for me, in fact, her (Maggie) motive and her (Maggie) condition, are my acting to spare her (Maggie) father. But it's with Maggie only that I'm directly concerned; nothing, ever--not a breath, not a look, I'll guarantee--shall I have, whatever happens, from Mr. Verver himself. So it is, therefore, that I shall probably, by the closest possible shave, escape the penalty of my crimes.'' (she)

``You mean being held responsible.'' (unknown)

``I mean being held responsible. My advantage will be that Maggie's such a trump.'' (unknown)

``Such a trump that, as you say, she (Maggie)'ll stick to you.'' (unknown)

``Stick to me, on our understanding--stick to me. For our understanding's signed and sealed.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
And to brood over it again was ever, for Mrs. Assingham, to break out again with exaltation.
``It's a grand, high compact. She (Maggie) has solemnly promised.'' (unknown)

``But in words--?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, in words enough--since it's a matter of words. To keep up HER lie so long as I keep up mine.'' (unknown)

``And what do you call `her (Maggie)' lie?'' (unknown)

``Why, the pretence that she (Maggie) believes me. Believes they're innocent.'' (unknown)

``She (Maggie) positively believes then they're guilty? She (Maggie) has arrived at that, she (Maggie)'s really content with it, in the absence of proof?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
It was here, each time, that Fanny Assingham most faltered; but always at last to get the matter, for her (Assingham) own sense, and with a long sigh, sufficiently straight.
``It isn't a question of belief or of proof, absent or present; it's inevitably, with her (Maggie), a question of natural perception, of insurmountable feeling. She (Maggie) irresistibly knows that there's something between them. But she (Maggie) hasn't `arrived' at it, as you say, at all; that's exactly what she (Maggie) hasn't done, what she (Maggie) so steadily and intensely refuses to do. She (Maggie) stands off and off, so as not to arrive; she (Maggie) keeps out to sea and away from the rocks, and what she (Maggie) most wants of me is to keep at a safe distance with her (Maggie)--as I, for my own skin, only ask not to come nearer.'' (she)
After which, invariably, she (Assingham) let him (It) have it all.
``So far from wanting proof--which she (Maggie) must get, in a manner, by my siding with her (Maggie)--she (Maggie) wants DISproof, as against herself, and has appealed to me, so extraordinarily, to side against her (Maggie). It's really magnificent, when you come to think of it, the spirit of her (Maggie) appeal. If I'll but cover them up brazenly enough, the others, so as to show, round and about them, as happy as a bird, she (Maggie) on her (Maggie) side will do what she (Maggie) can. If I'll keep them quiet, in a word, it will enable her (Maggie) to gain time--time as against any idea of her (Maggie) father's--and so, somehow, come out. If I'll take care of Charlotte, in particular, she (Charlotte)'ll take care of the Prince; and it's beautiful and wonderful, really pathetic and exquisite, to see what she (Charlotte) feels that time may do for her (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``Ah, but what does she (Charlotte) call, poor little thing, `time'?'' (unknown)

``Well, this summer at Fawns, to begin with. She (Charlotte) can live as yet, of course, but from hand to mouth; but she (Charlotte) has worked it out for herself, I think, that the very danger of Fawns, superficially looked at, may practically amount to a greater protection. THERE the lovers--if they ARE lovers!--will have to mind. They'll feel it for themselves, unless things are too utterly far gone with them.'' (unknown)

``And things are NOT too utterly far gone with them?'' (She)

She (Assingham) had inevitably, poor woman, her (Assingham) hesitation for this, but she (Assingham) put down her (Assingham) answer as, for the purchase of some absolutely indispensable article, she (Assingham) would have put down her (Assingham) last shilling.

``No.'' (him)

It made him (It) always grin at her (Assingham).

``Is THAT a lie?'' (unknown)

``Do you think you're worth lying to? If it weren't the truth, for me,'' (she)
she (Assingham) added,
``I wouldn't have accepted for Fawns. I CAN, I believe, keep the wretches quiet.'' (she)

``But how--at the worst?'' (unknown)

``Oh, `the worst'--don't talk about the worst! I can keep them quiet at the best, I seem to feel, simply by our being there. It will work, from week to week, of itself. You'll see.'' (He)

He (It) was willing enough to see, but he (It) desired to provide--!

``Yet if it doesn't work?'' (unknown)

``Ah, that's talking about the worst!'' (unknown)

Well, it might be; but what were they doing, from morning to night, at this crisis, but talk?

``Who'll keep the others?'' (unknown)

``The others--?'' (unknown)

``Who'll keep THEM quiet? If your couple have had a life together, they can't have had it completely without witnesses, without the help of persons, however few, who must have some knowledge, some idea about them. They've had to meet, secretly, protectedly, they've had to arrange; for if they haven't met, and haven't arranged, and haven't thereby, in some quarter or other, had to give themselves away, why are we piling it up so? Therefore if there's evidence, up and down London--'' (unknown)

``There must be people in possession of it? Ah, it isn't all,'' (she)
she (Assingham) always remembered,
``up and down London. Some of it must connect them--I mean,'' (she)
she (Assingham) musingly added,
``it naturally WOULD--with other places; with who knows what strange adventures, opportunities, dissimulations? But whatever there may have been, it will also all have been buried on the spot. Oh, they've known HOW--too beautifully! But nothing, all the same, is likely to find its way to Maggie of itself.'' (she)

``Because every one who may have anything to tell, you hold, will have been so squared?'' (she)
And then inveterately, before she (Assingham) could say--he (It) enjoyed so much coming to this:
``What will have squared Lady Castledean?'' (he)

``The consciousness'' (she)
--she (Assingham) had never lost her (Assingham) promptness--
``of having no stones to throw at any one else's windows. She (Lady) has enough to do to guard her (Lady) own glass. That was what she (Lady) was doing,'' (she)
Fanny said,
``that last morning at Matcham when all of us went off and she (Lady) kept the Prince and Charlotte over. She (Lady) helped them simply that she (Lady) might herself be helped--if it wasn't perhaps, rather, with her (Lady) ridiculous Mr. Blint, that HE (Blint) might be. They put in together, therefore, of course, that day; they got it clear--and quite under her (Lady) eyes; inasmuch as they didn't become traceable again, as we know, till late in the evening.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
On this historic circumstance Mrs. Assingham was always ready afresh to brood; but she (Assingham) was no less ready, after her (Assingham) brooding, devoutly to add
``Only we know nothing whatever else--for which all our stars be thanked!'' (she)

The Colonel's gratitude was apt to be less marked.

``What did they do for themselves, all the same, from the moment they got that free hand to the moment -LRB-long after dinner-time, haven't you told me?-RRB- of their turning up at their respective homes?'' (unknown)

``Well, it's none of your business!'' (unknown)

``I don't speak of it as mine, but it's only too much theirs. People are always traceable, in England, when tracings are required. Something, sooner or later, happens; somebody, sooner or later, breaks the holy calm. Murder will out.'' (unknown)

``Murder will--but this isn't murder. Quite the contrary perhaps! I verily believe,'' (she)
she (Assingham) had her (Assingham) moments of adding,
``that, for the amusement of the row, you would prefer an explosion.'' (she)

This, however, was a remark he (Colonel) seldom noticed; he (Colonel) wound up, for the most part, after a long, contemplative smoke, with a transition from which no exposed futility in it had succeeded in weaning him (Colonel).

``What I can't for my life make out is your idea of the old boy.'' (unknown)

``Charlotte's too inconceivably funny husband? I HAVE no idea.'' (unknown)

``I beg your pardon--you've just shown it. You never speak of him (husband) but as too inconceivably funny.'' (unknown)

``Well, he (husband) is,'' (she)
she (Assingham) always confessed.
``That is he (husband) may be, for all I know, too inconceivably great. But that's not an idea. It represents only my weak necessity of feeling that he (husband)'s beyond me--which isn't an idea either. You see he (husband) MAY be stupid too.'' (unknown)

``Precisely--there you are.'' (unknown)

``Yet on the other hand,'' (she)
she (Assingham) always went on,
``he (husband) MAY be sublime: sublimer even than Maggie herself. He (husband) may in fact have already been. But we shall never know.'' (she)
With which her (Assingham) tone betrayed perhaps a shade of soreness for the single exemption she (Assingham) didn't yearningly welcome.
``THAT I can see.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I say--!'' (the Colonel)
It came to affect the Colonel himself with a sense of privation.

``I'm not sure, even, that Charlotte will.'' (unknown)

``Oh, my dear, what Charlotte doesn't know--!'' (she)

But she (Assingham) brooded and brooded.

``I'm not sure even that the Prince will.'' (unknown)
It seemed privation, in short, for them all.
``They'll be mystified, confounded, tormented. But they won't know--and all their possible putting their heads together won't make them. That,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham,
``will be their punishment.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
And she (Assingham) ended, ever, when she (Assingham) had come so far, at the same pitch.
``It will probably also--if I get off with so little--be mine.'' (unknown)

``And what,'' (husband)
her (Assingham) husband liked to ask,
``will be mine?'' (husband)

``Nothing--you're not worthy of any. One's punishment is in what one feels, and what will make ours effective is that we SHALL feel.'' (She)
She (Assingham) was splendid with her (Assingham)
``ours'' (She)
; she (Assingham) flared up with this prophecy.
``It will be Maggie herself who will mete it out.'' (unknown)

``Maggie--?'' (unknown)

``SHE'LL know--about her (Maggie) father; everything. Everything,'' (she)
she (Assingham) repeated. On the vision of which, each time, Mrs. Assingham, as with the presentiment of an odd despair, turned away from it.
``But she (Maggie)'ll never tell us.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

XXXII

If Maggie had not so firmly made up her (Maggie) mind never to say, either to her (Maggie) good friend or to any one else, more than she (Maggie) meant about her (Maggie) father, she (Maggie) might have found herself betrayed into some such overflow during the week spent in London with her (Maggie) husband after the others had adjourned to Fawns for the summer. This was because of the odd element of the unnatural imparted to the so simple fact of their brief separation by the assumptions resident in their course of life hitherto. She (Maggie) was used, herself, certainly, by this time, to dealing with odd elements; but she (Maggie) dropped, instantly, even from such peace as she (Maggie) had patched up, when it was a question of feeling that her (Maggie) unpenetrated parent might be alone with them. She (Maggie) thought of him (resident) as alone with them when she (Maggie) thought of him (resident) as alone with Charlotte--and this, strangely enough, even while fixing her (Charlotte) sense to the full on his (resident) wife's power of preserving, quite of enhancing, every felicitous appearance. Charlotte had done that--under immeasurably fewer difficulties indeed--during the numerous months of their hymeneal absence from England, the period prior to that wonderful reunion of the couples, in the interest of the larger play of all the virtues of each, which was now bearing, for Mrs. Verver's stepdaughter at least, such remarkable fruit. It was the present so much briefer interval, in a situation, possibly in a relation, so changed--it was the new terms of her (Verver) problem that would tax Charlotte's art. The Princess could pull herself up, repeatedly, by remembering that the real

``relation'' (The Princess)
between her (Princess) father and his (father) wife was a thing that she (Princess) knew nothing about and that, in strictness, was none of her (Princess) business; but she (Princess) none the less failed to keep quiet, as she (Princess) would have called it, before the projected image of their ostensibly happy isolation. Nothing could have had less of the quality of quietude than a certain queer wish that fitfully flickered up in her (Princess), a wish that usurped, perversely, the place of a much more natural one. If Charlotte, while she (Charlotte) was about it, could only have been WORSE!--that idea Maggie fell to invoking instead of the idea that she (Maggie) might desirably have been better. For, exceedingly odd as it was to feel in such ways, she (Maggie) believed she (Maggie) mightn't have worried so much if she (Maggie) didn't somehow make her (Maggie) stepmother out, under the beautiful trees and among the dear old gardens, as lavish of fifty kinds of confidence and twenty kinds, at least, of gentleness. Gentleness and confidence were certainly the right thing, as from a charming woman to her (woman) husband, but the fine tissue of reassurance woven by this lady's hands and flung over her (woman) companion as a light, muffling veil, formed precisely a wrought transparency through which she (woman) felt her (woman) father's eyes continually rest on herself. The reach of his (father) gaze came to her (woman) straighter from a distance; it showed him (father) as still more conscious, down there alone, of the suspected, the felt elaboration of the process of their not alarming or hurting him (father). She (woman) had herself now, for weeks and weeks, and all unwinkingly, traced the extension of this pious effort; but her (woman) perfect success in giving no sign--she (woman) did herself THAT credit--would have been an achievement quite wasted if Mrs. Verver should make with him (father) those mistakes of proportion, one set of them too abruptly, too incoherently designed to correct another set, that she (Verver) had made with his (father) daughter. However, if she (Verver) HAD been worse, poor woman, who should say that her (Verver) husband would, to a certainty, have been better?

One groped noiselessly among such questions, and it was actually not even definite for the Princess that her (Princess) own Amerigo, left alone with her (Princess) in town, had arrived at the golden mean of non-precautionary gallantry which would tend, by his (husband) calculation, to brush private criticism from its last perching-place. The truth was, in this connection, that she (Princess) had different sorts of terrors, and there were hours when it came to her (Princess) that these days were a prolonged repetition of that night-drive, of weeks before, from the other house to their own, when he (husband) had tried to charm her (Princess), by his (husband) sovereign personal power, into some collapse that would commit her (Princess) to a repudiation of consistency. She (Princess) was never alone with him (husband), it was to be said, without her (Princess) having sooner or later to ask herself what had already become of her (Princess) consistency; yet, at the same time, so long as she (Princess) breathed no charge, she (Princess) kept hold of a remnant of appearance that could save her (Princess) from attack. Attack, real attack, from him (husband), as he (husband) would conduct it was what she (Princess) above all dreaded; she (Princess) was so far from sure that under that experience she (Princess) mightn't drop into some depth of weakness, mightn't show him (husband) some shortest way with her (Princess) that he (husband) would know how to use again. Therefore, since she (Princess) had given him (husband), as yet, no moment's pretext for pretending to her (Princess) that she (Princess) had either lost faith or suffered by a feather's weight in happiness, she (Princess) left him (husband), it was easy to reason, with an immense advantage for all waiting and all tension. She (Princess) wished him (husband), for the present, to

``make up'' (him)
to her (Princess) for nothing. Who could say to what making-up might lead, into what consenting or pretending or destroying blindness it might plunge her (Princess)? She (Princess) loved him (husband) too helplessly, still, to dare to open the door, by an inch, to his (husband) treating her (Princess) as if either of them had wronged the other. Something or somebody--and who, at this, which of them all?--would inevitably, would in the gust of momentary selfishness, be sacrificed to that; whereas what she (Princess) intelligently needed was to know where she (Princess) was going. Knowledge, knowledge, was a fascination as well as a fear; and a part, precisely, of the strangeness of this juncture was the way her (Princess) apprehension that he (husband) would break out to her (Princess) with some merely general profession was mixed with her (Princess) dire need to forgive him (husband), to reassure him (husband), to respond to him (husband), on no ground that she (Princess) didn't fully measure. To do these things it must be clear to her (Princess) what they were FOR; but to act in that light was, by the same effect, to learn, horribly, what the other things had been. He (husband) might tell her (Princess) only what he (husband) wanted, only what would work upon her (Princess) by the beauty of his (husband) appeal; and the result of the direct appeal of ANY beauty in him (husband) would be her (Princess) helpless submission to his (husband) terms. All her (Princess) temporary safety, her (Princess) hand-to-mouth success, accordingly, was in his (husband) neither perceiving nor divining this, thanks to such means as she (Princess) could take to prevent him (husband); take, literally from hour to hour, during these days of more unbroken exposure. From hour to hour she (Princess) fairly expected some sign of his (husband) having decided on a jump.
``Ah yes, it HAS been as you think; I've strayed away, I've fancied myself free, given myself in other quantities, with larger generosities, because I thought you were different--different from what I now see. But it was only, only, because I didn't know--and you must admit that you gave me scarce reason enough. Reason enough, I mean, to keep clear of my mistake; to which I confess, for which I'll do exquisite penance, which you can help me now, I too beautifully feel, to get completely over.'' (she)

That was what, while she (Princess) watched herself, she (Princess) potentially heard him (husband) bring out; and while she (Princess) carried to an end another day, another sequence and yet another of their hours together, without his (husband) producing it, she (Princess) felt herself occupied with him (husband) beyond even the intensity of surrender. She (Princess) was keeping her (Princess) head, for a reason, for a cause; and the labour of this detachment, with the labour of her (Princess) keeping the pitch of it down, held them together in the steel hoop of an intimacy compared with which artless passion would have been but a beating of the air. Her (Princess) greatest danger, or at least her (Princess) greatest motive for care, was the obsession of the thought that, if he (husband) actually did suspect, the fruit of his (husband) attention to her (Princess) couldn't help being a sense of the growth of her (Princess) importance. Taking the measure, with him (husband), as she (Princess) had taken it with her (Princess) father, of the prescribed reach of her (Princess) hypocrisy, she (Princess) saw how it would have to stretch even to her (Princess) seeking to prove that she (Princess) was NOT, all the same, important. A single touch from him (father)--oh, she (Princess) should know it in case of its coming!--any brush of his (father) hand, of his (father) lips, of his (father) voice, inspired by recognition of her (Princess) probable interest as distinct from pity for her (Princess) virtual gloom, would hand her (Princess) over to him (father) bound hand and foot. Therefore to be free, to be free to act, other than abjectly, for her (Princess) father, she (Princess) must conceal from him (father) the validity that, like a microscopic insect pushing a grain of sand, she (Princess) was taking on even for herself. She (Princess) could keep it up with a change in sight, but she (Princess) couldn't keep it up forever; so that, really, one extraordinary effect of their week of untempered confrontation, which bristled with new marks, was to make her (Princess) reach out, in thought, to their customary companions and calculate the kind of relief that rejoining them would bring. She (Princess) was learning, almost from minute to minute, to be a mistress of shades since, always, when there were possibilities enough of intimacy, there were also, by that fact, in intercourse, possibilities of iridescence; but she (mistress) was working against an adversary who was a master of shades too, and on whom, if she (mistress) didn't look out, she (mistress) should presently have imposed a consciousness of the nature of their struggle. To feel him (master) in fact, to think of his (master) feeling himself, her (mistress) adversary in things of this fineness--to see him (master) at all, in short, brave a name that would represent him (master) as in opposition-- was already to be nearly reduced to a visible smothering of her (mistress) cry of alarm. Should he (master) guess they were having, in their so occult manner, a HIGH fight, and that it was she (mistress), all the while, in her (mistress) supposed stupidity, who had made it high and was keeping it high--in the event of his (master) doing this before they could leave town she (mistress) should verily be lost.

The possible respite for her (mistress) at Fawns would come from the fact that observation, in him (master), there, would inevitably find some of its directness diverted. This would be the case if only because the remarkable strain of her (mistress) father's placidity might be thought of as likely to claim some larger part of his (father) attention. Besides which there would be always Charlotte herself to draw him (father) off. Charlotte would help him (father) again, doubtless, to study anything, right or left, that might be symptomatic; but Maggie could see that this very fact might perhaps contribute, in its degree, to protect the secret of her (Maggie) own fermentation. It is not even incredible that she (Maggie) may have discovered the gleam of a comfort that was to broaden in the conceivable effect on the Prince's spirit, on his (Prince) nerves, on his (Prince) finer irritability, of some of the very airs and aspects, the light graces themselves, of Mrs. Verver's too perfect competence. What it would most come to, after all, she (Verver) said to herself, was a renewal for him (Prince) of the privilege of watching that lady watch her (lady). Very well, then: with the elements after all so mixed in him (Prince), how long would he (Prince) go on enjoying mere spectatorship of that act? For she (lady) had by this time made up her (lady) mind that in Charlotte's company he (Prince) deferred to Charlotte's easier art of mounting guard. Wouldn't he (Prince) get tired--to put it only at that--of seeing her (Charlotte) always on the rampart, erect and elegant, with her (Charlotte) lace-flounced parasol now folded and now shouldered, march to and fro against a gold-coloured east or west? Maggie had gone far, truly for a view of the question of this particular reaction, and she (Maggie) was not incapable of pulling herself up with the rebuke that she (Maggie) counted her (Maggie) chickens before they were hatched. How sure she (Maggie) should have to be of so many things before she (Maggie) might thus find a weariness in Amerigo's expression and a logic in his (Charlotte) weariness!

One of her (Maggie) dissimulated arts for meeting their tension, meanwhile, was to interweave Mrs. Assingham as plausibly as possible with the undulations of their surface, to bring it about that she (Assingham) should join them, of an afternoon, when they drove together or if they went to look at things--looking at things being almost as much a feature of their life as if they were bazaar-opening royalties. Then there were such combinations, later in the day, as her (Assingham) attendance on them, and the Colonel's as well, for such whimsical matters as visits to the opera no matter who was singing, and sudden outbreaks of curiosity about the British drama. The good couple from Cadogan Place could always unprotestingly dine with them and

``go on'' (The couple)
afterwards to such publicities as the Princess cultivated the boldness of now perversely preferring. It may be said of her (Princess) that, during these passages, she (Princess) plucked her (Princess) sensations by the way, detached, nervously, the small wild blossoms of her (Princess) dim forest, so that she (Princess) could smile over them at least with the spacious appearance, for her (Princess) companions, for her (Princess) husband above all, of bravely, of altogether frivolously, going a-maying. She (Princess) had her (Princess) intense, her (Princess) smothered excitements, some of which were almost inspirations; she (Princess) had in particular the extravagant, positively at moments the amused, sense of using her (Princess) friend to the topmost notch, accompanied with the high luxury of not having to explain. Never, no never, should she (Princess) have to explain to Fanny Assingham again--who, poor woman, on her (Assingham) own side, would be charged, it might be forever, with that privilege of the higher ingenuity. She (Assingham) put it all off on Fanny, and the dear thing herself might henceforth appraise the quantity. More and more magnificent now in her (Fanny) blameless egoism, Maggie asked no questions of her (Maggie), and thus only signified the greatness of the opportunity she (Maggie) gave her (Maggie). She (Maggie) didn't care for what devotions, what dinners of their own the Assinghams might have been
``booked'' (She)
; that was a detail, and she (Maggie) could think without wincing of the ruptures and rearrangements to which her (Maggie) service condemned them. It all fell in beautifully, moreover; so that, as hard, at this time, in spite of her (Maggie) fever, as a little pointed diamond, the Princess showed something of the glitter of consciously possessing the constructive, the creative hand. She (Princess) had but to have the fancy of presenting herself, of presenting her (Princess) husband, in a certain high and convenient manner, to make it natural they should go about with their gentleman and their lady. To what else but this, exactly, had Charlotte, during so many weeks of the earlier season, worked her (Charlotte) up?--herself assuming and discharging, so far as might be, the character and office of one of those revolving subordinate presences that float in the wake of greatness.

The precedent was therefore established and the group normally constituted. Mrs. Assingham, meanwhile, at table, on the stairs, in the carriage or the opera-box, might--with her (Assingham) constant overflow of expression, for that matter, and its singularly resident character where men in especial were concerned--look across at Amerigo in whatever sense she (Assingham) liked: it was not of that Maggie proposed to be afraid. She (Maggie) might warn him (character), she (Maggie) might rebuke him (character), she (Maggie) might reassure him (character), she (Maggie) might--if it were impossible not to--absolutely make love to him (character); even this was open to her (Maggie), as a matter simply between them, if it would help her (Maggie) to answer for the impeccability he (character) had guaranteed. And Maggie desired in fact only to strike her (Maggie) as acknowledging the efficacy of her (Maggie) aid when she (Maggie) mentioned to her (Maggie) one evening a small project for the morrow, privately entertained--the idea, irresistible, intense, of going to pay, at the Museum, a visit to Mr. Crichton. Mr. Crichton, as Mrs. Assingham could easily remember, was the most accomplished and obliging of public functionaries, whom every one knew and who knew every one--who had from the first, in particular, lent himself freely, and for the love of art and history, to becoming one of the steadier lights of Mr. Verver's adventurous path. The custodian of one of the richest departments of the great national collection of precious things, he (custodian) could feel for the sincere private collector and urge him (custodian) on his (custodian) way even when condemned to be present at his (custodian) capture of trophies sacrificed by the country to parliamentary thrift. He (custodian) carried his (custodian) amiability to the point of saying that, since London, under pettifogging views, had to miss, from time to time, its rarest opportunities, he (custodian) was almost consoled to see such lost causes invariably wander at last, one by one, with the tormenting tinkle of their silver bells, into the wondrous, the already famous fold beyond the Mississippi. There was a charm in his (custodian)

``almosts'' (Mr. Verver)
that was not to be resisted, especially after Mr. Verver and Maggie had grown sure--or almost, again--of enjoying the monopoly of them; and on this basis of envy changed to sympathy by the more familiar view of the father and the daughter, Mr. Crichton had at both houses, though especially in Eaton Square, learned to fill out the responsive and suggestive character.
