It was at his (character) invitation, Fanny well recalled, that Maggie, one day, long before, and under her (Maggie) own attendance precisely, had, for the glory of the name she (Maggie) bore, paid a visit to one of the ampler shrines of the supreme exhibitory temple, an alcove of shelves charged with the gold-and-brown, gold-and-ivory, of old Italian bindings and consecrated to the records of the Prince's race. It had been an impression that penetrated, that remained; yet Maggie had sighed, ever so prettily, at its having to be so superficial. She (Maggie) was to go back some day, to dive deeper, to linger and taste; in spite of which, however, Mrs. Assingham could not recollect perceiving that the visit had been repeated. This second occasion had given way, for a long time, in her (Assingham) happy life, to other occasions--all testifying, in their degree, to the quality of her (Assingham) husband's blood, its rich mixture and its many remarkable references; after which, no doubt, the charming piety involved had grown, on still further grounds, bewildered and faint.

It now appeared, none the less, that some renewed conversation with Mr. Crichton had breathed on the faintness revivingly, and Maggie mentioned her (Maggie) purpose as a conception of her (Maggie) very own, to the success of which she (Maggie) designed to devote her (Maggie) morning. Visits of gracious ladies, under his (Crichton) protection, lighted up rosily, for this perhaps most flower-loving and honey-sipping member of the great Bloomsbury hive, its packed passages and cells; and though not sworn of the province toward which his (Crichton) friend had found herself, according to her (Maggie) appeal to him (Crichton), yearning again, nothing was easier for him (Crichton) than to put her (Maggie) in relation with the presiding urbanities. So it had been settled, Maggie said to Mrs. Assingham, and she (Maggie) was to dispense with Amerigo's company. Fanny was to remember later on that she (Fanny) had at first taken this last fact for one of the finer notes of her (Fanny) young woman's detachment, imagined she (Fanny) must be going alone because of the shade of irony that, in these ambiguous days, her (Fanny) husband's personal presence might be felt to confer, practically, on any tribute to his (husband) transmitted significance. Then as, the next moment, she (Fanny) felt it clear that so much plotted freedom was virtually a refinement of reflection, an impulse to commemorate afresh whatever might still survive of pride and hope, her (Fanny) sense of ambiguity happily fell and she (Fanny) congratulated her (Fanny) companion on having anything so exquisite to do and on being so exquisitely in the humour to do it. After the occasion had come and gone she (Fanny) was confirmed in her (Fanny) optimism; she (Fanny) made out, in the evening, that the hour spent among the projected lights, the annals and illustrations, the parchments and portraits, the emblazoned volumes and the murmured commentary, had been for the Princess enlarging and inspiring. Maggie had said to her (Maggie) some days before, very sweetly but very firmly,

``Invite us to dine, please, for Friday, and have any one you like or you can--it doesn't in the least matter whom;'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
and the pair in Cadogan Place had bent to this mandate with a docility not in the least ruffled by all that it took for granted.

It provided for an evening--this had been Maggie's view; and she (Maggie) lived up to her (Maggie) view, in her (Maggie) friend's eyes, by treating the occasion, more or less explicitly, as new and strange. The good Assinghams had feasted in fact at the two other boards on a scale so disproportionate to the scant solicitations of their own that it was easy to make a joke of seeing how they fed at home, how they met, themselves, the question of giving to eat. Maggie dined with them, in short, and arrived at making her (Maggie) husband appear to dine, much in the manner of a pair of young sovereigns who have, in the frolic humour of the golden years of reigns, proposed themselves to a pair of faithfully-serving subjects. She (Maggie) showed an interest in their arrangements, an inquiring tenderness almost for their economies; so that her (Maggie) hostess not unnaturally, as they might have said, put it all down--the tone and the freedom of which she (Maggie) set the example--to the effect wrought in her (Maggie) afresh by one of the lessons learned, in the morning, at the altar of the past. Hadn't she (Maggie) picked it up, from an anecdote or two offered again to her (Maggie) attention, that there were, for princesses of such a line, more ways than one of being a heroine? Maggie's way to-night was to surprise them all, truly, by the extravagance of her (Maggie) affability. She (Maggie) was doubtless not positively boisterous; yet, though Mrs. Assingham, as a bland critic, had never doubted her (Assingham) being graceful, she (Assingham) had never seen her (Assingham) put so much of it into being what might have been called assertive. It was all a tune to which Fanny's heart could privately palpitate: her (Fanny) guest was happy, happy as a consequence of something that had occurred, but she (Fanny) was making the Prince not lose a ripple of her (Fanny) laugh, though not perhaps always enabling him (Prince) to find it absolutely not foolish. Foolish, in public, beyond a certain point, he (Prince) was scarce the man to brook his (Prince) wife's being thought to be; so that there hovered before their friend the possibility of some subsequent scene between them, in the carriage or at home, of slightly sarcastic inquiry, of promptly invited explanation; a scene that, according as Maggie should play her (Maggie) part in it, might or might not precipitate developments. What made these appearances practically thrilling, meanwhile, was this mystery--a mystery, it was clear, to Amerigo himself--of the incident or the influence that had so peculiarly determined them.

The lady of Cadogan Place was to read deeper, however, within three days, and the page was turned for her (lady) on the eve of her (lady) young confidant's leaving London. The awaited migration to Fawns was to take place on the morrow, and it was known meanwhile to Mrs. Assingham that their party of four were to dine that night, at the American Embassy, with another and a larger party; so that the elder woman had a sense of surprise on receiving from the younger, under date of six o’clock, a telegram requesting her (woman) immediate attendance.

``Please come to me at once; dress early, if necessary, so that we shall have time: the carriage, ordered for us, will take you back first.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham, on quick deliberation, dressed, though not perhaps with full lucidity, and by seven o’clock was in Portland Place, where her (Assingham) friend,
``upstairs'' (friend)
and described to her (Assingham) on her (Assingham) arrival as herself engaged in dressing, instantly received her (Assingham). She (Assingham) knew on the spot, poor Fanny, as she (Fanny) was afterwards to declare to the Colonel, that her (Fanny) feared crisis had popped up as at the touch of a spring, that her (Fanny) impossible hour was before her (Fanny). Her (Fanny) impossible hour was the hour of its coming out that she (Fanny) had known of old so much more than she (Fanny) had ever said; and she (Fanny) had often put it to herself, in apprehension, she (Fanny) tried to think even in preparation, that she (Fanny) should recognise the approach of her (Fanny) doom by a consciousness akin to that of the blowing open of a window on some night of the highest wind and the lowest thermometer. It would be all in vain to have crouched so long by the fire; the glass would have been smashed, the icy air would fill the place. If the air in Maggie's room then, on her (Maggie) going up, was not, as yet, quite the polar blast she (Maggie) had expected, it was distinctly, none the less, such an atmosphere as they had not hitherto breathed together. The Princess, she (Princess) perceived, was completely dressed--that business was over; it added indeed to the effect of her (Princess) importantly awaiting the assistance she (Princess) had summoned, of her (Princess) showing a deck cleared, so to speak, for action. Her (Princess) maid had already left her (Princess), and she (Princess) presented herself, in the large, clear room, where everything was admirable, but where nothing was out of place, as, for the first time in her (Princess) life rather
``bedizened.'' (she)
Was it that she (Princess) had put on too many things, overcharged herself with jewels, wore in particular more of them than usual, and bigger ones, in her (Princess) hair?--a question her (Princess) visitor presently answered by attributing this appearance largely to the bright red spot, red as some monstrous ruby, that burned in either of her (Princess) cheeks. These two items of her (Princess) aspect had, promptly enough, their own light for Mrs. Assingham, who made out by it that nothing more pathetic could be imagined than the refuge and disguise her (Assingham) agitation had instinctively asked of the arts of dress, multiplied to extravagance, almost to incoherence. She (Assingham) had had, visibly, her (Assingham) idea--that of not betraying herself by inattentions into which she (Assingham) had never yet fallen, and she (Assingham) stood there circled about and furnished forth, as always, in a manner that testified to her (Assingham) perfect little personal processes. It had ever been her (Assingham) sign that she (Assingham) was, for all occasions, FOUND ready, without loose ends or exposed accessories or unremoved superfluities; a suggestion of the swept and garnished, in her (Assingham) whole splendid, yet thereby more or less encumbered and embroidered setting, that reflected her (Assingham) small still passion for order and symmetry, for objects with their backs to the walls, and spoke even of some probable reference, in her (Assingham) American blood, to dusting and polishing New England grandmothers. If her (Assingham) apartment was
``princely,'' (she)
in the clearness of the lingering day, she (Assingham) looked as if she (Assingham) had been carried there prepared, all attired and decorated, like some holy image in a procession, and left, precisely, to show what wonder she (Assingham) could work under pressure. Her (Assingham) friend felt--how could she (Assingham) not?--as the truly pious priest might feel when confronted, behind the altar, before the festa, with his (priest) miraculous Madonna. Such an occasion would be grave, in general, with all the gravity of what he (priest) might look for. But the gravity to-night would be of the rarest; what he (priest) might look for would depend so on what he (priest) could give.

XXXIII

``Something very strange has happened, and I think you ought to know it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie spoke this indeed without extravagance, yet with the effect of making her (Maggie) guest measure anew the force of her (Maggie) appeal. It was their definite understanding: whatever Fanny knew Fanny's faith would provide for. And she (Fanny) knew, accordingly, at the end of five minutes, what the extraordinary, in the late occurrence, had consisted of, and how it had all come of Maggie's achieved hour, under Mr. Crichton's protection, at the Museum. He (Crichton) had desired, Mr. Crichton, with characteristic kindness, after the wonderful show, after offered luncheon at his (Crichton) incorporated lodge hard by, to see her (Maggie) safely home; especially on his (Crichton) noting, in attending her (Maggie) to the great steps, that she (Maggie) had dismissed her (Maggie) carriage; which she (Maggie) had done, really, just for the harmless amusement of taking her (Maggie) way alone. She (Maggie) had known she (Maggie) should find herself, as the consequence of such an hour, in a sort of exalted state, under the influence of which a walk through the London streets would be exactly what would suit her (Maggie) best; an independent ramble, impressed, excited, contented, with nothing to mind and nobody to talk to, and shop-windows in plenty to look at if she (Maggie) liked: a low taste, of the essence, it was to be supposed, of her (Maggie) nature, that she (Maggie) had of late, for so many reasons, been unable to gratify. She (Maggie) had taken her (Maggie) leave, with her (Maggie) thanks--she (Maggie) knew her (Maggie) way quite enough; it being also sufficiently the case that she (Maggie) had even a shy hope of not going too straight. To wander a little wild was what would truly amuse her (Maggie); so that, keeping clear of Oxford Street and cultivating an impression as of parts she (Maggie) didn't know, she (Maggie) had ended with what she (Maggie) had more or less had been fancying, an encounter with three or four shops--an old bookseller's, an old printmonger's, a couple of places with dim antiquities in the window--that were not as so many of the other shops, those in Sloane Street, say; a hollow parade which had long since ceased to beguile. There had remained with her (Maggie) moreover an allusion of Charlotte's, of some months before--seed dropped into her (Maggie) imagination in the form of a casual speech about there being in Bloomsbury such

``funny little fascinating'' (Charlotte)
places and even sometimes such unexpected finds. There could perhaps have been no stronger mark than this sense of well-nigh romantic opportunity--no livelier sign of the impression made on her (Maggie), and always so long retained, so watchfully nursed, by any observation of Charlotte's, however lightly thrown off. And then she (Charlotte) had felt, somehow, more at her (Charlotte) ease than for months and months before; she (Charlotte) didn't know why, but her (Charlotte) time at the Museum, oddly, had done it; it was as if she (Charlotte) hadn't come into so many noble and beautiful associations, nor secured them also for her (Charlotte) boy, secured them even for her (Charlotte) father, only to see them turn to vanity and doubt, turn possibly to something still worse.
``I believed in him (us) again as much as ever, and I felt how I believed in him (us),'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said with bright, fixed eyes;
``I felt it in the streets as I walked along, and it was as if that helped me and lifted me up, my being off by myself there, not having, for the moment, to wonder and watch; having, on the contrary, almost nothing on my mind.'' (she)

It was so much as if everything would come out right that she (Charlotte) had fallen to thinking of her (Charlotte) father's birthday, had given herself this as a reason for trying what she (Charlotte) could pick up for it. They would keep it at Fawns, where they had kept it before--since it would be the twenty-first of the month; and she (Charlotte) mightn't have another chance of making sure of something to offer him (father). There was always the impossibility, of course, of finding him (father) anything, the least bit

``good,'' (him)
that he (father) wouldn't already, long ago, in his (father) rummagings, have seen himself--and only not to think a quarter good enough; this, however, was an old story, and one could not have had any fun with him (father) but for his (father) sweet theory that the individual gift, the friendship's offering, was, by a rigorous law of nature, a foredoomed aberration, and that the more it was so the more it showed, and the more one cherished it for showing, how friendly it had been. The infirmity of art was the candour of affection, the grossness of pedigree the refinement of sympathy; the ugliest objects, in fact, as a general thing, were the bravest, the tenderest mementos, and, as such, figured in glass cases apart, worthy doubtless of the home, but not worthy of the temple--dedicated to the grimacing, not to the clear-faced, gods. She (it) herself, naturally, through the past years, had come to be much represented in those receptacles; against the thick, locked panes of which she (it) still liked to flatten her (it) nose, finding in its place, each time, everything she (it) had on successive anniversaries tried to believe he (herself) might pretend, at her (it) suggestion, to be put off with, or at least think curious. She (it) was now ready to try it again: they had always, with his (herself) pleasure in her (it) pretence and her (it) pleasure in his (herself), with the funny betrayal of the sacrifice to domestic manners on either side, played the game so happily. To this end, on her (it) way home, she (it) had loitered everywhere; quite too deludedly among the old books and the old prints, which had yielded nothing to her (it) purpose, but with a strange inconsequence in one of the other shops, that of a small antiquarian, a queer little foreign man, who had shown her (it) a number of things, shown her (it) finally something that, struck with it as rather a rarity and thinking it would, compared to some of her (it) ventures, quite superlatively do, she (it) had bought--bought really, when it came to that, for a price.
``It appears now it won't do at all,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``something has happened since that puts it quite out of the question. I had only my day of satisfaction in it, but I feel, at the same time, as I keep it here before me, that I wouldn't have missed it for the world.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

She (Maggie) had talked, from the first of her (Maggie) friend's entrances coherently enough, even with a small quaver that overstated her (Maggie) calm; but she (Maggie) held her (Maggie) breath every few seconds, as if for deliberation and to prove she (Maggie) didn't pant--all of which marked for Fanny the depth of her (Fanny) commotion: her (Fanny) reference to her (Fanny) thought about her (Fanny) father, about her (Fanny) chance to pick up something that might divert him (father), her (Fanny) mention, in fine, of his (father) fortitude under presents, having meanwhile, naturally, it should be said, much less an amplitude of insistence on the speaker's lips than a power to produce on the part of the listener herself the prompt response and full comprehension of memory and sympathy, of old amused observation. The picture was filled out by the latter's fond fancy. But Maggie was at any rate under arms; she (Maggie) knew what she (Maggie) was doing and had already her (Maggie) plan--a plan for making, for allowing, as yet,

``no difference'' (she)
; in accordance with which she (Maggie) would still dine out, and not with red eyes, nor convulsed features, nor neglected items of appearance, nor anything that would raise a question. Yet there was some knowledge that, exactly to this support of her (Maggie) not breaking down, she (Maggie) desired, she (Maggie) required, possession of; and, with the sinister rise and fall of lightning unaccompanied by thunder, it played before Mrs. Assingham's eyes that she (Assingham) herself should have, at whatever risk or whatever cost, to supply her (Assingham) with the stuff of her (Assingham) need. All our friend's instinct was to hold off from this till she (Assingham) should see what the ground would bear; she (Assingham) would take no step nearer unless INTELLIGIBLY to meet her (Assingham), and, awkward though it might be to hover there only pale and distorted, with mere imbecilities of vagueness, there was a quality of bald help in the fact of not as yet guessing what such an ominous start could lead to. She (Assingham) caught, however, after a second's thought, at the Princess's allusion to her (Princess) lost reassurance.

``You mean you were so at your ease on Monday--the night you dined with us?'' (unknown)

``I was very happy then,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

``Yes--we thought you so gay and so brilliant.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny felt it feeble, but she (Maggie) went on.
``We were so glad you were happy.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie stood a moment, at first only looking at her (Maggie).

``You thought me all right, eh?'' (unknown)

``Surely, dearest; we thought you all right.'' (unknown)

``Well, I daresay it was natural; but in point of fact I never was more wrong in my life. For, all the while, if you please, this was brewing.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham indulged, as nearly as possible to luxury, her (Assingham) vagueness. ```This'--?''

``THAT!'' (the Princess eyes)
replied the Princess, whose eyes, her (Princess) companion now saw, had turned to an object on the chimney-piece of the room, of which, among so many precious objects--the Ververs, wherever they might be, always revelled peculiarly in matchless old mantel ornaments--her (Princess) visitor had not taken heed.

``Do you mean the gilt cup?'' (unknown)

``I mean the gilt cup.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

The piece now recognised by Fanny as new to her (Fanny) own vision was a capacious bowl, of old-looking, rather strikingly yellow gold, mounted, by a short stem, on an ample foot, which held a central position above the fire-place, where, to allow it the better to show, a clearance had been made of other objects, notably of the Louis-Seize clock that accompanied the candelabra. This latter trophy ticked at present on the marble slab of a commode that exactly matched it in splendour and style. Mrs. Assingham took it, the bowl, as a fine thing; but the question was obviously not of its intrinsic value, and she (Assingham) kept off from it, admiring it at a distance.

``But what has that to do--?'' (unknown)

``It has everything. You'll see.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
With which again, however, for the moment, Maggie attached to her (Maggie) strange wide eyes.
``He (you) knew her (You) before--before I had ever seen him (you).'' (He)

```He (Maggie)' knew--?'' But Fanny, while she (Fanny) cast about her (Fanny) for the links she (Fanny) missed, could only echo it.

``Amerigo knew Charlotte--more than I ever dreamed.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny felt then it was stare for stare.

``But surely you always knew they had met.'' (unknown)

``I didn't understand. I knew too little. Don't you see what I mean?'' (the Princess)
the Princess asked.

Mrs. Assingham wondered, during these instants, how much she (Assingham) even now knew; it had taken a minute to perceive how gently she (Assingham) was speaking. With that perception of its being no challenge of wrath, no heat of the deceived soul, but only a free exposure of the completeness of past ignorance, inviting derision even if it must, the elder woman felt, first, a strange, barely credible relief: she (woman) drew in, as if it had been the warm summer scent of a flower, the sweet certainty of not meeting, any way she (woman) should turn, any consequence of judgment. She (woman) shouldn't be judged--save by herself; which was her (woman) own wretched business. The next moment, however, at all events, she (woman) blushed, within, for her (woman) immediate cowardice: she (woman) had thought of herself, thought of

``getting off,'' (she)
before so much as thinking--that is of pitifully seeing--that she (woman) was in presence of an appeal that was ALL an appeal, that utterly accepted its necessity.
``In a general way, dear child, yes. But not--a--in connexion with what you've been telling me.'' (unknown)

``They were intimate, you see. Intimate,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

Fanny continued to face her (Fanny), taking from her (Fanny) excited eyes this history, so dim and faint for all her (Fanny) anxious emphasis, of the far-away other time.

``There's always the question of what one considers--!'' (unknown)

``What one considers intimate? Well, I know what I consider intimate now. Too intimate,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``to let me know anything about it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

It was quiet--yes; but not too quiet for Fanny Assingham's capacity to wince.

``Only compatible with letting ME, you mean?'' (She)
She (Assingham) had asked it after a pause, but turning again to the new ornament of the chimney and wondering, even while she (Assingham) took relief from it, at this gap in her (Assingham) experience.
``But here are things, my dear, of which my ignorance is perfect.'' (unknown)

``They went about together--they're known to have done it. And I don't mean only before--I mean after.'' (unknown)

``After?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

``Before we were married--yes; but after we were engaged.'' (unknown)

``Ah, I've known nothing about that!'' (she)
And she (Assingham) said it with a braver assurance--clutching, with comfort, at something that was apparently new to her (Assingham).

``That bowl,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on,
``is, so strangely--too strangely, almost, to believe at this time of day--the proof. They were together all the while--up to the very eve of our marriage. Don't you remember how just before that she (you) came back, so unexpectedly, from America?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

The question had for Mrs. Assingham--and whether all consciously or not--the oddest pathos of simplicity.

``Oh yes, dear, of course I remember how she (you) came back from America--and how she (you) stayed with US, and what view one had of it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie's eyes still, all the time, pressed and penetrated; so that, during a moment, just here, she (Maggie) might have given the little flare, have made the little pounce, of asking what then

``one's'' (she)
view had been. To the small flash of this eruption Fanny stood, for her (Fanny) minute, wittingly exposed; but she (Fanny) saw it as quickly cease to threaten--quite saw the Princess, even though in all her (Princess) pain, refuse, in the interest of their strange and exalted bargain, to take advantage of the opportunity for planting the stab of reproach, the opportunity thus coming all of itself. She (Princess) saw her (Princess)--or she (Princess) believed she (Princess) saw her (Princess)--look at her (Princess) chance for straight denunciation, look at it and then pass it by; and she (Princess) felt herself, with this fact, hushed well-nigh to awe at the lucid higher intention that no distress could confound and that no discovery--since it was, however obscurely, a case of
``discovery'' (she)
--could make less needful. These seconds were brief--they rapidly passed; but they lasted long enough to renew our friend's sense of her (Princess) own extraordinary undertaking, the function again imposed on her (Princess), the answerability again drilled into her (Princess), by this intensity of intimation. She (Princess) was reminded of the terms on which she (Princess) was let off--her (Princess) quantity of release having made its sufficient show in that recall of her (Princess) relation to Charlotte's old reappearance; and deep within the whole impression glowed--ah, so inspiringly when it came to that! her (Princess) steady view, clear from the first, of the beauty of her (Princess) companion's motive. It was like a fresh sacrifice for a larger conquest
``Only see me through now, do it in the face of this and in spite of it, and I leave you a hand of which the freedom isn't to be said!'' (father)
The aggravation of fear--or call it, apparently, of knowledge--had jumped straight into its place as an aggravation above all for her (Princess) father; the effect of this being but to quicken to passion her (Princess) reasons for making his (father) protectedness, or in other words the forms of his (father) ignorance, still the law of her (Princess) attitude and the key to her (Princess) solution. She (Princess) kept as tight hold of these reasons and these forms, in her (Princess) confirmed horror, as the rider of a plunging horse grasps his (rider) seat with his (rider) knees; and she (Princess) might absolutely have been putting it to her (Princess) guest that she (Princess) believed she (Princess) could stay on if they should only
``meet'' (she)
nothing more. Though ignorant still of what she (Princess) had definitely met Fanny yearned, within, over her (Fanny) spirit; and so, no word about it said, passed, through mere pitying eyes, a vow to walk ahead and, at crossroads, with a lantern for the darkness and wavings away for unadvised traffic, look out for alarms. There was accordingly no wait in Maggie's reply.
``They spent together hours--spent at least a morning--the certainty of which has come back to me now, but that I didn't dream of it at the time. That cup there has turned witness--by the most wonderful of chances. That's why, since it has been here, I've stood it out for my husband to see; put it where it would meet him (husband), almost immediately, if he (husband) should come into the room. I've wanted it to meet him (husband),'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``and I've wanted him (husband) to meet it, and to be myself present at the meeting. But that hasn't taken place as yet; often as he (husband) has lately been in the way of coming to see me here--yes, in particular lately--he (husband) hasn't showed to-day.'' (she)
It was with her (Maggie) managed quietness, more and more, that she (Maggie) talked--an achieved coherence that helped her (Maggie), evidently, to hear and to watch herself; there was support, and thereby an awful harmony, but which meant a further guidance, in the facts she (Maggie) could add together.
``It's quite as if he (husband) had an instinct--something that has warned him (husband) off or made him (husband) uneasy. He (husband) doesn't quite know, naturally, what has happened, but guesses, with his (husband) beautiful cleverness, that something has, and isn't in a hurry to be confronted with it. So, in his (husband) vague fear, he (husband) keeps off.'' (unknown)

``But being meanwhile in the house--?'' (unknown)

``I've no idea--not having seen him (husband) to-day, by exception, since before luncheon. He (husband) spoke to me then,'' (the Princess)
the Princess freely explained,
``of a ballot, of great importance, at a club--for somebody, some personal friend, I think, who's coming up and is supposed to be in danger. To make an effort for him (friend) he (friend) thought he (friend) had better lunch there. You see the efforts he (friend) can make'' (the Princess)
--for which Maggie found a smile that went to her (Maggie) friend's heart.
``He (friend)'s in so many ways the kindest of men. But it was hours ago.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham thought.

``The more danger then of his (friend) coming in and finding me here. I don't know, you see, what you now consider that you've ascertained; nor anything of the connexion with it of that object that you declare so damning.'' (unknown)
Her (Assingham) eyes rested on this odd acquisition and then quitted it, went back to it and again turned from it: it was inscrutable in its rather stupid elegance, and yet, from the moment one had thus appraised it, vivid and definite in its domination of the scene. Fanny could no more overlook it now than she (Fanny) could have overlooked a lighted Christmas-tree; but nervously and all in vain she (Fanny) dipped into her (Fanny) mind for some floating reminiscence of it. At the same time that this attempt left her (Fanny) blank she (Fanny) understood a good deal, she (Fanny) even not a little shared the Prince's mystic apprehension. The golden bowl put on, under consideration, a sturdy, a conscious perversity; as a
``document,'' (unknown)
somehow, it was ugly, though it might have a decorative grace.
``His (friend) finding me here in presence of it might be more flagrantly disagreeable--for all of us--than you intend or than would necessarily help us. And I must take time, truly, to understand what it means.'' (unknown)

``You're safe, as far as that goes,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie returned;
``you may take it from me that he (friend) won't come in; and that I shall only find him (friend) below, waiting for me, when I go down to the carriage.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Fanny Assingham took it from her (Assingham), took it and more.

``We're to sit together at the Ambassador's then--or at least you two are--with this new complication thrust up before you, all unexplained; and to look at each other with faces that pretend, for the ghastly hour, not to be seeing it?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie looked at HER with a face that might have been the one she (Maggie) was preparing. ```Unexplained,' my dear? Quite the contrary--explained: fully, intensely, admirably explained, with nothing really to add. My own love''--she (Maggie) kept it up--

``I don't want anything more. I've plenty to go upon and to do with, as it is.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny Assingham stood there in her (Assingham) comparative darkness, with her (Assingham) links, verily, still missing; but the most acceptable effect of this was, singularly, as yet, a cold fear of getting nearer the fact.

``But when you come home--? I mean he (Ambassador)'ll come up with you again. Won't he (Ambassador) see it then?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

On which Maggie gave her (Maggie), after an instant's visible thought, the strangest of slow headshakes.

``I don't know. Perhaps he (Ambassador)'ll never see it--if it only stands there waiting for him (Ambassador). He (Ambassador) may never again,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess,
``come into this room.'' (the Princess)

Fanny more deeply wondered,

``Never again? Oh--!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Yes, it may be. How do I know? With THIS!'' (she)
she (Fanny) quietly went on. She (Fanny) had not looked again at the incriminating piece, but there was a marvel to her (Fanny) friend in the way the little word representing it seemed to express and include for her (Fanny) the whole of her (Fanny) situation.
``Then you intend not to speak to him (Ambassador)--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie waited.

``To `speak'--?'' (unknown)

``Well, about your having it and about what you consider that it represents.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't know that I shall speak--if he (Ambassador) doesn't. But his (Ambassador) keeping away from me because of that--what will that be but to speak? He (Ambassador) can't say or do more. It won't be for me to speak,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie added in a different tone, one of the tones that had already so penetrated her (Maggie) guest.
``It will be for me to listen.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham turned it over.

``Then it all depends on that object that you regard, for your reasons, as evidence?'' (unknown)

``I think I may say that _I_ depend on it. I can't,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``treat it as nothing now.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Mrs. Assingham, at this, went closer to the cup on the chimney--quite liking to feel that she (Assingham) did so, moreover, without going closer to her (Assingham) companion's vision. She (Assingham) looked at the precious thing--if precious it was--found herself in fact eyeing it as if, by her (Assingham) dim solicitation, to draw its secret from it rather than suffer the imposition of Maggie's knowledge. It was brave and rich and firm, with its bold deep hollow; and, without this queer torment about it, would, thanks to her (Maggie) love of plenty of yellow, figure to her (Maggie) as an enviable ornament, a possession really desirable. She (Maggie) didn't touch it, but if after a minute she (Maggie) turned away from it the reason was, rather oddly and suddenly, in her (Maggie) fear of doing so.

``Then it all depends on the bowl? I mean your future does? For that's what it comes to, I judge.'' (unknown)

``What it comes to,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie presently returned,
``is what that thing has put me, so almost miraculously, in the way of learning: how far they had originally gone together. If there was so much between them before, there can't--with all the other appearances--not be a great deal more now.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
And she (Maggie) went on and on; she (Maggie) steadily made her (Maggie) points.
``If such things were already then between them they make all the difference for possible doubt of what may have been between them since. If there had been nothing before there might be explanations. But it makes to-day too much to explain. I mean to explain away,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said.

Fanny Assingham was there to explain away--of this she (Assingham) was duly conscious; for that at least had been true up to now. In the light, however, of Maggie's demonstration the quantity, even without her (Maggie) taking as yet a more exact measure, might well seem larger than ever. Besides which, with or without exactness, the effect of each successive minute in the place was to put her (Maggie) more in presence of what Maggie herself saw. Maggie herself saw the truth, and that was really, while they remained there together, enough for Mrs. Assingham's relation to it. There was a force in the Princess's mere manner about it that made the detail of what she (Princess) knew a matter of minor importance. Fanny had in fact something like a momentary shame over her (Fanny) own need of asking for this detail.

``I don't pretend to repudiate,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said after a little,
``my own impressions of the different times I suppose you speak of; any more,'' (she)
she (Fanny) added,
``than I can forget what difficulties and, as it constantly seemed to me, what dangers, every course of action--whatever I should decide upon--made for me. I tried, I tried hard, to act for the best. And, you know,'' (she)
she (Fanny) next pursued, while, at the sound of her (Fanny) own statement, a slow courage and even a faint warmth of conviction came back to her (Fanny)--
``and, you know, I believe it's what I shall turn out to have done.'' (she)

This produced a minute during which their interchange, though quickened and deepened, was that of silence only, and the long, charged look; all of which found virtual consecration when Maggie at last spoke.

``I'm sure you tried to act for the best.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

It kept Fanny Assingham again a minute in silence.

``I never thought, dearest, you weren't an angel.'' (unknown)

Not, however, that this alone was much help!

``It was up to the very eve, you see,'' (the Princess)
the Princess went on--
``up to within two or three days of our marriage. That, THAT, you know--!'' (the Princess)
And she (Princess) broke down for strangely smiling.

``Yes, as I say, it was while she (I) was with me. But I didn't know it. That is,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham,
``I didn't know of anything in particular.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
It sounded weak--that she (Assingham) felt; but she (Assingham) had really her (Assingham) point to make.
``What I mean is that I don't know, for knowledge, now, anything I didn't then. That's how I am.'' (She)
She (Assingham) still, however, floundered.
``I mean it's how I WAS.'' (unknown)

``But don't they, how you were and how you are,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie asked,
``come practically to the same thing?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
The elder woman's words had struck her (Maggie) own ear as in the tone, now mistimed, of their recent, but all too factitious understanding, arrived at in hours when, as there was nothing susceptible of proof, there was nothing definitely to disprove. The situation had changed by--well, by whatever there was, by the outbreak of the definite; and this could keep Maggie at least firm. She (Maggie) was firm enough as she (Maggie) pursued.
``It was ON the whole thing that Amerigo married me.'' (unknown)
With which her (Maggie) eyes had their turn again at her (Maggie) damnatory piece.
``And it was on that--it was on that!'' (visitor)
But they came back to her (Maggie) visitor.
``And it was on it all that father married HER.'' (visitor)

Her (Maggie) visitor took it as might be.

``They both married--ah, that you must believe!--with the highest intentions.'' (unknown)

``Father did certainly!'' (her)
And then, at the renewal of this consciousness, it all rolled over her (Maggie).
``Ah, to thrust such things on us, to do them here between us and with us, day after day, and in return, in return--! To do it to HIM--to him (Father), to him (Father)!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny hesitated.

``You mean it's for him (Father) you most suffer?'' (the Princess)
And then as the Princess, after a look, but turned away, moving about the room--which made the question somehow seem a blunder--
``I ask,'' (the Princess)
she (Princess) continued,
``because I think everything, everything we now speak of, may be for him (Father), really may be MADE for him (Father), quite as if it hadn't been.'' (she)

But Maggie had, the next moment faced about as if without hearing her (Maggie).

``Father did it for ME--did it all and only for me.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham, with a certain promptness, threw up her (Assingham) head; but she (Assingham) faltered again before she (Assingham) spoke.

``Well--!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

It was only an intended word, but Maggie showed after an instant that it had reached her (Maggie).

``Do you mean that that's the reason, that that's A reason--?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny at first, however, feeling the response in this, didn't say all she (Maggie) meant; she (Maggie) said for the moment something else instead.

``He (Father) did it for you--largely at least for you. And it was for you that I did, in my smaller, interested way--well, what I could do. For I could do something,'' (she)
she (Maggie) continued;
``I thought I saw your interest as he (Father) himself saw it. And I thought I saw Charlotte's. I believed in her (Charlotte).'' (she)

``And _I_ believed in her (Charlotte),'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

Mrs. Assingham waited again; but she (Assingham) presently pushed on.

``She (Charlotte) believed then in herself.'' (unknown)

``Ah?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie murmured.

Something exquisite, faintly eager, in the prompt simplicity of it, supported her (Maggie) friend further.

``And the Prince believed. His (Prince) belief was real. Just as he (Prince) believed in himself.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie spent a minute in taking it from her (Maggie).

``He (Prince) believed in himself?'' (unknown)

``Just as I too believed in him (Prince). For I absolutely did, Maggie.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
To which Fanny then added:
``And I believe in him (Prince) yet. I mean,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
she (Fanny) subjoined--
``well, I mean I DO.'' (she)

Maggie again took it from her (Maggie); after which she (Maggie) was again, restlessly, set afloat. Then when this had come to an end:

``And do you believe in Charlotte yet?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham had a demur that she (Assingham) felt she (Assingham) could now afford.

``We'll talk of Charlotte some other day. They both, at any rate, thought themselves safe at the time.'' (unknown)

``Then why did they keep from me everything I might have known?'' (friend)

Her (Assingham) friend bent upon her (Assingham) the mildest eyes.

``Why did I myself keep it from you?'' (unknown)

``Oh, you weren't, for honour, obliged.'' (unknown)

``Dearest Maggie,'' (the woman)
the poor woman broke out on this,
``you ARE divine!'' (the woman)

``They pretended to love me,'' (the Princess)
the Princess went on.
``And they pretended to love HIM.'' (unknown)

``And pray what was there that I didn't pretend?'' (unknown)

``Not, at any rate, to care for me as you cared for Amerigo and for Charlotte. They were much more interesting--it was perfectly natural. How couldn't you like Amerigo?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie continued.

Mrs. Assingham gave it up.

``How couldn't I, how couldn't I?'' (she)
Then, with a fine freedom, she (Maggie) went all her (Maggie) way.
``How CAN'T I, how can't I?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

It fixed afresh Maggie's wide eyes on her (Maggie).

``I see--I see. Well, it's beautiful for you to be able to. And of course,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added,
``you wanted to help Charlotte.'' (she)

``Yes'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
--Fanny considered it--
``I wanted to help Charlotte. But I wanted also, you see, to help you--by not digging up a past that I believed, with so much on top of it, solidly buried. I wanted, as I still want,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
she (Fanny) richly declared,
``to help every one.'' (she)

It set Maggie once more in movement--movement which, however, spent itself again with a quick emphasis.

``Then it's a good deal my fault--if everything really began so well?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny Assingham met it as she (Assingham) could.

``You've been only too perfect. You've thought only too much.'' (the Princess)

But the Princess had already caught at the words.

``Yes--I've thought only too much!'' (she)
Yet she (Princess) appeared to continue, for the minute, full of that fault. She (Princess) had it in fact, by this prompted thought, all before her (Princess).
``Of him (Charlotte), dear man, of HIM--!'' (friend)

Her (Princess) friend, able to take in thus directly her (Princess) vision of her (Princess) father, watched her (Princess) with a new suspense. THAT way might safety lie--it was like a wider chink of light.

``He (Charlotte) believed--with a beauty!--in Charlotte.'' (unknown)

``Yes, and it was I who had made him (Charlotte) believe. I didn't mean to, at the time, so much; for I had no idea then of what was coming. But I did it, I did it!'' (the Princess)
the Princess declared.

``With a beauty--ah, with a beauty, you too!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham insisted.

Maggie, however, was seeing for herself--it was another matter,

``The thing was that he (Charlotte) made her (Charlotte) think it would be so possible.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Fanny again hesitated.

``The Prince made her (Charlotte) think--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie stared--she (Maggie) had meant her (Maggie) father. But her (Maggie) vision seemed to spread.

``They both made her (Charlotte) think. She (Charlotte) wouldn't have thought without them.'' (unknown)

``Yet Amerigo's good faith,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham insisted,
``was perfect. And there was nothing, all the more,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
she (Assingham) added,
``against your father's.'' (she)

The remark, however, kept Maggie for a moment still.

``Nothing perhaps but his (father) knowing that she (Charlotte) knew.'' (unknown)

```Knew'?''

``That he (father) was doing it, so much, for me. To what extent,'' (she)
she (Maggie) suddenly asked of her (Maggie) friend,
``do you think he (father) was aware that she (Charlotte) knew?'' (friend)

``Ah, who can say what passes between people in such a relation? The only thing one can be sure of is that he (father) was generous.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
And Mrs. Assingham conclusively smiled.
``He (father) doubtless knew as much as was right for himself.'' (unknown)

``As much, that is, as was right for her (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``Yes then--as was right for her (Charlotte). The point is,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny declared,
``that, whatever his (father) knowledge, it made, all the way it went, for his (father) good faith.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Maggie continued to gaze, and her (Maggie) friend now fairly waited on her (Maggie) successive movements.

``Isn't the point, very considerably, that his (father) good faith must have been his (father) faith in her (Charlotte) taking almost as much interest in me as he (father) himself took?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny Assingham thought.

``He (father) recognised, he (father) adopted, your long friendship. But he (father) founded on it no selfishness.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie with still deeper consideration:
``he (father) counted her (Charlotte) selfishness out almost as he (father) counted his (father) own.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``So you may say.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on;
``if he (father) had none of his (father) own, he (father) invited her (Charlotte), may have expected her (Charlotte), on her (Charlotte) side, to have as little. And she (Charlotte) may only since have found that out.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Mrs. Assingham looked blank.

``Since--?'' (unknown)

``And he (father) may have become aware,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie pursued,
``that she (Charlotte) has found it out. That she (Charlotte) has taken the measure, since their marriage,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) explained,
``of how much he (father) had asked of her (Charlotte)--more, say, than she (Charlotte) had understood at the time. He (father) may have made out at last how such a demand was, in the long run, to affect her (Charlotte).'' (she)

``He (father) may have done many things,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham responded;
``but there's one thing he (father) certainly won't have done. He (father)'ll never have shown that he (father) expected of her (Charlotte) a quarter as much as she (Charlotte) must have understood he (father) was to give.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

``I've often wondered,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie mused,
``what Charlotte really understood. But it's one of the things she (Charlotte) has never told me.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Then as it's one of the things she (Charlotte) has never told me either, we shall probably never know it; and we may regard it as none of our business. There are many things,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham,
``that we shall never know.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Maggie took it in with a long reflection.

``Never.'' (unknown)

``But there are others,'' (friend)
her (Maggie) friend went on,
``that stare us in the face and that--under whatever difficulty you may feel you labour--may now be enough for us. Your father has been extraordinary.'' (friend)

It had been as if Maggie were feeling her (Maggie) way; but she (Maggie) rallied to this with a rush.

``Extraordinary.'' (unknown)

``Magnificent,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

Her (Assingham) companion held tight to it.

``Magnificent.'' (unknown)

``Then he (father)'ll do for himself whatever there may be to do. What he (father) undertook for you he (father)'ll do to the end. He (father) didn't undertake it to break down; in what--quiet, patient, exquisite as he (patient) is--did he (patient) ever break down? He (patient) had never in his (patient) life proposed to himself to have failed, and he (patient) won't have done it on this occasion.'' (unknown)

``Ah, this occasion!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
--and Maggie's wail showed her (Maggie), of a sudden, thrown back on it.
``Am I in the least sure that, with everything, he (patient) even knows what it is? And yet am I in the least sure he (patient) doesn't?'' (unknown)

``If he (patient) doesn't then, so much the better. Leave him (patient) alone.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean give him (patient) up?'' (unknown)

``Leave HER,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham went on.
``Leave her (patient) TO him (patient).'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie looked at her (Maggie) darkly.

``Do you mean leave him (patient) to HER? After this?'' (unknown)

``After everything. Aren't they, for that matter, intimately together now?'' (unknown)

```Intimately'--? How do I know?''

But Fanny kept it up.

``Aren't you and your husband--in spite of everything?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie's eyes still further, if possible, dilated.

``It remains to be seen!'' (unknown)

``If you're not then, where's your faith?'' (unknown)

``In my husband--?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham but for an instant hesitated.

``In your father. It all comes back to that. Rest on it.'' (unknown)

``On his (father) ignorance?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny met it again.

``On whatever he (father) may offer you. TAKE that.'' (unknown)

``Take it--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie stared.

Mrs. Assingham held up her (Assingham) head.

``And be grateful.'' (she)
On which, for a minute, she (Assingham) let the Princess face her (Princess).
``Do you see?'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie at last.

``Then there you are.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
But Maggie had turned away, moving to the window, as if still to keep something in her (Maggie) face from sight. She (Maggie) stood there with her (Maggie) eyes on the street while Mrs. Assingham's reverted to that complicating object on the chimney as to which her (Assingham) condition, so oddly even to herself, was that both of recurrent wonder and recurrent protest. She (Assingham) went over it, looked at it afresh and yielded now to her (Assingham) impulse to feel it in her (Assingham) hands. She (Assingham) laid them on it, lifting it up, and was surprised, thus, with the weight of it--she (Assingham) had seldom handled so much massive gold. That effect itself somehow prompted her (Assingham) to further freedom and presently to saying:
``I don't believe in this, you know.'' (her)

It brought Maggie round to her (Maggie).

``Don't believe in it? You will when I tell you.'' (unknown)

``Ah, tell me nothing! I won't have it,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham. She (Assingham) kept the cup in her (Assingham) hand, held it there in a manner that gave Maggie's attention to her (Maggie), she (Maggie) saw the next moment, a quality of excited suspense. This suggested to her (Maggie), oddly, that she (Maggie) had, with the liberty she (Maggie) was taking, an air of intention, and the impression betrayed by her (Maggie) companion's eyes grew more distinct in a word of warning.
``It's of value, but its value's impaired, I've learned, by a crack.'' (unknown)

``A crack?--in the gold--?'' (unknown)

``It isn't gold.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
With which, somewhat strangely, Maggie smiled.

``That's the point.'' (unknown)

``What is it then?'' (unknown)

``It's glass--and cracked, under the gilt, as I say, at that.'' (unknown)

``Glass?--of this weight?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``it's crystal--and was once, I suppose, precious. But what,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) then asked,
``do you mean to do with it?'' (she)

She (Maggie) had come away from her (Maggie) window, one of the three by which the wide room, enjoying an advantageous

``back,'' (She)
commanded the western sky and caught a glimpse of the evening flush; while Mrs. Assingham, possessed of the bowl, and possessed too of this indication of a flaw, approached another for the benefit of the slowly-fading light. Here, thumbing the singular piece, weighing it, turning it over, and growing suddenly more conscious, above all, of an irresistible impulse, she (Assingham) presently spoke again.
``A crack? Then your whole idea has a crack.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie, by this time at some distance from her (Maggie), waited a moment.

``If you mean by my idea the knowledge that has come to me THAT--'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

But Fanny, with decision, had already taken her (Fanny) up.

``There's only one knowledge that concerns us--one fact with which we can have anything to do.'' (unknown)

``Which one, then?'' (unknown)

``The fact that your husband has never, never, never--!'' (she)
But the very gravity of this statement, while she (Fanny) raised her (Fanny) eyes to her (Fanny) friend across the room, made her (Fanny) for an instant hang fire.

``Well, never what?'' (unknown)

``Never been half so interested in you as now. But don't you, my dear, really feel it?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie considered.

``Oh, I think what I've told you helps me to feel it. His (husband) having to-day given up even his (husband) forms; his (husband) keeping away from me; his (husband) not having come.'' (she)
And she (Fanny) shook her (Fanny) head as against all easy glosses.
``It is because of that, you know.'' (unknown)

``Well then, if it's because of this--!'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
And Fanny Assingham, who had been casting about her (Assingham) and whose inspiration decidedly had come, raised the cup in her (Assingham) two hands, raised it positively above her (Assingham) head, and from under it, solemnly, smiled at the Princess as a signal of intention. So for an instant, full of her (Princess) thought and of her (Princess) act, she (Princess) held the precious vessel, and then, with due note taken of the margin of the polished floor, bare, fine and hard in the embrasure of her (Princess) window, she (Princess) dashed it boldly to the ground, where she (Princess) had the thrill of seeing it, with the violence of the crash, lie shattered. She (Princess) had flushed with the force of her (Princess) effort, as Maggie had flushed with wonder at the sight, and this high reflection in their faces was all that passed between them for a minute more. After which,
``Whatever you meant by it--and I don't want to know NOW--has ceased to exist,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham said.

``And what in the world, my dear, did you mean by it?'' (Fanny)
--that sound, as at the touch of a spring, rang out as the first effect of Fanny's speech. It broke upon the two women's absorption with a sharpness almost equal to the smash of the crystal, for the door of the room had been opened by the Prince without their taking heed. He (Prince) had apparently had time, moreover, to catch the conclusion of Fanny's act; his (Prince) eyes attached themselves, through the large space allowing just there, as happened, a free view, to the shining fragments at this lady's feet. His (Prince) question had been addressed to his (Prince) wife, but he (Prince) moved his (Prince) eyes immediately afterwards to those of her (wife) visitor, whose own then held them in a manner of which neither party had been capable, doubtless, for mute penetration, since the hour spent by him (Prince) in Cadogan Place on the eve of his (Prince) marriage and the afternoon of Charlotte's reappearance. Something now again became possible for these communicants, under the intensity of their pressure, something that took up that tale and that might have been a redemption of pledges then exchanged. This rapid play of suppressed appeal and disguised response lasted indeed long enough for more results than one--long enough for Mrs. Assingham to measure the feat of quick self-recovery, possibly therefore of recognition still more immediate, accompanying Amerigo's vision and estimate of the evidence with which she (Assingham) had been--so admirably, she (Assingham) felt as she (Assingham) looked at him (Assingham)--inspired to deal. She (Assingham) looked at him (Assingham) and looked at him (Assingham)--there were so many things she (Assingham) wanted, on the spot, to say. But Maggie was looking too--and was moreover looking at them both; so that these things, for the elder woman, quickly enough reduced themselves to one. She (woman) met his (Assingham) question--not too late, since, in their silence, it had remained in the air. Gathering herself to go, leaving the golden bowl split into three pieces on the ground, she (woman) simply referred him (Assingham) to his (Assingham) wife. She (woman) should see them later, they would all meet soon again; and meanwhile, as to what Maggie had meant--she (Maggie) said, in her (Maggie) turn, from the door--why, Maggie herself was doubtless by this time ready to tell him (Assingham).

XXXIV

Left with her (Maggie) husband, Maggie, however, for the time, said nothing; she (Maggie) only felt, on the spot, a strong, sharp wish not to see his (husband) face again till he (husband) should have had a minute to arrange it. She (Maggie) had seen it enough for her (Maggie) temporary clearness and her (Maggie) next movement--seen it as it showed during the stare of surprise that followed his (husband) entrance. Then it was that she (Maggie) knew how hugely expert she (Maggie) had been made, for judging it quickly, by that vision of it, indelibly registered for reference, that had flashed a light into her (Maggie) troubled soul the night of his (husband) late return from Matcham. The expression worn by it at that juncture, for however few instants, had given her (Maggie) a sense of its possibilities, one of the most relevant of which might have been playing up for her (Maggie), before the consummation of Fanny Assingham's retreat, just long enough to be recognised. What she (Assingham) had recognised in it was HIS (husband) recognition, the result of his (husband) having been forced, by the flush of their visitor's attitude and the unextinguished report of her (Assingham) words, to take account of the flagrant signs of the accident, of the incident, on which he (husband) had unexpectedly dropped. He (husband) had, not unnaturally, failed to see this occurrence represented by the three fragments of an object apparently valuable which lay there on the floor and which, even across the width of the room, his (husband) kept interval, reminded him (husband), unmistakably though confusedly, of something known, some other unforgotten image. That was a mere shock, that was a pain--as if Fanny's violence had been a violence redoubled and acting beyond its intention, a violence calling up the hot blood as a blow across the mouth might have called it. Maggie knew as she (Maggie) turned away from him (husband) that she (Maggie) didn't want his (husband) pain; what she (Maggie) wanted was her (Maggie) own simple certainty--not the red mark of conviction flaming there in his (husband) beauty. If she (Maggie) could have gone on with bandaged eyes she (Maggie) would have liked that best; if it were a question of saying what she (Maggie) now, apparently, should have to, and of taking from him (husband) what he (husband) would say, any blindness that might wrap it would be the nearest approach to a boon.

She (Maggie) went in silence to where her (Maggie) friend--never, in intention, visibly, so much her (Maggie) friend as at that moment--had braced herself to so amazing an energy, and there, under Amerigo's eyes, she (Maggie) picked up the shining pieces. Bedizened and jewelled, in her (Maggie) rustling finery, she (Maggie) paid, with humility of attitude, this prompt tribute to order--only to find, however, that she (Maggie) could carry but two of the fragments at once. She (Maggie) brought them over to the chimney-piece, to the conspicuous place occupied by the cup before Fanny's appropriation of it, and, after laying them carefully down, went back for what remained, the solid detached foot. With this she (Fanny) returned to the mantel-shelf, placing it with deliberation in the centre and then, for a minute, occupying herself as with the attempt to fit the other morsels together. The split, determined by the latent crack, was so sharp and so neat that if there had been anything to hold them the bowl might still, quite beautifully, a few steps away, have passed for uninjured. But, as there was, naturally, nothing to hold them but Maggie's hands, during the few moments the latter were so employed, she (Maggie) could only lay the almost equal parts of the vessel carefully beside their pedestal and leave them thus before her (Maggie) husband's eyes. She (Maggie) had proceeded without words, but quite as if with a sought effect-in spite of which it had all seemed to her (Maggie) to take a far longer time than anything she (Maggie) had ever so quickly accomplished. Amerigo said nothing either-though it was true that his (husband) silence had the gloss of the warning she (Maggie) doubtless appeared to admonish him (husband) to take: it was as if her (Maggie) manner hushed him (husband) to the proper observation of what she (Maggie) was doing. He (husband) should have no doubt of it whatever: she (Maggie) _knew_ and her (Maggie) broken bowl was proof that she (Maggie) knew-yet the least part of her (Maggie) desire was to make him (husband) waste words. He (husband) would have to think-this she (Maggie) knew even better still; and all she (Maggie) was for the present concerned with was that he (husband) should be aware. She (Maggie) had taken him (husband) for aware all day, or at least for obscurely and instinctively anxious-as to that she (Maggie) had just committed herself to Fanny Assingham; but what she (Assingham) had been wrong about was the effect of his (husband) anxiety. His (husband) fear of staying away, as a marked symptom, had at least proved greater than his (husband) fear of coming in ; he (husband) had come in even at the risk of bringing it with him-and, ah, what more did she (Assingham) require now than her (Assingham) sense, established within the first minute or two, that he (husband) had brought it, however he (husband) might be steadying himself against dangers of betrayal by some wrong word, and that it was shut in there between them, the successive moments throbbing under it the while as the pulse of fever throbs under the doctor's thumb?

Maggie's sense, in fine, in his (doctor) presence, was that though the bowl had been broken, her (Maggie) reason hadn't ; the reason for which she (Maggie) had made up her (Maggie) mind, the reason for which she (Maggie) had summoned her (Maggie) friend, the reason for which she (Maggie) had prepared the place for her (Maggie) husband's eyes ; it was all one reason, and, as her (Maggie) intense little clutch held the matter, what had happened by Fanny's act and by his (husband) apprehension of it had not in the least happened to _her (Fanny)_ but absolutely and directly to himself, as he (husband) must proceed to take in. There it was that her (Fanny) wish for time interposed-time for Amerigo's use, not for hers, since she (Fanny), for ever so long now, for hours and hours as they seemed, had been living with eternity; with which she (Fanny) would continue to live. She (Fanny) wanted to say to him (husband),

`` Take it, take it, take all you need of it ; arrange yourself so as to suffer least, or to be, at any rate, least distorted and disfigured Only _see_ see that _I_ see, and make up your mind, on this new basis, at your convenience. Wait-it won't be long-till you can confer again with Charlotte, for you'll do it much better then-more easily to both of us. Above all don't show me, till you've got it well under, the dreadful blur, the ravage of suspense and embarrassment, produced, and produced by my doing, in your personal serenity, your incomparable superiority.'' (him)

After she (Fanny) had squared again her (Fanny) little objects on the chimney, she (Fanny) was within an ace, in fact, of turning on him (husband) with that appeal; besides its being lucid for her (Fanny), all the while, that the occasion was passing, that they were dining out, that he (husband) wasn't dressed, and that, though she (Fanny) herself was, she (Fanny) was yet, in all probability, so horribly red in the face and so awry, in many ways, with agitation, that in view of the Ambassador's company, of possible comments and constructions, she (Fanny) should need, before her (Fanny) glass, some restoration of appearances.

Amerigo, meanwhile, after all, could clearly make the most of her (Fanny) having enjoined on him (Ambassador) to wait--suggested it by the positive pomp of her (Fanny) dealings with the smashed cup; to wait, that is, till she (Fanny) should pronounce as Mrs. Assingham had promised for her (Assingham). This delay, again, certainly tested her (Assingham) presence of mind--though that strain was not what presently made her (Assingham) speak. Keep her (Assingham) eyes, for the time, from her (Assingham) husband's as she (Assingham) might, she (Assingham) soon found herself much more drivingly conscious of the strain on his (husband) own wit. There was even a minute, when her (Assingham) back was turned to him (husband), during which she (Assingham) knew once more the strangeness of her (Assingham) desire to spare him (husband), a strangeness that had already, fifty times, brushed her (Assingham), in the depth of her (Assingham) trouble, as with the wild wing of some bird of the air who might blindly have swooped for an instant into the shaft of a well, darkening there by his (husband) momentary flutter the far-off round of sky. It was extraordinary, this quality in the taste of her (Assingham) wrong which made her (Assingham) completed sense of it seem rather to soften than to harden and it was the more extraordinary the more she (Assingham) had to recognise it; for what it came to was that seeing herself finally sure, knowing everything, having the fact, in all its abomination, so utterly before her (Assingham) that there was nothing else to add--what it came to was that, merely by being WITH him (husband) there in silence, she (Assingham) felt, within her (Assingham), the sudden split between conviction and action. They had begun to cease, on the spot, surprisingly, to be connected; conviction, that is, budged no inch, only planting its feet the more firmly in the soil--but action began to hover like some lighter and larger, but easier form, excited by its very power to keep above ground. It would be free, it would be independent, it would go in--wouldn't it?--for some prodigious and superior adventure of its own. What would condemn it, so to speak, to the responsibility of freedom--this glimmered on Maggie even now--was the possibility, richer with every lapsing moment, that her (Maggie) husband would have, on the whole question, a new need of her (Maggie), a need which was in fact being born between them in these very seconds. It struck her (Maggie) truly as so new that he (husband) would have felt hitherto none to compare with it at all; would indeed, absolutely, by this circumstance, be REALLY needing her (Maggie) for the first one in their whole connection. No, he (husband) had used her (Maggie), had even exceedingly enjoyed her (Maggie), before this; but there had been no precedent for that character of a proved necessity to him (character) which she (Maggie) was rapidly taking on. The immense advantage of this particular clue, moreover, was that she (Maggie) should have now to arrange, alter, to falsify nothing; should have to be but consistently simple and straight. She (Maggie) asked herself, with concentration, while her (Maggie) back was still presented, what would be the very ideal of that method; after which, the next instant, it had all come to her (Maggie) and she (Maggie) had turned round upon him (character) for the application.

``Fanny Assingham broke it--knowing it had a crack and that it would go if she (Fanny) used sufficient force. She (Fanny) thought, when I had told her (Fanny), that that would be the best thing to do with it--thought so from her (Fanny) own point of view. That hadn't been at all my idea, but she (Fanny) acted before I understood. I had, on the contrary,'' (she)
she (Maggie) explained,
``put it here, in full view, exactly that you might see.'' (she)

He (character) stood with his (character) hands in his (character) pockets; he (character) had carried his (character) eyes to the fragments on the chimney-piece, and she (Maggie) could already distinguish the element of relief, absolutely of succour, in his (character) acceptance from her (Maggie) of the opportunity to consider the fruits of their friend's violence--every added inch of reflection and delay having the advantage, from this point on, of counting for him (character) double. It had operated within her (Maggie) now to the last intensity, her (Maggie) glimpse of the precious truth that by her (Maggie) helping him (character), helping him (character) to help himself, as it were, she (Maggie) should help him (character) to help HER. Hadn't she (Maggie) fairly got into his (character) labyrinth with him (character)?--wasn't she (Maggie) indeed in the very act of placing herself there, for him (character), at its centre and core, whence, on that definite orientation and by an instinct all her (Maggie) own, she (Maggie) might securely guide him (character) out of it? She (Maggie) offered him (character) thus, assuredly, a kind of support that was not to have been imagined in advance, and that moreover required--ah most truly!--some close looking at before it could be believed in and pronounced void of treachery.

``Yes, look, look,'' (she)
she (Maggie) seemed to see him (character) hear her (Maggie) say even while her (Maggie) sounded words were other--
``look, look, both at the truth that still survives in that smashed evidence and at the even more remarkable appearance that I'm not such a fool as you supposed me. Look at the possibility that, since I AM different, there may still be something in it for you--if you're capable of working with me to get that out. Consider of course, as you must, the question of what you may have to surrender, on your side, what price you may have to pay, whom you may have to pay WITH, to set this advantage free; but take in, at any rate, that there is something for you if you don't too blindly spoil your chance for it.'' (him)
He (character) went no nearer the damnatory pieces, but he (character) eyed them, from where he (character) stood, with a degree of recognition just visibly less to be dissimulated; all of which represented for her (Maggie) a certain traceable process. And her (Maggie) uttered words, meanwhile, were different enough from those he (character) might have inserted between the lines of her (Maggie) already-spoken.
``It's the golden bowl, you know, that you saw at the little antiquario's in Bloomsbury, so long ago--when you went there with Charlotte, when you spent those hours with her (Charlotte), unknown to me, a day or two before our marriage. It was shown you both, but you didn't take it; you left it for me, and I came upon it, extraordinarily, through happening to go into the same shop on Monday last; in walking home, in prowling about to pick up some small old thing for father's birthday, after my visit to the Museum, my appointment there with Mr. Crichton, of which I told you. It was shown me, and I was struck with it and took it--knowing nothing about it at the time. What I now know I've learned since--I learned this afternoon, a couple of hours ago; receiving from it naturally a great impression. So there it is--in its three pieces. You can handle them--don't be afraid--if you want to make sure the thing is the thing you and Charlotte saw together. Its having come apart makes an unfortunate difference for its beauty, its artistic value, but none for anything else. Its other value is just the same--I mean that of its having given me so much of the truth about you. I don't therefore so much care what becomes of it now--unless perhaps you may yourself, when you come to think, have some good use for it. In that case,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie wound up,
``we can easily take the pieces with us to Fawns.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

It was wonderful how she (Maggie) felt, by the time she (Maggie) had seen herself through this narrow pass, that she (Maggie) had really achieved something--that she (Maggie) was emerging a little, in fine, with the prospect less contracted. She (Maggie) had done for him (character), that is, what her (Maggie) instinct enjoined; had laid a basis not merely momentary on which he (character) could meet her (Maggie). When, by the turn of his (character) head, he (character) did finally meet her (Maggie), this was the last thing that glimmered out of his (character) look; but it came into sight, none the less, as a perception of his (character) distress and almost as a question of his (character) eyes; so that, for still another minute, before he (character) committed himself, there occurred between them a kind of unprecedented moral exchange over which her (Maggie) superior lucidity presided. It was not, however, that when he (character) did commit himself the show was promptly portentous.

``But what in the world has Fanny Assingham had to do with it?'' (She)

She (Maggie) could verily, out of all her (Maggie) smothered soreness, almost have smiled: his (character) question so affected her (Maggie) as giving the whole thing up to her (Maggie). But it left her (Maggie) only to go the straighter.

``She (Assingham) has had to do with it that I immediately sent for her (Assingham) and that she (Assingham) immediately came. She (Assingham) was the first person I wanted to see--because I knew she (Assingham) would know. Know more about what I had learned, I mean, than I could make out for myself. I made out as much as I could for myself--that I also wanted to have done; but it didn't, in spite of everything, take me very far, and she (Assingham) has really been a help. Not so much as she (Assingham) would like to be--not so much as, poor dear, she (Assingham) just now tried to be; yet she (Assingham) has done her (Assingham) very best for you--never forget that!--and has kept me along immeasurably better than I should have been able to come without her (Assingham). She (Assingham) has gained me time; and that, these three months, don't you see? has been everything.'' (She)

She (Maggie) had said

``Don't you see?'' (She)
on purpose, and was to feel the next moment that it had acted.
``These three months'?'' (the Prince)
the Prince asked.

``Counting from the night you came home so late from Matcham. Counting from the hours you spent with Charlotte at Gloucester; your visit to the cathedral--which you won't have forgotten describing to me in so much detail. For that was the beginning of my being sure. Before it I had been sufficiently in doubt. Sure,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie developed,
``of your having, and of your having for a long time had, TWO relations with Charlotte.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

He (Prince) stared, a little at sea, as he (Prince) took it up.

``Two--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Something in the tone of it gave it a sense, or an ambiguity, almost foolish--leaving Maggie to feel, as in a flash, how such a consequence, a foredoomed infelicity, partaking of the ridiculous even in one of the cleverest, might be of the very essence of the penalty of wrong-doing.

``Oh, you may have had fifty--had the same relation with her (Charlotte) fifty times! It's of the number of KINDS of relation with her (Charlotte) that I speak--a number that doesn't matter, really, so long as there wasn't only one kind, as father and I supposed. One kind,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``was there before us; we took that fully for granted, as you saw, and accepted it. We never thought of there being another, kept out of our sight. But after the evening I speak of I knew there was something else. As I say, I had, before that, my idea--which you never dreamed I had. From the moment I speak of it had more to go upon, and you became yourselves, you and she (our), vaguely, yet uneasily, conscious of the difference. But it's within these last hours that I've most seen where we are; and as I've been in communication with Fanny Assingham about my doubts, so I wanted to let her (Assingham) know my certainty--with the determination of which, however, you must understand, she (Assingham) has had nothing to do. She (Assingham) defends you,'' (she)
Maggie remarked.

He (Prince) had given her (Maggie) all his (Prince) attention, and with this impression for her (Maggie), again, that he (Prince) was, in essence, fairly reaching out to her (Maggie) for time--time, only time--she (Maggie) could sufficiently imagine, and to whatever strangeness, that he (Prince) absolutely liked her (Maggie) to talk, even at the cost of his (Prince) losing almost everything else by it.
