It was still, for a minute, as if he (Prince) waited for something worse; wanted everything that was in her (Maggie) to come out, any definite fact, anything more precisely nameable, so that he (Prince) too--as was his (Prince) right--should know where he (Prince) was. What stirred in him (Prince) above all, while he (Prince) followed in her (Maggie) face the clear train of her (Maggie) speech, must have been the impulse to take up something she (Maggie) put before him (Prince) that he (Prince) was yet afraid directly to touch. He (Prince) wanted to make free with it, but had to keep his (Prince) hands off--for reasons he (Prince) had already made out; and the discomfort of his (Prince) privation yearned at her (Maggie) out of his (Prince) eyes with an announcing gleam of the fever, the none too tolerable chill, of specific recognition. She (Maggie) affected him (Prince) as speaking more or less for her (Maggie) father as well, and his (father) eyes might have been trying to hypnotise her (Maggie) into giving him (father) the answer without his (father) asking the question.

``Had HE (Assingham) his (Assingham) idea, and has he (Assingham) now, with you, anything more?'' (he)
--those were the words he (father) had to hold himself from not speaking and that she (Maggie) would as yet, certainly, do nothing to make easy. She (Maggie) felt with her (Maggie) sharpest thrill how he (father) was straitened and tied, and with the miserable pity of it her (Maggie) present conscious purpose of keeping him (father) so could none the less perfectly accord. To name her (Maggie) father, on any such basis of anxiety, of compunction, would be to do the impossible thing, to do neither more nor less than give Charlotte away. Visibly, palpably, traceably, he (father) stood off from this, moved back from it as from an open chasm now suddenly perceived, but which had been, between the two, with so much, so strangely much else, quite uncalculated. Verily it towered before her (Charlotte), this history of their confidence. They had built strong and piled high--based as it was on such appearances--their conviction that, thanks to her (Charlotte) native complacencies of so many sorts, she (Charlotte) would always, quite to the end and through and through, take them as nobly sparing her (Charlotte). Amerigo was at any rate having the sensation of a particular ugliness to avoid, a particular difficulty to count with, that practically found him (their) as unprepared as if he (their) had been, like his (their) wife, an abjectly simple person. And she (wife) meanwhile, however abjectly simple, was further discerning, for herself, that, whatever he (their) might have to take from her (wife)--she (wife) being, on her (wife) side, beautifully free--he (their) would absolutely not be able, for any qualifying purpose, to name Charlotte either. As his (their) father-in-law's wife Mrs. Verver rose between them there, for the time, in august and prohibitive form; to protect her (Verver), defend her (Verver), explain about her (Verver), was, at the least, to bring her (Verver) into the question--which would be by the same stroke to bring her (Verver) husband. But this was exactly the door Maggie wouldn't open to him (husband); on all of which she (Maggie) was the next moment asking herself if, thus warned and embarrassed, he (husband) were not fairly writhing in his (husband) pain. He (husband) writhed, on that hypothesis, some seconds more, for it was not till then that he (husband) had chosen between what he (husband) could do and what he (husband) couldn't.

``You're apparently drawing immense conclusions from very small matters. Won't you perhaps feel, in fairness, that you're striking out, triumphing, or whatever I may call it, rather too easily--feel it when I perfectly admit that your smashed cup there does come back to me? I frankly confess, now, to the occasion, and to having wished not to speak of it to you at the time. We took two or three hours together, by arrangement; it WAS on the eve of my marriage--at the moment you say. But that put it on the eve of yours too, my dear--which was directly the point. It was desired to find for you, at the eleventh hour, some small wedding-present--a hunt, for something worth giving you, and yet possible from other points of view as well, in which it seemed I could be of use. You were naturally not to be told--precisely because it was all FOR you. We went forth together and we looked; we rummaged about and, as I remember we called it, we prowled; then it was that, as I freely recognise, we came across that crystal cup--which I'm bound to say, upon my honour, I think it rather a pity Fanny Assingham, from whatever good motive, should have treated so.'' (He)
He (husband) had kept his (husband) hands in his (husband) pockets; he (husband) turned his (husband) eyes again, but more complacently now, to the ruins of the precious vessel; and Maggie could feel him (husband) exhale into the achieved quietness of his (husband) explanation a long, deep breath of comparative relief. Behind everything, beneath everything, it was somehow a comfort to him (husband) at last to be talking with her (Maggie)--and he (husband) seemed to be proving to himself that he (husband) COULD talk.
``It was at a little shop in Bloomsbury--I think I could go to the place now. The man understood Italian, I remember; he (man) wanted awfully to work off his (man) bowl. But I didn't believe in it, and we didn't take it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie had listened with an interest that wore all the expression of candour.

``Oh, you left it for me. But what did you take?'' (He)

He (husband) looked at her (Maggie); first as if he (husband) were trying to remember, then as if he (husband) might have been trying to forget.

``Nothing, I think--at that place.'' (unknown)

``What did you take then at any other? What did you get me--since that was your aim and end--for a wedding-gift?'' (The Prince)

The Prince continued very nobly to bethink himself.

``Didn't we get you anything?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie waited a little; she (Maggie) had for some time, now, kept her (Maggie) eyes on him (Prince) steadily; but they wandered, at this, to the fragments on her (Maggie) chimney.

``Yes; it comes round, after all, to your having got me the bowl. I myself was to come upon it, the other day, by so wonderful a chance; was to find it in the same place and to have it pressed upon me by the same little man, who does, as you say, understand Italian. I did `believe in it,' you see--must have believed in it somehow instinctively; for I took it as soon as I saw it. Though I didn't know at all then,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added,
``what I was taking WITH it.'' (she)

The Prince paid her (Maggie) for an instant, visibly, the deference of trying to imagine what this might have been.

``I agree with you that the coincidence is extraordinary--the sort of thing that happens mainly in novels and plays. But I don't see, you must let me say, the importance or the connexion--'' (She)

``Of my having made the purchase where you failed of it?'' (She)
She (Maggie) had quickly taken him (Prince) up; but she (Maggie) had, with her (Maggie) eyes on him (Prince) once more, another drop into the order of her (Maggie) thoughts, to which, through whatever he (Prince) might say, she (Maggie) was still adhering.
``It's not my having gone into the place, at the end of four years, that makes the strangeness of the coincidence; for don't such chances as that, in London, easily occur? The strangeness,'' (she)
she (Maggie) lucidly said,
``is in what my purchase was to represent to me after I had got it home; which value came,'' (she)
she (Maggie) explained,
``from the wonder of my having found such a friend.'' (she)

```Such a friend'?'' As a wonder, assuredly, her (Maggie) husband could but take it.

``As the little man in the shop. He (man) did for me more than he (man) knew--I owe it to him (man). He (man) took an interest in me,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie said;
``and, taking that interest, he (man) recalled your visit, he (man) remembered you and spoke of you to me.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

On which the Prince passed the comment of a sceptical smile.

``Ah but, my dear, if extraordinary things come from people's taking an interest in you--'' (she)

``My life in that case,'' (she)
she (Maggie) asked,
``must be very agitated? Well, he (man) liked me, I mean--very particularly. It's only so I can account for my afterwards hearing from him (man)--and in fact he (man) gave me that to-day,'' (she)
she (Maggie) pursued,
``he (man) gave me it frankly as his (man) reason.'' (she)

``To-day?'' (the Prince)
the Prince inquiringly echoed.

But she (Maggie) was singularly able--it had been marvellously

``given'' (she)
her (Maggie), she (Maggie) afterwards said to herself--to abide, for her (Maggie) light, for her (Maggie) clue, by her (Maggie) own order.

``I inspired him (man) with sympathy--there you are! But the miracle is that he (man) should have a sympathy to offer that could be of use to me. That was really the oddity of my chance,'' (the Princess)
the Princess proceeded--
``that I should have been moved, in my ignorance, to go precisely to him (man).'' (the Princess)

He (Prince) saw her (Princess) so keep her (Princess) course that it was as if he (Prince) could, at the best, but stand aside to watch her (Princess) and let her (Princess) pass; he (Prince) only made a vague demonstration that was like an ineffective gesture.

``I'm sorry to say any ill of your friends, and the thing was a long time ago; besides which there was nothing to make me recur to it. But I remember the man's striking me as a decided little beast.'' (She)

She (Princess) gave a slow headshake--as if, no, after consideration, not THAT way were an issue.

``I can only think of him (man) as kind, for he (man) had nothing to gain. He (man) had in fact only to lose. It was what he (man) came to tell me--that he (man) had asked me too high a price, more than the object was really worth. There was a particular reason, which he (man) hadn't mentioned, and which had made him (man) consider and repent. He (man) wrote for leave to see me again--wrote in such terms that I saw him (man) here this afternoon.'' (unknown)

``Here?'' (the Prince)
--it made the Prince look about him (Prince).

``Downstairs--in the little red room. While he (man) was waiting he (man) looked at the few photographs that stand about there and recognised two of them. Though it was so long ago, he (man) remembered the visit made him (man) by the lady and the gentleman, and that gave him (man) his (man) connexion. It gave me mine, for he (man) remembered everything and told me everything. You see you too had produced your effect; only, unlike you, he (man) had thought of it again--he (man) HAD recurred to it. He (man) told me of your having wished to make each other presents--but of that's not having come off. The lady was greatly taken with the piece I had bought of him (man), but you had your reason against receiving it from her (lady), and you had been right. He (man) would think that of you more than ever now,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on;
``he (man) would see how wisely you had guessed the flaw and how easily the bowl could be broken. I had bought it myself, you see, for a present--he (man) knew I was doing that. This was what had worked in him (man)--especially after the price I had paid.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Her (Maggie) story had dropped an instant; she (Maggie) still brought it out in small waves of energy, each of which spent its force; so that he (Prince) had an opportunity to speak before this force was renewed. But the quaint thing was what he (Prince) now said.

``And what, pray, WAS the price?'' (She)

She (Maggie) paused again a little.

``It was high, certainly--for those fragments. I think I feel, as I look at them there, rather ashamed to say.'' (The Prince)

The Prince then again looked at them; he (Prince) might have been growing used to the sight.

``But shall you at least get your money back?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I'm far from wanting it back--I feel so that I'm getting its worth.'' (he)
With which, before he (Prince) could reply, she (Maggie) had a quick transition.
``The great fact about the day we're talking of seems to me to have been, quite remarkably, that no present was then made me. If your undertaking had been for that, that was not at least what came of it.'' (unknown)

``You received then nothing at all?'' (The Prince)
The Prince looked vague and grave, almost retrospectively concerned.

``Nothing but an apology for empty hands and empty pockets; which was made me--as if it mattered a mite!--ever so frankly, ever so beautifully and touchingly.'' (Amerigo)

This Amerigo heard with interest, yet not with confusion.

``Ah, of course you couldn't have minded!'' (she)
Distinctly, as she (Maggie) went on, he (Prince) was getting the better of the mere awkwardness of his (Prince) arrest; quite as if making out that he (Prince) need SUFFER arrest from her (Maggie) now--before they should go forth to show themselves in the world together--in no greater quantity than an occasion ill-chosen at the best for a scene might decently make room for. He (Prince) looked at his (Prince) watch; their engagement, all the while, remained before him (Prince).
``But I don't make out, you see, what case against me you rest--'' (unknown)

``On everything I'm telling you? Why, the whole case--the case of your having for so long so successfully deceived me. The idea of your finding something for me--charming as that would have been--was what had least to do with your taking a morning together at that moment. What had really to do with it,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``was that you had to: you couldn't not, from the moment you were again face to face. And the reason of that was that there had been so much between you before--before I came between you at all.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Her (Maggie) husband had been for these last moments moving about under her (Maggie) eyes; but at this, as to check any show of impatience, he (husband) again stood still.

``You've never been more sacred to me than you were at that hour--unless perhaps you've become so at this one.'' (she)

The assurance of his (husband) speech, she (Maggie) could note, quite held up its head in him (husband); his (husband) eyes met her (Maggie) own so, for the declaration, that it was as if something cold and momentarily unimaginable breathed upon her (Maggie), from afar off, out of his (husband) strange consistency. She (Maggie) kept her (Maggie) direction still, however, under that.

``Oh, the thing I've known best of all is that you've never wanted, together, to offend us. You've wanted quite intensely not to, and the precautions you've had to take for it have been for a long time one of the strongest of my impressions. That, I think,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added,
``is the way I've best known.'' (she)

``Known?'' (he)
he (husband) repeated after a moment.

``Known. Known that you were older friends, and so much more intimate ones, than I had any reason to suppose when we married. Known there were things that hadn't been told me--and that gave their meaning, little by little, to other things that were before me.'' (unknown)

``Would they have made a difference, in the matter of our marriage,'' (the Prince)
the Prince presently asked,
``if you HAD known them?'' (the Prince)

She (Maggie) took her (Maggie) time to think.

``I grant you not--in the matter of OURS.'' (he)
And then as he (Prince) again fixed her (Maggie) with his (Prince) hard yearning, which he (Prince) couldn't keep down:
``The question is so much bigger than that. You see how much what I know makes of it for me.'' (he)
That was what acted on him (Prince), this iteration of her (Maggie) knowledge, into the question of the validity, of the various bearings of which, he (Prince) couldn't on the spot trust himself to pretend, in any high way, to go. What her (Maggie) claim, as she (Maggie) made it, represented for him (Prince)--that he (Prince) couldn't help betraying, if only as a consequence of the effect of the word itself, her (Maggie) repeated distinct
``know, know,'' (he)
on his (Prince) nerves. She (Maggie) was capable of being sorry for his (Prince) nerves at a time when he (Prince) should need them for dining out, pompously, rather responsibly, without his (Prince) heart in it; yet she (Maggie) was not to let that prevent her (Maggie) using, with all economy, so precious a chance for supreme clearness.
``I didn't force this upon you, you must recollect, and it probably wouldn't have happened for you if you hadn't come in.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Prince)
said the Prince,
``I was liable to come in, you know.'' (Prince)

``I didn't think you were this evening.'' (unknown)

``And why not?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Maggie) answered,
``you have many liabilities--of different sorts.'' (she)
With which she (Maggie) recalled what she (Maggie) had said to Fanny Assingham.
``And then you're so deep.'' (unknown)

It produced in his (Prince) features, in spite of his (Prince) control of them, one of those quick plays of expression, the shade of a grimace, that testified as nothing else did to his (Prince) race.

``It's you, cara, who are deep.'' (she)

Which, after an instant, she (Maggie) had accepted from him (Prince); she (Maggie) could so feel at last that it was true.

``Then I shall have need of it all.'' (unknown)

``But what would you have done,'' (he)
he (Prince) was by this time asking,
``if I HADN'T come in?'' (he)

``I don't know.'' (She)
She (Maggie) had hesitated.
``What would you?'' (unknown)

``Oh; I oh--that isn't the question. I depend upon you. I go on. You would have spoken to-morrow?'' (unknown)

``I think I would have waited.'' (unknown)

``And for what?'' (he)
he (Prince) asked.

``To see what difference it would make for myself. My possession at last, I mean, of real knowledge.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (the Prince)
said the Prince.

``My only point now, at any rate,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``is the difference, as I say, that it may make for YOU. Your knowing was--from the moment you did come in--all I had in view.'' (she)
And she (Maggie) sounded it again--he (Prince) should have it once more.
``Your knowing that I've ceased--'' (unknown)

``That you've ceased--?'' (she)
With her (Maggie) pause, in fact, she (Maggie) had fairly made him (Prince) press her (Maggie) for it.

``Why, to be as I was. NOT to know.'' (he)

It was once more then, after a little, that he (Prince) had had to stand receptive; yet the singular effect of this was that there was still something of the same sort he (Prince) was made to want. He (Prince) had another hesitation, but at last this odd quantity showed.

``Then does any one else know?'' (he)

It was as near as he (Prince) could come to naming her (Maggie) father, and she (Maggie) kept him (Prince) at that distance.

``Any one--?'' (unknown)

``Any one, I mean, but Fanny Assingham.'' (unknown)

``I should have supposed you had had by this time particular means of learning. I don't see,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said,
``why you ask me.'' (she)

Then, after an instant--and only after an instant, as she (Maggie) saw--he (Prince) made out what she (Maggie) meant; and it gave her (Maggie), all strangely enough, the still further light that Charlotte, for herself, knew as little as he (Prince) had known. The vision loomed, in this light, it fairly glared, for the few seconds--the vision of the two others alone together at Fawns, and Charlotte, as one of them, having gropingly to go on, always not knowing and not knowing! The picture flushed at the same time with all its essential colour--that of the so possible identity of her (Charlotte) father's motive and principle with her (Charlotte) own. HE (father) was

``deep,'' (HE)
as Amerigo called it, so that no vibration of the still air should reach his (father) daughter; just as she (daughter) had earned that description by making and by, for that matter, intending still to make, her (daughter) care for his (father) serenity, or at any rate for the firm outer shell of his (father) dignity, all marvellous enamel, her (daughter) paramount law. More strangely even than anything else, her (daughter) husband seemed to speak now but to help her (daughter) in this.
``I know nothing but what you tell me.'' (unknown)

``Then I've told you all I intended. Find out the rest--!'' (unknown)

``Find it out--?'' (He)
He (husband) waited.

She (daughter) stood before him (husband) a moment--it took that time to go on. Depth upon depth of her (daughter) situation, as she (daughter) met his (husband) face, surged and sank within her (daughter); but with the effect somehow, once more, that they rather lifted her (daughter) than let her (daughter) drop. She (daughter) had her (daughter) feet somewhere, through it all--it was her (daughter) companion, absolutely, who was at sea. And she (daughter) kept her (daughter) feet; she (daughter) pressed them to what was beneath her (daughter). She (daughter) went over to the bell beside the chimney and gave a ring that he (companion) could but take as a summons for her (daughter) maid. It stopped everything for the present; it was an intimation to him (companion) to go and dress. But she (daughter) had to insist.

``Find out for yourself!'' (the party)

PART FIFTH

XXXV

After the little party was again constituted at Fawns--which had taken, for completeness, some ten days--Maggie naturally felt herself still more possessed, in spirit, of everything that had last happened in London. There was a phrase that came back to her (Maggie) from old American years: she (Maggie) was having, by that idiom, the time of her (Maggie) life--she (Maggie) knew it by the perpetual throb of this sense of possession, which was almost too violent either to recognise or to hide. It was as if she (Maggie) had come out--that was her (Maggie) most general consciousness; out of a dark tunnel, a dense wood, or even simply a smoky room, and had thereby, at least, for going on, the advantage of air in her (Maggie) lungs. It was as if she (Maggie) were somehow at last gathering in the fruits of patience; she (Maggie) had either been really more patient than she (Maggie) had known at the time, or had been so for longer: the change brought about by itself as great a difference of view as the shift of an inch in the position of a telescope. It was her (Maggie) telescope in fact that had gained in range--just as her (Maggie) danger lay in her (Maggie) exposing herself to the observation by the more charmed, and therefore the more reckless, use of this optical resource. Not under any provocation to produce it in public was her (Maggie) unremitted rule; but the difficulties of duplicity had not shrunk, while the need of it had doubled. Humbugging, which she (Maggie) had so practised with her (Maggie) father, had been a comparatively simple matter on the basis of mere doubt; but the ground to be covered was now greatly larger, and she (Maggie) felt not unlike some young woman of the theatre who, engaged for a minor part in the play and having mastered her (Maggie) cues with anxious effort, should find herself suddenly promoted to leading lady and expected to appear in every act of the five. She (Maggie) had made much to her (Maggie) husband, that last night, of her (Maggie)

``knowing'' (husband)
; but it was exactly this quantity she (Maggie) now knew that, from the moment she (Maggie) could only dissimulate it, added to her (Maggie) responsibility and made of the latter all a mere question of having something precious and precarious in charge. There was no one to help her (Maggie) with it--not even Fanny Assingham now; this good friend's presence having become, inevitably, with that climax of their last interview in Portland Place, a severely simplified function. She (Maggie) had her (Maggie) use, oh yes, a thousand times; but it could only consist henceforth in her (Maggie) quite conspicuously touching at no point whatever--assuredly, at least with Maggie--the matter they had discussed. She (Maggie) was there, inordinately, as a value, but as a value only for the clear negation of everything. She (Maggie) was their general sign, precisely, of unimpaired beatitude--and she (Maggie) was to live up to that somewhat arduous character, poor thing, as she (Maggie) might. She (Maggie) might privately lapse from it, if she (Maggie) must, with Amerigo or with Charlotte--only not, of course, ever, so much as for the wink of an eye, with the master of the house. Such lapses would be her (Charlotte) own affair, which Maggie at present could take no thought of. She (Maggie) treated her (Maggie) young friend meanwhile, it was to be said, to no betrayal of such wavering; so that from the moment of her (Maggie) alighting at the door with the Colonel everything went on between them at concert pitch. What had she (Maggie) done, that last evening in Maggie's room, but bring the husband and wife more together than, as would seem, they had ever been? Therefore what indiscretion should she (wife) not show by attempting to go behind the grand appearance of her (wife) success?--which would be to court a doubt of her (wife) beneficent work. She (wife) knew accordingly nothing but harmony and diffused, restlessly, nothing but peace--an extravagant, expressive, aggressive peace, not incongruous, after all, with the solid calm of the place; a kind of helmetted, trident-shaking pax Britannica.

The peace, it must be added, had become, as the days elapsed, a peace quite generally animated and peopled--thanks to that fact of the presence of

``company'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
in which Maggie's ability to preserve an appearance had learned, from so far back, to find its best resource. It was not inconspicuous, it was in fact striking, that this resource, just now, seemed to meet in the highest degree every one's need: quite as if every one were, by the multiplication of human objects in the scene, by the creation, by the confusion, of fictive issues, hopeful of escaping somebody else's notice. It had reached the point, in truth, that the collective bosom might have been taken to heave with the knowledge of the descent upon adjacent shores, for a short period, of Mrs. Rance and the Lutches, still united, and still so divided, for conquest: the sense of the party showed at least, oddly enough, as favourable to the fancy of the quaint turn that some near
``week-end'' (the party)
might derive from their reappearance. This measured for Maggie the ground they had all travelled together since that unforgotten afternoon of the none so distant year, that determinant September Sunday when, sitting with her (Maggie) father in the park, as in commemoration of the climax both of their old order and of their old danger, she (Maggie) had proposed to him (father) that they should
``call in'' (him)
Charlotte,--call her (Charlotte) in as a specialist might be summoned to an invalid's chair. Wasn't it a sign of something rather portentous, their being ready to be beholden, as for a diversion, to the once despised Kitty and Dotty? That had already had its application, in truth, to her (Dotty) invocation of the Castledeans and several other members, again, of the historic Matcham week, made before she (Dotty) left town, and made, always consistently, with an idea--since she (Dotty) was never henceforth to approach these people without an idea, and since that lurid element of their intercourse grew and grew for her (Dotty) with each occasion. The flame with which it burned afresh during these particular days, the way it held up the torch to anything, to everything, that MIGHT have occurred as the climax of revels springing from traditions so vivified--this by itself justified her (Dotty) private motive and reconsecrated her (Dotty) diplomacy. She (Dotty) had already produced by the aid of these people something of the effect she (Dotty) sought--that of being
``good'' (she)
for whatever her (Dotty) companions were good for, and of not asking either of them to give up anyone or anything for her (Dotty) sake. There was moreover, frankly, a sharpness of point in it that she (Dotty) enjoyed; it gave an accent to the truth she (Dotty) wished to illustrate--the truth that the surface of her (Dotty) recent life, thick-sown with the flower of earnest endeavour, with every form of the unruffled and the undoubting, suffered no symptom anywhere to peep out. It was as if, under her (Dotty) pressure, neither party could get rid of the complicity, as it might be figured, of the other; as if, in a word, she (Dotty) saw Amerigo and Charlotte committed, for fear of betrayals on their own side, to a kind of wan consistency on the subject of Lady Castledean's
``set,'' (Lady Castledean/Castledean)
and this latter group, by the same stroke, compelled to assist at attestations the extent and bearing of which they rather failed to grasp and which left them indeed, in spite of hereditary high spirits, a trifle bewildered and even a trifle scared.

They made, none the less, at Fawns, for number, for movement, for sound--they played their parts during a crisis that must have hovered for them, in the long passages of the old house, after the fashion of the established ghost, felt, through the dark hours as a constant possibility, rather than have menaced them in the form of a daylight bore, one of the perceived outsiders who are liable to be met in the drawing-room or to be sat next to at dinner. If the Princess, moreover, had failed of her (Princess) occult use for so much of the machinery of diversion, she (Princess) would still have had a sense not other than sympathetic for the advantage now extracted from it by Fanny Assingham's bruised philosophy. This good friend's relation to it was actually the revanche, she (Assingham) sufficiently indicated, of her (Assingham) obscured lustre at Matcham, where she (Assingham) had known her (Assingham) way about so much less than most of the others. She (Assingham) knew it at Fawns, through the pathless wild of the right tone, positively better than any one, Maggie could note for her (Maggie); and her (Maggie) revenge had the magnanimity of a brave pointing out of it to every one else, a wonderful irresistible, conscious, almost compassionate patronage. Here was a house, she (Maggie) triumphantly caused it to be noted, in which she (Maggie) so bristled with values that some of them might serve, by her (Maggie) amused willingness to share, for such of the temporarily vague, among her (Maggie) fellow-guests, such of the dimly disconcerted, as had lost the key to their own. It may have been partly through the effect of this especial strain of community with her (Maggie) old friend that Maggie found herself, one evening, moved to take up again their dropped directness of reference. They had remained downstairs together late; the other women of the party had filed, singly or in couples, up the

``grand'' (couples)
staircase on which, from the equally grand hall, these retreats and advances could always be pleasantly observed; the men had apparently taken their way to the smoking-room; while the Princess, in possession thus of a rare reach of view, had lingered as if to enjoy it. Then she (Princess) saw that Mrs. Assingham was remaining a little--and as for the appreciation of her (Assingham) enjoyment; upon which they stood looking at each other across the cleared prospect until the elder woman, only vaguely expressive and tentative now, came nearer. It was like the act of asking if there were anything she (woman) could yet do, and that question was answered by her (woman) immediately feeling, on this closer view, as she (woman) had felt when presenting herself in Portland Place after Maggie's last sharp summons. Their understanding was taken up by these new snatched moments where that occasion had left it.

``He (me) has never told her (I) that I know. Of that I'm at last satisfied.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
And then as Mrs. Assingham opened wide eyes:
``I've been in the dark since we came down, not understanding what he (me) has been doing or intending--not making out what can have passed between them. But within a day or two I've begun to suspect, and this evening, for reasons--oh, too many to tell you!--I've been sure, since it explains. NOTHING has passed between them--that's what has happened. It explains,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
the Princess repeated with energy;
``it explains, it explains!'' (the Princess)
She (Princess) spoke in a manner that her (Princess) auditor was afterwards to describe to the Colonel, oddly enough, as that of the quietest excitement; she (Princess) had turned back to the chimney-place, where, in honour of a damp day and a chill night, the piled logs had turned to flame and sunk to embers; and the evident intensity of her (Princess) vision for the fact she (Princess) imparted made Fanny Assingham wait upon her (Assingham) words. It explained, this striking fact, more indeed than her (Assingham) companion, though conscious of fairly gaping with good-will, could swallow at once. The Princess, however, as for indulgence and confidence, quickly filled up the measure.
``He (me) hasn't let her (it) know that I know--and, clearly, doesn't mean to. He (me) has made up his (me) mind; he (me)'ll say nothing about it. Therefore, as she (it)'s quite unable to arrive at the knowledge by herself, she (it) has no idea how much I'm really in possession. She (it) believes,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``and, so far as her (it) own conviction goes, she (it) knows, that I'm not in possession of anything. And that, somehow, for my own help seems to me immense.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Immense, my dear!'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham applausively murmured, though not quite, even as yet, seeing all the way.
``He (me)'s keeping quiet then on purpose?'' (unknown)

``On purpose.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie's lighted eyes, at least, looked further than they had ever looked.
``He (me)'ll NEVER tell her (it) now.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny wondered; she (Fanny) cast about her (Fanny); most of all she (Fanny) admired her (Fanny) little friend, in whom this announcement was evidently animated by an heroic lucidity. She (Fanny) stood there, in her (Fanny) full uniform, like some small erect commander of a siege, an anxious captain who has suddenly got news, replete with importance for him (captain), of agitation, of division within the place. This importance breathed upon her (Fanny) comrade.

``So you're all right?'' (unknown)

``Oh, ALL right's a good deal to say. But I seem at least to see, as I haven't before, where I am with it.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny bountifully brooded; there was a point left vague.

``And you have it from him (me)?--your husband himself has told you?'' (me)

```Told' me--?''

``Why, what you speak of. It isn't of an assurance received from him (husband) then that you do speak?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

At which Maggie had continued to stare.

``Dear me, no. Do you suppose I've asked him (husband) for an assurance?'' (unknown)

``Ah, you haven't?'' (companion)
Her (Maggie) companion smiled.
``That's what I supposed you MIGHT mean. Then, darling, what HAVE you--?'' (unknown)

``Asked him (husband) for? I've asked him (husband) for nothing.'' (Fanny)

But this, in turn, made Fanny stare.

``Then nothing, that evening of the Embassy dinner, passed between you?'' (unknown)

``On the contrary, everything passed.'' (unknown)

``Everything--?'' (unknown)

``Everything. I told him (husband) what I knew--and I told him (husband) how I knew it.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham waited.

``And that was all?'' (unknown)

``Wasn't it quite enough?'' (unknown)

``Oh, love,'' (she)
she (Assingham) bridled,
``that's for you to have judged!'' (she)

``Then I HAVE judged,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie--
``I did judge. I made sure he (judge) understood--then I let him (judge) alone.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Mrs. Assingham wondered.

``But he (judge) didn't explain--?'' (unknown)

``Explain? Thank God, no!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie threw back her (Maggie) head as with horror at the thought, then the next moment added:
``And I didn't, either.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

The decency of pride in it shed a cold little light--yet as from heights at the base of which her (Maggie) companion rather panted.

``But if he (God) neither denies nor confesses--?'' (unknown)

``He (God) does what's a thousand times better--he (God) lets it alone. He (God) does,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on,
``as he (God) would do; as I see now that I was sure he (God) would. He (God) lets me alone.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Fanny Assingham turned it over.

``Then how do you know so where, as you say, you `are'?'' (unknown)

``Why, just BY that. I put him (God) in possession of the difference; the difference made, about me, by the fact that I hadn't been, after all--though with a wonderful chance, I admitted, helping me--too stupid to have arrived at knowledge. He (God) had to see that I'm changed for him (God)--quite changed from the idea of me that he (God) had so long been going on with. It became a question then of his (God) really taking in the change--and what I now see is that he (God) is doing so.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny followed as she (Fanny) could.

``Which he (God) shows by letting you, as you say, alone?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie looked at her (Maggie) a minute.

``And by letting her (God).'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham did what she (Assingham) might to embrace it--checked a little, however, by a thought that was the nearest approach she (Assingham) could have, in this almost too large air, to an inspiration.

``Ah, but does Charlotte let HIM?'' (unknown)

``Oh, that's another affair--with which I've practically nothing to do. I dare say, however, she (Charlotte) doesn't.'' (the Princess)
And the Princess had a more distant gaze for the image evoked by the question.
``I don't in fact well see how she (Charlotte) CAN. But the point for me is that he (God) understands.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham cooed,
``understands--?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Well, what I want. I want a happiness without a hole in it big enough for you to poke in your finger.'' (unknown)

``A brilliant, perfect surface--to begin with at least. I see.'' (unknown)

``The golden bowl--as it WAS to have been.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
And Maggie dwelt musingly on this obscured figure.
``The bowl with all our happiness in it. The bowl without the crack.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

For Mrs. Assingham too the image had its force, and the precious object shone before her (Assingham) again, reconstituted, plausible, presentable. But wasn't there still a piece missing?

``Yet if he (God) lets you alone and you only let him (God)--?'' (unknown)

``Mayn't our doing so, you mean, be noticed?--mayn't it give us away? Well, we hope not--we try not--we take such care. We alone know what's between us--we and you; and haven't you precisely been struck, since you've been here,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie asked,
``with our making so good a show?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Her (Maggie) friend hesitated.

``To your father?'' (her)

But it made her (Maggie) hesitate too; she (Maggie) wouldn't speak of her (Maggie) father directly.

``To everyone. To her (our)--now that you understand.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

It held poor Fanny again in wonder.

``To Charlotte--yes: if there's so much beneath it, for you, and if it's all such a plan. That makes it hang together it makes YOU hang together.'' (She)
She (Maggie) fairly exhaled her (Maggie) admiration.
``You're like nobody else--you're extraordinary.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie met it with appreciation, but with a reserve.

``No, I'm not extraordinary--but I AM, for every one, quiet.'' (unknown)

``Well, that's just what is extraordinary. `Quiet' is more than _I_ am, and you leave me far behind.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
With which, again, for an instant, Mrs. Assingham frankly brooded. ```Now that I understand,' you say--but there's one thing I don't understand.'' And the next minute, while her (Assingham) companion waited, she (Assingham) had mentioned it.
``How can Charlotte, after all, not have pressed him (YOU), not have attacked him (YOU) about it? How can she (Charlotte) not have asked him (YOU)--asked him (YOU) on his (YOU) honour, I mean--if you know?'' (unknown)

``How can she (Charlotte) `not'? Why, of course,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess limpidly,
``she (Charlotte) MUST!'' (the Princess)

``Well then--?'' (unknown)

``Well then, you think, he (YOU) must have told her (Charlotte)? Why, exactly what I mean,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``is that he (YOU) will have done nothing of the sort; will, as I say, have maintained the contrary.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Fanny Assingham weighed it.

``Under her (Charlotte) direct appeal for the truth?'' (unknown)

``Under her (Charlotte) direct appeal for the truth.'' (unknown)

``Her (Charlotte) appeal to his (YOU) honour?'' (unknown)

``Her (Charlotte) appeal to his (YOU) honour. That's my point.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny Assingham braved it.

``For the truth as from him (YOU) to her (Charlotte)?'' (unknown)

``From him (YOU) to any one.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham's face lighted.

``He (YOU)'ll simply, he (YOU)'ll insistently have lied?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie brought it out roundly.

``He (YOU)'ll simply, he (YOU)'ll insistently have lied.'' (companion)

It held again her (Maggie) companion, who next, however, with a single movement, throwing herself on her (Maggie) neck, overflowed.

``Oh, if you knew how you help me!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie had liked her (Maggie) to understand, so far as this was possible; but had not been slow to see afterwards how the possibility was limited, when one came to think, by mysteries she (Maggie) was not to sound. This inability in her (Maggie) was indeed not remarkable, inasmuch as the Princess herself, as we have seen, was only now in a position to boast of touching bottom. Maggie lived, inwardly, in a consciousness that she (Maggie) could but partly open even to so good a friend, and her (Maggie) own visitation of the fuller expanse of which was, for that matter, still going on. They had been duskier still, however, these recesses of her (Maggie) imagination--that, no doubt, was what might at present be said for them. She (Maggie) had looked into them, on the eve of her (Maggie) leaving town, almost without penetration: she (Maggie) had made out in those hours, and also, of a truth, during the days which immediately followed, little more than the strangeness of a relation having for its chief mark--whether to be prolonged or not--the absence of any

``intimate'' (she)
result of the crisis she (Maggie) had invited her (Maggie) husband to recognise. They had dealt with this crisis again, face to face, very briefly, the morning after the scene in her (Maggie) room--but with the odd consequence of her (Maggie) having appeared merely to leave it on his (husband) hands. He (husband) had received it from her (Maggie) as he (husband) might have received a bunch of keys or a list of commissions--attentive to her (Maggie) instructions about them, but only putting them, for the time, very carefully and safely, into his (husband) pocket. The instructions had seemed, from day to day, to make so little difference for his (husband) behaviour--that is for his (husband) speech or his (husband) silence; to produce, as yet, so little of the fruit of action. He (husband) had taken from her (Maggie), on the spot, in a word, before going to dress for dinner, all she (Maggie) then had to give--after which, on the morrow, he (husband) had asked her (Maggie) for more, a good deal as if she (Maggie) might have renewed her (Maggie) supply during the night; but he (husband) had had at his (husband) command for this latter purpose an air of extraordinary detachment and discretion, an air amounting really to an appeal which, if she (Maggie) could have brought herself to describe it vulgarly, she (Maggie) would have described as cool, just as he (husband) himself would have described it in any one else as
``cheeky'' (he)
; a suggestion that she (Maggie) should trust him (husband) on the particular ground since she (Maggie) didn't on the general. Neither his (husband) speech nor his (husband) silence struck her (Maggie) as signifying more, or less, under this pressure, than they had seemed to signify for weeks past; yet if her (Maggie) sense hadn't been absolutely closed to the possibility in him (husband) of any thought of wounding her (Maggie), she (Maggie) might have taken his (husband) undisturbed manner, the perfection of his (husband) appearance of having recovered himself, for one of those intentions of high impertinence by the aid of which great people, les grands seigneurs, persons of her (Maggie) husband's class and type, always know how to re-establish a violated order.

It was her (Maggie) one purely good fortune that she (Maggie) could feel thus sure impertinence--to HER at any rate--was not among the arts on which he (husband) proposed to throw himself; for though he (husband) had, in so almost mystifying a manner, replied to nothing, denied nothing, explained nothing, apologised for nothing, he (husband) had somehow conveyed to her (Maggie) that this was not because of any determination to treat her (Maggie) case as not

``worth'' (he)
it. There had been consideration, on both occasions, in the way he (husband) had listened to her (Maggie)--even though at the same time there had been extreme reserve; a reserve indeed, it was also to be remembered, qualified by the fact that, on their second and shorter interview, in Portland Place, and quite at the end of this passage, she (Maggie) had imagined him (husband) positively proposing to her (Maggie) a temporary accommodation. It had been but the matter of something in the depths of the eyes he (husband) finally fixed upon her (Maggie), and she (Maggie) had found in it, the more she (Maggie) kept it before her (Maggie), the tacitly-offered sketch of a working arrangement.
``Leave me my reserve; don't question it--it's all I have, just now, don't you see? so that, if you'll make me the concession of letting me alone with it for as long a time as I require, I promise you something or other, grown under cover of it, even though I don't yet quite make out what, as a return for your patience.'' (She)
She (Maggie) had turned away from him (husband) with some such unspoken words as that in her (Maggie) ear, and indeed she (Maggie) had to represent to herself that she (Maggie) had spiritually heard them, had to listen to them still again, to explain her (Maggie) particular patience in face of his (husband) particular failure. He (husband) hadn't so much as pretended to meet for an instant the question raised by her (Maggie) of her (Maggie) accepted ignorance of the point in time, the period before their own marriage, from which his (husband) intimacy with Charlotte dated. As an ignorance in which he (husband) and Charlotte had been personally interested--and to the pitch of consummately protecting, for years, each other's interest--as a condition so imposed upon her (Charlotte) the fact of its having ceased might have made it, on the spot, the first article of his (husband) defence. He (husband) had vouchsafed it, however, nothing better than his (husband) longest stare of postponed consideration. That tribute he (husband) had coldly paid it, and Maggie might herself have been stupefied, truly, had she (Maggie) not had something to hold on by, at her (Maggie) own present ability, even provisional, to make terms with a chapter of history into which she (Maggie) could but a week before not have dipped without a mortal chill. At the rate at which she (Maggie) was living she (Maggie) was getting used hour by hour to these extensions of view; and when she (Maggie) asked herself, at Fawns, to what single observation of her (Maggie) own, in London, the Prince had had an affirmation to oppose, she (Maggie) but just failed to focus the small strained wife of the moments in question as some panting dancer of a difficult step who had capered, before the footlights of an empty theatre, to a spectator lounging in a box.

Her (dancer) best comprehension of Amerigo's success in not committing himself was in her (dancer) recall, meanwhile, of the inquiries he (spectator) had made of her (dancer) on their only return to the subject, and which he (spectator) had in fact explicitly provoked their return in order to make. He (spectator) had had it over with her (dancer) again, the so distinctly remarkable incident of her (dancer) interview at home with the little Bloomsbury shopman. This anecdote, for him (spectator), had, not altogether surprisingly, required some straighter telling, and the Prince's attitude in presence of it had represented once more his (Prince) nearest approach to a cross-examination. The difficulty in respect to the little man had been for the question of his (Prince) motive--his (Prince) motive in writing, first, in the spirit of retraction, to a lady with whom he (Prince) had made a most advantageous bargain, and in then coming to see her (lady) so that his (Prince) apology should be personal. Maggie had felt her (Maggie) explanation weak; but there were the facts, and she (Maggie) could give no other. Left alone, after the transaction, with the knowledge that his (Prince) visitor designed the object bought of him (Prince) as a birthday-gift to her (Maggie) father--for Maggie confessed freely to having chattered to him (Prince) almost as to a friend--the vendor of the golden bowl had acted on a scruple rare enough in vendors of any class, and almost unprecedented in the thrifty children of Israel. He (Prince) hadn't liked what he (Prince) had done, and what he (Prince) had above all made such a

``good thing'' (he)
of having done; at the thought of his (Prince) purchaser's good faith and charming presence, opposed to that flaw in her (Maggie) acquestion which would make it, verily, as an offering to a loved parent, a thing of sinister meaning and evil effect, he (Prince) had known conscientious, he (Prince) had known superstitious visitings, had given way to a whim all the more remarkable to his (Prince) own commercial mind, no doubt, from its never having troubled him (Prince) in other connexions. She (Maggie) had recognised the oddity of her (Maggie) adventure and left it to show for what it was. She (Maggie) had not been unconscious, on the other hand, that if it hadn't touched Amerigo so nearly he (Prince) would have found in it matter for some amused reflection. He (Prince) had uttered an extraordinary sound, something between a laugh and a howl, on her (Maggie) saying, as she (Maggie) had made a point of doing:
``Oh, most certainly, he (my) TOLD me his (my) reason was because he (my) `liked' me'' (she)
--though she (Maggie) remained in doubt of whether that inarticulate comment had been provoked most by the familiarities she (Maggie) had offered or by those that, so pictured, she (Maggie) had had to endure. That the partner of her (Maggie) bargain had yearned to see her (Maggie) again, that he (Prince) had plainly jumped at a pretext for it, this also she (Maggie) had frankly expressed herself to the Prince as having, in no snubbing, no scandalised, but rather in a positively appreciative and indebted spirit, not delayed to make out. He (Prince) had wished, ever so seriously, to return her (Maggie) a part of her (Maggie) money, and she (Maggie) had wholly declined to receive it; and then he (Prince) had uttered his (Prince) hope that she (Maggie) had not, at all events, already devoted the crystal cup to the beautiful purpose she (Maggie) had, so kindly and so fortunately, named to him (Prince). It wasn't a thing for a present to a person she (Maggie) was fond of, for she (Maggie) wouldn't wish to give a present that would bring ill luck. That had come to him (Prince)--so that he (Prince) couldn't rest, and he (Prince) should feel better now that he (Prince) had told her (Maggie). His (Prince) having led her (Maggie) to act in ignorance was what he (Prince) should have been ashamed of; and, if she (Maggie) would pardon, gracious lady as she (Maggie) was, all the liberties he (Prince) had taken, she (Maggie) might make of the bowl any use in life but that one.

It was after this that the most extraordinary incident of all, of course, had occurred--his (Prince) pointing to the two photographs with the remark that those were persons he (Prince) knew, and that, more wonderful still, he (Prince) had made acquaintance with them, years before, precisely over the same article. The lady, on that occasion, had taken up the fancy of presenting it to the gentleman, and the gentleman, guessing and dodging ever so cleverly, had declared that he (gentleman) wouldn't for the world receive an object under such suspicion. He (gentleman) himself, the little man had confessed, wouldn't have minded--about THEM; but he (man) had never forgotten either their talk or their faces, the impression altogether made by them, and, if she (lady) really wished to know, now, what had perhaps most moved him (man), it was the thought that she (lady) should ignorantly have gone in for a thing not good enough for other buyers. He (man) had been immensely struck--that was another point--with this accident of their turning out, after so long, friends of hers too: they had disappeared, and this was the only light he (man) had ever had upon them. He (man) had flushed up, quite red, with his (man) recognition, with all his (man) responsibility--had declared that the connexion must have had, mysteriously, something to do with the impulse he (man) had obeyed. And Maggie had made, to her (Maggie) husband, while he (husband) again stood before her (Maggie), no secret of the shock, for herself, so suddenly and violently received. She (Maggie) had done her (Maggie) best, even while taking it full in the face, not to give herself away; but she (Maggie) wouldn't answer--no, she (Maggie) wouldn't--for what she (Maggie) might, in her (Maggie) agitation, have made her (Maggie) informant think. He (informant) might think what he (informant) would--there had been three or four minutes during which, while she (Maggie) asked him (informant) question upon question, she (Maggie) had doubtless too little cared. And he (informant) had spoken, for his (informant) remembrance, as fully as she (Maggie) could have wished; he (informant) had spoken, oh, delightedly, for the

``terms'' (he)
on which his (informant) other visitors had appeared to be with each other, and in fact for that conviction of the nature and degree of their intimacy under which, in spite of precautions, they hadn't been able to help leaving him (informant). He (informant) had observed and judged and not forgotten; he (informant) had been sure they were great people, but no, ah no, distinctly, hadn't
``liked'' (people)
them as he (informant) liked the Signora Principessa. Certainly--she (Maggie) had created no vagueness about that--he (informant) had been in possession of her (Maggie) name and address, for sending her (Maggie) both her (Maggie) cup and her (Maggie) account. But the others he (informant) had only, always, wondered about--he (informant) had been sure they would never come back. And as to the time of their visit, he (informant) could place it, positively, to a day--by reason of a transaction of importance, recorded in his (informant) books, that had occurred but a few hours later. He (informant) had left her (Maggie), in short, definitely rejoicing that he (informant) had been able to make up to her (Maggie) for not having been quite
``square'' (he)
over their little business by rendering her (Maggie), so unexpectedly, the service of this information. His (informant) joy, moreover, was--as much as Amerigo would!--a matter of the personal interest with which her (Maggie) kindness, gentleness, grace, her (Maggie) charming presence and easy humanity and familiarity, had inspired him (informant). All of which, while, in thought, Maggie went over it again and again--oh, over any imputable rashness of her (Maggie) own immediate passion and pain, as well as over the rest of the straight little story she (Maggie) had, after all, to tell--might very conceivably make a long sum for the Prince to puzzle out.

There were meanwhile, after the Castledeans and those invited to meet them had gone, and before Mrs. Rance and the Lutches had come, three or four days during which she (Rance) was to learn the full extent of her (Rance) need not to be penetrable; and then it was indeed that she (Rance) felt all the force, and threw herself upon all the help, of the truth she (Rance) had confided, several nights earlier, to Fanny Assingham. She (Assingham) had known it in advance, had warned herself of it while the house was full: Charlotte had designs upon her (Charlotte) of a nature best known to herself, and was only waiting for the better opportunity of their finding themselves less companioned. This consciousness had been exactly at the bottom of Maggie's wish to multiply their spectators; there were moments for her (Maggie), positively, moments of planned postponement, of evasion scarcely less disguised than studied, during which she (Maggie) turned over with anxiety the different ways--there being two or three possible ones--in which her (Maggie) young stepmother might, at need, seek to work upon her (Maggie). Amerigo's not having

``told'' (Amerigo)
her (Maggie) of his (spectators) passage with his (spectators) wife gave, for Maggie, altogether a new aspect to Charlotte's consciousness and condition--an aspect with which, for apprehension, for wonder, and even, at moments, inconsequently enough, for something like compassion, the Princess had now to reckon. She (Princess) asked herself--for she (Princess) was capable of that--what he (spectators) had MEANT by keeping the sharer of his (spectators) guilt in the dark about a matter touching her (Princess) otherwise so nearly; what he (spectators) had meant, that is, for this unmistakably mystified personage herself. Maggie could imagine what he (spectators) had meant for her (Maggie)--all sorts of thinkable things, whether things of mere
``form'' (he)
or things of sincerity, things of pity or things of prudence: he (spectators) had meant, for instance, in all probability, primarily, to conjure away any such appearance of a changed relation between the two women as his (spectators) father-in-law might notice and follow up. It would have been open to him (spectators) however, given the pitch of their intimacy, to avert this danger by some more conceivable course with Charlotte; since an earnest warning, in fact, the full freedom of alarm, that of his (spectators) insisting to her (Charlotte) on the peril of suspicion incurred, and on the importance accordingly of outward peace at any price, would have been the course really most conceivable. Instead of warning and advising he (spectators) had reassured and deceived her (Charlotte); so that our young woman, who had been, from far back, by the habit, if her (Charlotte) nature, as much on her (Charlotte) guard against sacrificing others as if she (Charlotte) felt the great trap of life mainly to be set for one's doing so, now found herself attaching her (Charlotte) fancy to that side of the situation of the exposed pair which involved, for themselves at least, the sacrifice of the least fortunate.

She (Charlotte) never, at present, thought of what Amerigo might be intending, without the reflection, by the same stroke, that, whatever this quantity, he (guard) was leaving still more to her (Charlotte) own ingenuity. He (guard) was helping her (Charlotte), when the thing came to the test, only by the polished, possibly almost too polished surface his (guard) manner to his (guard) wife wore for an admiring world; and that, surely, was entitled to scarcely more than the praise of negative diplomacy. He (guard) was keeping his (guard) manner right, as she (wife) had related to Mrs. Assingham; the case would have been beyond calculation, truly, if, on top of everything, he (guard) had allowed it to go wrong. She (wife) had hours of exaltation indeed when the meaning of all this pressed in upon her (wife) as a tacit vow from him (guard) to abide without question by whatever she (wife) should be able to achieve or think fit to prescribe. Then it was that, even while holding her (wife) breath for the awe of it, she (wife) truly felt almost able enough for anything. It was as if she (wife) had passed, in a time incredibly short, from being nothing for him (guard) to being all; it was as if, rightly noted, every turn of his (guard) head, every tone of his (guard) voice, in these days, might mean that there was but one way in which a proud man reduced to abjection could hold himself. During those of Maggie's vigils in which that view loomed largest, the image of her (Maggie) husband that it thus presented to her (Maggie) gave out a beauty for the revelation of which she (Maggie) struck herself as paying, if anything, all too little. To make sure of it--to make sure of the beauty shining out of the humility, and of the humility lurking in all the pride of his (husband) presence--she (Maggie) would have gone the length of paying more yet, of paying with difficulties and anxieties compared to which those actually before her (Maggie) might have been as superficial as headaches or rainy days.

The point at which these exaltations dropped, however, was the point at which it was apt to come over her (Maggie) that if her (Maggie) complications had been greater the question of paying would have been limited still less to the liabilities of her (Maggie) own pocket. The complications were verily great enough, whether for ingenuities or sublimities, so long as she (Maggie) had to come back to it so often that Charlotte, all the while, could only be struggling with secrets sharper than her (Charlotte) own. It was odd how that certainty again and again determined and coloured her (Charlotte) wonderments of detail; the question, for instance, of HOW Amerigo, in snatched opportunities of conference, put the haunted creature off with false explanations, met her (Charlotte) particular challenges and evaded--if that was what he (Charlotte) did do!--her (Charlotte) particular demands. Even the conviction that Charlotte was but awaiting some chance really to test her (Charlotte) trouble upon her (Charlotte) lover's wife left Maggie's sense meanwhile open as to the sight of gilt wires and bruised wings, the spacious but suspended cage, the home of eternal unrest, of pacings, beatings, shakings, all so vain, into which the baffled consciousness helplessly resolved itself. The cage was the deluded condition, and Maggie, as having known delusion--rather!--understood the nature of cages. She (Maggie) walked round Charlotte's--cautiously and in a very wide circle; and when, inevitably, they had to communicate she (Maggie) felt herself, comparatively, outside, on the breast of nature, and saw her (Maggie) companion's face as that of a prisoner looking through bars. So it was that through bars, bars richly gilt, but firmly, though discreetly, planted, Charlotte finally struck her (Charlotte) as making a grim attempt; from which, at first, the Princess drew back as instinctively as if the door of the cage had suddenly been opened from within.

XXXVI

They had been alone that evening--alone as a party of six, and four of them, after dinner, under suggestion not to be resisted, sat down to

``bridge'' (a party)
in the smoking-room. They had passed together to that apartment, on rising from table, Charlotte and Mrs. Assingham alike indulgent, always, to tobacco, and in fact practising an emulation which, as Fanny said, would, for herself, had the Colonel not issued an interdict based on the fear of her (Fanny) stealing his (Colonel) cigars, have stopped only at the short pipe. Here cards had with inevitable promptness asserted their rule, the game forming itself, as had often happened before, of Mr. Verver with Mrs. Assingham for partner and of the Prince with Mrs. Verver. The Colonel, who had then asked of Maggie license to relieve his (Colonel) mind of a couple of letters for the earliest post out on the morrow, was addressing himself to this task at the other end of the room, and the Princess herself had welcomed the comparatively hushed hour--for the bridge-players were serious and silent--much in the mood of a tired actress who has the good fortune to be
``off,'' (a actress)
while her (actress) mates are on, almost long enough for a nap on the property sofa in the wing. Maggie's nap, had she (Maggie) been able to snatch forty winks, would have been of the spirit rather than of the sense; yet as she (Maggie) subsided, near a lamp, with the last salmon-coloured French periodical, she (Maggie) was to fail, for refreshment, even of that sip of independence.

There was no question for her (Maggie), as she (Maggie) found, of closing her (Maggie) eyes and getting away; they strayed back to life, in the stillness, over the top of her (Maggie) Review; she (Maggie) could lend herself to none of those refinements of the higher criticism with which its pages bristled; she (Maggie) was there, where her (Maggie) companions were, there again and more than ever there; it was as if, of a sudden, they had been made, in their personal intensity and their rare complexity of relation, freshly importunate to her (Maggie). It was the first evening there had been no one else. Mrs. Rance and the Lutches were due the next day; but meanwhile the facts of the situation were upright for her (Rance) round the green cloth and the silver flambeaux; the fact of her (Rance) father's wife's lover facing his (lover) mistress; the fact of her (Rance) father sitting, all unsounded and unblinking, between them; the fact of Charlotte keeping it up, keeping up everything, across the table, with her (Charlotte) husband beside her (Charlotte); the fact of Fanny Assingham, wonderful creature, placed opposite to the three and knowing more about each, probably, when one came to think, than either of them knew of either. Erect above all for her (Charlotte) was the sharp-edged fact of the relation of the whole group, individually and collectively, to herself--herself so speciously eliminated for the hour, but presumably more present to the attention of each than the next card to be played.

Yes, under that imputation, to her (Charlotte) sense, they sat--the imputation of wondering, beneath and behind all their apparently straight play, if she (Charlotte) weren't really watching them from her (Charlotte) corner and consciously, as might be said, holding them in her (Charlotte) hand. She (Charlotte) was asking herself at last how they could bear it--for, though cards were as nought to her (Charlotte) and she (Charlotte) could follow no move, so that she (Charlotte) was always, on such occasions, out of the party, they struck her (Charlotte) as conforming alike, in the matter of gravity and propriety, to the stiff standard of the house. Her (Charlotte) father, she (Charlotte) knew, was a high adept, one of the greatest--she (Charlotte) had been ever, in her (Charlotte) stupidity, his (father) small, his (father) sole despair; Amerigo excelled easily, as he (father) understood and practised every art that could beguile large leisure; Mrs. Assingham and Charlotte, moreover, were accounted as

``good'' (Charlotte)
as members of a sex incapable of the nobler consistency could be. Therefore, evidently, they were not, all so up to their usual form, merely passing it off, whether for her (Assingham) or for themselves; and the amount of enjoyed, or at least achieved, security represented by so complete a conquest of appearances was what acted on her (Assingham) nerves, precisely, with a kind of provocative force. She (Assingham) found herself, for five minutes, thrilling with the idea of the prodigious effect that, just as she (Assingham) sat there near them, she (Assingham) had at her (Assingham) command; with the sense that if she (Assingham) were but different--oh, ever so different!--all this high decorum would hang by a hair. There reigned for her (Assingham), absolutely, during these vertiginous moments, that fascination of the monstrous, that temptation of the horribly possible, which we so often trace by its breaking out suddenly, lest it should go further, in unexplained retreats and reactions.

After it had been thus vividly before her (Assingham) for a little that, springing up under her (Assingham) wrong and making them all start, stare and turn pale, she (Assingham) might sound out their doom in a single sentence, a sentence easy to choose among several of the lurid--after she (Assingham) had faced that blinding light and felt it turn to blackness, she (Assingham) rose from her (Assingham) place, laying aside her (Assingham) magazine, and moved slowly round the room, passing near the card-players and pausing an instant behind the chairs in turn. Silent and discreet, she (Assingham) bent a vague mild face upon them, as if to signify that, little as she (Assingham) followed their doings, she (Assingham) wished them well; and she (Assingham) took from each, across the table, in the common solemnity, an upward recognition which she (Assingham) was to carry away with her (Assingham) on her (Assingham) moving out to the terrace, a few minutes later. Her (Assingham) father and her (Assingham) husband, Mrs. Assingham and Charlotte, had done nothing but meet her (Assingham) eyes; yet the difference in these demonstrations made each a separate passage--which was all the more wonderful since, with the secret behind every face, they had alike tried to look at her (Assingham) THROUGH it and in denial of it.

It all left her (Assingham), as she (Assingham) wandered off, with the strangest of impressions--the sense, forced upon her (Assingham) as never yet, of an appeal, a positive confidence, from the four pairs of eyes, that was deeper than any negation, and that seemed to speak, on the part of each, of some relation to be contrived by her (Assingham), a relation with herself, which would spare the individual the danger, the actual present strain, of the relation with the others. They thus tacitly put it upon her (Assingham) to be disposed of, the whole complexity of their peril, and she (Assingham) promptly saw why because she (Assingham) was there, and there just as she (Assingham) was, to lift it off them and take it; to charge herself with it as the scapegoat of old, of whom she (Assingham) had once seen a terrible picture, had been charged with the sins of the people and had gone forth into the desert to sink under his (Assingham) burden and die. That indeed wasn't THEIR design and their interest, that she (Assingham) should sink under hers; it wouldn't be their feeling that she (Assingham) should do anything but live, live on somehow for their benefit, and even as much as possible in their company, to keep proving to them that they had truly escaped and that she (Assingham) was still there to simplify. This idea of her (Assingham) simplifying, and of their combined struggle, dim as yet but steadily growing, toward the perception of her (Assingham) adopting it from them, clung to her (Assingham) while she (Assingham) hovered on the terrace, where the summer night was so soft that she (Assingham) scarce needed the light shawl she (Assingham) had picked up. Several of the long windows of the occupied rooms stood open to it, and the light came out in vague shafts and fell upon the old smooth stones. The hour was moonless and starless and the air heavy and still--which was why, in her (Assingham) evening dress, she (Assingham) need fear no chill and could get away, in the outer darkness, from that provocation of opportunity which had assaulted her (Assingham), within, on her (Assingham) sofa, as a beast might have leaped at her (Assingham) throat.

Nothing in fact was stranger than the way in which, when she (Assingham) had remained there a little, her (Assingham) companions, watched by her (Assingham) through one of the windows, actually struck her (Assingham) as almost consciously and gratefully safer. They might have been--really charming as they showed in the beautiful room, and Charlotte certainly, as always, magnificently handsome and supremely distinguished--they might have been figures rehearsing some play of which she (Charlotte) herself was the author; they might even, for the happy appearance they continued to present, have been such figures as would, by the strong note of character in each, fill any author with the certitude of success, especially of their own histrionic. They might in short have represented any mystery they would; the point being predominantly that the key to the mystery, the key that could wind and unwind it without a snap of the spring, was there in her (Charlotte) pocket--or rather, no doubt, clasped at this crisis in her (Charlotte) hand and pressed, as she (Charlotte) walked back and forth, to her (Charlotte) breast. She (Charlotte) walked to the end and far out of the light; she (Charlotte) returned and saw the others still where she (Charlotte) had left them; she (Charlotte) passed round the house and looked into the drawing-room, lighted also, but empty now, and seeming to speak the more, in its own voice, of all the possibilities she (Charlotte) controlled. Spacious and splendid, like a stage again awaiting a drama, it was a scene she (Charlotte) might people, by the press of her (Charlotte) spring, either with serenities and dignities and decencies, or with terrors and shames and ruins, things as ugly as those formless fragments of her (Charlotte) golden bowl she (Charlotte) was trying so hard to pick up.

She (Charlotte) continued to walk and continued to pause; she (Charlotte) stopped afresh for the look into the smoking-room, and by this time--it was as if the recognition had of itself arrested her (Charlotte)--she (Charlotte) saw as in a picture, with the temptation she (Charlotte) had fled from quite extinct, why it was she (Charlotte) had been able to give herself so little, from the first, to the vulgar heat of her (Charlotte) wrong. She (Charlotte) might fairly, as she (Charlotte) watched them, have missed it as a lost thing; have yearned for it, for the straight vindictive view, the rights of resentment, the rages of jealousy, the protests of passion, as for something she (Charlotte) had been cheated of not least: a range of feelings which for many women would have meant so much, but which for HER husband's wife, for HER father's daughter, figured nothing nearer to experience than a wild eastern caravan, looming into view with crude colours in the sun, fierce pipes in the air, high spears against the sky, all a thrill, a natural joy to mingle with, but turning off short before it reached her (daughter) and plunging into other defiles. She (daughter) saw at all events why horror itself had almost failed her (daughter); the horror that, foreshadowed in advance, would, by her (daughter) thought, have made everything that was unaccustomed in her (daughter) cry out with pain; the horror of finding evil seated, all at its ease, where she (daughter) had only dreamed of good; the horror of the thing HIDEOUSLY behind, behind so much trusted, so much pretended, nobleness, cleverness, tenderness. It was the first sharp falsity she (daughter) had known in her (daughter) life, to touch at all, or be touched by; it had met her (daughter) like some bad-faced stranger surprised in one of the thick-carpeted corridors of a house of quiet on a Sunday afternoon; and yet, yes, amazingly, she (daughter) had been able to look at terror and disgust only to know that she (daughter) must put away from her (daughter) the bitter-sweet of their freshness. The sight, from the window, of the group so constituted, TOLD her (daughter) why, told her (daughter) how, named to her (daughter), as with hard lips, named straight AT her (daughter), so that she (daughter) must take it full in the face, that other possible relation to the whole fact which alone would bear upon her (daughter) irresistibly. It was extraordinary: they positively brought home to her (daughter) that to feel about them in any of the immediate, inevitable, assuaging ways, the ways usually open to innocence outraged and generosity betrayed, would have been to give them up, and that giving them up was, marvellously, not to be thought of. She (daughter) had never, from the first hour of her (daughter) state of acquired conviction, given them up so little as now; though she (daughter) was, no doubt, as the consequence of a step taken a few minutes later, to invoke the conception of doing that, if might be, even less. She (daughter) had resumed her (daughter) walk--stopping here and there, while she (daughter) rested on the cool smooth stone balustrade, to draw it out; in the course of which, after a little, she (daughter) passed again the lights of the empty drawing-room and paused again for what she (daughter) saw and felt there.

It was not at once, however, that this became quite concrete; that was the effect of her (daughter) presently making out that Charlotte was in the room, launched and erect there, in the middle, and looking about her (Charlotte); that she (Charlotte) had evidently just come round to it, from her (Charlotte) card-table, by one of the passages--with the expectation, to all appearance, of joining her (Charlotte) stepdaughter. She (Charlotte) had pulled up at seeing the great room empty--Maggie not having passed out, on leaving the group, in a manner to be observed. So definite a quest of her (Maggie), with the bridge-party interrupted or altered for it, was an impression that fairly assailed the Princess, and to which something of attitude and aspect, of the air of arrested pursuit and purpose, in Charlotte, together with the suggestion of her (Charlotte) next vague movements, quickly added its meaning. This meaning was that she (Charlotte) had decided, that she (Charlotte) had been infinitely conscious of Maggie's presence before, that she (Charlotte) knew that she (Charlotte) would at last find her (Charlotte) alone, and that she (Charlotte) wanted her (Charlotte), for some reason, enough to have presumably called on Bob Assingham for aid. He (Assingham) had taken her (Charlotte) chair and let her (Charlotte) go, and the arrangement was for Maggie a signal proof of her (Maggie) earnestness; of the energy, in fact, that, though superficially commonplace in a situation in which people weren't supposed to be watching each other, was what affected our young woman, on the spot, as a breaking of bars. The splendid shining supple creature was out of the cage, was at large; and the question now almost grotesquely rose of whether she (woman) mightn't by some art, just where she (woman) was and before she (woman) could go further, be hemmed in and secured.
