It would have been for a moment, in this case, a matter of quickly closing the windows and giving the alarm--with poor Maggie's sense that, though she (Maggie) couldn't know what she (Maggie) wanted of her (Maggie), it was enough for trepidation that, at these firm hands, anything should be to say nothing of the sequel of a flight taken again along the terrace, even under the shame of the confessed feebleness of such evasions on the part of an outraged wife. It was to this feebleness, none the less, that the outraged wife had presently resorted; the most that could be said for her (wife) being, as she (wife) felt while she (wife) finally stopped short, at a distance, that she (wife) could at any rate resist her (wife) abjection sufficiently not to sneak into the house by another way and safely reach her (wife) room. She (wife) had literally caught herself in the act of dodging and ducking, and it told her (wife) there, vividly, in a single word, what she (wife) had all along been most afraid of.

She (wife) had been afraid of the particular passage with Charlotte that would determine her (Charlotte) father's wife to take him (father) into her (Charlotte) confidence as she (Charlotte) couldn't possibly as yet have done, to prepare for him (father) a statement of her (Charlotte) wrong, to lay before him (father) the infamy of what she (Charlotte) was apparently suspected of. This, should she (Charlotte) have made up her (Charlotte) mind to do it, would rest on a calculation the thought of which evoked, strangely, other possibilities and visions. It would show her (Charlotte) as sufficiently believing in her (Charlotte) grasp of her (Charlotte) husband to be able to assure herself that, with his (husband) daughter thrown on the defensive, with Maggie's cause and Maggie's word, in fine, against her (Maggie) own, it wasn't Maggie's that would most certainly carry the day. Such a glimpse of her (Maggie) conceivable idea, which would be founded on reasons all her (Maggie) own, reasons of experience and assurance, impenetrable to others, but intimately familiar to herself--such a glimpse opened out wide as soon as it had come into view; for if so much as this was still firm ground between the elder pair, if the beauty of appearances had been so consistently preserved, it was only the golden bowl as Maggie herself knew it that had been broken. The breakage stood not for any wrought discomposure among the triumphant three--it stood merely for the dire deformity of her (Maggie) attitude toward them. She (Maggie) was unable at the minute, of course, fully to measure the difference thus involved for her (Maggie), and it remained inevitably an agitating image, the way it might be held over her (Maggie) that if she (Maggie) didn't, of her (Maggie) own prudence, satisfy Charlotte as to the reference, in her (Maggie) mocking spirit, of so much of the unuttered and unutterable, of the constantly and unmistakably implied, her (Maggie) father would be invited without further ceremony to recommend her (Maggie) to do so. But ANY confidence, ANY latent operating insolence, that Mrs. Verver should, thanks to her (Verver) large native resources, continue to be possessed of and to hold in reserve, glimmered suddenly as a possible working light and seemed to offer, for meeting her (Verver), a new basis and something like a new system. Maggie felt, truly, a rare contraction of the heart on making out, the next instant, what the new system would probably have to be--and she (Maggie) had practically done that before perceiving that the thing she (Maggie) feared had already taken place. Charlotte, extending her (Charlotte) search, appeared now to define herself vaguely in the distance; of this, after an instant, the Princess was sure, though the darkness was thick, for the projected clearness of the smoking-room windows had presently contributed its help. Her (Princess) friend came slowly into that circle--having also, for herself, by this time, not indistinguishably discovered that Maggie was on the terrace. Maggie, from the end, saw her (Maggie) stop before one of the windows to look at the group within, and then saw her (Maggie) come nearer and pause again, still with a considerable length of the place between them.

Yes, Charlotte had seen she (Charlotte) was watching her (Charlotte) from afar, and had stopped now to put her (Charlotte) further attention to the test. Her (Charlotte) face was fixed on her (Charlotte), through the night; she (Charlotte) was the creature who had escaped by force from her (Charlotte) cage, yet there was in her (Charlotte) whole motion assuredly, even as so dimly discerned, a kind of portentous intelligent stillness. She (Charlotte) had escaped with an intention, but with an intention the more definite that it could so accord with quiet measures. The two women, at all events, only hovered there, for these first minutes, face to face over their interval and exchanging no sign; the intensity of their mutual look might have pierced the night, and Maggie was at last to start with the scared sense of having thus yielded to doubt, to dread, to hesitation, for a time that, with no other proof needed, would have completely given her (Maggie) away. How long had she (Maggie) stood staring?--a single minute or five? Long enough, in any case, to have felt herself absolutely take from her (Maggie) visitor something that the latter threw upon her (Maggie), irresistibly, by this effect of silence, by this effect of waiting and watching, by this effect, unmistakably, of timing her (Maggie) indecision and her (Maggie) fear. If then, scared and hanging back, she (Maggie) had, as was so evident, sacrificed all past pretences, it would have been with the instant knowledge of an immense advantage gained that Charlotte finally saw her (Charlotte) come on. Maggie came on with her (Maggie) heart in her (Maggie) hands; she (Maggie) came on with the definite prevision, throbbing like the tick of a watch, of a doom impossibly sharp and hard, but to which, after looking at it with her (Maggie) eyes wide open, she (Maggie) had none the less bowed her (Maggie) head. By the time she (Maggie) was at her (Maggie) companion's side, for that matter, by the time Charlotte had, without a motion, without a word, simply let her (Charlotte) approach and stand there, her (Charlotte) head was already on the block, so that the consciousness that everything had now gone blurred all perception of whether or no the axe had fallen. Oh, the

``advantage,'' (Mrs. Verver)
it was perfectly enough, in truth, with Mrs. Verver; for what was Maggie's own sense but that of having been thrown over on her (Maggie) back, with her (Maggie) neck, from the first, half broken and her (Maggie) helpless face staring up? That position only could account for the positive grimace of weakness and pain produced there by Charlotte's dignity.

``I've come to join you--I thought you would be here.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, I'm here,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie heard herself return a little flatly.
``It's too close in-doors.'' (unknown)

``Very--but close even here.'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte was still and grave--she (Charlotte) had even uttered her (Charlotte) remark about the temperature with an expressive weight that verged upon solemnity; so that Maggie, reduced to looking vaguely about at the sky, could only feel her (Maggie) not fail of her (Maggie) purpose.
``The air's heavy as if with thunder--I think there'll be a storm.'' (She)
She (Maggie) made the suggestion to carry off an awkwardness--which was a part, always, of her (Maggie) companion's gain; but the awkwardness didn't diminish in the silence that followed. Charlotte had said nothing in reply; her (Charlotte) brow was dark as with a fixed expression, and her (Charlotte) high elegance, her (Charlotte) handsome head and long, straight neck testified, through the dusk, to their inveterate completeness and noble erectness. It was as if what she (Charlotte) had come out to do had already begun, and when, as a consequence, Maggie had said helplessly,
``Don't you want something? won't you have my shawl?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
everything might have crumbled away in the comparative poverty of the tribute. Mrs. Verver's rejection of it had the brevity of a sign that they hadn't closed in for idle words, just as her (Verver) dim, serious face, uninterruptedly presented until they moved again, might have represented the success with which she (Verver) watched all her (Verver) message penetrate. They presently went back the way she (Verver) had come, but she (Verver) stopped Maggie again within range of the smoking-room window and made her (Maggie) stand where the party at cards would be before her (Maggie). Side by side, for three minutes, they fixed this picture of quiet harmonies, the positive charm of it and, as might have been said, the full significance--which, as was now brought home to Maggie, could be no more, after all, than a matter of interpretation, differing always for a different interpreter. As she (Maggie) herself had hovered in sight of it a quarter-of-an-hour before, it would have been a thing for her (Maggie) to show Charlotte--to show in righteous irony, in reproach too stern for anything but silence. But now it was she (Maggie) who was being shown it, and shown it by Charlotte, and she (Charlotte) saw quickly enough that, as Charlotte showed it, so she (Charlotte) must at present submissively seem to take it.

The others were absorbed and unconscious, either silent over their game or dropping remarks unheard on the terrace; and it was to her (Charlotte) father's quiet face, discernibly expressive of nothing that was in his (father) daughter's mind, that our young woman's attention was most directly given. His (father) wife and his (father) daughter were both closely watching him (father), and to which of them, could he (father) have been notified of this, would his (father) raised eyes first, all impulsively, have responded; in which of them would he (father) have felt it most important to destroy--for HIS (father) clutch at the equilibrium--any germ of uneasiness? Not yet, since his (father) marriage, had Maggie so sharply and so formidably known her (Maggie) old possession of him (father) as a thing divided and contested. She (Maggie) was looking at him (father) by Charlotte's leave and under Charlotte's direction; quite in fact as if the particular way she (Charlotte) should look at him (father) were prescribed to her (Charlotte); quite, even, as if she (Charlotte) had been defied to look at him (father) in any other. It came home to her (Charlotte) too that the challenge wasn't, as might be said, in his (father) interest and for his (father) protection, but, pressingly, insistently, in Charlotte's, for that of HER security at any price. She (Charlotte) might verily, by this dumb demonstration, have been naming to Maggie the price, naming it as a question for Maggie herself, a sum of money that she (Maggie), properly, was to find. She (Maggie) must remain safe and Maggie must pay--what she (Maggie) was to pay with being her (Maggie) own affair.

Straighter than ever, thus, the Princess again felt it all put upon her (Princess), and there was a minute, just a supreme instant, during which there burned in her (Princess) a wild wish that her (Princess) father would only look up. It throbbed for these seconds as a yearning appeal to him (father)--she (Princess) would chance it, that is, if he (father) would but just raise his (father) eyes and catch them, across the larger space, standing in the outer dark together. Then he (father) might be affected by the sight, taking them as they were; he (father) might make some sign--she (Princess) scarce knew what--that would save her (Princess); save her (Princess) from being the one, this way, to pay all. He (father) might somehow show a preference-- distinguishing between them; might, out of pity for her (Princess), signal to her (Princess) that this extremity of her (Princess) effort for him (father) was more than he (father) asked. That represented Maggie's one little lapse from consistency--the sole small deflection in the whole course of her (Maggie) scheme. It had come to nothing the next minute, for the dear man's eyes had never moved, and Charlotte's hand, promptly passed into her (Charlotte) arm, had already, had very firmly drawn her (Charlotte) on--quite, for that matter, as from some sudden, some equal perception on her (Charlotte) part too of the more ways than one in which their impression could appeal. They retraced their steps along the rest of the terrace, turning the corner of the house, and presently came abreast of the other windows, those of the pompous drawing-room, still lighted and still empty. Here Charlotte again paused, and it was again as if she (Charlotte) were pointing out what Maggie had observed for herself, the very look the place had of being vivid in its stillness, of having, with all its great objects as ordered and balanced as for a formal reception, been appointed for some high transaction, some real affair of state. In presence of this opportunity she (Maggie) faced her (Maggie) companion once more; she (Maggie) traced in her (Maggie) the effect of everything she (Maggie) had already communicated; she (Maggie) signified, with the same success, that the terrace and the sullen night would bear too meagre witness to the completion of her (Maggie) idea. Soon enough then, within the room, under the old lustres of Venice and the eyes of the several great portraits, more or less contemporary with these, that awaited on the walls of Fawns their final far migration--soon enough Maggie found herself staring, and at first all too gaspingly, at the grand total to which each separate demand Mrs. Verver had hitherto made upon her (Verver), however she (Verver) had made it, now amounted.

``I've been wanting--and longer than you'd perhaps believe--to put a question to you for which no opportunity has seemed to me yet quite so good as this. It would have been easier perhaps if you had struck me as in the least disposed ever to give me one. I have to take it now, you see, as I find it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
They stood in the centre of the immense room, and Maggie could feel that the scene of life her (Maggie) imagination had made of it twenty minutes before was by this time sufficiently peopled. These few straight words filled it to its uttermost reaches, and nothing was now absent from her (Maggie) consciousness, either, of the part she (Maggie) was called upon to play in it. Charlotte had marched straight in, dragging her (Charlotte) rich train; she (Charlotte) rose there beautiful and free, with her (Charlotte) whole aspect and action attuned to the firmness of her (Charlotte) speech. Maggie had kept the shawl she (Maggie) had taken out with her (Maggie), and, clutching it tight in her (Maggie) nervousness, drew it round her (Maggie) as if huddling in it for shelter, covering herself with it for humility. She (Maggie) looked out as from under an improvised hood--the sole headgear of some poor woman at somebody's proud door; she (woman) waited even like the poor woman; she (woman) met her (woman) friend's eyes with recognitions she (woman) couldn't suppress. She (woman) might sound it as she (woman) could--
``What question then?'' (she)
--everything in her (woman), from head to foot, crowded it upon Charlotte that she (Charlotte) knew. She (Charlotte) knew too well--that she (Charlotte) was showing; so that successful vagueness, to save some scrap of her (Charlotte) dignity from the imminence of her (Charlotte) defeat, was already a lost cause, and the one thing left was if possible, at any cost, even that of stupid inconsequence, to try to look as if she (Charlotte) weren't afraid. If she (Charlotte) could but appear at all not afraid she (Charlotte) might appear a little not ashamed--that is not ashamed to be afraid, which was the kind of shame that could be fastened on her (Charlotte), it being fear all the while that moved her (Charlotte). Her (Charlotte) challenge, at any rate, her (Charlotte) wonder, her (Charlotte) terror--the blank, blurred surface, whatever it was that she (Charlotte) presented became a mixture that ceased to signify; for to the accumulated advantage by which Charlotte was at present sustained her (Charlotte) next words themselves had little to add.

``Have you any ground of complaint of me? Is there any wrong you consider I've done you? I feel at last that I've a right to ask you.'' (unknown)

Their eyes had to meet on it, and to meet long; Maggie's avoided at least the disgrace of looking away.

``What makes you want to ask it?'' (unknown)

``My natural desire to know. You've done that, for so long, little justice.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie waited a moment.

``For so long? You mean you've thought--?'' (unknown)

``I mean, my dear, that I've seen. I've seen, week after week, that YOU seemed to be thinking--of something that perplexed or worried you. Is it anything for which I'm in any degree responsible?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie summoned all her (Maggie) powers.

``What in the world SHOULD it be?'' (unknown)

``Ah, that's not for me to imagine, and I should be very sorry to have to try to say! I'm aware of no point whatever at which I may have failed you,'' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte;
``nor of any at which I may have failed any one in whom I can suppose you sufficiently interested to care. If I've been guilty of some fault I've committed it all unconsciously, and am only anxious to hear from you honestly about it. But if I've been mistaken as to what I speak of--the difference, more and more marked, as I've thought, in all your manner to me--why, obviously, so much the better. No form of correction received from you could give me greater satisfaction.'' (Charlotte)

She (Charlotte) spoke, it struck her (Charlotte) companion, with rising, with extraordinary ease; as if hearing herself say it all, besides seeing the way it was listened to, helped her (Charlotte) from point to point. She (Charlotte) saw she (Charlotte) was right--that this WAS the tone for her (Charlotte) to take and the thing for her (Charlotte) to do, the thing as to which she (Charlotte) was probably feeling that she (Charlotte) had in advance, in her (Charlotte) delays and uncertainties, much exaggerated the difficulty. The difficulty was small, and it grew smaller as her (Charlotte) adversary continued to shrink; she (Charlotte) was not only doing as she (Charlotte) wanted, but had by this time effectively done it and hung it up. All of which but deepened Maggie's sense of the sharp and simple need, now, of seeing her (Maggie) through to the end. ```If' you've been mistaken, you say?''--and the Princess but barely faltered.

``You HAVE been mistaken.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte looked at her (Charlotte) splendidly hard.

``You're perfectly sure it's ALL my mistake?'' (unknown)

``All I can say is that you've received a false impression.'' (unknown)

``Ah then--so much the better! From the moment I HAD received it I knew I must sooner or later speak of it--for that, you see, is, systematically, my way. And now,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte added,
``you make me glad I've spoken. I thank you very much.'' (Charlotte)

It was strange how for Maggie too, with this, the difficulty seemed to sink. Her (Maggie) companion's acceptance of her (Maggie) denial was like a general pledge not to keep things any worse for her (Maggie) than they essentially had to be; it positively helped her (Maggie) to build up her (Maggie) falsehood--to which, accordingly, she (Maggie) contributed another block.

``I've affected you evidently--quite accidentally--in some way of which I've been all unaware. I've NOT felt at any time that you've wronged me.'' (unknown)

``How could I come within a mile,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte inquired,
``of such a possibility?'' (Charlotte)

Maggie, with her (Maggie) eyes on her (Maggie) more easily now, made no attempt to say; she (Maggie) said, after a little, something more to the present point.

``I accuse you--I accuse you of nothing.'' (unknown)

``Ah, that's lucky!'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte had brought this out with the richness, almost, of gaiety; and Maggie, to go on, had to think, with her (Maggie) own intensity, of Amerigo--to think how he (Maggie), on his (Maggie) side, had had to go through with his (Maggie) lie to her (Maggie), how it was for his (Maggie) wife he (Maggie) had done so, and how his (Maggie) doing so had given her (wife) the clue and set her (wife) the example. He (Maggie) must have had his (Maggie) own difficulty about it, and she (wife) was not, after all, falling below him (Maggie). It was in fact as if, thanks to her (wife) hovering image of him (Maggie) confronted with this admirable creature even as she (wife) was confronted, there glowed upon her (wife) from afar, yet straight and strong, a deep explanatory light which covered the last inch of the ground. He (Maggie) had given her (wife) something to conform to, and she (wife) hadn't unintelligently turned on him (Maggie),

``gone back on'' (him)
him (Maggie), as he (Maggie) would have said, by not conforming. They were together thus, he (Maggie) and she (wife), close, close together--whereas Charlotte, though rising there radiantly before her (Charlotte), was really off in some darkness of space that would steep her (Charlotte) in solitude and harass her (Charlotte) with care. The heart of the Princess swelled, accordingly, even in her (Princess) abasement; she (Princess) had kept in tune with the right, and something, certainly, something that might be like a rare flower snatched from an impossible ledge, would, and possibly soon, come of it for her (Princess). The right, the right--yes, it took this extraordinary form of her (Princess) humbugging, as she (Princess) had called it, to the end. It was only a question of not, by a hair's breadth, deflecting into the truth. So, supremely, was she (Princess) braced.
``You must take it from me that your anxiety rests quite on a misconception. You must take it from me that I've never at any moment fancied I could suffer by you.'' (she)
And, marvellously, she (Princess) kept it up--not only kept it up, but improved on it.
``You must take it from me that I've never thought of you but as beautiful, wonderful and good. Which is all, I think, that you can possibly ask.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte held her (Charlotte) a moment longer: she (Charlotte) needed--not then to have appeared only tactless--the last word.

``It's much more, my dear, than I dreamed of asking. I only wanted your denial.'' (unknown)

``Well then, you have it.'' (unknown)

``Upon your honour?'' (unknown)

``Upon my honour:'' (she)

And she (Charlotte) made a point even, our young woman, of not turning away. Her (Charlotte) grip of her (Charlotte) shawl had loosened--she (Charlotte) had let it fall behind her (Charlotte); but she (Charlotte) stood there for anything more and till the weight should be lifted. With which she (Charlotte) saw soon enough what more was to come. She (Charlotte) saw it in Charlotte's face, and felt it make between them, in the air, a chill that completed the coldness of their conscious perjury.

``Will you kiss me on it then?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) couldn't say yes, but she (Charlotte) didn't say no; what availed her (Charlotte) still, however, was to measure, in her (Charlotte) passivity, how much too far Charlotte had come to retreat. But there was something different also, something for which, while her (Charlotte) cheek received the prodigious kiss, she (Charlotte) had her (Charlotte) opportunity--the sight of the others, who, having risen from their cards to join the absent members of their party, had reached the open door at the end of the room and stopped short, evidently, in presence of the demonstration that awaited them. Her (Charlotte) husband and her (Charlotte) father were in front, and Charlotte's embrace of her (Charlotte)--which wasn't to be distinguished, for them, either, she (Charlotte) felt, from her (Charlotte) embrace of Charlotte--took on with their arrival a high publicity.

XXXVII

Her (Charlotte) father had asked her (Charlotte), three days later, in an interval of calm, how she (Charlotte) was affected, in the light of their reappearance and of their now perhaps richer fruition, by Dotty and Kitty, and by the once formidable Mrs. Rance; and the consequence of this inquiry had been, for the pair, just such another stroll together, away from the rest of the party and off into the park, as had asserted its need to them on the occasion of the previous visit of these anciently more agitating friends--that of their long talk, on a sequestered bench beneath one of the great trees, when the particular question had come up for them the then purblind discussion of which, at their enjoyed leisure, Maggie had formed the habit of regarding as the

``first beginning'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
of their present situation. The whirligig of time had thus brought round for them again, on their finding themselves face to face while the others were gathering for tea on the terrace, the same odd impulse quietly to
``slope'' (the others)
--so Adam Verver himself, as they went, familiarly expressed it--that had acted, in its way, of old; acted for the distant autumn afternoon and for the sharpness of their since so outlived crisis. It might have been funny to them now that the presence of Mrs. Rance and the Lutches--and with symptoms, too, at that time less developed--had once, for their anxiety and their prudence, constituted a crisis; it might have been funny that these ladies could ever have figured, to their imagination, as a symbol of dangers vivid enough to precipitate the need of a remedy. This amount of entertainment and assistance they were indeed disposed to extract from their actual impressions; they had been finding it, for months past, by Maggie's view, a resource and a relief to talk, with an approach to intensity, when they met, of all the people they weren't really thinking of and didn't really care about, the people with whom their existence had begun almost to swarm; and they closed in at present round the spectres of their past, as they permitted themselves to describe the three ladies, with a better imitation of enjoying their theme than they had been able to achieve, certainly, during the stay, for instance, of the Castledeans. The Castledeans were a new joke, comparatively, and they had had--always to Maggie's view--to teach themselves the way of it; whereas the Detroit, the Providence party, rebounding so from Providence, from Detroit, was an old and ample one, of which the most could be made and as to which a humorous insistence could be guarded.

Sharp and sudden, moreover, this afternoon, had been their well-nigh confessed desire just to rest together, a little, as from some strain long felt but never named; to rest, as who should say, shoulder to shoulder and hand in hand, each pair of eyes so yearningly--and indeed what could it be but so wearily?--closed as to render the collapse safe from detection by the other pair. It was positively as if, in short, the inward felicity of their being once more, perhaps only for half-an-hour, simply daughter and father had glimmered out for them, and they had picked up the pretext that would make it easiest. They were husband and wife--oh, so immensely!--as regards other persons; but after they had dropped again on their old bench, conscious that the party on the terrace, augmented, as in the past, by neighbours, would do beautifully without them, it was wonderfully like their having got together into some boat and paddled off from the shore where husbands and wives, luxuriant complications, made the air too tropical. In the boat they were father and daughter, and poor Dotty and Kitty supplied abundantly, for their situation, the oars or the sail. Why, into the bargain, for that matter--this came to Maggie--couldn't they always live, so far as they lived together, in a boat? She (Maggie) felt in her (Maggie) face, with the question, the breath of a possibility that soothed her (Maggie); they needed only KNOW each other, henceforth, in the unmarried relation. That other sweet evening, in the same place, he (father) had been as unmarried as possible--which had kept down, so to speak, the quantity of change in their state. Well then, that other sweet evening was what the present sweet evening would resemble; with the quite calculable effect of an exquisite inward refreshment. They HAD, after all, whatever happened, always and ever each other; each other--that was the hidden treasure and the saving truth--to do exactly what they would with: a provision full of possibilities. Who could tell, as yet, what, thanks to it, they wouldn't have done before the end?

They had meanwhile been tracing together, in the golden air that, toward six o’clock of a July afternoon, hung about the massed Kentish woods, several features of the social evolution of her (They) old playmates, still beckoned on, it would seem, by unattainable ideals, still falling back, beyond the sea, to their native seats, for renewals of the moral, financial, conversational--one scarce knew what to call it--outfit, and again and for ever reappearing like a tribe of Wandering Jewesses. Our couple had finally exhausted, however, the study of these annals, and Maggie was to take up, after a drop, a different matter, or one at least with which the immediate connection was not at first apparent.

``Were you amused at me just now--when I wondered what other people could wish to struggle for? Did you think me,'' (she)
she (Maggie) asked with some earnestness--
``well, fatuous?'' (she)

```Fatuous'?''--he (Maggie) seemed at a loss.

``I mean sublime in OUR happiness--as if looking down from a height. Or, rather, sublime in our general position--that's what I mean.'' (She)
She (Maggie) spoke as from the habit of her (Maggie) anxious conscience something that disposed her (Maggie) frequently to assure herself, for her (Maggie) human commerce, of the state of the
``books'' (her)
of the spirit.
``Because I don't at all want,'' (she)
she (Maggie) explained,
``to be blinded, or made `sniffy,' by any sense of a social situation.'' (she)
Her (Maggie) father listened to this declaration as if the precautions of her (Maggie) general mercy could still, as they betrayed themselves, have surprises for him (father)--to say nothing of a charm of delicacy and beauty; he (father) might have been wishing to see how far she (Maggie) could go and where she (Maggie) would, all touchingly to him (father), arrive. But she (Maggie) waited a little--as if made nervous, precisely, by feeling him (father) depend too much on what she (Maggie) said. They were avoiding the serious, standing off, anxiously, from the real, and they fell, again and again, as if to disguise their precaution itself, into the tone of the time that came back to them from their other talk, when they had shared together this same refuge.
``Don't you remember,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``how, when they were here before, I broke it to you that I wasn't so very sure we, ourselves had the thing itself?'' (she)

He (father) did his (father) best to do so.

``Had, you mean a social situation?'' (unknown)

``Yes--after Fanny Assingham had first broken it to me that, at the rate we were going, we should never have one.'' (unknown)

``Which was what put us on Charlotte?'' (him)
Oh yes, they had had it over quite often enough for him (father) easily to remember.

Maggie had another pause--taking it from him (father) that he (father) now could both affirm and admit without wincing that they had been, at their critical moment,

``put on'' (he)
Charlotte. It was as if this recognition had been threshed out between them as fundamental to the honest view of their success.
``Well,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) continued,
``I recall how I felt, about Kitty and Dotty, that even if we had already then been more `placed,' or whatever you may call what we are now, it still wouldn't have been an excuse for wondering why others couldn't obligingly leave me more exalted by having, themselves, smaller ideas. For those,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``were the feelings we used to have.'' (she)

``Oh yes,'' (he)
he (father) responded philosophically--
``I remember the feelings we used to have.'' (he)

Maggie appeared to wish to plead for them a little, in tender retrospect--as if they had been also respectable.

``It was bad enough, I thought, to have no sympathy in your heart when you HAD a position. But it was worse to be sublime about it--as I was so afraid, as I'm in fact still afraid of being--when it wasn't even there to support one.'' (she)
And she (Maggie) put forth again the earnestness she (Maggie) might have been taking herself as having outlived; became for it--which was doubtless too often even now her (Maggie) danger--almost sententious.
``One must always, whether or no, have some imagination of the states of others--of what they may feel deprived of. However,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added,
``Kitty and Dotty couldn't imagine we were deprived of anything. And now, and now--!'' (she)
But she (Maggie) stopped as for indulgence to their wonder and envy.

``And now they see, still more, that we can have got everything, and kept everything, and yet not be proud.'' (unknown)

``No, we're not proud,'' (she)
she (Maggie) answered after a moment.
``I'm not sure that we're quite proud enough.'' (she)
Yet she (Maggie) changed the next instant that subject too. She (Maggie) could only do so, however, by harking back--as if it had been a fascination. She (Maggie) might have been wishing, under this renewed, this still more suggestive visitation, to keep him (Maggie) with her (Maggie) for remounting the stream of time and dipping again, for the softness of the water, into the contracted basin of the past.
``We talked about it--we talked about it; you don't remember so well as I. You too didn't know--and it was beautiful of you; like Kitty and Dotty you too thought we had a position, and were surprised when _I_ thought we ought to have told them we weren't doing for them what they supposed. In fact,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie pursued,
``we're not doing it now. We're not, you see, really introducing them. I mean not to the people they want.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Then what do you call the people with whom they're now having tea?'' (unknown)

It made her (Maggie) quite spring round.

``That's just what you asked me the other time--one of the days there was somebody. And I told you I didn't call anybody anything.'' (unknown)

``I remember--that such people, the people we made so welcome, didn't `count'; that Fanny Assingham knew they didn't.'' (She)
She (Maggie) had awakened, his (Maggie) daughter, the echo; and on the bench there, as before, he (Maggie) nodded his (Maggie) head amusedly, he (Maggie) kept nervously shaking his (Maggie) foot.
``Yes, they were only good enough--the people who came--for US. I remember,'' (he)
he (Maggie) said again:
``that was the way it all happened.'' (he)

``That was the way--that was the way. And you asked me,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie added,
``if I didn't think we ought to tell them. Tell Mrs. Rance, in particular, I mean, that we had been entertaining her (Rance) up to then under false pretences.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Precisely--but you said she (Rance) wouldn't have understood.'' (unknown)

``To which you replied that in that case you were like her (Rance). YOU didn't understand.'' (unknown)

``No, no--but I remember how, about our having, in our benighted innocence, no position, you quite crushed me with your explanation.'' (unknown)

``Well then,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie with every appearance of delight,
``I'll crush you again. I told you that you by yourself had one--there was no doubt of that. You were different from me--you had the same one you always had.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``And THEN I asked you,'' (father)
her (Maggie) father concurred,
``why in that case you hadn't the same.'' (father)

``Then indeed you did.'' (He)
He (father) had brought her (Maggie) face round to him (father) before, and this held it, covering him (father) with its kindled brightness, the result of the attested truth of their being able thus, in talk, to live again together.
``What I replied was that I had lost my position by my marriage. THAT one--I know how I saw it--would never come back. I had done something TO it--I didn't quite know what; given it away, somehow, and yet not, as then appeared, really got my return. I had been assured--always by dear Fanny--that I COULD get it, only I must wake up. So I was trying, you see, to wake up--trying very hard.'' (unknown)

``Yes--and to a certain extent you succeeded; as also in waking me. But you made much,'' (he)
he (father) said,
``of your difficulty.'' (he)
To which he (father) added:
``It's the only case I remember, Mag, of you ever making ANYTHING of a difficulty.'' (he)

She (Maggie) kept her (Maggie) eyes on him (father) a moment.

``That I was so happy as I was?'' (unknown)

``That you were so happy as you were.'' (unknown)

``Well, you admitted'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
--Maggie kept it up--
``that that was a good difficulty. You confessed that our life did seem to be beautiful.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

He (father) thought a moment.

``Yes--I may very well have confessed it, for so it did seem to me.'' (he)
But he (father) guarded himself with his (father) dim, his (father) easier smile.
``What do you want to put on me now?'' (unknown)

``Only that we used to wonder--that we were wondering then--if our life wasn't perhaps a little selfish.'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
This also for a time, much at his (father) leisure, Adam Verver retrospectively fixed.
``Because Fanny Assingham thought so?'' (unknown)

``Oh no; she (Fanny) never thought, she (Fanny) couldn't think, if she (Fanny) would, anything of that sort. She (Fanny) only thinks people are sometimes fools,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie developed;
``she (Fanny) doesn't seem to think so much about their being wrong--wrong, that is, in the sense of being wicked. She (Fanny) doesn't,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
the Princess further adventured,
``quite so much mind their being wicked.'' (the Princess)

``I see--I see.'' (daughter)
And yet it might have been for his (Verver) daughter that he (Verver) didn't so very vividly see.
``Then she (Fanny) only thought US fools?'' (unknown)

``Oh no--I don't say that. I'm speaking of our being selfish.'' (unknown)

``And that comes under the head of the wickedness Fanny condones?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't say she (Fanny) CONDONES--!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
A scruple in Maggie raised its crest.
``Besides, I'm speaking of what was.'' (father)

Her (Maggie) father showed, however, after a little, that he (father) had not been reached by this discrimination; his (father) thoughts were resting for the moment where they had settled.

``Look here, Mag,'' (he)
he (father) said reflectively--
``I ain't selfish. I'll be blowed if I'm selfish.'' (he)

Well, Maggie, if he (father) WOULD talk of that, could also pronounce.

``Then, father, _I_ am.'' (unknown)

``Oh shucks!'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
said Adam Verver, to whom the vernacular, in moments of deepest sincerity, could thus come back.
``I'll believe it,'' (he)
he (Verver) presently added,
``when Amerigo complains of you.'' (he)

``Ah, it's just he (father) who's my selfishness. I'm selfish, so to speak, FOR him (father). I mean,'' (she)
she (Maggie) continued,
``that he (father)'s my motive--in everything.'' (she)

Well, her (Maggie) father could, from experience, fancy what she (Maggie) meant.

``But hasn't a girl a right to be selfish about her (girl) husband?'' (unknown)

``What I DON'T mean,'' (she)
she (Maggie) observed without answering,
``is that I'm jealous of him (husband). But that's his (husband) merit--it's not mine.'' (she)

Her (Maggie) father again seemed amused at her (Maggie).

``You COULD be--otherwise?'' (unknown)

``Oh, how can I talk,'' (she)
she (Maggie) asked,
``of otherwise? It ISN'T, luckily for me, otherwise. If everything were different'' (she)
--she (Maggie) further presented her (Maggie) thought--
``of course everything WOULD be.'' (she)
And then again, as if that were but half:
``My idea is this, that when you only love a little you're naturally not jealous--or are only jealous also a little, so that it doesn't matter. But when you love in a deeper and intenser way, then you are, in the same proportion, jealous; your jealousy has intensity and, no doubt, ferocity. When, however, you love in the most abysmal and unutterable way of all--why then you're beyond everything, and nothing can pull you down.'' (Mr. Verver)

Mr. Verver listened as if he (Verver) had nothing, on these high lines, to oppose.

``And that's the way YOU love?'' (she)

For a minute she (Maggie) failed to speak, but at last she (Maggie) answered:

``It wasn't to talk about that. I do FEEL, however, beyond everything--and as a consequence of that, I dare say,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added with a turn to gaiety,
``seem often not to know quite WHERE I am.'' (she)

The mere fine pulse of passion in it, the suggestion as of a creature consciously floating and shining in a warm summer sea, some element of dazzling sapphire and silver, a creature cradled upon depths, buoyant among dangers, in which fear or folly, or sinking otherwise than in play, was impossible--something of all this might have been making once more present to him (Maggie), with his (Maggie) discreet, his (Maggie) half shy assent to it, her (Maggie) probable enjoyment of a rapture that he (Maggie), in his (Maggie) day, had presumably convinced no great number of persons either of his (Maggie) giving or of his (Maggie) receiving. He (Maggie) sat awhile as if he (Maggie) knew himself hushed, almost admonished, and not for the first time; yet it was an effect that might have brought before him (Maggie) rather what she (Maggie) had gained than what he (Maggie) had missed.

Besides, who but himself really knew what he (Maggie), after all, hadn't, or even had, gained? The beauty of her (Maggie) condition was keeping him (Maggie), at any rate, as he (Maggie) might feel, in sight of the sea, where, though his (Maggie) personal dips were over, the whole thing could shine at him (Maggie), and the air and the plash and the play become for him (Maggie) too a sensation. That couldn't be fixed upon him (Maggie) as missing; since if it wasn't personally floating, if it wasn't even sitting in the sand, it could yet pass very well for breathing the bliss, in a communicated irresistible way--for tasting the balm. It could pass, further, for knowing--for knowing that without him (Maggie) nothing might have been: which would have been missing least of all.

``I guess I've never been jealous,'' (he)
he (Maggie) finally remarked. And it said more to her (Maggie), he (Maggie) had occasion next to perceive, than he (Maggie) was intending; for it made her (Maggie), as by the pressure of a spring, give him (Maggie) a look that seemed to tell of things she (Maggie) couldn't speak.

But she (Maggie) at last tried for one of them.

``Oh, it's you, father, who are what I call beyond everything. Nothing can pull YOU down.'' (He)

He (Maggie) returned the look as with the sociability of their easy communion, though inevitably throwing in this time a shade of solemnity. He (Maggie) might have been seeing things to say, and others, whether of a type presumptuous or not, doubtless better kept back. So he (Maggie) settled on the merely obvious.

``Well then, we make a pair. We're all right.'' (unknown)

``Oh, we're all right!'' (unknown)
A declaration launched not only with all her (Maggie) discriminating emphasis, but confirmed by her (Maggie) rising with decision and standing there as if the object of their small excursion required accordingly no further pursuit. At this juncture, however--with the act of their crossing the bar, to get, as might be, into port--there occurred the only approach to a betrayal of their having had to beat against the wind. Her (Maggie) father kept his (father) place, and it was as if she (Maggie) had got over first and were pausing for her (Maggie) consort to follow. If they were all right; they were all right; yet he (father) seemed to hesitate and wait for some word beyond. His (father) eyes met her (Maggie) own, suggestively, and it was only after she (Maggie) had contented herself with simply smiling at him (father), smiling ever so fixedly, that he (father) spoke, for the remaining importance of it, from the bench; where he (father) leaned back, raising his (father) face to her (Maggie), his (father) legs thrust out a trifle wearily and his (father) hands grasping either side of the seat. They had beaten against the wind, and she (Maggie) was still fresh; they had beaten against the wind, and he (father), as at the best the more battered vessel, perhaps just vaguely drooped. But the effect of their silence was that she (Maggie) appeared to beckon him (father) on, and he (father) might have been fairly alongside of her (Maggie) when, at the end of another minute, he (father) found their word.
``The only thing is that, as for ever putting up again with your pretending that you're selfish--!'' (she)

At this she (Maggie) helped him (father) out with it.

``You won't take it from me?'' (unknown)

``I won't take it from you.'' (unknown)

``Well, of course you won't, for that's your way. It doesn't matter, and it only proves--! But it doesn't matter, either, what it proves. I'm at this very moment,'' (she)
she (Maggie) declared,
``frozen stiff with selfishness.'' (she)

He (father) faced her (Maggie) awhile longer in the same way; it was, strangely, as if, by this sudden arrest, by their having, in their acceptance of the unsaid, or at least their reference to it, practically given up pretending--it was as if they were

``in'' (her)
for it, for something they had been ineffably avoiding, but the dread of which was itself, in a manner, a seduction, just as any confession of the dread was by so much an allusion. Then she (Maggie) seemed to see him (father) let himself go.
``When a person's of the nature you speak of there are always other persons to suffer. But you've just been describing to me what you'd take, if you had once a good chance, from your husband.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I'm not talking about my husband!'' (unknown)

``Then whom, ARE you talking about?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Both the retort and the rejoinder had come quicker than anything previously exchanged, and they were followed, on Maggie's part, by a momentary drop. But she (Maggie) was not to fall away, and while her (Maggie) companion kept his (companion) eyes on her (Maggie), while she (Maggie) wondered if he (companion) weren't expecting her (Maggie) to name his (companion) wife then, with high hypocrisy, as paying for his (companion) daughter's bliss, she (Maggie) produced something that she (Maggie) felt to be much better.

``I'm talking about YOU.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean I've been your victim?'' (unknown)

``Of course you've been my victim. What have you done, ever done, that hasn't been FOR me?'' (unknown)

``Many things; more than I can tell you--things you've only to think of for yourself. What do you make of all that I've done for myself?'' (unknown)

```Yourself'?--'' She (Maggie) brightened out with derision.

``What do you make of what I've done for American City?'' (unknown)

It took her (Maggie) but a moment to say.

``I'm not talking of you as a public character--I'm talking of you on your personal side.'' (unknown)

``Well, American City--if `personalities' can do it--has given me a pretty personal side. What do you make,'' (he)
he (companion) went on,
``of what I've done for my reputation?'' (he)

``Your reputation THERE? You've given it up to them, the awful people, for less than nothing; you've given it up to them to tear to pieces, to make their horrible vulgar jokes against you with.'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear, I don't care for their horrible vulgar jokes,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
Adam Verver almost artlessly urged.

``Then there, exactly, you are!'' (she)
she (Maggie) triumphed.
``Everything that touches you, everything that surrounds you, goes on--by your splendid indifference and your incredible permission--at your expense.'' (he)

Just as he (Verver) had been sitting he (Verver) looked at her (Maggie) an instant longer; then he (Verver) slowly rose, while his (Verver) hands stole into his (Verver) pockets, and stood there before her (Maggie).

``Of course, my dear, YOU go on at my expense: it has never been my idea,'' (he)
he (Verver) smiled,
``that you should work for your living. I wouldn't have liked to see it.'' (he)
With which, for a little again, they remained face to face.
``Say therefore I HAVE had the feelings of a father. How have they made me a victim?'' (unknown)

``Because I sacrifice you.'' (unknown)

``But to what in the world?'' (she)

At this it hung before her (Maggie) that she (Maggie) should have had as never yet her (Maggie) opportunity to say, and it held her (Maggie) for a minute as in a vise, her (Maggie) impression of his (Verver) now, with his (Verver) strained smile, which touched her (Maggie) to deepest depths, sounding her (Maggie) in his (Verver) secret unrest. This was the moment, in the whole process of their mutual vigilance, in which it decidedly most hung by a hair that their thin wall might be pierced by the lightest wrong touch. It shook between them, this transparency, with their very breath; it was an exquisite tissue, but stretched on a frame, and would give way the next instant if either so much as breathed too hard. She (Maggie) held her (Maggie) breath, for she (Maggie) knew by his (Verver) eyes, the light at the heart of which he (Verver) couldn't blind, that he (Verver) was, by his (Verver) intention, making sure--sure whether or no her (Maggie) certainty was like his (Verver). The intensity of his (Verver) dependence on it at that moment--this itself was what absolutely convinced her (Maggie) so that, as if perched up before him (Verver) on her (Maggie) vertiginous point and in the very glare of his (Verver) observation, she (Maggie) balanced for thirty seconds, she (Maggie) almost rocked: she (Maggie) might have been for the time, in all her (Maggie) conscious person, the very form of the equilibrium they were, in their different ways, equally trying to save. And they were saving it--yes, they were, or at least she (Maggie) was: that was still the workable issue, she (Maggie) could say, as she (Maggie) felt her (Maggie) dizziness drop. She (Maggie) held herself hard; the thing was to be done, once for all, by her (Maggie) acting, now, where she (Maggie) stood. So much was crowded into so short a space that she (Maggie) knew already she (Maggie) was keeping her (Maggie) head. She (Maggie) had kept it by the warning of his (Maggie) eyes; she (Maggie) shouldn't lose it again; she (Maggie) knew how and why, and if she (Maggie) had turned cold this was precisely what helped her (Maggie). He (Maggie) had said to himself

``She (my)'ll break down and name Amerigo; she (my)'ll say it's to him (victim) she (my)'s sacrificing me; and its by what that will give me--with so many other things too--that my suspicion will be clinched.'' (He)
He (Maggie) was watching her (Maggie) lips, spying for the symptoms of the sound; whereby these symptoms had only to fail and he (Maggie) would have got nothing that she (Maggie) didn't measure out to him (Maggie) as she (Maggie) gave it. She (Maggie) had presently in fact so recovered herself that she (Maggie) seemed to know she (Maggie) could more easily have made him (Maggie) name his (Maggie) wife than he (Maggie) have made her (Maggie) name her (Maggie) husband. It was there before her (Maggie) that if she (Maggie) should so much as force him (Maggie) just NOT consciously to avoid saying
``Charlotte, Charlotte'' (him)
he (Maggie) would have given himself away. But to be sure of this was enough for her (Maggie), and she (Maggie) saw more clearly with each lapsing instant what they were both doing. He (Maggie) was doing what he (Maggie) had steadily been coming to; he (Maggie) was practically OFFERING himself, pressing himself upon her (Maggie), as a sacrifice--he (Maggie) had read his (Maggie) way so into her (Maggie) best possibility; and where had she (Maggie) already, for weeks and days past, planted her (Maggie) feet if not on her (Maggie) acceptance of the offer? Cold indeed, colder and colder she (Maggie) turned, as she (Maggie) felt herself suffer this close personal vision of his (Maggie) attitude still not to make her (Maggie) weaken. That was her (Maggie) very certitude, the intensity of his (Maggie) pressure; for if something dreadful hadn't happened there wouldn't, for either of them, be these dreadful things to do. She (Maggie) had meanwhile, as well, the immense advantage that she (Maggie) could have named Charlotte without exposing herself--as, for that matter, she (Maggie) was the next minute showing him (Maggie).

``Why, I sacrifice you, simply, to everything and to every one. I take the consequences of your marriage as perfectly natural.'' (He)

He (Maggie) threw back his (Maggie) head a little, settling with one hand his (Maggie) eyeglass.

``What do you call, my dear, the consequences?'' (unknown)

``Your life as your marriage has made it.'' (unknown)

``Well, hasn't it made it exactly what we wanted?'' (She)
She (Maggie) just hesitated, then felt herself steady--oh, beyond what she (Maggie) had dreamed.
``Exactly what _I_ wanted--yes.'' (he)

His (Maggie) eyes, through his (Maggie) straightened glasses, were still on hers, and he (Maggie) might, with his (Maggie) intenser fixed smile, have been knowing she (Maggie) was, for herself, rightly inspired.

``What do you make then of what I wanted?'' (unknown)

``I don't make anything, any more than of what you've got. That's exactly the point. I don't put myself out to do so--I never have; I take from you all I can get, all you've provided for me, and I leave you to make of your own side of the matter what you can. There you are--the rest is your own affair. I don't even pretend to concern myself--!'' (unknown)

``To concern yourself--?'' (He)
He (Maggie) watched her (Maggie) as she (Maggie) faintly faltered, looking about her (Maggie) now so as not to keep always meeting his (Maggie) face.

``With what may have REALLY become of you. It's as if we had agreed from the first not to go into that--such an arrangement being of course charming for ME. You can't say, you know, that I haven't stuck to it.'' (He)

He (Maggie) didn't say so then--even with the opportunity given him (Maggie) of her (Maggie) stopping once more to catch her (Maggie) breath. He (Maggie) said instead:

``Oh, my dear--oh, oh!'' (He)

But it made no difference, know as she (Maggie) might what a past--still so recent and yet so distant--it alluded to; she (Maggie) repeated her (Maggie) denial, warning him (Maggie) off, on her (Maggie) side, from spoiling the truth of her (Maggie) contention.

``I never went into anything, and you see I don't; I've continued to adore you--but what's that, from a decent daughter to such a father? what but a question of convenient arrangement, our having two houses, three houses, instead of one -LRB-you would have arranged for fifty if I had wished!-RRB- and my making it easy for you to see the child? You don't claim, I suppose, that my natural course, once you had set up for yourself, would have been to ship you back to American City?'' (unknown)

These were direct inquiries, they quite rang out, in the soft, wooded air; so that Adam Verver, for a minute, appeared to meet them with reflection. She (Maggie) saw reflection, however, quickly enough show him (Verver) what to do with them.

``Do you know, Mag, what you make me wish when you talk that way?'' (he)
And he (Verver) waited again, while she (Maggie) further got from him (Verver) the sense of something that had been behind, deeply in the shade, coming cautiously to the front and just feeling its way before presenting itself.
``You regularly make me wish that I had shipped back to American City. When you go on as you do--'' (he)
But he (Verver) really had to hold himself to say it.

``Well, when I go on--?'' (unknown)

``Why, you make me quite want to ship back myself. You make me quite feel as if American City would be the best place for us.'' (unknown)

It made her (Maggie) all too finely vibrate.

``For `us'--?'' (unknown)

``For me and Charlotte. Do you know that if we should ship, it would serve you quite right?'' (he)
With which he (Verver) smiled--oh he (Verver) smiled!
``And if you say much more we WILL ship.'' (unknown)

Ah, then it was that the cup of her (Maggie) conviction, full to the brim, overflowed at a touch! THERE was his (Verver) idea, the clearness of which for an instant almost dazzled her (Maggie). It was a blur of light, in the midst of which she (Maggie) saw Charlotte like some object marked, by contrast, in blackness, saw her (Maggie) waver in the field of vision, saw her (Maggie) removed, transported, doomed. And he (Verver) had named Charlotte, named her (Charlotte) again, and she (Charlotte) had MADE him (Verver)--which was all she (Charlotte) had needed more: it was as if she (Charlotte) had held a blank letter to the fire and the writing had come out still larger than she (Charlotte) hoped. The recognition of it took her (Charlotte) some seconds, but she (Charlotte) might when she (Charlotte) spoke have been folding up these precious lines and restoring them to her (Charlotte) pocket.

``Well, I shall be as much as ever then the cause of what you do. I haven't the least doubt of your being up to that if you should think I might get anything out of it; even the little pleasure,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) laughed,
``of having said, as you call it, `more.' Let my enjoyment of this therefore, at any price, continue to represent for you what _I_ call sacrificing you.'' (she)

She (Charlotte) had drawn a long breath; she (Charlotte) had made him (Verver) do it ALL for her (Charlotte), and had lighted the way to it without his (Verver) naming her (Charlotte) husband. That silence had been as distinct as the sharp, the inevitable sound, and something now, in him (Verver), followed it up, a sudden air as of confessing at last fully to where she (Charlotte) was and of begging the particular question.

``Don't you think then I can take care of myself?'' (unknown)

``Ah, it's exactly what I've gone upon. If it wasn't for that--!'' (she)

But she (Charlotte) broke off, and they remained only another moment face to face.

``I'll let you know, my dear, the day _I_ feel you've begun to sacrifice me.'' (unknown)

```Begun'?'' she (Charlotte) extravagantly echoed.

``Well, it will be, for me, the day you've ceased to believe in me.'' (her)

With which, his (Verver) glasses still fixed on her (Charlotte), his (Verver) hands in his (Verver) pockets, his (Verver) hat pushed back, his (Verver) legs a little apart, he (Verver) seemed to plant or to square himself for a kind of assurance it had occurred to him (Verver) he (Verver) might as well treat her (Charlotte) to, in default of other things, before they changed their subject. It had the effect, for her (Charlotte), of a reminder--a reminder of all he (Verver) was, of all he (Verver) had done, of all, above and beyond his (Verver) being her (Charlotte) perfect little father, she (Charlotte) might take him (Verver) as representing, take him (Verver) as having, quite eminently, in the eyes of two hemispheres, been capable of, and as therefore wishing, not--was it?--illegitimately, to call her (Charlotte) attention to. The

``successful,'' (The person citizen collector authority)
beneficent person, the beautiful, bountiful, original, dauntlessly wilful great citizen, the consummate collector and infallible high authority he (collector) had been and still was--these things struck her (Charlotte), on the spot, as making up for him (collector), in a wonderful way, a character she (Charlotte) must take into account in dealing with him (character) either for pity or for envy. He (character) positively, under the impression, seemed to loom larger than life for her (Charlotte), so that she (Charlotte) saw him (character) during these moments in a light of recognition which had had its brightness for her (Charlotte) at many an hour of the past, but which had never been so intense and so almost admonitory. His (character) very quietness was part of it now, as always part of everything, of his (character) success, his (character) originality, his (character) modesty, his (character) exquisite public perversity, his (character) inscrutable, incalculable energy; and this quality perhaps it might be--all the more too as the result, for the present occasion, of an admirable, traceable effort--that placed him (character) in her (Charlotte) eyes as no precious a work of art probably had ever been placed in his (character) own. There was a long moment, absolutely, during which her (Charlotte) impression rose and rose, even as that of the typical charmed gazer, in the still museum, before the named and dated object, the pride of the catalogue, that time has polished and consecrated. Extraordinary, in particular, was the number of the different ways in which he (character) thus affected her (Charlotte) as showing. He (character) was strong--that was the great thing. He (character) was sure--sure for himself, always, whatever his (character) idea: the expression of that in him (character) had somehow never appeared more identical with his (character) proved taste for the rare and the true. But what stood out beyond everything was that he (character) was always, marvellously, young--which couldn't but crown, at this juncture, his (character) whole appeal to her (Charlotte) imagination. Before she (Charlotte) knew it she (Charlotte) was lifted aloft by the consciousness that he (character) was simply a great and deep and high little man, and that to love him (character) with tenderness was not to be distinguished, a whit, from loving him (character) with pride. It came to her (Charlotte), all strangely, as a sudden, an immense relief. The sense that he (character) wasn't a failure, and could never be, purged their predicament of every meanness--made it as if they had really emerged, in their transmuted union, to smile almost without pain. It was like a new confidence, and after another instant she (Charlotte) knew even still better why. Wasn't it because now, also, on his (character) side, he (character) was thinking of her (Charlotte) as his (character) daughter, was TRYING her (Charlotte), during these mute seconds, as the child of his (character) blood? Oh then, if she (Charlotte) wasn't with her (Charlotte) little conscious passion, the child of any weakness, what was she (Charlotte) but strong enough too? It swelled in her (Charlotte), fairly; it raised her (Charlotte) higher, higher: she (Charlotte) wasn't in that case a failure either--hadn't been, but the contrary; his (character) strength was her (Charlotte) strength, her (Charlotte) pride was his (character), and they were decent and competent together. This was all in the answer she (Charlotte) finally made him (character).

``I believe in you more than any one.'' (unknown)

``Than any one at all?'' (She)

She (Charlotte) hesitated, for all it might mean; but there was--oh a thousand times!--no doubt of it.

``Than any one at all.'' (She)
She (Charlotte) kept nothing of it back now, met his (character) eyes over it, let him (character) have the whole of it; after which she (Charlotte) went on:
``And that's the way, I think, you believe in me.'' (she)

He (character) looked at her (Charlotte) a minute longer, but his (character) tone at last was right.

``About the way--yes.'' (unknown)

``Well then--?'' (She)
She (Charlotte) spoke as for the end and for other matters--for anything, everything, else there might be. They would never return to it.

``Well then--!'' (he)
His (character) hands came out, and while her (Charlotte) own took them he (character) drew her (Charlotte) to his (character) breast and held her (Charlotte). He (character) held her (Charlotte) hard and kept her (Charlotte) long, and she (Charlotte) let herself go; but it was an embrace that, august and almost stern, produced, for all its intimacy, no revulsion and broke into no inconsequence of tears.

XXXVIII

Maggie was to feel, after this passage, how they had both been helped through it by the influence of that accident of her (Maggie) having been caught, a few nights before, in the familiar embrace of her (Maggie) father's wife. His (father) return to the saloon had chanced to coincide exactly with this demonstration, missed moreover neither by her (Maggie) husband nor by the Assinghams, who, their card-party suspended, had quitted the billiard-room with him (husband). She (Maggie) had been conscious enough at the time of what such an impression, received by the others, might, in that extended state, do for her (Maggie) case; and none the less that, as no one had appeared to wish to be the first to make a remark about it, it had taken on perceptibly the special shade of consecration conferred by unanimities of silence. The effect, she (Maggie) might have considered, had been almost awkward--the promptitude of her (Maggie) separation from Charlotte, as if they had been discovered in some absurdity, on her (Maggie) becoming aware of spectators. The spectators, on the other hand--that was the appearance--mightn't have supposed them, in the existing relation, addicted to mutual endearments; and yet, hesitating with a fine scruple between sympathy and hilarity, must have felt that almost any spoken or laughed comment could be kept from sounding vulgar only by sounding, beyond any permitted measure, intelligent. They had evidently looked, the two young wives, like a pair of women

``making up'' (women)
effusively, as women were supposed to do, especially when approved fools, after a broil; but taking note of the reconciliation would imply, on her (women) father's part, on Amerigo's, and on Fanny Assingham's, some proportionate vision of the grounds of their difference. There had been something, there had been but too much, in the incident, for each observer; yet there was nothing any one could have said without seeming essentially to say:
``See, see, the dear things--their quarrel's blissfully over!'' (each observer)
``Our quarrel? What quarrel?'' (unknown)
the dear things themselves would necessarily, in that case, have demanded; and the wits of the others would thus have been called upon for some agility of exercise. No one had been equal to the flight of producing, off-hand, a fictive reason for any estrangement--to take, that is, the place of the true, which had so long, for the finer sensibility, pervaded the air; and every one, accordingly, not to be inconveniently challenged, was pretending, immediately after, to have remarked nothing that any one else hadn't.

Maggie's own measure had remained, all the same, full of the reflection caught from the total inference; which had acted, virtually, by enabling every one present--and oh Charlotte not least!--to draw a long breath. The message of the little scene had been different for each, but it had been this, markedly, all round, that it reinforced--reinforced even immensely--the general effort, carried on from week to week and of late distinctly more successful, to look and talk and move as if nothing in life were the matter. Supremely, however, while this glass was held up to her (Charlotte), had Maggie's sense turned to the quality of the success constituted, on the spot, for Charlotte. Most of all, if she (Charlotte) was guessing how her (Charlotte) father must have secretly started, how her (Charlotte) husband must have secretly wondered, how Fanny Assingham must have secretly, in a flash, seen daylight for herself--most of all had she (Assingham) tasted, by communication, of the high profit involved for her (Assingham) companion. She (Assingham) FELT, in all her (Assingham) pulses, Charlotte feel it, and how publicity had been required, absolutely, to crown her (Charlotte) own abasement. It was the added touch, and now nothing was wanting--which, to do her (Charlotte) stepmother justice, Mrs. Verver had appeared but to desire, from that evening, to show, with the last vividness, that she (Verver) recognised. Maggie lived over again the minutes in question--had found herself repeatedly doing so; to the degree that the whole evening hung together, to her (Maggie) aftersense, as a thing appointed by some occult power that had dealt with her (Maggie), that had for instance--animated the four with just the right restlessness too, had decreed and directed and exactly timed it in them, making their game of bridge--however abysmal a face it had worn for her (Maggie)--give way, precisely, to their common unavowed impulse to find out, to emulate Charlotte's impatience; a preoccupation, this latter, attached detectedly to the member of the party who was roaming in her (Charlotte) queerness and was, for all their simulated blindness, not roaming unnoted.

If Mrs. Verver meanwhile, then, had struck her (Verver) as determined in a certain direction by the last felicity into which that night had flowered, our young woman was yet not to fail of appreciating the truth that she (woman) had not been put at ease, after all, with absolute permanence. Maggie had seen her (Maggie), unmistakably, desire to rise to the occasion and be magnificent--seen her (Maggie) decide that the right way for this would be to prove that the reassurance she (Maggie) had extorted there, under the high, cool lustre of the saloon, a twinkle of crystal and silver, had not only poured oil upon the troubled waters of their question, but had fairly drenched their whole intercourse with that lubricant. She (Maggie) had exceeded the limit of discretion in this insistence on her (Maggie) capacity to repay in proportion a service she (Maggie) acknowledged as handsome.

``Why handsome?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie would have been free to ask; since if she (Maggie) had been veracious the service assuredly would not have been huge. It would in that case have come up vividly, and for each of them alike, that the truth, on the Princess's lips, presented no difficulty. If the latter's mood, in fact, could have turned itself at all to private gaiety it might have failed to resist the diversion of seeing so clever a creature so beguiled. Charlotte's theory of a generous manner was manifestly to express that her (Charlotte) stepdaughter's word, wiping out, as she (Charlotte) might have said, everything, had restored them to the serenity of a relation without a cloud. It had been, in short, in this light, ideally conclusive, so that no ghost of anything it referred to could ever walk again. What was the ecstasy of that, however, but in itself a trifle compromising?--as truly, within the week, Maggie had occasion to suspect her (Maggie) friend of beginning, and rather abruptly, to remember. Convinced as she (Maggie) was of the example already given her (Maggie) by her (Maggie) husband, and in relation to which her (Maggie) profession of trust in his (husband) mistress had been an act of conformity exquisitely calculated, her (Maggie) imagination yet sought in the hidden play of his (husband) influence the explanation of any change of surface, any difference of expression or intention. There had been, through life, as we know, few quarters in which the Princess's fancy could let itself loose; but it shook off restraint when it plunged into the figured void of the detail of that relation. This was a realm it could people with images--again and again with fresh ones; they swarmed there like the strange combinations that lurked in the woods at twilight; they loomed into the definite and faded into the vague, their main present sign for her (Princess) being, however, that they were always, that they were duskily, agitated. Her (Princess) earlier vision of a state of bliss made insecure by the very intensity of the bliss--this had dropped from her (Princess); she (Princess) had ceased to see, as she (Princess) lost herself, the pair of operatic, of high Wagnerian lovers -LRB-she (Princess) found, deep within her (Princess), these comparisons-RRB- interlocked in their wood of enchantment, a green glade as romantic as one's dream of an old German forest. The picture was veiled, on the contrary, with the dimness of trouble; behind which she (Princess) felt, indistinguishable, the procession of forms that had lost, all so pitifully, their precious confidence. Therefore, though there was in these days, for her (Princess), with Amerigo, little enough even of the imitation, from day to day, of unembarrassed references--as she (Princess) had foreseen, for that matter, from the first, that there would be--her (Princess) active conception of his (Princess) accessibility to their companion's own private and unextinguished right to break ground was not much less active than before. So it was that her (Princess) inner sense, in spite of everything, represented him (Princess) as still pulling wires and controlling currents, or rather indeed as muffling the whole possibility, keeping it down and down, leading his (Princess) accomplice continually on to some new turn of the road. As regards herself Maggie had become more conscious from week to week of his (Princess) ingenuities of intention to make up to her (Maggie) for their forfeiture, in so dire a degree, of any reality of frankness--a privation that had left on his (Princess) lips perhaps a little of the same thirst with which she (Maggie) fairly felt her (Maggie) own distorted, the torment of the lost pilgrim who listens in desert sands for the possible, the impossible, plash of water. It was just this hampered state in him (pilgrim), none the less, that she (Maggie) kept before her (Maggie) when she (Maggie) wished most to find grounds of dignity for the hard little passion which nothing he (pilgrim) had done could smother. There were hours enough, lonely hours, in which she (Maggie) let dignity go; then there were others when, clinging with her (Maggie) winged concentration to some deep cell of her (Maggie) heart, she (Maggie) stored away her (Maggie) hived tenderness as if she (Maggie) had gathered it all from flowers. He (pilgrim) was walking ostensibly beside her (Maggie), but in fact given over, without a break, to the grey medium in which he (pilgrim) helplessly groped; a perception on her (Maggie) part which was a perpetual pang and which might last what it would--for ever if need be--but which, if relieved at all, must be relieved by his (pilgrim) act alone. She (Maggie) herself could do nothing more for it; she (Maggie) had done the utmost possible. It was meantime not the easier to bear for this aspect under which Charlotte was presented as depending on him (pilgrim) for guidance, taking it from him (pilgrim) even in doses of bitterness, and yet lost with him (pilgrim) in devious depths. Nothing was thus more sharply to be inferred than that he (pilgrim) had promptly enough warned her (Charlotte), on hearing from her (Charlotte) of the precious assurance received from his (pilgrim) wife, that she (Charlotte) must take care her (Charlotte) satisfaction didn't betray something of her (Charlotte) danger. Maggie had a day of still waiting, after allowing him (pilgrim) time to learn how unreservedly she (Maggie) had lied for him (pilgrim)--of waiting as for the light of she (Maggie) scarce knew what slow-shining reflection of this knowledge in his (pilgrim) personal attitude. What retarded evolution, she (Maggie) asked herself in these hours, mightn't poor Charlotte all unwittingly have precipitated? She (Charlotte) was thus poor Charlotte again for Maggie even while Maggie's own head was bowed, and the reason for this kept coming back to our young woman in the conception of what would secretly have passed. She (woman) saw her (woman), face to face with the Prince, take from him (Prince) the chill of his (Prince) stiffest admonition, with the possibilities of deeper difficulty that it represented for each. She (woman) heard her (woman) ask, irritated and sombre, what tone, in God's name--since her (woman) bravery didn't suit him (God)--she (woman) was then to adopt; and, by way of a fantastic flight of divination, she (woman) heard Amerigo reply, in a voice of which every fine note, familiar and admirable, came home to her (woman), that one must really manage such prudences a little for one's self. It was positive in the Princess that, for this, she (Princess) breathed Charlotte's cold air--turned away from him (God) in it with her (Princess), turned with her (Princess), in growing compassion, this way and that, hovered behind her (Princess) while she (Princess) felt her (Princess) ask herself where then she (Princess) should rest. Marvellous the manner in which, under such imaginations, Maggie thus circled and lingered--quite as if she (Maggie) were, materially, following her (Maggie) unseen, counting every step she (Maggie) helplessly wasted, noting every hindrance that brought her (Maggie) to a pause.

A few days of this, accordingly, had wrought a change in that apprehension of the instant beatitude of triumph--of triumph magnanimous and serene--with which the upshot of the night-scene on the terrace had condemned our young woman to make terms. She (woman) had had, as we know, her (woman) vision of the gilt bars bent, of the door of the cage forced open from within and the creature imprisoned roaming at large--a movement, on the creature's part, that was to have even, for the short interval, its impressive beauty, but of which the limit, and in yet another direction, had loomed straight into view during her (woman) last talk under the great trees with her (woman) father. It was when she (woman) saw his (father) wife's face ruefully attached to the quarter to which, in the course of their session, he (father) had so significantly addressed his (father) own--it was then that Maggie could watch for its turning pale, it was then she (Maggie) seemed to know what she (Maggie) had meant by thinking of her (Maggie), in she (Maggie) shadow of his (father) most ominous reference, as

``doomed.'' (she)
If, as I say, her (Maggie) attention now, day after day, so circled and hovered, it found itself arrested for certain passages during which she (Maggie) absolutely looked with Charlotte's grave eyes. What she (Charlotte) unfailingly made out through them was the figure of a little quiet gentleman who mostly wore, as he (gentleman) moved, alone, across the field of vision, a straw hat, a white waistcoat and a blue necktie, keeping a cigar in his (gentleman) teeth and his (gentleman) hands in his (gentleman) pockets, and who, oftener than not, presented a somewhat meditative back while he (gentleman) slowly measured the perspectives of the park and broodingly counted -LRB-it might have appeared-RRB- his (gentleman) steps.
