There were hours of intensity, for a week or two, when it was for all the world as if she (gentleman) had guardedly tracked her (gentleman) stepmother, in the great house, from room to room and from window to window, only to see her (gentleman), here and there and everywhere, TRY her (gentleman) uneasy outlook, question her (gentleman) issue and her (gentleman) fate. Something, unmistakably, had come up for her (gentleman) that had never come up before; it represented a new complication and had begotten a new anxiety--things, these, that she (gentleman) carried about with her (gentleman) done up in the napkin of her (gentleman) lover's accepted rebuke, while she (gentleman) vainly hunted for some corner where she (gentleman) might put them safely down. The disguised solemnity, the prolonged futility of her (gentleman) search might have been grotesque to a more ironic eye; but Maggie's provision of irony, which we have taken for naturally small, had never been so scant as now, and there were moments while she (Maggie) watched with her (Maggie), thus unseen, when the mere effect of being near her (Maggie) was to feel her (Maggie) own heart in her (Maggie) throat, was to be almost moved to saying to her (Maggie):
``Hold on tight, my poor dear--without TOO MUCH terror--and it will all come out somehow.'' (her)

Even to that indeed, she (Maggie) could reflect, Charlotte might have replied that it was easy to say; even to that no great meaning could attach so long as the little meditative man in the straw hat kept coming into view with his (man) indescribable air of weaving his (man) spell, weaving it off there by himself. In whatever quarter of the horizon the appearances were scanned he (man) was to be noticed as absorbed in this occupation; and Maggie was to become aware of two or three extraordinary occasions of receiving from him (man) the hint that he (man) measured the impression he (man) produced. It was not really till after their recent long talk in the park that she (Maggie) knew how deeply, how quite exhaustively, they had then communicated--so that they were to remain together, for the time, in consequence, quite in the form of a couple of sociable drinkers who sit back from the table over which they have been resting their elbows, over which they have emptied to the last drop their respective charged cups. The cups were still there on the table, but turned upside down; and nothing was left for the companions but to confirm by placid silences the fact that the wine had been good. They had parted, positively, as if, on either side, primed with it--primed for whatever was to be; and everything between them, as the month waned, added its touch of truth to this similitude. Nothing, truly, WAS at present between them save that they were looking at each other in infinite trust; it fairly wanted no more words, and when they met, during the deep summer days, met even without witnesses, when they kissed at morning and evening, or on any of the other occasions of contact that they had always so freely celebrated, a pair of birds of the upper air could scarce have appeared less to invite each other to sit down and worry afresh. So it was that in the house itself, where more of his (witnesses) waiting treasures than ever were provisionally ranged, she (they) sometimes only looked at him (witnesses)--from end to end of the great gallery, the pride of the house, for instance--as if, in one of the halls of a museum, she (they) had been an earnest young woman with a Baedeker and he (witnesses) a vague gentleman to whom even Baedekers were unknown. He (witnesses) had ever, of course, had his (witnesses) way of walking about to review his (witnesses) possessions and verify their condition; but this was a pastime to which he (witnesses) now struck her (they) as almost extravagantly addicted, and when she (they) passed near him (witnesses) and he (witnesses) turned to give her (they) a smile she (they) caught--or so she (they) fancied--the greater depth of his (witnesses) small, perpetual hum of contemplation. It was as if he (witnesses) were singing to himself, sotto voce, as he (witnesses) went--and it was also, on occasion, quite ineffably, as if Charlotte, hovering, watching, listening, on her (Charlotte) side too, kept sufficiently within earshot to make it out as song, and yet, for some reason connected with the very manner of it, stood off and didn't dare.

One of the attentions she (Charlotte) had from immediately after her (Charlotte) marriage most freely paid him (witnesses) was that of her (Charlotte) interest in his (witnesses) rarities, her (Charlotte) appreciation of his (witnesses) taste, her (Charlotte) native passion for beautiful objects and her (Charlotte) grateful desire not to miss anything he (witnesses) could teach her (Charlotte) about them. Maggie had in due course seen her (Maggie) begin to

``work'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
this fortunately natural source of sympathy for all it was worth. She (Maggie) took possession of the mound throughout its extent; she (Maggie) abounded, to odd excess, one might have remarked, in the assumption of its being for her (Maggie), with her (Maggie) husband, ALL the ground, the finest, clearest air and most breathable medium common to them. It had been given to Maggie to wonder if she (Maggie) didn't, in these intensities of approbation, too much shut him (husband) up to his (husband) province; but this was a complaint he (husband) had never made his (husband) daughter, and Charlotte must at least have had for her (Charlotte) that, thanks to her (Charlotte) admirable instinct, her (Charlotte) range of perception marching with his (husband) own and never falling behind, she (Charlotte) had probably not so much as once treated him (husband) to a rasping mistake or a revealing stupidity. Maggie, wonderfully, in the summer days, felt it forced upon her (Maggie) that that was one way, after all, of being a genial wife; and it was never so much forced upon her (Maggie) as at these odd moments of her (Maggie) encountering the sposi, as Amerigo called them, under the coved ceilings of Fawns while, so together, yet at the same time so separate, they were making their daily round. Charlotte hung behind, with emphasised attention; she (Charlotte) stopped when her (Charlotte) husband stopped, but at the distance of a case or two, or of whatever other succession of objects; and the likeness of their connection would not have been wrongly figured if he (husband) had been thought of as holding in one of his (husband) pocketed hands the end of a long silken halter looped round her (Charlotte) beautiful neck. He (husband) didn't twitch it, yet it was there; he (husband) didn't drag her (Charlotte), but she (Charlotte) came; and those indications that I have described the Princess as finding extraordinary in him (husband) were two or three mute facial intimations which his (husband) wife's presence didn't prevent his (husband) addressing his (husband) daughter--nor prevent his (husband) daughter, as she (daughter) passed, it was doubtless to be added, from flushing a little at the receipt of. They amounted perhaps only to a wordless, wordless smile, but the smile was the soft shake of the twisted silken rope, and Maggie's translation of it, held in her (Maggie) breast till she (Maggie) got well away, came out only, as if it might have been overheard, when some door was closed behind her (Maggie).
``Yes, you see--I lead her (my) now by the neck, I lead her (my) to her (my) doom, and she (my) doesn't so much as know what it is, though she (my) has a fear in her (my) heart which, if you had the chances to apply your ear there that I, as a husband, have, you would hear thump and thump and thump. She (my) thinks it MAY be, her (my) doom, the awful place over there--awful for HER; but she (my)'s afraid to ask, don't you see? just as she (my)'s afraid of not asking; just as she (my)'s afraid of so many other things that she (my) sees multiplied round her (my) now as portents and betrayals. She (my)'ll know, however--when she (my) does know.'' (Charlotte)

Charlotte's one opportunity, meanwhile, for the air of confidence she (Charlotte) had formerly worn so well and that agreed so with her (Charlotte) firm and charming type, was the presence of visitors, never, as the season advanced, wholly intermitted--rather, in fact, so constant, with all the people who turned up for luncheon and for tea and to see the house, now replete, now famous, that Maggie grew to think again of this large element of

``company'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
as of a kind of renewed water-supply for the tank in which, like a party of panting gold-fish, they kept afloat. It helped them, unmistakably, with each other, weakening the emphasis of so many of the silences of which their intimate intercourse would otherwise have consisted. Beautiful and wonderful for her (Maggie), even, at times, was the effect of these interventions--their effect above all in bringing home to each the possible heroism of perfunctory things. They learned fairly to live in the perfunctory; they remained in it as many hours of the day as might be; it took on finally the likeness of some spacious central chamber in a haunted house, a great overarched and overglazed rotunda, where gaiety might reign, but the doors of which opened into sinister circular passages. Here they turned up for each other, as they said, with the blank faces that denied any uneasiness felt in the approach; here they closed numerous doors carefully behind them--all save the door that connected the place, as by a straight tented corridor, with the outer world, and, encouraging thus the irruption of society, imitated the aperture through which the bedizened performers of the circus are poured into the ring. The great part Mrs. Verver had socially played came luckily, Maggie could make out, to her (Maggie) assistance; she (Maggie) had
``personal friends'' (she)
--Charlotte's personal friends had ever been, in London, at the two houses, one of the most convenient pleasantries--who actually tempered, at this crisis, her (Maggie) aspect of isolation; and it wouldn't have been hard to guess that her (Maggie) best moments were those in which she (Maggie) suffered no fear of becoming a bore to restrain her (Maggie) appeal to their curiosity. Their curiosity might be vague, but their clever hostess was distinct, and she (hostess) marched them about, sparing them nothing, as if she (hostess) counted, each day, on a harvest of half crowns. Maggie met her (Maggie) again, in the gallery, at the oddest hours, with the party she (Maggie) was entertaining; heard her (Maggie) draw out the lesson, insist upon the interest, snub, even, the particular presumption and smile for the general bewilderment--inevitable features, these latter, of almost any occasion--in a manner that made our young woman, herself incurably dazzled, marvel afresh at the mystery by which a creature who could be in some connexions so earnestly right could be in others so perversely wrong. When her (woman) father, vaguely circulating, was attended by his (father) wife, it was always Charlotte who seemed to bring up the rear; but he (father) hung in the background when she (Charlotte) did cicerone, and it was then perhaps that, moving mildly and modestly to and fro on the skirts of the exhibition, his (father) appearance of weaving his (father) spell was, for the initiated conscience, least to be resisted. Brilliant women turned to him (father) in vague emotion, but his (father) response scarce committed him (father) more than if he (father) had been the person employed to see that, after the invading wave was spent, the cabinets were all locked and the symmetries all restored.

There was a morning when, during the hour before luncheon and shortly after the arrival of a neighbourly contingent--neighbourly from ten miles off--whom Mrs. Verver had taken in charge, Maggie paused on the threshold of the gallery through which she (Maggie) had been about to pass, faltered there for the very impression of his (father) face as it met her (Maggie) from an opposite door. Charlotte, half-way down the vista, held together, as if by something almost austere in the grace of her (Charlotte) authority, the semi-scared -LRB-now that they were there!-RRB- knot of her (Charlotte) visitors, who, since they had announced themselves by telegram as yearning to inquire and admire, saw themselves restricted to this consistency. Her (Charlotte) voice, high and clear and a little hard, reached her (Charlotte) husband and her (Charlotte) step-daughter while she (Charlotte) thus placed beyond doubt her (Charlotte) cheerful submission to duty. Her (Charlotte) words, addressed to the largest publicity, rang for some minutes through the place, every one as quiet to listen as if it had been a church ablaze with tapers and she (Charlotte) were taking her (Charlotte) part in some hymn of praise. Fanny Assingham looked rapt in devotion--Fanny Assingham who forsook this other friend as little as she (Assingham) forsook either her (Assingham) host or the Princess or the Prince or the Principino; she (Assingham) supported her (Assingham), in slow revolutions, in murmurous attestations of presence, at all such times, and Maggie, advancing after a first hesitation, was not to fail of noting her (Maggie) solemn, inscrutable attitude, her (Maggie) eyes attentively lifted, so that she (Maggie) might escape being provoked to betray an impression. She (Maggie) betrayed one, however, as Maggie approached, dropping her (Maggie) gaze to the latter's level long enough to seem to adventure, marvellously, on a mute appeal.

``You understand, don't you, that if she (my) didn't do this there would be no knowing what she (my) might do?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
This light Mrs. Assingham richly launched while her (Assingham) younger friend, unresistingly moved, became uncertain again, and then, not too much to show it--or, rather, positively to conceal it, and to conceal something more as well--turned short round to one of the windows and awkwardly, pointlessly waited.
``The largest of the three pieces has the rare peculiarity that the garlands, looped round it, which, as you see, are the finest possible vieux Saxe, are not of the same origin or period, or even, wonderful as they are, of a taste quite so perfect. They have been put on at a later time, by a process of which there are very few examples, and none so important as this, which is really quite unique--so that, though the whole thing is a little baroque, its value as a specimen is, I believe, almost inestimable.'' (neighbours)

So the high voice quavered, aiming truly at effects far over the heads of gaping neighbours; so the speaker, piling it up, sticking at nothing, as less interested judges might have said, seemed to justify the faith with which she (Assingham) was honoured. Maggie meanwhile, at the window, knew the strangest thing to be happening: she (Maggie) had turned suddenly to crying, or was at least on the point of it--the lighted square before her (Maggie) all blurred and dim. The high voice went on; its quaver was doubtless for conscious ears only, but there were verily thirty seconds during which it sounded, for our young woman, like the shriek of a soul in pain. Kept up a minute longer it would break and collapse--so that Maggie felt herself, the next thing, turn with a start to her (Maggie) father.

``Can't she (they) be stopped? Hasn't she (they) done it ENOUGH?'' (she)
--some such question as that she (Maggie) let herself ask him (father) to suppose in her (Maggie). Then it was that, across half the gallery--for he (father) had not moved from where she (Maggie) had first seen him (father)--he (father) struck her (Maggie) as confessing, with strange tears in his (father) own eyes, to sharp identity of emotion.
``Poor thing, poor thing'' (unknown)
--it reached straight--
``ISN'T she (they), for one's credit, on the swagger?'' (him)
After which, as, held thus together they had still another strained minute, the shame, the pity, the better knowledge, the smothered protest, the divined anguish even, so overcame him (father) that, blushing to his (father) eyes, he (father) turned short away. The affair but of a few muffled moments, this snatched communion yet lifted Maggie as on air--so much, for deep guesses on her (Maggie) own side too, it gave her (Maggie) to think of. There was, honestly, an awful mixture in things, and it was not closed to her (Maggie) aftersense of such passages--we have already indeed, in other cases, seen it open--that the deepest depth of all, in a perceived penalty, was that you couldn't be sure some of your compunctions and contortions wouldn't show for ridiculous. Amerigo, that morning, for instance, had been as absent as he (it) at this juncture appeared to desire he (it) should mainly be noted as being; he (it) had gone to London for the day and the night--a necessity that now frequently rose for him (it) and that he (it) had more than once suffered to operate during the presence of guests, successions of pretty women, the theory of his (it) fond interest in whom had been publicly cultivated. It had never occurred to his (it) wife to pronounce him (it) ingenuous, but there came at last a high dim August dawn when she (wife) couldn't sleep and when, creeping restlessly about and breathing at her (wife) window the coolness of wooded acres, she (wife) found the faint flush of the east march with the perception of that other almost equal prodigy. It rosily coloured her (wife) vision that--even such as he (prodigy) was, yes--her (wife) husband could on occasion sin by excess of candour. He (prodigy) wouldn't otherwise have given as his (prodigy) reason for going up to Portland Place in the August days that he (prodigy) was arranging books there. He (prodigy) had bought a great many of late, and he (prodigy) had had others, a large number, sent from Rome--wonders of old print in which her (wife) father had been interested. But when her (wife) imagination tracked him (father) to the dusty town, to the house where drawn blinds and pale shrouds, where a caretaker and a kitchenmaid were alone in possession, it wasn't to see him (caretaker), in his (caretaker) shirtsleeves, unpacking battered boxes.

She (wife) saw him (caretaker), in truth, less easily beguiled--saw him (caretaker) wander, in the closed dusky rooms, from place to place, or else, for long periods, recline on deep sofas and stare before him (caretaker) through the smoke of ceaseless cigarettes. She (wife) made him (caretaker) out as liking better than anything in the world just now to be alone with his (caretaker) thoughts. Being herself connected with his (caretaker) thoughts, she (wife) continued to believe, more than she (wife) had ever been, it was thereby a good deal as if he (caretaker) were alone with HER. She (wife) made him (caretaker) out as resting so from that constant strain of the perfunctory to which he (caretaker) was exposed at Fawns; and she (wife) was accessible to the impression of the almost beggared aspect of this alternative. It was like his (caretaker) doing penance in sordid ways--being sent to prison or being kept without money; it wouldn't have taken much to make her (wife) think of him (caretaker) as really kept without food. He (caretaker) might have broken away, might easily have started to travel; he (caretaker) had a right--thought wonderful Maggie now--to so many more freedoms than he (caretaker) took! His (caretaker) secret was of course that at Fawns he (caretaker) all the while winced, was all the while in presences in respect to which he (caretaker) had thrown himself back, with a hard pressure, on whatever mysteries of pride, whatever inward springs familiar to the man of the world, he (man) could keep from snapping. Maggie, for some reason, had that morning, while she (Maggie) watched the sunrise, taken an extraordinary measure of the ground on which he (man) would have HAD to snatch at pretexts for absence. It all came to her (Maggie) there--he (man) got off to escape from a sound. The sound was in her (Maggie) own ears still--that of Charlotte's high coerced quaver before the cabinets in the hushed gallery; the voice by which she (Maggie) herself had been pierced the day before as by that of a creature in anguish and by which, while she (Maggie) sought refuge at the blurred window, the tears had been forced into her (Maggie) eyes. Her (Maggie) comprehension soared so high that the wonder for her (Maggie) became really his (man) not feeling the need of wider intervals and thicker walls. Before THAT admiration she (Maggie) also meditated; consider as she (Maggie) might now, she (Maggie) kept reading not less into what he (man) omitted than into what he (man) performed a beauty of intention that touched her (Maggie) fairly the more by being obscure. It was like hanging over a garden in the dark; nothing was to be made of the confusion of growing things, but one felt they were folded flowers, and their vague sweetness made the whole air their medium. He (man) had to turn away, but he (man) wasn't at least a coward; he (man) would wait on the spot for the issue of what he (man) had done on the spot. She (Maggie) sank to her (Maggie) knees with her (Maggie) arm on the ledge of her (Maggie) window-seat, where she (Maggie) blinded her (Maggie) eyes from the full glare of seeing that his (man) idea could only be to wait, whatever might come, at her (Maggie) side. It was to her (Maggie) buried face that she (Maggie) thus, for a long time, felt him (man) draw nearest; though after a while, when the strange wail of the gallery began to repeat its inevitable echo, she (Maggie) was conscious of how that brought out his (man) pale hard grimace.

XXXIX

The resemblance had not been present to her (Maggie) on first coming out into the hot, still brightness of the Sunday afternoon--only the second Sunday, of all the summer, when the party of six, the party of seven including the Principino, had practically been without accessions or invasions; but within sight of Charlotte, seated far away, very much where she (Charlotte) had expected to find her (Charlotte), the Princess fell to wondering if her (Princess) friend wouldn't be affected quite as she (Princess) herself had been, that night on the terrace, under Mrs. Verver's perceptive pursuit. The relation, to-day, had turned itself round; Charlotte was seeing her (Charlotte) come, through patches of lingering noon, quite as she (Charlotte) had watched Charlotte menace her (Charlotte) through the starless dark; and there was a moment, that of her (Charlotte) waiting a little as they thus met across the distance, when the interval was bridged by a recognition not less soundless, and to all appearance not less charged with strange meanings, than that of the other occasion. The point, however, was that they had changed places; Maggie had from her (Maggie) window, seen her (Maggie) stepmother leave the house--at so unlikely an hour, three o’clock of a canicular August, for a ramble in garden or grove--and had thereupon felt her (Maggie) impulse determined with the same sharpness that had made the spring of her (Maggie) companion's three weeks before. It was the hottest day of the season, and the shaded siesta, for people all at their ease, would certainly rather have been prescribed; but our young woman had perhaps not yet felt it so fully brought home that such refinements of repose, among them, constituted the empty chair at the feast. This was the more distinct as the feast, literally, in the great bedimmed dining-room, the cool, ceremonious semblance of luncheon, had just been taking place without Mrs. Verver. She (Verver) had been represented but by the plea of a bad headache, not reported to the rest of the company by her (Verver) husband, but offered directly to Mr. Verver himself, on their having assembled, by her (Verver) maid, deputed for the effect and solemnly producing it.

Maggie had sat down, with the others, to viands artfully iced, to the slow circulation of precious tinkling jugs, to marked reserves of reference in many directions--poor Fanny Assingham herself scarce thrusting her (Assingham) nose out of the padded hollow into which she (Assingham) had withdrawn. A consensus of languor, which might almost have been taken for a community of dread, ruled the scene--relieved only by the fitful experiments of Father Mitchell, good holy, hungry man, a trusted and overworked London friend and adviser, who had taken, for a week or two, the light neighbouring service, local rites flourishing under Maggie's munificence, and was enjoying, as a convenience, all the bounties of the house. HE (adviser) conversed undiscouraged, Father Mitchell--conversed mainly with the indefinite, wandering smile of the entertainers, and the Princess's power to feel him (Mitchell) on the whole a blessing for these occasions was not impaired by what was awkward in her (Princess) consciousness of having, from the first of her (Princess) trouble, really found her (Princess) way without his (Mitchell) guidance. She (Princess) asked herself at times if he (Mitchell) suspected how more than subtly, how perversely, she (Princess) had dispensed with him (Mitchell), and she (Princess) balanced between visions of all he (Mitchell) must privately have guessed and certitudes that he (Mitchell) had guessed nothing whatever. He (Mitchell) might nevertheless have been so urbanely filling up gaps, at present, for the very reason that his (Mitchell) instinct, sharper than the expression of his (Mitchell) face, had sufficiently served him (Mitchell)--made him (Mitchell) aware of the thin ice, figuratively speaking, and of prolongations of tension, round about him (Mitchell), mostly foreign to the circles in which luxury was akin to virtue. Some day in some happier season, she (Princess) would confess to him (Mitchell) that she (Princess) hadn't confessed, though taking so much on her (Princess) conscience; but just now she (Princess) was carrying in her (Princess) weak, stiffened hand a glass filled to the brim, as to which she (Princess) had recorded a vow that no drop should overflow. She (Princess) feared the very breath of a better wisdom, the jostle of the higher light, of heavenly help itself; and, in addition, however that might be, she (Princess) drew breath this afternoon, as never yet, in an element heavy to oppression. Something grave had happened, somehow and somewhere, and she (Princess) had, God knew, her (Princess) choice of suppositions: her (Princess) heart stood still when she (Princess) wondered above all if the cord mightn't at last have snapped between her (Princess) husband and her (Princess) father. She (Princess) shut her (Princess) eyes for dismay at the possibility of such a passage--there moved before them the procession of ugly forms it might have taken.

``Find out for yourself!'' (she)
she (Princess) had thrown to Amerigo, for her (Princess) last word, on the question of who else
``knew,'' (Amerigo)
that night of the breaking of the Bowl; and she (Princess) flattered herself that she (Princess) hadn't since then helped him (father), in her (Princess) clear consistency, by an inch. It was what she (Princess) had given him (father), all these weeks, to be busy with, and she (Princess) had again and again lain awake for the obsession of this sense of his (father) uncertainty ruthlessly and endlessly playing with his (father) dignity. She (Princess) had handed him (father) over to an ignorance that couldn't even try to become indifferent and that yet wouldn't project itself, either, into the cleared air of conviction. In proportion as he (father) was generous it had bitten into his (father) spirit, and more than once she (Princess) had said to herself that to break the spell she (Princess) had cast upon him (father) and that the polished old ivory of her (Princess) father's inattackable surface made so absolute, he (father) would suddenly commit some mistake or some violence, smash some windowpane for air, fail even of one of his (father) blest inveteracies of taste. In that way, fatally, he (father) would have put himself in the wrong--blighting by a single false step the perfection of his (father) outward show.

These shadows rose and fell for her (Princess) while Father Mitchell prattled; with other shadows as well, those that hung over Charlotte herself, those that marked her (Charlotte) as a prey to equal suspicions--to the idea, in particular, of a change, such a change as she (Charlotte) didn't dare to face, in the relations of the two men. Or there were yet other possibilities, as it seemed to Maggie; there were always too many, and all of them things of evil when one's nerves had at last done for one all that nerves could do; had left one in a darkness of prowling dangers that was like the predicament of the night-watcher in a beast-haunted land who has no more means for a fire. She (Maggie) might, with such nerves, have supposed almost anything of any one; anything, almost, of poor Bob Assingham, condemned to eternal observances and solemnly appreciating her (Maggie) father's wine; anything, verily, yes, of the good priest, as he (priest) finally sat back with fat folded hands and twiddled his (priest) thumbs on his (priest) stomach. The good priest looked hard at the decanters, at the different dishes of dessert--he (priest) eyed them, half-obliquely, as if THEY might have met him (priest) to-day, for conversation, better than any one present. But the Princess had her (Princess) fancy at last about that too; she (Princess) was in the midst of a passage, before she (Princess) knew it, between Father Mitchell and Charlotte--some approach he (Father) would have attempted with her (Charlotte), that very morning perhaps, to the circumstance of an apparent detachment, recently noted in her (Charlotte), from any practice of devotion. He (Father) would have drawn from this, say, his (Father) artless inference--taken it for a sign of some smothered inward trouble and pointed, naturally, the moral that the way out of such straits was not through neglect of the grand remedy. He (Father) had possibly prescribed contrition--he (Father) had at any rate quickened in her (Charlotte) the beat of that false repose to which our young woman's own act had devoted her (Charlotte) at her (Charlotte) all so deluded instance. The falsity of it had laid traps compared to which the imputation of treachery even accepted might have seemed a path of roses. The acceptance, strangely, would have left her (Charlotte) nothing to do--she (Charlotte) could have remained, had she (Charlotte) liked, all insolently passive; whereas the failure to proceed against her (Charlotte), as it might have been called, left her (Charlotte) everything, and all the more that it was wrapped so in confidence. She (Charlotte) had to confirm, day after day, the rightness of her (Charlotte) cause and the justice and felicity of her (Charlotte) exemption--so that wouldn't there have been, fairly, in any explicit concern of Father Mitchell's, depths of practical derision of her (Charlotte) success?

The question was provisionally answered, at all events, by the time the party at luncheon had begun to disperse--with Maggie's version of Mrs. Verver sharp to the point of representing her (Verver) pretext for absence as a positive flight from derision. She (Verver) met the good priest's eyes before they separated, and priests were really, at the worst, so to speak, such wonderful people that she (Verver) believed him (priest) for an instant on the verge of saying to her (Verver), in abysmal softness:

``Go to Mrs. Verver, my child--YOU go: you'll find that you can help her (Verver).'' (her)
This didn't come, however; nothing came but the renewed twiddle of thumbs over the satisfied stomach and the full flush, the comical candour, of reference to the hand employed at Fawns for mayonnaise of salmon. Nothing came but the receding backs of each of the others--her (Verver) father's slightly bent shoulders, in especial, which seemed to weave his (father) spell, by the force of habit, not less patiently than if his (father) wife had been present. Her (wife) husband indeed was present to feel anything there might be to feel--which was perhaps exactly why this personage was moved promptly to emulate so definite an example of
``sloping.'' (this personage)
He (father) had his (father) occupations--books to arrange perhaps even at Fawns; the idea of the siesta, moreover, in all the conditions, had no need to be loudly invoked. Maggie, was, in the event, left alone for a minute with Mrs. Assingham, who, after waiting for safety, appeared to have at heart to make a demonstration. The stage of
``talking over'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
had long passed for them; when they communicated now it was on quite ultimate facts; but Fanny desired to testify to the existence, on her (Fanny) part, of an attention that nothing escaped. She (Fanny) was like the kind lady who, happening to linger at the circus while the rest of the spectators pour grossly through the exits, falls in with the overworked little trapezist girl--the acrobatic support presumably of embarrassed and exacting parents--and gives her (girl), as an obscure and meritorious artist, assurance of benevolent interest. What was clearest, always, in our young woman's imaginings, was the sense of being herself left, for any occasion, in the breach. She (woman) was essentially there to bear the burden, in the last resort, of surrounding omissions and evasions, and it was eminently to that office she (woman) had been to-day abandoned--with this one alleviation, as appeared, of Mrs. Assingham's keeping up with her (Assingham). Mrs. Assingham suggested that she (Assingham) too was still on the ramparts--though her (Assingham) gallantry proved indeed after a moment to consist not a little of her (Assingham) curiosity. She (Assingham) had looked about and seen their companions beyond earshot.

``Don't you really want us to go--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie found a faint smile.

``Do you really want to--?'' (friend)

It made her (Maggie) friend colour.

``Well then--no. But we WOULD, you know, at a look from you. We'd pack up and be off--as a sacrifice.'' (unknown)

``Ah, make no sacrifice,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.
``See me through.'' (unknown)

``That's it--that's all I want. I should be too base--! Besides,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny went on,
``you're too splendid.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

``Splendid?'' (unknown)

``Splendid. Also, you know, you ARE all but `through.' You've done it,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
said Mrs. Assingham. But Maggie only half took it from her (Assingham).

``What does it strike you that I've done?'' (unknown)

``What you wanted. They're going.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie continued to look at her (Maggie).

``Is that what I wanted?'' (unknown)

``Oh, it wasn't for you to say. That was his (I) business.'' (unknown)

``My father's?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie asked after an hesitation.

``Your father's. He (father) has chosen--and now she (you) knows. She (you) sees it all before her (you)--and she (you) can't speak, or resist, or move a little finger. That's what's the matter with HER,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

It made a picture, somehow, for the Princess, as they stood there--the picture that the words of others, whatever they might be, always made for her (Princess), even when her (Princess) vision was already charged, better than any words of her (Princess) own. She (Princess) saw, round about her (Princess), through the chinks of the shutters, the hard glare of nature--saw Charlotte, somewhere in it, virtually at bay, and yet denied the last grace of any protecting truth. She (Charlotte) saw her (Charlotte) off somewhere all unaided, pale in her (Charlotte) silence and taking in her (Charlotte) fate.

``Has she (you) told you?'' (she)
she (Charlotte) then asked.

Her (Charlotte) companion smiled superior.

``_I_ don't need to be told--either! I see something, thank God, every day.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
And then as Maggie might appear to be wondering what, for instance:
``I see the long miles of ocean and the dreadful great country, State after State--which have never seemed to me so big or so terrible. I see THEM at last, day by day and step by step, at the far end--and I see them never come back. But NEVER--simply. I see the extraordinary `interesting' place--which I've never been to, you know, and you have--and the exact degree in which she (God) will be expected to be interested.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``She (God) WILL be,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie presently replied.
``Expected?'' (unknown)

``Interested.'' (unknown)

For a little, after this, their eyes met on it; at the end of which Fanny said:

``She (God)'ll be--yes--what she (God)'ll HAVE to be. And it will be--won't it? for ever and ever.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
She (Fanny) spoke as abounding in her (Fanny) friend's sense, but it made Maggie still only look at her (Maggie).

These were large words and large visions--all the more that now, really, they spread and spread. In the midst of them, however, Mrs. Assingham had soon enough continued.

``When I talk of `knowing,' indeed, I don't mean it as you would have a right to do. You know because you see--and I don't see HIM. I don't make him (God) out,'' (she)
she (Assingham) almost crudely confessed.

Maggie again hesitated.

``You mean you don't make out Amerigo?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

But Fanny shook her (Fanny) head, and it was quite as if, as an appeal to one's intelligence, the making out of Amerigo had, in spite of everything, long been superseded. Then Maggie measured the reach of her (Maggie) allusion, and how what she (Maggie) next said gave her (Maggie) meaning a richness. No other name was to be spoken, and Mrs. Assingham had taken that, without delay, from her (Assingham) eyes--with a discretion, still, that fell short but by an inch.

``You know how he (God) feels.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie at this then slowly matched her (Maggie) headshake.

``I know nothing.'' (unknown)

``You know how YOU feel.'' (she)

But again she (Maggie) denied it.

``I know nothing. If I did--!'' (unknown)

``Well, if you did?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny asked as she (Fanny) faltered.

She (Fanny) had had enough, however.

``I should die,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said as she (Fanny) turned away.

She (Fanny) went to her (Fanny) room, through the quiet house; she (Fanny) roamed there a moment, picking up, pointlessly, a different fan, and then took her (Fanny) way to the shaded apartments in which, at this hour, the Principino would be enjoying his (fan) nap. She (Fanny) passed through the first empty room, the day nursery, and paused at an open door. The inner room, large, dim and cool, was equally calm; her (Fanny) boy's ample, antique, historical, royal crib, consecrated, reputedly, by the guarded rest of heirs-apparent, and a gift, early in his (boy) career, from his (boy) grandfather, ruled the scene from the centre, in the stillness of which she (Fanny) could almost hear the child's soft breathing. The prime protector of his (boy) dreams was installed beside him (boy); her (Fanny) father sat there with as little motion--with head thrown back and supported, with eyes apparently closed, with the fine foot that was so apt to betray nervousness at peace upon the other knee, with the unfathomable heart folded in the constant flawless freshness of the white waistcoat that could always receive in its armholes the firm prehensile thumbs. Mrs. Noble had majestically melted, and the whole place signed her (Noble) temporary abdication; yet the actual situation was regular, and Maggie lingered but to look. She (Maggie) looked over her (Maggie) fan, the top of which was pressed against her (Maggie) face, long enough to wonder if her (Maggie) father really slept or if, aware of her (Maggie), he (father) only kept consciously quiet. Did his (father) eyes truly fix her (Maggie) between lids partly open, and was she (Maggie) to take this--his (father) forebearance from any question--only as a sign again that everything was left to her (Maggie)? She (Maggie) at all events, for a minute, watched his (father) immobility--then, as if once more renewing her (Maggie) total submission, returned, without a sound, to her (Maggie) own quarters.

A strange impulse was sharp in her (Maggie), but it was not, for her (Maggie) part, the desire to shift the weight. She (Maggie) could as little have slept as she (Maggie) could have slept that morning, days before, when she (Maggie) had watched the first dawn from her (Maggie) window. Turned to the east, this side of her (Maggie) room was now in shade, with the two wings of the casement folded back and the charm she (Maggie) always found in her (Maggie) seemingly perched position--as if her (Maggie) outlook, from above the high terraces, was that of some castle-tower mounted on a rock. When she (Maggie) stood there she (Maggie) hung over, over the gardens and the woods--all of which drowsed below her (Maggie), at this hour, in the immensity of light. The miles of shade looked hot, the banks of flowers looked dim; the peacocks on the balustrades let their tails hang limp and the smaller birds lurked among the leaves. Nothing therefore would have appeared to stir in the brilliant void if Maggie, at the moment she (Maggie) was about to turn away, had not caught sight of a moving spot, a clear green sunshade in the act of descending a flight of steps. It passed down from the terrace, receding, at a distance, from sight, and carried, naturally, so as to conceal the head and back of its bearer; but Maggie had quickly recognised the white dress and the particular motion of this adventurer--had taken in that Charlotte, of all people, had chosen the glare of noon for an exploration of the gardens, and that she (Charlotte) could be betaking herself only to some unvisited quarter deep in them, or beyond them, that she (Charlotte) had already marked as a superior refuge. The Princess kept her (Princess) for a few minutes in sight, watched her (Princess) long enough to feel her (Princess), by the mere betrayal of her (Princess) pace and direction, driven in a kind of flight, and then understood, for herself, why the act of sitting still had become impossible to either of them. There came to her (Princess), confusedly, some echo of an ancient fable--some vision of Io goaded by the gadfly or of Ariadne roaming the lone sea-strand. It brought with it all the sense of her (Princess) own intention and desire; she (Princess) too might have been, for the hour, some far-off harassed heroine--only with a part to play for which she (heroine) knew, exactly, no inspiring precedent. She (heroine) knew but that, all the while--all the while of her (heroine) sitting there among the others without her (heroine)--she (heroine) had wanted to go straight to this detached member of the party and make somehow, for her (heroine) support, the last demonstration. A pretext was all that was needful, and Maggie after another instant had found one. She (Maggie) had caught a glimpse, before Mrs. Verver disappeared, of her (Verver) carrying a book--made out, half lost in the folds of her (Verver) white dress, the dark cover of a volume that was to explain her (Verver) purpose in case of her (Verver) being met with surprise, and the mate of which, precisely, now lay on Maggie's table. The book was an old novel that the Princess had a couple of days before mentioned having brought down from Portland Place in the charming original form of its three volumes. Charlotte had hailed, with a specious glitter of interest, the opportunity to read it, and our young woman had, thereupon, on the morrow, directed her (woman) maid to carry it to Mrs. Verver's apartments. She (woman) was afterwards to observe that this messenger, unintelligent or inadvertent, had removed but one of the volumes, which happened not to be the first. Still possessed, accordingly, of the first while Charlotte, going out, fantastically, at such an hour, to cultivate romance in an arbour, was helplessly armed with the second, Maggie prepared on the spot to sally forth with succour. The right volume, with a parasol, was all she (Maggie) required--in addition, that is, to the bravery of her (Maggie) general idea. She (Maggie) passed again through the house, unchallenged, and emerged upon the terrace, which she (Maggie) followed, hugging the shade, with that consciousness of turning the tables on her (Maggie) friend which we have already noted. But so far as she (Maggie) went, after descending into the open and beginning to explore the grounds, Mrs. Verver had gone still further--with the increase of the oddity, moreover, of her (Verver) having exchanged the protection of her (Verver) room for these exposed and shining spaces. It was not, fortunately, however, at last, that by persisting in pursuit one didn't arrive at regions of admirable shade: this was the asylum, presumably, that the poor wandering woman had had in view--several wide alleys, in particular, of great length, densely overarched with the climbing rose and the honeysuckle and converging, in separate green vistas, at a sort of umbrageous temple, an ancient rotunda, pillared and statued, niched and roofed, yet with its uncorrected antiquity, like that of everything else at Fawns, conscious hitherto of no violence from the present and no menace from the future. Charlotte had paused there, in her (Charlotte) frenzy, or what ever it was to be called; the place was a conceivable retreat, and she (Charlotte) was staring before her (Charlotte), from the seat to which she (Charlotte) appeared to have sunk, all unwittingly, as Maggie stopped at the beginning of one of the perspectives.

It was a repetition more than ever then of the evening on the terrace; the distance was too great to assure her (Maggie) she (Maggie) had been immediately seen, but the Princess waited, with her (Princess) intention, as Charlotte on the other occasion had waited--allowing, oh allowing, for the difference of the intention! Maggie was full of the sense of THAT--so full that it made her (Maggie) impatient; whereupon she (Maggie) moved forward a little, placing herself in range of the eyes that had been looking off elsewhere, but that she (Maggie) had suddenly called to recognition. Charlotte had evidently not dreamed of being followed, and instinctively, with her (Charlotte) pale stare, she (Charlotte) stiffened herself for protest. Maggie could make that out--as well as, further, however, that her (Maggie) second impression of her (Maggie) friend's approach had an instant effect on her (Maggie) attitude. The Princess came nearer, gravely and in silence, but fairly paused again, to give her (Princess) time for whatever she (Princess) would. Whatever she (Princess) would, whatever she (Princess) could, was what Maggie wanted--wanting above all to make it as easy for her (Maggie) as the case permitted. That was not what Charlotte had wanted the other night, but this never mattered--the great thing was to allow her (Charlotte), was fairly to produce in her (Charlotte), the sense of highly choosing. At first, clearly, she (Charlotte) had been frightened; she (Charlotte) had not been pursued, it had quickly struck her (Charlotte), without some design on the part of her (Charlotte) pursuer, and what might she (Charlotte) not be thinking of in addition but the way she (Charlotte) had, when herself the pursuer, made her (Charlotte) stepdaughter take in her (Charlotte) spirit and her (Charlotte) purpose? It had sunk into Maggie at the time, that hard insistence, and Mrs. Verver had felt it and seen it and heard it sink; which wonderful remembrance of pressure successfully applied had naturally, till now, remained with her (Verver). But her (Verver) stare was like a projected fear that the buried treasure, so dishonestly come by, for which her (Verver) companion's still countenance, at the hour and afterwards, had consented to serve as the deep soil, might have worked up again to the surface, to be thrown back upon her (Verver) hands. Yes, it was positive that during one of these minutes the Princess had the vision of her (Princess) particular alarm.

``It's her (I) lie, it's her (I) lie that has mortally disagreed with her (I); she (I) can keep down no longer her (I) rebellion at it, and she (I) has come to retract it, to disown it and denounce it--to give me full in my face the truth instead.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
This, for a concentrated instant, Maggie felt her (Maggie) helplessly gasp--but only to let it bring home the indignity, the pity of her (Maggie) state. She (Maggie) herself could but tentatively hover, place in view the book she (Maggie) carried, look as little dangerous, look as abjectly mild, as possible; remind herself really of people she (Maggie) had read about in stories of the wild west, people who threw up their hands, on certain occasions, as a sign they weren't carrying revolvers. She (Maggie) could almost have smiled at last, troubled as she (Maggie) yet knew herself, to show how richly she (Maggie) was harmless; she (Maggie) held up her (Maggie) volume, which was so weak a weapon, and while she (Maggie) continued, for consideration, to keep her (Maggie) distance, she (Maggie) explained with as quenched a quaver as possible.
``I saw you come out--saw you from my window, and couldn't bear to think you should find yourself here without the beginning of your book. THIS is the beginning; you've got the wrong volume, and I've brought you out the right.'' (She)

She (Maggie) remained after she (Maggie) had spoken; it was like holding a parley with a possible adversary, and her (Maggie) intense, her (Maggie) exalted little smile asked for formal leave.

``May I come nearer now?'' (she)
she (Maggie) seemed to say--as to which, however, the next minute, she (Maggie) saw Charlotte's reply lose itself in a strange process, a thing of several sharp stages, which she (Maggie) could stand there and trace. The dread, after a minute, had dropped from her (Maggie) face; though, discernibly enough, she (Maggie) still couldn't believe in her (Maggie) having, in so strange a fashion, been deliberately made up to. If she (Maggie) had been made up to, at least, it was with an idea--the idea that had struck her (Maggie) at first as necessarily dangerous. That it wasn't, insistently wasn't, this shone from Maggie with a force finally not to be resisted; and on that perception, on the immense relief so constituted, everything had by the end of three minutes extraordinarily changed. Maggie had come out to her (Maggie), really, because she (Maggie) knew her (Maggie) doomed, doomed to a separation that was like a knife in her (Maggie) heart; and in the very sight of her (Maggie) uncontrollable, her (Maggie) blinded physical quest of a peace not to be grasped, something of Mrs. Assingham's picture of her (Assingham) as thrown, for a grim future, beyond the great sea and the great continent had at first found fulfilment. She (Assingham) had got away, in this fashion--burning behind her (Assingham), almost, the ships of disguise--to let her (Assingham) horror of what was before her (Assingham) play up without witnesses; and even after Maggie's approach had presented an innocent front it was still not to be mistaken that she (Maggie) bristled with the signs of her (Maggie) extremity. It was not to be said for them, either, that they were draped at this hour in any of her (Maggie) usual graces; unveiled and all but unashamed, they were tragic to the Princess in spite of the dissimulation that, with the return of comparative confidence, was so promptly to operate. How tragic, in essence, the very change made vivid, the instant stiffening of the spring of pride--this for possible defence if not for possible aggression. Pride indeed, the next moment, had become the mantle caught up for protection and perversity; she (Princess) flung it round her (Princess) as a denial of any loss of her (Princess) freedom. To be doomed was, in her (Princess) situation, to have extravagantly incurred a doom, so that to confess to wretchedness was, by the same stroke, to confess to falsity. She (Princess) wouldn't confess, she (Princess) didn't--a thousand times no; she (Princess) only cast about her (Princess), and quite frankly and fiercely, for something else that would give colour to her (Princess) having burst her (Princess) bonds. Her (Princess) eyes expanded, her (Princess) bosom heaved as she (Princess) invoked it, and the effect upon Maggie was verily to wish she (Maggie) could only help her (Maggie) to it. She (Maggie) presently got up--which seemed to mean
``Oh, stay if you like!'' (She)
and when she (Maggie) had moved about awhile at random, looking away, looking at anything, at everything but her (Maggie) visitor; when she (Maggie) had spoken of the temperature and declared that she (Maggie) revelled in it; when she (Maggie) had uttered her (Maggie) thanks for the book, which, a little incoherently, with her (Maggie) second volume, she (Maggie) perhaps found less clever than she (Maggie) expected; when she (Maggie) had let Maggie approach sufficiently closer to lay, untouched, the tribute in question on a bench and take up obligingly its superfluous mate: when she (Maggie) had done these things she (Maggie) sat down in another place, more or less visibly in possession of her (Maggie) part. Our young woman was to have passed, in all her (woman) adventure, no stranger moments; for she (woman) not only now saw her (woman) companion fairly agree to take her (woman) then for the poor little person she (woman) was finding it so easy to appear, but fell, in a secret, responsive ecstasy, to wondering if there were not some supreme abjection with which she (woman) might be inspired. Vague, but increasingly brighter, this possibility glimmered on her (woman). It at last hung there adequately plain to Charlotte that she (Charlotte) had presented herself once more to -LRB-as they said-RRB- grovel; and that, truly, made the stage large. It had absolutely, within the time, taken on the dazzling merit of being large for each of them alike.

``I'm glad to see you alone--there's something I've been wanting to say to you. I'm tired,'' (Mrs. Verver)
said Mrs. Verver,
``I'm tired--!'' (Mrs. Verver)

``Tired--?'' (unknown)
It had dropped the next thing; it couldn't all come at once; but Maggie had already guessed what it was, and the flush of recognition was in her (Maggie) face.

``Tired of this life--the one we've been leading. You like it, I know, but I've dreamed another dream.'' (She)
She (Maggie) held up her (Maggie) head now; her (Maggie) lighted eyes more triumphantly rested; she (Maggie) was finding, she (Maggie) was following her (Maggie) way. Maggie, by the same influence, sat in sight of it; there was something she (Maggie) was SAVING, some quantity of which she (Maggie) herself was judge; and it was for a long moment, even with the sacrifice the Princess had come to make, a good deal like watching her (Princess), from the solid shore, plunge into uncertain, into possibly treacherous depths.
``I see something else,'' (she)
she (Princess) went on;
``I've an idea that greatly appeals to me--I've had it for a long time. It has come over me that we're wrong. Our real life isn't here.'' (she)

Maggie held her (Maggie) breath. ```Ours'--?''

``My husband's and mine. I'm not speaking for you.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie, only praying not to be, not even to appear, stupid.

``I'm speaking for ourselves. I'm speaking,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte brought out,
``for HIM.'' (Charlotte)

``I see. For my father.'' (unknown)

``For your father. For whom else?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
They looked at each other hard now, but Maggie's face took refuge in the intensity of her (Maggie) interest. She (Maggie) was not at all even so stupid as to treat her (Maggie) companion's question as requiring an answer; a discretion that her (Maggie) controlled stillness had after an instant justified.
``I must risk your thinking me selfish--for of course you know what it involves. Let me admit it--I AM selfish. I place my husband first.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie smiling and smiling,
``since that's where I place mine--!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``You mean you'll have no quarrel with me? So much the better then; for,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte went on with a higher and higher flight,
``my plan is completely formed.'' (Charlotte)

Maggie waited--her (Maggie) glimmer had deepened; her (Maggie) chance somehow was at hand. The only danger was her (Maggie) spoiling it; she (Maggie) felt herself skirting an abyss.

``What then, may I ask IS your plan?'' (unknown)

It hung fire but ten seconds; it came out sharp.

``To take him (husband) home--to his (husband) real position. And not to wait.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean--a--this season?'' (unknown)

``I mean immediately. And--I may as well tell you now--I mean for my own time. I want,'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
Charlotte said,
``to have him (husband) at last a little to myself; I want, strange as it may seem to you'' (Charlotte Stant/Charlotte/Stant)
--and she (Charlotte) gave it all its weight
``to KEEP the man I've married. And to do so, I see, I must act.'' (she)

Maggie, with the effort still to follow the right line, felt herself colour to the eyes.

``Immediately?'' (she)
she (Maggie) thoughtfully echoed.

``As soon as we can get off. The removal of everything is, after all, but a detail. That can always be done; with money, as he (man) spends it, everything can. What I ask for,'' (Charlotte)
Charlotte declared,
``is the definite break. And I wish it now.'' (Charlotte)
With which her (Charlotte) head, like her (Charlotte) voice rose higher.
``Oh,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) added,
``I know my difficulty!'' (she)

Far down below the level of attention, in she (Charlotte) could scarce have said what sacred depths, Maggie's inspiration had come, and it had trembled the next moment into sound.

``Do you mean I'M your difficulty?'' (unknown)

``You and he (man) together--since it's always with you that I've had to see him (man). But it's a difficulty that I'm facing, if you wish to know; that I've already faced; that I propose to myself to surmount. The struggle with it--none too pleasant--hasn't been for me, as you may imagine, in itself charming; I've felt in it at times, if I must tell you all, too great and too strange, an ugliness. Yet I believe it may succeed.'' (She)

She (Maggie) had risen, with this, Mrs. Verver, and had moved, for the emphasis of it, a few steps away; while Maggie, motionless at first, but sat and looked at her (Maggie).

``You want to take my father FROM me?'' (Charlotte)

The sharp, successful, almost primitive wail in it made Charlotte turn, and this movement attested for the Princess the felicity of her (Princess) deceit. Something in her (Princess) throbbed as it had throbbed the night she (Princess) stood in the drawing-room and denied that she (Princess) had suffered. She (Princess) was ready to lie again if her (Princess) companion would but give her (Princess) the opening. Then she (Princess) should know she (Princess) had done all. Charlotte looked at her (Charlotte) hard, as if to compare her (Charlotte) face with her (Charlotte) note of resentment; and Maggie, feeling this, met it with the signs of an impression that might pass for the impression of defeat.

``I want really to possess him (father),'' (Mrs. Verver)
said Mrs. Verver.
``I happen also to feel that he (father)'s worth it.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie rose as if to receive her (Maggie).

``Oh--worth it!'' (she)
she (Maggie) wonderfully threw off.

The tone, she (Maggie) instantly saw, again had its effect: Charlotte flamed aloft--might truly have been believing in her (Charlotte) passionate parade.

``You've thought YOU'VE known what he (father)'s worth?'' (unknown)

``Indeed then, my dear, I believe I have--as I believe I still do.'' (She)

She (Charlotte) had given it, Maggie, straight back, and again it had not missed. Charlotte, for another moment, only looked at her (Charlotte); then broke into the words--Maggie had known they would come--of which she (Maggie) had pressed the spring.

``How I see that you loathed our marriage!'' (unknown)

``Do you ASK me?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie after an instant demanded.

Charlotte had looked about her (Charlotte), picked up the parasol she (Charlotte) had laid on a bench, possessed herself mechanically of one of the volumes of the relegated novel and then, more consciously, flung it down again: she (Charlotte) was in presence, visibly, of her (Charlotte) last word. She (Charlotte) opened her (Charlotte) sunshade with a click; she (Charlotte) twirled it on her (Charlotte) shoulder in her (Charlotte) pride. ```Ask' you? Do I need? How I see,'' she (Charlotte) broke out,

``that you've worked against me!'' (I)

``Oh, oh, oh!'' (the Princess)
the Princess exclaimed.

Her (Princess) companion, leaving her (Princess), had reached one of the archways, but on this turned round with a flare.

``You haven't worked against me?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie took it and for a moment kept it; held it, with closed eyes, as if it had been some captured fluttering bird pressed by both hands to her (Maggie) breast. Then she (Maggie) opened her (Maggie) eyes to speak.

``What does it matter--if I've failed?'' (unknown)

``You recognise then that you've failed?'' (Charlotte)
asked Charlotte from the threshold.

Maggie waited; she (Maggie) looked, as her (Maggie) companion had done a moment before, at the two books on the seat; she (Maggie) put them together and laid them down; then she (Maggie) made up her (Maggie) mind.

``I've failed!'' (she)
she (Maggie) sounded out before Charlotte, having given her (Charlotte) time, walked away. She (Charlotte) watched her (Charlotte), splendid and erect, float down the long vista; then she (Charlotte) sank upon a seat. Yes, she (Charlotte) had done all.

PART SIXTH.

XL

``I'll do anything you like,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said to her (Charlotte) husband on one of the last days of the month,
``if our being here, this way at this time, seems to you too absurd, or too uncomfortable, or too impossible. We'll either take leave of them now, without waiting--or we'll come back in time, three days before they start. I'll go abroad with you, if you but say the word; to Switzerland, the Tyrol, the Italian Alps, to whichever of your old high places you would like most to see again--those beautiful ones that used to do you good after Rome and that you so often told me about.'' (husband)

Where they were, in the conditions that prompted this offer, and where it might indeed appear ridiculous that, with the stale London September close at hand, they should content themselves with remaining, was where the desert of Portland Place looked blank as it had never looked, and where a drowsy cabman, scanning the horizon for a fare, could sink to oblivion of the risks of immobility. But Amerigo was of the odd opinion, day after day, that their situation couldn't be bettered; and he (they) even went at no moment through the form of replying that, should their ordeal strike her (themselves) as exceeding their patience, any step they might take would be for her (themselves) own relief. This was, no doubt, partly because he (they) stood out so wonderfully, to the end, against admitting, by a weak word at least, that any element of their existence WAS, or ever had been, an ordeal; no trap of circumstance, no lapse of

``form,'' (he)
no accident of irritation, had landed him (they) in that inconsequence. His (they) wife might verily have suggested that he (they) was consequent--consequent with the admirable appearance he (they) had from the first so undertaken, and so continued, to present--rather too rigidly at HER expense; only, as it happened, she (wife) was not the little person to do anything of the sort, and the strange tacit compact actually in operation between them might have been founded on an intelligent comparison, a definite collation positively, of the kinds of patience proper to each. She (wife) was seeing him (they) through--he (they) had engaged to come out at the right end if she (wife) WOULD see him (they): this understanding, tacitly renewed from week to week, had fairly received, with the procession of the weeks, the consecration of time; but it scarce needed to be insisted on that she (wife) was seeing him (they) on HIS (they) terms, not all on hers, or that, in other words, she (wife) must allow him (they) his (they) unexplained and uncharted, his (they) one practicably workable way. If that way, by one of the intimate felicities the liability to which was so far from having even yet completely fallen from him (they), happened handsomely to show him (they) as more bored than boring -LRB-with advantages of his (they) own freely to surrender, but none to be persuadedly indebted to others for,-RRB- what did such a false face of the matter represent but the fact itself that she (wife) was pledged? If she (wife) had questioned or challenged or interfered--if she (wife) had reserved herself that right--she (wife) wouldn't have been pledged; whereas there were still, and evidently would be yet a while, long, tense stretches during which their case might have been hanging, for every eye, on her (wife) possible, her (wife) impossible defection. She (wife) must keep it up to the last, mustn't absent herself for three minutes from her (wife) post: only on those lines, assuredly, would she (wife) show herself as with him (wife) and not against him (wife).

It was extraordinary how scant a series of signs she (wife) had invited him (wife) to make of being, of truly having been at any time,

``with'' (him)
his (wife) wife: that reflection she (wife) was not exempt from as they now, in their suspense, supremely waited--a reflection under the brush of which she (wife) recognised her (wife) having had, in respect to him (wife) as well, to
``do all,'' (him)
to go the whole way over, to move, indefatigably, while he (wife) stood as fixed in his (wife) place as some statue of one of his (wife) forefathers. The meaning of it would seem to be, she (wife) reasoned in sequestered hours, that he (wife) HAD a place, and that this was an attribute somehow indefeasible, unquenchable, which laid upon others--from the moment they definitely wanted anything of him (wife)-- the necessity of taking more of the steps that he (wife) could, of circling round him (wife), of remembering for his (wife) benefit the famous relation of the mountain to Mahomet. It was strange, if one had gone into it, but such a place as Amerigo's was like something made for him (wife) beforehand by innumerable facts, facts largely of the sort known as historical, made by ancestors, examples, traditions, habits; while Maggie's own had come to show simply as that improvised
``post'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
--a post of the kind spoken of as advanced--with which she (Maggie) was to have found herself connected in the fashion of a settler or a trader in a new country; in the likeness even of some Indian squaw with a papoose on her (Maggie) back and barbarous bead-work to sell. Maggie's own, in short, would have been sought in vain in the most rudimentary map of the social relations as such. The only geography marking it would be doubtless that of the fundamental passions. The
``end'' (the Prince)
that the Prince was at all events holding out for was represented to expectation by his (Prince) father-in-law's announced departure for America with Mrs. Verver; just as that prospective event had originally figured as advising, for discretion, the flight of the younger couple, to say nothing of the withdrawal of whatever other importunate company, before the great upheaval of Fawns. This residence was to be peopled for a month by porters, packers and hammerers, at whose operations it had become peculiarly public--public that is for Portland Place--that Charlotte was to preside in force; operations the quite awful appointed scale and style of which had at no moment loomed so large to Maggie's mind as one day when the dear Assinghams swam back into her (Maggie) ken besprinkled with sawdust and looking as pale as if they had seen Samson pull down the temple. They had seen at least what she (Maggie) was not seeing, rich dim things under the impression of which they had retired; she (Maggie) having eyes at present but for the clock by which she (Maggie) timed her (Maggie) husband, or for the glass--the image perhaps would be truer--in which he (husband) was reflected to her (Maggie) as HE (husband) timed the pair in the country. The accession of their friends from Cadogan Place contributed to all their intermissions, at any rate, a certain effect of resonance; an effect especially marked by the upshot of a prompt exchange of inquiries between Mrs. Assingham and the Princess. It was noted, on the occasion of that anxious lady's last approach to her (lady) young friend at Fawns, that her (lady) sympathy had ventured, after much accepted privation, again to become inquisitive, and it had perhaps never so yielded to that need as on this question of the present odd
``line'' (friend)
of the distinguished eccentrics.

``You mean to say really that you're going to stick here?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
And then before Maggie could answer:
``What on earth will you do with your evenings?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie waited a moment--Maggie could still tentatively smile.

``When people learn we're here--and of course the papers will be full of it!--they'll flock back in their hundreds, from wherever they are, to catch us. You see you and the Colonel have yourselves done it. As for our evenings, they won't, I dare say, be particularly different from anything else that's ours. They won't be different from our mornings or our afternoons--except perhaps that you two dears will sometimes help us to get through them. I've offered to go anywhere,'' (she)
she (Maggie) added;
``to take a house if he (Colonel) will. But THIS--just this and nothing else--is Amerigo's idea. He (Colonel) gave it yesterday'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``a name that, as, he (Colonel) said, described and fitted it. So you see'' (she)
--and the Princess indulged again in her (Princess) smile that didn't play, but that only, as might have been said, worked--
``so you see there's a method in our madness.'' (the Princess)

It drew Mrs. Assingham's wonder.

``And what then is the name?'' (he)

```The reduction to its simplest expression of what we ARE doing'--that's what he (Princess) called it. Therefore as we're doing nothing, we're doing it in the most aggravated way--which is the way he (Princess) desires.'' With which Maggie further said:

``Of course I understand.'' (unknown)

``So do I!'' (visitor)
her (Maggie) visitor after a moment breathed.
``You've had to vacate the house--that was inevitable. But at least here he (Colonel) doesn't funk.'' (woman)

Our young woman accepted the expression.

``He (Colonel) doesn't funk.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

It only, however, half contented Fanny, who thoughtfully raised her (Fanny) eyebrows.

``He (Colonel)'s prodigious; but what is there--as you've `fixed' it--TO dodge? Unless,'' (she)
she (Fanny) pursued,
``it's her (Colonel) getting near him (Colonel); it's--if you'll pardon my vulgarity--her (Colonel) getting AT him (Colonel). That,'' (she)
she (Fanny) suggested,
``may count with him (Colonel).'' (she)

But it found the Princess prepared.

``She (Colonel) can get near him (Colonel) here. She (Colonel) can get `at' him (Colonel). She (Colonel) can come up.'' (unknown)

``CAN she (Colonel)?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham questioned.

``CAN'T she (Colonel)?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie returned.

Their eyes, for a minute, intimately met on it; after which the elder woman said:

``I mean for seeing him (Colonel) alone.'' (the woman)

``So do I,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

At which Fanny, for her (Fanny) reasons, couldn't help smiling.

``Oh, if it's for THAT he (Colonel)'s staying--!'' (unknown)

``He (Colonel)'s staying--I've made it out--to take anything that comes or calls upon him (Colonel). To take,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on,
``even that.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Then she (Maggie) put it as she (Maggie) had at last put it to herself.
``He (Colonel)'s staying for high decency.'' (unknown)

``Decency?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham gravely echoed.

``Decency. If she (Colonel) SHOULD try--!'' (unknown)

``Well--?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham urged.

``Well, I hope--!'' (unknown)

``Hope he (Colonel)'ll see her (Colonel)?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie hesitated, however; she (Maggie) made no direct reply.

``It's useless hoping,'' (she)
she (Maggie) presently said.
``She (Colonel) won't. But he (Colonel) ought to.'' (friend)
Her (Maggie) friend's expression of a moment before, which had been apologised for as vulgar, prolonged its sharpness to her (Maggie) ear--that of an electric bell under continued pressure. Stated so simply, what was it but dreadful, truly, that the feasibility of Charlotte's
``getting at'' (Charlotte)
the man who for so long had loved her (Charlotte) should now be in question? Strangest of all things, doubtless, this care of Maggie's as to what might make for it or make against it; stranger still her (Maggie) fairly lapsing at moments into a vague calculation of the conceivability, on her (Maggie) own part, with her (Maggie) husband, of some direct sounding of the subject. Would it be too monstrous, her (Maggie) suddenly breaking out to him (husband) as in alarm at the lapse of the weeks:
``Wouldn't it really seem that you're bound in honour to do something for her (Colonel), privately, before they go?'' (him)
Maggie was capable of weighing the risk of this adventure for her (Maggie) own spirit, capable of sinking to intense little absences, even while conversing, as now, with the person who had most of her (Maggie) confidence, during which she (Maggie) followed up the possibilities. It was true that Mrs. Assingham could at such times somewhat restore the balance--by not wholly failing to guess her (Assingham) thought. Her (Assingham) thought, however, just at present, had more than one face--had a series that it successively presented. These were indeed the possibilities involved in the adventure of her (Assingham) concerning herself for the quantity of compensation that Mrs. Verver might still look to. There was always the possibility that she (Verver) WAS, after all, sufficiently to get at him (Maggie)--there was in fact that of her (Verver) having again and again done so. Against this stood nothing but Fanny Assingham's apparent belief in her (Assingham) privation--more mercilessly imposed, or more hopelessly felt, in the actual relation of the parties; over and beyond everything that, from more than three months back, of course, had fostered in the Princess a like conviction. These assumptions might certainly be baseless--inasmuch as there were hours and hours of Amerigo's time that there was no habit, no pretence of his (Maggie) accounting for; inasmuch too as Charlotte, inevitably, had had more than once, to the undisguised knowledge of the pair in Portland Place, been obliged to come up to Eaton Square, whence so many of her (Charlotte) personal possessions were in course of removal. She (Charlotte) didn't come to Portland Place--didn't even come to ask for luncheon on two separate occasions when it reached the consciousness of the household there that she (Charlotte) was spending the day in London. Maggie hated, she (Maggie) scorned, to compare hours and appearances, to weigh the idea of whether there hadn't been moments, during these days, when an assignation, in easy conditions, a snatched interview, in an air the season had so cleared of prying eyes, mightn't perfectly work. But the very reason of this was partly that, haunted with the vision of the poor woman carrying off with such bravery as she (woman) found to her (woman) hand the secret of her (woman) not being appeased, she (woman) was conscious of scant room for any alternative image. The alternative image would have been that the secret covered up was the secret of appeasement somehow obtained, somehow extorted and cherished; and the difference between the two kinds of hiding was too great to permit of a mistake. Charlotte was hiding neither pride nor joy--she (Charlotte) was hiding humiliation; and here it was that the Princess's passion, so powerless for vindictive flights, most inveterately bruised its tenderness against the hard glass of her (Princess) question.

Behind the glass lurked the WHOLE history of the relation she (Princess) had so fairly flattened her (Princess) nose against it to penetrate--the glass Mrs. Verver might, at this stage, have been frantically tapping, from within, by way of supreme, irrepressible entreaty. Maggie had said to herself complacently, after that last passage with her (Maggie) stepmother in the garden of Fawns, that there was nothing left for her (Maggie) to do and that she (Maggie) could thereupon fold her (Maggie) hands. But why wasn't it still left to push further and, from the point of view of personal pride, grovel lower?--why wasn't it still left to offer herself as the bearer of a message reporting to him (Maggie) their friend's anguish and convincing him (Maggie) of her (Maggie) need?

She (Maggie) could thus have translated Mrs. Verver's tap against the glass, as I have called it, into fifty forms; could perhaps have translated it most into the form of a reminder that would pierce deep.

``You don't know what it is to have been loved and broken with. You haven't been broken with, because in your RELATION what can there have been, worth speaking of, to break? Ours was everything a relation could be, filled to the brim with the wine of consciousness; and if it was to have no meaning, no better meaning than that such a creature as you could breathe upon it, at your hour, for blight, why was I myself dealt with all for deception? why condemned after a couple of short years to find the golden flame--oh, the golden flame!--a mere handful of black ashes?'' (woman)
Our young woman so yielded, at moments, to what was insidious in these foredoomed ingenuities of her (woman) pity, that for minutes together, sometimes, the weight of a new duty seemed to rest upon her (woman)--the duty of speaking before separation should constitute its chasm, of pleading for some benefit that might be carried away into exile like the last saved object of price of the emigre, the jewel wrapped in a piece of old silk and negotiable some day in the market of misery.

This imagined service to the woman who could no longer help herself was one of the traps set for Maggie's spirit at every turn of the road; the click of which, catching and holding the divine faculty fast, was followed inevitably by a flutter, by a struggle of wings and even, as we may say, by a scattering of fine feathers. For they promptly enough felt, these yearnings of thought and excursions of sympathy, the concussion that couldn't bring them down--the arrest produced by the so remarkably distinct figure that, at Fawns, for the previous weeks, was constantly crossing, in its regular revolution, the further end of any watched perspective.
