Whoever knew, or whoever didn't, whether or to what extent Charlotte, with natural business in Eaton Square, had shuffled other opportunities under that cloak, it was all matter for the kind of quiet ponderation the little man who so kept his (man) wandering way had made his (man) own. It was part of the very inveteracy of his (man) straw hat and his (man) white waistcoat, of the trick of his (man) hands in his (man) pockets, of the detachment of the attention he (man) fixed on his (man) slow steps from behind his (man) secure pince-nez. The thing that never failed now as an item in the picture was that gleam of the silken noose, his (man) wife's immaterial tether, so marked to Maggie's sense during her (Maggie) last month in the country. Mrs. Verver's straight neck had certainly not slipped it; nor had the other end of the long cord--oh, quite conveniently long!--disengaged its smaller loop from the hooked thumb that, with his (man) fingers closed upon it, her (Maggie) husband kept out of sight. To have recognised, for all its tenuity, the play of this gathered lasso might inevitably be to wonder with what magic it was twisted, to what tension subjected, but could never be to doubt either of its adequacy to its office or of its perfect durability. These reminded states for the Princess were in fact states of renewed gaping. So many things her (Princess) father knew that she (Princess) even yet didn't!

All this, at present, with Mrs. Assingham, passed through her (Assingham) in quick vibrations. She (Assingham) had expressed, while the revolution of her (Assingham) thought was incomplete, the idea of what Amerigo

``ought,'' (Amerigo)
on his (father) side, in the premises, to be capable of, and then had felt her (Assingham) companion's answering stare. But she (Assingham) insisted on what she (Assingham) had meant.
``He (I) ought to wish to see her (myself)--and I mean in some protected and independent way, as he (I) used to--in case of her (myself) being herself able to manage it. That,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie with the courage of her (Maggie) conviction,
``he (I) ought to be ready, he (I) ought to be happy, he (I) ought to feel himself sworn--little as it is for the end of such a history!--to take from her (myself). It's as if he (I) wished to get off without taking anything.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Mrs. Assingham deferentially mused.

``But for what purpose is it your idea that they should again so intimately meet?'' (unknown)

``For any purpose they like. That's THEIR affair.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny Assingham sharply laughed, then irrepressibly fell back to her (Assingham) constant position.

``You're splendid--perfectly splendid.'' (the Princess)
To which, as the Princess, shaking an impatient head, wouldn't have it again at all, she (Princess) subjoined:
``Or if you're not it's because you're so sure. I mean sure of HIM.'' (she)

``Ah, I'm exactly NOT sure of him (I). If I were sure of him (I) I shouldn't doubt--!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
But Maggie cast about her (Maggie).

``Doubt what?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny pressed as she (Fanny) waited.

``Well, that he (I) must feel how much less than she (I) he (I) pays--and how that ought to keep her (I) present to him (I).'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

This, in its turn, after an instant, Mrs. Assingham could meet with a smile.

``Trust him (I), my dear, to keep her (I) present! But trust him (I) also to keep himself absent. Leave him (I) his (I) own way.'' (unknown)

``I'll leave him (I) everything,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.
``Only--you know it's my nature--I THINK.'' (unknown)

``It's your nature to think too much,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny Assingham a trifle coarsely risked.

This but quickened, however, in the Princess the act she (Princess) reprobated.

``That may be. But if I hadn't thought--!'' (unknown)

``You wouldn't, you mean, have been where you are?'' (unknown)

``Yes, because they, on their side, thought of everything BUT that. They thought of everything but that I might think.'' (unknown)

``Or even,'' (friend)
her (Princess) friend too superficially concurred,
``that your father might!'' (friend)

As to this, at all events, Maggie discriminated.

``No, that wouldn't have prevented them; for they knew that his (father) first care would be not to make me do so. As it is,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie added,
``that has had to become his (father) last.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Fanny Assingham took it in deeper--for what it immediately made her (Assingham) give out louder.

``HE (father)'S splendid then.'' (She)
She (Assingham) sounded it almost aggressively; it was what she (Assingham) was reduced to--she (Assingham) had positively to place it.

``Ah, that as much as you please!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie said this and left it, but the tone of it had the next moment determined in her (Maggie) friend a fresh reaction.

``You think, both of you, so abysmally and yet so quietly. But it's what will have saved you.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie returned,
``it's what--from the moment they discovered we could think at all--will have saved THEM. For they're the ones who are saved,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) went on.
``We're the ones who are lost.'' (unknown)

``Lost--?'' (unknown)

``Lost to each other--father and I.'' (friend)
And then as her (Maggie) friend appeared to demur,
``Oh yes,'' (friend)
Maggie quite lucidly declared,
``lost to each other much more, really, than Amerigo and Charlotte are; since for them it's just, it's right, it's deserved, while for us it's only sad and strange and not caused by our fault. But I don't know,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) went on,
``why I talk about myself, for it's on father it really comes. I let him (father) go,'' (she)
said Maggie.

``You let him (father), but you don't make him (father).'' (unknown)

``I take it from him (father),'' (she)
she (Maggie) answered.

``But what else can you do?'' (unknown)

``I take it from him (father),'' (the Princess)
the Princess repeated.
``I do what I knew from the first I SHOULD do. I get off by giving him (father) up.'' (unknown)

``But if he (father) gives you?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham presumed to object.
``Doesn't it moreover then,'' (she)
she (Assingham) asked,
``complete the very purpose with which he (father) married--that of making you and leaving you more free?'' (she)

Maggie looked at her (Maggie) long.

``Yes--I help him (father) to do that.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Mrs. Assingham hesitated, but at last her (Assingham) bravery flared.

``Why not call it then frankly his (father) complete success?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``that's all that's left me to do.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``It's a success,'' (friend)
her (Maggie) friend ingeniously developed,
``with which you've simply not interfered.'' (friend)
And as if to show that she (Maggie) spoke without levity Mrs. Assingham went further.
``He (father) has made it a success for THEM--!'' (unknown)

``Ah, there you are!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie responsively mused.
``Yes,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said the next moment,
``that's why Amerigo stays.'' (she)

``Let alone it's why Charlotte goes.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
that Mrs. Assingham, and emboldened, smiled
``So he (father) knows--?'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

But Maggie hung back.

``Amerigo--?'' (she)
After which, however, she (Maggie) blushed--to her (Maggie) companion's recognition.

``Your father. He (father) knows what YOU know? I mean,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny faltered--
``well, how much does he (father) know?'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Maggie's silence and Maggie's eyes had in fact arrested the push of the question--which, for a decent consistency, she (Maggie) couldn't yet quite abandon.
``What I should rather say is does he (father) know how much?'' (She)
She (Maggie) found it still awkward.
``How much, I mean, they did. How far'' (she)
--she (Maggie) touched it up--
``they went.'' (she)

Maggie had waited, but only with a question.

``Do you think he (father) does?'' (unknown)

``Know at least something? Oh, about him (father) I can't think. He (father)'s beyond me,'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
said Fanny Assingham.

``Then do you yourself know?'' (unknown)

``How much--?'' (unknown)

``How much.'' (unknown)

``How far--?'' (unknown)

``How far.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)

Fanny had appeared to wish to make sure, but there was something she (Assingham) remembered--remembered in time and even with a smile.

``I've told you before that I know absolutely nothing.'' (unknown)

``Well--that's what _I_ know,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess.

Her (Princess) friend again hesitated.

``Then nobody knows--? I mean,'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)
Mrs. Assingham explained,
``how much your father does.'' (Mrs. Assingham/Assingham)

Oh, Maggie showed that she (Maggie) understood.

``Nobody.'' (unknown)

``Not--a little--Charlotte?'' (unknown)

``A little?'' (the Princess)
the Princess echoed.
``To know anything would be, for her (Charlotte), to know enough.'' (unknown)

``And she (Charlotte) doesn't know anything?'' (unknown)

``If she (Charlotte) did,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie answered,
``Amerigo would.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``And that's just it--that he (father) doesn't?'' (unknown)

``That's just it,'' (the Princess)
said the Princess profoundly.

On which Mrs. Assingham reflected.

``Then how is Charlotte so held?'' (unknown)

``Just by that.'' (unknown)

``By her (Charlotte) ignorance?'' (unknown)

``By her (Charlotte) ignorance.'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
Fanny wondered.
``A torment--?'' (unknown)

``A torment,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie with tears in her (Maggie) eyes.

Her (Maggie) companion a moment watched them.

``But the Prince then--?'' (unknown)

``How is HE (Prince) held?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie asked.

``How is HE (Prince) held?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I can't tell you that!'' (the Princess)
And the Princess again broke off.

XLI

A telegram, in Charlotte's name, arrived early--

``We shall come and ask you for tea at five, if convenient to you. Am wiring for the Assinghams to lunch.'' (Charlotte)
This document, into which meanings were to be read, Maggie promptly placed before her (Maggie) husband, adding the remark that her (Maggie) father and his (father) wife, who would have come up the previous night or that morning, had evidently gone to an hotel. The Prince was in his (Prince)
``own'' (The Prince)
room, where he (Prince) often sat now alone; half-a-dozen open newspapers, the
``Figaro'' (he)
notably, as well as the
``Times,'' (he)
were scattered about him (Prince); but, with a cigar in his (Prince) teeth and a visible cloud on his (Prince) brow, he (Prince) appeared actually to be engaged in walking to and fro. Never yet, on thus approaching him (Prince)--for she (Maggie) had done it of late, under one necessity or another, several times--had a particular impression so greeted her (Maggie); supremely strong, for some reason, as he (Prince) turned quickly round on her (Maggie) entrance. The reason was partly the look in his (Prince) face--a suffusion like the flush of fever, which brought back to her (Maggie) Fanny Assingham's charge, recently uttered under that roof, of her (Maggie)
``thinking'' (Fanny/Fanny Assingham)
too impenetrably. The word had remained with her (Maggie) and made her (Maggie) think still more; so that, at first, as she (Maggie) stood there, she (Maggie) felt responsible for provoking on his (Prince) part an irritation of suspense at which she (Maggie) had not aimed. She (Maggie) had been going about him (Prince) these three months, she (Maggie) perfectly knew, with a maintained idea--of which she (Maggie) had never spoken to him (Prince); but what had at last happened was that his (Prince) way of looking at her (Maggie), on occasion, seemed a perception of the presence not of one idea, but of fifty, variously prepared for uses with which he (Prince) somehow must reckon. She (Maggie) knew herself suddenly, almost strangely, glad to be coming to him (Prince), at this hour, with nothing more abstract than a telegram; but even after she (Maggie) had stepped into his (Prince) prison under her (Maggie) pretext, while her (Maggie) eyes took in his (Prince) face and then embraced the four walls that enclosed his (Prince) restlessness, she (Maggie) recognised the virtual identity of his (Prince) condition with that aspect of Charlotte's situation for which, early in the summer and in all the amplitude of a great residence, she (Charlotte) had found, with so little seeking, the similitude of the locked cage. He (Prince) struck her (Charlotte) as caged, the man who couldn't now without an instant effect on her (Charlotte) sensibility give an instinctive push to the door she (Charlotte) had not completely closed behind her (Charlotte). He (man) had been turning twenty ways, for impatiences all his (man) own, and when she (Charlotte) was once shut in with him (man) it was yet again as if she (Charlotte) had come to him (man) in his (man) more than monastic cell to offer him (man) light or food. There was a difference none the less, between his (man) captivity and Charlotte's--the difference, as it might be, of his (man) lurking there by his (man) own act and his (man) own choice; the admission of which had indeed virtually been in his (man) starting, on her (Charlotte) entrance, as if even this were in its degree an interference. That was what betrayed for her (Charlotte), practically, his (man) fear of her (Charlotte) fifty ideas, and what had begun, after a minute, to make her (Charlotte) wish to repudiate or explain. It was more wonderful than she (Charlotte) could have told; it was for all the world as if she (Charlotte) was succeeding with him (man) beyond her (Charlotte) intention. She (Charlotte) had, for these instants, the sense that he (man) exaggerated, that the imputation of purpose had fairly risen too high in him (man). She (Charlotte) had begun, a year ago, by asking herself how she (Charlotte) could make him (man) think more of her (Charlotte); but what was it, after all, he (man) was thinking now? He (man) kept his (man) eyes on her (Charlotte) telegram; he (man) read it more than once, easy as it was, in spite of its conveyed deprecation, to understand; during which she (Charlotte) found herself almost awestruck with yearning, almost on the point of marking somehow what she (Charlotte) had marked in the garden at Fawns with Charlotte--that she (Charlotte) had truly come unarmed. She (Charlotte) didn't bristle with intentions--she (Charlotte) scarce knew, as he (man) at this juncture affected her (Charlotte), what had become of the only intention she (Charlotte) had come with. She (Charlotte) had nothing but her (Charlotte) old idea, the old one he (man) knew; she (Charlotte) hadn't the ghost of another. Presently in fact, when four or five minutes had elapsed, it was as if she (Charlotte) positively, hadn't so much even as that one. He (man) gave her (Charlotte) back her (Charlotte) paper, asking with it if there were anything in particular she (Charlotte) wished him (man) to do.

She (Charlotte) stood there with her (Charlotte) eyes on him (man), doubling the telegram together as if it had been a precious thing and yet all the while holding her (Charlotte) breath. Of a sudden, somehow, and quite as by the action of their merely having between them these few written words, an extraordinary fact came up. He (man) was with her (Charlotte) as if he (man) were hers, hers in a degree and on a scale, with an intensity and an intimacy, that were a new and a strange quantity, that were like the irruption of a tide loosening them where they had stuck and making them feel they floated. What was it that, with the rush of this, just kept her (Charlotte) from putting out her (Charlotte) hands to him (man), from catching at him (man) as, in the other time, with the superficial impetus he (man) and Charlotte had privately conspired to impart, she (Charlotte) had so often, her (Charlotte) breath failing her (Charlotte), known the impulse to catch at her (Charlotte) father? She (Charlotte) did, however, just yet, nothing inconsequent--though she (Charlotte) couldn't immediately have said what saved her (Charlotte); and by the time she (Charlotte) had neatly folded her (Charlotte) telegram she (Charlotte) was doing something merely needful.

``I wanted you simply to know--so that you mayn't by accident miss them. For it's the last,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

``The last?'' (unknown)

``I take it as their good-bye.'' (she)
And she (Maggie) smiled as she (Maggie) could always smile.
``They come in state--to take formal leave. They do everything that's proper. Tomorrow,'' (she)
she (Maggie) said,
``they go to Southampton.'' (she)

``If they do everything that's proper,'' (the Prince)
the Prince presently asked,
``why don't they at least come to dine?'' (the Prince)

She (Maggie) hesitated, yet she (Maggie) lightly enough provided her (Maggie) answer.

``That we must certainly ask them. It will be easy for you. But of course they're immensely taken--!'' (He)

He (Prince) wondered.

``So immensely taken that they can't--that your father can't--give you his (father) last evening in England?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

This, for Maggie, was more difficult to meet; yet she (Maggie) was still not without her (Maggie) stop-gap.

``That may be what they'll propose--that we shall go somewhere together, the four of us, for a celebration--except that, to round it thoroughly off, we ought also to have Fanny and the Colonel. They don't WANT them at tea, she (Fanny) quite sufficiently expresses; they polish them off, poor dears, they get rid of them, beforehand. They want only us together; and if they cut us down to tea,'' (she)
she (Maggie) continued,
``as they cut Fanny and the Colonel down to luncheon, perhaps it's for the fancy, after all, of their keeping their last night in London for each other.'' (she)

She (Maggie) said these things as they came to her (Maggie); she (Maggie) was unable to keep them back, even though, as she (Maggie) heard herself, she (Maggie) might have been throwing everything to the winds. But wasn't that the right way--for sharing his (Prince) last day of captivity with the man one adored? It was every moment more and more for her (Maggie) as if she (Maggie) were waiting with him (Prince) in his (Prince) prison--waiting with some gleam of remembrance of how noble captives in the French Revolution, the darkness of the Terror, used to make a feast, or a high discourse, of their last poor resources. If she (Maggie) had broken with everything now, every observance of all the past months, she (Maggie) must simply then take it so--take it that what she (Maggie) had worked for was too near, at last, to let her (Maggie) keep her (Maggie) head. She (Maggie) might have been losing her (Maggie) head verily in her (Maggie) husband's eyes--since he (husband) didn't know, all the while, that the sudden freedom of her (Maggie) words was but the diverted intensity of her (Maggie) disposition personally to seize him (husband). He (husband) didn't know, either, that this was her (Maggie) manner--now she (Maggie) was with him (husband)--of beguiling audaciously the supremacy of suspense. For the people of the French Revolution, assuredly, there wasn't suspense; the scaffold, for those she (Maggie) was thinking of, was certain--whereas what Charlotte's telegram announced was, short of some incalculable error, clear liberation. Just the point, however, was in its being clearer to herself than to him (husband); her (Charlotte) clearnesses, clearances--those she (Charlotte) had so all but abjectly laboured for--threatened to crowd upon her (Charlotte) in the form of one of the clusters of angelic heads, the peopled shafts of light beating down through iron bars, that regale, on occasion, precisely, the fevered vision of those who are in chains. She (Charlotte) was going to know, she (Charlotte) felt, later on--was going to know with compunction, doubtless, on the very morrow, how thumpingly her (Charlotte) heart had beaten at this foretaste of their being left together: she (Charlotte) should judge at leisure the surrender she (Charlotte) was making to the consciousness of complications about to be bodily lifted. She (Charlotte) should judge at leisure even that avidity for an issue which was making so little of any complication but the unextinguished presence of the others; and indeed that she (Charlotte) was already simplifying so much more than her (Charlotte) husband came out for her (Charlotte) next in the face with which he (husband) listened. He (husband) might certainly well be puzzled, in respect to his (husband) father-in-law and Mrs. Verver, by her (Verver) glance at their possible preference for a concentrated evening.

``But it isn't--is it?'' (he)
he (husband) asked--
``as if they were leaving each other?'' (he)

``Oh no; it isn't as if they were leaving each other. They're only bringing to a close--without knowing when it may open again--a time that has been, naturally, awfully interesting to them.'' (she)
Yes, she (Verver) could talk so of their
``time'' (she)
--she (Verver) was somehow sustained; she (Verver) was sustained even to affirm more intensely her (Verver) present possession of her (Verver) ground.
``They have their reasons--many things to think of; how can one tell? But there's always, also, the chance of his (it) proposing to me that we shall have our last hours together; I mean that he (it) and I shall. He (it) may wish to take me off to dine with him (it) somewhere alone--and to do it in memory of old days. I mean,'' (the Princess)
the Princess went on,
``the real old days; before my grand husband was invented and, much more, before his (husband) grand wife was: the wonderful times of his (husband) first great interest in what he (husband) has since done, his (husband) first great plans and opportunities, discoveries and bargains. The way we've sat together late, ever so late, in foreign restaurants, which he (husband) used to like; the way that, in every city in Europe, we've stayed on and on, with our elbows on the table and most of the lights put out, to talk over things he (husband) had that day seen or heard of or made his (husband) offer for, the things he (husband) had secured or refused or lost! There were places he (husband) took me to--you wouldn't believe!--for often he (husband) could only have left me with servants. If he (husband) should carry me off with him (husband) to-night, for old sake's sake, to the Earl's Court Exhibition, it will be a little--just a very, very little--like our young adventures.'' (the Princess)
After which while Amerigo watched her (Princess), and in fact quite because of it, she (Princess) had an inspiration, to which she (Princess) presently yielded. If he (husband) was wondering what she (Princess) would say next she (Princess) had found exactly the thing.
``In that case he (Earl) will leave you Charlotte to take care of in our absence. You'll have to carry her (Charlotte) off somewhere for your last evening; unless you may prefer to spend it with her (Charlotte) here. I shall then see that you dine, that you have everything, quite beautifully. You'll be able to do as you like.'' (She)

She (Princess) couldn't have been sure beforehand, and had really not been; but the most immediate result of this speech was his (husband) letting her (Princess) see that he (husband) took it for no cheap extravagance either of irony or of oblivion. Nothing in the world, of a truth, had ever been so sweet to her (Princess), as his (husband) look of trying to be serious enough to make no mistake about it. She (Princess) troubled him (husband)--which hadn't been at all her (Princess) purpose; she (Princess) mystified him (husband)--which she (Princess) couldn't help and, comparatively, didn't mind; then it came over her (Princess) that he (husband) had, after all, a simplicity, very considerable, on which she (Princess) had never dared to presume. It was a discovery--not like the other discovery she (Princess) had once made, but giving out a freshness; and she (Princess) recognised again in the light of it the number of the ideas of which he (husband) thought her (Princess) capable. They were all, apparently, queer for him (husband), but she (Princess) had at least, with the lapse of the months, created the perception that there might be something in them; whereby he (husband) stared there, beautiful and sombre, at what she (Princess) was at present providing him (husband) with. There was something of his (husband) own in his (husband) mind, to which, she (Princess) was sure, he (husband) referred everything for a measure and a meaning; he (husband) had never let go of it, from the evening, weeks before, when, in her (Princess) room, after his (husband) encounter with the Bloomsbury cup, she (Princess) had planted it there by flinging it at him (husband), on the question of her (Princess) father's view of him (husband), her (Princess) determined

``Find out for yourself!'' (him)
She (Princess) had been aware, during the months, that he (husband) had been trying to find out, and had been seeking, above all, to avoid the appearance of any evasions of such a form of knowledge as might reach him (husband), with violence or with a penetration more insidious, from any other source. Nothing, however, had reached him (husband); nothing he (husband) could at all conveniently reckon with had disengaged itself for him (husband) even from the announcement, sufficiently sudden, of the final secession of their companions. Charlotte was in pain, Charlotte was in torment, but he (husband) himself had given her (Charlotte) reason enough for that; and, in respect to the rest of the whole matter of her (Charlotte) obligation to follow her (Charlotte) husband, that personage and she (Charlotte), Maggie, had so shuffled away every link between consequence and cause, that the intention remained, like some famous poetic line in a dead language, subject to varieties of interpretation. What renewed the obscurity was her (Maggie) strange image of their common offer to him (husband), her (Maggie) father's and her (Maggie) own, of an opportunity to separate from Mrs. Verver with the due amount of form--and all the more that he (husband) was, in so pathetic a way, unable to treat himself to a quarrel with it on the score of taste. Taste, in him (husband), as a touchstone, was now all at sea; for who could say but that one of her (Verver) fifty ideas, or perhaps forty-nine of them, wouldn't be, exactly, that taste by itself, the taste he (husband) had always conformed to, had no importance whatever? If meanwhile, at all events, he (husband) felt her (Verver) as serious, this made the greater reason for her (Verver) profiting by it as she (Verver) perhaps might never be able to profit again. She (Verver) was invoking that reflection at the very moment he (husband) brought out, in reply to her (Verver) last words, a remark which, though perfectly relevant and perfectly just, affected her (Verver) at first as a high oddity.
``They're doing the wisest thing, you know. For if they were ever to go--!'' (he)
And he (husband) looked down at her (Verver) over his (husband) cigar.

If they were ever to go, in short, it was high time, with her (Verver) father's age, Charlotte's need of initiation, and the general magnitude of the job of their getting settled and seasoned, their learning to

``live into'' (Charlotte)
their queer future--it was high time that they should take up their courage. This was eminent sense, but it didn't arrest the Princess, who, the next moment, had found a form for her (Princess) challenge.
``But shan't you then so much as miss her (Charlotte) a little? She (Charlotte)'s wonderful and beautiful, and I feel somehow as if she (Charlotte) were dying. Not really, not physically,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on--
``she (Charlotte)'s so far, naturally, splendid as she (Charlotte) is, from having done with life. But dying for us--for you and me; and making us feel it by the very fact of there being so much of her (Charlotte) left.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

The Prince smoked hard a minute.

``As you say, she (Charlotte)'s splendid, but there is--there always will be--much of her (Charlotte) left. Only, as you also say, for others.'' (unknown)

``And yet I think,'' (the Princess)
the Princess returned,
``that it isn't as if we had wholly done with her (Charlotte). How can we not always think of her (Charlotte)? It's as if her (Charlotte) unhappiness had been necessary to us--as if we had needed her (Charlotte), at her (Charlotte) own cost, to build us up and start us.'' (the Princess)

He (Prince) took it in with consideration, but he (Prince) met it with a lucid inquiry.

``Why do you speak of the unhappiness of your father's wife?'' (her)

They exchanged a long look--the time that it took her (Princess) to find her (Princess) reply.

``Because not to--!'' (unknown)

``Well, not to--?'' (unknown)

``Would make me have to speak of him (father). And I can't,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``speak of him (father).'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``You `can't'--?'' (unknown)

``I can't.'' (She)
She (Maggie) said it as for definite notice, not to be repeated.
``There are too many things,'' (she)
she (Maggie) nevertheless added.
``He (father)'s too great.'' (The Prince)

The Prince looked at his (Prince) cigar-tip, and then as he (Prince) put back the weed:

``Too great for whom?'' (he)
Upon which as she (Maggie) hesitated,
``Not, my dear, too great for you,'' (she)
he (Prince) declared.
``For me--oh, as much as you like.'' (unknown)

``Too great for me is what I mean. I know why I think it,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie said.
``That's enough.'' (He)

He (Prince) looked at her (Maggie) yet again as if she (Maggie) but fanned his (Prince) wonder; he (Prince) was on the very point, she (Maggie) judged, of asking her (Maggie) why she (Maggie) thought it. But her (Maggie) own eyes maintained their warning, and at the end of a minute he (Prince) had uttered other words.

``What's of importance is that you're his (father) daughter. That at least we've got. And I suppose that, if I may say nothing else, I may say at least that I value it.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, you may say that you value it. I myself make the most of it.'' (he)

This again he (Prince) took in, letting it presently put forth for him (Prince) a striking connection.

``She (daughter) ought to have known you. That's what's present to me. She (daughter) ought to have understood you better.'' (unknown)

``Better than you did?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Prince) gravely maintained,
``better than I did. And she (daughter) didn't really know you at all. She (daughter) doesn't know you now.'' (he)

``Ah, yes she (daughter) does!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie.

But he (Prince) shook his (Prince) head--he (Prince) knew what he (Prince) meant.

``She (daughter) not only doesn't understand you more than I, she (daughter) understands you ever so much less. Though even I--!'' (unknown)

``Well, even you?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie pressed as he (Prince) paused.
``Even I, even I even yet--!'' (he)
Again he (Prince) paused and the silence held them.

But Maggie at last broke it.

``If Charlotte doesn't understand me, it is that I've prevented her (Charlotte). I've chosen to deceive her (Charlotte) and to lie to her (Charlotte).'' (The Prince)

The Prince kept his (Prince) eyes on her (Maggie).

``I know what you've chosen to do. But I've chosen to do the same.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie after an instant--
``my choice was made when I had guessed yours. But you mean,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) asked,
``that she (Charlotte) understands YOU?'' (she)

``It presents small difficulty!'' (unknown)

``Are you so sure?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie went on.

``Sure enough. But it doesn't matter.'' (He)
He (Prince) waited an instant; then looking up through the fumes of his (Prince) smoke,
``She (Charlotte)'s stupid,'' (He)
he (Prince) abruptly opined.

``O--oh!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie protested in a long wail.

It had made him (Prince) in fact quickly change colour.

``What I mean is that she (Charlotte)'s not, as you pronounce her (Charlotte), unhappy.'' (he)
And he (Prince) recovered, with this, all his (Prince) logic.
``Why is she (Charlotte) unhappy if she (Charlotte) doesn't know?'' (unknown)

``Doesn't know--?'' (She)
She (Maggie) tried to make his (Prince) logic difficult.

``Doesn't know that YOU know.'' (him)

It came from him (Prince) in such a way that she (Maggie) was conscious, instantly, of three or four things to answer. But what she (Maggie) said first was:

``Do you think that's all it need take?'' (she)
And before he (Prince) could reply,
``She (Charlotte) knows, she (Charlotte) knows!'' (he)
Maggie proclaimed.

``Well then, what?'' (she)

But she (Maggie) threw back her (Maggie) head, she (Maggie) turned impatiently away from him (Prince).

``Oh, I needn't tell you! She (Charlotte) knows enough. Besides,'' (she)
she (Maggie) went on,
``she (Charlotte) doesn't believe us.'' (she)

It made the Prince stare a little.

``Ah, she (Charlotte) asks too much!'' (wife)
That drew, however, from his (Prince) wife another moan of objection, which determined in him (Prince) a judgment.
``She (Charlotte) won't let you take her (Charlotte) for unhappy.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I know better than any one else what she (Charlotte) won't let me take her (Charlotte) for!'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Amerigo)
said Amerigo,
``you'll see.'' (Amerigo)

``I shall see wonders, I know. I've already seen them, and I'm prepared for them.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie recalled--she (Maggie) had memories enough.
``It's terrible'' (her)
--her (Maggie) memories prompted her (Maggie) to speak.
``I see it's ALWAYS terrible for women.'' (The Prince)

The Prince looked down in his (Prince) gravity.

``Everything's terrible, cara, in the heart of man. She (Charlotte)'s making her (Charlotte) life,'' (he)
he (Prince) said.
``She (Charlotte)'ll make it.'' (wife)

His (Prince) wife turned back upon him (Prince); she (wife) had wandered to a table, vaguely setting objects straight.

``A little by the way then too, while she (Charlotte)'s about it, she (Charlotte)'s making ours.'' (he)
At this he (Prince) raised his (Prince) eyes, which met her (wife) own, and she (wife) held him (Prince) while she (wife) delivered herself of some thing that had been with her (wife) these last minutes.

``You spoke just now of Charlotte's not having learned from you that I `know.' Am I to take from you then that you accept and recognise my knowledge?'' (He)

He (Prince) did the inquiry all the honours--visibly weighed its importance and weighed his (Prince) response.

``You think I might have been showing you that a little more handsomely?'' (unknown)

``It isn't a question of any beauty,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie;
``it's only a question of the quantity of truth.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Oh, the quantity of truth!'' (the Prince)
the Prince richly, though ambiguously, murmured.

``That's a thing by itself, yes. But there are also such things, all the same, as questions of good faith.'' (unknown)

``Of course there are!'' (the Prince)
the Prince hastened to reply. After which he (Prince) brought up more slowly:
``If ever a man, since the beginning of time, acted in good faith!'' (he)
But he (Prince) dropped it, offering it simply for that.

For that then, when it had had time somewhat to settle, like some handful of gold-dust thrown into the air--for that then Maggie showed herself, as deeply and strangely taking it.

``I see.'' (she)
And she (Maggie) even wished this form to be as complete as she (Maggie) could make it.
``I see.'' (him)

The completeness, clearly, after an instant, had struck him (Prince) as divine.

``Ah, my dear, my dear, my dear--!'' (he)
It was all he (Prince) could say.

She (Maggie) wasn't talking, however, at large.

``You've kept up for so long a silence--!'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes, I know what I've kept up. But will you do,'' (he)
he (Prince) asked,
``still one thing more for me?'' (he)

It was as if, for an instant, with her (Maggie) new exposure, it had made her (Maggie) turn pale.

``Is there even one thing left?'' (unknown)

``Ah, my dear, my dear, my dear!'' (him)
--it had pressed again in him (Prince) the fine spring of the unspeakable. There was nothing, however, that the Princess herself couldn't say.
``I'll do anything, if you'll tell me what.'' (unknown)

``Then wait.'' (unknown)
And his (Prince) raised Italian hand, with its play of admonitory fingers, had never made gesture more expressive. His (Prince) voice itself dropped to a tone--!
``Wait,'' (he)
he (Prince) repeated.
``Wait.'' (She)

She (Princess) understood, but it was as if she (Princess) wished to have it from him (Prince).

``Till they've been here, you mean?'' (unknown)

``Yes, till they've gone. Till they're away.'' (She)

She (Princess) kept it up.

``Till they've left the country?'' (She)
She (Princess) had her (Princess) eyes on him (Prince) for clearness; these were the conditions of a promise--so that he (Prince) put the promise, practically, into his (Prince) response.
``Till we've ceased to see them--for as long as God may grant! Till we're really alone.'' (unknown)

``Oh, if it's only that--!'' (she)
When she (Princess) had drawn from him (Prince) thus then, as she (Princess) could feel, the thick breath of the definite--which was the intimate, the immediate, the familiar, as she (Princess) hadn't had them for so long--she (Princess) turned away again, she (Princess) put her (Princess) hand on the knob of the door. But her (Princess) hand rested at first without a grasp; she (Princess) had another effort to make, the effort of leaving him (Prince), of which everything that had just passed between them, his (Prince) presence, irresistible, overcharged with it, doubled the difficulty. There was something--she (Princess) couldn't have told what; it was as if, shut in together, they had come too far--too far for where they were; so that the mere act of her (Princess) quitting him (Prince) was like the attempt to recover the lost and gone. She (Princess) had taken in with her (Princess) something that, within the ten minutes, and especially within the last three or four, had slipped away from her (Princess)--which it was vain now, wasn't it? to try to appear to clutch or to pick up. That consciousness in fact had a pang, and she (Princess) balanced, intensely, for the lingering moment, almost with a terror of her (Princess) endless power of surrender. He (Prince) had only to press, really, for her (Princess) to yield inch by inch, and she (Princess) fairly knew at present, while she (Princess) looked at him (Prince) through her (Princess) cloud, that the confession of this precious secret sat there for him (Prince) to pluck. The sensation, for the few seconds, was extraordinary; her (Princess) weakness, her (Princess) desire, so long as she (Princess) was yet not saving herself, flowered in her (Princess) face like a light or a darkness. She (Princess) sought for some word that would cover this up; she (Princess) reverted to the question of tea, speaking as if they shouldn't meet sooner.
``Then about five. I count on you.'' (him)

On him (Prince) too, however, something had descended; as to which this exactly gave him (Prince) his (Prince) chance.

``Ah, but I shall see you--! No?'' (he)
he (Prince) said, coming nearer.

She (Princess) had, with her (Princess) hand still on the knob, her (Princess) back against the door, so that her (Princess) retreat, under his (Prince) approach must be less than a step, and yet she (Princess) couldn't for her (Princess) life, with the other hand, have pushed him (Prince) away. He (Prince) was so near now that she (Princess) could touch him (Prince), taste him (Prince), smell him (Prince), kiss him (Prince), hold him (Prince); he (Prince) almost pressed upon her (Princess), and the warmth of his (Prince) face--frowning, smiling, she (Princess) mightn't know which; only beautiful and strange--was bent upon her (Princess) with the largeness with which objects loom in dreams. She (Princess) closed her (Princess) eyes to it, and so, the next instant, against her (Princess) purpose, she (Princess) had put out her (Princess) hand, which had met his (Prince) own and which he (Prince) held. Then it was that, from behind her (Princess) closed eyes, the right word came.

``Wait!'' (unknown)
It was the word of his (Prince) own distress and entreaty, the word for both of them, all they had left, their plank now on the great sea. Their hands were locked, and thus she (Princess) said it again.
``Wait. Wait.'' (She)
She (Princess) kept her (Princess) eyes shut, but her (Princess) hand, she (Princess) knew, helped her (Princess) meaning--which after a minute she (Princess) was aware his (Prince) own had absorbed. He (Prince) let her (Princess) go--he (Prince) turned away with this message, and when she (Princess) saw him (Prince) again his (Prince) back was presented, as he (Prince) had left her (Princess), and his (Prince) face staring out of the window. She (Princess) had saved herself and she (Princess) got off.

XLII

Later on, in the afternoon, before the others arrived, the form of their reunion was at least remarkable: they might, in their great eastward drawing-room, have been comparing notes or nerves in apprehension of some stiff official visit. Maggie's mind, in its restlessness, even played a little with the prospect; the high cool room, with its afternoon shade, with its old tapestries uncovered, with the perfect polish of its wide floor reflecting the bowls of gathered flowers and the silver and linen of the prepared tea-table, drew from her (Maggie) a remark in which this whole effect was mirrored, as well as something else in the Prince's movement while he (Prince) slowly paced and turned.

``We're distinctly bourgeois!'' (she)
she (Maggie) a trifle grimly threw off, as an echo of their old community; though to a spectator sufficiently detached they might have been quite the privileged pair they were reputed, granted only they were taken as awaiting the visit of Royalty. They might have been ready, on the word passed up in advance, to repair together to the foot of the staircase--the Prince somewhat in front, advancing indeed to the open doors and even going down, for all his (Prince) princedom, to meet, on the stopping of the chariot, the august emergence. The time was stale, it was to be admitted, for incidents of magnitude; the September hush was in full possession, at the end of the dull day, and a couple of the long windows stood open to the balcony that overhung the desolation-- the balcony from which Maggie, in the springtime, had seen Amerigo and Charlotte look down together at the hour of her (Charlotte) return from the Regent's Park, near by, with her (Charlotte) father, the Principino and Miss Bogle. Amerigo now again, in his (father) punctual impatience, went out a couple of times and stood there; after which, as to report that nothing was in sight, he (father) returned to the room with frankly nothing else to do. The Princess pretended to read; he (father) looked at her (Princess) as he (father) passed; there hovered in her (Princess) own sense the thought of other occasions when she (Princess) had cheated appearances of agitation with a book. At last she (Princess) felt him (father) standing before her (Princess), and then she (Princess) raised her (Princess) eyes.

``Do you remember how, this morning, when you told me of this event, I asked you if there were anything particular you wished me to do? You spoke of my being at home, but that was a matter of course. You spoke of something else,'' (he)
he (father) went on, while she (Princess) sat with her (Princess) book on her (Princess) knee and her (Princess) raised eyes;
``something that makes me almost wish it may happen. You spoke,'' (she)
he (father) said,
``of the possibility of my seeing her (you) alone. Do you know, if that comes,'' (he)
he (father) asked,
``the use I shall make of it?'' (he)
And then as she (Princess) waited:
``The use is all before me.'' (she)

``Ah, it's your own business now!'' (wife)
said his (father) wife. But it had made her (Princess) rise.

``I shall make it my own,'' (he)
he (father) answered.
``I shall tell her (you) I lied to her (you).'' (unknown)

``Ah no!'' (she)
she (Princess) returned.

``And I shall tell her (you) you did.'' (She)

She (Princess) shook her (Princess) head again.

``Oh, still less!'' (he)

With which therefore they stood at difference, he (father) with his (father) head erect and his (father) happy idea perched, in its eagerness, on his (father) crest.

``And how then is she (you) to know?'' (unknown)

``She (you) isn't to know.'' (unknown)

``She (you)'s only still to think you don't--?'' (unknown)

``And therefore that I'm always a fool? She (you) may think,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie,
``what she (you) likes.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

``Think it without my protest--?'' (The Princess)

The Princess made a movement.

``What business is it of yours?'' (unknown)

``Isn't it my right to correct her (you)--?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie let his (father) question ring--ring long enough for him (father) to hear it himself; only then she (Maggie) took it up. ```Correct' her (Maggie)?''--and it was her (Maggie) own now that really rang. ``Aren't you rather forgetting who she (you) is?'' After which, while he (father) quite stared for it, as it was the very first clear majesty he (father) had known her (Maggie) to use, she (Maggie) flung down her (Maggie) book and raised a warning hand.

``The carriage. Come!'' (unknown)

The

``Come!'' (unknown)
had matched, for lucid firmness, the rest of her (Maggie) speech, and, when they were below, in the hall, there was a
``Go!'' (him)
for him (father), through the open doors and between the ranged servants, that matched even that. He (father) received Royalty, bareheaded, therefore, in the persons of Mr. and Mrs. Verver, as it alighted on the pavement, and Maggie was at the threshold to welcome it to her (Maggie) house. Later on, upstairs again, she (Maggie) even herself felt still more the force of the limit of which she (Maggie) had just reminded him (father); at tea, in Charlotte's affirmed presence--as Charlotte affirmed it--she (Charlotte) drew a long breath of richer relief. It was the strangest, once more, of all impressions; but what she (Charlotte) most felt, for the half-hour, was that Mr. and Mrs. Verver were making the occasion easy. They were somehow conjoined in it, conjoined for a present effect as Maggie had absolutely never yet seen them; and there occurred, before long, a moment in which Amerigo's look met her (Maggie) own in recognitions that he (father) couldn't suppress. The question of the amount of correction to which Charlotte had laid herself open rose and hovered, for the instant, only to sink, conspicuously, by its own weight; so high a pitch she (Charlotte) seemed to give to the unconsciousness of questions, so resplendent a show of serenity she (Charlotte) succeeded in making. The shade of the official, in her (Charlotte) beauty and security, never for a moment dropped; it was a cool, high refuge, like the deep, arched recess of some coloured and gilded image, in which she (Charlotte) sat and smiled and waited, drank her (Charlotte) tea, referred to her (Charlotte) husband and remembered her (Charlotte) mission. Her (Charlotte) mission had quite taken form--it was but another name for the interest of her (Charlotte) great opportunity--that of representing the arts and the graces to a people languishing, afar off, in ignorance. Maggie had sufficiently intimated to the Prince, ten minutes before, that she (Maggie) needed no showing as to what their friend wouldn't consent to be taken for; but the difficulty now indeed was to choose, for explicit tribute of admiration, between the varieties of her (Maggie) nobler aspects. She (Maggie) carried it off, to put the matter coarsely, with a taste and a discretion that held our young woman's attention, for the first quarter-of-an-hour, to the very point of diverting it from the attitude of her (woman) overshadowed, her (woman) almost superseded companion. But Adam Verver profited indeed at this time, even with his (Verver) daughter, by his (Verver) so marked peculiarity of seeming on no occasion to have an attitude; and so long as they were in the room together she (daughter) felt him (Verver) still simply weave his (Verver) web and play out his (Verver) long fine cord, knew herself in presence of this tacit process very much as she (daughter) had known herself at Fawns. He (Verver) had a way, the dear man, wherever he (man) was, of moving about the room, noiselessly, to see what it might contain; and his (man) manner of now resorting to this habit, acquainted as he (man) already was with the objects in view, expressed with a certain sharpness the intention of leaving his (man) wife to her (wife) devices. It did even more than this; it signified, to the apprehension of the Princess, from the moment she (Princess) more directly took thought of him (man), almost a special view of these devices, as actually exhibited in their rarity, together with an independent, a settled appreciation of their general handsome adequacy, which scarcely required the accompaniment of his (man) faint contemplative hum.

Charlotte throned, as who should say, between her (Charlotte) hostess and her (Charlotte) host, the whole scene having crystallised, as soon as she (Charlotte) took her (Charlotte) place, to the right quiet lustre; the harmony was not less sustained for being superficial, and the only approach to a break in it was while Amerigo remained standing long enough for his (man) father-in-law, vaguely wondering, to appeal to him (man), invite or address him (man), and then, in default of any such word, selected for presentation to the other visitor a plate of petits fours. Maggie watched her (Maggie) husband--if it now could be called watching--offer this refreshment; she (Maggie) noted the consummate way--for

``consummate'' (she)
was the term she (Maggie) privately applied--in which Charlotte cleared her (Charlotte) acceptance, cleared her (Charlotte) impersonal smile, of any betrayal, any slightest value, of consciousness; and then felt the slow surge of a vision that, at the end of another minute or two, had floated her (Charlotte) across the room to where her (Charlotte) father stood looking at a picture, an early Florentine sacred subject, that he (father) had given her (Charlotte) on her (Charlotte) marriage. He (father) might have been, in silence, taking his (father) last leave of it; it was a work for which he (father) entertained, she (Charlotte) knew, an unqualified esteem. The tenderness represented for her (Charlotte) by his (father) sacrifice of such a treasure had become, to her (Charlotte) sense, a part of the whole infusion, of the immortal expression; the beauty of his (father) sentiment looked out at her (Charlotte), always, from the beauty of the rest, as if the frame made positively a window for his (father) spiritual face: she (Charlotte) might have said to herself, at this moment, that in leaving the thing behind him (father), held as in her (Charlotte) clasping arms, he (father) was doing the most possible toward leaving her (Charlotte) a part of his (father) palpable self. She (Charlotte) put her (Charlotte) hand over his (father) shoulder, and their eyes were held again, together, by the abiding felicity; they smiled in emulation, vaguely, as if speech failed them through their having passed too far; she (Charlotte) would have begun to wonder the next minute if it were reserved to them, for the last stage, to find their contact, like that of old friends reunited too much on the theory of the unchanged, subject to shy lapses.

``It's all right, eh?'' (unknown)

``Oh, my dear--rather!'' (He)

He (father) had applied the question to the great fact of the picture, as she (Charlotte) had spoken for the picture in reply, but it was as if their words for an instant afterwards symbolised another truth, so that they looked about at everything else to give them this extension. She (Charlotte) had passed her (Charlotte) arm into his (father), and the other objects in the room, the other pictures, the sofas, the chairs, the tables, the cabinets, the

``important'' (She)
pieces, supreme in their way, stood out, round them, consciously, for recognition and applause. Their eyes moved together from piece to piece, taking in the whole nobleness--quite as if for him (father) to measure the wisdom of old ideas. The two noble persons seated, in conversation, at tea, fell thus into the splendid effect and the general harmony: Mrs. Verver and the Prince fairly
``placed'' (the Prince)
themselves, however unwittingly, as high expressions of the kind of human furniture required, esthetically, by such a scene. The fusion of their presence with the decorative elements, their contribution to the triumph of selection, was complete and admirable; though, to a lingering view, a view more penetrating than the occasion really demanded, they also might have figured as concrete attestations of a rare power of purchase. There was much indeed in the tone in which Adam Verver spoke again, and who shall say where his (Verver) thought stopped?
``Le compte y est.. You've got some good things.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

Maggie met it afresh--

``Ah, don't they look well?'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Their companions, at the sound of this, gave them, in a spacious intermission of slow talk, an attention, all of gravity, that was like an ampler submission to the general duty of magnificence; sitting as still, to be thus appraised, as a pair of effigies of the contemporary great on one of the platforms of Madame Tussaud.
``I'm so glad--for your last look.'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)

With which, after Maggie--quite in the air--had said it, the note was struck indeed; the note of that strange accepted finality of relation, as from couple to couple, which almost escaped an awkwardness only by not attempting a gloss. Yes, this was the wonder, that the occasion defied insistence precisely because of the vast quantities with which it dealt--so that separation was on a scale beyond any compass of parting. To do such an hour justice would have been in some degree to question its grounds--which was why they remained, in fine, the four of them, in the upper air, united in the firmest abstention from pressure. There was no point, visibly, at which, face to face, either Amerigo or Charlotte had pressed; and how little she (Charlotte) herself was in danger of doing so Maggie scarce needed to remember. That her (Maggie) father wouldn't, by the tip of a toe--of that she (Maggie) was equally conscious: the only thing was that, since he (father) didn't, she (Maggie) could but hold her (Maggie) breath for what he (father) would do instead. When, at the end of three minutes more, he (father) had said, with an effect of suddenness,

``Well, Mag--and the Principino?'' (he)
it was quite as if that were, by contrast, the hard, the truer voice.

She (Maggie) glanced at the clock.

``I `ordered' him (Le) for half-past five--which hasn't yet struck. Trust him (Le), my dear, not to fail you!'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't want HIM to fail me!'' (Mr. Verver)
was Mr. Verver's reply; yet uttered in so explicitly jocose a relation to the possibilities of failure that even when, just afterwards, he (Verver) wandered in his (Verver) impatience to one of the long windows and passed out to the balcony, she (Maggie) asked herself but for a few seconds if reality, should she (Maggie) follow him (Verver), would overtake or meet her (Maggie) there. She (Maggie) followed him (Verver) of necessity--it came, absolutely, so near to his (Verver) inviting her (Maggie), by stepping off into temporary detachment, to give the others something of the chance that she (Maggie) and her (Maggie) husband had so fantastically discussed. Beside him (husband) then, while they hung over the great dull place, clear and almost coloured now, coloured with the odd, sad, pictured,
``old-fashioned'' (him)
look that empty London streets take on in waning afternoons of the summer's end, she (Maggie) felt once more how impossible such a passage would have been to them, how it would have torn them to pieces, if they had so much as suffered its suppressed relations to peep out of their eyes. This danger would doubtless indeed have been more to be reckoned with if the instinct of each--she (Maggie) could certainly at least answer for her (Maggie) own--had not so successfully acted to trump up other apparent connexions for it, connexions as to which they could pretend to be frank.

``You mustn't stay on here, you know,'' (Adam Verver/Adam)
Adam Verver said as a result of his (Verver) unobstructed outlook.
``Fawns is all there for you, of course--to the end of my tenure. But Fawns so dismantled,'' (he)
he (Verver) added with mild ruefulness,
``Fawns with half its contents, and half its best things, removed, won't seem to you, I'm afraid, particularly lively.'' (he)

``No,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
Maggie answered,
``we should miss its best things. Its best things, my dear, have certainly been removed. To be back there,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) went on,
``to be back there--!'' (she)
And she (Maggie) paused for the force of her (Maggie) idea.

``Oh, to be back there without anything good--!'' (she)
But she (Maggie) didn't hesitate now; she (Maggie) brought her (Maggie) idea forth.
``To be back there without Charlotte is more than I think would do.'' (she)
And as she (Maggie) smiled at him (Verver) with it, so she (Maggie) saw him (Verver) the next instant take it--take it in a way that helped her (Maggie) smile to pass all for an allusion to what she (Maggie) didn't and couldn't say. This quantity was too clear--that she (Maggie) couldn't at such an hour be pretending to name to him (Verver) what it was, as he (Verver) would have said,
``going to be,'' (he)
at Fawns or anywhere else, to want for HIM. That was now--and in a manner exaltedly, sublimely--out of their compass and their question; so that what was she (Maggie) doing, while they waited for the Principino, while they left the others together and their tension just sensibly threatened, what was she (Maggie) doing but just offer a bold but substantial substitute? Nothing was stranger moreover, under the action of Charlotte's presence, than the fact of a felt sincerity in her (Charlotte) words. She (Charlotte) felt her (Charlotte) sincerity absolutely sound--she (Charlotte) gave it for all it might mean.
``Because Charlotte, dear, you know,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) said,
``is incomparable.'' (she)
It took thirty seconds, but she (Charlotte) was to know when these were over that she (Charlotte) had pronounced one of the happiest words of her (Charlotte) life. They had turned from the view of the street; they leaned together against the balcony rail, with the room largely in sight from where they stood, but with the Prince and Mrs. Verver out of range. Nothing he (Prince) could try, she (Verver) immediately saw, was to keep his (Prince) eyes from lighting; not even his (Prince) taking out his (Prince) cigarette-case and saying before he (Prince) said anything else:
``May I smoke?'' (he)
She (Verver) met it, for encouragement, with her (Verver)
``My dear!'' (She)
again, and then, while he (Prince) struck his (Prince) match, she (Verver) had just another minute to be nervous--a minute that she (Verver) made use of, however, not in the least to falter, but to reiterate with a high ring, a ring that might, for all she (Verver) cared, reach the pair inside:
``Father, father--Charlotte's great!'' (she)

It was not till after he (Prince) had begun to smoke that he (Prince) looked at her (Verver).

``Charlotte's great.'' (unknown)

They could close upon it--such a basis as they might immediately feel it make; and so they stood together over it, quite gratefully, each recording to the other's eyes that it was firm under their feet. They had even thus a renewed wait, as for proof of it; much as if he (Prince) were letting her (Verver) see, while the minutes lapsed for their concealed companions, that this was finally just why--but just WHY!

``You see,'' (he)
he (Prince) presently added,
``how right I was. Right, I mean, to do it for you.'' (he)

``Ah, rather!'' (she)
she (Verver) murmured with her (Verver) smile. And then, as to be herself ideally right:
``I don't see what you would have done without her (Charlotte).'' (unknown)

``The point was,'' (he)
he (Prince) returned quietly,
``that I didn't see what you were to do. Yet it was a risk.'' (he)

``It was a risk,'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
said Maggie--
``but I believed in it. At least for myself!'' (Maggie/Maggie Verver)
she (Maggie) smiled.

``Well NOW,'' (he)
he (Prince) smoked,
``we see.'' (he)

``We see.'' (unknown)

``I know her (Charlotte) better.'' (unknown)

``You know her (Charlotte) best.'' (unknown)

``Oh, but naturally!'' (she)
On which, as the warranted truth of it hung in the air--the truth warranted, as who should say, exactly by the present opportunity to pronounce, this opportunity created and accepted--she (Maggie) found herself lost, though with a finer thrill than she (Maggie) had perhaps yet known, in the vision of all he (Prince) might mean. The sense of it in her (Maggie) rose higher, rose with each moment that he (Prince) invited her (Maggie) thus to see him (Prince) linger; and when, after a little more, he (Prince) had said, smoking again and looking up, with head thrown back and hands spread on the balcony rail, at the grey, gaunt front of the house,
``She (Charlotte)'s beautiful, beautiful!'' (he)
her (Maggie) sensibility reported to her (Maggie) the shade of a new note. It was all she (Maggie) might have wished, for it was, with a kind of speaking competence, the note of possession and control; and yet it conveyed to her (Maggie) as nothing till now had done the reality of their parting. They were parting, in the light of it, absolutely on Charlotte's VALUE--the value that was filling the room out of which they had stepped as if to give it play, and with which the Prince, on his (Prince) side, was perhaps making larger acquaintance. If Maggie had desired, at so late an hour, some last conclusive comfortable category to place him (Prince) in for dismissal, she (Maggie) might have found it here in its all coming back to his (Prince) ability to rest upon high values. Somehow, when all was said, and with the memory of her (Maggie) gifts, her (Maggie) variety, her (Maggie) power, so much remained of Charlotte's! What else had she (Charlotte) herself meant three minutes before by speaking of her (Charlotte) as great? Great for the world that was before her (Charlotte)--that he (Great) proposed she (Charlotte) should be: she (Charlotte) was not to be wasted in the application of his (Great) plan. Maggie held to this then--that she (Maggie) wasn't to be wasted. To let his (Great) daughter know it he (Great) had sought this brief privacy. What a blessing, accordingly, that she (daughter) could speak her (daughter) joy in it! His (Great) face, meanwhile, at all events, was turned to her (daughter), and as she (daughter) met his (Great) eyes again her (daughter) joy went straight.
``It's success, father.'' (unknown)

``It's success. And even this,'' (he)
he (Great) added as the Principino, appearing alone, deep within, piped across an instant greeting--
``even this isn't altogether failure!'' (he)

They went in to receive the boy, upon whose introduction to the room by Miss Bogle Charlotte and the Prince got up--seemingly with an impressiveness that had caused Miss Bogle not to give further effect to her (Bogle) own entrance. She (Bogle) had retired, but the Principino's presence, by itself, sufficiently broke the tension--the subsidence of which, in the great room, ten minutes later, gave to the air something of the quality produced by the cessation of a sustained rattle. Stillness, when the Prince and Princess returned from attending the visitors to their carriage, might have been said to be not so much restored as created; so that whatever next took place in it was foredoomed to remarkable salience. That would have been the case even with so natural, though so futile, a movement as Maggie's going out to the balcony again to follow with her (Maggie) eyes her (Maggie) father's departure. The carriage was out of sight--it had taken her (Maggie) too long solemnly to reascend, and she (Maggie) looked awhile only at the great grey space, on which, as on the room still more, the shadow of dusk had fallen. Here, at first, her (Maggie) husband had not rejoined her (Maggie); he (husband) had come up with the boy, who, clutching his (husband) hand, abounded, as usual, in remarks worthy of the family archives; but the two appeared then to have proceeded to report to Miss Bogle. It meant something for the Princess that her (Princess) husband had thus got their son out of the way, not bringing him (husband) back to his (husband) mother; but everything now, as she (mother) vaguely moved about, struck her (mother) as meaning so much that the unheard chorus swelled. Yet THIS above all--her (mother) just being there as she (mother) was and waiting for him (husband) to come in, their freedom to be together there always--was the meaning most disengaged: she (mother) stood in the cool twilight and took in, all about her (mother), where it lurked, her (mother) reason for what she (mother) had done. She (mother) knew at last really why--and how she (mother) had been inspired and guided, how she (mother) had been persistently able, how, to her (mother) soul, all the while, it had been for the sake of this end. Here it was, then, the moment, the golden fruit that had shone from afar; only, what were these things, in the fact, for the hand and for the lips, when tested, when tasted--what were they as a reward? Closer than she (mother) had ever been to the measure of her (mother) course and the full face of her (mother) act, she (mother) had an instant of the terror that, when there has been suspense, always precedes, on the part of the creature to be paid, the certification of the amount. Amerigo knew it, the amount; he (mother) still held it, and the delay in his (mother) return, making her (mother) heart beat too fast to go on, was like a sudden blinding light on a wild speculation. She (mother) had thrown the dice, but his (mother) hand was over her (mother) cast.

He (mother) opened the door, however, at last--he (mother) hadn't been away ten minutes; and then, with her (mother) sight of him (mother) renewed to intensity, she (mother) seemed to have a view of the number. His (mother) presence alone, as he (mother) paused to look at her (mother), somehow made it the highest, and even before he (mother) had spoken she (mother) had begun to be paid in full. With that consciousness, in fact, an extraordinary thing occurred; the assurance of her (mother) safety so making her (mother) terror drop that already, within the minute, it had been changed to concern for his (mother) own anxiety, for everything that was deep in his (mother) being and everything that was fair in his (mother) face. So far as seeing that she (mother) was

``paid'' (she)
went, he (mother) might have been holding out the money-bag for her (mother) to come and take it. But what instantly rose, for her (mother), between the act and her (mother) acceptance was the sense that she (mother) must strike him (mother) as waiting for a confession. This, in turn, charged her (mother) with a new horror: if that was her (mother) proper payment she (mother) would go without money. His (mother) acknowledgment hung there, too monstrously, at the expense of Charlotte, before whose mastery of the greater style she (Charlotte) had just been standing dazzled. All she (Charlotte) now knew, accordingly, was that she (Charlotte) should be ashamed to listen to the uttered word; all, that is, but that she (Charlotte) might dispose of it on the spot forever.

``Isn't she (Charlotte) too splendid?'' (she)
she (Charlotte) simply said, offering it to explain and to finish.

``Oh, splendid!'' (he)
With which he (mother) came over to her (Charlotte).

``That's our help, you see,'' (she)
she (Charlotte) added--to point further her (Charlotte) moral.

It kept him (mother) before her (Charlotte) therefore, taking in--or trying to--what she (Charlotte) so wonderfully gave. He (mother) tried, too clearly, to please her (Charlotte)--to meet her (Charlotte) in her (Charlotte) own way; but with the result only that, close to her (Charlotte), her (Charlotte) face kept before him (mother), his (mother) hands holding her (Charlotte) shoulders, his (mother) whole act enclosing her (Charlotte), he (mother) presently echoed: ```See'? I see nothing but you.'' And the truth of it had, with this force, after a moment, so strangely lighted his (mother) eyes that, as for pity and dread of them, she (Charlotte) buried her (Charlotte) own in his (mother) breast.
